It is very small in its scope especially when compared to Notre Dame however the stained glass and story/history of it is simply sensational. It is located within the walls of the Palace of Justice, tucked away, a gem. Make sure to take the spiral staircase up to the second story where more stories in stain glass are told. There a placards one can take and read about the chapel and its glass. It is included in the Paris Pass. Very special indeed.

Expected .... More. Yes, it is a world heritage site...I was excited to fit this into our itinerary. Logistics to see this, and the Notre Dame Towers and lunch at the Tour D'Argent worked timing wise...but I was just disappointed. It seemed just tired and dusty. It is all about the glass, no other furnishings. Maybe on a sunnier day it would have showed better. I just was not inspired. Yeah, everyone raves about this, but I thought maybe I should put on the record that maybe u do not need to put this at the tip of your list for visiting. Of the many lovely places we visited in Paris, this was at the bottom of the list.
See the night concert!. I highly recommend spending a lovely evening in Paris, listening to chamber style medieval music inside this little jewel box. The stained glass is amazing...the colors

Worth Standing In Line. If you love stained glass, you will be knocked out by these incredible towering windows of this small royal chapel built in 1248 for King Louis IX in only 5 years! These windows are considered the most outstanding example of 13th century Gothic stained glass in the world. Be prepared to wait in line as this is a very famous and popular venue.
Exquisite. A sacred few moments... beautiful and relaxing. It was worth the walk on a rainy, cold day to see this sublime place.
Amazing. Most beautiful stained glass windows. Nothing compares. Recently cleaned windows are magnificant. Narrow tightly curving stairs could be hard for many to navigate.

Breathtaking. First visit 3.5.16. A mere stone's throw from Notre Dame sits St. Chapelle, adjacent to the Conciergerie. Its smaller stature belies the grandeur housed within. Upon entry be prepared to question the seemingly steep entry fee of E10. The ground floor is unique and interesting but hardly world-beating, especially among the many treasures in Paris. But make way up the tight spiral staircase in the corner and you will behold a truly breathtaking masterpiece of stained glass (just don't visit on a cloudy day). The windows at Notre Dame get rightful attention but they are just windows. St. Chapelle seems to be constructed almost entirely of stained glass, an effect that must be seen to be understood. Even for those who don't love stained glass (such as this reviewer) it is recommended.

Beautiful Concert at the Saint-Chapelle!. A friend told us that we MUST see a string quartet concert at the Saint-Chapelle while we were in Paris, so we did just that. It was absolutely breathtaking (despite the annoying idiot in front of us who texted the entire time). These concerts seem to be in the evenings only, and you must have your ticket pre-purchased and PRINTED upon entry. I highly recommend this experience.

The most moving experience in Paris. It's very difficult to describe the impact of walking into this glowing chamber of stained glass. When you are inside, it's completely jaw dropping, and it's difficult to comprehend how much labor went into its creation. It's well worth the lines.Make sure to leave time to wander at a leisurely pace - this is not an attraction you will want to breeze through. It's best when you can spend a little more time and lose yourself in the intricacies of the small details as well as the overwhelming beauty of the whole.

Awesome. First the bad: when you first get to Sainte Chapelle you enter on the ground floor, and you ask yourself, " is that' all there is to it?" When I asked a guid, he told us we had to go upstairs to view the windows, and WOWNow the good:, The windows are absolutely awe inspiring and absolute must see. Everybody talks about the rose window at Notre Dame, and it is beautiful, BUT Nothing like the windows at Sainte Chapelle, both are in easy walking distance.
Sainte Chapelle. Beautiful and stunning! To truly experience the stain glass windows, visit on a sunny day! The church is small but worth the visit.

Amazing work of art indeed!. This is definitely a must see in Paris! The pictures do not justify how grand and extravagant this work of art is. Make sure to follow the signs outside as there are long queues that go to to the ministry of justice, which is on the same premises. The chapel is under construction so make sure you ask for right directions as the entrance was hidden a bit due to the construction barricades and temp offices.
Beautiful spot. Nice to just sit and take it in. There is info packets near the door that explain the stain glass windows which was interesting.
Unique archtecture. Not far from Notre dame, this is a structural masterpiece given the amount of glass. It's a bit chaotic to visit but is well worth it.

A little disappointed after all the hype but worth a visit. After all the reviews we were really excited to see this place, it took a little while to find and was understandably very heavily policed/security etc. Was suprised to have to pay €10 each for one room but it is beautiful.
Gorgeous. . It's a pretty small place, but this is a stained glass enthusiasts heaven. So ornate and well put together, especially the rose that has been there for centuries.

Exquisite Stained Glass. Tucked back in a corner, but renowned for it's windows, Sainte-Chapelle is a sight to behold. Try to make it on a sunny day to get the full effect of a royal chapel illuminated through magnificent stained glass on all sides. Be sure to take time so you can look at each unique window.The chapel, completed in 2 years (from 1246 to 1248) was erected by Louis IX, king of France, to house the Crown of Thorns and a fragment of the True Cross, precious relics of the Passion of Christ.Regardless of your religious affiliation, or lack thereof, the chapel, in and of itself, is a masterpiece of architecture and art. The best aspect of a visit to the Sainte-Chapelle is that, unlike the large cathedrals and churches, the Saint-Chapelle has an intimate feeling and one can feel a part of the chapel rather than an external viewer of an impersonal edifice.If it comes to a choice between the Notre Dame De Paris and the Sainte-Chapelle, visit the latter. You'll see more and it will be up close and personal.
Up the short Sprial Staircase for a breath taking view. No matter how one feels about religion - The stain glass on a sunny day will give your heart and head an experience not to forget.
Breathtaking. Never been in a church like it and it was stunning. Very peaceful even though it was busy and absolutely beautiful. Well worth taking time out for.

Beautiful stained glass. The stained glass is stunning. the wait to get in was not long, and the history is worth seeing. But a word of warning. My pocket knife was confiscated at the security checkpoint and not returned
Wow . This has got the most exceptional stained glass windows I've ever seen. The colours just dance around you. Much more impressive than Notre Dame.

Restoration work is marvellous. This is what many of the other magnificent church's stained glass would look like once lovingly restored (or not destroyed or broken in the many conflicts over the years). Magnificent is the best adjective I can think of right now.

A very special must do place to visit. This wasnt initially on my schedule but was brought to my attention when we were on our Sandimans walking tour.
It is a beautiful must do place. The stained glass windows are amazing and dont forget to check out the floor
Paris pass inclusive of fast track helped up to maintain a good time .. which was a bonus

Absolutely gorgeous medieval architecture . The Sainte Chapelle is located in a part of the city with several other famous monuments and might be overlooked, but it is worth a stop by. It is a prime example of medieval architecture, and the stained glass is amazing and could rival nearly any cathedral in France. Absolutely breathtaking, even on a gloomy day.

Unforgettable evening concerts. The place is amazing enough during the day, but sign up for one of the evening concerts held there. Often not a particularly adventurous program (the Pachelbel Canon and Vivaldi 4 Seasons are staples) but great familiar pieces performed wonderfully well by charismatic performers in that wonderful historic place with its awesome acoustics. It is an experience that will remain imprinted on your brain for the rest of your life. Don't hold back due to the cost, just do it - you won't regret it.

Beautiful but small and a long wait. If you are an art history buff like me, the long wait was worth it. However, my boyfriend who didn't know the history of this church was not super impressed because it is kind of small (compared to Notre Dame where we went first). The stained glass and architecture is very beautiful though and anyone who knows about the history of this church will appreciate it very much.

A dissapointment.. We waited for a long time in the line. When we got in it was a small exhibition of the church an after that we got up to a large mirror room, that's it! Beatiful but, not worth the wait or the entrence fee.

Worth seeing . . . once.. Price for entry is 10 euro and keep in mind this is not a full church like Notre Dame or Sacre Couer. You enter into a small chapel that is full of stain glassed windows. The stained glass is amazing, especially at dusk, as is the rose window. Avoid going on a cloudy day and I really don't see a reason to visit again.
lovers gone wild. me and my husband did it for the first time there ever and im so happy we did because now i have a my oldest song Roscoe

Rainbow of colours. The vast ceilings of colored glass really illuminates in the morning sun. I think this is the only two floor sacral building that I've ever visited and the experience is really memorable one.

Hidden Gem. Sainte-Chapelle is hidden around the corner from the Notre Dame and could easily be missed. It has beautiful Gothic architecture and stain glass windows. The cost of 10GBP per head is quite steep for the short amount of time you need to spend there, considering all the other churches in Paris are free. Entrance is controlled by the gendarmerie and your bags have to go through security. No suitcases allowed.

The most beautiful thing I've ever seen. Do not miss this place! It's worth whatever sort of line you may (or may not) end up waiting in. I'd never heard of Sainte-Chapelle before going to Paris with my grandmother, and I am grateful that she chose to take me here as part of our trip.The first floor is unassuming, though there is some lovely mosaic work and some small stained glass windows. Going upstairs, however, transports you into a magical rose-colored fantasy world. The windows are enormous and intricate. After visiting more than a handful of churches and cathedrals throughout Normandy, this is still my favorite.

A Jewel Box!. This is a "must visit" in Paris. The stained glass is spectacular. It is a small chapel that was built to house the crown of thorns (which is now displayed in Notre Dame). The lower level has beautifully restored and colorful vaults and windows and then you go upstairs and it will take your breath away. Buy your ticket in advance on line (or use the Paris Museum Pass) so you can skip the line.

Must See. One of the highlights of my trip to Paris. The stained glass windows are just breathtaking. Go early in the morning to avoid the long lines and definitely get a Museum Pass. But this is a must-see.

Breathtaking stained glass walls!. This is truly a must see on each trip to Paris. I marvel at the beauty of it all and it doesn't get old, even though I have seen it over a dozen times. Sunny days are a bonus!

Astonishing; don't miss it!. Apparently this church is overlooked by lots of tourists as they go straight to the Notre Dame which is nearby, and in fact this is the 6th I'd been to Paris and the 1st time I visited this church. It's quite small, and very pretty on the ground level with beautiful coloured ceilings and tiled reliefs. When i went upstairs however, the sheer beauty of this amazing church actually brought a tear to my eyes. 90% of the 2nd level is just stained glass, with a beautiful golden casket that holds a very special relic - the corn of thorns worn by Jesus Christ (apparently). Without any doubt, one of the most beautiful churches I have ever been to, even if it is quite small in comparison to more grander of the churches / cathedrals in Paris.Don't miss it!
Always a treat. Except for the crowds, this is truly spectacular. Perhpas when something big is going on across the street at Notre Dame would be a good time to see Sainte-Chapelle.

A hidden gem. Around the corner from Notre Dame its easy to pass by this hidden wonder, but don't! Built to house the most important relics brought back from the crusades, pioneering new building techniques allowed glass to be used like never before. The result is breathtaking. Stained glass had never beenn seen like this before, and has probably not been bettered since. Definitely take a half hour out of your day to admire it.Be warned though, the relics (crown of thorns, piece of the real cross) are no longer housed here, they are in Notre Dame.

Liked it better than Notre Dame. Like standing inside of a jeweled box. Extraordinary and not as overwhelming as ND. Security lines were very long but worth it. This is a must see when you visit Paris.

Stunning stained glass windows. This was a beautiful place to visit, but it was quite pricey at 15 Euros with the justice palace too. Loved the stain glass windows and the ambience of the place, the information given around the edges of the room was also appreciated.

not what you're expecting. I'll be honest: first time I went there I though it would be a bit lame: couldn't be more wrong! it is most certainly oneof the spots with the most extraordinary vitrals I've ever seen in my entire life. the whole bible is draw on them, that's for sure. what's also interesting is the fact that it doesn't work lke a religious temple anymore.spotlight: the walls colored painted are one of the beautiful and different things of this old chapel.
Meh. Not really worth it in my opinion. Notre Dam is much better and free for really the same architecture, stained glass etc. we bought with the concierge which was slightly better.

Stunning stained glass. I am so impressed with the care and time that must have been taken to restore the glass to its' original beauty and lustre. The painstaking and revered treatment provided for rejuvenating this Church demonstrates the love for such works of historical significance par excellence!

Astounding . The stained glass here is spectacular, it really does take your breath away. I chose this over Notre Dame, less busy, much smaller and less people. There was a small queue outside and a €10 charge, but I believe it is worth it.
A must see. Wow! This is the only way to describe La Sainte Chapelle. Purchase the audio tour. You will not regret it

Wow!!. This church and its thousands of stained glass windows is stunning. Well worth the cost and the wait. The one downside is that there is no express entry along with the included cost in the museum pass

Amazing Architecture. This was my second time in Paris, and I had been to the world-reknowned Notre Dame before. My daughter told me about Sainte-Chapelle, only a short distance away, and I decided that the less-imposing church deserved a visit. Wait time was short, and soon we entered the church's lower level. Please be sure to go upstairs! The walls of stained glass are breathtaking, although--or because--the space is much more intimate than the famous Notre Dame. Finished in 1248, the glass is approximately 2/3 original.

Sunday Evening Concerts. If you love stained-glass windows and classical music, adding a Sunday evening at Saint-Chapelle is a must! The acoustics are fantastic and listening to Vivaldi performed in this setting is heavenly! Even without advanced tickets, we entered, purchased excellent seats two rows from the musicians and enjoyed a wonderful hour of music and beauty.

Simply breathtaking!. Definitely visit since it's only a short walk from Notre Dame. If you're a bit of a gamer like me, seeing the chapel was like walking into the area where the last boss is waiting for you--it's that type of intense atmosphere when you reach the top of the stairs and are surrounded by all the beauty that are these stained-glass windows, each pane with a story to tell. Worth a visit even if its cloudy but seeing it on a sunny day would be best!
For art lovers. In my opinion, one of the most beautiful churchs of all Paris. The windows are amazing, so colorful and the wall print is amazing as well. Don't hesitate!

A surprise in store. Recently visited this most excellent monument in the heart of Paris, just a short walk from Notre-Dame Cathedral. As we did, you will usually have to join a short queue which moves quite rapidly. It is worth the wait to enter a magnificent church, built in the stunning perpendicular style. The light from the stained glass windows has to be seen to be believed! Many visitors then leave without noticing the small door at the rear which gives access to a spiral staircase, leading to the even more magnificent upper floor. This is your "surprise in store". Don't miss it.....!
Favorite Church in all of Paris.. It is absolutely beautiful! Worth seeing, but plan for a sunny day if you have the option. The stained glass is exquisite.

Wow!. We visited Sainte-Chapelle on a rainy day in February and the windows were still stunning. There are laminated papers by the entryway, in multiple languages, to help explain the windows. The stairways themselves are a treat, winding in a circular path from the lower chapel up to the church.

Not just another church..... This is one of the best churches I've been too, stain glass work is overwhelming, you will have to line up to get in, but well worth it...recommend to plan for you visit first thing in the morning to avoid long queue, sunny days are better of course as the stain glass will pop!

Stunning Stained Glass. This is a small place with large beauty and history. The stained glass windows bring serenity, though they are impossible to see in their entirety--they are so detailed, large and encompassing. If you are lucky enough to go to a concert there, do and soak in its majesty.

Listening to Vivaldi's Quattro Staggioni here was spell-binding!. We visited last in 2013. attended a Vivaldi concert in the spectacular chamber of San Chapelle was a wonderful experience. The leadlight windows were spell-binding. I hope to re-visit in May 2016. The visit date section below does not enable me to state 2013 visit.
Beautiful!. Just across Notre Dame Cathedral is Saint Chapelle. Go up the second floor to witness the beautiful stained windows that make Saint Chapelle worth a visit.

Beautiful stained glass. Started downstairs which was mostly a souvenir shop, then went upstairs which is where the visual delight is. Used museum pass. About 45 min wait even when we arrived about 20 min before it opened.
The most amazing stained glass. So worth a visit, because of the 15 huge stained glass windows, which have recently been cleaned up / restored, and are so bright and colourful. -

Sainte Chappelle. A hidden gem beside the Palace of Justice .The glass has recently been renovated so sparkles as new,....has the wow!!! factor.
To reach the chapel one has to climb spiral stone stairs which may be difficult for some ,there is a lift for disabled people that brings you to the outside of the great doors.

Beautiful Church. This is not an extremely large building, but it is beautiful. The wait to get in was only 15 minutes at most, for the day I went, and the ticket couldn't have been more than 10 euro. I did buy some kind of a dual use ticket for another building that was supposed to be in the compound, but never actually found it. There was a lot of construction going on and then it was also somehow connected to a police station headquarters building... all of that was confusing. But the stained glass was so amazing, on a sunny day it would've been breathtaking! It was still a great experience on a rainy day though. There is some pamphlets in a few different languages and an informational video on some of the work they did recently in order to restore the glass panels. Overall, I would highly recommend seeing this sight, it may be smaller than the usual destination, but that in no way makes it any less valuable.

Sacred and Beautiful. What an amazing place. Even though we had visited it 10 years before my husband and I both considered a "must do" on our recent trip. Each vertical panel of stained glass illustrates a book of the Bible. The detail and consistency of the glass colors make it remarkable. Only someone with the gift of OCD could have pulled this off. It glows from the outside in.
brilliant colors. It was worth the 10 year restoration of the windows. The difference between dirty stained glass and clean is amazing. You wont recognize the site.

Beautiful. The shop in the crypt, and the noise level from some of my fellow visitors were a little odd. But climbing the stairs to the main chapel just left me breathless. So much stained glass; even on a dull day the colours were amazing.

Take your Time. This is truly worthy of at least three hours. Its easy to find within the Palace of Justice and at €20.00 for two people its worth having a little research done before the visit. Once inside , words can not describe the Aura of those Stained Glass Windows with their Biblical Scenes. The upper area would be difficult with mobility issues , but there is inspiration here , not found in other "Monuments or Churches"

A stunning start to your day. Go here before going to Notre Dame. We bought our museum pass across the street from Sainte-Chapelle, grabbed more coffee, then stood in the relatively sane line. The windows are astounding--we'd never seen anything like them. It's a really low-key way to start compared to the hundreds of people on line for Notre Dame, and with your museum pass, it's super affordable.

Stunning stained glass. As the other reviewers have mentioned, the stained glass in Sainte-Chapelle is amazing and needs to be seen. It is part of the Museum Pass and very close to Notre Dame so why not see it? When you get to Sainte-Chapelle, you will line up on the street and enter through some metal detectors. Then you buy your ticket and enter the chapel's basement. The basement has some interesting history and artifacts, but climb the winding stairs and behold the beauty of the stained glass. Its best on a sunny day, but nice anytime...

WOW!. STUNNING. Sainte-Chapelle is simply stunning. The queue is relatively short, around 20 minutes, however, 18-25 year olds from the EU enter free and can go straight to the kiosk, where you show proof of age and country of birth and enter Sainte-Chapelle. Once inside, there are various pieces of art, on the walls and as artifacts. There are a few stalls where you can purchase gifts and books and audioguides are available just beside the stairs. There is a short climb to the top floor where the long stained glass windows are situated. It is breathtakingly beautiful and this is evident as soon as you reach the top step of the stairs. You are able to take some amazing photographs and take in the marvellous work around you. It is 100% worth a visit whilst in Paris and it is somewhere I will always remember.

Just a gorgeous chapel!!. Built as a tribute to his royal mother by Louis IX, (hence the towers on the pillars and wallpaper), the colours of the walls and stained glass windows in the upper chapel (worth the dizzying climb) have been preserved quite well! The high stained glass windows show the tales from the bible and can be read like a comic book.

Look UP. It is definitely a treat to view the beautiful stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle. Sainte-Chapelle built between 1226 and 1248 is now part of the Palace of Justice which is also a very interesting place to visit. When you first go into the lower chapel you don't quite realize that there is an upper chapel to visit, but don't miss it. The upper chappel is truly magificant, bathed in all of the beautiful colors of the stained glass windows. The windows tell the story of mankind from Genesis through to Christ's resurrection.
Beautiful , old chapel, don't miss.. Beautiful old chapel, extraordinary colored windows. Don't miss a visit . Enjoy a special classic music concert, buy tickets in advance.

Sightseeing . This chapel is absolutely breathtaking probably one of the most beautiful sights in Paris! Very close to the more popular notre dame cathedral but more beautiful in many ways. The chapel is small but it is almost completely made up of the more gorgeous stained glass windows with rich history.

Definitely worth the hassle. You have to go through airport type security before you can even enter the area. You then go outside and walk over to the site. Once inside it is definitely worth it. The stained glass windows are stunning.

Definitely go in.. There is a charge but worth it. Stained glass is amazing sight. Norte Dame is free but make sure to stop here. Not much to see if you don't pay to go in. Can't see church from street.

An oasis of calm and light in the City of Lights. Saint Chappelle is an absolute gem. It is small and unassuming from the outside, and so it may be easy to overlook. That would be a mistake. Once you climb the short fight of steps to the second floor, you are surrounded by breathtakingly beautiful stained glass. My favorite time to go is early to beat the crowds. Then take a seat along the side and just watch the vibrant blues, reds, and yellows subtly change as the sunlight pours in. They often do concerts in the evening and sell tickets on location. It is a lovely, intimate contrast to the massive grandeur of nearby Notre Dame. It is easily reached by metro.

Beautiful. The stain glass is stunning, but so is the admission. Be prepared to pay a pretty penny to just see some old glass. Yes it's beautiful and the money probably does go to help with restoration and such so we didn't mind paying.
The best stained glass. We did not have to wait long. Good security. Breath taking stained glass windows. To have survived intact so long is incredible. Well worth the visit

For the stained glass and architecture fan.. If you love stained glass and architecture, this is a good stop while in the area. Saint Chappelle is worth seeing and in the museum pass, however, lines can be long and slow moving due to the limited space inside the attraction.
Breathtaking stained glass windows. The wait may be a bit long but it is definitely worth it. Once you are inside on the second floor, the beauty of this chapel will take your breath away!
Prettiest stain glass windows. Go early and see the beautiful stain glassed windows. Seeing this church doesn't take long but stop to admire the beauty and craftsmanship that went into each piece!

Not to be missed when in Paris. Waits and lines can be daunting and no the museum pass does not allow you to skip any line but if too long come back early. Impressive for its very uniqueness. Well worth the wait. Bring a snack or book you will love it.
Beautiful but small. When i saw this on Rick Steve's it looked like a mammoth cathedral. It is an amazing spectacle of colored glass, a bit smaller than i thought.

Marvellous music in an unforgettable setting. The stunning stain glass windows of this gorgeous chapel soar magnificently throughout the length and practical the full height of this magnificent building. The effects of the sun playing on the rich colours is quite breathtaking. The chapel is tucked away within the palace of justice and doesn’t feature in the usual Paris list of must see sights. It is a gem. I first saw it years ago and since then there has been restoration to the windows that has allowed the beautiful colours to be seen with even greater clarity. There is an added bonus now with regular concerts performed by excellent musicians. The atmosphere in the evening with soft lights illuminating the beautiful stone work is a wonderful experience. The performance we went to included Albinoni, Tomaso Giovanni Adagio Pachelbel, Johann Canon Vivaldi, Antonio The Four Seasons, op. 8. The performers were Les Solistes Français (Orchestra) with Paul Rouger solo violin. It was completely entrancing.

Magnificient gothic Chapelle, with impressive stained glass windows and acoustic. If you are planning to visit the Ile de la Cité and the Notre-Dame Cathedral, please don't miss this nearby magnificient gothic Chapelle, with impressive colourful stained glass windows and an astonishing acoustic. If you love music, don't miss any concert at it, especially any performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons or other baroque plays, chorus, gospel and the like.
The most beautiful place in Paris. Being born in Paris, I think this is the most beautiful place in the city. Be aware of a quite long waiting line.

Paris secret gothic gem within Justice Court. This is'my favourite place in Paris, where I take all my friends from abroad. It's not as famous as Notre-Dame (which is at walking distance) but it's the most striking example in France of "gothique flamboyant" architecture. Once you indulged in classical gothic at Notre-Dame, do consider paying a visit to this little blazing gothic masterpiece. Wonderful stained glass, walls painted in gold and bright colours, it's pure marvel on a sunny day.

Beautiful and accessible. This is one of the most stunning yet accessible chapels in Paris. What I mean accessible, is that they regularly host concerts in this venue that anyone can attend. The acoustics are amazing (as they should be in a Gothic structure) and the feel is serene. I highly recommend visiting and if you can swing it attending any kind of concert at this chapel or really any church, chapel or cathedral in Paris.It's a great experience you don't hear about much, that also doesn't cost a fortune!

Favour place to visit!. First came here after ready Dan Brown years back, and took friends who had never been. Queue was difficult to understand, but worth the wait 30minutes I think.We all just lived it thoroughly recommend

Do NOT miss Sainte-Chapelle!. Because of time pressures and the desire to see the 'holy trinity' of Notre Dame / Eiffel Tower and Sacre Coeur, it is easy to walk straight past Sainte-Chapelle. DON'T! It is probably the most impressive and overlooked of all the Parisian churches. It was built by St-Louis to house the Crown of Thorns. It cost a fortune, and it now extensively restored. The glasswork is amazing. Don't drop it off the end of your itinerary.

'Like walking into heaven'. I heard a teenage English girl say this. The entrance is not inspiring, but go up the stairs and the colour attacks you and embraces you. The High Gothic chapel is a gem in itself and the glass is one of the glories of France, rivalled only by Chartres. Allow time, and sit and look. And look. And look.

Stunning sight. We went here as our friend had told us it was a Paris must-see. We had to agree, the history of the chapelle is very interesting and the preservation of the décor along with the stunning windows has to be seen to be believed. At a 10 euro entrance fee it is an absolute bargain.Great inspiration for any budding interior designer!

The most amazing stained glass in the world!. If you are interested in stained glass windows, Sainte-Chapelle is not to be missed. A short walk from Notre Dame Cathathedral this 13th cent Gothic Chapel was built by Louis IX as his Royal Chapel and once housed part of the 'Crown of Thorns' which Louis brought back from Constantinople, as well as a fragment of the True Cross. Work on restoring the magnificent stained glass windows was completed in 2015 and they can now be gazed at in their original magnificence. The windows dominate because the stonework is so fine. Take one of the 'guide cards' and follow the biblical stories from the Old and New Testaments in the stained glass. Take a seat if you can to save straining your neck ... but if you do, it will be well worth it.

Beautiful cathedral. This building was gorgeous. Though there was extra security because of the shootings ( there was everywhere ) the guards were friendly and there was no charge to enter, unlike some of the other beautiful cathedrals. We visited with our tour guide who explained all of the moseic to us enhancing our experince, but the building would be beautiful and worth it even without the back story.

An amazing Church. First off there are two parts to this church. The lower level is about Saint Louie and has some very old decorations but the real treat is up an old circular staircase. The stained glass Chapel, it is spectacular. it is truly amazing of the detail and precision of the stained glass done at a very early time. Just be careful on your way back down to the ground floor. It is another circular staircase. Well worth the climb.

Hidden treasure. This place is an absolute gem. After exhausting the other top tourist sights with a visiting friend, I suggested we check this out as I hadn't been here in my 5 months in Paris. I'm so glad we went! The stain glass in the upper level is absolutely breath taking. Make sure you go up to level two though - we nearly missed it!

Stone lace, mandatory to see in Paris!. Stone lace, mandatory to see in Paris!Begun in 1242 at the request of St. Louis, it will only take 7 years to complete; and no defect is noted, a real achievement, to house the Crown of Thorn and a relic of the cross of Christ. The visit with a guide is recommended to discover timed the richness of the place.And a good alternative is to go to a concert (there are 2 or 3 per week minimum) to enjoy the sites, acoustics and travel in this beautiful architecture ...

absolutely gorgeous stain glass windows. I would highly recommend this chapel just for its gorgeous windows. Though it might not have the rasmataz of the notre dame, when caught at the right time, with the sun blasting through the panes, it is breathtakingly beautiful.My only advice would be go on a summers day, or if in winter or spring not a cloudy day!! It will still look good on a grey day but not as good as a sunny one!

Hidden gem! Don't miss this off your list! . Absolutely stunning! Don't miss this gem, this place was more impressive than Notre Dame! We visited the Sainte-Chapelle after visiting the Conceirgerie. Didn't need to queue to get in and the stain glass windows were amazing. Do not miss!

Beautiful stained glass experience. As others have mentioned the chapel is beautiful and worth seeing. I went in the daytime and I also attended an evening concert. The concert experience is outstanding and I highly recommend that. One thing that's worth noting is that Saint Chapelle is closed from 12-2 pm so the staff can have lunch which is not noted on the website ( you'd think that would be a pertinent piece of information ). After lunch the day I was there it wasn't reopened until 2:25 which was somewhat annoying since it was quite cold out and many of us had started to line up well before 2pm ( I recommend this because otherwise the lines get really long ). So I guess the lesson in February is - bring lots of warm clothes because you will probably be waiting. I also take off a star for the tacky gift shop sitting right in the chapel - kind of ruined the experience of the lower chapel for me.

Wow, what a beautiful place. I visited this beautiful chapel after hearing about how wonderful the stain glass windows are. After walking up the narrow stairs, to look up and see the beautiful windows was amazing. I would thoroughly recommend. We probably spent about an hour here so you could easily fit it into your itinerary.

Magnificent!. Having recently undergone a major restoration, we were fortunate to see the huge stained glass windows in all their glory (by the way, now we know why Velux windows cost so much!). Each window panel takes the viewer through the Old Testament books of the Bible. For those who would wish to examine the panels in more detail and follow the stories which are depicted on them, it might be worthwhile bringing some compact binoculars, as it's difficult to make out everything from floor level. However, simply viewing the panels as a whole still gives a sense of amazement at the artistry involved in their production.

Breathtaking Stained Glass Windows. Although this chapel is relatively small compared to the magnificent cathedrals I have visited, the artistry of the stained glass windows will amaze you. This is definitely a sight you do not want to miss. I would say that if you are planning a visit to Paris, you must make time to see La Sainte Chapelle. The stunning Gothic architecture of the chapel is some of the best I have seen. The resplendent stained glass windows are the visual focal point of this landmark. Simply amazing.

Don't Miss. With Notre Dame being the main reason you'll be in the area, its easy to overlook this one, especially since from the road you can hardly notice the towers of a church. But this is not to be missed. The awe inspiring huge vaulted stained glass is a spectacle that can not be missed.
The jewell in the crown .... In the very heart of Paris - Exquisite, refined glass work, nothing else comes close. Add a concert and have a divine experience !

Beyond Beautiful. The stained glass windows here are some of the best in the world. Definitely a must do experience in Paris, one of my favorites and I can not recommend it enough. Great to do on a really sunny day with lots of light coming through but even on a cloudy overcast day it was still amazing. Doesn't look like much on the outside but don't let that fool you

Like a jewel box. Absolutely stunning. Go on a sunny day if you can to get the full effect with the light through the windows. Take the time to study the detail of the cathedral itself (inside) as well as the glass.

Best stained glass windows I've ever seen. This chapel is quite amazing. The lower chapel is quite low key, some nice decorative walls, a statue of a French King. Then you go upstairs - the most amazing stained glass windows - 750m2 of them. They have been recently restored and are absolutely spectacular. You could spend hours looking at the different stories.There are several religious relics stored here ( mentioned in all the literature and websites) apparently including a section of the Crown of Thorns. If it is still here, you can't see it as the shrine containing them is elevated halfway up to the ceiling!This is extremely good value if you buy the combined ticket with the Conciergerie.
Amazing Glass work. To me what makes this a stand out Chapelle is the stained glass work. If you look beyond the normal structures you will be amazed at the intricate glass works.

Stunning. This chapelle is absolutely stunning. The stained glass windows were renovated and cleaned last year so it is absolutely magnificent. It only takes approximately 30 mins to view this sight but it is definitely worth paying to see.

Breath-taking stained glass. Too many tourists miss the Sainte-Chapelle. Perhaps it's the lines. Perhaps it's that it can't be easily spotted from the street. But those who miss it will indeed regret it, until they realize that they now have a reason to return to Paris....

one of the finest and ultimate gothic structure in the world. The Sainte Chapelle in Paris is the place to see in order to get an impression of what is a fine gothic structure.Compared to other cathedrals, this is a chapel, where one can enjoy the finest in tainted glass and very delicate example of a gothic structure.

The most beautiful church in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle must be the most beautiful church in Paris. While it may not be so impressive from the outside, you will be blown away by its sheer beauty once you step inside. The lower chapel is gorgeous, painted in wonderful, vibrant colours. However, the highlight of the visit is undoubtedly the upper chapel with its astonishing, breathtakingly beautiful stained glass windows. It seems as if the walls were made solely of stained glass. The light coming through the windows adds to the magical atmosphere of this architectural gem. The beautiful ribbed vaulting and highly detailed decoration of the chapel are absolutely stunning, and enhance the unique experience. Words cannot express the beauty of this special place. Just go and see for yourself. If there is a place in Paris worth queuing for, that certainly would be Sainte-Chapelle!

a treat to see this. the incredible architecture, especially the stained glass windows were amazing
both levels are important to see glad we took the time here

The great perpendicular, brilliant conceptually and in executive!. The first time I walked into Sainte Chapelle, I was impressed by the richness around me, but actually it was the service level that sold the usual tourist trinkets and books, etc. That area had been used as I recall for worship by servants, etc.Sainte-Chapelle was the private chapel of King Louis IX, the crusader king whose crusader army managed to be utterly defeated and captured by a Mameluk Army. In time he came home with what he claimed to be genuine relics from Jerusalem including the crown of thorns. If you can convinced yourself of that ... But it managed to convince Rome to declare him a saint.Be that as it may, Sainte Chappell is his most extraordinary relic, intended for him alone, as his personal royal chapel. He entered directly from his palace. As a more casual visitor, you climb a narrow stair case, nothing grand about it and a bit difficult for we infirm, and ascend, into a luminous fantasy of stained glass that seems to float, little holding them up but the light that pours them through them.The decoration of the the chapel is lush - no wonder, it was for the King. I've been back to the chapel many times over the last 40 years. Nothing has quit equaled the astonishment I had that first visit. Sometimes the light in terms of weather and time of day change the view. I would probably avoid a dismal rainy or very cloudy day. But it makes no difference to me. I go. FWIW, the chapel is said to be connected conceptually and construction methods to the great Cathedral of Amiens. I think that's not at all unlikely, but if you're a cathedral fanatic like me, Amiens is worth a trip, for the Cathedral in general, a night view if possible to see the LED replication of the polychrome exterior that was part of the original exterior.
Awesome. Went in on entry level and thought yeah pretty ok then as an afterthought went up the narrow stairs to the main chappel and was totally floored by how beautiful it is...stunning

Spotlight on French history. A small and intimate chapel. I chose to take the guided tour in French, our guide was very knowledgable and invited us to follow his lectures at the Sorbonne. An English-speaking visitor can also learn the history by reading the well written documentation in each chapel. Examine the windows carefully t see the differences and artistic techniques of the artists.
Absolutely gorgeous - much prettier than Notre Dame. What a gorgeous place! It was very crowded but definitely worth visiting. The stained glass windows are breath-taking.
simply gorgeous. This is a very small church compared to many others but is so well worth visiting. The stained glass windows have to be seen to be believed, they are just incredible.

Gorgeous Jewel Worth Your Time. This might be one of my favorite churches in Paris, and that is saying a lot. Buy the museum pass in advance and check your guide book for hours. The Isle de Cite area closes at odd hours, but this place is well worth your time. The stained glass 360 degrees around you is...ridiculous.
Stained Glass Heaven. Love, love, love Chapelle! If you are into stained glass, you definitely can't miss a trip here. But even if you're not, it's beautiful so trust me and go anyways!!

Great Stained Glass. This church has an interesting downstairs but the main attraction is upstairs. There are towering stained glass window on two sides of the large upstairs chapel area. It is not too far from Notre dame and can easily been done in the same morning/afternoon.
Best stained glass in Paris. Paris has numerous churches but Sainte-Chapelle is worth a visit as it has the best stained glass of all the churches in Paris. It is definitely worth a visit.

One of the most important buildings in the world.. This simply cannot be missed by any visitor to Paris. I had seen images and film of this years before I first went there many years ago. A recent revisit just emphasized what an extraordinary building this is! It is utterly beautiful and steeped in history. You have to go there because words cannot convey the experience of being inside this amazing place.
highlight. those wonderful stained glasses always give a special thrill, although being cloudy outside, the atmosphere is wonderful

Most beautiful stained glass windows I've ever seen.. I advice that you do St Chapelle on the same day as the Notredame and Ile St Louis because they are very close to each other. You can also do The Conciergerie (jail of the French Revolution and others details which I don't remember) on this day too as it is within the same gates as St Chapelle. Tickets can be purchased at St Chapelle which allows entry to this jail along with the Chapel itself. The first level of the chapel is boring, but don't forget that there is a second level! (we almost walked out without seeing it). You just have to go and see it yourself. It is beautiful. I wouldn't recommend this for people who are not Christian or at least interested in religion or maybe even architecture. The conciergerie is interesting. You can see the replica of Mary Antoinette's cell, and the chapel where it once was. There are exact replicas of jail cells which was very cool. Entry for these things is relatively expensive, but worth it for those interested in churches and/or jails.

St Chapelle Church. This is a must see if you are staying in Paris. The stained glass windows are the most amazing I have ever seen. It is probably the best kept secret in Paris as it is not far from Notre Dame yet nowhere near as advertised.
good place. a cool place in Paris. very easy to find out. should visit place in paris. many other touristic sites located near by.

Sight and Sound. The interior of Saint Chapelle is magnificent in and of itself. It's worth a visit if you're in Paris. That being said, it's even better if you can go and take in a concert in the chapel. Combine the wonderful acoustics with the beauty of the place...an evening well spent, in my book.

Breathtaking. We visited on 1st Sunday of the month, so entry was free of charge, but meant we had to queue. But, that was all worthwhile to see the stunning stained glass windows of the chapel. Informative sheets (in different languages) available at no cost describing the glass panels. A 3D touch screen also available.

This will blow your mind. Words cannot express how beautiful is la Sainte-Chapelle. It is in such an unusual location (middle of law courts) that you would not realize it was there if you didn't know to look for it. I cannot believe we waited for our fourth trip to Paris to visit it; honestly, you could skip Notre Dame (which is just down the road), or at least just look at it from outside, and just do la Sainte Chapelle. It is so light and airy and the blue is divine. No wonder St. Louis built it! This should be on everyone's top ten list of things to do in Paris.
Very nice. It is another must while in Paris. It has lots of history behind and great architecture. I wish next time will go to a concert there.

INTO FRENCH ATTITUDE AND ABUSE? BON CHANCE!. While it is a stunning visit, it may not be worth your while if you are subject to career minimum wage low lifes with big power at entry security, who exhibit the worst of French arrogance, attitude, loud yelling anger at the start of an otherwise wonderful visit. What a way to enter. These folks ought to be fired, but French civil service and manners as they are will be life long "ambassadors" for liberty, egualité, fraternity and non hospilaté.
Beautiful. Try to visit when it is bright and sunny outside. It is magical! Definitely one of my favorite places to visit in Paris
MUST visit in Paris. I visit there in the day and in the evening (for a "Vivaldi" concerto) and it delight in each of one of those visits

Another crowning jewel to Paris' exquisite architectural heritage. This unique Gothic gem is a not-to-be-missed attraction on any serious lover of European and Parisian culture. For almost a millenium this church stands as unquestionable testimony to French monarchs passion for superb art and architecture as well as profound dedication to Christian ideals. While the stonework is superb, vitrailles are just AMAZING!

Spectacular Stained Glass. Wow, we've been to a lot of churches and cathedrals in Europe over the past year and this one really stands out. If you are a stained glass lover, the windows here are simply spectacular. The lower church is unusual in the colors are very vivid. You don't need a lot of time here and the 10 euro fee is a little high, but you do see is beautiful

Architectural magic. This old gem is often not the first or even the second church visitors to Paris get to see. Still, it is the most unique one. It is a well kept treusure, it is small, so the queues can take a while, but it is worth it. The windows are magnificent and give a glistening light. This is where King Louis IX - known as Louis the Pious - kept the relics of Christ that he collected (and paid enormous amounts of money for..)

Absolutely Stunning. Our favorite church in Paris, it outdid the other marvels we saw, and did so by a significant margin. A completely spell-binding experience, it's unique architecture and lighting provide an effect you cannot see anywhere else.

Hidden gem. Located inside the palace of justice, it is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. All the walls are mede of beatifully painted glass. I recommend visiting while there is still light outside to appreciate better the luminosity of the chapel
Exquisite!. Booked to see a concert there, very special, great acoustics in a very special setting, a must do in Paris.
Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. We had the good luck of attending a wonderful violin concert at Sainte-Chapelle. It was great. Discovered this possibility on the Internet.

Breathtaking. when you enter the first floor it may seems so small but when you walk up to the main hall, it's breathtaking scene, the stained glass is more than 'beautiful' can describe. I went there in the morning of weekday and there's no queue.this chapel also included in museum pass.
I was blown away!. OMG, the stain glass windows here are well worth queuing to see. Detailed scenes of the Bible depicted.
Beauty in Glass. Absolutely breathtaking stained glass windows, but not sure about the waiting in line. I'm sure the windows could be seen better in a video. Not for the weak or with disabilities.
So small but so impressive!. If you like Notre Dame then you should definitely visit this small church. It is close back and you won't regret your visit!!!

Extraordinary. I visited years ago and had been unable to return till 2016. This turned out to be good because all the stained glass was cleaned and repaired last year. Even on a grey winter Parisian day, the glass in the Windows positively glowed. I have visited many churches over the intervening years but none are anything like this. It must be seen & experienced to be believed.Not to be missed!
Beautiful. Pictures do not do it justice. The windows are so very beautiful. If you are under 25 and from the EU, entry is free, so please make the most of it and visit! You won't regret it.
Spectacular stained glass!. Simply breathtakingly beautiful stained glass windows. Find a seat and drink in the kaleidoscope of colors. Stunning.

Memorizing!! One of the most beautiful chapels I've ever seen!. A visit to Sainte-Chapelle is a MUST! The stained glass in this church will literally take your breath away. You enter the main part of the chapel through a spiral staircase and as soon as you turn the corner and see this room...WOW! It is exquisite. So colorful and detailed.It's the most extensive 13th stained glass collection in the world and 70% of what you see is original. Definitely stop in here during your visit to Paris, even just for a half hour!

Small yet to Beautiful !. This small Chapell is situated inside an administrative building of Paris just on the bank of Seine (erstwhile palace). The uniqueness of this chapel is its beautiful and marvelous frescos which are more than 40 in numbers. You may well spend a couple of hours enjoying these beautiful frescos.
Best thing I saw. Absolutely stunning. The best thing I saw in Paris during my whole trip. Awe inspiring. The beauty of the chapel is unrivaled

Beautiful. Well worth pre-booking and visiting at anti-social times because it's a small space so fills quickly. To get the most out of the stained glass try to get there on a sunny day-early-it's well worth it for the stunning windows which will take your breath away. I wouldn't spend a lot of time on the ground floor-go straight upstairs. Worth every penny.

Breathtaking...favorite night in Paris.. We went to Sainte-Chapelle for one of their evening concerts, Vivaldi's Four Seasons, and it gave us chills. Listening to such a fabulous piece of music with the sun setting behind the most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen....it was our most memorable night in Paris.

Lovely windows. This is a worthwhile visit just for the stained glass. However, be aware that if you buy concert tickets and the advertisement shows beautiful windows for the event, you will not see those windows at all if it is dark out. For the "Chiristmas Concert", we sat in a cold, dark space with no capacity to see any windows at all. Very disappointing. If the concert were held in the late afternoon that would not have been an issue. False advertising was at play. The music also was not Christmas music, however there were some nice classical pieces, well-executed. Thankfully it was short, as we were very cold. Had to go back another day to enjoy the windows.

hidden surprise!. Thank goodness that I was told about this ahead of time, I would've walked past it without a second glance. You will see a smallish line standing near Notre Dame, waiting to enter some nondescript looking building. What is hidden inside though is an architectural gem. if you only have time to do Saint-Chapelle or Notre Dame, this is the one to spend time at...

Must See!. St. Chapelle was my favorite site in Paris that I had visited. I had studied St. Chappelle in art history classes prior to visiting but nothing could prepare me for the amazing stained glass windows. If you’re religious you should make this a pilgrimage, if you’re not it is an amazing chapel and you really must make the effort to see it when you’re in Paris.

The two-story royal chapel with impressive stained glass interior. After 90 minutes stay in line in front of the Palace of Justice complex we entered the courtyard of the Royal Palace on the Île de la Cité which houses The Sainte-Chapelle. The 42 m high structure is fronted by a two-story porch. The Lower Chapel`s walls are decorated with arcades and twelve medallions representing the Apostles. The Upper Chapel, which can be reached getting on the stairs at the left side of the entrance, was used by the king, his friends and family, and to display different religious relics as well. Sainte-Chapelle became famous for its dominant red and blue stained-glass windows, which cover a 600 square meters area, tellingthe story of humanity.
Fell In Love. Beautiful stained glass that left me in awe. Sunlight streamed through the multicoloured glass just brightened the old church and kept visitors like me in wonderment.

Fantastic but warm. We went for a concert there in the summer of 2015. It was amazing. Loved all the beautiful colors of the glass. The concert was fantastic, and the acoustic was surprisingly good. But it was soooo hot. But worth a visit

One of my favourite sites in Paris.. Not a big place, so for those who are short of time and want to see beautiful artwork. You should visit Sainte Chapelle. I stayed for 45 minutes starring at the beautifully detailed, stained glasses. Such beauty, highly recommend.

A hidden gem. We went in because we had the Museum pass and it was raining. So glad we did. While Notre Dame soars, Sainte-Chapelle is small and intimate. The former praises the majesty of God while the latter gives a sense of intimacy with Him.

One of the treasures of Medieval France. This church was part of the royal palace of King Louis IX, Saint Louis. It was built to house sacred relics. The lower church was for the common people and has painted walls as the principal decoration. The upper church for for royalty and is a glory of stained glass almost unbroken my walls. The restoration of the glass is complete and now attention is turned on repairing the stonework and painted walls. Some of the lower church has badly deteriorated but still beautiful to see as the restoration continues. Located on the Isle de Cite near Notre Dame cathedral, it must not be missed!
Amazing. you must go to this hidden gem in the heart of Paris, sit and take wonder at the art work done over 800 yrs ago

Breathtaking stained class. We visit Sainte Chapelle every time we visit Paris. It's worth it to sit and absorb the beauty. If possible, try to catch a concert in the Chapel. I never have, but it would be amazing.
Fantasic stained glass. A very interesting chapel with fantastic stained glass. Slightly out of the way but worth tracking down. Probably only an hour or so visit, but worth doing.

The stained glass windows are the most spectacular I've ever seen.. This is the most glorious chapel - it puts Notre Dame in the shade! The restoration work on the stained glass has been expertly carried out and they have to be seen to be believed. An uplifting experience!

An amazing beauty!. Oh, my favourite church in Paris! It is like a treasure box of light and colour!
You do not need a lot of time for your visit, in fact there is not much to see, just to stand in the middle of colourful shining and enjoy!

The 'OH MY GOD' church!. There seems to be beauty on every corner in Paris - after a few days it feels like all your senses are heightened and you start to appreciate subtlety and beauty in every thing! (Is this why it is the city of Romance?) Even in the city of the Versailles, Louvre, Notre Dame, and Monet, there is this wonder that just captures your imagination the moment you step in. I have always been a sucker for stained glass but nothing prepared me for this church! My wife and I kept exclaiming 'Oh My God!' at least half a dozen times. We were blown away the beauty, scale and the artistry that has gone into making the church! Highly recommended!

misleading opening times. We tried to visit today, the website says it is open all day, 9.30 - 6pm; we arrived at 1.15 to find a small queue outside, the big poster at the door stated it was open all day, after waiting for 15 minutes I asked the policeman outside the Palais de Justice next door if he knew what was going on and he told us it was closed until 2pm. No sign, no member of staff. Very disappointing. We had to leave without visiting as we had to catch the train back to England.

Awesomely Amazing!!. This is by far one of my most favorite places in the entire world. Sainte Chappelle is always breathtaking and inspiring. Even if you are not religious, you cannot help but being moved by the super-abundance of such beauty in both the lower and upper chapels. Going in the off season gives you the opportunity to see the chapels and truly bask it the glory of it. Even on a gloomy day the stained glass windows exude such vibrancy and color!
Incredible!. The best exemple of stained glass for the middle age in the world and freshly cleaned and renovated. The feeling is amazing!
small beautiful chapelle. not far from Notre Dame , you can see it same day, recommended, great art work , pay attention to the outside too, art, statues, gargoyles, great

I would give it more than 5 stars if possible. We waited on a long-ish line to go to Sainte Chapelle and the other members of my party were getting antsy. We were there close to closing and almost did not get in - which would have been a terrible shame. ALL of us were speechless at the beauty of Ste Chapelle. I had been here in 1984 but had not gone back in my visits to Paris since them. I was kicking myself when I saw it again. Will visit it any time I return to Paris - not to be missed.

A Gem on Île de la Cité. Sainte-Chapelle ("Holy Chapel" in English) is a wonderful gem of a church a few block from Notre Dame on the Île de la Cité. There are 12-15 tall, magnificent stained glass windows, plus a large, round "rose window," that depict scenes from the Hebrew Testament on one side, with displays from the Christian Testament on the other.Sainte-Chapelle has been discovered by tourists, but it's still a welcome respite from the crowds at the nearby Notre Dame. Buy a Paris Museum pass so that you can freely attend a number of museums, at your own pace and timing.

Thing of beauty. Incredible stained glass works of art, masquerading as windows. Unfortunately overcast weather the day we went, the sun streaming thru the windows would be breathtaking I'm sure. Really glad we saw it, 10 euro admission, must see in my opinion.
Amazing window work. Gorgeous stained glass that make the interious spakle with colours. Great place for history lovers. Get here early enough and the queue won't even be that long.

Stained Glass Wonder. This church is amazing! The line can be daunting, but it moves steadily. Once inside, the traveler is rewarded with the most beautiful stained glass collection. The interior is minuscule compared to its neighbor, Notre Dame, so it does not take much time to explore. I imagine the experience varies vastly depending on the angle of the sun and cloud cover, but I cannot imagine the church not providing an amazing view to its visitors.

It's all about the light through the magnificent windows. I have come to Sainte-Chapelle in the summer, when the blazing sunlight illuminate the beautiful stained-glass windows so that you feel as if you're inside a magical jewel box. I went to a concert at Xmas time here at night, thinking they would light the windows from behind. No such luck. After waiting in line for 90 minutes, we entered a darkened chapel, the only lights on the gilded pulpit, where the musicians performed. How I wish that they had spent the extra Euros to turn on the magic.

Dont miss!. Beautiful stain glass windows, impossible to compare. This historical building with the windows in incredible condition is something that everyone needs to see. Don't let the line outside the gate scare you. It moves at a steady pace.
Stained glass!. Gorgeous stained glass from the 13th century! Go upstairs and try to go when the sun is setting and streaming through the windows. Not to be missed
Beautiful as always.. There were queues here as well as Notre Dame but once inside it was worth all the wait. What an amazing light show inside. Our second visit here and worth the revisit.
Beautiful!. You will be amazed about the beauty of this Chapelle. The stained glass is beyond compare. You will be in awe as you wander inside this place.

Fabulous Stainglass. My has been and I enjoyed the tour of this chapel during a recent trip to Paris . The Stainglass is truly stunning and definitely worth the trip . Small lines small cost incurred to see the Stainglass windows definitely worth it .

lost in a world of beautiful glass. Being surrounded by an extravaganza of stained glass, rising up around you on all sides is truly a unique and wonderful experience. The colors are intense, bright and gorgeous!
The chapel and it's glass has been beautifully restored ; Louis IX would be happy with the results.

Time your visit well. The stained glass windows are great but they are hard to view to their best extent - choose a sunny day (possibly), summer may be better due to the angle of the sun as well. The place is not big and does not need a long time to do it justice. The place is closed at lunchtime (hours not clearly defined) and there are narrow winding stairs to get into the major portion.

Beautiful. I visited here by myself. It was a short visit not a lot to see but what there is in this small church or chapel was beautiful. I was very fascinated with the stain glass windows and how King Louis (I believe) had them done. Each one tells a story. The first one is about the garden of eden. Amazing structure. This was also on my pass.

a wonderful venue and even better when there is a concert. For several years Sainte-Chapelle has been undergoing extensive repairs of its glorious stained glass windows. During this period a few windows at a time were blocked. The repairs are now finished and the chapel looks as it always looked. There are two ways to visit it: a direct visit which starts in the basement and then you walk up a narrow staircase to this fabulous room or you can get tickets for a concert in which case you enter through the Palais de Justice and miss the surprise by coming up the stairs. Personally I prefer to go to a concert. There are signs for them near the entrance to Sainte Chapelle.

Over the Top!. I can't describe the feeling of standing in this chapel with the beautiful colored light flooding through the enormous windows. Get the audio tour. It is worth it. The audio tour is extensive and you can listen to as little or as much as you like. It will take you through the pictures in many of the windows, if you like, which could take hours.

Lost my fruit knife!. Arbitrary I know, but I had to hand over my knife. The most officious security I met in Paris. Part if the chael was being restored when I was there, but it is of course absolutely amazing.

Worth the wait in line. I have visited Paris a number of times, but never made it inside Saint Chapelle before. This time I was determined! We arrived early....I usually suggest visiting busy attractions in the afternoon when the crowds have cleared...but that doesn't seem to happen here due to the tight security, which is the real reason for the line, not ticket purchases. We took our place in the line about an hour before the scheduled opening time. Unfortunately, without explanation, the doors did not open until an hour after they were supposed to....so we still waited. But once inside, it was definately worth it! The gold and stained glass is truly breathtaking. I was surprised to find many vistitors taking a quick look around, a few snaps with their phones, and leaving. Try to get a seat and sit for a few minutes to enjoy the beauty properly, also the changes in light.

Hidden Gem!. Many people that go to Paris miss this chapel. Once the King's private chapel it has the most astounding stained glass of any historic church that I have visited. It is not very far from Notre Dame and very close to the Concierge where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned before she was beheaded. A young lady at the Concierge recommended that we visit the chapel and it is breathtaking. Be aware that you have to climb a circular stairway that is very cramped.

Better than the Notre Dame. My first time at the Sainte Chapelle and certainly not my last time. The stained steel windows are overwhelming especially when the sun shines through. Basically the chapel is a festival of lights and different colors. France can be proud to have so many diamonds.
Breathtaking. The stained glass windows are so magnificent and amazing! No word can describe its beautiful. Highly recommended!

Nice!. It's worth visiting while you stay in Paris. One of those things you just have to see while you travel in another city. Specially if you are a fan of art of any shape, then go here.
If you are able, climb the stairs - definitely worth it!

Evening Classical Music Concerts at the Sainte-Chapelle. One of my favorite things to do in Paris. Have come and brought guests each time I am in Paris, and it is always a highlight of everyone's trip. Buy tickets early online and avoid the lines/disappointment as the concerts usually sell out the day of. Come during sunset to see the light pass through the gorgeous stained glass windows. You won't regret it!
stunning. Now that the windows have been cleaned and replaced all round it is quite simply unrivalled, even by Chartres.

Unreal.. We attended a Christmas Concert on December 7 and it was absolutely worth every frozen toe. The only part that made was sad was that it was not as pictured on the website. We did not get to see the beautiful colors of the stained glass. I assumed it would be lit to showcase the stunning beauty of the windows...and it was not. The music was incredible.
Breathtaking !!!. Definitely worth climbing the stairs. It was beautiful to be surrounded by that beautiful glass and realizing that it was the story of the bible .

step inside a jewel box. Absolutely breathtaking. And its a pretty quick "in and out", so you can fit it in on a busy day. Go very early and avoid the inevitable lines (unless, like me, you go to Paris inJanuary- then no lines anywhere !)

Stained glass windows alone worth the trip. My former pastor was the one who told me to make sure to visit St. Chapelle. I had never heard of it, and i will always be grateful for his recommendation. This was the longest line of our entire trip to Paris, and thank goodness we made the cut-off before they closed for lunch. Really? Closing for lunch? You would think they could afford to hire more help with the tourist money coming into this place. The stained glass windows on the second floor are probably the most beautiful windows in the world. I saw the rose windows in Notre Dame, and while they were beautiful, they did not surpass St. Chapelle. The detail of the Bible stories told on these windows is nothing short of legendary. It just saddened me that the building is no longer used for worship, for I am quite sure that the makers of the stained glass intended them to be aids to understanding the stories of the Old and New Testament. You do not have to be religious to appreciate their beauty, however, just go. Sit down. Take a deep breath. Enjoy

Most amazing stained glass windows. The stained glass windows in Sainte-Chapelle are the the most amazing I have ever seen. I would recommend visiting earlier in the day to avoid the lines. I was raining the day we visited and the light through the windows was still spectacular.

Breathtaking. This is perhaps the most beautiful building I have ever been in, it is awe inspiring, beautiful and you could spend all day just looking at this beautiful piece of art.Queue wasn't too bad and the security checks were quick and understandable co spidering its location. Would return to see this site again in a heartbeat!
Most amazing stained glass windows ever. The stained glass windows in the upper level have just been restored and they are spectacular! Go around the room and try to follow the stories of the bible.

Great visit with guide. We were lucky to find an empty Sainte Chapelle (no lines)at 10 am on a Saturday morning this January. We were fortunate to pick a French speaking guided tour, by a Ph.D. Candidate at the Sorbonne that made all the difference, transforming the visit into a glance at the gothic style of the church, the history of France and the stained glass of the haute Chapelle. The guided tour is free by the way.

A small marvel. Built by Louis IX to house the Crown of Thorns "rescued" from the Byzantines in the aftermath of the fourth Crusade in 1204 which undermined the Roman Empire in the East and led to the eventual fall of Constantinople in 1453. Nevertheless, this small chapel is a marvel and should be seen on a sunny summer's day when the windows can be appreciated. Small concerts are held here and whilst they offer access to the building they do not allow it to be seen at its full advantage.

One of the most beautiful and incredible chapels in Europe, I've ever seen.. I promised myself I couldn't go to Paris without seeing this place. I'd heard from so many other travelers and friends how amazing it was...but words can't describe this, it's a must see. You'll see why the most descriptive words in the world couldn't tell you what it's really like. Yes, I was completely blown away. No lines while I was there and the cost was well worth it. The next time I'm in Paris, I'll be sure to stop in again and I would love to attend a concert here, which you should definitely look into if you have a free night while in Paris! I think they happen pretty often.
Stained glass and music. The most beautiful stained glass windows which become even more spectacular if you can attend a one hour classical concert there.

Breathtaking. what a delightful respite and beautiful to behold. Paris is a lot to take in, and there are many churches for rest and reflection. This is by far the most beautiful. I did not get a lot from the audio guide. I finally just sat on a chair and soaked it all in.
Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. Christmas Eve we attended a concert at Sainte-Chapelle. This is a beautiful location for enjoying Concerts de Noel!

Christmas Concert. What a stunning location for these concerts. The first time I went to one of these concerts it was the usual Vivaldi Four Seasons. This year it was an absolutely first-rate early music ensemble. The leader of the group was a virtuosic recordist. I've never heard this instrument played so well.It's kind of a magical experience to hear early music in this beautiful space.

Stunning church with a wonderful atmosphere. While Notre Dame is more well known, Sainte-Chapelle is a must see as well. The vivid colouring of the roof of the chapel and the wonderful glass and floor work are somethings that are worth seeing. It was originally a small church that was built as a personal place of worship but has become something much more in the past centuries.

Literally breathtaking. This is the only sight that literally took my breath away as I entered the floor after coming up the small spiral staircase. I don't think I've ever seen anything manmade that compares to this, including Notre Dame or anywhere else. Stunning. MAJOR TIP: BRING BINOCULARS! You can see the details in the 45 ft high stained glass panels with them while everyone else is bothered with their selfie sticks.
A must see. Definitely worth the time to visit. The stained glass is beautiful and the atmosphere is so peaceful.

Three words: CROWN OF THORNS. Yep, that's right. The crown of thorns worn by Christ are enshrined within this "chapel." Need I say more? A MUST see for any Christian, certainly.
If you are not interested in this, the stained glass is incredible and very notable in and of itself.
The Best. The stained-glass windows are so beautiful, it is worth the effort to go through all the security required to visit this true icon of French culture!

Magnificent Chapel, Magnificent Windows. My husband and I have been in Paris many times, but this was our first visit to Sainte-Chapelle. This intimate and uniquel chapel, which is tucked away next to the Conciergerie, could be easily overlooked by visitors to Paris. The windows are superbly detailed and about 75% of them are originals from the 13th century. The colors are brilliant. Take the time to visit while you are on the Ile de Cite visiting Notre Dame. Highly recommend!
Very nice photos taken. I tooksome photos of this place with my wide angle lens. It is beautiful, i really recommend going there !

One of the most beautiful church spaces in the world. Right now is an excellent time to visit this breathtaking space as renovation of one batch of windows is done, and it has yet to start on the others (last time we went one side of the space was covered up with renovation work). And it's well worth the climb up a very steep and narrow circular staircase (if there's an elevator I didn't see it, so if you are unable to climb, do a bit of investigating before you get there to make sure there is another option).If it's a sunny day, the colors are glorious as these are some of the best examples of stained glass windows you will ever see.

One of most beautiful spots in Paris and I've been negleting it for years!. One of most beautiful spots in Paris and I've been negleting it for years, just went because my husband asked me to ... we went on a rainy Sunday, there were not much left from my Paris to do list, and the most amazing thing is that I've visited the neighboor attraction, located in the same area, the Conciergerie!A little help to my 76 years old in order to climb the stairs and there we were, inside this magnifence room surrounded by blue glasses ... 70% of each "original", surviving the centuries and all the french and world history. My top place in Paris!

Take in a concert. This was a spectacular chapel, hidden from the outside but the stained glass seen when you are inside is unparalleled! We also attended an evening concert here and the lovely setting was perfect for the beautiful music. Peaceful and serene. One caution, there are no restrooms available so be sure to go before!

BEYOND STUNNING; TRULY A HIDDEN GEM OF PARIS (AND THE WORLD). Ok, well it's not exactly hidden, but it's definitely not as well known as destinations like Notre Dame. However, in all of my years of travelling, this chapel was one of the most impressive and awe-inspiring things I have ever seen. It almost brings you to tears. When I entered, I was like, "yeah, OK," but when you go upstairs, it absolutely takes your breath away. Definitely check it out.

Astounding. This small chapel is breathtakingly beautiful. From the outside it doesn't look particularly spectacular but once inside its magnificent stained glass windows will take your breath away. Well worth a visit.

If the sun is shining, go enjoy the stained glass. Since we usually stay in Paris during the winter, the number of sunny days is limited. So, if the sun is shining, I take off for the Sainte Chapelle and bask in the beauty. And the history of its raison d'etre is so cool, too.

Stunning beauty. Sainte-Chappelle is the height of Gothic beauty - walls of glass holding up a stone roof. You will feel as though you have been transported to heaven when you enter the second floor.There is now wheelchair access to the chapel. Wheelchair users are taken through the Palais de Justice. I did not measure the elevator, but it didn't seem smaller than most French elevators. (I doubt the door is only 60 cm wide, as I've seen said elsewhere online.) Then you get to enter the chapel through the main large doors, instead of the small staircase everyone else goes up. The only access problem for me was the cobblestone street outside. Everything else was quite accessible.
