Breathtaking. This church is gorgeous. Built to house the Crown of Thorns and for the exclusive use of royalty, it is lavish and beautiful. Make sure to go on a sunny day to get the full experience of the backlit stained glass!
Jesus' Crown of Thorns. A 13th century chapel that was built to house Jesus' Crown of Thorns. Beautiful stained glass depicting many bible scenes from Creation to Judgement Day. Absolutely beautiful!
Most beautiful Stained Glass. Sainte Chapelle is a must see. The stained glass windows are awesome. If possible try to hear a concert there

surreal experience. We attended a concert at Sainte-Chapelle. 4 piece strings. The way the music filled the chapel was unreal. I had goosebumps thinking of who had been in that room before enjoying a similar experience. I love the history of Paris and was frequently caught up in the moment and the experience that I am sure has been played over hundreds of times.
Magic. Is the most beautiful church in Paris. Not very big, but very very beautiful. In purple colours, it seems like a beatiful sunset. I recomand!
An unexpected delight. We came upon Sainte Chapelle rather by accident the day we visited Notre Dame...and it was without doubt a major highlight of our trip.

Fantastic holiday concert venue. Unfortunately, the concert we saw was at night, so we didn't get to see the stained glass in all it's glory. The concert was fantastic, though, very moving in the setting. We did have to wait in a long line, both inside and out, through very strict security, as you have to enter through the judicial building. I'm not sure how you'd access it for a non-concert visit. We didn't have time during our trip to make a day time visit, but I would have loved to have seen the stained glass in full daylight.

Such a good experience we visited twice. We attended a Christmas Eve concert which was an amazing experience in this small chapel but we could not get the full picture of the stained glass windows at night so we made time in our busy schedule to go back during the day.We were so pleased we did what an amazing chapel the stained glass is outstanding as it covers the entire chapel all walls and ceiling.Photos are allowed. The evening visit we has prepaid tickets and arrived 1 hour early to be at the front if you go to Ann evening concert make sure you pre book.When we returned we had to wait an hour to get in would have been quick with pre paid ticket.Very popular site so go early.Security checks to get in which is good as we felt safe.Well worth 2 visits

“…as if rapt to heaven, to enter ...". Seek this one out, walking distance from Notre Dame, spring for the small entry fee (under 10 Euro) and, there’ll likely be no lines! Sainte-Chapelle is considered one of the world’s most beautiful chapels, and once you’ve been struck in awe beneath its beauty of towering stained glass windows, hovering above like the angels, you’ll beg of its position as the best. You can easily spend a few hours here, deciphering the iconography pictured in the windows, audio at additional cost helps, and there’s seats, taken in courteous turn, around the perimetre of the upper chapel for better comfort of this pursuit. The praise of French philosopher, Jean de Jandun, rings as true today as it did centuries ago, “…as if rapt to heaven, to enter one of the best chambers of Paradise.”Cute guards standing sentinel at the Palace Gates through which you exit, complete added bonus!PS – photos don’t do it justice. One to see with your own eyes.

For color addicts and concert affectionates. Ben there for a Vivaldi concert (booked online) a totally enjoyed it! A beautiful place and a great sound - makes you feel as if you were sitting close to the King listening to Hos Majesty's new musicians audition... Adds the right feeling! And the windows - already pretty much described before by other people, and shown on pictures. Beautiful!

Like standing inside a rainbow. Located on the Ile de Cite. Built in the 13th century it is a small church made almost entirely out of stained glass. The weather was up and down all day, but we were fortunate that the sun was shining when we were there. It made it feel like we were standing inside a rainbow when we were in the upper chapel. Definitely worth seeing.

Always amazing!. Stunning stained glass. I could stand there all day looking at the windows being mesmerised by their beauty. Was a little confusing finding the way in, but if we had looked for the signs more carefully, we wouldn't have had a problem.

Long line up but worth it. In all our holiday in Paris, our line up for this tiny beautiful church was by far the longest of any! We lined up for over an hour, paid to get in and still had to wait some more. It is a one in, one out system so it can be a long wait. Down stairs are beautiful wall paintings and some stained glass... But the magic is upstairs! Stunning stunning stunning! Anyone would be hard pressed to not be amazed by these!

The Most Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. The cleaning of the huge stained glass windows in Sainte-Chapelle is just about complete, as well as the exterior façade. It is amazing how beautiful it all is especially when the sun shines. This chapel is on the Ile de la Cite in the center of Paris and was one of the original Gothic buildings in the first palace in Paris. Definite worth a visit. It is now in the same complex as France's Dept. of Justice.

Beautiful Church. This was our second visit to this beautiful church. The ground level of this church is interesting but fairly plain and some in our group wondered what was so special about our visit. The beauty is on the upper level, especially if it is a sunny day. The stained glass windows are stunning, primarily blue. Sainte Chapelle is an easy walk from Notre Dame and neither should be missed when visiting Paris.

breath taking. this chapel was so amazing to visit. I hadn't really heard of it and saw on the map it was a short walk to Notre Dame and wow its SO amazing inside!! there's a fee to get in which is 8 euro i think from memory but this is well worth paying!

LITTLE BUT BIG CHURCH. many years ago i was there in concert,and i loved it, this church is very nice in the morning and the evening,i have been there 4 times, and was never disappointed, the vitrage window are amazing,
Medieval Chapel Beautifully preserved. Restoration of stained glass windows added to the enjoyment of this work of art -- a treat for those who enjoy visiting masterpieces from the past

Read the history before going please. People here shoot their mouths off saying that it is not worth a visit since it is just a small place and stuff. But if you study the history and you will find that the stained glasses itself is the most stunning among the finest of their type in the world. As quoted in "Wiki" - "For whose benefit the stone wall surface is reduced to little more than a delicate framework. Fifteen huge mid-13th-century windows fill the nave and apse, while a large rose window with Flamboyant tracery (added to the upper chapel c.1490) dominates the western wall. Despite some damage the windows display a clear iconographical programme. The three windows of the eastern apse illustrate the New Testament, featuring scenes of The Passion (centre) with the Infancy of Christ (left) and the Life of John the Evangelist (right). By contrast, the windows of the nave are dominated by Old Testament exemplars of ideal kingship/queenship in an obvious nod to their royal patrons. The cycle starts at the western bay of the north wall with scenes from the Book of Genesis (heavily restored). The next ten windows of the nave follow clockwise with scenes from Exodus, Joseph, Numbers/Leviticus, Joshua/Deuteronomy, Judges, (moving to the south wall) Jeremiah/Tobias, Judith/Job, Esther, David and the Book of Kings. The final window, occupying the westernmost bay of the south wall brings this narrative of sacral kingship right up to date with a series of scenes showing the rediscovery of Christ's relics, the miracles they performed, and their relocation to Paris in the hands of King Louis himself".

Vivaldi and cathedral. my wife and I had bought advance tickets to this recital as part of a Christmas weekend trip .Not very well organised as we were standing outside in the cold for nearly 45 minutes waiting to take our seats. Upon entering we were told that we had not got allocated seating so would have to sit around the edge . This suited us as we had an unobstructed view of the musicians. Just before it started however, we were told that we had to sit with everybody else as it was a fire risk. strange!!1. once the show started the performance was excellent. It would be nice , if for an evening performance, they could illuminate the stunning 15 metre high stained glass windows fro outside. That would make it look spectacular!!

Bathed in light. Step into the cathedral and the multi-colored light descending upon you from the stained glass windows is unlike any other cathedral. A truly amazing place. A must-visit attraction, even if you are not religious.

Beyond Beautiful!. We attended a Vivaldi Four Season s concert December 20. We sat in the dark with only the musicians at the front in light. It was splendid. The high point was when the violinist came down the centre aisle in the dark playing his violin. Astounding! We returned the following day to see the stained glass by light of day. Although we wanted to see several attractions we spent an hour musing at the extraordinary beauty of this place. Don't miss a visit to Saint Chapelle.

One of my favorite places in Paris.. After I dropped off my bags at the apartment rental, my first stop was Sainte-Chapelle. It's an amazing experience to walk up the spiral staircase and to see the stain glass surrounding you; I can't describe it. I made a point to go in the later afternoon, as the sun hits the glass a certain way, which makes for great viewing. It's the one place in Paris I return to.The line to get in can seem intimidating and a long wait, but it moves pretty quickly. Just be prepared to open bags and take off coats and quickly move through it.

Stunning stained glass windows. This chapel is stunning for the amount of beautiful stained glass windows and other decorations. If you stop to think what it must have been like when it was first built, it defies the imagination.

extraordinary stained glass. Get there early and on a sunny day. Like everything in Paris, it had a long line (almost an hour for us and we arrived 30 minutes after opening in late December). Museum pass holders don't get to cut the line. (Other advance ticket holders do get to cut in line but I don't know how those passes are obtained.) That said, once the wait is over, you can buy your Museum pass there. Incidentally, we were glad to have the Museum pass for getting into the Louvre. It saved us a 2 hours wait. If travelling with kids, buy passes for the adults. Kids get in free at the Louvre and are able to cut the line if their parents are pass holders.This was my fourth trip to Paris and my first trip to Sainte-Chapelle. I wish I'd discovered it sooner. The stained glass is stunning. In the corner of the chapel, there a cards in English that give some background information on each window. I handed my 12-year-old a camera and he was quite engaged in taking photos of the windows if not the history behind them.

The line looks daunting, but it goes fast.. Don't let the line for admittance deter you...it moves fast and it worth the wait. I was expecting a large cathedral (which it wasn't....apparently I didn't do too much research for this stop before hand), but I was blown away by the beauty of it. It was like walking into a large stained glass Tiffany Lamp. Beautiful! Each pane of glass is so intricate. Worth the visit & part of the Paris Museum Pass.

TALL!!!. These give the impression, at least, of being the tallest stained glass windows I've seen. It's a rather narrow area so your gaze must go straight UP. Beautiful. (Just make sure you actually go upstairs to see the windows. I almost missed them, as the stairways to go up are not clearly marked.) However, the paintwork and other details on the ground floor are worth examining, too, as well as the mosaic floors.

Gorgeous!. Waited in a very long line to visit. Should have bought tickets ahead of time! Once inside the lower level is nothing much. Then you walk upstairs into the chapel with all the stained glass and it's beautiful! The crown of thorns is displayed here on occasion which is why it was originally built.

An absolute jewel. I adore this superb chapel - but was so excited to take my two children for the first time and see the wonder on their faces as they emerged from climbing the narrow stone staircase into the glory of this stunning and sacred place. An unforgettable experience.

It was simply stunning!. We went through into the chapel, and the shop and thought it was lovely with the small stained glass windows. Then we saw a staircase in the corner and wandered up to see what was there, and lo, and behold, there were the major stained glass windows and the actual church! It was awe inspiring! The colours and the size of the windows, and the light filtering through them! Just magical!

A small chapel near Notre Dame. This is a small chapel near Notre Dame. It has nice decorations inside but does not worth paying the entrance fee. If you have a Paris museum pass, you can visit it for free. Otherwise try Notre Dame which is free and much more attractive.

Splendid. Don't miss out on this feast for the eyes and the soul! This old church with the magnificent stained glass windows took our breath away- so so beautiful! I've seen the inside of many cathedrals but this felt unique!  Well worth the queue to get in!
Overwhelming!. A lovely place if you love stained glass, it was outstanding in beauty! All the windows tell a story and it is very interesting!

An emotional experience. I visited Sainte-Chapelle on Boxing Day evening (26 Dec) to attend a Vivaldi concert of the Four Seasons which was played by a classic ensemble. Saints-Chapelle is a beautiful building which added to the emotive sounds from the violins. I would recommend attending a concert at this venue.

Vivaldi Christmas Concert at Ste. Chapelle. The beautiful Gothic Ste. Chapelle on Ile de Cite was the location for a Vivaldi Concert performed by Les Solistes Francais. It was Christmas time in a city recovering from the horrific scars of a terrorist attack and there was no more fitting place than this centre of peace to contemplate the absolute beauty of western culture - architecture and music.The walk to Ste. Chapelle, across the Pont au Change from Chatelet set the tone.
It's All About the Stained Galss. All I can say is, you will walk up one flight of stairs and immediately say WOW! I've never seen anything like it.

Gorgeous. Our favorite Church in Paris! once you climb the stairs and enter the second floor your jaw will drop. Tip: the line out front looks very long, but there were two entrances, one for the government building and then the one for Sainte-Chapelle. Make sure you are in the right line.
Wow!. Absolutely unbelievable stained glass windows in hues of red and blue that soar upwards to the pointed arches. Don't be put off by the long line to enter - it is very much worth the wait.

LIGHT ALL AROUND . THE TALLEST GLASS PAINTED WINDOWS EVER SEEN. GO there on a sunny day.
The colours of the glass painted windows going up for tens of meters will simply leave you breathless

Worth the long wait. We waited for an hour in line to get in and we stayed for about 45 minutes. But it was worth it! Beautiful stained glass windows that can take one's breathe away. The windows are all very high and they all looked amazing. It was worth my one hour wait in the cold and worth the entrance ticket more than many other attractions in the city!
Amazing. A must see. The upper chapel is amazing, the colour, the light, the detail, all off it comes together perfectly.

Gorgeous.. There was a fairly large and slow moving queue to get it but it was so worth it. This chapel is awe inspiring. The sheer amount of glazing makes it appear as though the building is weightless. The rich blues and reds of the stained glass gives a purple hue to the building.It was the highlight of my trip to Paris and most importantly it was free because I'm a student!Tip: make sure you leave enough time to see the chapel in day light. Visit on a sunny day. Photography is allowed.

Unique and Brilliant!!. It was different from rest of the chapels and was a good experiece. Downside was the long queue on the pavement due to security checks(only 1 counter :( ) , but was definitely worth it.Tip:There seems to be a way to avoid the queues by getting priority tickets. If you are going in peak time, check it out.
Must see. The most amazing stained glass in the world... go there off season tho as the queues can be long....
Beautiful. Not to be missed!! Sainte-Chapelle's beauty will take your breath away. Go when the sun is shining if you can.

Beautiful stained glass. Small but the stained glass is beautiful. I wouldn't say this was something I would have to see if I went to Paris again, but it's well worth seeing once, especially if you happened to buy the Paris Museum Pass which includes entry here.

Amazing Stain Glass Windows. Never miss this beautiful chapel when visiting Paris. It's truly one of my favorite sites in Paris. When purchasing your ticket for San Chappelle, be sure to get one for the Concergerie, where Marie Antoinette wa s heard before her beheading.
Traveling with a High School group from NH.. I was told that among other things; this Chapel was built by Louis IX after the Crusades and housed the Crown of Thorns from the Crucifixion.

Closed due to workers' strike. Was looking forward to it during our visit in Dec 2015, but it was closed indefinitely due to a workers' strike. Just thought to share with those travelling there to check first.

Probably the most beautiful chapel in France. This was never intended to be open to the public (it was built aas a private chapel for French King Louis IX aka Louis the Saint. Don't let the present renovation deter you, there are still plenty of beautiful things to be seen.
Beautiful Stained Glass. It is a very small chapel that once housed the kings relics from the crusades. It's much smaller than I had expected but I thought it was worth the 7 euros.

Amazing Stained Glass. This place is amazing, especially considering it was built in the 1200's. The floor to ceiling cathedral sized stained glass was quite impressive. Lines were long to pay to get in so buy tickets in advance and skip the line!!

Graceful. I've been in Sainte-Chapelle some days ago. It is little but the first floor is pretty nice, with big, beautifully coloured windows.
I didn't pay because I am under 26 but I think 10€ for the entrance is quite expensive for a such little (albeit really graceful) chapel.
Breathtaking. Heard a Christmas concert at Ste. Chapelle. It is stunning - stained glass all around. Acoustics were awesome.
Amazing. We attended an concert at St Chappelle. Unbelievable church, great concert, and beautiful stained glass.
The most beautiful chapel in all of Europe. This is a truly remarkable experience - The 15 stained glass panels and the rose window tell a remarkable story King Louis private chapel

Impressive worth the wait . We were able to get in quickly because we purchased the tickets together when we went to see the conciergerie. This gave us special access tickets and thus avoided the waiting in line. The stained glass windows are definitely a must see. One of the many beautiful sights to see in Paris.

A Taste of Heaven. Beautiful church. Visiting with my daughter and boyfriend while in Paris. So lovely, so historic. I got chills when we walked in. The lights, the colors, the gorgeous stained Windows just took my breath away. They just don't make churches like this anymore. If you get a chance, go see.

LOVELY - incredibly slow line. I was more excited about this than any other attraction in Paris. It met my expectation, but since they were SO high to begin with, I wasn't blown away. I had the museum pass.

Go for concert at sunset. Some of the stained glass in Europe. Wonderful classical concerts, make sure you go to concert so you are there during sunset so you can see the light changing as it shines through the glass. No need to buy vip seats as aucutics are great no matter where you sit. We have been there several times over the years.

Oh, to be King!. This is a magical place - the chapel of royalty rather than the massive cathedral for the masses. The stain glass windows are magnificent - but the ceiling is particularly special. Easiest way to see Saint-Chapelle without the crowds is to take in a concert.

Stained glass heaven . When we entered the first floor, it was a normal chapel, i was a slight disappointed until we climbed up to the second floor, and the stained glasses were simply amazing. You could spend hours just staring at the panels. Unfortunately the sun was coming down, so it was not as brilliant as it would have been. Still a must visit!

Stunning stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle is part of the Conciergerie Palace of Justice complex just a block from the more famous and much larger Notre Dame Cathedral. Sainte-Chappele was built in less than ten years in the mid-13th century--light speed by medieval standards--to house Louis IX's collection of relics of Christ's Passion. The church's display of stained glass is stunning, reported to be the largest of its kind in the world. You can easily read about the history and see the photos, but you cannot appreciate this stunning gem of Gothic architecture unless you see with your own eyes. It's very small compared to its more famous neighboring church but so well worth an hour or so of your time in Paris.

No matter how many times you visit, Sainte Chappelle is breath taking!. Sainte Chappelle is one of the most amazing and wondrous sites in the world. Both the simpler more introspective lower chapel and the heart stopping, transporting upper chapel are a must in Paris. Seeing each gives you a perspective of life during these times. BOOK IN ADVANCE! the lines here are huge, worth the wait, but huge!, we have been here multiple times and still are in AWE!

Breath taking stain glass windows!. Wow - is what I said as we stepped into the top floor chapel of Saint-Chapelle. I sat on a bench and just observed in awe. Worth checking out and while you are there, have a look at La Concierge.
Amazing Concert Venue. The sunset concerts are wonderful. Only attended the string ensembles but the sound was wonderful and the setting was perfect.

Most beautiful building...ever?. This is truly magnificent, a real treasure of a building. Do not miss this on your visit to Paris. It is stunningly lovely, the glass windows awe inspiring, the inlaid stone floors charming, the painted ceilings worth the neck cramp. Bring a camera, and a bit of time to enjoy just looking around. Worth the wait in line.

Great building and worth the visit.. If you are in the neighbourhood for the Notre Dam then this church is not far away and worth a visit too. There are audio guides and you may have a wait but its well worth it.

Magnificent Saint Glass . Magnificat Saint Glass is what you don't want to miss. Truly inspiring but the story of the chapters bible depicted through the color glass. Very inspiring. The scale of chapel is small and it brings intimacy!

Amazing Stained Glass. Finally managed to fit Sainte-Chapelle into a Paris visit and it did not disappoint. The stained glass is overwhelming. This is not to be missed because no picture or words can truly describe it.

A must see. Absolutely breathtaking. I have seen many churches and this is right up there as one of the spectacular ones. When you walk in and see the beautiful stained glass windows in a very small space amazing! Easily done in less than an hour

It Took Us Four Trips. I won't bore you with the details. Long story short, don't go there with a Swiss Army knife, no matter how small it is. The wait in the cold was worth the wait. The Chapelle is quite amazing. You will not be disappointed. Get the audio guide once you get inside so you can learn all about the history. It's a small Paris treasure. Glad we found it.
Sublime.... Magical. Sublime. Glorious. So much smaller in scale than nearby Notre Dame and so much more charming.

Awe Inspiring. Again, went to Sainte Chappelle for a concert. These are very brief interludes at night which are perfect for unwinding after flight to Paris. Its cold in the chapel at night as its not heated but the music is wonderful and feels you with good feelings for the rest of the trip. The chapel is beautiful and best viewed on a sunny day in order to see the stained glass windows.
Beautiful church and windows. What a beautiful church and exquisite stained glass windows. Definitely worth the visit. Not a bad wait in line.

Simply stunning. Saints-Chapelle was simply stunning. It's hard to imagine the effort that gone into creating the amazing stained glass windows, but we were particularly lucky to be able to watch a documentary about the renovation of the chapel while we were there. It was incredible to see the painstaking work that went into transforming the old and dirty windows back to their original glory.

Can't be missed. We have been here several times, and each time it is just as wonderful. This is a small chapel, but there are hundreds of stained glass windows. It's one of the greatest sights in Paris.
Christmas concert. Enjoyed the Christmas concert on Dec. 19. Beautiful music appropriate for the season. I just wish it took place in the day time to get a better view of the stained glass windows.

Do not miss. This is one of the most stunning sights I have seen in Paris. When you go up the stairs to the chapel and the sun is shining through the mulitude of stain glass windows, it truly takes your breath away. As you study the indiviual windows and really look at the glass, you can help but be in awe. It will make the long line worth every minute of the wait.

Hidden gem. This was probably my favorite church of our week-long visit and we saw many. The bottom part of the chapel is simple and beautiful, even though it seems to be undergoing some renovations. The gift shop area really didn't take away from the simplicity and reverence, even though it's smack in the middle of everything. The upstairs...magnificent. It's hard to believe that all that glass and stone was handworked in six years for one man.
Wow. Probably the most beautiful thing in Paris really take the time to admire the 50ft stained glass windows each depicting something different. We got duel tickets for the concierge next door also.

My favorite church in Paris. Let's face it, there are many beautiful churches in Paris. Notre Dame, Sacre-Coeur...the list goes on. I am a lover of stained glass, so my vote for most beautiful goes to a smaller church, Sainte-Chapelle. Try to go on a day with at least some sun so you can get the full effect. The windows are truly dazzling. If you plan ahead you may be able to get tickets to one of the concerts they occasionally hold there. Although you won't get the effect of the windows at night, seeing a concert here is a magical experience. We went on Christmas Eve, and it was an evening we will never forget.
Go to a concert. We listened to Vivaldi in this fantastic building - it was a highlight of our trip. You can buy the tickets during the day for evening performances.

Christmas Concert Was Fabulous!. My husband and I spent Christmas in Paris this year and the Christmas concert at La Sainte-Chapelle was a highlight. What a beautiful church. It was an intimate setting and the quartet was great. The woman who sang was obviously trained in opera and her Ave Maria was amazing. They played many known Christmas songs from around the world and we left with an abundance of Christmas spirit. Do not miss this if you spend Christmas in Paris.

Stunning. We have just visited Sainte-Chapelle for a lovely Christmas concert. I was expecting a programme of baroque "favourites", so it was a real pleasure to find that it was actually a recital by a singer, violinist and harpsichord player, consisting of a broad range of songs and short instrumental pieces from the 16th century, right through to the 20th.The chapel itself is utterly stunning. The stained glass windows are even more beautiful than we had expected, and really do appear to be holding up the roof. We lingered for as long as possible after the recital, to take in the splendour, and will definitely return soon for a daylight visit.

Horrific line. The wait in line was pure torture. It would move for awhile and then nothing for 15 minutes. A complete standstill as they let the priority folks jump the line. The place itself is sensational but getting in is hell

Attend A Recital. La Sainte Chapelle hosts string quartets for wonderful evenings of classical music. The acoustics of the place is incredible and the stained glass setting gives the whole experience a magical touch.

Worth the wait. We had to wait for 45 minutes to get in (museum pass is no help here), but it was completely worth it. Everything you read about the beautiful stained glass is true. Go only on a sunny day so you can experience the windows in all their glory. There are English language cards near the exit in the upper chapel that explain the windows in detail. An audio guide is also available downstairs.

Classical music concert Sublime strings. What an incredible experience - Vivaldi four seasons played in this exceptional venue by Les Solistes Francais. This was a highlight of our Paris trip. Great artists in the dramatic Sainte Chapelle. Thank you for a wonderful evening - and beguiling our two teenagers to the magic of classical music
Beautiful, a must see.... Historically interesting and definitely beautiful. After three trips to Paris, my daughter convinced me to go. I wish I'd gone sooner!
Definitely an underrated attraction in Paris. Absolutely incredible attraction, better than the Notre Dame in my opinion. The stained glass upstairs is breathtaking. Even young kids looked awestruck!

Lives up to the hype. The main reason anyone visits if for the stained glass, and it is incredible. Lineups are not bad here as most people are on the other side of the island. My only beef is the €7.5 entry fee into a church. I completely understand that since it is no longer an active church they need to raise money for restorations. All the other churches asked for donations or had candles you could light for €2. The price is very steep, especially since we also had to pay for our 4 year old to get in.

Long, long, long queue to see the most beautiful stained glass. This place is stunning, & we have never seen such gorgeous stained glass windows anywhere else in the world. However we waited for 2.5 hours to get in, & nothing is worth that wait. Do NOT visit around lunch time because it is closed. Go there before it opens & hopefully you will only have to queue for a little while. Good luck!

Paris History!. Beautiful old chapel with an amazing history! Get the headphones, the history is amazing and there is so much to see. I don't recommend not using the headphones. Each statue and relic need explaining

Amazing. Must see for Paris! Stained glass is breathtaking. Don't be confused when you walk in like we were. The main chapel is upstairs not at the entry level. Although the entry chapel is nice, it is not the stain glass wonder.

Worth the wait in line. There's usually a long line outside of the gates to Sainte-Chapelle, but once you get inside the courtyard, you can buy a Museum Pass at the front and avoid the rest of the line (totally worth the money if you plan to visit more than 2 museums). Once inside the chapel, you'll see why this is such a busy venue. The stained glass, bas relief carvings and medieval structure is amazing. It's truly one of the most beautiful churches in the world, in my opinion.

Don't miss the history and stained glass. First,take in the awesome stained glass, then take time to see the collection of Passion relics. The stained glass is astonishing and hard to believe it was built in 1248. The Sainte-Chapelle is located just a few minutes walk from Notre Dame Cathedral with nearby restaurants.

Beautiful stained glass windows, and bring your wide angle lens. Along with Notre Dame, Sainte Chapelle is a must-see. The beautiful stained glass windows, which date back to the 13th century, are truly magnificent. This is one place where the museum pass doesn't get you to the front of the line. You'll have to wait it out with the rest of them, but fortunately the line moves pretty steadily. You'll enter through the lower chapel which is smaller and beautiful in its own right. There is a gift shop and a staircase ascending to the main chapel. You can feel free to spend as much time as you like there. Wander amongst the stain glass panels and soak it all in. It is absolutely amazing. Be sure to have a wide angle lens if you want to adequately photograph the interior. Best to stand toward the back, hold your camera up high and use the live view mode. Meter your exposure for the glass, and then underexpose your shot. If you are pressed for time, make sure you see the lower and main chapels.

Mind blowing history... The Sainte Chapelle that holds the collection of Passion relics, including Christ's Crown of Thorns!! Astonishing History and stunning stained glass.. Cant believe it was built in 1248 and is still up and standing. The building in itself if very small and has 2 floors. The ground floor has the smalll stained glass panels and a statue of christ. Take the steps up and you will see the amazing tall stained glass windows. The room is beautiful and you can spend time just looking at it and observing the paintings in awe. The history of this place is totally unbelievable. If you have a Paris pass, this is free entry, else buy a ticket. The Sainte Chapelle is located just a few minutes walk from Notre Dame Cathedral. We visited on a Sunday and there were some lovely sunday markets just outside the nearest metro station next to Sainte-Chapelle.

When you step into the chapel upstairs - Wow!!. Notre Dame is impressive, but Sainte-Chapelle is the most beautiful! Best seen on a sunny day, the tall, stained-glass windows not only lift your eyes, but your spirit as well. The line can be long here, but it's worth the wait - don't miss it!

Absolutely amazing. This has got to be one of the most beautiful churches I have ever been in! The stain glass windows are amazing! If you only have time for one church while in Paris I would go here over Notre Dame.
Beautiful! . The Saint-Chapelle is definitely worth going to if you are in Paris. Amazing stain glass windows. One of the best things we did in Paris.

Stained glass like you've never seen before. Sainte-Chalelle is "inside" the gates of a public building, so security is tight and the hours are short. It is very crowded, but it is quite an experience to see the floor-to-ceiling stained glass windows.

Avoid the concert. With so much expectation, I went to the concert of Christmas Eve at Sainte-Chapelle. It was a big disappointment with sub-standard performers (except the violin quartet). I could not believe my ears when the singers (a group of 4 men and 4 women) sang "O Come All Ye Faithful) out of tune. They were shocked by themselves - one singer even stopped singing. The voices did not harmonize as they should. I think even not a seasoned audience could notice the problem. It gave me an impression that they did not practice and rush to finish the performance (probably because of other Christmas Eve activities). I sat in front and noticed that one of the singer did not even know which lines to sing and seek help from another singer. Towards the end, they did sing some nice songs with the violin quartet. It saved the show from complete disaster. Meanwhile, one could not deny that it was a beautiful 13th century chapel. For the concert, better avoid it or check very carefully who the performers are. If one insists to take the risk, here are some practical information regarding the logistic. You have to arrive at the main entrance early to go through the airport style security. There is no one to guide the queuing or provide any information. We just formed a line with some early birds (we arrived at 6.15pm for 7.30pm show) and hoped that it was the entrance and the way to line up. There was no information or usher of whether what to do. We just guessed that it was the way. We started to feel anxious when it was very quiet (the doors were tightly shut and not much light at the entrance. Just like a closed store). At 6.45pm, the door finally opened. We entered the place and went through the security. We then lined up again in an outdoor passage for another 10 mins. At 7.15pm, the security guard led us to the building and we waited a short while outside the chapel. If you visit the place in winter, better bring some warm clothing due to the outdoor waiting and there was no heating system inside the chapel. I would suggest to visit the place during day time to appreciate the stained glasses.

'the most beautiful church in the world. Visit on a sunny day, preferably on an afternoon when the sun shines through the exquisite leaded windows. And don't be scared of the long queues, it's worth it.

A jewel - on a sunny day!. Sainte Chapelle is a magnificent, hidden jewel. It is in the courtyard of the Palais de Justice, and you must enter to the left of the gates. You climb a tiny, winding staircase, and the stained glass windows astound you with their complexity and jewel-like tones. The columns are all painted in beautiful colors and patterns, with huge amounts of gold leaf. It is often quite empty, and a lovely spot to meditate. Don't miss the window through which the royals viewed the service - and do go on a sunny day, to better appreciate the stained glass masterpieces.

Stunningly beautiful!. We were amazed at the beautiful colors and intricate work involved in this small chapel. Thought I would have liked a small pair of binoculars to better see the upper level panels. Wish we had studied the history and layout a bit more before going. Would love the experience of seeing it without the crowds to study the stories. A must visit in my opinion!
Beautiful windows. You must go to see the huge stained glass windows. They are absolutely amazing. It seems to be a hidden gem.
Classical concert. Make sure to attend a concert. The acoustics are amazing and the atmosphere is welcoming. It was a lovely evening.

Visit to Sainte-Chapelle. This hidden gem is a little difficult to find, but well worth it. The beauty and enormity of the windows is unsurpassed. We were awed at the age of the windows, some many hundreds of years old!
Better Than Notre Dame. most beautiful chapel in paris.Stained glass and ceilings outstanding.Loved walking up and down the narrow circular staircase

A Stained-Glass Lovers Dream.... Sainte-Chapelle is by no means as grandiose as Notre Dame or a dozen other churches in Paris, but the gothic architecture is exquisite and the stained glass windows are breathtaking. It is a bit of a tight squeeze and a short climb to get to the main basilica, but it is well worth the minimal physical effort.
Beautiful. One of the finest chapels in the world. Go on a sunny day to get the full effect. If its raining save your money and do something else!
Some fantastic architecture. Buitiful building with some views of Paris from up the bell tower. Even though security was high it was still a loverly pace to visit.
Worth a visit!!!. This church is so amazing of how human can create such a wonderful glass that telling a story from the bible. It is really worth a visit.

Often overlooked!!. Many miss this jewel! Such a find! Many travel agents neglect to mention this lovely place of early worship. We loved the lower level which included the oldest fresco in France and all the history unveiled! We were further enchanted with the upper level whose stained glass windows depicted all majors events in the Bible from the birth of Christ to the end of time as we know it-the judgement throne. The entry line moved slowly, but it was definitely worth the wait. Don't miss this unique experience especially if you are a true Believer.

Don't miss this one!. A friend recommended we stop in here after Notre Dame and I am so glad we did or I might have passed it by. It was never intended for public use and was built by Saint Louis for the royal family and their religious relics. The stained glass windows actually made my jaw drop when we walked in. So worth it although I can't speak to wait time to get in as there was no line for us. We were in Paris not long after the terrorist attacks and not many tourists about.

Worth waiting in line for the beautiful stained glass. Make sure you take the stairs to the second floor and pause and take a deep breath before the last step because the beauty will take your breath away. Take the time to examine each of the window panels in the main chapel as each tells a story.
Exquisite. I can see why everyone raves about this place. We were so lucky that we visited on a quiet afternoon. It's just draw dropping-ly gorgeous - has to be seen to be believed.

Unrivaled Stained Glass. We came to see the stained glass and were not disappointed. Wow! We came back for music in the evening, which was good, but in the dark the space just isn't the same. If you planned to come for music, check the sunset time to be sure the stained glass will still be shimmering.

Wow. This is a beautiful Gothic place build by the French King Saint Louis. Next to the also beautiful Justice Building and the Quai de l'horloge. It's beautiful inside out, and the stained glass are wonderful. If you have the time, they have concert of classical music ; the acoustic is amazing. I went to listen to the Four Seasons from Vivaldi, as the Spring was our wedding music . Enjoy beautiful Paris. I love this city

Must see in Paris. Everyone talks about Notre Dame and while it is amazing and a must see attraction in Paris this should be added to the list too!Sainte Chapelle has the most amazing stained glass windows I've ever seen! It's cheap to get in and you can spend some time looking at the detail in the glass!
Great Glass. I loved the stained glass in this church. The staff were very helpful and had some good suggestions for other sites to see.

Overwhelming beautiful. Go here! Dont miss is. Hard to find but worth it. You come in and go huh! Then you go up some windy stairs and there you are in a room of just stained glass. Get the card and read all about each section. Worth the time it takes.
Beautiful.. Well worth the climb up the tiny spiral staircase. Thankfully, there is a staircase for up, as well as down.

Best lesser-known attraction in Paris.. Everybody knows about the Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, and Notre Dame... But even Parisians forget about Sainte-Chapelle. Located two blocks behind Notre Dame, the chapel is inside the police/courthouse building's courtyard. The stained glass is UNBELIEVABLY beautiful and worth every penny to see.
Very intricate stained glass. Excellent art work and intricate stained glass. Not as popular as Notre Dame, but if you are in the area it is cool to see

Breathtakingly beautiful. We visited the Sainte-Chapelle on Monday 15th December - due to the terrorist attacks, security in Paris is on high alert which made us feel safer. Once past security, visiting the Chapelle was stunning. It was not too busy, and the information about the windows upstairs was very interesting. A large group being given a guided tour stood at the front of the room upstairs for about 15 minutes meaning that no one else could look at the surroundings which was frustrating. Definitely recommend visiting.

Outstanding stained glass. The cleaning of the 13th century stained glass has made this an even more extraordinary experience. Look out for the video description and ensure you get a description board from near the exit on the upper floor. It gives a good outline of how the "stories" work. There are audio guides available downstairs. A small pair of binoculars might be worth carrying.Be careful to join the correct queue outside, the entrance to the Palais de Justice is next to the entrance and can look like the queue for Sainte Chapelle and the entrance to the attraction can appear as if one needs a pre-booked ticket, which is not the case.Security means that the queues are taking much longer to clear so allow plenty of time.

Spectacular Stained Glass. This is a smaller cathedral in terms of the huge ones in Europe, but the stained glass makes it one of the most beautiful that we have seen. A sunny day enhances the experience, but anytime you can appreciate the detail of the handiwork and beauty of the stained glass.
Jewel box perfection. My third visit here was a stunning as my first. Perhaps the finest stained-glass in France soars above your head, lifting your gaze and your spirit. You must see this chapel.

Amazing. One of the best attractions in Paris, if not the best one. Although visit takes not a long time, it is totally worth to find time for visiting, even on rainy day. Be ready for a long line (possible to skip if buying combined ticket with concierge).

Breathtaking chapel. I literally walked up the stairs, into the chapel, and gasped out loud. The stain glasses windows are simply moving. The colors and the stories they tell are fascinating! Plan about an hour here tops..there are descriptions in all languages for you to read (laminated sheets of paper you take from the entrance), so I didn't feel the need to get the audio. The descriptions are perfect. Logistic advice-- if you have the museum pass, this does NOT entitle you to the skip the line at this attraction until you get past security. To "buy" your entrance tickets, you can go the advance pass line, but NOT before security. The reason they are strict with this is this Chapel is adjacent and shares grounds with a governmental French agency. I went in November, around 11:00 am with a 30 min wait. Sometimes they close from 12-2pm so check the website before heading around that time!
Wondrous!. The most fascinating collection of stained glass windows. Each window told a story, chronologically and beautifully. It's a must see amazement. Go early - lines are long.

Vue d'une parisienne. Strangers or not. "Une Parisienne vous parle"... Such a beauty . If there is one place to visit in Paris, it's this one. But before, be kind to read something about our king Louis the 9th and his story and his minister too, Abbé Suger. After go to St Denis Abbey, and try assimilate. It's much better and so nicer than Djihad !!!!! Many restaurants, not expansive, besides. En famille, en solo, encore et encore. Depuis des années. Tout est restauré.N'oubliez pas au 1er étage de lever les yeux pour voir la loge du roi.

The one must see of Paris!. This was downright jaw dropping amazing! Words can describe it! I only wish I could have been on a tour where I was the only person there!! Crowds were the only negative. We originally got in line for this tour on a Saturday about 45 minutes before close. Turns out the line shuts down 30 minutes before close. Oh well, not a huge loss of time and the line was moving rapidly. The next morning we went and there was no line and somehow we were given free passes! So bonus! It does not allow for those that have the Museum pass to cut in line- just in case those folks were interested. (We did not opt for the museum pass as even though there were long lines for attractions, everything actually moved very quickly.)

A wow experience. Worth a visit....was not overly crowded and enough time to stop and LOOK UP...the stained glass windows really do provide the wow factor. Concerts held here are truly amazing and worth going to ....advertised outside.
another must-do. Try to go on a sunny day if you can; the windows are absolutely amazing! It doesn't take a lot of time and its very close to Notre Dame.
Wow!. The Sainte Chapelle is a sight to behold and will take your breath away. Try going around noon when the line to get in isn't as long!

WOW. This was our favorite site in all of Paris...It's only a few blocks away from Norte Dame but it's just stunning inside...while Norte Dame is Ominous and huge this is beautiful...it's was partly cloudy on our day...I can't fathom how it would look on a sunny day. from left to right facing the alter each section of stained glass features a book of the bible Genesis to Revelation's with the Passion just above the Alter. The fact that buildings like this could be built in basically what we call the "dark ages" is astonishing.

Concert venue. We booked tickets for a Christmas Ave Maria et Noel concert on the Friday evening. We enjoyed the performance from the string quartet with Bertrand Cervera and the mezzo-soprano Ghislaine Roux. However, we found the system for getting into the building to be chaotic and the chapel was freezing cold.

As good as Notre Dame. This church gets overlooked because it sits so close to Notre Dame but it has the most incredible stain glass windows. Research it before you go so you can learn about the intricate patterns and story lines of the windows

Beautiful - go to a concert at night.. Each time that I bring groups of women to Paris, we attend a concert in this stellar chapel. With the evening lights shining through the windows and the glorious music, it is one of the most memorable parts of our tour.

Worth the price. Sainte Chapelle is very close to Notre Dame but I think its not very well advertised or visible unless you know where to go. It is a beautiful building and a must see for me. Its not free and there were no ques (unlike Notre Dame). The stain glass windows are ceiling high and most are still original! all the stain glass windows tell a story or an event. Do pick up one of the information slates available next to the stairs when you enter. Its amazing to see the intricate details on those stain glass windows. The ticket price was I think around 10 Eurs. It definitely well-worth the price.

Short Visit but Spectacular. There isn't a ton to see, but the second floor is worth the wait and the walk. Like many of the museum attractions, a useful peace of advice is to but a museum pass (which can be bought at CDG). The first floor of Sainte-Chapelle is worthy, but don't miss walking up the stairs to the stained glass chapel. This latter chapel is spectacular and the highlight of the visit. The stairs are just to the left of the entrance, and they could be easily missed.

Vivaldi Concert at Sante-Chapelle. The evening concert was an incredible treat in this historic setting. There's no heating so if you go in winter dress as if an outdoor concert, also you miss the beautiful stainglass windows. Regardless, it was magnificant!

The most Beautiful Chapel. Sainte Chapelle is walking distance from Notre Dame but can be easily missed which is a great shame as it is the most beautiful building we have had the opportunity to visit.Built almost a 1000 years ago the stain glass windows are ceiling high and 75% are original! An amazing building, to think that for almost a thousand years people have sat and enjoyed seeing the sunlight streaming through the coloured glass. Also there are concerts on some evenings, well worth the ticket price.
A concert at Sainte Chapelle. Excellent evening in one of the more highly rated areas of Paris. Good activity for anyone visiting Paris.

Magical. On a rainy day, it's stunning. On a sunny day it's staggeringly beautiful. Arrive early. Endure the poorly set up security checks. Ignore the crowds. Appreciate the architecture inside and out. Worth it.

Beautiful 13th-century medieval royal Gothic chapel. The Sainte-Chapelle contains one of the largest 13th-century stained glass collections in the world. The upper chapel also contains finely sculptured statues of the twelve apostles. Descriptive hardback guides in over ten languages are available for borrowing while observing. The lower chapel contains a statue of the Virgin Mary among other items. Great place to visit if one is interested in such things. Otherwise, it may be of some historical interest.

One of the most beautiful sites on earth, but sullied by massive tourism. Whenever I am in Paris I try to visit the Saint Chapelle, which I first visited in 1959 and to which I wish to visit on every trip to or through Paris since. I emphasize "try" because most days in the past few years the tourist lines have become enormous and I will not suffer it. These are two intimate chapels, one romanesque and the other gothic, stacked on one another, each with its fantastic stained glass. If you could be there nearly alone (as I have experienced) or with people who respect it, it is moving. If you are there with a gazillion tourists snapping photos with a flash that will not give them a good photo in that grand space then you will not have a good experience.

Music to warm the ears. Caught a night concert performance here on the coldest wettest night of our trip to Paris. We heard a fantastic mix of violin led by David Braccini bundled up in full coat, scarves, and gloves. The venue was gorgeous with the stained glass lit subtly from outside. Just remember there is no central heating and you'll enjoy your night.

Beautiful concerts. My friends love being taken here at night to listen to the moving musical experience. It's quite dramatic to be sitting in that Chapel, and looking at the stained glass and hearing those wonderful musicians. Go in the summer if possible to take advantage of the sunlight streaming in the windows.

Beautiful Chapel in Paris. This beautiful chapel has amazing history. The stained glass windows each tell the story of a book of the Bible. I was amazed at the artwork that went into making these beautiful windows. It was a wonderful place to stand in amazement and reflect on the artwork of artists from the past.

Very Beautiful. The first floor is very nice, but the second floor is really beautiful. There is a narrow stairway leading up to the second floor, so it's easy to miss. Another stairway leads one down.
Amazing!. I had never heard of this, but it was jaw-droppingly amazing. I have never seen so much stained glass! Really worth a visit - so glad I queued in the rain to see this, absolutely worth it.
Nothing special. Pretty room with huge detailed stain glass windows.. But that's all. Worth seeing if you get a joint ticket with the Conciergerie but not otherwise.
THE paradigm for stained glass. One of the world's greatest gothic cathedrals and one that has arguably the best and most extensive stained glass collections anywhere. It is truly breathtaking.

The stained glass it is wonderful in this church. The stained glass it is wonderful in this church. The localization is in the Justice Palace. Simples tourist spot, but is cool for meet and visit. I recommend if you have more time.

Minutely detailed stained glasses worthy of admission!. Before you skip Sainte Chapelle because it's probably Paris's only church that requires paid admission, read on, because you do not want to miss perhaps one of the most impressive churches you will ever see!With a small modest exterior that especially pales in comparison to the nearby Notre Dame Cathedral, Sainte Chapelle - French for "Holy Shrine" - was constructed by Louis IX (Now one of France's two top saints with Joan of Arc) to house the holy relics such as a piece of True Cross. Although the relics moved to the Notre Dame's treasury, the chapel still retained the very beauty that the French king deemed worthy to hold Christianity's most sacred items.Sure, by photo, Sainte Chapelle looks like just another church with stained glass windows, but look more carefully. While other churches' stained glass tend to be geometric or single-scene on a macro scale, Sainte Chapelle's take it to a much more meticulous level. Each of the fourteen windows tells a chapter in the Bible with all fourteen windows holds 1113 near-microscopic scene! The most impressive is the circular Rose Window that has even more minute details to illustrate the Apocalypse of St John.Combined with the beautiful blue ceiling dotted with golden stars and the twelve apostles that stood watch at every pillar, Sainte Chapelle is certainly a sight that you do not want to miss! Take about an hour to take in the beauty within. €9 is truly nothing compared to the feast for your eye that Sainte Chapelle has to offer.---tl;dr version:1) Holy Chapel designed to hold True Cross and other relics2) Impressive minutely detailed stained glass windows

The most breathtaking stained glass around. Visited here in November immediately after Notre Dame and it held up! Be careful not to get stuck in line for the courthouse next door ... we assumed there was a line and wasted 10 minutes waiting there. There was no wait for Sainte Chapelle. It is smallish but breathtakingly beautiful with stained glass floor to ceiling and almost 360 degrees. It was gorgeous. Don't miss it.

Awe Inspiring Stained Glass. Go on a sunny day to appreciate the towering stain glass windows and if you have time, return for an evening concert - amazing acoustics (skip the VIP ticket - the champagne is just a coupon for the bistro across the street)

Amazing stained glass!. Not too far from Notre Dame is the small Sainte Chapelle. Built in the 13th century, it has amazing stained glass windows! It is definitely worth visiting! Unfortunately, we waited in line longer than it took us to visit the chapel itself!
Must see on île de la cité. Incredible stained glasses and architecture. Unbelievable construction. Show up early, you won't be alone.

Spectacular!. I've been fortunate to visit Sainte-Chapelle three time. Once to visit the church and twice to attend concerts in the evening! The ecustics are magnificent. The concerts lovely! The church itself is breath taking, on a sunny day the stained glass brilliant! A must see if visiting Paris.

Spectacular. Truly a spectacular church. Worth a visit. Read up on Sainte-Chapelle history before you arrive to get a bit more out of your experience. They do provide cards in many languages to translate the stories depicted on the stain-glass.

Expensive!. Expensive since the chapel actually quite small and but the stained glass do look magnificent. Each stained glass tell a story corresponding to the bible. So please do take your time and enjoy the stained glass.

A very special spot. This magnificent, very small chapel is simply gorgeous. The stained glass windows is exceptional. It rivals Notre Dame's famous stained glass but I prefer it here at Sainte-Chapelle. The intimate size makes the sun streaming through the glass more exquisite. It's a graceful space. The wood, instead of stone, parts of the interior edifice is interesting. It's simply a lovely place to stop. I've gone to a few classical chamber music recitals here. They are a very nice way to spend an hour or two during the early evening. Sitting in this impossibly beautiful chapel, precious in size, listening and watching young musicians play (admittedly the program is always a "greatest hits" type affair like Vivaldi or Bach) is really another special aspect of a trip to Paris

Breathtaking. A chapel made for a king that truly shows the magnificence of stained glass. You need to stop and really look at the patterns in the glass and the richness of colors, a must see in Paris.

Unbelievably Beautiful!. You're surrounded by floor to ceiling stained glass panels dating from the 13th century. Try to go when the sun is shining to get the full effect. I wanted to video and had my camera attached to a monopod. A guard insisted that the monopod was not allowed, but would not explain why. This spoiled what otherwise would have been a perfect experience.

Medieval gem. My family spent an inspired hour in this jewel of a chapel. My art history class raved about the stained glass windows, and amazing gothic architecture - offering extraordinary luminescence.

So freaking terrible about queue organizing. Tip : For the one who use Paris Museum Pass please skip this place. I was waiting more than 2 hours, it's so freaking horrible.If you wanna visit here, you have to buy direct ticket especially for this place, and officer will be let you in suddenly.Architecture, and interior design were really great but im not impressive with queue organizing
Gorgeous on a sunny day. The stained glass windows are one of the most beautiful things in the world with the sun shining through. And even at night it has wonderful acoustics for concerts at night.
Stained Glass Wonder. Dragged here by my daughter under protest, I quickly apologized to her being a dunderhead. This place is awesome, lots of beauty and history. Highly recommend it

Simply beautiful. A simply stunning example of a beautiful very historically significant building - Other reviewers have suggested that the optimum time to visit would be when the sun is shining, however,McHenry you have limited time in this fantastic city - it is well worth the visit even on an overcast day the building and the stained glass windows are simply stunning !Recommended.

OH MY GOODNESS. I'm sure you've had that experience in your life where you just get chills the moment you see or hear something that just enters your bones somehow....that is how this place affected me. I have never seen anything like this and I don't know that anything comparable exists in the world. This is a MUST SEE.

Sublime - but there are problems .... This is a gem of Gothic art and architecture - not just my opinion, although I started what passed for my adult live in medieval studies. The chapel is laid out on two levels - the lower chapel, designed for use by the servants and courtiers of Saint Louis, the upper chapel the personal chapel of the King and his family. The lower chapel is low-ceilinged, and decorated with heraldic motifs of France and Castile (the country of the Queen Mother). The upper chapel (reached by means of narrow spiral staircases designed to allow servants access) is a soaring space dominated by stained glass windows supported by improbably slim stone dividers. The windows relate the main events of the Old and New Testaments. Below the windows, the France/Castile heraldic motif from the lower chapel is continued, supplemented by (sadly decayed) portrayals of Christian martyrs - the chapel was built by Saint Louis to house a first-class relic of Christ's Crown of Thorns. My most recent visit was last October (2015); I have been here six times before. Sublime, sublime, especially since the completion of recent restoration programme.There are, however, a number of "issues" -Standing in Line (Queuing): Long queues to be expected, especially in high tourist season. One reason - not sure that this is official policy, but the small size of the Sainte Chapelle makes it less than suitable for the sort of armies of visitors perpetually circulating in neighboring Cathedral of Notre Dame. Less justifiable is the very French talent for over-manning - trio of ticket issue and clearance "officials" is clearly unnecessary, and slows matters up even more than necessary (we queued for about 45 minutes in October, at a less than peak time). Related to this is ...Security: Delays in getting through the security check point at the entrance to the complex add significantly to the overall delay in the "Line" (dividing it - usually, I suspect, into two lines). This is very irritating but, I suspect, there is not much that can be done about it. Worth bearing in mind that the Sainte Chapelle is in the same security zone as the Superior Law Courts of Paris, not to mention the Préfecture de Police. When I was there in October, there was only one (admittedly slightly clunky) security checkpoint, manned by the Gendarmerie). May be different after recent unfortunate events. I can only say that it would be hard to expect the authorities to operate on a lower level of security in these painful times. Then there is ...Charmless staff - I do not generally seem to have as much problems with Parisian "rudeness" than most visitors. Perhaps because I have become used to it over the years. Nonetheless, I have to say that the crowd at the Sainte-Chapelle are a particularly charmless lot. It is hard to excuse this, really; the only thing I can suggest in their favor is they have a lot to put up with at times, the curatorial staff in particular. A very small number of such staff are required to supervise the behavior of a large number of visitors, some of whom themselves can be rude and careless of the need to behave themselves as adults. For example - on my most recent visit, a distinctly hen-pecked American husband decided he needed to tie a shoelace with his muddy boot supported by a chair. I can hardly blame the American for being distracted by his "hen" - but neither can I blame the (sole) curator in the upper chapel from being rather firm (not rude) in insisting that he desist. By the way - it is not, NOT a Good Idea to get into any form of confrontation with French security forces, whether Agents de Police (the ordinary Paris Police Force), Géndarmerie Nationale, CRS, Army ... whatever. Not that I have ever done it myself but ... trust me.Toilets - a matter raised in some of the negative reviews In Here. What can I say ? This should not be an issue, were it not for the fact that the lines/queues are so long, as far as ordinary visits are concerned. As far as concerts go - I have attended concerts here (including one magical one, on my honeymoon, thirty years ago) and I have not had this problem. Hint - the area around is not short of bars and cafés. Take precautions. The authorities are not likely to install convenient loos in the immediate vicinity of the Sainte-Chapelle soon (the medieval buildings are not terribly ... convenient for modern conveniences) and, while there are toilets in the surrounding official buildings, the question of security comes back into question there.The Light: In the Hands of God. No amount of floodlighting will compensate for the fact that the stained glass windows were designed to be seen, at their best, in strong to moderate natural light. If you are frustrated in your wish to take photographs, aim to visit at a time of reasonable light, and perhaps pray. And be reasonable. The unfortunate hen-pecked Yank to whom I referred above was being particularly "pecked" because his wife was not happy that the prevailing light was strong enough for her to take photos, even though it was actually quite strong. The Middle Ages were what they were ...Cost: Yes, it is expensive. This is the French model of financial support for national monuments and museums. One could make the same point about the Louvre, the Museé d'Orsay, the Musee Guimet, the Museé de l'Armee ... Can't say I approve of it, but there it is. What I can say about this case, at least, is that it is for the experience of seeing a truly world class example of Gothic architecture and art. Hence my recommendation.Conclusion: Lines/queues are likely to be a problem at any time of year. Try to come early, and be flexible. The areas of Ile de la Cité, Ile de Saint-Louis and the adjacent Left Bank are beautiful. If the line at the Saint-Chapelle seem a bit long - veer off, and explore ... Come back at another time. And, always remember, Paris has many charms ... Best regards, JR.
Expensive but gorgeous. The ticket is very expensive (8,50€), it's a lot because the chapel is very small, yet overwhelming, most of all the second floor. It's worth a visit.

Most beautiful glass . The entrance was free (any European under 25 with ID), however the line was ultra long even though we arrived early, for a very short visit. From the outside it seems pretty big but it's actually small the space you see. The glass is in fact very beautiful(upstairs) and you can take awesome pictures! There are a few guides around in many languages that you can read and learn more about the how the glass is made. As well as interactive screens to go back in time and look at the building when it was first built. Some shopping for gifts can be done too.

Worth the visit. Go here when the lines are short and there are clear skies. The sun radiates beautifully through the stained glass in the chapel and that's the reason to see this. The stained glass is stunning.

Go when sunny, or not at all. The entrance fee (5.60 Eur) seems awfully steep for such a short visit. I guess we are paying for the restoration being done currently. We went at the end of the day and the stained glass was not that impressive due to the low natural light. I would not recommend this based on my experience.
Gem well worth a visit. This should be high up any list of must see sights in Paris. It doesn't need long but is an exceptional building - we all said "wow" when we got up to the upper level.

Stained glass. This building is beautiful overall, but the truly impressive part for me was the stained glass. I cannot even express how beautiful and detailed it was. Probably some of the best stained glass work I've ever seen!

Literally breathtaking. I hate to repeat what others have said, but the sight of this chapel is quite literally breathtaking. It's such a quiet, little gem in the heart of this bustling city. Quite honestly, it's so small and unassuming, we couldn't find it at first! When we finally did locate it, we were able to walk right in and skip the ticket queue thanks to our Museum Passes! Upon stepping into the lobby, we were a little underwhelmed. Don't get me wrong, the architecture is beautiful, but it was also where the gift shop was housed. My daughter looked at me and said, "Is that it?" I was convinced it wasn't, since I'd seen photos of the inside of Sainte-Chapelle and knew of the exquisite stained glass. So I poked around a bit, and there, tucked almost behind the gift shop counter was a small sign that read "Haute Chapel" next to a dimly lit stairwell. We climbed up the small spiral staircase to what is the main chapel, and comprises all those gorgeous photos you see online, and were just in awe. My daughter actually gasped when we approached the top of the staircase! There, you are surrounded by the most stunning, jaw-dropping, detailed stained glass I've ever seen. Photos don't do it justice. You simply must make a promise to see it yourself in person. Our visit here ended up being our favorite of the entire trip in Paris!
Breathtaking. A tiny, perfect jewel of a chapel, flooded with light from stunning stained glass windows made possible by very thin supporting masonry columns.

Another Exquisite Paris Church. This exquisite Gothic Church facing the Place du Louvre and the Louvre has exquisite mainly original stain glass windows and a wonderful atmosphere - a wonderful tourist site for those interested in examples of Paris churches.

Heavenly. A must visit in my book. The cathedral is magnificent with a surround of stained glass that it unparalleled. If you are able, try to attend one of the chamber concerts that are held here. We saw Vivaldi's 4 seasons performed and it was simply on e of the most beautiful experiences we have ever had.

The windows are the main thing. The church itself is not that interesting but the windows with stories from the bible are huge and beautiful.There might be a lot of people inside so be there early to avoid the peak hours. Inside there are some information about all the different windows that you can borrow.

Travel back in time. The fact that this structure has stood since the mid-13th century brings a sense of awe, regardless that it is a church. We went to see the stained glass and were not disappointed. It's mesmerizing. The detail of each piece of glass is gorgeous and each tell a story corresponding to the bible. Really beautiful. Not a fan of the extensive gift shop in the church which is crass.
Artistic place. Huge and artistic murals.... A place very close to Notre Dame... So can be covered along with Notre Dame on the same day.... The tickets are a bit costly... But worth it....

Perfection!. This gem, hidden in the Justice Palace, is surely one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen in my life.It's an ethereal atmosphere that I'll never forget.There's a line at the door, and airport-like security, and then you can buy your tickets, but it's really fast. Once inside, look the first floor and take a deep breath before going to the second: you will lose it.
Da Vinci Code church. This was an amazing church to see for us. We have retraced the steps of both Da Vinci code movies and this was exactly as we saw it in the movei

Another Great European Church. While Sainte Chapelle is worth the trip, it is after all, just another church. After you have seen many churches they start to look the same. It is beautiful inside, but not as dramatic has Notre Dame. Your museum pass will get you in quicker than waiting to buy tickets.

On reflection would give this a miss in fact orpf notre dame and other paid attractions. €26 for my wife and I to enter this attraction next door to the free Notre dame cathedral. On reflection I'd have given ts one a miss and gone to the justice building for free, walked around saint German a little longer and enjoyed another course for lunch

Magnificent church was with some of the most beautiful, spectacular stain glass windows. We were in Paris at the time of the terrorist attack. Everything was closed for 3 days, but luckily when we went to St. Chapelle it was open. There was a line when it opened, but when we returned an hour later there was no line and we used our Paris Museum pass to get in. Interesting first floor with some stained glass, but the climb of 35 steps up an old winding staircase takes you into an a magnificent area that has stained glass windows about 20 feet high going completely around the top floor of the church. These tell the story of the Bible. A sight not to be missed if you are in Paris.
Absolutely Stunning.. This is a sight to be seen! I have never seen such a beautiful church, as you walk through you see even more beautiful sights. Glorious
Spectacularly stunning . I've seen quite a few churches but this is an absolute standout when it comes to stained glass windows. The colours are vibrant and I recommend this as a must see in Paris

Most Beautiful Church in Paris. I have never seen so many stained glass windows in a church. They have just restored a lot of them and they are spectacular! This is definitely the most beautiful church in Paris. The other ones are spectacular on the outside but surprisingly boring when you walk inside. The crown of thorn is stored here so don't forget to take a snapshot of it. You can't really see the crown itself, but you can take a picture of the case where it is housed in.

Beautiful stained glass windows. Located on the Ile de La Cite near the Cite metro. Well worth going for the windows, especially those upstairs. We stood in the queue on the Sainte Chapelle not the Palais de Justice and it was very quick to get in.

not the same as the other churches / cathedrals. I have seen quite a few churches and cathedrals over the years and they have begun to bore me a bit - same motifs are presented over and over again and in most cases with a quite similar techniques therefore I wasn't really sure what to expect from Sainte-Chapelle. It was a pleasant surprise. From the moment you enter the main chamber you fell a difference - you entered into extremely tall but rather small room. Main attraction are huge tall painted windows through which sunlight interestingly reflects various colors / parts. In addition, french royal sign is commonly embedded throughout the building giving it a charm I haven’t experience for quite some time in churches/cathedrals..

Just amazing. We were dodging a shower and near Isle de la Citi when my wife suggested that we might be able to duck into the Conciergerie, the oldest remaining part of the Palais de la Cité, the first royal palace in the French capital that was used as a prison during the French Revolution. The added bonus being that you could buy a combined ticket for it and Sainte Chapelle next door.I never would have waited through the line to get into Sainte Chapelle, but with our tickets in hand we wandered past the snaking line and sauntered into the building. We overcame an initial underwhelming when we realised that we had to find a stairway in the corner that let up a winding staircase to the chapel. Now I have read quite a few reviews and spoken to people who had visited this chapel and I can tell you that not all visits are created equal. Luckily the shower we were dodging had gone on its way. It was mid September and late afternoon. When we entered the chapel the North side of windows was completely lit and quite spectacular. The sunlight was probably too bright if anything. The South side was completely dark. It didn't even look like windows - it looked like it was broken. Luckily we were impressed enough with what we could see to hang around. After a while we noticed that there was a bit of light coming through the south side and fpr the next half hour we were transfixed. As the sun moved further to the west and lowered in the sky the south side became brighter and brighter while the north side lost the slightly washed out look it had from too much sun and the coulours actually became stronger. After a half hour or so the light was even across the whole expanse of the windows and it was just mesmerizing.
Beautiful stained glass windows. Small but gorgeous!! The amount of detail that went into these windows is incredible. You can get great pictures here, if that's what you're into!
Beautiful!. I highly recommend this beautiful, historic Catholic church. The stained glass windows are remarkable!
Windows!. Beautiful jewel! Worth a little wait in line! The downstairs chapel, for the commoners, was gorgeous too!

Unbelievable . Beautiful stained glass from 12th century. Over 70% is original. Upper and lower churches here with crazy winding stairwell connection. Note there is an elevator from a connecting building if you have trouble with stairs. Just ask the security guards

Amazing Gem. It's a small cathedral with huge impact and some of the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. It won't take you much time and worth the stop with the combo ticket with the Concergerie.

Stunning stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle was not something I knew much about prior to my trip to Paris, but I'm very happy that I decided to go. The small chapel had magnificent, vibrant stained glass windows all around. Each piece was unique - all the windows were done in a different style and had distinct pattern and overall look. All of the windows told a different bible story and if you look closely, you can "read" them from bottom to top. It did not disappoint and I would recommend it to any stained glass lover.

Dark Mysterious Private. This takes a bit more effort to see than Montmartre or Notre-Dame and once inside it is a bit dark and crowded and there is sort of a sense of pressure not to stay too long. I love how old and secretive it is -- the king's private church! -- and really like the wallpaper motif and such.
