Add to your visit if you are in Paris for 6 or 7 days or longer or if this is your second or third trip. Would not advise as a must see if you are taking a short trip or anything.
Ste Chapelle. What a Gothic wonder! Sunny day and the stained glass windows sparkled. Notre Dame and Ste. Chapelle make perfect companion visits.
amazing little place. impressive stained glass - better than Notre Dame actually. Difficult to find the way in but that may have been due to the extra security

Bring your opera glasses. At the opposite end of the island, from Notre Dame, Saint Chapelle greets your with a richness of the color and patterns on the walls and ceilings matched by the intricacies of gothic architecture, surpassed by the stunning windows found on the upper floor of the church. The stories in the glass are are quite detailed, hence the recommendation for monocular or binoculars. In a city with no end to impressive sites, Saint Chapelle ranks right at the top for me.

Utterly Amazing. Must go see Vivaldi's Four Seasons here (I am sure other concerts are equally good but I saw this one) The acoustics are splendid and the light streaming through the stained glass is magical! Buy tickets in advance and prepare to be amazed!

A must visit to this beautiful cathedral. After visiting Notre Dame a 5 minute walk from there we found Sainte Chapelle. And what a find it turned out to be. The glass stained windows are massive and stunning to look at. Small cost to go in.

Awe inspiring . We wanted to walk Ile de citie and happened upon the Conciergie and when asked if we wanted to see both Conciergie and Sainte Chapelle, we figured why not?! Great choice. The Conciergie showed the types of cells prisoners (including Marie Antoinette) were held in. It also has huge gothic arches at thee try. Then on to Sainte Chapelle, a gorgeous 1200's chapel with awe inspiring stained glass! Hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of them! And one giant rosette like Notre Dame. There are tiny spiral staircases, one up and another for down. Then you exit outside the Palais de Justice. You will be asked to go through metal detectors and open your bags for inspection.

Beautiful but not worth the wait.. Pretty much all you see here is what the picture shows...the windows. It's small with nothing much to it. The outside is pretty when you look up. Inside, you can spend 5 minutes. I waited in line for an hour and was out of there in 5 minutes. Aside from the windows you see in the picture, which are lovely, there's nothing else to look at. Unless I missed something entirely! But if that's the case, they would need more signs and directions or information posted. I just thought it was uneventful and not the experience of Notre Dame or Sacre-Coeur. I wish there was more info given, or a tour. For the cost...I didn't feel it was worth waiting in line.

Soaring elegance that is hard to match. Nothing on the outside of this hidden gem gives a hint of the awesome color-filled chapel inside. Enter on the lower level to a dimly lit space. Ascend the spiral stairs to one of the most amazing examples of biblical stories in colored glass. Depending on the amount and location of the sun, the colors take on varying depths of intensity. When in Paris, I never miss the chance to revisit this awesome place. A wonder to be sure.

Amazing Church, Amazing Concert. We arrived in Paris embracing rain, Paris is even more charming with the rain. We went to St. Chapelle for the classic concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. In a romantic city like Paris, in a classic church like this, to listen to the most beautiful piece of masterwork by Vivaldi, I could not ask more.We have to come back other day when the sun will be shining through the stained windows, the most spectacular view.

GO!!!. Make time to stop here! Its close to the Notre Dame Cathedral so enjoy both spots in an afternoon. As far as we knew there were no advance ticket sales so everyone had to stand in line. The line looked long, but only took us about 10 minutes to get through. The stained glass is absolutely beautiful!!!! You will compare every other piece of glass to this afterward, and it will not even come close to comparing! This is a quick stop and I'd suggest going when the sun is shining to experience the full effect of the beautiful windows. Go go go!

A Medieval Splendor in the Heart of Paris. The Sainte-Chapelle is a medieval gem in the very heart of Paris. Located on Ile de La Cité, on the same island Notre Dame Cathedral is, it is within the Palais de Justice, the courthouse complex. Commissioned by Louis IX construction began in 1239 and was completed by 1248. Lines can be long as one has to go through security before entering the complex but even then well worth the wait. I highly recommend it!

Make sure to go at 3 p.m. in fall (November). Great chapel, but you need to go when the sun is shining to really appreciate the story telling of the stained glass. Unbelievable that kings were seated in this chapel. Very small but what a biblical story is told by stained class... about 15 windows of story telling.. cost ~ 8.50 euro.. many classical concerts at 8 p.m. ... very close to Notre dame (within minutes and worth seeing both!) Lovely square north of chapel.. well hidden...

Breathtakingly Beautiful. The stain glass windows are some of the most beautiful that I have ever seen. Take the time to visit. We bought a museum pass which can be used to expedite entry into other attractions and will save you money.

Lovely 13th Century Church-- Amazing stained glass!. This little gem is a must see. The walls are filled with stained glass, and it is just beautiful. This is in the heart of Paris, in Ile de la Cite. The stained glass is from the 13th century! This was built to house Louis IX collection of relics of Christ. Don't miss seeing this!

Take in a concert. we attended a concert, Vivaldi's Four Seasons, in this breathtaking Gothic chapel, the light was streaming in through the stunning stained glass windows. the violinist were spectacular and the acoustics in the church were outstanding. a wonderful experience. If you attend an evening concert you can avoid the lines to view the church during the day.

Breathtaking . Included with the Paris Museum Pass don't miss the stained glass in this former church. The line is not that bad and totally worth it. The first floor where commoners worshiped has interesting nooks and a small gift shop. Then you can go up to the king's entrance to see the glass.
Another beautiful Cathedral. Wow the stained glass is so intricate. The narrow arches are beautiful and the serene atmosphere is welcoming.
Old. They started building it almost 900 years ago. It's still looking good. Marvel at the size, the height, the volumes.

The most beautiful windows you will ever see in a church. I strongly suggest to visit it. There is a big queue in the weekends so avoid (if you can) going there during weekends and especially Sunday. Sit down in one of the chairs and appreciate the beauty of the windows. They have so much detail and they "tell" the whole story of our religion starting from genesis. I spend lovely time, trying to understand what each part of the windows means. So many colours around you. There are also concerts being held here during some evenings. Ask for information.
Exceptional!. An historic an incredibly stunning work of architecture. Unbelievable stained glass windows. A must see.

The evening concert is a must for someone looking for something a bit different!. I came across this concert whilst looking for 'Events in Paris' and 'Unusual things to do in Paris'. I noticed that once wandering the area around Notre Dame and the surroundings that there were a number of leaflets/flyers for various evening concerts however didn't see anything in regards to St.Chapelle.This probably added to the experience as it was certainly not a tourist attraction compared to the usual sites of Paris.The 'getting in' was a bit frustrating as, given that there was not allocated seating, a number of people arrived early (as recommended) only to be greeted by a queue, then a second queue for security and then a third queue for entrance to the concert itself. However, once inside, it was magnificent. The concert itself (speaking from someone who is not particularly familiar with classical music) consisted of complete darkness other than the lights around the quartet and accompanying pianist and the natural light (whatever was left of it) coming through the stained glass windows.The highlight however was the music, Vivaldi's Four Seasons with a twist is the only way I can describe it. The musicians were incredibly interactive with the audience, at one point stopping to discuss (albeit in French so my understanding was limited) the individual components from each instrument.It was arguably the highlight of this and all other trips I've made to Paris and I would highly recommend.
Amazing!!! Do not miss!. Amazing chappel, full of vitrals!Unespected good surprise, completely different than everything that I visit before.Do not miss the opportunity to visit it!

Music nights. I would definitely advise going there for a night of classical music. I was listening to Vivaldi's Four Seasons and was impressed by the ambiance of the venue and brilliant performance of the musicians. The tickets can be purchased in the Tabac shop across and the starting price is 25.00 euro per ticket. Come early to get in the venue first.

Magnificent. One of Paris' treasures. Beautiful historic and solemn building. The stained glass windows are unbelievable as are other features from the times it was used. Do not miss taking a look at the tiles on the floors.

Beautiful. You must take the time to visit this beautiful church. There is usually a queue but it goes quite quickly. When you get inside, its rather lovely but a little bit of a non event! THEN you go upstairs and I can honestly say this place then takes your breath away. I have never experienced stained glass windows like it, each telling a story. There are sheets available to help you follow the story. Even if you are not religious you will appreciate this beautiful place.

Most Beautiful Stain glass windows, Sainte Chapelle. This chapel has the most beautiful stain glass windows in the world, I believe. It isa must see when you first get to the City of Paris. With in walking distance of all the great areas to visit!.
Great, but not worth the 9 euro entry fee. In there for around 10 minutes as it is small! It is beautiful in the top floor and the queue is normally huge

Walls of stained glass were amazing!. It was more than we had expected to see. We didn't realize how tall the stained glass windows were or that they pretty much were the walls of the church. Bright sunshine filtered through and we were able to take exquisite pictures.

Don't miss this hidden gem. Stopped here as part of our Rick Steves audio Paris walk tour. Our museum pass got us in here, but unfortunately we did have to wait in a line which our museum pass helped us avoid in other areas. Chapels is amazing and the amount of stain glass you will see is very different from other Churches.
Beautiful. Beautiful inside. Definitely worth a visit. The stained glass windows are amazing. Beautiful location close to Norte Dame.

Lives up to expectations. Probably my favorite spot in all of Paris...if not Europe. The glass literally appears to be floating in the air. it is not as grand as Notre Dame, but when you walk into the chapel from the little wooden staircase, the experience is pretty awesome.
Gorgeous!. This chapel/church/palace has so much intricate stained glass that was so pretty. Worth the trip through, wont take long at all

Do not miss!!. This is a must do location, the stain glass absolutely breath taking. The room is large and there will be a lot of visitors BUT - so worth the visit. Sit and just enjoy for a bit, it has a very spiritual feeling. We were there on a cloudy day, I have been in the past on a sunny day - both are just fine. Lines moved quick and were not a problem.

Breathtaking Chapel. There was a line of about 30-40 people when we arrived. I was afraid that the line would extend into the courtyard that you have to go thru before entering the chapel. But once we got thru the initial line and security we were able to walk right up to the chapel and enter. There is another line at the chapel entrance to purchase tickets. But we had the museum pass, so could walk right thru. We traveled off season. Lines could be worse at other times. The chapel was very small but absolutely gorgeous. You enter thru the small chapel for palace staff on the ground level. This space was very pretty with a lovely blue ceiling. In this space there is also a small gift shop. You climb a small staircase to get to the main chapel above (I don't know if there is an accessible option for those who cannot navigate the steps) and what else can you say but "breathtaking"? We were fortunate to be there on a sunny day so most of the glass was illuminated. Do try to go on a sunny day near the middle of the day so that the sun will be shining thru the glass. The buildings around the chapel could block the sun very early or late in the day so around mid-day is probably best. It doesn't take long to see the site, but it is well worth going. There are information sheets in various languages in both chapels.

Stunning!. Be sure to go upstairs! "haute chapelle." That's where the windows are--and they are amazing! Also, be aware of the hours--they close for lunch, and if you are on line, oh well, too bad. We made the most of our time by walking a few blocks over to Notre Dame. The line there moves very quickly. The line at Sainte-Chapelle is much slower. Also, there is an admission fee.

Super long lines. Traveler be aware that this place closes for the lunch hour...so go early morning or after 2:00 p.m.Travelers with museum passes are not allowed to cut the line. There is one line for bag check, with or without a prepaid ticket, it is the same line :(

Best stained glass anywhere!. FIrst, you should be prepared to wait in line to visit -- and a museum pass offers no special line. We stopped fairly early in the day but were put off by the long line, came back later in the afternoon -- still a long line. However, if you have the time to wait, it is well worth a visit to see the most awe inspiring windows! We've visited cathedrals and other churches in Rome, Brussels, Cologne, London . . . these are just the best windows -- and most are the originals from the 13th century. You do need to go to the second floor to see them -- not sure if there is an elevator.
Most beautiful vitraux in. Paris. A small chapel with the most beautiful stained glass. Restoration has just been finished and it looks amazing. Worth a visit.

You need to see to believe. Of course this is a feature of Art 101 but you really have to see it wonder how all that glass holds up the roof, The lower level (for regualr pepople as oppsed to royalty) is beautiful as well.Be advised your Paris Museum Pass does NOT get you to the head of the line at this attracion so be prepared to wait

Paris' first choice. The Sainte Chapelle is a must-see in Paris. Maybe a little unknown, and eclipsed by nearby Notre-Dame Dom, the Sainte Chapelle is a jewel of gothic architecture and glasswork.If you have the chance, visit it in a sunny day so you will see the effect of the color shadows from the right glowing in the left side. Absolutely superb!

Beautiful evening concert. Having planned a daytime visit, for which we had seen the huge queues, we changed and booked to go to an evening concert there on the Saturday.It wasn't cheap but really worth it, seeing the chapel in such a stunning situation of low lighting and sublime music was magical. We saw several versions of Ave Maria by strings and soprano and it was beautiful. We went to the earlier concert of 7pm and there was a later one listed for after- we didn't book until 4pm the same day. Highly recommended!

Some of the oldest painted glass ever.... Quiet and impressive spot located inside the premices of the parisian "upper" court of law.Really worthwhile and a little more intimate than Notre Dame on one of the Parisian central islands
Impressive stain glass!. I feel in love with the beautiful stained glass. Well worth the effort it took to wait in line and get through security.

Lovely old Gothic Cathedral. We were not able to go inside as it was late but we walked by and around it many times. It is located in the Ile de la Cite in the center of Old Paris and is very near the metro .

Stunning!!. What a gorgeous cathedral! My husband and I recently visited Sainte-Chapelle along with the Conciergie which is located next door and less than a minute walk from here. A quick visit to this beautiful building is all you need, but it is well worth a stop. If you buy tickets on line, you can get a two for one deal to both Sainte Chapelle and the Conciergie.
Exceptionally beautiful windows and impressive chapel. Gorgeous chapel. Fascinating windows. Very crowded. Don't forget to take a few pictures that scan the windows as they will be beautiful!
My favorite cathedral in Paris. Breath taking stained glass chapel. The entire room is stained glass windows. When you walk in you are on the lower level. The chapel is on the second floor.
Day and night. Enlarge the experience and take a concert in the evening. Both experiences complement each other. Our fifth visit and we always enjoy SC

My favourite place in Paris. Sainte-Chappelle is jaw-droppingly beautiful -- and that is significant in a city that houses beauty around every corner. The delicate fleur-de-lys and golden castles painted on the lower floor are impressive. When you ascend the tight spiral stairs and walk in to see the stained glass -- breath taking! I have visited more than 6 times - never gets old!!
Wow!!! Must see in Paris!. That's a place to see. Plan three hours to see every window, to understand every story and feel the history.

It's small, but the stained glass is divine. When I visited Paris decades ago with a European friend this is one place he took me. So on my recent trip I wanted to see if it was as wonderful as I remembered. Yes. It is. It is in the same neighborhood as Notre Dame. It is small and they charge a few euros to visit and I stood in a decent sized line on a Sunday morning. But, really, if you are a fan of stained glass, you have to check it out.
Beautiful. Not many small chapels with this level of beauty. The detail is quite incredible and stunning. Get there early to avoid very long queues.
Must see!. A true hidden gem! I only discovered Sainte-Chappelle upon my second visit after hearing about it at the Paris Story (also highly recommend, just behind the Opera)

They don't tell you about the steps. There are a bunch of steps to get up to view the stained glass. I didn't know about it had of time - my legs were sore from climbing Eifel. It is worth the effort to see the incredible Stainglass- especially if you have the museum pass
better than Notre Dame de Paris. Paris' best stained glass windows are seen when there is sunlight shining through the windows. Also offers good acoustics for concerts.
take the time to visit. With so much to see in Paris, I am glad we took the time to visit this gem! The tour is quick but there is so much beauty in this place!

Beautiful!. This is a don't miss location! It is absolutly beautiful. Try to learn about it before you go but if you don't, there is a guide sheet available. It describes what is in all the stained glass windows. It is a nice quiet break from the busy streets.

lovely concert. Went one evening to pre booked classical concert. Musicians very good, even when one of their strings broke, and they had to stop to repair for 5 minutes. Lovely setting and acoustics very good. Stained glass magnificent, returned during the day to see it at its best.
Beautiful but oh so crowded. Lovely but get there early. The crowds can spoil your enjoyment of the experience. Grab a guide to help make sense of the Windows.

Fourth time's the charm and worth the persistence. After attempting to visit this major attraction 3 times before and finding it inexplicably closed, once because it was snow-flurrying, and twice for no apparent reason, we finally got lucky and our persistence paid off. The stained glass was awe inspiring, like none I have ever seen. And to top it all, it turned out to be a free admission because we were there on the first Sunday of the month. Talk about finally getting lucky!

Fantastique. Exceeded my expectation by a country mile. Cant even describe how beautiful this church is. Look at your guidebooks and know that it will far exceed what you thought it might be. Must see
Amazing Windows.. The sheer size of the stained glass windows in this place of worship are truly amazing, they take your breath away.
The Gothic top. Without doubt, maybe is the most beautiful Gothic church in the world. Magic when the sun light pass through the stained glass windows...
Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. The beautiful 50ft tall stained glass windows that surround you and tell the story of the Bible are wonderful to see.

The most beautiful church I have ever seen. Skip the lines at Notre Dame and come see this church! It is a must see! Even on a rainy day, the stained glass is absolutely stunning. One of my most favourite places in Paris.

Beautiful! Quick to visit. No need to plan a ton of time to see this beautiful chappel, but if at all possible take in a sunset performance rather than doing a day visit. The views of the stained glass while listening to a volinist play as the sun sets behind them is spectacular. Seeing it in the daytime doesn't require much time as you will be standing craning your neck to see the details and the line typically moves fairly quickly as the ushers tend to keep people inside moving through. Be very careful what you have in your bag when you go in though! They are very strict about their banned items list. We accidentally tried to bring in a glass bottle and were asked to leave to discard it and come back in line once we had done so. Our fault for not following the rules but save yourself the time!
Gorgeous Colors!. This isn't on the first page of attractions in Paris, but the inside of this place is gorgeous! Full of amazing colors and stained glass beauty. Worth a stop

Vivaldi's Four Seasons. We had the good fortune to read a poster about L' Orchestra Les Violins de France playing Vivaldi's Four Seasons in Sainte-Chapelle . We bought tickets and needless to say seeing this great work performed by a wonderful orchestra in the stunningly beautiful Sainte-Chapelle was a highlight of our trip to Paris. If you do nothing else in Paris in they way of a cultural event make sure you take this concert in. You will not be disappointed.

Mesmorizing Stained glass. If you're coming to Paris, don't forget about this church! I think I sat and stared in the stained glass room for 15 minutes. When the sun is out, the room is enchanting looking and makes you feel as if you're in a fairy tale church. I think I enjoyed visiting Sainte Chapelle more than Notre Dame - so don't miss out on this great find!

San Louis did a Great Thing. Read some history of this stunning edifice before you go. The story certainly enhances the experience. Although I believe the King was duped by a mid-eastern merchant who recognized a customer with more money than sense, this was one of the highlights of my few days in Paris. It was nice to enter a space that didn't totally overwhelm you. So many attractions demand whole days this can be enjoyed fully in 90 minutes. The stained glass is marvelous. many attractions really need a whole day or more

Breathtaking! Do not skip or miss!. Sainte-Chapelle is a stunning chapel made up almost completely of stained glass windows. It has an ethereal air that you will not experience at Notre Dame and it is far smaller and intimate a space. Worth the wait in line to see!

Stained glass beauty!. This is an absolute must-see in Paris. It is a perfect example of a royal medieval chapel in a Gothic style. At least 2/3 of the original stained glass windows from the 13th century some how survived the damage suffered during the French revolution. You may find yourself just staring in awe of the beauty of these windows.

Great stained glass windows.... St. Chapelle has the most colorful stained glass windows in Paris, each window tells a biblical story since the majority of the people could not read. Be sure to get either their audio guide or read their handouts...

Stain-glass lighting not to be missed!. After visiting Notre Dame Cathedral, a good recommendation is to visit Sainte Chapelle. There is usually a long line to get in by mid-day as every bag needs to be placed under the x-ray machine. It is nice to have the Paris Museum pass in hand as it will get you ahead of the long line. There are 2 levels here at Sainte Chapelle with the entrance into the Lower level where the commoners went. The ceiling is decorated in blue with "fleur de lys" all over. A sight to enjoy before heading upstairs to see the stain glass lights! There is a narrow spiral staircase with around 20-30 steps that leads to the upstairs for the view of the sunlight reflection into the stain glass windows that are a story in pictures of the Bible. A sight that is totally unbelievable! There are chairs to sit and enjoy as well as interpretation boards that explain the 15 stain glass panels. It is well-worth the long line wait as well as the climb up the stairs to see it!Restrooms are located outside and are limited to only one for women and one for men--; therefore, an unavoidable long line is there.

Best of Cathedral Stained Glass. Sainte Chapelle was recommended to me by a former Paris resident as the best example of Paris stained glass. It did not disappoint. The church is small, but it is like sitting inside a beautiful jewel box. Breathtaking, and also a reverent view of the Christian story. St. Chapelle is on the island in the Seine, along with Notre Dame. Visit both, but for different experiences, special in their own way.

Breathtaking!. My boyfriend and I visited here on our recent trip to Paris. We had the Paris Museum Pass but it didn't allow us to bypass the queue, which luckily wasn't too long. We we're probably waiting around 30 minutes to get in which we were fine with considering it was a busy Saturday. The first room you enter isn't the only room, rest assured there is definitely more. (I was very confused when I couldn't see the windows everyone had been talking about!) Head through the little doorway on the right and you'll be in the royal chapel. I cannot describe how beautiful this place is, it is incredible. Definitely take some time to sit and look at the windows and get an information card, it'll tell you all about the stories the windows tell. This place is absolutely fantastic and is super close to the Notre Dame so you can do both in a day. MUST SEE!

Evening Concert Treat. This is a wonderful site to see, but our time here was enhanced by taking in the opportunity for an evening concert, would reccomend for the beauty of the music in the cathedral.

Sainte-Chapelle..the chapel of les Royales. This has to be the finest stainglass enclosure ever built. Breathtaking interior! I have been going here since 1995 and it had been under restoration for years...now finished. Truely a masterpiece of medieval architecture...it was built in the 1300s.

Not a pleasant experience.. This church is part of the museum pass so we decided to go. Forget the "skip the line" aspect of the ticket - what a joke. The line we were told to get in for the museum pass was actually longer than the other line. Beware that these outside lines are only for security and have nothing to do about whether or not you have a museum pass. We when earlier in the day and luckily an English speaking group had just come out and told us the security was down so no one was getting in. The employee standing in the front was very rude to them and they were basically told they would have to go to the back of the line when they came back later even though they had already waited in line once. When we came back later people were getting in again. The security check is a conveyer belt type so you have to take off your bags. After the security check you end up in a small courtyard (bathrooms to the left). You walk straight and get in line to either buy tickets or go straight up to the check in if you have the museum pass. It's fairly small inside compared to the number of people that were here. There is a room downstairs then your have to walk up a narrow one way spiral staircase to get to the room with the large windows. When you come down the other side in the other one way narrow spiral staircase you end up back in the same room you started in. I would recommend going in then straight up to the second floor since this is what people think about when they see pictures of this church. I personally would not waste my time going back here.
Beautiful !. This is a must see. It only needs to be a short visit but it's well worth making the time to see the interior.

Stunning.. We visited Sainte-Chapelle first thing in the morning since we knew it'd get quite the line and its not that large. We were able to skip the lines with the museum pass, which was nice and highly recommended. The chapel with floor to ceiling stained glass makes it one of the most beautiful places in Paris. We went to Notre Dame after and this is more beautiful in my opinion. Its really a special, beautiful place. Must do in Paris, especially since it won't take too much of your time!

classical music concerts great here. Been to Paris twice, saw a classical music concert here both times. This is a small chapel, so it only seats 150-200 at most. Any seat is great, but you can pay more for up front. Excellent acoustics, lighting. I've never seen the stained glass in the daytime,but I suspect it would be marvelous.

The most beautiful stained glass ever!. I first went with my girlfriend as a tack on to the Conciergerie and I cannot tell you how we thanked our lucky stars for going here. Also we nearly didn't climb the steps up to the heavenly stained glass. My next visit I made sure to buy special tickets to a night with an ensemble in this glorious place with my sons. God was really there that night.

A not to be missed sight. The number of visitors are less than at Notre Dame although because of its small size, it can be much more crowded. Still, the stained glass is much better than Notre Dame and easier to view. Fi you visit Notre Dame, don't miss Sainte-Chapelle.

Beautiful stained glass. This is a small chapel but is beautiful nonetheless! Queue can be very long even in the morning but worth the wait. Once inside, you will be treated to the most beautiful stained glass. Remember there are two levels in this church. The access to the second level can be quite discrete. Plan your visit just after lunch when the sun is the brightest. That way, you can enjoy the beautiful different hues of the stained glass.

Night Concert is a special romantic night. For a special night we went to a Vivaldi concert (earlier concerts you get the sun setting through the stain glass) The acoustics are fantastic and the quartet put on one of the best concerts we have been to in Europe - A very special memory for Paris

Awesome. I love Sainte Chappelle. It is an incredible beautiful chapel with the most amazing stained glass windows. That's all you really see on first glance when you enter. It is small and intimate and a great place for a concert. Whenever I am in Paris I always try to go to a concert here The music is always first rate, the setting exquisite and the acoustics fantastic

Certainly worth a visit. When we arrived, there was quite a big queue outside but it moved fairly quickly and it didn't take long for us to get in. It's certainly worth a visit having some of the most impressive stain glass windows I have seen.Just to note, we got in using the museum pass but there in no priority entrance. It wasn't a big problem though because the queue didn't take that long.

Amazing architectural gem. This place is worth the wait! The stained glass is the best I've ever seen, and the architecture is amazing, especially considering that it was built in the 13th century! Over 70% of the stained glass is original, which is pretty amazing

early morning visit. got to go there at the opening, around 10 amif you wait too long crowd comes and hard to really appreciate the fantastic glass workspretty expensive, but they give a tourist booklet for free for the kids, nicely doneand booklets for adults in many different languages

Well worth a visit. . Was only 8euros to go in. Well worth going in to have a look at the stain glass windows. It's on two floors. The ground floor was the smaller windows, and then you go upstairs to see the large ones-truly beautiful.
Loved It. So beautiful! Looks totally ordinary until you walk upstairs and see the stunning chapel. It's close to Notre Dame so don't miss this!

Most memorable event of Paris vacation!. Our hotel got us tickets for a Sunday evening concert of Vivaldi and others at the Church of Sainte-Chapelle. Nice to have VIP seats right up front, but it's a small church and all the seats are good. Not sure if it was the glorious setting, the masterful musicianship, or the genius of the composers, but more than once my eyes teared up, and I was in heavenly bliss.
Light, Bright and Lovely. Sainte-Chapelle is amazing for the lightness of the structure. The lass is magical. It bogels the mind how such ancient builders could have achieved this structure.

Lovely, if you can get in. We wanted to see wonderful St Chapelle again but were shocked to find a huge queue, barely moving, outside. This was on a grey November day, goodness knows what it is like in peak season - years ago we just walked in. Clearly you must plan ahead carefully these days or be disappointed, as we were.

Would visit again!. Absolutely stunning and a must see. We went on a Sunday and got in line a half hour before they opened. It worked well since we got to visit the museum with very few other tourists.
A Bit Underwhelming. You've got to admire the 8-century-old towering stained-glass windows, but otherwise this was pretty much a one-trick pony. Something to admire, but probably not to love.

Not just for the beauty. We have attended a number of concerts in this church. The quality of the musicians has always been superb. The acoustics are wonderful and need less to say the setting is breath taking.

The most beautiful stained glass windows!!. The church entry was not accessible by wheelchair, so we were directed to the main entrance in the Ministry of Justice next door. We went thru serious metal detection/ security. This is the French national court. Once we got into the elevator to the main floor, we were assisted by a very nice and helpful staff from the church. He found all of the other elevators we needed, to get to the right level. (Every place requires multiple elevators and extra time to figure it out.)The windows are amazing!!! All in one room, it was gorgeous. It was a gray day but the windows still had light coming through. Really worth seeing the beautiful colors. Amazing that was created in the Middle Ages. There is a lot of information on the particular bible passages each window illustrates. We bypassed the line completely, by having someone in our group in a wheelchair. I could see the line was very long. You might want to come early and allow for some time on line. There's a cafe across the street.

Stained glass like nowhere else!. From the minute you step into this chapel- an amazing example of flamboyant gothic architecture- you will be astounded. The stained glass windows surround you with vibrancy, color and shimmering light. Try to visit on a sunny day- the light on and through the glass is spectacular. The history of the building combined with the beautiful dome ceiling and the stained glass makes this a must see while in Paris. Generally, there are long entrance lines- so here is a tip. Go to the Conciergerie next door and purchase the combined ticket for it and Sainte- Chapelle. Visit the Conciergerie first, then go to St-Chapelle where you will be allowed to skip the line because you purchased this double ticket. The Conciergerie is fascinating and you will be glad you toured it as well.

Classical music concert. We went to the classical music concert one night and it was a great way to see the chapel. Just a pity the sun had already set by the time the concert started as you can't see the stained glass windows anymore. But worth a visit.
Check this out instead of Notre Dame. Much more interesting, and older than its successor to house the crown of thorns. What this church may lack in grand scope it makes up with genuine ambience!
Medieval gorgeousness. Breathtaking stained-glass windows and medieval decoration. Better to visit during daylight when you can see the windows more clearly.

An extraordinary church. This church was built in the 1200's by King (Saint) Louis IX. There are two levels, the upper was reserved for the king and his family. The stained class windows are exceptionally bright and beautiful. It is the largest collection of stained glass windows dating to the 13th century. A must see.

Stunningly beautiful!. This was on my must see list and I'm glad I went. We bought the paris pass, with it we could skip the line.You enter the lower level which is absolutely beautiful! I thought that was it, no you then go upstairs to see the real star of the show. These stained glass windows were amazing, especially when the afternoon sun was shining through the windows. You'll be pleased if you take the time to visit.
Fascinating place.. Well worth a visit. Admission free on first Sunday of the month from November to March which is worth remembering . Early start avoids the queues.
Nice, but not to much to see. To be honest you can see everything in 10 mins. Make sure you have the museum pass. Not worth spending the money
Breathtaking. One of my best memories of Paris is exploring the architecture of Saint-Chapelle. Certainly worth a visit if you are an architectural history lover.

Amazing. I've seen photos, but nothing could prepare me for the amazing beauty of this space. The windows are sublime, try to go on a sunny day. There is so much glass and so little structure, I don't know how it stays up! Highly recommended!

Great Spot For Atmosphere And History. On our trip to Paris we visited Sainte-Chapelle twice. Entrance is included with the Paris Museum Pass. The security line moved rather quickly on one visit and then slowly on the second (both early morning visits). The architecture outside is fantastic and the interior is stunning. The commoners worshipped below and their area is less ornate than the space reserved for the nobility that is on the top floor. You ascend a tight spiral staircase (reminded me of the Blarney Castle except it wasn't wet and slippery) into a massive nave filled with coloured light streaming in through massive stained glass windows. Rick Steves book offers a great little tour of the church and its windows. Oddly the written guides available inside had some of the windows confused. In any event you'll see pictures from the bible and antiquity (Cain and Abel, Moses, Jesus and Holofernes). Louis IX built this church to house the Crown of Thrones relic (now in the treasury at Notre Dame). It was built in record time and cost a fraction of what he paid for the relic.

The highlight of Paris. To me this is the highlight of Paris. You will probably spend longer in line to visit than at the actual site, but it is worth it. The most beautiful room I have ever seen. Will go back every time I am in Paris.
Heaven, simply heaven. Please go here on a sunny day, midday for the best effect. Make sure a guide helps you to appreciate even more what you see. You will not regret it.
Worth it!. The stained glass is amazing! Each large panel tells a story of the book of the bible. Worth a visit.

A must for all Paris visitors. Try to be there when the sun lights the vitreaux.
In the midlle of the city, easy to get there, you don't need a long stay

Amazing - but difficult to be orginal. The work done here is truly amazing - but it's all been said before. We were lucky to be the very first people admitted on the day as the group behind us got stuck. Seeing the chapel empty on a sunny day makes the trip to Paris worthwhile for this alone. Compares with the Chagall windows in Jerusalem or the Rose window at York, except on a grander scale. Has to be on the Paris "must see" list - givev me a revisit here rather than another trip up the Eiffel Tower please.
Must see. This is not known like the Eiffel Tower and other major attractions, but it is definitely a must see for the interior and the stained glass.

Magical String Quartet concert in Royal Chapel. Walking along Boulevard de Palais at sunset, we noticed a line forming at the security entrance for the chapel and the Cour de Justice. Since it was Saturday evening and too late for the church to still be open, we crossed the street and discovered the programme for a string quartet concert that evening in the chapel. We joined the line, and after passing through airport-style x-ray machines, we climbed a flight of ancient stone stairs to the vestibule where ticket holders waited for entrance. Non-ticket holders were directed to a small table where a young man with a cash box sold tickets from one of 3 price tiers, ranging from 25€ to 65€. After a brief wait, we entered the nave and chose a seat; the lights dimmed, and the performance of Mozart's Requiem, Bach, Handel, and Vivaldi, by a string quartet and accompanying choir, began. Excellent acoustics, though cold, as medieval churches would be expected to feel at night, made for a magical evening.

Absolutely gorgeous.. I'd learned about Sainte-Chapelle in my art history class, and when I was planning a trip to Paris I knew I had to see it. It's small, but certainly worth the price of admission. Go on a sunny day to get the full effect of the stained glass - pictures don't do it justice.

magical evening!. we attended a bach quartet concert here around 7:30 in the evening. the music with the windows and small gathering was exquisite, I highly recommend seeing the inside of this cathedral!

An Inspiring Jewel. Regardless of one's religious views or lack thereof, this sweet place is worth a visit. The prevailing blues of the stained-glass windows are so calming; however getting in is a hassle. When we visited in October, the crowds were so great, we waited over an hour (in the supposed "off-season").

Fabulous!. Sainte Chapelle is a must see! It's centrally located, close to Notre Dame, and the Ile Saint Louis, the stained glass windows are beyond compare! The ceilings are gorgeous, and it's small enough to do in an hour or so. Don't miss this unique, and very beautiful spot!

Definitely worth the wait. I somehow had missed this in previous trips to Paris; mostly because I got scared of the entrance line. It took my mom and I to have a quick meal in the café in front of the entrance to realize the line actually moves pretty fast. Once you go past security everything moves quickly.Pictures do not make justice to this majestic place. We went in the afternoon, and the way the light enters the place is surreal. The level of detail and color in all the glassworks is definitely worth paying close attention.

A gem of architechture. Built by King Louis IX in the 13th Century to host his extensive collection of relic of the Christ as a showcase of his religious and political power, la Sainte Chapelle is a rare 2 storey church (said to be inspired by Emperor Charlemagne's palace) and a gem of Gothic architecture with magnificent stain glasses. A must see !The relics included at that time some Holy Cross fragments and the Crown of Thorns, now at Notre-Dame Cathedral and shown to the public the first Friday of each month.Buy ticket in advance to avoid the line and check for classical music concert in the church on some evening. The tickets can be paired with the visit of the Conciergerie (heavy atmosphere, as it served as a prison during the French Revolution...).On the way to or from, check out the flower market next block before heading to Notre Dame and salute Charlemagne on his horse ! On the opposite side of the ile de la Cite, you'll find King Henry IV on his horse facing the old, yet good tavern bearing his name.

Stunning revisit after 37 years. First visited in 1978 when queues were on-existent. Short wait (15 mins) in queue this time. Some people were disappointed on entering, not realising the main Chapelle is up a tight winding staircase. When you arrive 'in the light' you will be blown away by the stained glass, but choose a sunny day. Magnificent!

Secrets of Seeing and Really Enjoying La Sainte-Chapelle, Paris France. HelloThere are a few suggestions that I have to seeing and really enjoying the sounds and beauty of Saint-Chapel which is on the Ile de la Cite’, near Notre-Dame. During the day you will see very long queue lines to view this beautiful building. My suggestion to really enjoy this beautiful blue stained glass cathedral is to take in one of the many concerts that are preformed weekly in this cathedral. By doing this, it cuts down the wait time considerable, however the seats are not reserved so getting here 45 minutes early before the concert would not be a bad idea. There are usually 2 performances each night, take the first performance if it is in late spring, summer or early fall and you can watch the light come through the beautiful blue stained glass windows as the sun sets. Then you can sit back and enjoy the fantastic acoustic sounds throughout the cathedral from the concert you have chosen.A suggestion for purchasing tickets, you can buy them on line or wait until you are in Paris depending how long you are in Paris to visit. If you choose to purchase while in Paris, across the street from the cathedral, there is a small tobacco/smoke shop (NOT the Restaurant) that sells tickets, they are very helpful and will show you the seating chart, concert times and what composers that are available. I would also choose the seat section Category “A” which is the middle section for the best value. Please remember the seat are only reserved by section and not by individual seats so the earlier you get into the line outside prior to the concert time the better the seat will be inside.Have a Great time and enjoy Paris the “City of Lights” to its fullest.ThanksLary1047

Unique architecture, well preserved and a must se. We went to a chambre concert which was excellent, we enjoyed every minute of it.A remarquable Chapelle.Unfortunately,you have to queue up for over an hour. Will the organizers give a thought to the misery of waiting without a cover on top in bad weather or for elders and challenged visitors.

A Prayer Escapes Me. This very small church is a one of many major attractions in Paris in regards to places of worship that are in the area. Here's a hint, arrive early to avoid the long lines that I have witnessed not only during the day but in the evening. You can expect to wait 30-45 minutes to get in. Between 5 to 10 people are allowed in at a time since it is such a small church. There is a 8.50 Eur. fee (at the time of this writing) charged and you will have to go through a security check of purses, coats and totes. The first floor has wonderful colors, designs and other artifacts to see but the real treat is on the second floor. Be careful because the staircase is narrow and winding like one you would find inside a lighthouse. Once you catch your breath, look up and around and get ready to be impressed.This is the jewel in the crown of this church. The 1,113 scenes are astounding. It took almost forty years to complete these panels that are read left to right, bottom to top. I've been told that on a sunny day, the colors spill out throughout the building like jewels. Look for the information cards that are in various languages that explain the panels and how they were created.The stain glass will humble you as you give thanks that such craftmanship has been perserved for all generations to see.
Must See. This church is beautiful. The stained glass windows are amazing. A must see. Don't be fooled like I was when you first walk in. I thought we were ripped off...until I went upstairs.

Went Here By Mistake. We thought we were in a line for the Notre Dame Cathedral. After half hour of waiting we found out our mistake and decided that since we were getting close we would continue. It cost 8.50 each. Not worth it. All we saw was a number of stained glass windows.

Worth a visit if the lines are not long. The stained glass was very impressive, however after standing for 2 hours in line, I was less impressed and there is major security to get into the church. it was very beautiful but not worth 2 hours in line.

Stained glass heaven. We visited this church only because we were near Notre Dame and it was included in the Paris Museum Pass. What a find. Inside, the first floor is interesting. Go upstairs and the experience is spellbinding. The stained glass windows are beyond belief. Pay a visit!

Front row at the evening concert - one of our best memories in Paris!. The church gives you an intimate feeling in a chaotic city and the tall stained glass windows are spectacular. However, sitting in the front row of an evening concert and the amazing solo performed by the first violinist, Frederic Moreau, was amazing! Be sure to go if you can.

Small but Worth it. This church is in the middle of the Ministry of Justice and just a short walk from Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are fantastic and the colors are magnificent even when it's cloudy. When you are at Notre Dame, stroll down here.

Beautiful Stained Glass. If you have a museum pass, you still have to stand in line quite a while unless you get there early, but the stained glass in the room upstairs is gorgeous. If you go to a free concert there (check the website) you can sit and listen to Bach or Hayden and enjoy the glass for free...

Gorgeous!!. Go early! The lines were long waiting to get in in the afternoon. We went early in the morning, and it was a quick walk in. There was room to move around and I wish it had been a sunny day. The stained glass was absolutely beautiful! Go upstairs!!!! You might miss that, but it is the best.

Not to be missed on a sunny day. Sainte-Chapelle's windows glow in the sunlight. Even on a cloudy day, the are attractive, BUT with the sun shining, they sparkle.
Well worth the time in line.

Fantastic spot. Great place to visit. very impressive and not that noticeable from the street. Be prepared to queue up to 90 minutes. Well worth it. There is priority access available through advanced bookings
Stunning. Not what you expect from the outside .. Well worth the short queue .. The stained glass windows are beautiful

Very impressive church. This is a very impressive place, but despite this I would not really recommend standing in line for the 45 minutes it takes to get in. If you are into churches, there is Notre Dame (must see) and lots of others you can just walk into for free.

Breathtaking!. This small church is a Paris 'must see!' The long line moves quickly even though only a number of people are admitted at one time. There is a charge (included if you have the Paris Museum Pass) although we happened to visit on a day when the admission was waived.The lower chapel is lovely (and still under reconstruction) but the real treasure is on the second floor. The side walls of the upper chapel are all long, thin arched stained glass windows. Tip: Be sure to visit on a sunny day for the full effect--the many brilliant colors is like being in a kaleidoscope. Simply stunning!

Stained glass. We didn't have much time, but 1/2 hour was all it took to fall in love with this church. Soaring pillars and stained glass windows that keep the eyes pointed towards the heavens. Wish we had more time; if ever I return to Palace, I will revisit this church and give it the time it deserves.

Simply Beautiful. We came to the Chapelle on the Rick Steves walking tour. If you want to visit the line will be long for tickets unless you get the Paris Pass which will allow one to bypass the line. Beautiful.

must, must must attend a concert there. Attended Vivaldi Four seasons concert with string ensemble. The acoustics were so fantastic, the musicians superb, and the setting incredible. Abolutely must get tickets if you like classical music.

highlight of my day. We rushed to get in before 3 pm so that we could be certain to have as much sunlight filling the space as possible. It was breathtaking! Had a bit of a claustrophobic moment in the crowded spiral staircase though.
Amazing stained glass.. Just a short distance from Notre Dame, it's worth waiting in line to see the interior. Go up a set of stairs to see the amazing stained glass windows.

Stunning Stained Glass. Visited here after Notre Dame and queue was quite long. It moves quickly though as they let in a number of people at a time. Lower chapel was nice but the Upper chapel was stunning!

Magnificent. Even though I had studied and thought I knew what I was going to see, I was completely awed by the actuality. It is so beautiful that it is easy to forget the story that is told in the stained glass. I did not want an audio guide to interrupt my thoughts, so I just studied about what I was going to see and followed my notes throughout the tour. People were very quiet and respectful so it was easy to "take it all in." Truly magnificent.

Stunning stained glass. There are few words that can truly describe the beauty of this church. The Bible done in stained glass!! WOW!! Give yourself lots of time for this and remember that it is an active church so please keep your voices down. Pick a sunny day as well so that you can fully enjoy the splendor of the artistry. There are chairs to sit in. I recommend you pick one section at a time to enjoy. If you are traveling with younger ones you can make a game of finding the Bible story. My husband and I played this with each other and it was quite fun!

Vivaldi Four Seasons Concert an Experience for the Soul. I have attended concerts twice at Sainte Chapelle. The first was in the summer and started early enough to appreciate the stained glass in its full glory. This latest concert was in late October, so it was dark when the concert started, but it was truly a spectacular evening anyway. The concert last night was Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It is a spectacular venue for acoustics, the venue is small and personal for a concert. For those looking for a break from the hustle and bustle of shopping, eating and touring, this is a highly recommended event.

Gothique masterpiece. See Notre Dame from the outside but see this masterpiece from the inside. Walls of stained glass windows tell the story of the Bible. Go on a sunny day. The lines can be long, so if possible purchase a ticket ahead of time or go with a group. The renovations of the stained glass have been completed. A must see if you are touring Paris.
Word can't describe the beauty. You have to step into the room and take in the beauty of the stain glass in person to understand why it is worth going...

A Must-See Site. While a sunny day sets this jewel alight, the soaring stained glass windows on the upper level inspire awe even on an overcast day. This was the first time our grandchildren had been to Paris. It was clear that they were thrilled. For Generation One and Generation Two, it was akin to a pilgrimage. It wonderful to observe Generation Three's response.

Marvelous place. This medieval chapel with ita marvelous vitreux is one of Paris' best attractions. Try not to miss it, nevertheless the long line... Don't miss the second floor! This is SAINT Louis' best cultural heritage

An amazing experience. You will never forget the first time you step into the upper chapel of Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny day. The first level is okay, but if that is all you see, you wonder what all the fuss is about. Go upstairs and you will see.

A feast for your eyes!. This church is located right by the Conciergerie museum and only a few blocks away from Notre-Dame and the vibrant neighborhood of St Michel. It is definitely worth being included on your list of things to do while in the Ile de la Cité and Ile St Louis. You should particularly appreciate the amazing stained glass in this chapel: a feast for the eyes!

Must see. Not much needs to be said about the place: it's some of the most spectacular stained glass you will see anywhere in the world. Once you get in, look around but then find a chair and sit for awhile. I stayed there for close to an hour. Now, some particulars: The chapel is small so they can't let hordes of people in. Ergo, there will be a long and slow queue. It's never short, so you just have to queue up and wait. It was not especially busy when we visited and it took us 45 minutes to get in. Just plan on it. Second item: When we visited they closed from 1pm to 2:30pm. Check the sign at the head of the queue. If you are in line when they close you are just out of luck and have to return later. Don't get in line less than an hour before closing because you run a good risk of wasting your time and not getting in.

One of the Most beautiful churches!. Love it, love it, love it! I have been to many churches around the world, none compare in beauty and history. This is really a must do! You can go for a little walk around Notre Dame afterwards, or even enter Notre Dame and have an afternoon of churches of Paris :). This one is a must!

Another grand religious site. While not the first level tour in guide books, this massive display of arched columns and stained glass is magnificent. This huge church was built as a private chapel for Louis IX on his estate. Interesting architecture of mostly windows for light and heat, which it lacks in winter.

Go upstairs. When you first walk into a dingy low ceiling room with a gift shop, most people think "is this it for €14?! ". Make sure you go upstairs via the small not-very-obvious spiral stair. A cathedral of lights and colours awaits. Amazingly beautiful on a sunny day.

Inspirational. For anyone who loves stained glass and medieval architecture. The lower level is most but interesting, but the revelation after climbing the narrow stairs is nothing short of spectacular. It is amazing that something so beautiful and transcendental was created a thousand year ago. A visit is highly recommended.

Amazing a Dont Miss. In talking with family before coming to Paris this was one of the must see sights that I was told about. So as I wandered out to the 1st Arr. to go to Notre Dame I run across Sainte Chapelle. Luckily it was part of my Museum Pass although there was not Fast Pass but the line moves quickly. So as you enter you are not sure exactly where you are going pr what it is you are seeing. That does not end as you enter the Chapel, I was taken a back a bit as I thought really this is what the big ta do was about. But DONT leave... the amazing part is upstaires. There is a small sign pointing to a stairwell leading upstairs. It is a bit of a windy staircase kind of reminds me of the staircase to the Blarney Stone. But once up there you will be awe struck. I cannot put into words enough how absolutely beautiful this place is. My niece told me don't try and capture it with pictures it just does not do it justice. Make sure you take the time and just look not through a viewfinder or with your IPhone but just your eyes. As I was looking my eyes starting tearing with just how beautiful it is. The story is amazing and the history behind the stained glass windows is so interesting. There are so many sights in Paris to see but this will go down in my top 5. Take the time, take your time and see this amazing site.
Amazing building structure. Although I have been to Paris many times, I only recently visited the Sainte Chapelle - and am now surprised I never went before. It is an absolutely amazing building.

Spectacular stained glass. One of the most beautiful cathedrals ever. It depicts the life of Christ in stained glass which was done thousand of years ago. Just gorgeious. Hightly recommend you put this on your agenda. Very near Notre Dame cathedral.

Went to a concert. Absolutely wonderful. Amazing child choir. It is a beautiful building. The acoustics were great. I was amazed at the level of performance. I would recommend this to anyone. it was well worth the money.

Surprised... In a good way!!!. My wife suggested we visited, in my ignorance I hadn't heard of this little gem.Make sure you go up the stairs, we saw some leave without seeing the main part as they missed the small staircase.Last heard complaining it didn't look like the pictures. Lovely stained glass.
Pictures don't do it justice. Jaw-dropping beauty! Not too busy or crowded. Museum Pass speeds you past ticket line, but not past security, FYI.

The most beautiful lace-like archtecture and stained glass anywhere. The former royal chapel should not be missed if you appreciate beautiful Gothic architecture. Sit inside and marvel at high thin columns and arches and stained glass depictions. Best when there's sun from outside.
Sainte-Chapelle. Bought a museum pass ahead of time which worked everywhere but here. They wouldn't let us use it so we didn't go in as the lines were very long.

My favorite in Paris. The first floor is stunning, with it's painted, vaulted, ceiling, but the pièce de résistance are the tall, think and unbelievable stain glass windows in the main chapel. Go on a sunny day or at night. They also have classical concerts there which allow you a seat and time to really enjoy both the colors of the glass and the sound of music in the tall, vaulted chamber.

breathtakingly beautiful. A spectacularly beautiful place, feels like you're inside a jewel. The audio-tour was informative, but almost a distraction from the beauty of the place. Lines are much better than at nearby Notre Dame.

Oh, those stain glass windows. We went here for a Vilvaldi's Four Season concert. It was a highlight of our trip. During the day and every day we were there the line getting in to the Chapelle, not the concert , was incredibly long. Why not enjoy it the way we did? Purchase tickets online and enjoy the Chapelle and the concert without the wait.

Mesmerising. This was on my must do in Paris list and I wasn't disappointed. The architecture is impressive but the enormous stained glass windows steal the show. Try and go on a sunny day to see them at their best, I would love to see a concert in the chapel if I am lucky enough to return to Paris.I bought a Paris museum pass and found it invaluable, I definitely got my money's worth but more importantly you skip the long queues.

Wonderful venue for concerts .... Wonderful for concerts, if you don't mind standing in a long line out on the street, then going through airport style security, then more lines to get into the hall. Frankly, all that rigmarole can take a lot out of the pleasure of anticipating Mozert's symphonies.

So beautiful, we went twice!. Such a beautiful church, certainly any trip to Paris would be incomplete if this is not on your itinerary. On our recent trip to France, we had the luxury of time and being able to enjoy Sainte-Chapelle not once, but twice.So many terrific reviews on TA for this sanctuary, I would only be repeating the obvious, however, here is a few things to know, if you go:- Sainte-Chapelle is only a few minutes away from Notre Dame on the Isle de la Cite.- Don’t let the line dissuade you from going in! Actually, the line you see on the street is the security line. As Sainte-Chapelle sits among several occupied government buildings.- Once you are past the security checkpoint and scanners, follow the signs back to the entrance of the church, where you can buy admission tickets (8.5 Euros for adults), cash or credit cards- The box office, for concerts at Sainte-Chapelle, is located just to the left of the line to buy general admission tickets – if you want to buy concert tickets in person, please note they only accept cash.- The lower level of the church, where the bookstore is located, is almost as beautiful as the upper levels.- Once upstairs, you are surrounded by the beautiful stained glass panels, it’s like being inside a jewelry box!- We attended a violin and harp concert at 8:30pm; it was a magical experience that was only shared with about 40 other attendees. Purchased VIP section seats at 30-40 Euros, however, ANY seat would have been just fine, as there was not a huge crowd.- Seeing the church late at night it a very different experience that during the day, you do lose the jewel box effect, however the church is just as stunning.Based on our experience, if you want to take lots of photos, see Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny day, if you want to an almost “private” experience enjoy a concert at night. I am glad that we captured the photos in the day, as it the ability to take them at night is limited.

A wonderful experience. If you like stained glass this is a venue you should not miss. It is worth the wait in the queue and once inside the chapel go straight up the winding staircase to the upper chamber. It is unique and you will not be disappointed. Stay as long as you can but be prepared to look upwards for a long time. It is truly remarkable. Return to the lower floor and spend a while in the shop area where there are other interesting artefacts to see.

Really awe inspiring.. This will just take your breath away. The colour and detail is incredibly beautiful no photo does the real life vision justice. However I dread to think of the suffering of those who slaved to create this masterpiece of lead-light. The air feels heavy with its history.

2nd Visit And Still Impressive. This little church is in the center of a palace on the Notre Dame island. It is one of Paris unique treasures and a must for any visitor to Paris. You should not miss it.The admission is 8.50 euro which is great for what you get. The lines were extraordinary long. We come back second time, as we stayed closed by, and it was even longer so third time, we got up early, and was there about 9am and had only a dozen in from of us as it opens at 9:30am. yes we had to wait 40 minutes but it is worth it, I promise. The church itself is situated in the centre of one of Paris many palace which is now used for government buildings, I think. You go through security, and then into a smaller courtyard area through to front of church, that's where you buy your tickets. There is two levels to this small church, the bottom level being gift shop area and an alster area, Then you go up a spiral staircase to nothing more than sheer magnificence, its beautiful. I am sure you can get on the internet and see for yourself, but not one of those photos have anything on seeing it real. its just breathtaking. Definitely, get up early, beat the line and see it before the crowds. Also do this church first then Notre Dame. Its easy to find just one street north (lourve direction) from Notre Dame. You'll see huge iron gates, entrance is just to left off them. Also keep in mind, while we were there plenty of people we going up with pre purchsed tickets and Paris Pass tickets expecting to skip the line but they didnt let them, so keep that in mind. So Go there, spend an 1/2hour or so and just take in the magnificence which is Saint Chapelle's Church
Beautiful!. Buy your ticket at the Conciergerie (jail) next door, so you can avoid the lines after you get through security. The stained glass upstairs in amazing!

Stunning . This chapel is absolutely stunning to say the least. The stained glass windows and the ceilings look absolutely beautiful and cast a spell on the onlooker. I would highly recommend visiting this as it's centrally located and doesn't take very long either. The effect caused by light coming through the stained windows makes for a sight to behold. Highly recommended.

Sublime. I should rate this gorgeous chapel poorly so the lines would thin a little but I can't -- it would be a lie. A top choice for any visit to Paris, but try to go on a sunny day because the colors of the glass will be most vibrant. The Museum Pass won't save the line outside but it will keep you from standing in the ticket line inside. First-timers may not know -- because it's really not well marked inside -- that the main chapel is up the stairs from the lower entry area (some visitors were happy that I led them upstairs). It's a bit stressful to wait and finally get in, but take some deep breaths to get your head straight and slow down, then quietly feel the space. Isn't it sublime?

Long wait, but wow. When we first walked in, our reaction was "This is it?" We were in the lower chapel. Don't spend more than 5 minutes there. The real beauty of this attraction is in the upper chapel.Absolutely gorgeous. It cannot really be described in words. The beauty and detail has to be seen to be properly appreciated. A word of caution: They restrict the number of guests inside, so they only let in groups of 10 or so at a time. We were there on a Monday at 4 p.m. and waited more than an hour.

Mesmerizing Stained Glass. The chapel is undergoing a renovation at the tim elf my visit. However the stained glass in this church is wonderful, I was in awe looking at the colors and images as the sun shined through them. Well worth a visit
Wonderful. Finally go to visit Sainte-Chapelle andbit is spectacular inside. Only issue is we had to wait over an hour to get inside
Joke. I've seen better stained glass in Leon And Milan . Very small it's a beautiful building but you don't have to wait in line to see that

Just breathtaking!. I'm one of those people who never read too much about popular sights simply because I like to be positively surprised and reading about it afterwards just makes more sense. And boy was I surprised with Sainte - Chapelle! I had no idea what I was in for and I fell in love with it right away! The smell, the low light downstairs and the breathtaking stained-glass windows upstairs, the blue and the gold, the gothic in it and all the elegance: it just easily became one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen!The Sainte - Chapelle is a definite must when visiting Paris and it is most definitely worth the usual loooong queue!

Hidden Gem. This was my second trip to Paris and the first time I had visited Sainte-Chapelle. This place was breathtaking. I had heard that it was built to house the Crown of Thornes. When you go up the tiny winding staircase, you enter a chapel that has stained glass on every side. Every window represents a time period of the Bible and the detail is absolutely stunning. You can visit here within and hour's time and I absolutely guarantee you will be happy you came. The history of the place is just so intriguing!

Not to be missed!. My husband and I had a most memorable evening enjoying the classical music concert in the Sainte-Chapelle. We loved the selections that they chose, including two versions of Ave Maria. The musicians were extremely talented. There were a couple of younger children in attendance, and they were so quiet you could hear a pin drop. It was truly anexperience that we will revisit if we return to Paris.

Much better than the Cathedral of Notre Dame. If you can see Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny day, it is worth a trip just to spend fifteen minutes sitting in the chapel, basking in the glow of the muted light. Sainte-chapelle is much more impressive to me than its more famous neighbor, the Cathedral of Notre Dame.

Spectacular!. Wish I had purchased the museum pass prior to the visit - would have avoided a long wait to get in. Once you're inside head upstairs. The stained glass is amazing. The outside facade is also spectacular

Amazing!. This is by far, one of the most incredibly beautiful things that I have ever seen! So breathtaking. The upper level of the chapel is full of tall, tall stained glass windows. This church is also nearly 800 years old. We were lucky enough to see a classical music concert here. So incredible. A MUST see.

Wonderful concert in a magnificent chapel. Went to a concert of "Four Seasons" in this magnificent chapel. Beautiful stained glass windows that are definitely a must see. Heavy security since it is in the building of Paris' court so there's always a line. Worth the wait. And if there's a concert, get tickets!

Beautiful. The stain glass is beautiful. Well worth it if you have the museum pass. However, the church closes for lunch from 1-2 and this is not posted. While waiting in line, the guards simply went to lunch without telling anyone and did not reopen the line until 2:15. Apparently, this occurs daily. A beautiful sight but not worth a wait of more than 30 minutes.

Spectacular. You wend you way up a spiral staircase that gets narrower and narrower (not for the faint hearted or impaired), and begin to wonder whether this was worth doing, until you step into this amazing chapel, majestic in appearance if not necessarily so in size. The 'walls' as such are continual panels of stained glass some 700 years old. So beautiful as the sunlight illuminates the religious stories held within. Reported to hold the Religious Relic of the Crown of Thorns, this Chapel is a 'must see'. Expect queues unless early.

Stunning stained glass windows. When we entered the lower floor of the chapel I felt it was quite breathtaking despite the low ceiling. The stained glass windows were beautiful but paled into insignificance compared to that of the upper floor. A bit tricky to find but well worth a visit if you are interested in churches etc

Vivaldi concert at Sainte-Chapelle. You must see the sun coming through the spectacular windows during the day but also make time for a Vivaldi concert at night. The setting is exceptional and the violins will almost bring you to tears.

Just wow!. If you dont mind waiting in line and is a sunny day, then you have to come to this place. is only 2 rooms but wow! such a beautiful place. the stainglass windows are just the most amazing, colorful thing.

Most beautiful church of Paris. This little church is not as famous as the other ones in Paris, birt it is the most beautiful one. Because it is small you could just miss out. It is not as crowded if you go early morning.
Startling beauty. I visited Saint Chapelle as the setting sun was shining through the stained glass and it was an overwhelming experience. Incredible colours and beauty.
Amazing stained glass. The Chapelle is small and the stained glass windows are fabulous, however we thought the E8.50 entry fee was too expensive.
Some of the most beautiful stained glass you'll ever see. It was really crowded, but it's worth a 20-30 minute visit if you're already in the area to see Notre Dame.

Classical music is performed here in the evening an the acoustics do shine. The Sainte Chapelle is difficult to find and you will have to stand in line but the experience and architecture of this chapel is worth the visit.The stained glass windows are unique and how the light enters,magical and...do go up the stairs and try to book a classical soiree there in advance.This is in The Palace of Justice and The Sainte Chapelle was built by Louis IX.

Glorious! ( the last night of anniversary trip). I had our hotel book us for a concert at Saint- Chapelle. the concert series of classical music is a wonderful way to experience the exceptional beauty of this chapel. It was built as a reliquary of sorts to house the Crown of Thorns and parts of the True Cross, hence the unusual design of tall narrow stained glass walls supported by delicate columns that are carved with the likeness of the 12 apostles. It is the most beautiful interior , all rich colors and carvings that you can imagine. To sit and hear an intimate quartet or sextet while sitting inside such an exquite and historic space is memorable.

Saint Chapelle. We waited about a half hour and this was defintely worth it. The stained glass was the prettiest and most intricate that I have seen. Go in the afternoon when one side of the chapel is lit by the sun.

Absolutely beautiful.....allow time...there are always long queues to get in. In Palace of Justice are the Sainte Chapelle stained glass windows- there are some wonderful windows downstairs but don't miss climbing the stairs to the chapel to see more windows. Well worth a visit, go early to avoid the tour buses, can queue for over an hour before getting in.

Amazing Stained Glass Windows and More!!. On our first visit I was so impressed with the marvelous windows, there are so many of them and the room just lit up with light. Returning to Paris a second time I preordered concert tickets before leaving the US. We ordered tickets for the earlier time frame and enjoyed the sun gleaming through the colored glass as the sun was setting. It was one of the most moving sights with the sun shining in and the Opera being performed. What a wonderful experience we had that day! The music and glass was heavenly. We paid extra for close seats but I don't think there is a bad seat in there. Its so much smaller than Notre Dame.

Jewel in the middle of Paris. A little difficult to find, once found, live in the realm of centuries long past. Built by Louis IX, (Saint Louis) this chapel is extraordinary. The small building with walls of stained glass changes character as the sunlight moves through the day. Watch for posters that advertise the classical musical performances in the evening usually after 7pm--I have had some of the best musical experiences there.

Not To be missed. This little Chapel is unique and the upper level was the Kings private chapel. Amazing stained glass windows. There are frequent concerts there. We attended a Vivaldi concert that made the hairs on your neck stand up when you think of the historic place that you are in listening to this beautiful music from the era.

Beautiful place to visit. Another great place to see. I really liked the artist colony that is very close. There were many people enjoying this area. we actually went twice since there was so much to see and do.

Amazing. If you want to understand the power of light and stained glass in a small space, this is it. A jewel box of a church. You must be able to navigate some very steep and twisty stairs, but once you arrive there are places to sit and look at this old and incredible display of stained glass. You'll want to sit, because the images have to be studied to really appreciate them. Just go, please. It's beautiful. Again, you'll be better off with a museum pass, but you'll still have to wait outside to get in - it's a small space and only a limited number of people can be there at any one time. Part of what's special about it.

Masterpiece. The ultimate example of gothic architecture, graceful, bright, colorful, simply beautiful. Try to visit early in the morning to avoid the crowds and get more sunlight.It is a pity it is being so badly maintained and manned by such sour public servants.
