Nice Concert. You can buy concert tickets at the small shop across the street. Nice way to see the Chapel without standing in a long line. Make sure the sun is still up so you can really enjoy the windows.
Very good string ensemble but skip the CD's - production quality is poor at least on the one we purchased.

A Jewel Box. Saint Chapelle is one of the top tourist attractions of Paris with reason. As Louis XVI private Chapel it's foot print is small but the loft is as high many of the large cathedrals. The stained glass is very well preserved and brilliant. Make sure to get there early; there seems to be a line at all times.
Just exquisite. Long lines to get in, but well worth it. I had no expected to have to pay to get in, so that was a bit unnerving, but it was lovely

A jewel box of colours. Tucked away in the Palace of Justice is the private chapel Sainte Chapelle - go in the main room then up 33 winding stone steps to the chapel itself - and you are surrounded by colour from the 13thc stained glass windows (many are original) Try to go on a sunny day for a spectacular display. Much more beautiful than Notre Dame interior.

Staggeringly Beautiful. My partner and I queued for over an hour but it was worth the wait. Nothing can quite prepare you for the glorious stained glass windows in the Upper Chapel. It's an almost overwhelming experience, the sculptures and beautiful windows depict scenes from the Bible and the Chapel is bathed in multi-coloured light from the stained glass. Angels adorn corner pieces and the statue of Saint Peter is the original, holding in his hands the keys to Heaven.
The Stained Glass Windows are Spectacular!. The windows--most of them original--in Sainte Chapelle were amazing! I enjoyed this much more than Notre Dame. I would highly recommend spending time here.
amazing. Absolutely stunning, so glad we went here during our stay in Paris, it is an amazing site to behold.

Inspiring..... There are so many churches in Europe and you can reach a point where you feel you have seen enough. Sainte-Chapelle, however, is definitely one that you should see.Try to get there early and don't be afraid of the line. Unfortunately, the long line is because everyone has to go through security before buying their ticket. Upon entering Sainte-Chapelle, you will realize that it was worth the wait, especially the upstairs. You enter the upstairs by winding stairs. You can stay as long as you like. Sit down and read the cards provided in different languages, then take in the beauty of the stained glass. Magnificent!

The most beautiful stained glass. It may not be as popular as Notre Dame or the Eiffel Tower but it should be as the stained glass is beyond description, you can only stand back and admire the craftsmanship of these windows - do not miss this Parisian highlight

Stunning. Magnificent. I bought a ticket for the Conciergerie & Sainte Chappell together. I went to the Cociergerie first which was the mideval prison. Very interesting. There was a huge line after I left but I was skipped to the front because I already had the ticket. I have been to other cathedrals in Europe but this is beyond description. The lower floor is fabulous but climb the narrow winding stairs to the second level...breath-taking!
Breath taking. It doesn't get better than this folks! Seriously. On a sunny day, those windows are something you'll want to have experienced before you leave this earth.

Beautiful. The stain glass is beautiful and definitely worth seeing. Make sure you go upstairs to see the stain glass also, we almost missed doing that. There is a chart you can read upstairs that describes some history of Sainte-Chapelle.

Unsurpassed. Earlier this Summer we attempted to see the chapel but the line was extremely long. The Museum Pass does not give you skip the line here. Because of a recommendation on tripadvisor we acquired e-tickets for the Vivaldi concert and were thrilled with the performance and the ability to see the chapel while daylight was still exhibiting the windows in early October. We did arrive at 6:15 due to security for a 7:00 p.m. concert and a line had already formed for admission. They are very organized to admit the audience and the performance started on time lasting a little over one hour. Enjoy!

The best stained glass I have ever seen, absolutely brilliant.. You enter the main chapel and see a wonderful ceiling and glass, take time to study the detail on the walls as well, an awful lot of detail. You take the spiral stairs to the conciergerie as you get to the last few steps the walls glow purple and you turn the corner and wow. Highly recommend the chapel, queue is always long for this event but get priority tickets and slide past the queues.Note all bags are checked, coats off Etc Etc as it's also the entry to the Palais du Justice.

Stain glass windows to die for!. Located on the Ile de la Cite, the chapel is located within the Court of Justice. For security reasons, you will be asked to go through a metal detector. Leave knives and other sharp objects in your hotel room. Visit this monument early in the day unless you like standing in line for a long time... The chapel has two levels. The chapel at the top has the marvelous windows.

Breathtakingly beautiful. As far as the interior goes, I would consider this to be the most beautiful church in Paris. The towering stained glass windows make this church look like a jewelbox when the sunshine is streaming through.The biblical stories being told in the stained glass windows are not easily decipherable unless you buy, bring, or download a guidebook. We didn’t try too hard to figure them out. We just sat in the chairs and looked around, soaking in the beauty of this church.Tip: When you enter the church, turn left and head for the staircase in the corner, to go upstairs where you can see the stained glass windows. You can always see the ground floor on your way out.
Stunning Glass, Long Wait. This would be a no-brainer if you can go when there is no line. We arrived late morning and had about an hour-long queue. Very enjoyable once inside.

Beautiful windows!!!. The stained glass windows in this chapel are the most beautiful that we saw in all the cathedrals we went into in Paris and France. They are just breath-taking. We were there on a sunny day, so the light pouring through the windows was stunning.We arrived to the line just in time for them to have closed for lunch (from 1pm to a little after 2pm!) So please time your visits more carefully than we did! By the time the chapel reopened after lunch, the line to get in was around the corner, down the street and looped back on itself all the way to the front of the line again! It is a small chapel, so they don't let too many people in all at once. It shares an airport-style security entrance with a justice hall, so don't let the other line/entrance confuse you.Once you exit the security area, you are in a courtyard area and it isn't terribly obvious where to go. Go around a smaller building in the center of the courtyard to the left side of the central building. On the far side of the smaller central building, you will find the entrance to the chapel.Inside the chapel, you enter on the lower floor, which seems kind of dark and disappointing. Turn to your left just inside the entrance and go up the small staircase to the room upstairs, where the beautiful windows extending up to the roof will greet you. There are chairs around the outer edge of the open room upstairs for you to sit and just gaze up at the stunning windows. When you have soaked it all in, then you can go down the little stairs to the left of the ones you came up and visit the room below before exiting out the entrance to the chapel.To get back out onto the sidewalk and street - follow along the side of the chapel and head to your left. You will go out a large gated area. It is a little confusing, but if you keep in mind that the chapel is inside the courtyard of a justice center, some of these unusual-for-a-tourist-attraction features will make a little more sense.Tips: The Paris Museum Pass doesn't seem to get you priority access - or it didn't when we were there, but it will save you waiting in line to buy a ticket.The courtyard area is partially cobblestoned and uneven, so watch your step.The staircases going to the upper room in the chapel are small and uneven and worn down, so step carefully.As with all museums in Paris, check the opening/closure times and closure days, so you aren't disappointed to arrive to find it closed. (Although there was no where that I read that Sainte-Chapelle closes for lunch, so that was a surprise!)

The audio guide is worth the money!. There will always be a queue to get in to big tourist attractions so take a book along to pass the time! It is 5 minutes from the Notre Dame and it is so beautiful when you get inside. The audio guide is really worth the money as it explains all of the windows. It is a stunning chapel but it is worth the audio guide as it was helpful to see where to look for certain paintings.
Beautiful Stain Glass. The church is not very big, free with museum pass, but th Stan glass is just beautiful. . The church is worth a visit

Exquisite. I have visited Saint Chapelle at least ten times. It remains my first port of call on the tourist trail in Paris. It is all the more fascinating whilst the stained glass is being restored. To see Before & After is a real experience. The evening concerts are a delight with the low evening sun coming through the windows. Tickets obtainable at the cafe opposite. You get a bonus as the entrance to the chapel is through the law courts building. Notre Dame is big and brash but to me Saint Chapelle is the real hidden gem on Ile de la Cité.

Windows to die for. Stunning designs and windows. You have to line up outside but it's only to pass through the security as the site is in a secure area. The acoustics are awesome and the stained glass windows great. Much more impressive on a sunny day with the light through the windows

HEAVEN. I have been more than half a dozen times for the 4 Estaciones of Vivaldi. I love when the Sunset reflects the Vitrales on the Walls while you are listening to the Clasical Music allways the Best of the Best Music Masters of this Planet. I have a DREAM that some Day I will get Married there. That AMAZING for me it is with some HARP music and Violins that would make it for me to FLY AWAY.

Glorious spot in Paris. Saint-Chapelle is one of my favourite spots in Paris, particularly if you're looking for a moment of calm in the city. Saint-Chapelle has two chapels - a tiny one downstairs and a large one upstairs. The larger one will simply take your breath away - the stained-glass is simply glorious. This attraction is right in the heart of the city (near Notre-Dame), you will need to queue to gain entry, but it is tres-magnifique!

Stunning stained glass windows; hideous queue. The windows in this church are phenomenal & stunning; but the 2.5 hour wait was not! Most things in Paris close for lunch & this is no exception so make sure you go there early, or after 2.15pm & be prepared to wait. The French are hopeless are organising queues or anything else & they are not interested in reducing tourist discomfort in the slightest. Beautiful attraction but not sure if anything is worth such a long wait.
Stained glass. There was about a 20 minute wait to get in. The stained glass windows were beautiful. Some sections were in sunlight making them really brilliant

Don't overlook this gem!. St Chapelle is too often overlooked. It is the home of splendid stained glass windows cleverly designed that allows the pillars almost disappear from view. It is only a few blocks from Notre Dame - Don't miss it!

Get your tickets in advance for this excellent small cathedral.. It is worth it to visit this cathedral if just for the stained glass windows which surround three walls of the cathedral. It is much smaller than Notre Dame but has a lot to offer. Please get your tickets in advance as the wait is long if you don't.

If you see it, see it this way..... Beat the crowds and go across the street to purchase concert tix. You won't be disappointed. The concerts from summer to early fall take place at sunset and illuminate this entire building. Vivaldi being played on the intimate stage is breathtaking.

Unexpected Magic. This frankly wasn't even on my radar until I spotted a photograph of it while riding the Paris Metro. I'd intended to visit the Musee D'Orsay that day, but the lines were insane so I opted for St. Chapelle (circa 1239), a 10 minute walk away. After waiting in a very slow moving queue for over an hour (I considered leaving on several occasions), I finally obtained my ticket to enter. I climbed the 40+ stairs from the entry point, and emerged into one of the most dazzling spaces I've ever seen. I literally gasped. The sun pouring through the 15 stained glass windows created a light more beautiful than I could have ever imagined. I'm not a particularly religious person, but I can truthfully say I felt the presence of the divine during my visit to this amazing temple.

Disappointing. I had really looked forward to seeing Sainte-Chapelle and waited in line a very long time to enter a security check. But inside it was disappointing. The stained glass windows are fascinating with their storybook of the bible, but the rest of the church is not the "most beautiful" as advertised. Word to the wise: if you can't climb up uneven, small spiral stairs, you will not be able to get to the second floor. And it is quite small, except for the very high ceiling.

Immeasurably better after restoration. The wonderful medieval glass lancet windows have taken 7 years to restore and are now breathtakingly beautiful. Good audioguides available. Wheelchairs available but allow time to take the longish path to the llift in an adjacent buidling.Book tickets in advance online to avoid some queuing. We have to accept a full airport-style security check on the way in.

Skip this!. The fee is just not worth to see one room full of stained glass windows. Advertises that Jesus's crown of thorns is displayed so that is why we went. When asked about this, we were told that there was no such thing there! False advertising! Also , if you are elderly or handicapped the stairs are treacherous! If there is an elevator, no one knew where it was located!
Amazing. Make sure that you go to Sanite-Chapelle in the daytime to get the most out of the beautiful colors, then, if you can attend one of the concerts there in the evening, even better.
Worthwhile just for the windows. Very old and very impressive, worth the wait and price. Make sure to get the placards that explain the windows, or the audiocassette.

A MUST DO IN PARIS. Sainte-Chapelle is breathtaking in its magnificent stained glass windows and to hear Vivaldi's Four Seasons played brilliantly in these beautiful surrounds was the icing on this cake.
Beautiful stories through stain glass. This was absolutely amazing. The story of the Bible is so beautfully seen in the stain glass windows.
Must see. Not sure why we did not visit on one of our previous trips. Located close to Notre Dame. Simply spectacular. I'd recommend a visit on a sunny day.

Stunning Gothic Chapel, amazing acoustics. We went to St. Chappelle on the advice of a friend. It was absolutely breathtaking. We also saw a flyer for a Baroque Concert later that evening and bought tickets for a string quintet. The stained glass windows are one of the most beautiful things we saw in Paris.

Don't miss the upstairs. The first time my husband and I visited Sainte-Chapelle we almost missed the upstairs. This is the place for stained glass. It is the most beautiful chapel I have seen. On our last trip we were able to attend a concert featuring Vivaldi's Four Seasons in the upstairs chapel. Definitely a highlight of the trip. Stained glass and Vivaldi.
Bucket List Place. Really one of the most beautiful rooms you'll step into in your life. Not like any place I've ever been. It's not a religious thing - it's just a work of art.
Sainte Chapelle. Buy the combined Chapelle & Concergerie ticket together & visit both the Chapelle & the Concergierie (prison)..
Not worth the wait!. The stained glass windows are quite beautiful, but honestly, to wait in line for an hour to see them was just too much.

Best part of the trip!. We attended the concert here at night. They only had the "good" seats near the front left so we had to splurge a bit, but we were absolutely blown away by the experience. It was amazing. You must see a concert here. Just do it, you won't regret it unless you really hate classical music. We were not huge classical music fans, but don't dislike it either, and we still absolutely loved it. The musicians clearly loved what they were doing and seemed to really enjoy playing music with each other, so it was cool to see them having such a good time too. We only saw the church during the evening, in the rain, and it was still amazing. I'm really jealous of those that got to see it in the sunlight.

360 degrees of magical. This place would have been overlooked on my visit but it was recommended as a must see so i took the time to stop by... and it was just wonderful. The line up was significant and the chapel itself quite small, but it was just totally unique and wondrous. Different to all others wed seen, it really is a must see, especially with its proximity being so close to Notre Dame. Make the effort to see it, you wont regret it, it is 360 degrees of magical!

Sensational but get there early. If I'm in Paris with people who have never been here, I always bring them - but first thing, because it can be hellishly busy, with huge queues and - despite the 'silence' notices and shushing attendants - a fair amount of noise and people too busy taking selfies to look about them.Be there early enough and it is completely magical, like being inside a jewellery box - which, of course, you almost are, because it's a huge reliquary. Now that more of the astonishing medieaval glass has been cleaned it is even more amazing - sparking in red and gold and blue, with not an inch left undecorated. Wonderful, and even better if you let the magic work on you. Everyone I have brought has been blown away by it, but in other, busier, circumstances it could be horrible.Some people are reluctant to climb the spiral stairs to the main chapel. If you are uncomfortable with this, there's little point in visiting. There's some glass downstairs, and the sales area (of course), but hardly worth the effort. And the main chapel is not easily accessible, as far as I know, any other way. Upstairs - get there early.

Some things are worth waiting for.. It took us three times to get in --the lines were always really long--and they close for lunch! BUT it was completely worth it. We were three people of very different ages and we each listed this as our favorite attraction of the trip.

Classical Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. The one hour concert inside the stunning Sainte-Chapelle chapel was romantic and intimate, and is a worthwhile experience for anyone that enjoys classical music. We booked tickets for the concert online a couple weeks before arriving in Paris. We opted for seats in the VIP section and ended up sitting in the fourth row, which allowed us a good view of the musicians and ample time to sit and appreciate the impressive alter and architecture without the distraction of hordes of tourists. The 800 year-old chapel's towering stained glass windows make for a beautiful and unique concert venue, especially if you can catch one of the sunset shows, and the acoustics were perfect. Music by Pachelbel, Vivaldi, and Vitali was featured, and many of the pieces were familiar to us. The musicians also played passionately and really seemed to enjoy playing together. The concert lasted around one hour and let out around 8PM time, and we were able to walk to one of the many nearby restaurants for dinner.The chapel is located within an important government ministry complex, so arrive early and expect a long line to get through security. Once inside, the seating is not assigned, so the best seats will be taken early. The lead violinist did wander down the main aisle during one of his solos, but it can be difficult to see the rest of the musicians unless you stake out an aisle seat or sit close to the front. The price difference between the VIP and regular seats wasn't much and puts you much closer to the front. The weather was also hot when we visited, and the ancient chapel became quite warm with all the concert-goers packed in, so dress appropriately. Lastly, there is only one public restroom stall located in the courtyard of the complex, and there will be a long line after the concert if you need to use it.We really enjoyed the concert and the beautiful chapel, and would recommend the concert to anyone that appreciates classical music and is seeking a one-of-a-kind experience during their tour of Paris.
Beat the lines. If you wait in line to get in you'll ask, "is this is"? The best way to see St. Chappelle is to attend one of the evening musical performances. It was an awesome experience.
Stand in line, it is worth it!. There is usually a line to get in and this time was no exception. I was blown away by the beauty of this chapel, it is for sure something everyone should see
A miracle to see!. Built to house the Crown of Thorns of Jesus Christ....absolutely incredible, and the structure, so light, tall and airy, is a miracle of construction and faith!
I simply I love you it!. a great historic site to visit when in Paris. The stained glasses will really impress you. probably one of the most beautiful chapels.
Essential on a sunny day. Probably the best (and most surprising) moment of the trip to Paris. On a sunny day, absolutely stunning.

Just ok. If you are tight with time this is one you can pass. After waiting in line for a long time and paying 8 € I was expecting to learn some history or see something of interest. It's a very small room with stain glass and that's it!

A journey into magic and back. the queue is well worth the trouble. and it wasn't that long after all, even though I joined it late morning, the Saturday of the Bastille weekend. I gave the Concierge a miss, thank you very much, and just concentrated on the pleasure of royal indulgence in the Divine. A complete visual orgasm, that lasts until you leave. Recently renovated and rejuvenated, the colors are as vivid now in memory as anything I ever recalled. And you must go back and enjoy a concert in the evening. It was quite full, but it didn't matter, as there are attendants keeping foolish people from making too much noise. All together a wonderful and memorable sight see.
Stained Glass!!. Worth the visit to see the stained glass work. Purchase a museum pass. this venue is included. It also allows you to skip the queue where guests are purchasing tickets.

Stunningly beautiful Stained Windows!. The Sainte Chapelle situated on the larger Ile de la Cite is a must see in Paris - seeing the sunlight stream through the spectacular stained glass is awsome! DON"T forget to visit the top floor!! The lines to get in are daunting but I have a plan!! - visit the much quiter Conciergerie first (Marie Antoinette holding prison cell amongst other highlights) and buy a COMBINATION ticket that covers admission to both sites ie. Conciergerie and St Chapelle - you can use this to skip the painfully long queue at St Chapelle. Don't miss!

Best glassworks . We came here early afternoon and the line was super long (we later on found out that they were closer during lunch in the afternoon and we probably picked the worst time to line up). I was doubtful if the wait is worthwhile. I have to say "it is!!!" The glass work on the 2nd floor is stunning - the best I have ever seen in church or anywhere else. Definitely worth a visit. Just try to pick a better time next time.

Vivaldi at Sainte-Chapelle. Toured Sainte-Chapelle during the day and what an amazing chapel. Standing in the middle of the King's Chapel surrounding by stained glass -- very mesmerizing with the sun shining through. Could only imagine the engineering feat this was wen the stained glass was originally installed. Visited Saint-Chapelle later that evening to listen to Vivaldi's Four Seasons. Was truly magical as concert occurred during sunset. The acoustics in the Cathedral was amazing as was an amazing experience. Highly recommend everyone to attend a concert at Saint-Chapelle
Not Back to the Future !. A fascinating journey in history, under the same roof as the most powerful leaders of French Monarchy

Don't be put off by the line. The line was large but I joined it and hoped for the best. It moved fairly fast and I was inside in 20-30 mins. Once I got in I was thinking, "this wasn't what I expected" I was just about to leave when I saw people walking upstairs. Wow. The upstairs is just breathtaking. Must see

Most beautiful stained-glass windows in all of Paris!. The stained-glass windows of the Sainte-Chapelle are almost all original and although the chapel itself is empty of decor, the windows alone are worth the visit.

Find time to visit this gem!. It's worth the queue to see this amazing chapel. Best go on a sunny day to really appreciate the stained glass windows. It's worth getting the audio guide as it really helps to explain the biblical scenes.

line up was too long and too slow, so we gave up. line up was too long and too slow, so we gave up
we stood there for a while and when we noticed it wasn't moving much we left.
MUST see!. The BEST site in the city, especially when the light shines thru the amazing windows. (Pillars of the Earth/Ken Follett fans know how phenomenal the architecture was for its time.)

incredible stained glass. This is a magnificent piece of history and art. Built by the King to house the crown of thorns (and other relics) which were eventually moved to Notre Dame Cathedral, the building has breathtaking stained glass windows, beautiful statuary and wonderful glazed tiles. Recently the interior has been undergoing maintenance and restoration work. Oddly, Sainte Chapelle doesn't get the same notoriety as Notre Dame, but it is very nearby and worth the entrance fees which are used to maintain and preserve it. This is truly a best kept secret of Paris and something that shouldn't be missed.

Stunning stained glass. It's such a tiny church, tucked inside a government complex...with a STUNNING interior! It doesn't take long to see, can be tacked on to your visit to Notre Dame, and is TOTALLy worth it!

Awe Inspiring Stained Glass. This "chapel" has the most spectacular stained glass windows imaginable. Because the palace that surrounds the chapel now serves as a criminal court, all visitors must go through a metal detector, and the number of visitors allowed in at one time is limited. Expect at least a one hour wait to get in, but is is well worth it. As with other attractions, if this is high on your list, as it should be, get there shortly before it opens and your wait will probably be shorter.
Breathtaking Stained Glass. This decommissioned church is well worth a visit - one of the most beautiful interiors I've seen in all of Western Europe.
Secret Surprise. Add this to your list! Beautiful small and intimate gothic cathedral in all stained glass on second floor.

String Quartet and Choralle Concert. I treated myself to a concert in the magnificent upper chapel of Ste. Chapelle for my birthday and what a treat it was. I've heard several Vivaldi concerts but this was a new string quartet and a choral group that was magnificent. They were so good we applauded them into not one but THREE encore numbers. The acoustics are wonderful and the combination of the ethereal music and magnificent blue stained glass makes for an experience not to be missed!!

An Unforgetable Evening!. Every time I've planned to visit Sainte-Chapelle, something has hindered me from seeing it in all its glory! This trip I finally made it! I read several reviews on other sites recommending attending a concert here. So, I went on-line and secured tickets to an evening of Vivaldi. I decided since my aim was to see the windows at sunset to book tickets in the least expensive area and at the earliest time. Those were good choices! 95% of the windows were visible and even though the day had been cloudy, the sunset shone through them. and, the music? It was wonderful! No, we didn't have a clear view of the musicians, but the music engulfed us.

One of Paris' true gems. Visit this ahead of other churches.. A small chapel built for royalty, with stunning stained glass windows where the blue and red glass give a wonderful purple effect. Best to go when the sun is shining and book in advance as the queues can get lengthy. Note it closes between 1pm and 2.15pm.
Must Visit. So So beautiful. I read that this must the the most beautiful building in France and can quite believe it. Queued for over an hour which I HATED but really worth it. A must see.

Truly 5 Stars. By now we have seen a lot of stained glass. As a tourist in the world of churches with stained glass this was one of the best. As an extra, it is old: the 1250's. A Paris must see site.

Most Amazing Stained Glass Windows in the World!. The Sainte-Chapelle (French pronunciation: ​[sɛ̃t ʃapɛl], Holy Chapel) is a royal medieval Gothic chapel. This is a site that definitely shouldn't be missed, but for the best experience make sure to come on a bright & sunny day around noon. This small chapel was built by Louis IX to house the crown of thorns and other relics of Christ. The walls of the 2nd floor are made almost entirely of stained glass and it's absolutely breathtaking on a sunny day. Be prepared to wait close to an hour in line.
A stones throw from Notre Dame - don't miss it!. Absolutely gorgeous! Go early to avoid a long wait. We were there on a rainy/overcast day and it was still beautiful.
STUNNING DISPLAY OF STAINED GLASS. By far the most stunning display of stained glass I have ever seen in Europe. Well worth the long time and price of admission.
Evening concert. Visited for an evening concert. Amazing acoustics and a lovely way to enjoy the sunset light through the windows.
You must to see. beautiful, stoning place to visit. very clean, noise sometimes but i could visit over and over again.
Must visit for Architecture Students. Nice architecture, nice view, very beautiful, please see the windows carefully as it tells a nice story.

Stained glass sensation. Sainte-Chapelle is a stained glass stunning dessert tray with exquisite colours and designs once you get upstairs. It is constantly busy with tourists so get there early. The other option is you could purchase a combination ticket from the Conciergerie, another tourist trap next door where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned. The key is though, that this combo ticket will although costing you an extra 6 euros or so, let you bypass the line to get into the Sainte-Chapelle which at the best of times can be 45 minutes along the side of the church.It's not a big cathedral but it is an important one. The views are stunning and what you'd expect to see from a 13th century masonry wonder. It's part of the tourist collection on the island of Paris close to Cathedral de Notre Dame, and easy access from metro subway. One of the things you have to see in Paris if you like keepsake pictures or appreciate old and beautiful architecture.

Magnificent place to keep such holy pieces. We have been trying to go to this chapel for the las two times we have been in Paris, but there is alwas so many people that we have left it for some other time, but we found something great!If get in line to visit the Conciergerie or Palais de la Cité, you can buy at the same time nthe ticket to visit la Sainte Chapelle and you do not have to make any line at all, so it is quite worth it.This is a magnificent chapel, it really was built as a giant reliquary to keep a nail from the holy cross, a large piece of the Holy Cross, and the most important, the crown of thorns. It is importan to mention that this items are not kept there anymore, they are at Notre Dam's Treasures, buy they were kept there for many years.

Stunning 11th century gothic chapel, stained glass like no other.... On the ile de la Citi the Sainte Chapelle is the part of the last remains of the Palais de la Citi built by Saint Louis in the centre of Paris. It's magnificent stained glass windows flood light into the upper floor depicting Old Testament books and have been restored beautifully.Well worth the €8.50 entry fee

Beautiful in the day, but book the stunning classical concert in the evening. I have visited Sainte Chapelle a couple of times before in the daytime. It must be the most beautiful church in Europe. It seems like the roof is floating on a wall of exquisite stained glass. This time I wanted to hear Vivaldi's Four Seasons in the Chapel. Tickets can be bought a few days before at the tabac over the street from the entrance, or for a little more on line on the day. The concert was at 7pm so the stained glass windows were glowing with the setting sun. As the concert progressed, the colour slowly faded as it got dark. The musicians were first rate and the violin soloist who featured most of the time was extraordinary. The atmosphere and acoustics were perfect. If you can afford to pay a little more for your ticket, this is the best possible way to experience this breathtaking work of art, Sainte Chapelle. In my top five things to do in Paris. My pictures do not do it justice.Tip: make sure you book, and arrive at least an hour before the concert to get your pick of seats.
Stained glass !. Stunning 12th century stained glass (can save you a trip to Chartres). Highly inefficient queue and staff detract from the experience. Get the audioguide and bring binoculars.
Amazing Glass Work and Arches. The place is amazing yet not KNown to all tourists. Long waiting line is disavantage - come early - I have waited One hour to enter
Favorite Church. Always a line, but it goes fast. This is one of my favorite sites in Paris, make it in your top 5 things to do. take binocs with you so you can see the stained glass

So very beautiful and colorful.... It took me 30 minutes of queuing to get in -- short in comparison to the late afternoon crowd, and the EUR 8.50 was worth it. Do note that you have to pay extra for an audio set for commentaries.The lower level was already quite impressive, though much less colourful than the upper level, which is where all the famous pictures come from. Once you ascend the narrow winding stairs and emerge from the stairwell, the sight of the chapel which greets you is breathtaking. I'm no churchgoer, but the colors and that soft, warm hue which bathes the high halls of the chapel, illuminated by the sunlight outside shining through the painted glass windows... it's so amazing and beautiful.I could've just sat in there and gaped at those gorgeous, colorful painted glass windows for hours. And when the church crew turned on the chandeliers hanging from the ceilings, it threw the hall into yet another kind of bright, glowing beauty.Do take a look if you're in Paris. If you like beautiful things, you should like this.
church. Classic historical gothic church. ground floor has beautiful fresco and stenciled decoration. Upper floor and church sanctuary reveals fin gothic architectural design
Beautiful. Not to be missed, this is a wonderful but small church, almost a chapel. Has to be seen from the inside to truly enjoy the stained glass windows

Breathtaking!. You will have to stand in line to go through the security screening, but it is worth the wait! The most beautiful stained glass in all of Europe. While standing in line, we read the posters and bought tickets for an evening chamber concert. if you can attend the earlier show, the sun was still up and lighting the windows through out the evening event. Truly magical!

Stunning Stained Glass. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see! The chapel, with its wonderful stained glass, is gorgeous. On our most recent visit, we had the opportunity to visit the chapel one evening, shortly before sunset, when we attended a marvelous Vivaldi concert. Anytime of the day, or early evening, is a good time to visit Sainte-Chapelle.
A must see. This place is absolutely gorgeous. I plan to go again to see the reflection on the stain glass. It's a little hard to find so ask if you get lost.

Beautiful!. What a beautiful chapel! After many trips to Paris, we finally made it here and it was worth it. Not a very long line to get in (in September) and such lovely, jewel-like windows with an interesting history.

Long Line, but worth it!. If you're a lover of stained glass then this is a can't miss for your trip. The line was very long and seemingly slow moving when we went, but once you step inside it is so worth it! Things to note: there are big laminated sheets (almost like a placemat) that you can grab in a variety of languages that point out various things you should pay attention to around the room. It can be overwhelming to step into an open space with lots of other bodies, but the cheat sheet helped a lot. And you'll want to just stand there staring up at the huge windows for a while anyway!

Rain. Perfect for a visit in the rain but one million other people must of had the same idea. Never mind. I've seen at least 200 churches and cathedrals around Europe , probably seen one as good , if not better. ( ie: church of the spilt blood at st Petersburg )

Vivaldi concert at Sainte Chapelle. This is the best way to see Sainte Chapelle. As the light streamed through those amazing windows we listened to an hour of chamber music. It was truly moving, and I know that sounds sappy. Can't recommend this highly enough.

ASTONISHING. Considering the age of the building and the techniques (and limitations) available to the builders, the achievement is both breath-taking and beautiful. But the atmosphere needs quietness and contemplation and the number of generally noisy tourists make that extremely difficult.
So beautiful. The queue can be kind of long, but it's well and truly worth it. A stunning chapel that you won't regret visiting.

awesome. Really a site that leaves you impression for its beauty . Fantastic .
Don't miss such a like beutiful thing . Windows, atmosphere and so on .
a place where stay to think

Interesting stained glass. Really interesting building, originally intended as a Holy Reliquary for artifacts acquired by Louis IX (subsequently St. Louis). Also recommended if you've been playing "Assassin's Creed: Unity"!

Stained glass galore at Sainte-Chapelle. We visited Sainte-Chapelle on the Paris Pass and had no wait to enter. The chapel is filled with beautiful stained glass and the floor is very ornate. We stopped by after going up the towers at Notre Dame Cathedral and before going to the Musee d'Orsay. The chapel is not that big but it has a large amount of stained glass, which is really magnificent.
Stunning. Stained glass well worth the visit. A place of great beauty. A highlight of my recent Pars visit. Must see.
Beautiful. We stopped in on a whim so I had no expectations. The stain glass is simply stunning. So happy we did this.

Best Attraction in Paris!. We decided to spend our time here, instead of tackling The Notre Dame. We had such a memorable experience! We went in the evening and were treated to a string quartet performance. It was magical listening to the gorgeous music, while watching the light pour through the unbelievable stain glass windows. Never have we seen such spectacular stain glass. You DON'T want to miss this unique treasure in Paris!

The King's Treasure Chapel on Ille.. Nicely tucked away inside of a governmental complex on the IIIe de la Cite', you'll discover this 2 story stained glass treasure trove. If you've bought your Paris Pass ticket, it's basically a no wait destination - if not, you wait in line. While visiting take the multilingual placard whole explains the Windows . After visiting, it's a short walk to Notre Dame cathedral.

Simply breathtaking stained glass!. I have been to a lot of cathedrals but I had never seen anything quite like this--the stained glass is simply breathtaking. I decided to avoid the long lines for security (the church is in the courthouse) and attended a concert from 7:00-8:00pm. In October, it was the perfect time to attend because I got there before the sun went down and the glass was still lit. Totally worth the price of the concert ticket and no wait in the security line.
Fantastic site. We were taken here by friends, and what a place! I had no idea what to expect and it really is amazing with the stained glass windows and ornate artwork. Very much worth visiting.

amazing. The most beautiful stained glass you will ever see.Simply amazingMy wife and I visited in September .We were supposed to spend an hour before lunch and were still there three hours later.The colours are wonderful

Great Windows. This is a tiny little church hidden from view behind Palais de Justice walls, with incredible windows. We waited on a long line on a cloudy, chilly day for about one hour to get a peek, and it was worth the wait. There is really nothing else to say but that the windows are the church, and they are beautiful.
Fantastic on a sunny day. Paris hidden treasure. This is a must for all visitors to Paris. Best on a sunny day when the colors become vibrant.

Glorious but humble Sainte-Chapelle. If I were given one chance to go to Paris and one place to visit, it would be a concert at Sainte-Chapelle. The beauty of the church is stunning--not like other churches. It has an upper chamber completely made of Fleurs-de-Lis. Some stained glass windows, but the Fleur-de-Lis makes my heart sing.I have visited Sainte-Chapelle three times and all three times I was lucky enough to enjoy an ensemble playing Vivaldi's Four Seasons, in the evening, by candlelight. In my entire life, perhaps due to the setting, but also the fine musicians, I have never enjoyed a concert so much. My husband and daughter felt the same.You have to check a schedule and see what is playing when.It may be a little hard to fine--a bit of a walk from Notre Dame, and somewhere near the police station. But everyone was so helpful to us--once you find it, you never let it go.

A deeply moving chapel. Everyone goes to Sainte-Chapelle. I first saw it (both downstairs and up) three decades ago, and several times since, the last time in May 2015 for an evening concert. The concert itself was not bad (mainly Vivaldi, nothing adventurous), but the surroundings in the upper chapel are beyond compare. The upper chapel was executed at a time when High Gothic lay great emphasis on soaring arches and windows so large that the interior, notwithstanding the extraordinary stained glass that fills every inch of the openings, has light of almost daylight intensity. It is actually difficult to believe that this chapel was constructed almost simultaneously with nearby Notre Dame, in a style that is far heavier. Sainte-Chapelle, which along with the Concergerie (also worth a visit) is nearly the only survivor of the original Capetian palace, needs a lot of time to absorb.

Wonderful, don't pass up due to line!. Sainte-Chapelle is one of my favorite sites in Paris. The stained glass is amazing and they limit numbers do you can actually move around. I great to see what the inside of Notre Dame must have looked like when it was original (painted). There are concerts here in the evenings that are wonderful.

breath taking. do not make the same mistake I did and wait for 45 minutes in the court room line. Same entrance two different lines. There is a pass line along side of Sainte-Chapelle. I saw the sign for pass and thought the very long line was for those who did not plan ahead.

An Unforgettable Gothic Medieval Church in the Heart of Paris....Saint Chapelle.. After Notre Dame, the three of us travellers from Asia had a quick Japanese lunch and sauntered to the nearby Sainte-Chapelle. The church interiors evoked of solemnity and makes one appreciative of the arts and crafts of medieval past. Located near the Palais de la Cité, Sainte Chapelle is a hallmark of a gothic medieval church in the very heart of Paris. My cousin a professional photographer was so enthralled by the interiors that we spent more than an hour appreciating the beautiful portals, stained glass on all the surrounding walls, the magnificent altar and the pillars of the church that meets at the center reflecting the theme of "Tree of Life". I counted 15 stained glass that reflected the afternoon sun and provided illuminating multi colored rays to the insides of the church. One rose stained window adorned the western portion of the church and I can't help but sit there for 15 minutes in silence to feel the solemnity of the chapel and marvel at this architectural wonder.

So amazing. . We weren't originally going to visit, however it was included in the museum pass, so we decided to check it out. We are so glad we did, this place is so very beautiful and stained glass is truly amazing. A great surprise! The only thing we couldn't help but notice was that some of the building was falling apart. Hopefully they are going to restore it.
Best stained glass of the trip!. Absolutely gorgeous windows! Definitely worth the wait to get in. You can really see that this church is very old and it really looks like it needs to be dusted!

Fabulous Stained Glass. The stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle is every bit as breath taking as you may have read. It is definitely a must see while in Paris and was one of the high points of our recent visit to this great city.

Must be amazing when the sun comes out!. We visited on the first Sunday of the month, when there is no admission charge, but had to contend with a 45-minute wait to get it. Understandable, given the circumstances. The entrance is very unassuming, as the church is located inside the Palais de Justices de Paris, but once inside, the lower level certainly does not prepare you for the splendor of the upper chapel! The windows are amazing, and sadly, we visited on a cloudy day, so I can only assume how spectacular they must be on a bright, sunny day! Grab one of the information cards at the entrance to the chapel to pin-point each of the windows and its significance. Try to follow each of the stories from the bible. Sadly, our experience was marred by a large scaffold hiding the rose window at the far end of the room, but with buildings this old, there is bound to be some restoration work being done eventually, and I guess the scaffold is a good trade-off to Sainte-Chapelle closing completely. All in all, worth the wait, but I would definitely return on a sunnier day!

My favorite church in Paris.. My favorite church in Paris. Not big, and not beautiful from the outside, but so amazing inside, especially when the sun hits the windows. The church often has special small concerts in the evenings. Well worth attending.

A jewel in the heart of the city. With sunlight flowing in through the splendid stained glass windows, Sainte Chapelle is transformed into a place of outstanding beauty, a jewel box hidden in the heart of the city. Richly painted and decorated, this inspirational place of worship since medieval times is well worth visiting. Truly astounding.

Beautiful Chapel and very interesting stain glass paintings. The visit to Sainte-Chappele is much smoother compared to the more popular Notre Dame. It is very close to Metro station Cite and St. Michael offering excellent connectivity.The Chapel itself is beautiful with its large stained glass windows . It is a good place to visit.Only small thing to complain about is the entry fees. I felt the 8.5 euros is a bit steep.

Don't bother, watch the video.. Loooong, looong queues all the time we were there. While we were there the tour groups bypassed the regular queue, adding to the waiting time. Also the street you queue on is a wind tunnel so very cold.

The Jewell box of France. Aptly nick named the 'Jewel Box', this 13th century royal chapel is an ABSOLUTE must-see for all travellers. Its architecture is amazing with a huge percentage of its walls made entirely of incredibly beautiful stained glass windows. It is a miracle they have survived for so many centuries!. The low ceilinged bottom floor [entry level] of the chapel is impressively ornate, but when you climb the twisty little medieval stairs to the second floor, the chapel reserved uniquely for the king, your jaw will literally drop. The soaring walls of richly colored stained glass will take your breath away. If possible go on a day that is not very sunny, as the bright light can diminish the richness of the windows' colours.

Go on a sunny day. Beautiful stained glass...don't forget the upper floor...the real showpiece...we almost missed it! Easy entrance today because we had bought a combo ticket and visited the Conciergerie first. By-passed a long long line because of this!
Must See. My Mom's second pick to visit so glad we saw the stories of bible depicted in stained glass. Circular Steps may challenge those folks who aren't able to climb.

So beautiful. The stained glass windows in this small chapel are stunningly beautiful. We attended a concert here one evening and had the opportunity to see the windows change with the setting sun. Highly recommend it -- you get to visit the chapel without the crowds!
auditory and visual delight. Evening concert was delightful. Music was exceptional and listening while the sun set and the light faded through the magnificent stained glass windows made it special.

Skip the line with tickets purchased at Door #2. Absolutely beautiful Chapel! Skip the line by going to Door #2 and purchasing tickets to enter the Chapel. The line outside on the street is waiting to go through security and then will wait in line again inside to purchase tickets.

Gorgeous Sainte-Chapelle Cathedral. Recently took at trip with my daughter and spent some time in Paris. On our first day in town we hit a few of the beautiful cathedrals in the center of town. Sainte-Chapelle was really stunning. The outside looks old and brown. The ground floor is pretty enough. But I was unprepared for the main chapel as I climbed the narrow spiral stairs. The stained glass windows make up most of the walls, with remarkable effect. It was really humbling to see the faith and craftsmanship that went into this beautiful edifice. Don't miss this one.
Superb. Very beautiful church with stained glass. Don't forget the upper floor.There was a queue but it went quick.

Amazing Stained Glass on Display!. What a beautiful place. The windows are spectacular and the story of it's reason for being is very interesting. We had to stand in line for about an hour but it was worth it.
Must see it.. It's really amazing! But, I didn't like to make...shopping into a church! They sake souvenirs into it!
A must see. The most beautiful church I have ever see. It was built in 7 years only by saint Louis. It use the store the spike crown of Jesus. You must know the visit is for free if you are under 26.
Beautiful!. Beautiful stained glass. Don't be intimidated by the line. It can be long but moves quickly. Be patient. It is worth the wait!
Pouring down rain!. The day we were there it was raining heavily. But the amazing stained glass was brilliant even on a dreary day!
Breathtaking. Went on a Sunday afternoon and waited in line for approximately 30 minutes. This place has the most amazing stained glass I have ever seen and photos do not do it justice!

beautiful flamboyant architecture,but beware if you are of a certain age.. Get a special ticket to not stand in line to visit. I stood in line for a minimum of 1 1/2 hour. They only let so many people in, so you stand. It is the security (tight) that holds up the visit. The lower church is all I was able to visit. Otherwise, you need to climb a very narrow staircase with uneven steps, and due to the standing in line (besides my age), I could not continue upward. But the lower church as well and the architecture is stunning.

Stunning!. What a stunning building; a must do in Paris. The stained glass is unbelievable. You don't have to allocate a lot of time to the visit but get there on opening time (join the queue if one) and entry is pretty straight forward. We didn't pay to see the consierge as well because we didn't know what it was at the time and the significance wasn't explained, but now I wished we had.

Great concert. Great place to see a music concert. When we were in Paris recently, we went to see Vivaldi's 4 season. Great lively rendition of an old favourite and the opportunity to see this beautiful church. Well worth it !

Mesmerizing Indeed. Sainte-Chapelle is considered to be one of the most beautiful chapels with a Gothic architecture. The most famous features of the chapel are the great stained glass windows which will leave you in awe. The sight of majestic 13th century stained glasses will ensure that your eyes are only stuck to them during the entire duration you are in. Also, not to forget, the lower chapel has beautiful royal blue and golden domes that is a mesmerizing sight in itself. Though you might have to brave an one hour queue to get in, its totally worth it.

A treasure. It is a treasure. The ancient walls and stained glass speak to you. The light that comes through the windows makes pattern in the floor. It is a very ancient building but surprisingly modern in some ways because it is an intimate space.
Awe Inspiring!. This chapel is just awe inspiring. For someone that loves stained glass windows, this is heaven. The King was one lucky man to have had his own private chapel. Go, you won't be sorry!

Beautiful! A must see!. I drug my husband to Sainte Chapelle early in the morning when we had an afternoon excursion to Versailles planned. He really didn't want to go since it was on the other side of town from our hotel and would require a cab but I had seen some photos online and knew I absolutely had to see it. We had to stand in line for about 45 minutes to get inside and - when you initially enter you see the shopping area where they have postcards and paper weights and stuff for sale - but once you go up the small staircase and come out into the actual chapel - it's gorgeous! The 17 (?) stained glass windows date back to the 11th-12th century and, according to the paperwork I saw inside the chapel, over 70% of the glass is original.
A Paris must see.. We returned to view the recently restored stain glass windows which was well worth the 45 minute wait to pass through security.

stunning church. This building and its decoration and stain glass windows are stunning and well worth a visit. We arrived at 9.15am and even though we had the museum pass you still need to line up on the main queue and there is no fast entry. They let the groups in first at 9.30am when it opens and then it takes a while before they let the people on the main queue in so we waited about 20 minutes to get in as fhere were about 40 people ahead of us. The church is not very large so there is a limit to how many they let in at a time so you can end up waiting a while to get in. The stain glass windows and chapel decorations are stunning and its a beautiful place to visit and so its worth waiting for.

Great Vivaldi Concert. Enter the jewel box of Sainte-Chapelle and get ready for a truly memorable experience. It is a magnificent room and just perfect for a Violin Concert. The acoustics are nearly perfect and the Windows take your breath away. Such a treat when in Paris.

This is an Important Monument from a Catholic Saint, Saint Louis, King of France.. Saint Louis built this right next to his palace (now a court of justice). Saint Louis would go to mass there via a passage that went directly from his palace to the splendid upper chapel of the Sainte Chapelle. This chapel's walls are filled with very many stained glass windows, showing scenes from the Bible. During mass, Saint Louis sat under the stained glass windows showing the kings of Israel as provided in the Old Testament's books of Chronicles and Kings. Of course, this was an appropriate spot for a man who himself was a king. His mother sat across from him on the other side of this chapel during mass, a woman who had much responsibility for Saint Louis' holiness.  Over the altar at the front end of the chapel was the crown of thorns Christ wore and slivers of the cross on which he was crucified. Saint Louis had purchased the crown of thorns from the Byzantine emperor, who was in need of money at the time. Saint Louis built the Sainte Chapelle to put the crown of thorns in. (The crown of thorns is no longer in the Sainte Chapelle, though, but kept in a safe place in Paris' Notre Dame Cathedral.) I did not think the stained glass windows of the Sainte Chapelle, individually, impressive works of art, but all together they are impressive. To have the wall of a church filled with glass was a new and outstanding accomplishment in architecture at the time, and remains an impressive accomplishment today. There is a lower chapel in the Sainte Chapelle which was built for the general public in Saint Louis' day, but the upper chapel is the memorable part of this building.

Classical music concerts. The best part of going to Saint Chapelle is to take advantage of the classical music concerts offered in the evening (check their website). I would recommend the earlier 7 PM concert (we attended the 8 PM) so that you can enjoy the light coming through the windows. There is no point in purchasing better seats, everyone is close and the acoustics are fantastic. You can buy tickets on-line with a fee or purchase them at the church. Don't expect to tour the church during the concert, you are basically lead in and then lead out. We visited earlier in the day and it is worthwhile for both trips. It was a very relaxing evening to end our Paris trip.

Stunning little chapel with brilliant history. Who knew the Passion relics were once housed here, that the chapel is an extremely large reliquary in its own right, constructed under the direction of King Louis IX, damaged during the French Revolution, but retaining some of the oldest and most stunning stained glass in all of France?We were fortunate to visit on a day in which the Chapel was the venue for a Concert (Vivaldi), and if you have this opportunity, seize it.We combined the visit with a tour of the Notre Dame Treasures for a delightful afternoon.

Stunning Building and Beautiful Music. This review is for our second visit to the building. This is one of my favorite buildings in all of Europe so we made a point of returning for a baroque concert held in the evening after it is otherwise closed. This is a magnificent setting for a concert and the musicians were superb. A wonderful experience and money well spent.
Worth the wait! Absolutely beautiful!!!. Absolutely beautiful!!! The beauty is breathtaking! A must see while in Paris! Well worth the wait in line.

Visited Sainte-Chapelle at Paris on 21 August 2015. I along with my dear wife visited the historical royal mediev Sainte-Chapelle located near Palais de la City which is in the heart of Paris. I will recommend the visitors of Paris that must find some time to visit awesome stained glass Sainte-Chapelle famous Cathedral. It is now national monument since 1862. In size it is smaller than Notre Dame.

Jewel Box of a Building. A jewel of a structure in the heart of Paris. Still standing after 800 years. A must see for anyone visiting Paris.. The stain glass works are stunning. I also attended a solo violin performance in the evening and the acoustics of the chapel is amazing.
Beautiful Stained Glass. Sainte-Chapelle is highly regarded for it's stained glass windows. It is worth visiting to see them. It does not take a lot of time and is on the Paris Pass.

Beautiful!. Do not overlook going to the second floor which is where the stunningly beautiful stained glass is. There is an elevator if you need it...simply ask the museum staff. Try to visit on a sunny day...very important as you won't get the full effect of the colors. Enjoy!
Beautiful windows.. The most beautiful stained glass windows, dating back to the 1400's, they are presently being restored so we will return when we can see the whole effect.
The glass windows in wonderful colours. I went there many years ago!. A bit difficult to find because it is behind the Palais de Justice in front of Notre Dame de Paris but absolutely Worth visiting!
Breath-taking on a sunny day. Astonishing that most of the stained glass is original! Breath-taking, especially on a sunny day when the sun shines in on all the stained glass.

Hidden Gem!. I don't think you hear much about this chapel - it is behind gates and security in the middle of the courts, so it is a little difficult to find. It is right around the corner from Notre Dame and visiting it after Notre Dame is a great comparison and contrast. The windows are beautiful and since it is smaller, the experience is more intimate. There are narrow, windy stairs to climb, but not too many. Be very aware of the time it closes, they stop letting people in about 30 minutes before and the line was quite long - we were one of the last groups to make it in, many were turned away. This was another attraction where the Museum Pass came in handy - would highly recommend getting one!

Very Pretty. Impressive but either get in line a half hour before it opens or check the line length later in the day as space is limited. People are allowed to enter only when people inside leave so the line moves very slow. Try to go when the sun is out. Need to go through security, no sharp metal objects are allowed. Information is available in English in the upstairs area where the stained glass windows are located.
Jewel Box. A jewel box, but needs some restoration. Exquisite stained glass windows. Lovely chamber music concert.

Gorgeous! Fabulous place to attend a concert of classical music.. Even if you're "churched-out", you shouldn't miss this breathtaking chapel. Arrive early in the day or expect a long line to get in.Hint: If you're attending a concert there and arrive early enough, you'll be able to walk around, so there's no need to pay to come in at another time. (It's not cheap.)

An all time favorite Cathedral. As t his is much smaller than the famous Notre Dame, I highly recommend not missing the beautiful stained glass in Sainte-Chapelle. There will be a long line, but it is well worth it. The PMP is accepted here, however, the day we went, there was free admission.

Take a Pass on This. It was very nice but not worth the hour wait in line. Very disappointing that the passes we purchased did not allow us to avoid the cue. If you have extra time and you are in the area, then it may be worth visiting. Otherwise there are so many better things to do and see.
MUST-SEE. This is one of my absolute favorite places in Paris. I love the stained glass and the gothic-styled architecture. It's a must-see!!

What aBeautiful Sight!!!. This is part of a complex that also includes Palais de Justice and La Conciergerie. Sainte-Chapelle is a masterpiece of Gothic architecture; the roof appears to be supported by stained-glass so that this magical space feels like the inside of a jewel. The stained-glass will leave you speechless. This is a MUST see. It took a while to get in because of the heavy security.

Penny worth spending. We went on a weekday in the morning and had to wait in queue for maybe half an hour. By the time we left (at around 11 30 something) the queue was hardly 2-3 people. The Chapel had an entry fee (around 13 Euros) but my wife and I really liked the place. The murals, their beauty, their precision, the details in them…All of it was really worth it. A must visit. If you could read about it before going you may be able to appreciate it better

Beautiful glass works!. Absolutely stunning space up the spiral staircase to the stain glass hall with good audio commentary. Buy both tickets for the Conciergery as well, as this was of great historical interest especially fir those interested in the revolution. It presented the actual condition in which the prisoners waiting the Guillotine had to endure. There was a preserved area where Marie Atoinette was kept for a few years while awaiting her finale. Not yo be missed

Magical. This review is actually for the evening classical music concerts held in the chapel. We heard a 5 piece string ensemble with harpsichord perform Vivaldi ' s 4 seasons. The performance was very good with an interesting arraignment of the classic. The setting was almost the main attraction. We were seated while the sun was setting and the stain glass windows were still glowing and the acoustics seemed very good to my untrained ears. It's only about an hour but worth the money.

Stunning and beuatiful chapel. This is one of my favorite sites in Paris. I love the intimacy of the space and of course the stained glass windows. I've been here twice before, but my husband and I came here in February. The line was long because it was right before they close in the afternoon, so the wait was awhile even on a February weekday. But it was still as beautiful as I remembered it. I also like that they have the laminated guides so you can read what each panel is about. Note there isn't much seating. There's are also concerts on Sunday nights, so next time I go that would be a great way to see the chapel!A definite must see in Paris

Stunning Windows in Historic Chapel. I had visited there 20 years ago and remembered beautiful stained-glass windows, but nothing about the chapel's history. Fortunately on this visit we decided to rent the audio tour - a must if you aren't with a tour guide. The details on the windows are overwhelming without an explanation. Amazing history in an exquisite setting! And although you have to wait in a line the tickets are free. Put this on your list!

Worth the wait. We pre-bought tickets to Sainte-Chapelle and still had a 30 minute line to get in. Even though it was my second time visiting it was amazing. This chapel contains the most beautiful stained glass window display anyone has ever seen.

A jewel of a chapel worthy of your attention and presence.. This was the first time I could ever get into Saint Chappelle without the scaffolding - it was worth the wait. Instantly you got a greater sense of the intimacy I this private chapel. Nicely restored with and excellent commentary on the extensive work that has been done. Very worth while as attested to by the. Throngs of tourists like me who wanted to see this architectural marvel first hand.

Glorious Chapel in the Heart of Paris. This intimate chapel has the most beautiful stained glass that changes in color intensity throughout the day. What a delight. The chapel offers chamber concerts, with tickets available online. The combination of the music and the stained glass changing with the setting sun was truly sublime. Seek this chapel out and if you are able, be amazed by a concert within this magnificent space.
Wow!. Beautiful! Went to a concert and it was amazing. The place and the music made for a magical evening.
Breathtaking.. This space was mesmerizing. All the details, work that was put into this is breathtaking. I am so glad we did this, and waited in line. So worth it.

Amazing stained glass windows!. This chapel has the most beautiful and largest stained glass windows we've ever seen. It is truly a marvel and a feast for the eyes. It proved to be a magnificent, awe-inspiring experience. I'ts on the Paris card and easily done with Notre Dame.

Don’t be put off by the line, it moves quickly. The finest stained glass we have seen anywhere.
Don’t overlook the many fine statues and the delicately painted stonework which surrounds the windows.
Awesome stained glass chapelle. Stunningly beautifully stained glass chapel that was still amazing even though we had to visit it on a gray and rainy day.

Must-see place in Paris. This place is and unbelievably beautiful, MUST-see in Paris. You will definitely be delighted by wonderful, breathtaking stained-glass windows. Try to visit Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny day and be prepared to stand for 40-50 minutes in a queue (visited this place in the end of September, Museum Pass did not allow priority pass here), but be sure that is worth and, in my opinion, much more beautiful than famous Notre-Damme.

Awe inspiring. Go on a sunny day so that the stained glass windows show their true beauty.The spiral staircase up to the chapel is a good way to approach it because as you step out at the top you will be awed by the beauty in contrast to the confining staircase.

Exquisite. A very small jewel box of a Chapel....The stained glass windows are the most beautiful in Paris. A few times a week there are small musical recitals in the Chapel: well worth the trip, especially as the windows are illuminated by the setting sun

A must see. This is a must. Located within the Conciergerie, you must pass security to enter, but it is well worth the effort. It is a beautiful small gothic church constructed by St. Louis with stunning stained glass.

Beautiful St. Chapelle. What an amazing Chapel with gorgeous stained glass. The line seemed long but it actually moved very fast so don't give up if you see a long time, we went in after only 10 minutes.

Seven years to restore, and worth every minute. Impressive on the outside, but the real beauty lies within. The stained glass and the ornately painted arches and other architectural components are breathtaking. The altar is particularly fabulous. If you don't spend an hour or two taking this treasure, then you are missing a visual treat.

go early. Arrive before it opens to avoid the lines. Use the big cards that explain the panels. Would have gone for a night time concert if I had more time...go to the souvenir shop across the street to buy tickets.

Stained Glass Treasure. Just a couple of blocks down from Notre Dame is the Sainte-Chapelle, a chapel that contains some of the most beautiful stained glass windows in Europe. The entrance is shared with the Court Palais so there's a security line before entering. Once inside, check out the richly-colored first floor but BE SURE to climb the winding stone staircase to the second floor.You'll be pleasantly astonished by enormous liturgical windows of all colors. Truly amazing.

Breathtaking. The most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen. Worth the wait to get in, which was about an hour. This small chapel is close to Notre Dame, and contains the oldest wall painting in Paris. I did not realize until I climbed to the upper chapel how breathtaking the windows would be.

If you love Gothic stained glass, go here.. This is a gothic church built on the Ile de La Cite, very close to Notre Dame Cathedral. The windows are original Gothic stained glass and give you a heavenly feeling when you enter the second floor.

A must see in Paris. This is an amazing place, two chapels in a place which was the first residence of the Kings of France. There is a long line to see this place, it is better to get there before 10 AM, when the line is smaller.

Chamber music concerts provide set entry time and extended stay. Beautiful, amazing, breathtaking--what else can one say about Sainte-Chapelle? Buy tickets to one of the evening concerts and gain access at a guaranteed time, plus a chance to sit and linger, marveling at the stained glass while listening to some excellent chamber music.

Perhaps the Most Wonderful Human Creation on the Planet. We try to visit the Sainte Chapelle each time we come to Paris. It is truly a wondrous, uplifting spot. One of the delights is to see the expression on the face of each first -time visitor as he or she enters the upper room after climbing the rather difficult spiral staircase. The "Wow" factor is universal. Built in the 1400s to house holy relics purchased from the declining Byzantine Empire it is a triumph of late mediaeval stained glass. How the walls with so much glass and so little stone has survived all Paris has been through is a minor miracle. Definitely a "Must See." Don't leave Paris without seeing it, on a sunny day if possible. You have to pass through a metal detector so remember to leave Swiss Army knives etc. with the tobacconist across the street.

The Glory of High Gothic Architecture and Glass. Little Useful to say after all the other reviews e tolling the wonders of this temple of stained glass. Only suggestion is thus is a place to arrive at least 20 minutes before opening, even on off season as your Paris museum pass does not allow you to bypass the security screening line.

Worth a visit. Simple ... its awesome. I cannot quite explain the colours reflecting through all that stained glass. Situated very close to Notre Dame (5mins away on foot) St Chapelle is worth a visit
Stunning!. What an absolutely beautiful stained glass display! A museum pass is a must to avoid the huge second line inside - so thankful we had that pass!

Stunning. This is a stunning church to visit, the stained glass is just gorgeous. My advice is to buy tickets for the evening concert, you can do this on line. Also, go to the early performance, that way the church is still lit from outside by the sun and you can enjoy the beautiful stained glass windows.

Breathtaking. I went in summer about 5pm and the queue was fast moving. It was really crowded inside the chapelle which made it awkward to stay longer. However the stained glasses were so breathtakingly beautiful. Definitely worth visiting. I prefer this over Notre Dame though.

Must see for stained glass windows. The line into Sainte-Chapelle was long, and I was hoping that it would be worth the wait in the rain. I was not disappointed. In fact, the space really was breathtaking. I would highly recommend taking the time to see Sainte-Chapelle.
Breathtaking -- a must do. Worth the long wait to get inside. Breathtaking stained glass brings tears to the eyes as soon as you've climbed the stairs.
Must see in Paris. A short walk from Notre Dame, Sainte-Chapelle has famous stained glass windows in an intimate atmosphere that contrasts with the usual grandiose church.

Pretty stain glass!. The prettiest stain glass windows!
Beautiful little chapel just around the corner from Notre Dame Cathedral
They limit the number of visitors soothe wait can be long.

Amazing . The stained glass alone in this church makes it worth a stop. Be prepared to stand in line for awhile because they only allow so many people in at one time. Just a heads up, we bought our tickets online through the tourism office which actually granted us skip the line privilege...some others had purchased the Paris Museum pass and we're not granted the same privilege and we're not too happy but it saved us from waiting in line for what would of been over an hour.

Evening concert...be sure to go before dark if possible. I first visited Saint Chapelle in 2011 and my jaw dropped after climbing to second floor and entering the unique and magnificent chapel. For me it is all about the stained glass windows since the upper three quarters of the walls are stained glass. We jumped at the chance this visit to go to an evening concert there...Vivaldi and Pachelbel. This was scheduled for 7 pm, it was September and still daylight, therefore the magnificent stained glass windows could still be appreciated. Not so by the time we left. While still an impressive room, i would have been sorely disappointed to come in for the later hour concert without seeing the colors of the glass and I thought I would mention that. Do come and enjoy.

A place that will take your breath away. This has to be one of the most beautiful places I've seen. There are huge queues to get in but if you buy a 'double ticket' for the Palais of Justice and the chapelle (they are side by side), you can fast track the queue.

You Have To See It. The stained glass in this church is enough of a reason to visit, it is stunning. I went to a classical concert here, and that is highly recommended also. It is on one of the islands of the Seine, the center of Paris pretty much. It is just a storied, wonderful church.

Holy Stained Glass!. The inside of Sainte-Chapelle is gorgeous. The stained glass windows are beautiful with the light shining through them. This church might not be a great visit for someone that is unsteady on their feet as there are some narrowing and winding steps to go up to reach the main room with the stained glass. If you can get tickets ahead of time, I highly recommend it. The line to purchase tickets was quite long but worth it.

My favorite experience in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle was stunning. I loved every moment within it.To get inside, two lines form outside the government building. One line was for the government access and the other was for the Sainte-Chapelle. The line took about 25 minutes. When we were there, there was no queue for the Museum Pass.This is a small structure and has two stories. The lower level is wonderful and deserves to be soaked in. However, the upper level is perhaps one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. Stained glass circles the second level. There are 12 pillars (one for each Apostle.) There are 12 section of stained glass (one per Book in the Bible.) This means each glass section is unique. I loved it.If possible, try to go on a somewhat sunny day. When the sun hits that glass, it is a memory you will never forget.Sainte-Chapelle is truly a gift.

Exquisite. Neither words nor photos can describe the exquisite and ethereal beauty of this chapel. Notre Dame is the Martha to Sainte-Chapelle's Mary.
If you visit only one church in France, visit Sainte-Chappelle
Hidden Gem. Highly recommend visiting La Sainte-Chapelle - we first visit it every time we go to Paris, its absolutely beautiful. The upper chapel is a wonderful surprise the first time you visit.

Stunning church, frequently overlooked. Get there early to avoid the queues to see some of the most spectacular stained glass windows in France. Floor to ceiling windows up a small flight of stairs, tucked away in a courtyard not far from Notre Dame, this is definitely worth a visit.

Not Impressed. We waited in line almost one hour to get in. We had our museum passes and were so glad we did not pay to see this. It is a small chapel and although the stain glasses is beautiful, we saw more impressive glass in Notre Dame just down the street and there was not wait. We felt this was a waste of our time.

Not just another Church!. The renovations have now been completed & the centuries old stained glass windows & panels are at their stunning best. I know many people get tired of visiting churches & cathedrals but this place is unique. It's not a huge dark space full of enormous columns, high vaults & ceilings etc like these other places. Rather its a small two level chapel that is a manageable size thus allowing easy viewing of the magnificent windows. Queues waiting to get in can be long but I can assure you the wait will be worth it. Don't miss it.
Amazing Stained Glass Art. The stained glass panels are magnificent. The details are amazing. A must visit. You should go here very early and have a Paris pass so you can cut your qeue.

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Beautiful, the day I visited the sun was shining and the room seemed to be a rose colour.
