Wow! What A View of Magnificent Stained Glass. The view of the stained glass windows when you walk through the tiny door to the second floor almost knocks you down! You are so close it is almost overwhelming. I have never seen stained glass windows up this close. The laminated guide that tells you the story of each window is very helpful. Don't miss this jewel of a church. Another good thing is there was not a huge crowd so we got to spend as much time as we wanted viewing the church.

Hidden Gem. Less visited then bigger counterparts, this is a beautiful, inspiring, religious edifice stuck in the middle of the securities force compound. One line goes to the chapel, the other is for visitors to the jail. The first floor has you wondering why you made the effort. Don't be put off. Upstairs is stunning. If you are lucky enough to avoid heavy crowds, this is a wonderful place to move from stained glass window to stained glass window, and then enjoy the beauty of the altar. I could have easily been persuaded to worship here twice a day. The graceful arches, gold and blue hues and vibrant stained glass are unsurpassed.

Best stained glass in Europe. This chapel in the shadows of Notre Dame has the best stained glass in all of Europe; and most of it is original. Just be sure not to be misled by the small chapel on the ground floor; go up the stairs to main sanctuary, the windows soar above you.

Beautiful and valued. Im waiting at least 1 hr in the line to buy the ticket. It will be much better if you can buy ticket before coming or museum pass.
Inside is very beautiful with color mirror! Valued to wait and see.
PS. Less and dirty Toillet here!!!

Worth the line. Other than the long long line to get in, it was quite beautiful and the stained glass was spectacular. Amazing to think it was built in the 13th century and is still standing. Worth a visit!

Amazing Stained Glass. Sainte Chapelle may have the most beautiful stained glass windows in Europe.
My wife and I noted that even difficult to impress teenagers were awed as they climbed the last step up into the chapel and saw the glorious windows.
Expect to wait in line to enter.
magnificent. the first floor is beautiful but wait til you see the upper level. WOW, it takes your breath away. I've never seen such magnificent stained glass.

WOW. What can I say but WOW -- the stained glass is awe inspiring -- don't be put off by the line -- it is a small space and they let only a certain number in at a time. Climb the stairs to the second level and be ready to see stained glass!
Vivaldi soud inside the chapel. Except the beauty of the construction and the stained glasses if you could find on your stay period tickects for a concert don't miss it. It is fantastic.
Go early or at noon. Beautiflul glass. Must go up and down spiral stairs to view it. Go early (9:30 opening) or noon time to avoid long waiting line to get in.
Beautiful and unique. The cathedral was gorgeous from the inside with intricate stain glass. Smaller than expected from what visitors can view but worth the visit. Less crowds than Notre Dame.

Hands down the best church worth seeing!!!. I had low expectations for this chapel since I had very little interest in going to touristy attractions in my vacation. However, this was an absolute treat and worth the wait in line! When we first walked in I was thinking, "Oh yeah...this is nice. I have no idea why my boyfriend thought this was so great." But then we walked upstairs...it took my breath away. It was like walking into the inside of a huge pink jewel. The riser colored light they filled the room was so peaceful (even in the unbearable summer heat) and the detail in the stained glass windows was exquisite. I highly recommend going to this chapel. It was well worth the trip. And I suggest going on a sunny day when you can really see the windows shine.
excellent piece of french history. A very charming building steeped in history . it shows French artitecure at its best. A must see if you get a chance.

Vivaldi: The Four Seasons at Ste Chapelle. Attended a string quartet concert at Ste Chapelle that was the highlight of my Paris visit. It was a surreal experience in the restored 13th century chapel. The early evening sun played beautifully through the stained glass. Concerts are held periodically and can be found on their website. No need to dress up.

Beautiful Medieval Cathedral - Better than Notre Dame. We were 'wowed' by this beautiful chapel that's only a few blocks away from Notre Dame. This chapel's walls are covered in stained glass. We were there in the afternoon & it glistened with color! Notre Dame's exterior is impressive but we saw it after Sainte-Chapelle, so Notre Dame seemed dark & very gothic

Uneventful. The holy chapel at Sainte Chapelle =save your time and euros. It is dilapidated and out of the way. Dedicated history buffs, knock yourself out. Even the people selling souvenirs inside were either falling asleep or making more money selling post cards of the Eiffel Tower. It's a very tight squeeze and turn to go upstairs to see stained glass. Although it is my passion, I was in and out in 5 minutes. I didn't even take pictures, there is one on my ticket.

A favorite and so much more beautiful than Notre Dame inside.. This was my second visit to Paris and Sainte-Chapelle. Whenever I hear someone is going to Paris, I tell them they must find this church! It's on the same island as Notre Dame but does not have the crowds. To me it is so much more beautiful than Notre Dame because it is smaller, more colorful, and not as dark. It has the most amazing stained glass I've ever seen. So much that it's hard to believe the church can stand. Built by King Louis IX, later to become Saint Louis. The upper chapel was only used for he and his family. This trip I purchased the audio tour and it was so worth it to really hear and understand all about this amazing chapel. So glad I went a second time and did this. It can be a bit hard to find as it is located behind the Palais de Justice which was built in front of it at some point in time. There is a sign on a building just past the huge gate of the Palais de Justice telling you this is where the line for Sainte-Chapelle is. This also means that you have to go through extra security screening of bags, etc. not because of the church itself, but because of the security for the Palais de Justice. Not a big deal, but does make the line move a bit slower. Reading other reviews I cannot believe people say it's not worth it or the price of admission. Yes, I've been in some amazing churches in Rome, Sienna, Dublin, Pisa, Venice, London, Paris just to name a few over the years. If there is a church or cathedral, I want to see it as they all have a piece of history or something beautiful be it the alter, floors, chapels, paintings, sculptures, etc. Yes, this is not as huge as St. Peter's or Notre Dame, but to realize the stained glass tells the stories of the Old and New Testament running up and down the length of each of these stained glass panels...amazing! Honestly, if you want to go in and out quickly just to say you went, if you only have 1 day in Paris, or if you have small children with you and will be distracted, don't bother. Read the history of this place and I think you will agree it's worth your time.

Beautiful House of God . We came for a concert and it was lovely to get to observe the windows and listen to beautiful music. This is one of the most stunning stained glass displays I have seen in many years of church visits.

A wall of Stained Glass. The gothic chapel, as you enter, is stunning, but then when you go up the spiral staircase to the main chapel, you are met with almost a wall of stained glass on all sides. It is one of the best examples of a stained glass church you will find anywhere in the world. Simply stunning.

Never got inside. Waited in line only to have them close for a period of time. We understand that this is more beautiful then Notre Dame. Plan your trip and try to buy advance tickets, plus they do not allow back packs in the church.
Must see. Short lines and stunning interior. Well worth an hour or so. Go on a sunny day to fully appreciate the beauty of the stained glass windows.

Stain Glass and that's it. Must see windows, detailing is exquisite. However last time i went most of the building was under renovation hence there really wasn't much else + the lines were quite long, perhaps 20 min wait

Don't miss this gem. for one of the most breathtaking experiences in Paris be sure to visit sainte-Chappelle. when you enter and get your first glimpse of the floor to cieling stained glass masterpieces you will never be Quite the same. their beauty and stunning presence will leave you gasping. Very impressive.

Awesome. This was on my back up list of churches to see. BUT...it was breathtaking. It's amazing how much stain glass is in the church. From the outside, it looks kinda plain, like a skeleton. But once inside, just beautiful. We had the museum pass, but everyone had to stand in the same line, the day we went.

Spectacular Gothic Beauty. Today I took a couple of visiting friends. They explored the magnificent church on their on so I decided to rent the audioguide and learn more about the stories in the ABSOLUTELY UNBELIEVABLY BEAUTIFUL stained glass. It was very soothin to lean against a wall, look up at a window and hear the narrator tell me about who was doing what, where, why the colors were chosen, which panes of glass date all the way back to the 13th century. I've been a few times and it is beautiful in all kinds of light. If you can, go at sunset....heartbreakingly beautiful play of light through the colored slivers of glass. Allow at least an hour. We spent about 90 minutes and felt that we had just scratched the surface.

Amazing concert at La Sainte Chapelle. We booked this concert with Classictic for July 21st. My wife and I had never attended a classical concert before and we were delighted with the music and the setting. La Sainte Chapelle is a 13th. Century chapel sourounded by court buildings. You have to go through these areas to get to the chapel. However, once you are inside you are met by huge stain glass windows and beautiful architecture. We passed the chapel a day earlier and saw people lined up by the hundreds to get a look inside. The concert consisted of three violinists, a cello, and a harpsichord. The program was Vilvaldi's The Four Seasons. We were lucky enough to be seated in the Vip section (five rows back) because the musicians played off each other, sometimes funny and sometimes seriously. Their expressions at points were priceless. The building seemed as if it was meant for this music. I highly recommend you give this a try. One note of caution. If you just want to visit the chapel several people told us that they waited on line for a couple of hours before they got in. Frank44d
Must See. The windows are exquisite...small but powerful chapel...we did the Paris pass...best way to save money and see the sites!
Extraordinary chapel!. This chapel took our breath away! We were not expecting to be in awe of these gorgeous stained glass windows. Well worth the extra time in addition to Notra Dame.

Royal Paris..... Known as the Holy Chapel of Louis IX, used to gather all the most important religious relics of Christ. Now a days, its a beautiful display of vitro's and stained glasses maintaining the gothic architecture and the impeccable decorations. The first view you get when you enter will blow your mind but its a little pricey for such a small place (around 12 euros unless you get the paris pass). Still, its something different to see if you are in the area.

An evening listening to Vivaldi at Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass is worth the visit to Sainte-Chapelle alone, but if you have the time check out classictickets.com and book tickets to listen to a performance. The music is wonderful and if you are there in the evening when the sun shines through the windows the view is breathtaking.

Amazing Stained Glass. We found the stained glass even more impressive than Norte Dame's. Arrive early to avoid the crowds. Once inside take the spiral staircase on the left to the Haute chapel where the stained glass panels are huge and very detailed.
Beautiful. Another great architectural building with so much history. Just beautiful with the stained glass windows and high ceilings and long columns. A must visit

Amazing venue for a concert. We went to an evening concert of Pachobels Canon and Vivaldis Four Seasons. The music was beautiful, the performance was fun and entertaining and the room was stunning. Go early for best seats, as it is open seating. The chapel is very warm on a warm summer evening with no breeze even with the windows open. When you arrive, there is security to walk through and X-ray your bag. It's okay to have a water bottle with you. If you enjoy churches and sitting and looking at stained glass, this is a beautiful way to enjoy Sainte Chappelle.
Go see the stained glass. This chapel has some of the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. It is covered by the museum pass.

Stunning. I had heard that the stained glass here was so much better than Notre Dame but I didn't believe it until I saw it. The colors were so vibrant, and the way that the sunlight was ducking in and out of clouds outside made the windows glow from time to time. We waited an hour in line outside and I would do it again. Make sure it is a sunny day though as that really adds to the ambiance of the room.

Nearly 1000 years old.. We are content to choose several seats in Sainte Chapel and simply "read" the stained glass.Is Sainte Chapel holy? Yes, it is to us.And seated, we take little notice of other tourists.

Best stained glass in Paris. A must-visit but GO EARLY and go with the Museum Pass. Everyone has to go through the security line which gets VERY long. With the Museum Pass you avoid the second ticket line once inside the court yard. Expect huge crowds, but it's worth it.
An 800 year old church. This is a must see. The stained glass windows are incredible. The main part of the church is fully restored and is truly amazing.

Go for the Windows. What they say about the windows is true. They are wonderful. You do not have to linger a long time if you do not have it, but this is worth a visit. It is far different from Norte Dame nearby. Said to have been built to house the "Crown of Thorns" it is a work of art containing works of art.

Amazing. This Church is the most beautiful I have seen. A not to miss for its stunning design and decor. It's easy to get to and not too expensive. The tall glass windows are incredible. As well as the small entry chapel sitting underneath the main church. An engineering fete.

Amazing stained-glass. when you first enter, it's a little underwhelming. there's a sign asking for silence and yet along the left hand wall are stalls set up to sell Sainte-Chapelle themed tourist items. there's some smaller stained-glass windows but that's about it. then you realise very quickly you're only experiencing the warm-up to the main act.you begin to ascend an old stone spiral staircase and eventually emerge into Sainte-Chapelle. the colour from the floor to ceiling stained-glass windows is unlike anything I have ever seen - it was a jaw-dropping moment. there is free information available in many different languages on the set-up of all the windows and the stories they tell.my suggestion is to go early. it opens at 10 and you need to pass through security first. it's worth being there by 9.30 and waiting a little over 30mims because the initial line passes reasonably quickly. once the tourists are in, the line moves more slowly.

A cathedral of stained glass!. When you visit, remember that it was completed in only 6 years (1242 - 1248), unheard of in Gothic history. Recall that Notre Dame took over 200 years. The first floor is drab and then you walk into the second floor of stained glass. There is nothing that can describe the fifteen panels that cover 6,500 square feet, two-thirds of it 13th-century original. You must do your homework before entering this room or use a guidebook to understand what you are seeing. Stand to one side, review the panels that tell the entire Christian history.

Sainte-Chapelle gives Notre Dame a run for its money. Beautiful, historically significant Gothic church in the heart of Paris - Ile de la Cité. The stunning stained glass windows tell the story of the Old Testament, and are structural marvels of glasswork. Although Notre Dame can be more structurally interesting, with its naturalistic flying buttresses, and awe-inspiring in scale, Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely breathtaking.

The Bible in stained glass windows. If you happen to have the time, then yes, go to Chartres. And if you only have time for Paris, then go to the Sainte Chapelle. Spend time in there and try to decipher the glass windows with the material they offer in the upper chapel. It simply is mind boggling.

Not to be missed. Arrive early to avoid the long lines, but worth the wait. Very impressive and not that well known, the stained glass is stunning and the interiors are wonderful. Don't miss this one!

One of the Don't MIsses in Paris. This is one of the great masterpieces of Paris. The stained glass windows are unsurpassed anywhere I've been. The Museum Pass will cut the wait some, but the security check will take sometime nonetheless, especially in the summer. Best strategy is to go first thing in the morning on a sunny day. It is well-worth whatever wait there is. It's a good time to visit Notre Dame and the islands after.

beautiful full of art Chapelle. It's just besides the Conciergerie, and close to Notre Dame. So you can see all these three on a single trip to "ile de cite".The glassworks there are amazing, and if I'm not mistaken you can follow a story on these glasses.It doesn't sound interesting when you get there, but once you get inside it will hit your eyes.

Visit as part of a concert!. I've seen the Sainte-Chappelle several times and consider it one of the most beautiful, if not the most beautiful, and worthwhile sight in Paris. However, at least during the summer months, the wait to get in is way too long. We struck gold when we found out that there are concerts in the evening, after the normal viewing hours. We heard a 7 piece string plus harpsicord concert of Bach violin concerto and Mozart's Eine kleine Nachtmusik,sitting comfortably in the magnificent upstairs chapel. The acoustics were very good, as were the musicians and of course sitting there surrounded by the early evening light flooding through the stained glass windows is magical. Getting tickets online was easy, though it did cost about 9 euro more, and we needed to have a way to print them out. You can also get tickets at several of the large department stores until the day before the performance, and some people even bought on site, though I would not have chanced that for fear of a sold out room. Sainte Chapelle is after all not that large.The only thing you do lose out on if you visit as part of a concert is the lower floor, which I also love, though the upper floor is the well known and loved view

A MUST each time you visit Paris. There are no words, pictures, or descriptions I could provide that would be able to convey how startlingly awed you will be when you step into the main chamber of this beautiful and inspiring place.There are 1,113 stained glass renderings of stories from the Bible - and one feels like you are in a fabulously constructed and regal birdcage made of ancient and beautifully colored glass - with light coming from all directions.

Too difficult to enjoy.... Have to go through quite an extensive security/metal detor and pay more than $17 American to enter...my husbands first comment was "is this it?"...the stain glass is amazing especially if read corresponding with the bible stories that go with each pane...amazing actually....enjoy!!
Oh my goodness!. This was my first visit to Sainte Chapelle, wish I had gone before. The stained glass takes your breath away. And the stone carvings depicting Bible stories are so detailed.

Definitely worth a look. Beautiful stained glass.. Sainte Chappelle is a nice stop when seeing memorable and beautiful sites in Paris. It's include with the Paris Museum Pass and that's already another good reason to go. You can enjoy your visit in about an hour.

When in Paris ... A MUST visit. Very impressive "vitraux" windows. Well preserved. You can't see the top parts because they are very high. But the details in the bottom ones give a good idea of the fine details and mastery.The queue and wait to get in is long. We had to wait about an hour

Beautiful Chapel. What an under rated chapel. It is the most beautiful chapel that I have ever seen. There was a bit of a queue but absolutely a must see. Luckily a localer that we met on the train told us about this gem. We were delighted and not disappointed at all.

Very Simple Design and Overpriced. While Sainte-Chapelle certainly has a long held reputation as being a prominent landmark of Paris, it was clearly overpriced and not nearly as fascinating as the other well-known monuments. We waited for nearly 2 hours in line, which ultimately only resulted in the opportunity to tour 2 small chambers. If you have the time and energy, by all means come. Otherwise, Sainte-Chapelle is definitely not at the top of my "must see" list.

Historical and a Treasure. Was not in my original itinerary was actually a last minute decision...boy am I glad I decided eventhough we waited about 1/2 hr for the security check......the architecture and the stain glass was just mesmerizing and worth every wait. A must must must in your itinerary.

Breathtaking and Beautiful. This church had the most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen. Each panel details different events from the Bible, with the Rose Window detailing the Apocolypse. Look for the large museum cards that describe the various windows and their historical significance. Then watch the expressions of awe on people's faces as they enter into the upstairs room and gaze upward at the magnifigance of the glass.

It takes your breath away!. I've been inside many cathedrals and churches. As for hugeness.. this one doesn't make the grade. But the intricate, amazing, unbelievable (how many more adjectives can I use??), breathtaking - stained glass windows in the upper church just cannot be adequately described nor photographed. I don't know why I'd never ventured inside before. It's magnificent!!It was built to house the crown of thorns from Christ's Crucifixion. If you look closely at the decoration around the altar, you can see the inference there. There will be lines, count on it. But it's worth the wait, even if it's raining outside, like it was the day I visited.
The Windows are amazing!. breath taking. Worth the small fee and line to get in. The stained glass windows tell the story. I suggest taking a seat and several minutes just to take it in.
Beyond Stunning!. Do not leave Paris without a visit. Absolutely worth the wait to get in (in April it was about 45 min.).

A Well-Kept Secret. We traveled to this chapel to see a Renaissance music trio perform. The music was delightful and the setting incredible. The stained glass windows reach from head to ceiling level and are beautiful, especially if one is able to see a performance near dusk.

Small but Necessary. Not a huge chapel, but nothing like it anywhere in Europe. Sainte Chapelle boast the most amazing display of stained glass artwork you will ever see. This visit won't take long, but make sure you camera batteries are full when you show up.

Stained Glass is worth the time. Just a short walk from Notre Dame, and the stained glass is really pretty. It is one more great thing to see in Paris, and a don't miss if you are on the center islands.

Security check!. Because St Chapelle is located with some of the courts they have a scanned security checkpoint. I had to surrender my small travel pocket knife - very annoying but understandable.
They r the most amazing windows in Paris.
Very beautiful but queue was 50 minutes!. It was beautiful and very detailed and was worth taking the time to study all the columns etc. The queue was very long though.

Stunning stained glass windows. I lived in Paris years ago and have visited Paris several times but I had never been to La Sainte- Chapelle. A friend recommended it and I am so glad I went. It is worth the 8.50 euro entrance fee and the queue wasn't too long. The 15 panels tell the story of the Bible and there is a story card to use but it is better to just soak up the beauty of the place. The decorated woodwork is beautiful too.

Stunning, but definitely a time commitment. Stunning windows! I hogged a group of chairs until one became available, pushed play on the classical playlist of my mp3 player, sat and reveled in the beauty of the stained glass. A worshipful experience.That said, even on a quiet day and with a museum pass, it was a longer than expected wait to get through security (about 45 minutes to an hour). I had a book with me, so didn't mind too much. It's a great stop if you have the time, but may not be worth it if you are on a quick trip in Paris.
Unique.. We arrived without tickets in July and waited 35 minutes. People with Museum Passes were marching right in.It is a small chapel but the stained glass is quite unique and worth seeing.

What a Gem - a Must-See in Paris. Words can't really describe the beauty of this medievel church. Brave the line-ups if there are any as it is well worth it see the beauty of the spectacular stained glass windows. The line-up on the street to get through the security check may be deceptively short: ask how long the line-up on the inside is to gain entrance to the chapel itself. We happily stood in what we thought was a short line-up (10-15 minutes) outside, and then had another 45 minutes wait once we got inside.
Must see, really. Magical location.. One of my favorite places in Paris. Time it so you are there at sunset, if possible. It is stunning. No words to describe it. Must see.

Sainte-Chapelle. Small but stunning chapel. We visited in June around midday and had no trouble getting in. But I'd have queued for an hour anyway as its stained glass windows and unique atmosphere are second to none!

Go see a classical music concerto at St. Chapelle!. We're not a big museum or cathedral type of family. But some good friends of ours recommended we go see a concert at St. Chapelle. We booked a concert at www.classictic.com/Sainte-ChapelleThis ended up being one of our Paris highlights. Seeing a string/harpsichord group perform Vivaldi in St. Chappelle's beautiful stained glass sanctuary was absolutely ethereal. Even if you're not a classical music type of family, I highly recommend doing this!

A hidden jewel ofter overlooked due to the Notre Dame.. We actually got a bonus. Our friend arranged the evening which included a wonderful String Quartet Concert. Very enjoyable, plus the chapel itself is worth the visit.

Pierre Potet - unsung French hero for fixing windows.. I love looking at the stained glass windows here! They'd been pretty damaged by WW2 bombings but with the help of Mr. Pierre Potet, were put back together again! He's definitely an unsung hero!The pros - you can get an audio-guide (like a phone) and it's interesting to hear the story of each window. The downside is that the audio-guide is hard to follow sometimes because the track number and the item you're looking at number are sometimes hard to coordinate. Another con is that if you've got some mobility issues, the stairs are steep and dark and challenging. If you are pressed for time, skip this and go another day because sometimes the lines are crazy long. I've been here several times and it's pretty amazing.
Long Wait, Beautiful Inside. Absolutely amazing inside, very long line to wait in before you get in but worth it. Cameras allowed inside, many photo ops, stunning historical interior.

Stunning, beautiful stained glass. Don't miss it.. Very nice stained glass downstairs. Upstairs is amazingly beautiful stained glass everywhere. We went to an evening opening- I think it was a Wednesday, about 6 or 6.30 and not busy. A good time to visit. No waiting. If you are in Paris you shouldn't miss this. My very practical husband got to the top of the stairs, stood still and said "Wow!"
Concert at la Sainte Chapelle. Wow. It was spectacular the sound, the glass windows, the colors the harmony of the music. If I die I would love that my soul would rest in that place.

Amazing Beauty. We happened upon this spot on a whim because it was part of the museum pass but, I will likely go back here every time I'm in Paris. The stained glass is amazing, especially on a sunny day. You could spend hours trying to see all the images instead of hours waiting in line, like at Notre Dame. Completely worth a trip. You can do a combo pass with the concierge however, this is the highlight.

Best in Paris. Some say that this church is more beautiful than Notre Dame and I would actually have to agree. The stained glass windows are stunning and detailed, making the room feel magical. On a really sunny day the colors really come through. There is a line to view this and you might find yourself waiting an hour, but it is very much worth it. If you have a museum pass you will still have to wait to get checked at security, but afterwards can use it.

The biggest surprise. My biggest surprise in Paris this time was this amazing place. It was a rather long waiting line to get in, but it was totally worth every minute. The glass paintings that covers most of the walls are really works of art. It is small, but to me - the most beautiful place I have seen on my visits to Paris. I would rather go back here than visiting Notre Dame again so that says a lot.... Don`t miss this if you appreciate beautiful buildings.

Very unorganised ....don’t waste time standing in queue. We visited here twice stood in a not so long queue and did not stand a chance to get in 2 hours so had to leave. It is one of the most unorganised sites in Paris. We saw some people with tickets being allowed to get in straight, but when others asked about where to get the tickets, the guards said that we have to stand in the queue. Obviously this attitude caused a lot of inconvenience and waste of time. I will suggest that visit this site only if you have extra time in hand. Use your time to visit other great sites in Paris.
Vivaldi Four Seasons. This was the second time that we went to Sainte-Chapelle for a concert. It is an awesome venue and the music was wonderful. This is a must see for us anytime we are in Paris.

No toilettes available. We went to see an amazing concert one night. They were performing Vivaldi for an 1 1/2. The concert was fabulous, however we had to get there 45 minutes ahead of time. Once we sat down, were told there were no toilettes which really made it uncomfortable for the three hours.Again, the concert was fabulous and the church is spectualar.
Surprisingly wonderful. Was very surprised by how much my wife and I enjoyed this chapel. The stained-glass windows are breathtaking!

Stunning medieval beauty. Saint Chapelle is by far one of the top ten Paris monuments.To be honest it is much more impressive then the nearby standing Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are amazing and the whole atmosphere of the place will take you back to the medieval times.Don´t miss this sight, you won´t regret. But go early morning as it gets crowded later during a day.

Beautiful!. I LOVED THIS PLACE. The stained glass is absolutely beautiful. I'm sad I didn't go sooner! The whole thing is just stunning and if you have time after seeing Notre Dame, go around the corner and visit this place. There is a cost of admission, but you can use the same ticket to get into the Conciergerie.

Best stained glass exhibit in the world. Despite the long lines this small church is not to be missed. In years past it was not easily found but improved signage today is helpful. A short walk from Notre Dame it is well worth the visit - especially on a sunny day when the interior view of the stained glass is extraordinary. I've visited this church every time I've been in Paris - and unlike some of the larger churches and museums, keep coming back. A wonderful visual experience.

Amazing!. Saint Chappelle was just around the corner of our hotel (holiday inn Notre Dame). We walked by many times during our trip and wondered why there was always a line in front of this nondescript building,One day there was no line and we thought we would check it out. We bought tickets (my daughter was free because she was 17) and we entered the chapel and we thought this is nice but why is everyone standing in line?We saw a set of steps (round, narrow) but no one was going up. We were wondering , "What's the big deal."So we went up the steps . When we got to the top we stopped dead in our tracks . It was beyond beautiful! It was awe inspiring. It was spectacular. We literally stopped and looked up and didn't move.The best part...we had no idea what we were walking into , which made it a special find, a treasure if u will. We stood there, looking up and my daughter said she started to tear up from its beauty What made Saint Chappell (Im spelling it wrong I think ) is the unexpected find . That is the treasure.

The windows are back; the windows are back!!. Long lines but well worth the visit. The windows are back, so it's a must see again. I visited again after 55 years. Pretty cool that it has only gotten more beautiful (not I though)

Beauty and Grace beyond compare. we visited Saint Chapelle and had to wait in line for over 45 minutes in 35c Heat and yet the spectacular impact when entering the church from the staircase as resonated with all in our party. helpful tip : if you have a Paris museum pass apparently that gives you access to skip the queue.

Amazing. This is a must see if you are visiting Paris. The stained glass windows are some of the most beautiful in the world. Go early to avoid the line, which can be very long. We got in line about 40 minutes before the chapel opened and we were sixth and seventh in line. By opening, there had to be at least 200 people waiting.

Breathtakingly beautiful!. A gem! As my children climbed the narrow circular staircase into the main sanctuary I heard first one then the other exclaim "Wow!" as the sight of the truly amazing windows came into view. A treasure!

loved it. Much more impressive than the nearby Notre Dame. Lovely stained glass windows were beautiful in the sun. Ornate floors as well. A very long line to get in (much more police presence and inspection than other places)

Most beautiful church in France. Absolutely breathtaking beauty of Sainte-Chapelle, of walls of stained glass.
It is most beautiful church in France.
You must see it!

A beautiful way to spend an evening. This is a wonderful way to listen to some talented string musicians whilst sitting and admiring the beautiful stain glass windows. You can actually book the performance on line to avoid the crowds. We saw the earlier show then walked to a local restaurant for dinner.

You have to love stained glass. Originally built as the private chapel for the king, the stained glass is second to none. Much of the glass tells stories from the old and new testaments of the bible. Do not bother going on a heavily overcast day. You need bright sunlight to give the real feeling of the place.

Concert at Saint-Chapelle. We attended an evening concert at Saint-Chapelle and had a delightful experience. The program was Vivaldi's Four Seasons and the musicians were excellent and amusing. The playing was intense and very good and the interaction of the musicians was terrific. The evening sun came through the stained glass windows in a myriad of colors. Unfortunately, we did not have time to return for a daytime visit to the chapel. No one should miss a visit to Saint-Chapelle and, if possible, attend a concert there. (It is advisable to purchase tickets online in advance to ensure availability of seating.)

Don't miss this national monument. you will regret it if you do.. Climbing up from the lower chapel is like ascending into heaven... breath taking. The upper sanctuary appears to soar to heaven and is lit by the most beautiful stain glass I have ever seen.
Beautiful Upper Chapel. Be sure to get the printed info so you can understand the story behind this beautiful chapel. Arrive early to miss the crowds.

Open late on Wednesdays. Arrived at 8:15 pm with a 9 pm closing time. Walked right in the security area, through the open courtyard to the ticket office. Entered the first floor sanctuary and went directly up the winding stairs. Only 25 or so visitors were enjoying the amazing walls of stained glass. It was still light enough to have the glow of the sun reflect from outside and inside (through the large doors of the terrace). I took advantage of the English language poster boards that proved all the important details needed to truly enjoy this masterpiece.

Most enjoyable part of Paris. It is the best kept secret of Paris. If you love music, there is no better place to go for an evening concert in the most beautiful chapel in France. The music was a 10 and the environment was too.

Worth the wait. With a twenty minute wait, we watched the city go by before entering security and then walking straight in (Museum Pass, I can't stress this enough). I could have sat there all day and enjoyed the light coming through. FYI - you can grab a laminated tour that guides through all the windows. ResourcesRick Steves Historic Paris Tour (Map and Audio Tour)Museum Pass
Amazing stained glass, and history.. What an in interesting chapel, with amazing stained glass. The history really tells you how opulent the French aristocracy was leading up to the revolution.

Gorgeous!. Gorgeous!!! Most inspiring stained glass windows that I've ever witnessed! Go early or late to get the best lighting. The most beautiful (and inexpensive!) attraction that you can enjoy in the heart of Paris!

Stained glass windows that take your breath away. The Saint Chapelle Chapel was built to house the Crown of Thorns and other relics acquired during the Crusades. It is not just another huge Gothic Cathedral with a very tall nave. Saint Chapelle is not as big as Westminster Abbey. When you walk into the interior, all you see are dramatic floor-to-ceiling stained glass. The impression I had is that the supporting stone pillars visually disappear. The visitor is bathed in colorful light streaming in from the windows. Stories from the Old Testament, New Testament and the Life of Christ are portrayed in the stained glass.

Stunning Stained Glass Windows. Sainte Chapelle is one of the older Paris churches and has incredible stained glass windows. Each vertical window tells various Bible stories. Once you are in the upper chapel, there is a stack of guide cards (sitting on a stand in the corner) in various languages that you can pick up and walk around with to tell you more about each window. Sainte-Chapelle typically has very long lines. The first line at the street is only a security line. There is a second line inside security to purchase tickets and then go in. If you can purchase tickets in advance or use a museum pass, this will speed up your visit. You will still have to wait for security, but once past security, you will be able to skip the second line for tickets and go into the church.

Most beautiful windows in Paris!!. This is a must see!! it is worth the wait in the line! the sense of awe when you step from the last stair into the scared space of the church with those incredible stain glass windows - awesome!!!!

Beautiful setting. Once getting through the security line, shared by Sainte-Chappelle and the French Supreme Court, the rest of the visit was magnificent. The outside of the building is not much to notice, but the interior and the stained-glass windows are the reason to visit, anyway. The stained-glass windows tell the Biblical story and then some. I was there on a bright sunny Monday and the upper chapel was filled with the brilliant colors of the windows. This was truly a spectacular sight.
Stained Glass at it's best. Maybe it's a little way from the beaten track, but it is well worth visiting. Downstairs is low ceilinged and vaulted, and upstairs - wait for the 'WOW' effect.

All scaffolding is gone! Magnificent this summer!. There are some wonderful guides at this sight- so be sure to sign up for one of the tours. You will learn a lot of fascinating things! Even if you don't- the stained glass windows are in they're cleaned up splendor- no others like them!

Simply stunning stained glass windows. You enter St Chapelle on what turns out to be the ground floor. The stained glass windows are pleasant on this level but, if like me and you don't realise that the chapel and the real display is one level up, you are left with the feeling that it is really nothing special. Climb to the next level, and you immediately realise what all the fuss is about - individually and collectively the stained glass windows and their overall effect are quite stunning, especially with the sun in the right.direction. They sometimes have musical programs in the chapel. If you are there at the right time, one of these would be a must - the overall ambience would be hard to beat
Stunning. Of all the churches we visited on our two week tour of Europe, this one was my favorite. Absolutely breathtaking beauty of walls of stained glass.
Breath-takingly beautiful. It's worth having a look in here, and if the sun is shining, you'll see just what an exquisite chapel this is. Truly beautiful.

Beautiful but busy. We had the museum pass and that line moved slower and was longer than those people buying on the day. These lines mean nothing. they both just lead to security and you both walk to the church after this and those wanting a ticket line up there to get one and those with the pass go straight in. My advice, get in the shortest line, it doesn't matter either way. But once in the church it is amazing and beautiful

Long Q to go in. Didnt manage to go in as there is long q to go in on friday. It was friday on that day and they put a notice that it is closed for visiting from 12pm until 2.30pm. It is 1pm and already long q outside this chapelle. We gave up this place as we still got other places to go visiting. Also there is charges imposed to visit this place. Maybe will come back next time.

Awestruck, Inspiring, one of the Architectural Wonders. We have been in Paris more times than I can count, perhaps 35 to 40 times. We missed this incredible place several visits, pleased don't miss her. The stained glass is one of the most incredible sites in a cathedral anyplace in the world. It can be a bit complicated to enter and on the way in, frankly it doesn't look like much, once you climb that flight of steps and it opens up, prepare to be astonished. Her history is so interesting, be sure to read all about Sainte Chapelle and don't miss it.

A beautiful sight!. A friend told me that this little chapel was well worth the wait and that it was better than Notre Dame, in her opinion. Was she ever right! We got in line to be one of the first people of the day, when it was still cool. Once inside....words fail you, just walls of gorgeous stained glass, intricate stone carvings, just a feast for the eyes. A sight I will never forget.

Most beautiful church in Paris. I loved the stained glass in this church. There is so much of it, and all of it so beautiful, that it would take forever to look at and absorb it all. We visited with our two teens and they enjoyed it as well. We'd talked in advance about some of the biblical stories depicted in the windows, and it was fun for them to find Moses, Jesus, and some of the other people depicted. We arrived at the chapel just a few minutes before its opening time of 9:30. There was already a line to the golden Palace of Justice gate, and it took us about 20 minutes to get through the security check. The line had gotten even longer by the time we exited, so I would recommend coming as early as possible. Once through security, you walk around the outside of the chapel to the entrance (separate lines for Museum Pass holders vs. those that need to purchase). It's interesting to look at the foundation of the church as you walk and see how much the ground level has risen since it was built. Once in the church, we pretty much went straight upstairs to the Haute Chapel. The lower one is pretty but no comparison to the upper. We spent about 30 minutes looking at the glass, taking pictures, and enjoying the light. You can also exit under the rose window to see some of the exterior decorations. I love this church and make a point of visiting every time I'm in Paris.
Stained glass mother lode!. Definitely a must see, every other church pales in comparison when it comes to stained glass windows!
My favorite sight in Paris. Not as known as Sacre Coeur or Notre Dame, but this small chapel is a gem which always leaves me enthralled. Go on sunny days!

Worth queueing for..... One of the most beautiful chapels, with a fascinating history. There are not many places that have stained glass of this quality from the 13th century. Quite breathtaking. Go early in the day, as there are a lot of visitors.

Stunning. We have visited Paris many times and have never been able to get into this building; the line ups are crazy! However, we arrived very early a couple of days ago and started standing in the line that was already forming at 9am. The building opens at 9:30. This is an astounding and gorgeous building. It is amazing to consider how these skilled people managed to build such incredible glass windows with so little lead/wood between the glass. We were not through at all, so you can stay as long as you'd like to enjoy this spectacular building. I think it was less than 5E to enter.

I was AWE STRUCK. We waited in line for well over an hour to see this little Chapel. Because it is in the same complex as a courthouse and other government buildings, security is really tight.Once you get in, it looks like a regular old wooden church. At first I was thinking "wow, I waited online for THIS???" but back by the entrance, there is a staircase marked "haut entrance" or something like that. Go up a few flights of stairs and prepare to be stunned!!This is a recently restored chapel with very high ceilings completely made of stained glass. It was late afternoon, and the sun shone thru. Pictures could not capture how absolutely beautiful it was. There are places to sit and contemplate.Do take the time to see this if you are by the Notre Dame area as it is truly stunning.

Amazing. Sainte-Chapelle has to be one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. When we were so lucky as they had just unveiled the restored stained glass windows which had been covered up for 15 years. We attended a concert there in the evening, these concerts are on regularly and I would absolutely recommend you book a ticket. The atmosphere was fantastic and the musicians were incredibly talented. We had a very special evening here and would recommend the experience to anyone.

Breathtaking!. This cathedral is relatively underrated when compared to other sites in Paris. Beautiful church where visits can last between 5 minutes to an hour, depending on how hard you look at the stained glass.

Not worth the wait or money. Sure, Sainte-Chapelle is an amazingly beautiful chapel, but it's just not worth the time for what the venue offers. You walk in and up and around and out in about 10 minutes.

AWESOME!. We had to wait in line for a very long time to get in. It would have probably been very advantageous to buy a pass just to not have to wait in the lines for a few of the venues we went to. This was simply the most unbelievable amount of stain glass we have ever seen. The windows are beautiful and the story behind each of the panels is fascinating. It was worth the wait.
Not to be missed!. This is a beautiful church and is close to the metro. It is not to be missed! There is a line to check through your bags.

A must see. The stained glass windows of this church make it exceptional and a must see. It was built around 1240 in accordance with the orders of Louis the IX to house relics from the Passion of Christ. One of the relics included the Crown of Thorns. NOTE: This relic is currently in the treasury of Notre Dame and is not at Sainte-Chapelle. That being said, this church is incredibly beautiful and still worth the visit.

Great -- especially since the restoration work has ended. This is without question the most beautiful display of stained glass we've ever seen, and we wouldn't think of coming to Paris without seeing it again. After our first trip seven years ago, restoration work began, and on two subsequent trips, one side or the other was covered up. This year we still expected the rose window to be behind scaffolding but we were pleasantly surprised to find everything clear. Whenever we visit we're always amazed again how brilliant the colorful display is. A lot of people like to see it on a sunny day, but for our money a bright, but overcast day works best since all the windows glow equally. Bring your wide angle lens and don't forget to bring your patience. This place is always crowded.A lot of people are put off by the line outside. Security is especially tight here, and even with the museum pass you have to stand in line for screening. It moves pretty quickly, so don't let it get to you. But, if you don't have the museum pass, you'll face a second line inside to buy tickets. The pass will save you 15 or 20 minutes of line-standing. Don't get sidetracked by the lower chapel when you first enter. Hurry on upstairs. You can see the lower chapel before you leave.

Stunning stained glass windows - a must see!. The best display of stained glass windows we've seen - it brought us to tears. Everywhere you look you see beauty - all the way down to the floor you stand on - don't miss the colorful floor tiles! It was a very hot evening when we visited - luckily we had a short line.

Stained glass heaven. The chapel is fanstastic! Pictures are hard to get that do the glass justice to show its beauty. You have to see this one yourself. Make sure to go on a sunny day while the sun is at its peak so the light coming through the windows is at its prime. Take time to look at the outside of the chapel as well. The architecture is worth some time to admire.
If you are a lover of stained glass. A beautiful setting to contemplate life. Go early in the day. The best stained glass in Paris. A must see

Beautiful!. Very impressive. One of the most impressive we saw in Europe. Don't worry about the lines. We seemed to be a long way back, however the line cleared quickly. Timetable said closed at 1pm. We thought wed take our chances and got there at 15mins to 1pm. It didn't close. Worth checking that out, however wasn't a problem at least in peak season.
Best looking church. I think this is the best looking church in Paris. Astounding glass stained mirrors. Church is small but it is one of the best I have ever seen and I have been to a lot.

A must see for the stained glass windows alone!!. A beautiful church with spectacular stained glass windows. A little difficult to get to with the police headquarters next door but worth the trouble!!

Beautiful pictures but disappointed not seeing in person.. Was appointed as the Chapelle was closed the day we wanted to visit without notice of reasoning. Other Americans were there and also disappointed. All would find another attraction.

Beautiful chapel, incredible history. If you want to understand Paris history, you need to visit this chapel. The architecture is incredible. The stained glass... the history of the French Revolution... you'll be glad you spent a couple hours.

The Most Beautiful Stained Glass I've Ever Seen. Everyone that visits Paris makes sure to visit Notre Dame, but this chapel is a gem not to be missed! I chose the word gem intentionally! This chapel has floor to ceiling stain glass windows that give it a gem-like feel. It is not loud and ornate like the large cathedrals, it is just simply beautiful in it's simple beauty! I understand that the chapel's windows are undergoing a cleaning. (That may be finished by now) For some reason instead of that being a distracting, the comparison of the cleaned to the yet-to-be-cleaned just highlighted the beauty of the cleaned windows more! Glad we visited.

Go there for a concert. Do NOT get in line with the day time tourists. Book a seat at an early evening concert and you will be rewarded. The longer you sit and take the time to look around, the more this place captivates you.
Like a mediaeval manuscript. Beautiful little chapel with a wonderful ornate ceiling and lovely stained glass windows. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful History. The history behind this chapel is so rich. It is a beautiful piece of architecture that houses so much meaning behind it. The stained glass was unlike anything I have seen. It was done so well.

To Avoid Lineup. Go to the jail next door where they held marie antoinette. if you're facing the church, it's to the right of the justice building. if you buy a double pass there for both, you can walk right by the lineup at st chapelle and you're in. I'm not religious, but when you get upstairs and see the entire bible story told in the stained glass, it takes your breath away.

Astounding. As you walk into the church, the stained glass overwhelms you. It is omnipresent due to its size and beauty. Despite the crowd, try to sit and mediate and revel in the serene beauty of the place.

Try to see this chapel!. Built by french King Louis IX as his personal chapel. It is mostly tall stained-glass windows and is exquisite. The chapel below this is also beautiful. Be sure to arrive early as a line will form before its 9 am opening. You need an hour or so to enjoy this site. It cost 9 euros, I think ... Well worth it.

This is a must see. This little chapel is tucked away across the street from Notre Dame Cathedral. It is well worth venturing over to see it. As you enter it seems very small after just walking through Notre Dame. The ceiling seems low and just seems like a waste of time until you go up the spiral staircase. You feel like you have just walked into a jewel box. It is breath taking as you are surrounded by stained glass windows that are right there within reach. If you have the Paris Museum Pass you skip the line and go right in.

Better than Notre Dame. This is far more intimate and up close than its more famous neighbor. You can get in close to the stain glass and follow their stories. The crowd is very well controlled and not a mob scene.

Not to be missed. After suffering from cathedral fatigue we almost decided to give Sainte-Chapelle a miss - so glad we didn't! This beautiful little jewelbox was created by Louis IX to house his purchase of the crown of thorns and it is just gorgeous. Try to go on a sunny day so you can truly appreciate the stained glass windows. We lined up half an hour before opening and it only took 40 minutes to get in.

Best kept secret in Paris.. I have visited 20 times and have never been encouraged to visit this place. Most of my Parisien friends were unaware of its secrets. It is worth the entrance fee and wait. Optimize your visit by studying in advance. Fasten your seatbelt and prepare to be transported to a different era. It will change you.

My Favorite Church. The stain glass windows are like no other. My breath was literally taken away when I entered. I came up from the lower level via the winding staircase. The interior is small but absolutely beautiful...like gems.

An absolute treat for the eyes!. Although much less grand in scale than Notre-Dame Cathedral, this is a must see. It is difficult to describe, but the stained glass will leave a lasting impression. This is a gem!

Not to Be Missed!. This was the second time I visited Sainte-Chapelle. We arrived around 1:00 pm and there were about 100 people in line. We waited about an hour (people that work outside are not very helpful) The line in was annoying because people were trying to cut the line. However, all is forgiven once you enter the chapel. I was there 5 years ago and it was under construction and it still is. The stained glass windows are SO old and intricate that the restoring process is very long. There are information sheets to read about the chapel in about 15 languages. It is a sight NOTto miss!

On a sunny day!. Go late afternoon on a sunny day; the sun shines directly in the best direction. There's a line-up? Go around and get your ticket on the other side so you can get by the line and line up......inside! Yes, there's another queue inside! So, plan to be there before closing time? Also, check for concert time on different days, it's worth the wait!

A little hard to find but worth it. When you visit Notre Dame, don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. Its across a couple of streets in the police station area. Will need to go thru security, no knives or sharp objects. They say no pockets knives. The stained glass in this chapel in beautiful, another don't miss while in Paris.

Get a joint ticket with Concierge. The Saint Chapelle is a genuinely breath-taking beautiful chapel with 13 amazing stained glass windows. However, the queues to get in are long even if you arrive first thing. We got a joint ticket with the Concierge which we visited first. This however meant when it came to visiting the Saint Chapelle, we got to jump the queue. We loved it but I wouldn't queue 2 hours for it. With the joint tickets though, it is a must see.

Most beautiful stained glass ever!. I had read on a TripAdvisor review that if you could only visit one church in Paris that this should be it! I totally agree! This is the most impressive stained glass that I have ever seen! Every story of the bible is depicted in the stained glass. Hopefully you are there on a sunny day or while the sun comes out! Spectacular! Don't miss!

Jewel Box of Paris. Do you ever find yourself returning to someplace over and over, because you can't believe it actually exists? That's how I feel about Sainte-Chapelle. Every single year I got to France (going on 15 years) I make sure I stop in, if only for a few minutes. (it's easier using a museum pass). The entrance is the former servants space, which in itself is stunning...but climb those spiral stairs and you are awe-struck. Three walls of stained glass, containing the stories of the bible. On a sunny day, it's indescribable. Don't overlook the details of the door locks or wood carvings. While they are adornments, they are just as magnificent. Be sure to look for the concert schedules here. Hearing Vivaldi here is like nothing on earth.

The Worth the Wait Chapel. After having waiting in line about 45 minutes and being the last two admitted as they close from 1 to 4 the first impression is HUMM? was this worth the wait? Then you climb the concealed circular stairway up and enter the most beautiful stained glass chapel ever erected !!! Breath taking is a very close description but not really enough in my opinion. I love the Fluer des Les symbol and so I had my eye filled with it's magic. Truly a beautiful place and well worth the visit.
Floor to Ceiling Stained Glass!. The most beautiful stained glass we saw in Paris. Arrived late, just before closing, but it was pretty in the late afternoon sun.
Worth a 2nd visit. Of the multitude of chapels, cathedrals and other places of worship, this chapelle stands out. It is beautiful and despite the crowds of visitors retained a lovely calm ambience

Be prepared to queue and then be awed!. It's one of the few places I've not minded queueing for because it's just so staggeringly beautiful. You'll get a crick in your neck from bending backwards to gaze upwards in awe. Definitely worth spending a few euros on and probably the main reason to be sensible (unlike us) and get a Paris pass. There is a long slow queue for security and your pass will be of no use at the start BUT once you pass through security, you can skip the even longer queue for tickets and just go in. Had we had longer, we'd have got the joint ticket to the Conciergerie but we didn't have time. There are some pretty gruesome depictions of people being martyred, in the little rosettes all around the walls. They don't mention that too much in the publicity!

Huge Line, Entrance Through Garbage Dump. Don't get me wrong, the church itself is quite interesting and beautiful. It's also strategically located close to the Notre Dame, so you can do them both in a relatively short time.However, the staff of the place really underestimate the volume of people the church can handle, so they overrestrict the crowd, making for gigantic lines. I was there in March and waited for over an hour in the rain (don't forget your umbrella!), imagine what it's like in the summer July sun when the line is probably twice as long.Anyway, even when you brave the line and enter, the entrance itself is very awkward. It's basically a courtyard with many huge garbage containers. It stinks a bit, and is generally unpleasant.The church itself is known for its beautiful vitrages (glass), and it's indeed quite something. However, it's fairly small and there isn't much to do there beyond ~15 minutes. If you come here and notice the line is very short, go ahead. If not, I recommend skipping this place.

A glittering medieval jewel in the heart of Paris.. Less well known than neighbouring Notre Dame, the Sainte-Chapelle is a masterpiece of medieval architecture with some of the most stunning stained glass you've ever seen. Set in the Palais de Justice, you have to pass through security checks to gain admittance, but this is a small price to pay for such a spectacular visit.

Best vitreous in the world. As soon as you walk in, the place will blow you away. I am glad we went, recommended by a French friend. The entrance is easy to miss, but well worth the visit, just around the corner from Notre Dame. The acoustic was also amazing.

Stunning!. The stained glass windows are stunning. Wish I could have sat in a chair and just taken my time to enjoy the beauty, but so many things to see in Paris. We were through the line and on our way in an hour or maybe less. They check your bags, so make sure you don't have anything like a Swiss Army knife.

Like being on the inside of a jewel!. That's what a dear old friend told me many years ago about the gorgeous stained glass windows that actually compose the walls of the upper level of this church near Notre Dame, in the Palais de Justice. On a sunny day, it takes your breath away when you walk up the stairs and are literally surrounded by the shards of light and color from these huge stained glass windows. Don't miss it!

Breathtaking. This wonderful little church is the best place to see stained glass in Paris. The first floor is somewhat dark and dreary but once you go upstairs and the sun shines through those windows, it brings tears to your eyes. It is just beautiful and I got to experience only half of it. It was undergoing maintenance and the entire left wall was covered and it still was amazing.Buying tickets in advance was not necessary, I just stumbled upon it by accident, though it was on my must see places.Note: I traveled in July 2012.

A gem very close to Notre Dame Cathedral. The highlight of the Sainte Chapelle is the Stained Glass Windows. As you enter the Chapelle, you are struck by the beauty of the stained glass windows but this is nothing compared to the feeling you get when you walk up the stairs to the Kings Chapelle. You have to see it to believe it. WOW.

Breathtaking. Worth waiting an hour in the hot sun to see this. If you are disabled ,or have mobility/knee problems, you will have difficulty making it up the narrow spiral staircase. I did not see a lift so enquire first if there is one available.

Among favorite "churches" in Paris. The stained glass and intimacy of the chapel makes it feel just right. A place that makes one stop and be quiet just because it has that effect. Do take time to read about the stained glass "stories". Goosebumps.

Lovely. We waited in line for about an hour and when we went into the chapel we were bummed as it was pleasant but not as nice as other places we had been and then we went upstairs and ah ha. THIS is why you come here. Surrounded by beautiful stained glass windows. It is not far from Notre Dame. Note it is closed for lunch every day from 1:00 until 2:15. We did not know and came back on another day. Nice but liked the Charlemagne Cathedral in Aachen, Germany better for the beauty and more significant history.
The Bible presented in Stain Gllass. we liked figuring out which Bible Story was in each WindowBe sure to get brochure to know if you are correct

Stunning hidden gem. Sainte Chapelle is no longer such a hidden treasure as it once was. Word has got out about how beautiful it is and now in peak season the queues stretch down past the Conciergerie and the French Court. That said, if you can bear the queue or are prepared to get there as it opens, you will not be disappointed. The stained glass and the painted walls and ceiling in this tiny chapel are truly breathtaking.

Don't miss this. Hadn't seen this gem on an earlier visit. Really glad I decided to add it to the list of things to do. Simply stunning stained glass inside that is a wonder to behold. A true gem of the city.

Lovely surprise. We had seen the signs but never visited. The most breathtaking place we have seen! Beautiful paintings and windows! The queues were quite long but it was Sunday afternoon - we will visit again but perhaps on an early morning weekday.
Intricate Work of Glass. Intricate work of Glass across the Chappelle . A very beautiful place . Museum pass not valid so please reach early

Beautiful & intimate, buy tickets in advance. Even though this is one of the few churches you have to pay to enter, it is worth it. You can go to the front of the security line if you buy your tickets in advance (you have to buy them from fnac; it doesn't work with the Paris Museum pass).

Better Than Niotre Dame. This is the one site you HAVE to see in Paris. We have done this and skipped Notre Dame on one trip- but we ALWAYS go here. the stained glass is INCREDIBLE. Now that it has been cleaned, its even more striking.

Must See!. The stained glass windows are incomparable. This is truly a must-see sight. To avoid the long ticket buying lines, purchase a Paris Museum Pass so that you only have to wait for the security line. Regardless, the history, style, and architecture are worth the wait.

Worth the visit. Beautiful Chapel worth the visit. If you go there on a sunny day, it is like being inside a rainbow. The stained glass windows that deptict the Bible are a wonder. This is covered with the Museum Pass.

Stunning!. What's not to like! If church architecture is your thing you must pay a visit. We visited just before going to Notre Dame, equally stunning but the queues are a little smaller (only went in because they have the only toilets we could find). When done visit the restaurant directly opposite (can't remember the name) on your way to Notre Dame and just before the small street market even if it's just to sample the waiters humour. You will be well catered for, a bit pricey but worth it.

Stain glass heaven. I read about other people having long waits. We went in the morning before it opened 20 min prior to opening- security was easy to get through and we flashed our museum pass to get in. An audio tour was 5 extra euros. It told the story in depth of each of the stain glassed windows which was maybe more than we needed but would be great for those wanting to match the biblical books to the windows. It was our favorite church- over Notre Dame and Sacre Coeur. This can easily be followed with a tour through La Conciergerie.

Awe-Inspiring. Just around the corner from Notre Dame de Paris, Sainte-Chappelle is apparently no longer Paris's best-kept secret, given the line to get in, but it is worth the wait and not ridiculously expensive. The stained glass, notably the famous rose window, with its complex depiction of the Apocalypse, is perhaps the most stunning stained glass you will see anywhere. Mostly it's the glass that makes the space worth visiting, but it also has the oldest surviving mural in Paris and some excellent bas-relief carvings. A must-see for history buffs, especially ones interested in the history of the Catholic church. and these is also a decent souvenir shop, complete with little Quasimodo figurines (wrong church, but close enough!).

This has the wow factor. Much smaller than Notre- Dame it's a beautiful church full of character and interesting things to read up about. The upstairs is mind blowing totally spectacular windows really an enjoyable experience

Conciergerie and Sainte-Chapelle tour. If you are going to visit Sainte-Chapelle in Paris, we recommend that you buy the dual ticket for $4 more and see the Conciergerie (Prison where 2,700+ prisoners were held before being executed, including Marie Antionette), which is next to Sainte-Chapelle. This ticket allows you access to Sainte-Chapelle without waiting in line (can be quite long). Even if you only spend 15 minutes in the Conciergerie - your time will be well worth it.

Go upstairs.. Be sure and not walk out before you see the fantastic upstairs of the church. A couple did that but I ran up to them and tould them the best is up the stairs. Try and go when sun is out as to light up the beautiful windows.

How Not to Wait in Line. This place is amazing and beautiful. So many people complained about waiting in line it's worth mentioning that you don't have to if you buy tickets at France's Centre des Monuments Nationaux http://www.monuments-nationaux.fr/ You can print out the tickets which are good for a year from the date of purchase. When we arrived at the entrance the building we showed the paper with the printed out tickets and they let us through - skipping the very long line down the street (you can't actually skip this particular line with the Paris Museum Pass.) Also I think some of the people who wrote reviews describing the place as mostly a gift shop or windows cut off didn't go to the second floor. Walk up one of the two staircases near the door to see Sainte-Chapelle's amazing soaring windows. This was one of the highlights of our trip.

Wait times. My husband stood in line at 8:55am yesterday. It was a saturday. It opens at 9:30am. He was 5th in line. Bring your croissant and have breakfast in line. Well worth it. This church is a MUST DO!! Smaller than the Notredame but the stained glass windows are breathtaking

Breathtaking. I'm not a religious/ churchy person and really didn't want to go here, but it was one of the highlights of our trip. Stunning building. The wait to get in was a bit of a pain, but worth it.
Long wait in queue. Waited a long time for entry, several pre booked tours went straight through, staff not terribly helpful, so be prepared to wait.
All LIT UP. The stained glass windows are stunning in the upper cloister? we went to a violin concert- Vivaldi 4 Seasons at St. Chapelle and it was an amazing experience.
Very unique, stunning chapel. The 360 degrees of gorgeous stained glass makes for an unparalleled experience! Well worth any wait and ticket price.

Magnificent Stained Glass and Starry Ceiling. It is obvious why this was the king's private chapel at one time. While the downstairs is relatively simple, you ascent a narrow stone stairway to the magnificent upstairs flooded with light through wall to wall stained glass windows. The starry ceiling is magical. While a relatively small church compared to something like Notre Dame, it packs a real punch visually. Well worth the wait in line to get in. Due to the size and the staircase, they need to control the entry to limit the number of people inside at any one time.

Largely a waste of time. Rick Steves, in his tour guide, highly recommends Sainte Chapelle. It is a misfire, in my opinion. There is a lengthy security line to get in, as the building is within the Palace of Justice. We had planned on buying our museum passes here, thinking it would be less of an ordeal than at the Louvre or Orsay. Wrong. It took us 45 minutes to get through the security line. The chapel itself is small and underwhelming. The stained glass is about 1/3 obscured by a building that buts up against the chapel. The glass itself may have been fantastic for the time, but just seems adequate now. Half of the chapel seems like a souvenir shop. The Concergerie, where prisoners awaited execution next door, is more interesting in my opinion.

Beautiful church with a bit of a line to visit. Even though I'd been to Paris several times, I didn't remember ever visiting Sainte Chapelle. There was a bit of a line to get in, maybe 20 minutes or so, and they'd been closed for a few hours earlier that day. If I'd been on a tight schedule, I might not have been able to visit with the unannounced closing (not on the website that morning) and the line. As it was, I ended up in conversation with a lovely Canadian family so the time passed quickly.The church was beautiful, but there was some renovation work going on that limited access to parts of the church and its exterior. I know renovations have to be done, but that's always a bummer to me. Also, the steps might be a bit hard for people with disabilities yo navigate. It was a sunny day, so the stained glass was at its most magnificent. They also controlled the number of people allowed inside at a time, and that helped give everyone space to view and photograph without being so crowded. I didn't get an audio guide & don't recall if there was one offered, but I regret that I didn't have one. If you have a choice, always get the audio guide. It's worth a few extra euros. I did not care for the way the boutique was arranged at the church, but that is a personal preference. Long story short - go see this beautiful stained glass; it's one of the most beautiful examples of stained glass I've seen anywhere in the world.
Beautiful!. Worth the visit - doesn't take long at all to view - feast for the eyes. I recommend getting tickets online ahead of time to avoid the lines.

Goldberg Variations in a sauna. Beautiful venue but unbearably hot on a 33 degree day made worse as they close the doors and virtually no air.Also first time I have heard the Variations with strings. Can't remember the advertising saying it was not piano or harpsichord. Leaving soon before melting.

Concert in Sainte-Chapelle. My son found online that you could attend a concert in Sainte-Chapelle and it was one of the highlights of our trip to Paris. A string quartet played Vivaldi in the most incredible setting imaginable. It was dusk and sunlight still came through the well known beautiful stained glass windows. What an experience!

A beautiful Chapelle to visit along with Conciergerie. We loved Sainte-Chapelle but especially loved the history of the Conciergerie which can be part of the same tour. Read the history of the Conciergerie before you take the tour.

Breathtaking!. This may not be the biggest church in Paris but it is one of grandest! Search it out as it is hidden in the courtyard of government buildings and beside the Conciergerie. Guidebooks suggested there would be a long line; however, we arrived around 9:30 -10:00 am and had to wait only 15 minutes (thorough security check). Absolutely breathtaking ....the lower chapel for peasants is grand, and the upper chapel built for the King is all stained glass. Just sit on a chair, follow the guidebook provided which explains how the windows tell the whole story of the Bible, and meditate in the serenity of the moment. Not to be missed!
Magnificent!. This chapel is very beautiful to see but the concert at dusk was magical. Make reservations, it is worth it.
inadequate signage. waiting on line for about half an hour, we were finally told that the church has closed until 5. it was 230. why int this publicly posted?
Drop dead gorgeous. The line moved very quickly and was in the shade. The chapel is AMAZING. A MUST SEE. The windows are phenomenal the details in the artwork... wow.

Beyond Words. A visit to Sainte-Chapelle is a must-do. The beauty of this small chapel is breath-taking. Don't let the lines keep you from seeing this gem. Words can't describe our visit here and photos do not do it justice.

Stained glass is breathtaking. On the same island as Notre Dame you will find this smaller but beautiful cathedral. If you buy the Paris pass you can skip the long lines. There is a security check in as it's also surrounded by court buildings so you will have to queue for this line first. Definitely worth the visit.
Not far from Notre Dame and a must-see. The stained glass windows are worth the effort to get inside the church. Long lines and crowds are fairly typical.

Gorgeous stained glass windows - come early. The Paris Museum Pass works at this site but does not give you a "fast pass". The line can easily be a two hour wait for this small chapel. We got in line 20 minutes before it opened and got right in. I would go right up the the main chapel and come back to look at the small lower chapel in the way out. It is hard to describe the huge panels of stained glass in the upper chapel.

Finally got inside Sainte-Chapelle. This attraction is well known for its discouraging lines, which persist through the day. Finally the penny dropped -- it's sometimes open in the evenings: why not go at 6? Bingo! So after 4 or 5 tries, we finally found the right (and rather elementary) formula. And indeed Sainte-Chapelle lived up to its billing. It's a fabulous building, and the stained glass is, as advertised, breathtaking. One can sit for half an hour (also possible after 6) and just drink in the beauty which, to use a hackneyed but in this case deserved phrase, breathtaking.
Perfect. When you are in Paris you should definetely visit there, it is a different atmosphere and the location is very good.

I got chills when I first stepped in - our 13 y/o said "wow".... What an amazing place that we almost skipped. Probably the most beautiful church I've been in, and I've been in many (England, Ireland, Spain, Germany, Italy, and Greece). Go on a sunny day if possible.

over rated. we waited in a long line - 1.5 hours to see this site. It is very nice but not worth the wait. The gatekeeper at the front of the line yesterday (July 1 2015) was a nasty little fellow who reacted rudely and angrily when my 15 year old objected to him splitting our family up when we reached the front of the line to be admitted. One of the few instances of the stereotype of our French hosts (as far as Americans are concerned) matched our experience- rude , haughty, unwelcoming. The chapel is beautiful and has some interesting history but is not worth a prolonged wait. If you can arrive at a time when the line is short and , especially if you have the Paris museum pass, it's worth a quick stop.

Stunning.
