I'd wanted to see Sainte-Chapelle for years and so was thrilled to finally get a chance on my first trip to Paris.The queue looked long but actually moved quite quickly and we only spent approx 40 mins in line, and our wait was in the shade out of the hot Paris sun. It was 8euros per adult to go in, which is a fair price. The stained glass of the upper chapel is just stunning and we spent a long time looking at it, and enjoying its spectacular display.A really beautiful and unique thing to see, a visit is definitely recommended.

Inspiring Stained Glass windows- need to be seen to be believed!. PROS; 15 beautiful, stories-high stained glass windows telling numerous bible stories; gargoyles, chimeras on the exterior; beautiful archway and carvings inside; as long as you arrive 30 minutes before it opens, you should be in the front of the line and its an easy 1 hour stop; after entering immediately go to the upper level where the windows are; CONS: mostly unrestored, peeling paint on the floor and walls; the windows are the redeeming factor; smaller than you think; weird dirty one side then very clean other side facing the Palais De Justice;

Serenity and light. I once read a description of Sainte-Chapelle comparing it to being inside a light-filled jewel box, a wonderful comparison. I've seen many Gothic cathedrals and chapels in several countries, none as magnificent as the small Sainte Chapelle with its brilliant stained glass walls. I first visited Sainte-Chapelle many years ago and couldn't wait to take my family. Rather than fighting the hoards, I purchased tickets to an evening concert. Although a tourist concert, it was quite good and provided the opportunity to enjoy the beauty and the serenity that Sainte Chapelle is meant to have. We had an hour to sit quietly and absorb the light and color of the chapel with a background of Handel and Vivaldi. No one should visit Paris without seeing Sainte Chapelle.

Great stained glass!. I would not have known about this place if it hadn't been for some ladies I met at a restaurant the night before. It's a little church but the stained glass windows are incredible. Definitely worth the wait. The line outside is confusing because it looks like you need prepurchased tickets to stand there but you actually buy them once inside.

Absolutely mesmerizing light. This room full of stained glass will make your day. We went around 4pm and the light was filling the entrance making it quite surreal, almost magical. The details of the 15 windows, the floor and the high vaulted ceiling is breath taking. What is more amazing is that is was built in 1248! The chapel is small compared to nearby Notre-Dame but the elegance on the outside as well as inside, is unforgetable.Go ahead and put up with the line up if it looks short outside because inside, after security, is another line up. We waited about 45 minutes and had second thoughts until we got inside. No regrets.WOW.

The real treat is on the second floor. Unbelievably beautiful church! There was a fairly long wait to get through the security line but It was worth the It. The main floor of the church was lovely but the real treat was on the second floor!
Saint Chapelle. I loved the stain glass here more than that at Notre Dame, One could almost miss this in the rush to do it all. Love it, and recommend it.

Breathtaking. You will be amazed if you visit, don't miss it ! there are queus here but nothing like at the more popular attractions. It's hard to imagine the man hours required to construct this beautiful church.

Celebrate the Light. It has no rival. As beautiful as so many other cathedrals are, Sainte-Chapelle transforms light into an intimate setting with vibrant colors made more-so by the (fairly) recent cleaning of the windows.

The best of Paris and likely France. This one is 5 plus. It is unlike anywhere else in the size and scope of its stained glass. Something like 6500 square feet of stained glass (2/3rds original) in a relatively small chapel. A friend said it was like walking into a Jewel Box and I have to agree. It was my ultimate Paris hit.

Better than Notre Dame.. If I had to choose, I would come here before Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are definitely something to be seen. Try to go on a sunny day to get the full effect of the beauty and the best pictures. But don't worry, it is incredible all the time. Don't miss going upstairs where all the BIG stained glass windows are located.

Smaller than I had imagined. The stained glass is obviously the draw and well worth the visit. Set of small curved, steep stairs might be a problem for some. Very beautiful although smaller than I had imagined; especially after seeing other gothic churches in the city. In addition to visit, went back for a great Vilvadi concert the next day.

The most beautiful and historically significant religious structure in Paris. Although smaller in size and less famous than the more highly visited Notre Dame Cathedral just two blocks away, the stained glass windows and history of this 13th century Gothic Chapel are unparalled. Due to long lines necessitated by security checks, your best bet is to arrive 15 minutes before opening (9:30 from March through October, 9:00 from November through February). Do some reading about Sainte-Chapelle before you go to enhance your understanding of it. Photos don't do it justice - you have to see this magnificent chapel built by Saint Louis himself to house relics such as the crown of thorns (though this has since been moved to Notre Dame). Take your time here - get an audio guide and don't rush through it.
Beautiful Gothic church. The stained glass is amazing. It is all scenes from the Bible with each individual scene being very interesting. Most of the stained glass is original from the 13th century.
Beautiful. Beautiful church. The windows are amazing. The wait can be rather intimidating and find out when it will be open to visitors before you go.
beautiful example of rayonnant romanesque. a little hidden jewel in the heart of the Cite, not as popular with tourists, so less waiting in line.

Exqusite Stained Glass. Absolutely beautiful towering walls of stained glass in a city where stained glass is nearly commonplace. The entrance is in the lower level, but just go up the spiral staircase and prepare to have your breath taken away!

awe-inspiring. I'd seen pictures of the stained glass and it was a must-see. You enter through a downstairs area, and I thought - huh - have I made a mistake? Then you climb a small stone circular staircase and emerge into the chapel - and the beauty and color and richness and lights just fill your senses. Be sure to read the guide, and if possible take a tour for the history of the art. We were lucky enough to be there in late afternoon as the western sun came through the windows and light danced upon the floor and room. Don't miss !
I question if it is worth the eruos for the visit. The stained glass windows are beautiful. We had the Paris Pass that got us admission and also skip the line of those waiting to buy tickets.

Thought I'd Seen Stained Glass Windows. Have traveled extensively in Europe and frequently visited churches. My wife teases me about my stained-glass window picture collection. It is extensive. But I never really saw stained-glass windows until today at Sainte-Chapelle. Do spend the extra for the audio tour. It's incredibly informative and greatly enhances the visual experience.

Amazing. This church is very close to Notre Dame and alot of people will miss it. It does not have anything inside (pews) but it is worth your time. I suggest going early in the morning because the sun hits the amazing stained glass windows. I could stay there forever.

Close to Heaven. Visiting the king's chapel in daytime is a most worthy destination for a first time or an old hand Paris visitor. Attending an evening concert here is a transcendent experience, especially if it involves trumpets and music by the likes of Vivaldi and Telemann. The extraordinary array of stained glass windows, lit by candle or soft electric light, will stay with you for as long as your memory works. Without the burdens and privileges of being a king or courtier, you can admire the exceptional craftsmanship and religious inspiration that makes this one of the most beautiful religious venues in the world.
Magical.. Magical. Must-see in Paris for its unique and incredible stained glass art. The light and color they create inside the church is out of this world.

An Unexpected Visit. We were a family of 12 visiting Paris and decided to go to Sainte-Chapelle on a whim. We all were very surprised and delighted to see the beauty of the walls and ceilings of the rooms while we listed to the fascinating history of this chapel. A lucky find.

peace. I could swear I saw an angel :) opening the doors for those entering. Of course it was my imagination and of course the place is blessed in every way . A place you must visit. DO not count on guides. Get a map some comfortable shoes and visit. Make sure you have coins for poor angels hanging outside. Bring your camera.
The most magnificent stained glass in Paris. Frequently missed, this little chapel is extraordinary. You will catch your breath after climbing the stairs and viewing the glass. Absolutely spectacular

Some people skip this place because of the admission fee, don't be one of them. This church is on the small side especially compared to the legendary Notre-Dame Cathedral which is just a few minutes away. However, don't be put off by the small size as it is one of the most beautiful churches in the city. On a sunny day, the stained glass is absolutely mind-blowing. This attraction charges an entrance fee so we saw some people turning around without going in. Don't make the same mistake and make sure you check this place out. It's worth every penny.

Music at Sainte-Chapelle. The best way to see Sainte-Chapelle is to book tickets for a concert. We heard an ensemble play Vivaldi's Four Season one evening . The acoustics were brilliant and the sun setting and shining through the stain glass created an amazing atmosphere. It made a perfect evening which we followed with a walk along the Seine with our heads full of music.
A delight!. It's like nothing I ever seen. It's something behind description, so incredible and astonishing. It's definitely a must see!

A jewel box. Among the wonders of the world, a perfect gothic chapel with the most beautiful stained glass and preserved medieval decoration. I was moved that after Sante-Chapelle and St Denis the glaziers moved on to York Cathedral and the grandsons and great nephews of the glaziers mad e the glass for Canterbury.

Must go!. Absolutely stunning glass windows. I had to rush to get there before closing but it was worth every bit of effort... enjoyed it more than Notre Dame! Plus glass has just been restored and cleaned so gleaming! Would recommend it to anyone visiting Paris... should be up with Arc DTriomphe and Tower!

A stained glass marvel !. Located by the side of the Palais du Justice, visitors undergo stringent security check before being permitted to enter this building with its soaring stained glass panels in the upper chapel. You should coordinate visiting this gem with the one to the Cathedral of Notre Dame, which is located in the square opposite but hidden from view by the Police headquarters. The relics of the crown of thorns and the cross, earlier housed in the Cathedral are now kept here. They are open to public view once a week and on certain festive days.

A magical musical evening. Listening to Vivaldi's four seasons (along with 200 other folk) in this beautiful church was an outstanding and moving experince. Three violins, a viola, a cello and a harpsichord delivered a magical sound in this ancient place.

Sainte Chapelle. After every day of sightseeing, we said 'it can't get any better tomorrow', but this was the icing on the cake. It is incredible. The stained glass windows are huge and have brilliant colours shining in the sun. It is still being restored so you can see small areas where it is still a little dirty so good to see the contrast.This is a must visit.

Concert in Sainte Chapelle. We visited Paris in June. To avoid too much standing in line for the Sainte Chapelle we opted to prebuy tickets to a 7pm concert followed by dinner nearby. We liked this option as we turned up as the city was quieting down, we arrived early enough to be near front of line (seats are first in, first seated, depending on section you buy), quick through security and up to chapel. Concert was professional and displayed great violin playing skills. And we had plenty of time to view and photograph splendid stained glass windows before and after concert. Light was great at this time of day too. Recommended.

Needs to be more widely known. We visited this gem because a relative living in the suburbs of Paris confessed that this was his favorite spot. From the outside, it is another stately old Paris church, of which there is no scarcity. On entering, one sees a bunch of well-preserved stained glass windows, half of which are hidden by a bunch of booths selling tchotchkes. Nothing prepares you for what is to come. You go up a spiral stone staircase, and enter this astoundng place. Soaring gothic ceilings (around 90 feet high) are held up by a few thin stone columns. The ENTIRE remaining space, floor to ceiling, consists of stained glass, illustrating in numerous panels the entire bible!! A truly jaw-dropping, beautiful sight, which puts every other church I have seen in Europe in the shade. Almost everyone goes to Notre Dame. This is a few steps away, and a shame to miss!!!!

Amazing stained glass. The stained glass in this church is not to be missed. You should go in the late afternoon as the sun will be shining on the windows and it looks brilliant and the definition is fantastic. Please remember that this church was built in the 1200's. We had a line and even with the museum pass we had to wait. We waited for 1 hour and I thought my husband would want to bail as it was the end of the day before getting cleaned up for dinner. Afterwards he was thrilled that we had seen the glass. We both thought it was well worth it. One of the nice things for us is that we chose a hotel on the Ile Saint Louis and we just a few minute walk back. The line is on a tree lined street so you are in the shade as you are waiting.
Museum Pass won't get you in quickly.. Beautiful stained glass windows. A long queue which you can't skip with your Museum Pass due to security checks and the small size of the Chapel.

Sainte-Chapelle - Spectacular!!!! Don't miss this.. We visited Sainte-Chapelle in mid-May 2015 with the Paris Museum Pass. You still have to stand in line as you have to pass through security, but you don't have to wait for the person in front of you to purchase their ticket (you are in the courtyard of the Justice Center?) We went there later in the day, and it didn't take long to get in. When you enter the chapel on the first level, you are wowed by the ceiling - the most beautiful blue and gold. The stained glass is beautiful in here, as is the rest of the chapel. But, ascend the small staircase and prepare to be overwhelmed by the most beautiful panels of stained glass you've ever seen. Be sure to get an oversized laminated card (free to use) with the description of each panel in the chapel. Each panel depicts a different book of the Bible. Even for a non-religious person like me, it is really moving. Do not miss this while in Paris. TIP: If you are in Paris for a few days, get the Paris Museum Pass - you really do get into places quicker. Be sure to get in lines for Passes (most places have separate lines).

Brilliant. This church is small yet has no rivals when it comes to its lovely stain glass. In summer you may spend more time in line than in the church but it is worth the effort. Better yet pick up a concert ticket and sit in on a one hour evening concert and enjoy the beauty at the same time.

Historic Paris Walk. This is another stop along the Rick Steves audio tour, and a perfect way to to spend a lovely June day. The crowds are huge, but the audio tour allows you to stop when you need or want to. Architecture is everything in this part of Paris.

What money buys you. Since day one it's been like that. Ste. Chapelle is a wonderful example of this. After visiting Notre Dame, walked town to Ste. Chapelle. Don't be surprise when you entered the first floor, that is what the "poor" got. It is amazing to see how little was given to them. Then go up the stairs and get blinded by all the stained glass on the walls. The second floor was for the rich people! amazing beauty! Funny, the first floor didn't even had 1 window. Really a pretty church, amazing contrast and very close to N. Dame.
Hidden gem. A gorgeous small cathedral with phenomenal stained glass windows. The laminated guides that explain what is pictured in each window are very informative. Definitely worth a quick visit.

one of the top ten sights. one of the few remaining original medieval buildings and often overlooked (including me). Go on a sunny day and make sure the sun is shining on the best stain glass windows in Paris. For me the walk from the basement into the light was memorable.

Beautiful but SLOW lines. Beautiful chapel, but the line to see it were about an hour with the slowest ticket sellers possible. We were wondering if this was their attempt to reduce the size of the crowds visiting? By your tickets in advance if you plan on seeing this attraction
See a musical performance. We saw this chapel during a string Quintet. Bought tickets at FNAC. Such a breathtaking place. The music lasted 1.5 hours. A great evening activity.

Stop-in-your-tracks beautiful. Getting to the top of the stairs at Sainte-Chapelle is like being inside a jewelry box. It's impossible to understand how incredible it is until you're there. It's worth the wait in the security line!
So so .... You have to pay to enter.I expected more. It is a beautiful chapel, it is true, but does not call attention to great detail. The stained glass windows are beautiful but that's it.
Absoulutely Beautiful. Upper Chapel is breathtaking, full of stained glass windows depicting all the books of the bible and the stories contained within. Wonderful to take in!
Breathtaking stained glass. I had seen stained glass before, but nothing like this- numerous detailed scenes rendered in stained glass that remind you of mosaics.

Breathtaking. We decided to visit Sainte Chapelle by attending a classical music concert in the early evening. It was perfect - the windows are wonderful and the music fabulous....Get there a bit early as there aren't really reserved seats...
Hidden Gem. Such beautiful stained glass windows... I could have spent much more time there "reading" the stories they tell. Don't miss this!

Breathtaking. The moment you walk in to the Saint Chapelle you are blown away by the amazing stain glass windows and rich decorations. One of the prettiest churches I have ever seen, simply stunning. A must see. Go early at opening time, 9.30 in the morning and there is only a short queue.

A must when visiting Paris. Worth the wait if there is a queue due to security screening f bags etcThe stained glass is simply stunning and not to be missed.Have been in morning and afternoon and I believe the later is the best.Wait for a seat, grab the info provided on large sheets and give it a read.It will really enhance your visit.
beautiful windows. it was a beautiful building- ie stained glass windows. unfortunately it was under renovations, so the outside of the building was surrounded by scaffolding.

Narrow space but beautiful stained glass. I have been in the chapel several times and always say WOW! when I get to the second floor. Lines are long, and the sunlight is sometimes not helpful (i.e., it is cloudy outside) so the glass doesn't glow as much, but it is always worth a visit.
Worth the visit. The wait ouside the police station to be searched and the wait ouside the chapel are well worth it to see the amazing mostly original windows.
Beautiful!. On the same island as Notre Dame, absolutely beautiful stained glass windows! Worth the walk from Notre Dame, see the Concergerie next door if you have time!

A Gem. The Upper Chapel may have been my favorite thing to see within Paris city limits. Recently cleaned and restored, the stained glass was STUNNING! Notre Dame is an engineering marvel, but Saint Chapel (where Louis IX, Saint Louis worshiped) is truly much more beautiful.

The most beautiful stsined glass windows in the world. For me there is no more beautiful stained glass windows in the world and is the highlight of sites to see in Paris. Although the signs outside say it is open all day long, be advised that it is closed from 1PM to 2:15. Last entrance is at 5:30. Well worth the effort to adjust your schedule to see this beauty of a church. Make sure to see both levels. The upper level has the spectacular windows and is reached by a narrow wi ding stone staircase.
Stained Glass House. This medieval Gothic church is a must see for it's stained glass walls. Leave your camera behind and just admire the light pass through it's walls.

A paradise of stained glass. The beauty of the second floor chapel is overwhelming -more than a thousand bible images portrayed in glass. The line seems unbearably long (no quick entrance with museum pass) but it moved fairly quickly and was well worth the 20 minute wait.

Beautiful chapel. This chapel is usually passed over for Notre Dame on the other side of the island. It is very beautiful, with many stained glass windows all around the chapel. The biggest drawback is the additional security, as it is next to the Palace of Justice. Worth the visit!

Simply breathtaking. I'd heard about Ste.-Chapelle for years. Even studied it in school long ago. But nothing can prepare one for the sudden feeling of "oh my goodness" when one catches that first glimpse of the chapel itself coming up the stairs. The only comparable thing I've ever experienced is my first in person glimpse of the Grand Canyon.Come early, or even better, come very late, right before it closes. On a sunny day, the place is even better in the late afternoon than in the morning.On somewhat of a sidelight, Louis IX; "St. Louis", who build this place, might be one of the more overrated kings in French history. He was corrupt. He was a virulent anti-Semite, who burned copies of the Talmud and persecuted mightily the Jews of Paris. However, the Pope loved him because he gave LOTS of money to the Church, and thus his sainthood. But as a legacy, he couldn't do better than this, his private chapel. One of the most beautiful, if not THE most beautiful, interior of a building you'll ever see, anywhere.
Spectacular Stained Glass. I had heard that the stained glass windows were worth seeing, but was skeptical. Well worth the short wait to go through security. The windows were spectacular and ornate.

One of the Most Beautiful Spots Ever. This former church/chapel is a gem of a spot. The walls are all stained glass 30-40 feet high. It's beautiful, quiet, with a nice feel inside. As a bonus, try to attend a concert there. The acoustics are incredible. A must see.

Unappreciated Spectacular Church. This is the most awe inspring church on all of Paris!!! Because of it hidden location it is unappreciated and little advertised. But it is a MUST see! I have no words to describe its beauty.

Beautiful. Really beautiful WOW! It seemed a bit over priced but I still say it was well worth the stop. Only a 15 min wait, I would suggest going either realy early or at the end of the say to avoid long lines.
Insanely beautiful. Looking in from outside, you'd never imagine the perfect stained glass jewel box that awaits you inside. The line is often long, but I thought it was 100% worth the wait.
GORGEOUS!. Loved this chapel. The stained glass is absolutely AMAZING! Lines can be long but we thought it was worth the wait.

Well worth the wait. The wait outside was about an hour. There is a charge to get in. Once you get through the outside line you will be taken to a center courtyard, which is the outside of the church. I would wait to take pictures outside, as there is another line to wait in to pay to get inside. You can take your outside pictures when you are done. If you are going to see the tall stained glass, you will enter the main floor of the church and have to make your way up a spiral staircase. The glass is almost floor to ceiling. It is awesome. Try to go on a sunny day.

Beautiful!. The line may be long to get in, but Sainte Chapelle IS beautiful. It's not as large as Notre Dame and the downstairs area is in need of repairs (I believe they are happening now), but once you walk upstairs and view the King's Chapel...it's quite magnificent!There's not a lot to see/do here, but if you're in the area, it's definitely worth a visit.FYI: if you have a Museum Pass, this will NOT allow you to get in any faster.
Exquisite. Sainte-Chapelle has exquisite stained glass. The ground floor can be skimmed. Head on upstairs and enjoy the beauty. Certainly best viewed when not crowded.

Beautiful. Lovely light filled chapel. Seeing pictures of it is not the same as experiencing this beautiful space filled with colored light. - do this! The lines can be long but they move pretty quickly and it is totally worth it!
Open Late. Our hotel information said that the church was open late. We did not know that a Valdi concert was to be conducted. Double bonus for us!

Took my breath away. I am so glad I didn't receive much information about this cathedral before arriving, only "you must see this" - it literally took my breath away when I was inside the cathedral. I would go so far as to say my entire trip to Paris was worth it on this site alone.
Stunning stained glass. Newly renovated charming chapel near Notre Dame with breathtaking stained glass windows. Lines can be long so go early if possible.

Favorite- not to be missed. What an amazing sight! All that stained glass soaring in such an intimate setting is stunning. Each panel tells another biblical story, going around the chapel in chronological order. It is hard to absorb it all. Optimally you should go every week and explore another section!I can only wonder how they created such beauty all those centuries ago.The line to get in takes a while and it is crowded with other tourists but the Sainte-Chapelle is not to be missed.
A spectacular stained glass display. We had a long wait to enter and there was a fee, but the stained glass was magnificent. Near Notre Dame.
Something special. It takes a bit of a wait and the place is not too big, but the design and windows are just spectacular. It is different from other churches, which makes it interesting.

stunning. The queue went down the pavement to the big gates and back again but only took about 20 minutes to get in.The chapel is breathtaking with the coloured roofing on the lower level and the towering glass windows on the upper floor.Not to be missed.

Amazing. The long line was off putting and we did quit and come back when it was shorter but we were so glad we did. The stained glass was breath-taking. Unbelievable how this church was made. Beautiful.

My favourite of all the churches.. Even though they charge to get in, it is well worth the visit. It is unlike all the other Parisian churches, The architecture is so fine and the stained glass windows are just breathtaking. A must see

"Light and Bright". When we arrived and got on the long line only to find that the museum was closed for lunch and would not reopen until 2PM. We decided not to wait for over an hour and went to lunch ourselves. When we returned and got on line again, only to wait for over an hour. After going through the Notre Dame Cathedral we found this church/museum to be light and bright with the most beautiful stained glass windows. We were disappointed that they had many pamphlets in different languages, but none available in English. They have a whole section of the church designated as a gift shops that were quite pricey. I guess it would have been worth having a museum pass to avoid some of the long lines at these venues.

The most beautiful building in the world. A friend recently shared with me the written reaction of her thirteen-year-old daughter when she walked into Sainte-Chapelle. Her sense of awe was exactly what I experienced in my recent visit. There is no other place like it. A drawback is the large crowds that throng to it. A suggestion: there are frequent chamber music concerts in the evening. We went to a concert of Mozart and Schubert. The combination of the music and the venue were incredible.
A masterpiece not to be missed. Breath-taking colors, especially on a sunny day, been several times and always return, can look at these glass illustrations for hours
Amazing Stained Glass. The recently renevated Saint Chapelle was breath taking. The church is unlike a lot of the other churches we saw in the Paris. The Stainted glass was absolutely beautiful.

Worth the visit. Beautiful church with amazing architecture and stained glass windows. A much better description for the windows would truly be works of art, masterpieces.We visited late afternoon and waited in line for 45 minutes. This was true of most museums in Paris. I wish there was a good system for buying tickets online but the wait was fine. This stop was a welcomed change of pace from the museum visits which were also wonderful.

Stunning. You are not prepared for the sheer beauty of Sainte Chapelle. Even though there are a lot of people, it has a real feeling of spirituality. The stained glass has to be seen to be believed. And the ground floor is equally fantastic, though because the gift shop is located here, the feeling isn't quite the same. There are queues to enter the chapel, but be patient - it is worth it.

Interesting Side Stop. We had purchased the museum pass and so stopping at this attraction after Notre Dame was a no brainer. It didn't take too much time, and was next door. I'd classify this stop as an easy to do and mildly interesting place to visit.

Absolutely stunning stained glass. Be sure to go on a sunny day to fully appreciate the nearly 360 degrees of stained glass. Absolutely beautiful! A short walk from Notre Dame - go there first to admire the architecture, but save any studies of stained glass for St. Chapelle.
most beautiful church windows. its a little bit hidden but trust me its worth to find it - and to wait in case there is a queue.. absolutely stunning church windows will leave you speechless.. a must

Amazing stained glass windows. Fantastic chapel with enormous stained glass windows - very impressive. Never seen anything like it elsewhere. 8.5 euros may seem a little steep for entry to what is quite a small chapel - it's by no means a cathedral but well worth the visit

By far, our favorite church we visited in the city. Gorgeous stained glass. Breathtaking. Be sure to either use the recordings, or for a shorter tour, grab one of the laminated cards by the upstairs exit (not sure why they are placed there) to get more out of your window viewing. The first floor is a little underwhelming, but the tour explains that this area was the worship space for the servants and the poor. The second floor is really what you are visiting to see. You will have to walk up a narrow stair to it, so be advised. This is where the royalty worshiped. I wish we had gone to an evening concert, as I am sure they must be magical. Next time! Museum Pass here allows you to skip the entrance line right up to the security.

Stunning. This church is exquisite. Towering ceiling. Stained glass windows unbelievably high and delicate. Every surface is covered in some sort of different painted decoration. Just beautiful. The line for entry is always long. There are concerts held here, we attended a Vivaldi violin concert (Four Seasons), had front row seats, this way we saw the church and the magical concert. Just perfect. Highly recommend this beautiful building

beautiful church. We didn't go on a tour of the church but rather went to an evening concert. We didn't buy tickets in advance but rather showed up just before a performance and waited on the sidelines to see if there were any seats available. We had 2 teenagers who got reduced rates. We were given options of which type of seats we wanted - we opted for the cheap seats in the back as you don't really need to see the performers for a music concert.The church was beautiful - gorgeous stained glass windows. As the sun went down, the way the light shines thru the glass was glorious. We went to a Vivaldi quintet which lasted over an hour. Beautiful music - you can look around and admire the setting as you listen to the music. Highly recommended.

Beautiful stained glass!. We went early on Sunday morning at 9:30AM. While there was a short wait in the security line, we had the Paris Museum Pass which allowed us to bypass the line and see the chapel with stained glass very efficiently. There is a chapel when you first go in and then climb some spiral stairs to the second floor where the tall windows are gorgeous. We saw this attraction in under an hour.

Some of the most beautiful stained glass windows I have seen. Yes, I stop at churches. Sometimes it seems like ALL of them or so my husband says. The church is nearly hidden from the street but don't let that deter you. The bottom floor still looks like a work in progress and I was a little put off that half of one side is a gift shop BUT once you go up the stairs there is a glorious exhibit of stained glass windows. There are information cards in several languages to help you decipher what you are seeing. Very impressive and worth the line and entrance fee.

Vivaldi at Sainte Chapelle. We arrived late and were on the wait list for tickets that evening. No problem, there are lots of empty space. Ended up seated in the 2nd and 4th rows. A magical night of music in such an exquisite place
Beautiful stained glass windows. This was our second time here & it still took my breath away. The stained glass windows were so beautiful. This is a must stop whe you're in Paris.

My favorite site in Paris. It's like entering a perfect jewel box of glorious colors. If you can, visit when the sun is out. The line can be long, and the Paris Museum Pass does not give you priority to skip the line, but the wait is worth it.
A sweet amazing beautiful place. Very old, pretty, and small....can be very crowded with long lines.....I would try to go early in the day, or in a less tourist traveled period of the year.

Most Beautiful Chapel. Saint Chappelle has the most memorable Stained Glass windows I have ever seen in my life. There is always a line, try to get there early. Some say it is even more beautiful than Notre Dame. It was built as a private chapel for King Louis the 9th.

AMAZING!. This was the one place I really wanted to see in Paris. And it was so worth the walk. We waited in line for about 45 minutes on the street. Once inside the gate and through security, yes security, you have to sort of find your way to the entrance. But once inside - it is truly spectacular. It's not your usual church tour. You can find your own way and stay as long as you like. In this case, words can't describe...

Another beautiful Parisian church. Beautiful architecture, and a bit quieter than some of the other cathedrals e.g. Notre Dame. We happened to come by on a Sunday morning, so we went in and listened to a sung mass - beautiful!
Europe 2015. If you thought Notre Damn was amazing wait until you see this. If it is stained glass you want to see then here it is! Just inspirational, framed by the most elegant arches.

The top floor was very colorful. Most memorable church during trip.. It was so beautiful inside that I hide to buy a post card because the camera couldn't capture all of the stained glass and colors inside. A lot more memorable than the Norte Dame Cathedral. Line was long in the morning (~10am). Maybe waited 45min-1hr.

Better than Notre Dame. This is the most beautiful Church that I have ever seen, I think even more so than Notre Dame. It takes your breath away when you walk up the stairs and first see the stained glass chapel, it's stunning. There are two lines, one for the department of Justice (I think) and the other for Sainte Chappelle. It appeared to me that both lines gave you access to the same complex. The reason I mention this, is that the queue for Justice was a fraction of the one for Sainte Chappelle.

Always a must on your tourist itinerary !. This place is so beautiful, everyone should visit at least once. I have been to Paris 6 times and each time I go to see the glass and the beauty of the church.

Ahhh... The Stained Glass. Tough to take in in one sitting. Do the best you can. This is by far my family's favorite in all of Europe. The glass work on the 1st level is impressive enough, but the 2nd level is beyond words. Many, many visitors to Paris miss this Cathedral/Chapel. Don't be like them! Well Worth the look!
Stunning. The stained glass;so beautiful.Go on a sunny day and go upstairs(I might have not known to do this without the contributors on TA)

The most awe-inspiring sight I have ever seen.. I am so glad we saw this place. It is sacred, historical, breath-takingly beautiful. The line took a little time, but it was worth it. We went on a Saturday, after lunch, so I am sure it was at its more crowded time. When we walked through the doors into the church, my mouth just dropped open and stayed that way until I remembered to close it. Just WOW.

The lines are long- and worth every minute.. This architectural gem is worth the long lines and crowds. The stained glass and the architecture changed how churches are built. It is part of the Museum Passes program of Paris attractions. Purchase your pass in advance for quicker access to the Church.
Better than Notre Dame. Sainte-Chappelle was more beautiful than Notre Dame for us. The stained glass windows were breathtaking and we didn't want to rush the experience.

Beautiful glass.. After a bit of a wait we finally arrived at the ground floor and thought it a disappointment. Fortunately I decided to climb the stairway, and, what a wonderful surprise The superb colours of the glass were worth the wait. It was the first time I had heard of this Chapel and very happy we found it. They do have a problem with the double line in conjuction with the Palace of Justice. I could not find a brochure which clearly defined the layout of of the building which would have been helpful. It seemed they closed for lunch. For us, it was a favourite site.

The music and setting are breathtaking. We attended a violin concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons at Sainte Chappelle. The concert was conducted by members of a the Orchestre de Paris who performed the music that ranged from traditional to fairly non-traditional, perfectly orchestrated. I highly recommend this concert to everyone. Beautiful music in a beautiful setting is an unbeatable combination. The concert lasts 70 minutes. I do not recommend this concert for small children.

Stained glass that will make your jaw drop. I have seen many cathedrals and chapels in my time, but the stained glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle are simply stunning. The chapel is small enough that you feel like you're completely surrounded by their colours, especially if you're fortunate enough to be there when the sun shines through them. Beautiful, emotional experience. The carvings of figures on the walls are also fascinating. Note: I could not date my review any earlier than July 2014, but this is based on my visit in 2012.

Trip highlight!. The stained glass encrusted cocoon that you climb up into is utter eye candy! I thoroughly enjoyed visiting Sainte Chapelle over Notre Dame. It is warm in the chapel, yes- but it's cooler downstairs and the souvinier vendors are fun to walk through. Next time I visit Paris, this is one of my first stops! You won't regret a visit here. Just a caution- they won't let anyone in past 5:30pm. Make sure you give yourself enough time make it inside.

Hidden Gem!. Tucked away inside the Palace of Justice, you have to know to look for this. A lot of people miss it. King Louis wanted an all-glass chapel to house the crown of thorns relic brought back from the holy land. This chapel was built in 5 years to accommodate that. All the walls are elaborate stained glass. The light is spectacular. In the evenings, they have a concert series, so if you get the opportunity to attend one, it is a great setting for this type of entertainment.

Forget the crowds and Enjoy the History. Recently renovated - we were told - this is the most impressive historical destination of our trip. A bit of a hidden gem on the Ile St-Louis and not a far walk from Notre-Dame, this stain glass marvel is one of the original Paris landmarks predating much of the history elsewhere.We went mid morning and aside from the queue for security there were no lines at all. If you buy the Museum Pass, you'll walk right in ... and if not, you may wait just a bit for an available pass purchase at 8.50. Audio tour or simple viewing is available and you could expect this to take an hour or so for a complete review.Enjoy.

Always wonderful!. This was our third concert visit to Sainte-Chapelle. We heard Vivaldi's Four Seasons by Orchestre Paris Classic, featuring violinist Bertrand Cervera, who really was fantastic. We bought a CD, which he signed, and he told us his group is planning a concert in New York's Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.As always, the atmosphere at Ste. Chapelle was majestic: the 360-degree floor to ceiling stained glass, the amazing acoustics, the whole thing.

grotesque & airy. I had spent some 40 min to enter the place even on April but it s rather worth it. Ive never seen such elaborate stained-glass & wooden carvings before & You can take Your coffee & cigarette together with plenty of judges on the steps of Supreme Court just after.

Sublime venue for concert despite cameras. We enjoyed a fine concert in this exquisite building. The music in this light filled space was great. Entry is drawn out due to security procedures and organisers are a little casual overall. For example no public request is made not to photograph during the concert despite lots of time to make photos of the space beforehand. Overall it is well worth the long entry process to have such a special experience.

One of the most beautiful attractions of Paris!. We "happened" upon this gem on a rainy, cold hail stormed day. We were literally coming in out of the storm. And found this wonderful surprise! One of the highlights!
A staggeringly wonderful experience every time. I haven't been there since the renovations/cleanings. WOW! Phenomenal. I find blue in the stained glass mesmerizing.

Well worth a visit. This was my second visit to this chapel and worth the repeat. There was a small line to get in and the price at 8.50E is reasonable. The first time here I just looked around the ground floor and thought that was it until I noticed people going up a stairway in the corner. When I got to the top of the stairs I was just amazed. The stained glass was just spectacular. This visit I went straight upstairs upon entering and there was a bit of a crowd. Plus it was quite warm up there so the big doors at one end were open. This actually let alot of light in which I felt took away from the dramatic effect of the stained glass. You don't need alot of time here because it is quite small, but well worth a visit.
Gasp!. That's all I could say when I entered. An amazing and inspiring, sacred place not to be missed. The windows are like nothing else in any other cathedral. The walls are stained glass!

Beautiful concert venue. Absolutely stunning venue for live music. Would recommend seeing whatever show they have and upgrading to VIP tickets so you'll get the free glass of champagne at the restaurant across the street, which is absolutely wonderful with the best service ever!
Gorgeous!. This is the most beautiful stained-glassed church I have ever seen, bar none. Your neck will be sore because there's so much to appreciate ! (traveled in May 2012)

A must see . . .. Went to one of their evening concerts (Vivaldi's Four Seasons) and loved hearing that gorgeous music in that gorgeous space. If you haven't been there I highly recommend adding it to the top of your list of Paris attractions. And listening to music only adds to the experience.

Early evening concert magical.. A must for both the setting (intimate, setting sun streaming through stain glass windows) and the music. In this case, the orchestra was "Paris Classik" playing Vivaldi's The Four Seasons. I paid a bit extra for VIP seats which were much closer, but don't sit too much to the front, or you won't get the full impact of the stain glass.
renovations are done: see it. The renovations are finally finished and it looks wonderful. This is a tiny little chapel that's pretty much all stained glass.

Breath taking. Ascend the tight, winding spiral stone steps to the top level and prepare to have your breath taken away by the magnificent, towering panels of stained glass. The most amazing color I've ever experienced.

Breathtaking. There were lines to visit so plan ahead. It sometimes closes for lunch. This is a gem and should not be missed. It is unforgettable. There is always a gasp of delight as visitors enter the chapel.

Try To Enjoy A Concert Here. I have been here and truly was amazed by the beauty of the stained glass windows. (Be sure to go to the second floor -- it can be a little confusing the first time.) This time, I wanted to attend a concert -- You can find the schedule and book the tickets online before you leave home. Yes, there are a couple of lines to wait, but so what.The space is truly incredible. We felt so fortunate to enjoy lovely, classical music while watching the sunlight dance and dim across the stained glass as the evening progressed. The musicians, and opera singer, were very good an friendly -- They greeted their "guests" as we left for the evening. I can not recommend this highly enough.

No "skip the line" at this site. The stained glass work is beyond beautiful. The only thing good to know is that although they accept the Museum Pass they do NOT have a skip the line option like other attractions, so plan to possibly wait.

Glorious. Skip Notre Dame - it's splendid from the outside, dim and cramped-feeling inside. Come to Sainte-Chappelle instead ... you can miss it from the outside, grubby and nondescript, but inside... oh, inside! One enters at the lower level, the level of the less important worshippers, which is lovely in itself, all painted and decorated walls. But once you climb the little spiral stair to St Louis's dream - oh! The world is made of light. It's a miracle today - imagine yourself in the Middle Ages, seeing something like this, walls seemingly all of glass, a rainbow of jewels, a ceiling arched to heaven. Utterly gorgeous.

WOW. There are very few truely WOW moments when travelling - but this is one.The first few steps into the first-floor chapel are an experience to remember.(Put up with any long queues - you'll be glad you did),

Be prepared to be surprised and amazed. due to time constraints, we chose Sainte-Chapelle above Notre Dame. We were not disappointed. A beautiful church with amazing lead light on the second level. Not to be missed!

Breathtaking. Sainte-Chapelle is near to Notre Dame and is it possible to visit both in one day. Sainte-Chapelle is smaller than Notre Dame.Tthe stained glass is so beautiful you stare up at them trying to decipher the stories. The line outside the building may be long but it goes quickly. You do have to go through security screening and they inspect your bags. I would recommend going to Sainte-Chapele. Overall I would say an hour is a good amount of time to spend here.

Best stained glass windows I have ever seen. This will always be my favourite in Paris... try to go on a clear sunny day as it will give you the best effect from the windows. On my second visit here, it was raining and part of the windows were being restored... still stunning.
Do not miss this!. Though the line through security is lengthy, don't miss out on this beautiful hidden gem! We were blown away by the beauty of this chapel! A highlight of our 5 days in Paris!

Beautiful. A really quick visit but worth it just to see these incredible windows. You enter the chapel downstairs and we were disappointed, thinking the windows would be better. We were very impressed when we walked upstairs and saw the actual incredible windows.

Most beautiful church in the world. I've been to Saint-Chapelle several times and never cease to be amazed at the beauty. 360 degree stained glass windows that, amazingly, survived the French Revolution.

Where is that entry?. One of the most difficult entries to locate, but well worth it. (It shares the entry to the jail.) Ground floor is dark with impressive stained glass, but don't stop there. My husband preceded me up the winding steps to the church. I heard "WOW!" when he reached the top. This is nothing short of spectacular! It is amazing that this beauty was spared during the war. Sainte-Chappelle is a "must see."

The bluest blue-truly heavenly.. Another not-to-be missed experience in Paris. You enter and immediately your eye goes to the " starry" blue ceiling studded with gold fleur-de-lis. But then you go up the stairs to see stained glass from the 1240s. Let there be light indeed! The workmanship is incredible-look at the folds and details. Takes Museum Pass.

A "history pearl" near Notre Dame. After visiting Notre-Dame, we decided to walk around till the Flowers Market where we were informed that Sainte-Chapelle was 100 mts away and shoudn´t miss it. We went there for a visit, decided to visit also the Concirgerie where, after the Revolution of 1789, Marie Antoinette and her children was inprisioned before being executed. The Chapell is small but beautifull with lovelly vitrals that on a sunny day are simply astonishings. The Conciergerie is worthwhile to visit for historic memories. We didn´t have the time to attend a Concert (our last day) but we certainly would have if we knew (usually saturday night 20h30). One final curiosity that should be copied by other countries / cities: free entrance till 18 yo, 70% from 19 till 25 yo. I do recommend it.
Treat for the soul. The stained glass windows have been cleaned and as you walk in they take your breath away absolutely beautiful. The atmosphere is so peaceful.Refreshing

Stain glass paradise. We visited this cathedral because there was such a long line up to tour Notre Dame so we opted to skip ND and go to Sainte-Chapelle which is nearby. Sainte-Chapelle is famous for recording history through use of stained glass as a medium. It was well worth the visit.
Beautiful. Beautiful architecture with peaceful atmosphere inside the chapel is making it worth visiting even one is not religious.

Two Churches on Two Floors. This used to be a royal church and is one of the oldest monument of the capital. It is dedicated to Saint Louis, the King of France who reigned at the time when "crusades" was flourishing...

Gorgeous!. Stunning windows and architecture. This is a must for anyone visiting Paris! Entry was free for us as we were in the 18-25/26 range and were a member of the EU. Have to go through security (bag check) before entering the church. Was blown away by how beautiful and colourful this place was. Would visit again.

Heavy security makes this difficult to see. Since the Charlie Hebdo incident in January 2015, the security to get into Sainte-Chapelle has made this attraction much harder to see, as the entry is through the same gate as for the main courts (Palais de Justice) and the screening is much more rigorous than in past years. Parisian friends tell me that the best way to see this is to get tickets to a concert or to try to get a reserved-entry ticket with set time, but warn that they've heard that the wait time to get in can be an hour or more even for reserved entry tickets. Wait time for entry was over three hours during each of the several times we passed by during our latest visit at the end of May, so we ended up skipping this sight in favor of other attractions where the wait time was shorter.

Favorite Spot in Paris. Just don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. It cannot be adequately described in words. The stained glass windows here are breath taking. A sunny morning is the best time to visit. Don't stop with just visiting the lower level. You must go up the winding, narrow stone stairs to see the splendor of this place.

Hidden Gem. It is hard to believe this beautiful church survived the tragedies of war and has been preserved for future generations to marvel.Even with arthritis inboth knees and ankles, I am so glad I went up those spiral stairs to view the most beautiful stained glass!

Worth the wait - beautiful stained glass windows. Worth the wait in line to see the inside. There are multiple panes of glass arranged around the church depicting the books of the Bible (Genesis, Exodus, etc.) Short walk from Notre Dame - you can do both in a day.

Exquisitely beautiful chapel. Do not miss a visit to Sainte-Chapelle, dating from the 1200's and a beautiful gothic chapel. It is small and just a few blocks from Notre Dame--- breathtaking! it has an extensive display of some of the most beautiful stained glass and wood carvings.

Beautiful windows!. The stained glass windows in this place are phenomenal. When you go make sure you pick up a laminated guide that will tell you how to read the windows. I didn't notice this until the end of my visit but it really helped me see that the windows told a story from left to right and from the bottom to the top. It was incredible!
A gem. This is my favorite spot to visit. It is worth the wait to get in. Be sure to check the schedule as it closes midday.

A must-see. The stained glass windows are a beautiful sight. It was a bit crowded, but I felt calm there.Beware, however. At security they wouldn't let me in with a tiny Swiss Army knife (more of a nail file). I had to leave it with a waiter at the cafe across the street and picked it up after the tour. He says it happens all the time.

Stunning Stained Glass. The upper chapel is stunning, with about 2/3 of the walls covered in stained glass (more than 1000 scenes). The scenes cover the Biblical accounts from creation through the final judgement, along with some scenes from the crusades, etc. The detail in the stained glass is striking. Make sure you examine the detail in the ceiling.

Spectacular chapel. This is a beautiful little chapel built by Louis 9 (later St. Louis) to house the Crown of Thorns (which cost him three times as much to buy as the chapel cost to build!) You go to Sainte Chapelle to admire the spectacular stained-glass as there is almost nothing else in the chapel. It is worth buying the audio tour which explains what is depicted in the panels of stained-glass (which are upstairs and downstairs.) If you don't do this, then you are simply looking at pretty windows for 10 minutes and leaving. It is a good idea to get there about one half hour before the chapel opens (it opens at 9:30 a.m so be sure to be standing on line by 9 a.m.) The reason for this is that there is always a line and it moves slooooowly, since you have to go through a security checkpoint before going into the chapel. The entrance to the chapel is shared with the Palais du Justice (the French equivalent of the Court of Appeals) so security is tight. If you go to the chapel later in the day you will wait that much longer, perhaps up to an hour, and it is a hot wait in the summertime.

Don't miss it, but long lines.. We skipped this site due to long lines on our previous trips to Paris. This time we were determined to see it and went early. The wait was about 20 minutes. Later in the day, you will wait an hour. Your museum pass does not let you avoid the line. You have to enter security and amount of people are limited. Once you are inside, you understand why.It is an amazing site. The stained glass is spectacular. I am so glad we did not miss it this time. You will spend about 45 min there in awe.

6 year renovation just completed. Finally after 6 years the scaffolding is down, the stained glass windows are shining. Beautiful!! Buy tickets on line ahead. You may want to book a concert in early evening. Remember - in the summer it gets dark after 10:00 pm!

Stained glass. I think one of the best stained glasses you can admire in Sainte Chapelle. It is a little hidden, but even though, you should wait till you get in. A real wonder this "small chapelle". And on the top of that, you can have a wonderful concert expereince here too!

Beautiful. When you enter Saint Chappelle on lower level, you are impressed, but it pales to what you see on the 2nd level. It is awesome, so beautiful. The light coming thru the windows on a sunny day are wonderful. It might be one of the prettiest church's I have ver seen.

Gem hidden in the justice center. Went here in lieu of Notre Dame....lines there were crazy long...short wait to enter the courtyard and there stands a little Notre Dame. You enter on the lower level and silly us, we didn't immediately realize there was more. When you ascend the tight spiral staircase to the Kings level you will be just blown away by the stained glass and the light. Spectacular.

My god... . This was incredible. I came to Paris 7 years ago and my parents didn't take me here. Now that I traveled alone I decided to go, (free with museum pass). It was amazing! I have never seen such beautiful stain glass works... And I've backpacked most of Western Europe and have seen quite a few churches in my time... The lady who got up the stairs behind me about had a heart attack in the morning from its glory. A must see, and a quick one so well worth it. (Opens at 9:30 am year round, has a security check even if have Paris pass which is a line, then there is ticket line). It went by quick for us, but I would go here in morning then make way down to Notre Dame

stalned glass . A beautiful chapelle to visit although after a search of your bags and belongings like what you have to do going through the airport. Then queuing for it seemed a long time you get into the start of the chapelle then to climb up a narrow spiral stone staircase to the top to the main chapelle it's well worth the visit but only on a bright sunny day otherwise it would be gloomy you get the full experience the awesomeness of the stained glass is phenomenal only on a clear day.

A lesser known gem. We loved the interior beauty of the stained glass and ornate ceilings. This was once the personal chapel of the King Louis IX of France. He was Sainted for buying the crown of thorns worn by Christ back to Paris. Another amazingly beautiful place. A shorter tour than many other site. Some areas were restricted due to refurbishment.

An interesting foil to Notre Dame. We visited this beautiful old church on the way from the Louvre to Notre Dame and were glad we took the time. Beautiful stained glass and interesting layout of upper and lower chapels and altars. We visited many old churches in and out of Paris and were never disappointed. Make it a stop while on the Island.

our favorite sight in Paris!!!. Walked into a musty, dark dungeon and was quite disappointed...climbed the stairs and it opened into the most stunning chapel I've ever seen. I loved walking around and "reading" the Bible stories depicted in the exquisite stained glass. Last summer was undergoing some renovations and 3 of the panels were covered, but not enough to affect the view of the whole chapel. Stood in line for <60minutes, but worth it!!!

Stunning! Arrive early on a sunny day. The trick is to go early.We were in the queue about 10 minutes before opening time and were already about 20 metres from the front. It took about 10 minutes for us to get in once things started moving. We bought our museum passes here.The first place visited was the lower floor which has small windows and very ornate decoration. Then it is upstairs to the main chapel where the stained glass really impresses. We were there on a nice sunny day and saw it at its best.Overall, the visit only took around 30 minutes, but by the time we got back outside the queue had grown to about a 30 minute wait I'd estimate. We visited the Conciergerie next door afterwards and by the time we came out of that the queue for Sainte Chappelle was even longer.

Spend about 10 minutes viewing that one stained glass room, really not worthed the queuing time and money. It is just one main room. Too many tourists in the afternoon spoil the atmosphere. On average, 10-15 minutes is enough for photos. The stained glass windows look new. If you are an avid fan of stained glass and history, go. Otherwise go notre -dame cathedral or la fayette which also has stained glass that is way more beautiful, tranquil and free. It was disappointing. Also, if you pay in cash, the counter strangely doesn't accept 5 cents or 1, 2 cents. So don't bring those.

impressive church. paris is never short of impressive cathedral. Sainte chapelle is one of the must-see. again, expect a long queue but with the museum pass, at least one can skip the queue for buying tickets (security check queue still applies). the stained glass windows in the upper chapel is really impressive. time the visit so it will not be too early (there is a queue for palace of justice), or near lunch hour. (saw a notice during my visit there is a lunch break, for the security check perhaps? need to confirm this)

Go for a concert and take time to really study the windows. We actually visited twice, as it was one of my favorite things on our 8-day trip to Paris. On the recommendations of a friend, we got tickets for a concert early in our trip, which was really wonderful. The acoustics are fabulous! The setting sun was streaming in the windows, and we watched for another sunny day to come back and really examine the windows. On our second visit, having the Paris Museum Pass allowed us to skip the ticket line, but the security line was about 10-15 minutes long. We made good use of the large laminated guides (available in several languages and kept in a rack just to the right of the main door as you enter) to find various scenes from the Bible illustrated in the windows.

Incredibly beautiful!. WOW! WOW! WOW! How else can I describe absolute beauty? It is not its religious character at all, it is a monument to man's creative gift and love for beauty. You can't miss it!
A Gem. What a magnificent chapel. The stained glass will take your breath away. I visit here every time I'm in Paris

Stunning on a Sunny Day. Sainte-Chapelle is amazing. It retains the look it would have had in medieval times. The beautiful windows glow on a sunny day. While those using the chapel in its day would have "read" and understood all of the stories depicted, we don't. Explanations are provided to help us out. Evening concerts are lovely and held frequently. You are able to enter at the upper level, through the doors Louis used. I would highly recommend attending one, if possible. You do need to pass through security to get in.

Long wait. The stained glass windows are very beautiful, but takes only 30 min to look at. We waited 1.5 hours to get in because of the ridiculously slow security line (came around 4pm on a weekday). It is definitely NOT a must-do if you are tight on time. Wouldn't have even came if it wasn't for the Paris Museum pass.

Gorgeous, small.... I came here on a Saturday so there was quite a queue. Security is tight as it's adjacent to the palace of justice and that adds a lot to the wait. The actual attraction itslf is very small and very beautiful, you want to come in the afternoon on a sunny day to get optimal window viewing. It can be a very brief visit though, so don't expect too much, just really gorgeous stained glass windows. They have concerts here, when I was visiting they had Vivaldi's Four Seasons and Mozart's Requiem which I would have loved to see if I didn't have plans already so If that interests you look up your options! I'd definitely recommend coming on a weekday as I waited in line longer than I spent in the chapel itself.
Beautiful stain glass windows. You have to visit to see the beautiful Stain Glass windows in person, just around the corner from Notre Dame

Pure magic. Sainte-Chapple is beautiful to visit under any circumstance, however, combining your visit with a string ensemble concert is simply unforgettable. The music was perfectly matched to this devine space and you get to admire the stined glassfor more than an hour. The lead violinist was amazing as he walked the length of the chappel playing.

The chapel is amazing, just don't bother going to a Euromusic "concert".. Chapel with its restored windows is stunningly beautiful, well worth the queue. However as we were leaving we saw there was a concert on that night and bought two tickets at 30€ each. The program was an assortment of popular pieces which would have been fine if they had been played properly (things are usually popular because they are beautiful - I'm not a snob) but the trio of a harpsichord, violin and flute were often very out of time with each other and sometimes even a bit out of tune. The concert lasted 50 minutes, just about an hour after the encore. I felt the musicians had no respect for their audience or for the music. I suspect that many people in the audience were not regular concert goers because there was lots of very undeserved applause. A rip-off.

Breath Takingly Beautiful.. Oh those Louis' certainly had great style and taste. With their great wealth they created a Heavenly place on Earth in the upstairs portion of Sainte-Chapelle. This is one of favorite spaces anywhere. When you exit the narrow, winding stairs you are surely treated to the most airy, colorful chapel that exist. The King built this Chapel to house a portion of Christ Crown-of- Thorns and the stained glass used in it's construction is breath-taking. It is almost as if the glass is floating. So much of the architecture of the the 13th century was heavy and bulky, but not this church. Definitely worth a visit.
Breathtaking!. Definitely glad that we fit in a short visit to Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass windows are stunning. Frequent concerts are held here, check their website for details.

Sainte-Chapelle. Breathtaking stained glass windows, this beautiful and very old church is one of the most beautiful sights I have ever seen. We went there and then to the Concierge at next door building. There is reproduction of the prison cell where Marie Aintoniette was confined.

Has to be Seen. We went into this Chapel as an afterthought with not much expectation. Boy, were we surprised at the incredible windows in this chapel that documents many biblical events. Really cannot be described must be seen on a sunny day, absolutely dazzling.

One of the most beautiful churches on earth. So many tourist sights are hyped, but it's impossible to hype Sainte-Chapelle, which is one of the most beautiful churches on earth & certainly one of the 3 or 4 most beautiful sites in Paris -- all the more so since the stained glass windows for which it's famous have been painstakingly renovated; after 7 years of work, they're now on view. Two tips: first, go when it's sunny because the sunlight makes all the difference; second, be prepared to wait 45 minutes to an hour to get in because it's one of the top spots in Paris, along with the Louvre & the chateau de Versailles. But on a bright sunny day, it's worth it, with the light streaming in & creating a dazzling effect, like being inside a jewel box. You can get a ticket just for the chapel or for the chapel + the Conciergerie; I'd recommend the latter if you have the time; the Conciergerie isn't beautiful like Sainte-Chapelle, but it's fascinating & well worth an hour of your time to see the prison where 3,000 people were executed in the Terror during the French Revolution, including Marie-Antoinette. Best time to go: mid-to-late morning, between 10 a.m. to noon, or else evening, after 4 p.m. Both the Conciergerie & Sainte Chapelle have nice gift shops.

Brilliant restoration of a medieval masterpiece. I have visited the Sainte Chapelle many times, on occasions for summer concerts. My highlight was a concert of Bach on unaccompanied cello. That music in that ambiance was unearthly - a heavenly feast for the ears and eyes. During my visits over the years, there has always been scaffolding up in various parts of the chapel. Now that the restoration is complete, the result is magnificent. The gorgeous blues and reds fill the interior with a wondrous light. My favourite practice is to take people there. I ask them to close their eyes before emerging into the upper chapel, all the while guiding them. Then I tell them to open their eyes. The gasps of wonder are worth it every time.

By Notre Dame. If you're spending an afternoon exploring Notre Dame, stop by here. It wasn't too much to get inside. The upstairs is beautiful. Very old. Windows tell stories of the Bible. Also see the Concierge which is an old prison that housed Marie Antoinette. It's literally right next door.

Don't miss this sight-- consider a concert here. We went to Saint Chappelle on our skip the line pass and walked right in. The downstairs where the lower class worshiped helps set the stage for the upper floor. After climbing a steep winding staircase, you emerge into a room filled with stained glass --breathtaking. After an afternoon visit, we went back for an evening concert. Great memory
Breathtaking stained glass. This is the most beautiful church and piece of art I have ever seen. The wall to wall stained glass is truly awe-inspiring. Definitely visit this church in Paris.

Gothic sublime. If you are a gothic arquitecture fan, you must visit Saintr Chapelle because of the vitral paintings and policromic sculpture. It's like a gigantic jewel! It is a bit hidden in the ile de france, but it is one of a kind.
Gorgeous!. Beautiful church set behind and very near Notre Dame. Don't miss is and definitely go upstairs. The laminated sheets that they have in every language are very informative :)

Unbelievable stained glass windows. I have always wanted to visit Sainte-Chapelle, but just missed it.
We had the pleasure of attending a concert in the church.
These windows have endured since the 1300's.

Gorgeous. You might have to wait a while to see this gorgeous chapel, but I believe that it is well worth the wait. The stained glass windows can take one's breath away and I recommend just taking one's time to take it all in. While not as large as Notre Dame, the Sainte-Chapelle gets better light in and is just as beautiful.

One Church Not to Miss - Sainte-Chapelle. It's a smaller church - but the stained glass windows are simply breathtaking. When you walk in on the lower level of the church - you wonder why this is considered so special - then tucked away in a corner is a winding and tight staircase to the second floor. And you walk into the chapel - and are surrounded by history. From mid way on the wall to the vaulted ceiling the stained glass windows depict the bible stories thru Louis IX

A tiny jewel box. Ste Chapelle is probably my favorite Gothic Chapel OF-ALL-TIME. It's a prime example of the reason for the flying buttress - more glass! It's all about the glass, the glass... Even if I'm in Paris for only a short visit - this is the place I want to go to be awed.

Vivaldi Concert Venue. What an amazing place this is to hear a concert, in this case, Vivaldi. With the setting sun lighting up the gorgeous windows at the 7:00 PM performance, and the gorgeous music filling our ears, it was as close to heaven as one could be here on earth.

Beautiful Glass, Small Church & Short Visit (30min). Sainte-Chappelle was the personal chapel of King Louis IX and therefore is a very small church. After arriving at the Cité Metro stop and walking a few minutes, we got in line at 9:15am for the 9:30 opening; we were 20th in the queue. At 9:30, there were about 100 in line. There is no 'skip the line' for Paris Museum Pass holders but you split off from those who have to buy tickets just before entering the church. Be aware that at the SAME entry door there are two lines... Sainte-Chapelle and the Palais de Justice. Get in the correct queue as you can't access the Chapelle via Justice line. Once in the church, turn left into the corner and go direct upstairs to the chapelle- we were first up there for a few minutes and got some great pictures. When you come down, you can browse the gift shop and lower altar area. We were at the chapel for 30 minutes.
Concert. My wife and I went to the concert in the church. Small and intimate with great sound. Highly recommend too see the church via the concert.

spectacular. We did not know anything about Sainte-Chapelle before we went there. We went there to attend a concert in the chapel. The concert was very enjoyable, but the chapel was spectacular. The stained glass windows were awesome. They ran from floor to ceiling. The windows go back four or five hundred years and you would think the glass made two weeks ago, the colors are so vivid. How they stand up is a mystery to me. The floors have interesting tiles. I cannot remember the number of photographs I took. The chapel is on the Island and it is a lovely place to walk around. I found it more impressive than Notre Dame which is much larger.

not to get in because of a long quew. we would have liked to get in, but there was such a long quew, that it made no sense to wait. It should have a separate entrance for people with online tickets...

Sensational. Reading the comments about being too crowded and expensive (which seems ridiculous to me to see one of the greatest works of art in the world) I'm glad we visited as part of seeing an evening concert. Unfortunately much of the altar was covered in canvas during renovation but even so this was a glorious sight.Given its relatively low profile compared to say the stained glass at Chartres I was taken aback at sensational this was.

Mind-Blowing!!. This place tucked away in behind the law buildings was a mind blower!!! After waiting in line for about 1 hour or so we went through security and wandered the courtyard to the entrance to this ancient gothic cathedral. The beautiful gothic archways and stained glass and atmosphere was awe- inspiring! After soaking in the atmosphere, we found a small spiral well worn staircase which we ascended. At the top we came out into a very expansive space with slender gothic arches, with the most beautiful stained glass windows which seemed to reach for the stars, and which surrounded all the walls except for the end with the beautiful "rose" window!! Absolutely stunning!! There were seats which you could relax in and soak up this stunning environment. Both inside and outside the architecture and the colours and the light from the glass were to die for!!! (This is coming from me who has a passion for all of these things!!) But aside from that Sainte- Chapelle is a must to see! Go and make up your own mind!!

Stained glass masterpiece!. It is a small chapel, but surely must visit if you are visiting near Notre dame cathedral. First level has massive windows with stained glass paintings and the quality of space will blow you! Plan during a sunny afternoon if possible.

Off the charts "WOW" factor. The chapel is small and just a few blocks walking distance from Notre Dame. There is usually a bit of a line so get there early when they open. TAKE YOUR CAMERA!!. The stained glass windows in the chapel are simply magical on a sunny day. Breathtaking
Hidden Gem near Notre Dame. Breathtaking! The second floor stained glass windows is one of the most magnificent sites anywhere in the world. you MUST go here and check it out in person!

Must see in Paris!. The wait is longer than anything else we did in Paris, but it was well worth it. Only a limited number of people are allowed in at one time, making the experience much more intimate. The Chapel is absolutely gorgeous on both the top and bottom floor. The top floor is the true scene stealer with those stained glass windows surrounding you in colors and light. You can almost hear the song and prayers from year's past.

breathtaking. We queued for around 40 minutes for the security check, once inside due to having a museum pass we skipped the second queue.On entering the chapel you see a very plain entrance, a small shop and pieces in need of restoration. Neither myself or my husband were prepared for the breathtaking view when reaching the top of the stairs, the stain glass is like nothing I have ever seen before, when the light shines through the glass it is truly breathtaking.Whilst in the queue we were unsure whether to skip the chapel, but we are so glad we waited, truly a must see.

Amazing stained glass. Sante-Chapelle has been a favorite of ours for decades, Recently, a number of the windows were cleaned and extensively restored, adding still more to the beauty of the upstairs chapel. Not to be missed.

A gothic stainglass jewel. This small gothic cathedral is situated in the very hearth of Paris, inside the walls of the Consiergerie, the initial seat of French kings. The place has an outstanding art value because of its marvellous windows. Over thousand biblical scenes illustrate almost all of Old and New Testament. The inside is like a fairy tale. Absolutely worth to visit.

Stained glass makes this one of the most beautiful churches in the world. Sainte Chapelle is one of the most beautiful churches in the world. The walls of stained glass are fantastic although we could only see two walls of glass because of construction, but we were glad to see that the church is being maintained. This is a must see that can easily be accessed on the Isle de la Cite across the street from Notre Dame. It is also near the Cite Metro site.

Amazing stained glass!. We went at night because we bought concert tickets it is a fantastic time to sit in Saint Chapelle listen to music and take in the Stain a Glass in a very quiet way , reflective manner. It really is quite stunning keep in mind it is no longer functioning church , I would definitely visit here again we listen to a string Quartet it was a beautiful sound in such lovely surroundings. You can buy tickets during the day in the lineup will , actually they will have you go forward inside to buy tickets or you can buy tickets across the street at the Tabac.

Go to a music concert here in the evening. Check online to find out when music concerts are being performed and GO! The crowds are gone, and you get to sit and really look at the beautiful stained glass while listening to classical music. We went to a Vivaldi- "Four Seasons" performance and arrived just as the sun set outside, so the windows were spectacular!

Wow..... Worth visiting to see the most beautiful stained glass windows - just amazing!!! Enjoyed this after a stroll around the Sunday flower/bird market, which is close by. Then stopped across the street for a coffee - what a wonderful way to spend a Sunday morning.
