Stained Glass Anyone?. It is amazing to think how much work went into these intricate and huge stained glass walls/windows. The audio tour accessory is worth renting. The stairs are fairly short but steep and the steps are pretty narrow.

Just beautiful. We were a little later getting there than I had hoped but still made it before they opened. Waited in line about 30 mins to get in. All I can say is it's just breath taking. One of our favorite sites on the trip. Glad we got there early because when we exited the venue the line was wrapped around the building! Even the floor was pretty.

Dazzling!. 40 years in Paris and I had never visited this site. After 6 years of renovations they opened the chapel up for a free weekend and guided tours so I followed the crowd into the lower chapel, which was nice, as are all French chapels with stained glass windows. We were then lead up the stairs to the upper chapel, and there at the top of the stairs was the most dazzling set of almost floor to ceiling wall to wall stained glass windows - over 1000 different windows, reaching up over 20 meters. On the left as you face the alter, the whole old testament fills the wall, on the right is the new testament. And a beautifully formed Rosace in the back. There I stood in the middle bathed in all the colorful light coming through the windows, not knowing where to look first. And very reluctant to leave.
Stunning!. This is one of those places that just takes your breath away with beauty! The Bible translated through stained glass. A definite must do!

Arrive Early. The line ups are long for good reason. Arrive early if you can. There is no museum pass that will allow you to skip the line. The windows are marvellous, and if you have a Christian church upbringing, you will be able to make out what some of the windows are depicting. If you know a little French, the video explanation of how they restored the windows is fascinating.

Long Line and Didn't Get In. The line for Sainte-Chapelle was quite long and moved very slowly. They only let in about 3-4 people every so often (more than 10 minutes between groups). We were very disappointed. We had heard how beautiful it is.We had a Museum Pass but really never saw anyone to show it to.I would suggest getting there before it opens so you can get in.I didn't know how to rate it so I gave it a 3.
Spectaular Stained Glass!. The beauty of the windows in the king's chapel is by far the most beautiful I've seen in all of Europe. This was a favorite spot in Paris for me.

One of the 'must sees' in Paris. With its restoration and cleaning La Sainte Chapelle is even more astoundingly beautiful than previously. The colour of the stained glass is amazing and the sheer length and breadth of the windows makes it an architectural wonder. Its important to have one of the free explanatory cards with you to aid your understanding of the windows, and a bit of biblical knowledge will help too.Be warned, the chapel itself cannot accommodate many people and unless you have already booked your visit online you will be fated to stand in the queue for a long time.

Sainte-Chapelle in a nutshell. Paris is full of Cathedrals and churches, but out of all the ones I have seen, Sainte-Chapelle is my favorite. A smaller more quaint version of Notre Dame, tucked into the secure walls of a French government building, Sainte-Chapelle is a Cathedral that simply takes your breath away with the intricate stained glass windows and stunning pew. Its small size, although dwarfed by Notre Dame,Sainte-Chapelle makes up for in beauty and style. As a side note, the lines are shorter than Notre Dame, there are less people around and it is close to many other attractions as it is on the Ile de France. This place is worth the money and time and is a must-see in Paris.

The Stained Glass Windows are nice. Honestly we expected a much bigger place (from the pictures we had seen). But once you enter its not so big. The stained glass panels are indeed beautiful, but the number of people inside the little chapel makes it difficult to enjoy the beauty of the place. Not worth it if there are too many people.

Absolutely beautiful. We went early on a damp Sunday morning as we'd heard about huge queues. We only queued for about ten minutes, and this was for the security checks (why don't people read the signs that say to open bags and what you can't have, rather than be surprised when they reach the checkpoint!?) Lovely ground floor area, but then go up the stairs and be blown away by the beauty of these amazing ceilings. We forgot out binoculars which would be a great help to see and 'read' the bible stories in the glass. We are non believers anf loved it, I'm sure those with Christian faith would gain even more from a visit. And when we left mid morning there was no queue at all!

Buy the Museum Pass to skip the line. We loved the Chapelle, everybody in our group agreed that it was better than Notre Dame. We all had the Museum Pass, so after a short wait in the security line, we were able to enter the chapel right away and skip the long ticket line. I disliked the large book/ souvenir store that took up nearly 1/3 of the bottom level and found it tacky. Oh well.

Surprise!. I had not heard of this location in advance, but our group went early. It was truly amazing. I have some of the most beautiful pictures imaginable from their stan glass--and I am not a great photographer.
Best Stained Glass windows. This church looks very unassuming from outside. But once inside, the floor to ceiling height stained glass panels are awesome. Not to be missed.

Only small - but amazing. We used the metro followed by a short walk and then joined the queue which took approx 40 minutes.You have to go via a baggage scanner / security check then buy your tickets inside.It's only small but amazing to look at all the glass panels. They tell a story. Allow about 30 to 60 minutes depending on your level of interest.

Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. We attended a one-hour evening concert - great music (Vivaldi's Four Seasons) and beautiful stained glass. It is a good idea to reserve tickets in advance, because the concerts are very popular.

Wonderful stain glass. The long queue is worth every minute! The ticket is 8,5 E and at first you visit the ground floor which is not so spectacular. But once you go up...wooow! be aware, the stairs are not for the calustrophobic people, extremely narrow hallway; there is a separate entrace for disabled people.
In the dark. You are in La Consiergrie and walk a many steps you are there in the light again. Sainte- Chapelle is wonderful amazing and calm. Go there you'l love it.

Second visit, this time for a concert. I had book the concert tickets without paying too much attention to what type of concert it was. As it turned out, it was for string ensemble playing Vivaldi. The procedure to get us all into the church was very drawn out; first security check for everyone then wait, then walk upstairs and wait and finally into the top level of Saint Chapelle. The cellist was running late so there was more waiting after that. I have to admit I had booked the concert for DH's enjoyment and I was just along for the ride but I actually really enjoyed it. Of course, the stained glass was just as amazing as the first time we visited.

A must visit every time when in Paris.. The Royal Medieval Gothic chapel from the 1200's. Every wall and ceiling is vibrantly coloured. The ceilings are a magnificent blue with gold stars and the walls are multicoloured. A real surprise and delight.

concert tickets. It was huge waiting line; and I hate to waste time. We noticed an add that across the street they sell ticket to music concert at the chapel. It was good decision. I do not have words to describe chapel stain-glass windows. And classical music enriched the experience.

Worth the wait.. My friend Annie and I went to Saint-Chapelle (Cité metro station) and waited an hour in line before getting our tickets and being admitted-there is always a long line and getting through security takes time. Also, due to the limited space, there seems to be some timing control at the entrance. As we slowly moved up to the front of the line, we saw a sign explaining that the ticket office closes for lunch! Not sure if this happens every day at 12:30 pm. Our visit was in late March, before the busy tourist season.The lower level space is being renovated so about half of it is closed off, but you still get to see the ceilings and the altar space. Be sure, after you walk up the spiral stone stairs, to pick up a plastic covered guide to the stained glass windows; it is quite helpful to understanding which panels depict which scenes from the Bible.I highly recommend reserving tickets to a classical concert at Saint-Chapelle. My husband and I attended one on a Sunday evening at 7 pm. You can choose a more expensive option and have reserved seating in rows 3-10, which for 20 euros, was well worth it. We heard Pachelbel's Canon and then Four Seasons played by a wonderful French string ensemble. Tickets may be purchased (and printed out) here:http://www.classictic.com/en/special/concerts-in-la-sainte-chapelle/216/Sainte-Chapelle is a beautiful cathédrale.

Maybe the most beautiful church in the world?. First of all, I don't go to church. I don't even like going into churches. But that's another story. I went to a concert at Sainte-Chapelle on a whim with my wife at Christmas. We've walked past it dozens of times before and didn't even know it was there. We thought the lineups outside were for court cases. The concert was in the evening and only seated 150 people. After entering the courtyard entrance and clearing security we were led to and fro through the courtyard, past courtrooms then into a tunnel and up some stairs to the chapel encased within the court's building. When we entered the chapel I was stunned to see the towering, semi-circular stained glass windows curving up to a point above our heads. Some of the glass dates back to the 1200's. At night, with the lights and candles it was absolutely the most beautiful sight I had ever seen. We had arrived in Paris just hours before the concert. While listening to Pachelbel's Canon and Vivaldi's Four Seasons in the spectacular venue I was brought to tears. And that isn't easy! After the concert I said to my wife as we wended our way back out to the street, " I could go straight back out to the airport and fly home tonight because It won't get any better than that". And it didn't. Go!
Amazing!. Queue was so worth the wait. A small Chapel and was slightly disappointed until we climbed a small spiral staircase to and OMG moment. Utterly jaw dropping! You have to go!
Stained glass is gorgeous. This is a beautiful cathedral. The stained glass is breathtaking and to realize that it was done centuries ago is mind boggling. Well worth the visit.
Stunning stained glass.. Recently restored Saint-Chapelle provides a kaleidoscope of colours and narrative that is awe inspiring.

Overwhelming. The Stained Glass and the story behind each section & window ( oh yeah, the Bible) is truly awe inspiring. A University could offer a degree on Saint-Chappelle! To truly enjoy this spectacle, do your homework , plan on 2 hours, and bring a reference book to fully appreciate..

Amazing!. Sainte-Chapelle is awe-inspiring. There is usually a long wait to buy tickets, but once inside, the actual visit doesn't take very long (it's kind of nice if you've been touring around and spent many hours in the Louvre and other museums). We were able to buy a combined ticket with the conciergerie and skip the line for Saint-Chapelle. Even if you have to wait, it's worth it!

Beautiful stained glass. This does have beautiful stained glass! The line moves fairly quickly - your museum passes do not let you skip the line here. I thought the queue was very disorganized, and the people in charge were a little rude - but don't let this dissuade you.

OMG. I have never seen anything so beautiful as this medievil chapel. They have just spent 7 years restoring all of the stain glass windows and the results had me standing in awe of this beautiful place. For me this was the best thing I saw in Paris, could have stayed all day just looking at it's beauty.
Elegant and beautiful. A treasure too many people miss when visiting Paris. A short walk from Notre Dame. The inside of the cathedral is stunning. Lines can be long, so get there early.

Serine. The queues to get in to this small chapel can be quite long and therefore plan ahead to either come very early or to be content to wait in line. When you do finally get in you will enter a small but incredibly ornate chapel with Stainglass windows that rise from the floor to the ceiling in amazing detail. It's fairly easy to transport yourself back in time and a place like this and just wonder at the craftsmanship time and effort that went into creating such a place of beauty. This was definitely worth the time in line in my opinion and is itself a work of art.

Fourth trip up the treacherous stairway. First time the sun was actually shining! Much more impressive! I must admit my favorite part has always been the downstairs with all the blues and reds and the gold stars and fleur de lys .i understand that is where the minions prayed... I am a minion at heart I guess!

Wow!. Well worth queuing and 8 euros entry fee. This refurbished Chappelle in the Palais de Justice just takes your breath away. The stained glass is vibrant and well worth the short climb up a windy, narrow stair case. A place not to miss!

Incredible!. Don't be discouraged by the line, it moved fairly quickly, and the initial area we walked into through us for a bit of a loop. Take a left right when you walk in and go up the stairs to see the most amazing display of stained glass....breathtaking!
Stunning stained glass. Do your homework before you arrive so you'll understand all of the windows. Lines are long so bring a book and a lot of patience.

Don't miss this cathedral. Several friends had told us not to miss Sainte-Chapelle on our next trip to Paris, and we now know why. It is a small cathedral hidden near Notre Dame. When you walk in, the first floor is interesting. When you go up the staircase to the second level, you will find out why this has become so popular. The stain glass windows and overall appearance are amazing.

Amazing church. This is a gorgeous church, a must to visit when in Paris. We attended a Vivaldi concert one evening, and it was one of the most beautiful things we did on a trip. Check the schedules, there is always some kind of concert going on.

Vivaldi and the 4 seasons was excellent!. We saw a concert in here and I would say to do it if you can! awesome acoustics in the building made it even better! That mixed with the stained glass is amazing!

Magnificent. This is the most beautiful church I have ever seen and I have seen many! It must have been a labor of love for the artisans and the stained glass in the upper chapel is not to be believed. My first glimpse made me gasp -- it is unbelievable.

WOW! This has to be on your list of places to see!. Although going through the security line was cumbersome we were rewarded for our troubles. Entering the chapel we were presented with a chapel that was very nice, and then went up some stairs to what is one of the most beautiful examples of stained glass we've ever seen. It is the story of the bible told in stained glass. You can't just whisk through here, you have to take time and look at the craftsmanship as well as follow the story line. We weren't rushed, we were able to absorb all we wanted to at our own pace. This was another use of our three day museum pass, well worth purchasing it.

Magnificent Stained Glass!. Sainte-Chapelle- This is worth the short wait in line- especially if you have the Museum Pass. On the street outside the walls of St. Chappelle, there is a "No priority" line- meaning everyone waits in the same line to go through security. Once you are through security and inside the walls, you will wait in another line to buy tickets and enter the church. **If you have a "Paris Museum Pass," you can skip the long line inside the walls and just enter the church directly to see the beautiful stained glass! When we were there (a Sunday afternoon), it was surprisingly crowded, and the "non-pass" line to buy tickets was very long. Since we had the Museum Pass, there was NO WAIT for us! Once inside, we stayed for ~20 minutes. We didn't have a guide, and that was more than enough time to experience the magnificence of Sainte-Chapelle's stained glass. (It was late in the day, and we were trying to make it next door to Le Conciergerie before it closed for the day.) There are large handheld placards available inside in multiple languages that will explain how the windows are arranged, and walk you through the "story" they are telling. When you walk into the Church, you actually enter through the gift shop. Make sure you go up the stairs directly to your left (past the available audioguides- extra 5 Euro?), to enter the main church. Once inside, it's actually pretty small- but tall. There are chairs lining the church for you to sit and rest while gazing upwards.

Absolutelly stunning. This hidden jewel is a must see in Paris. The windows are stunning and the history well presented. Warning the lines are long, even with the Museum pass because you must go through a rigorous security. The steps to the main cathedral are steep and narrow, so elderly are limited.

Beautiful Windows on a Sunny Day. Sainte-Chapelle is hard to find, nestled as it is in the courtyard of the Palais de Justice on Ile de la Cite. The line was particularly long, but thankfully we had a sunny day to appreciate the church's exterior and then those gorgeous windows once we were inside. I wonder how many folks wander in and never get to the second floor where the really beautiful stained glass soars! The stairs are tucked away and not marked particularly well. Make sure to go when the sun is out and streams through on all sides - fabulous! The culture card works here once you go through security.
Beautiful!. Well worth the wait in line. The church is absolutely beautiful. I saw enough cathedrals until I saw this one.
Vivaldi at Sainte-Chapelle. The Chapelle is awe-inspiring. Listening to Vivaldi while perusing all the stained glass panels was a highlight of my latest visit to Paris.
Wonderful Stain Glass. This is a "can't miss" because of its spendid and extensive stain glass. Be prepared to wait in line to enter.
Beautiful!. The line took about 30 minutes, but it was well worth it. The stained glass inside the chapel was amazing. We hit it on a cloudy day, so the lighting was perfect on the stained glass.

Beautiful. Sainte-Chapelle was wonderful. It has the most gorgeous stained glass windows I have ever seen. It's a very small church and you can't see much from the outside, but it is definitely worth a visit.
Stained glass windows are breathtaking!. We were not familiar with this site and were so glad that we took the time to see it--the stained glass windows are like no other.

Must see in Paris. This little chapel surely hosts the most beautiful stained glass in the world. There are few places that literally take my breath away but this one certainly does. Definitely worth the queue which is always quite a wait. Photos really cant capture just how exquisite it is. It must be experienced.

Amazing. Free with the Paris City Pass and you can skip the line once you get past security. We went into the first level and thought okay the stain glass is nice but average with other churches...... then we went upstairs..... beautiful. It was so amazing and hard to believe that most of the windows are original. This is a must see. There are large cards in the back that are in many languages which explain all the pains.

Beaautiful church. the second floor is absolutely gorgeous but is exquisite when the sun is out. We went there when it was cloudy and raining but you could see how beautiful it would be when it was sunny

The Paris site most tourists never see. Sainte-Chapelle, tucked away behind the Conciergerie, is a miracle in that it escaped the depradations of the French Revolution. Built by King/Saint Louis IX to house the Crown of Thorns (or what was left of it when he bought it from a Byzantine emperor), it is the closest thing to what Gothic cathedrals actually looked like when they were new: walls painted floor-to-ceiling in vivid colors, all intact stained-glass telling Bible stories, and so on. Mos t people think of Gothic as gray. Sainte-Chapelle shows otherwise. Don't miss it. Oh, and there are two floors to it, the lower one for commoners, the top one for the king and court.
awe-inspiring. Magnificent chapel. Be sure to go upstairs to see the stained glass windows. No need to spend a lot of time to get a full appreciation of the place. On the Museum Pass.
Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. This site is not to be missed. The stained glass windows are beautiful. Go early or use a Museum Pass to miss the lines.
Breathtaking. Visited Paris during college. Sainte- Chapelle was my favorite thing to see. Most beautiful how the sunlight enters through the beautiful windows! Cannot wait to return.
Awe Inspiring. Just do not miss this fantastic place. The 12th Century windows are a marvel. You are whisked back in time to a completely different way of life.

Wow ....should be on everyone's bucket list. I have seen some fabulous things in my time but this Chapel, newly restored is simply amazing. Every piece of glass has been painstakingly removed, cleaned and reset before being put back and the effect is quite extraordinary. All the morellos when you remember this was built in the 13th century!!It is simple breathtaking and for me well worth the almost 90 minutes of queuing on the pavement outside.

Hidden Gem of Paris! . We had never even heard of Sainte-Chapelle until a week before we took our vacation. It was absolutely beautiful! There was a line down the sidewalk, but the earlier you get there, the better! Also see the concierge since it's right there too and full of history. The stained glass windows are absolutely exquisite and the architecture and gothic arches are ornate! It's seriously a MUST SEE if you're ever in Paris.

How Catholicism prevails in time``. A small museum, but the architecture of the church is stunning. The stained glasses at the upper floor tells story of Jesus. Of course the famous Rose Window is worth paying a visit. I think it costs around 8 euros to get in.

Awkward visit with Restrooms Closed. We traveled with a handicapped person and were unable to communicate the need for handicapped entrance to the security guards but once they saw our difficulty, our passage was eased through this check point and there was a bench where our companion could wait nearby. There was no sign for handicapped entrance at the ticket office, but we eventual realized our companion could sit near the entrance while we waited through the line. Once there, the lower level chapel is worth the look, but the entry to the upper level is via the traditional stone staircases that wind up and only have a handrail on one side (this made the visit upstairs impossible for our one usable-armed guest).For non-handicapped visitors, the chapel upstairs is very beautiful and holds concerts with folding chairs (we didn't attend one) but those chairs are removed during visiting hours.The bathrooms are at the exit gate (which is also the entrance for handicapped visitors) but most were closed except the handicapped bathroom and so there was a lengthy line for its use.

Stained Glass. The structure was never a church but it is church-like. The stained glass ranks up there as one of the best in Europe. We also attended two classical concerts during the week we were there. Outstanding talent, intimate surroundings. You can purchase tickets online, save them to a smart phone and make it simple. Tickets can be collected at the site and it appeared that tickets were being sold inside. Getting in the the Chapel is a security ordeal because it adjoins the police hq. You have to go through some airport type screening but it is a small inconvenience for the reward inside.

stunning. Get in early to see la Chapelle before people realise that ihas only recently opened after extensive restoration to the windows which are magnificent. This Royal chapel was built to house the Crown of thorns which now reside in Notre Dame. The queue is not too bad and moves quickly so don't give up.

One Of The Highlights Of Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is perhaps the world's best cathedral depicting bible history in stained glass and sculpture. An amazing feat of architecture and art. If you like stained glass, Sainte-Chapelle is the high bar of excellence and design.

Lovely and extensive stained glass window panels - simply WOW you away. Expect long queue getting in... queue is because of some security checks, similar to airport where you will need to empty your pockets and have your bag scanned. However, the guards didn't appear to be looking at the scanning monitor - they were happily chatting among themselves, kind of wonder what's the purpose of the security check (?!)So weird way to start the visit; once passed the security, you will walk in the big courtyard towards the chapel. Just as noted by the brochure/website - the chapel consists of two levels... ground level is not too impressive; the walls look really old as in not being restored in anyway... but don't get put off.Going up to the next level.... as soon as you walk in - WOW!! The chapel looks simply amazing - it lits up because of the sun light coming through the stained glass. There are some (limited) chairs to sit down and enjoy the view of the stained glass panels.If you didn't hire the audio guide, be sure to look out for the thick plasticised info which give some brief info about the stained glass.If I knew better, I would had packed a pair of binocular or some sort to get a better look at the glass panels.Wheelchair access is possible to the top floor, ask the staffs for help - they will accompany you to the lift access.** 5-star for the staffs who helped us.

Breathtaking!!. Some other tourists had recommended Sainte Chapelle to us and we were very grateful. Notre Dame is dark and busy. The second floor of Sainte Chapelle will take your breathe away. The line was 20 minutes long and once inside it didn't feel that crowded. Definitely worth visiting!!

A must see church. Sainte Chapelle was a great surprise for us when we visited during a six day trip to Paris. From the outside the church does not seem special but step inside and you will be in for a treat. The stained glass windows stretch from the bottom to the top of the walls. Many of the scenes were difficult to tell what they represented but it did not matter because the colors were so beautiful. Don't skip the carvings on the door frame and the wall outside the door. These are exceptional carvings of scenes from the bible.

Breath-taking. Would highly recommend this site and make sure that you take the steps to the upper level, which is the true highlight. If you are lucky enough to visit on a sunny day, prepare for a experience of a lifetime.

Prepare to be awed... #2. Without question, the most beautiful church in Paris!! Do not be deceived when entering on first floor - you must go upstairs to actually be in the sanctuary.Go on a sunny day to get the best effect. It is stunning!

See a Concert Here. A magical, and affordable, Paris experience is hearing a classical music concert amidst the stained glass of Sainte-Chappelle. I experience Vivaldi's Four Seasons while gazing up at the finest stained glass windows in the world. There is ample time before the concert to walk around the small chapel and see the windows that are not near your seats. The music was wonderful and the price was only 25 Euros—not bad for skipping the line and spending far more time with the windows than I would during a day visit. 2 concerts are offered nearly every night, so there will be plenty of time to squeeze one in.

Mixed feelings. There is no cutting the lines here and they were long and slow. Security was tight because it is next to a police station I believe. This is a restoration tourist site. Walk in, look and leave. But, it is beautiful. The entire view is the stained glass windows, so the sunnier the day the better. Cloudy and rainy, forget it.

Breathtaking. This is the most beautiful church I have ever seen. It is incredibly small but just stunning. I was more impressed with this church than Notre Dame. Definitely worth the wait in line and not to be missed!

Definitely go!. We went at about 4.15pm and so didn't have to wait long in line. Don't spend too long on the ground floor. The magnificent stained glass windows are up a flight of stairs. The great thing about this place is that you get almost instantaneous gratification. No hundred of steps to climb nor miles of corridors to navigate in order to locate "the" masterpiece. The beautiful windows are just there!

A real treat. Saint Chapelle is in a very inspiring place to visit. You'll be amazed by the towering stained glass windows. It is well worth the price of admission and it is something that doesn't take hours to tour though you could easily sit there and marvel at this wonderful stain glass display for quite a while.

Wonderous Windows of Glass. We visited the Chapelle on our last day in Paris. We went early in the morning to be there when it opened. We were surprised to see about a hundred people already in a line. A quick investigation revealed that the Chapelle entrance is right next to the Palace of Justice. I presume this is where Parisians go for police or court matters. So make sure you are in the right line when you first arrive. It was the one on the North side of the entrance.The windows in the Chapelle are all that people say....huge and spectacular. The audio tour is worth the money as it details various panes and how they connect to the bible. The planning and effort that went into the Chapelle and the windows is impressive.It is worth a couple hours.

Worth it for the Stain Glass Alone. Saint-Chapelle has some of the most beautiful, and historic, stain glass windows on the second floor of the chapel. They have guide cards in various languages to help decipher the windows. The stain glass is worth any wait you may endure. On to the wait. Don't be deceive but there are two lines. One to get past security (since the entrance also serves for some government buildings), then another line to get to the church. Sometimes these lines can get rough to wait in from what I hear. We probably waiting in total an hour or so. But we got lucky because the day we showed up they were allowing free entrance at night. That is why we had to wait a bit longer. So even though we waited a bit, we felt like we got a good deal. If your trip is short, I would say you can skip. But if you have the time, make sure you check out Saint-Chapelle.

The most beautiful Chapel I've ever seen. It is a long wait outside. I must warn you but this is because this Medieval jewel is located within the French Ministry so limited numbers and security must be passed. Rest assured it is incredible inside. I've seen many churches across Europe and this one is pristine and incredible. The stained glass is original and towers above you, the painted ceilings make you feel like you are in a jewelry box. Its a step back into time. Exceptional site.

Beautiful......Awesome. Worth the wait and security theatre, How do I review this wonderful, special, medieval master piece. The down stairs is inspiring, the actual chapel upstairs now that renovation has been finished is wonderful. Allow enough time for a photo safari .If you have the time, money and are there on the correct evening see a concert..... You will be dumb struck.

Beautiful!. I went for a tour of the church but I went back for an evening Classical music concert, Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It was magical, and you can get tickets right across the street from the church. Highly recommend this experience!
Concert in the Chapel. It was a wonderful string ensemble at sundown with the windows illuminated. The chapel is very well appointed.

Breathtaking windows. The church had only just been re-opened following refurbishment. The stained glass windows take your breath away. They span the whole height of the church and each tells a story. The refurbishment was to clean away the pollution and to add more light by removing some of the lead lines. This meant that the colours radiated with the light behind.

Your neck will hurt from all the beautiful stained glass!. I wish I'd noticed the big plates of plexi-glass that explain (in 6 languages at least!) the significance of each of the panels of stained glass before I'd spent twenty minutes admiring and taking pictures. Once I saw the explanation written out it all made more sense; not sure why they have these near the exit side of the second floor, would be better placed near the entrance side! The first floor has a very fun virtual tour machine that allows you to experience the chapel as it was hundreds of years ago, tilting and zooming the display as you move from site to site. Be warned: the museum pass does not get you past the security line which can take up to 1 hour as it's the same entrance for the courthouse attached to the chapel.

Great place for a concert. This is worth a look. You have to be escorted in to see the place. I've only ever gone there to listen to the regular classical music concerts. It is located on the Ile de Citè, in the Palais de Justice. It is considered a national monument. The windows are spectacularly beautiful. The only thing I didn't enjoy, and it has nothing to do with the church, but if you go to listen to an orchestra be prepared for the very small uncomfortable seats.

Stunning Chapel of Stained Glass. We visited the Sainte-Chapelle in May 2015 and the line was minimal. I read about this royal private chapel in a guide book and the history and description really interested me. The chapel was built by the pious King Louis in 1200 and the stained glass windows are the oldest in Paris. The chapel was built to house holy relics, among them, Christ's Crown of Thorns. This is not a large church or cathedral, so being able to see it without crowds was amazing. The first floor sets the stage for the chapel upstairs and the audio guide gives background to the visitor. Then follow the spiral staircase to the chapel and be prepared to gasp in amazement! The entire room is stained glass panels - just breathtaking. Make the time to see this glorious bit of history.

Superb concert in Sainte-Chapelle. We took advice from previous reviews and bought tickets online for the 7pm concert on Sunday 24 May. You have to be there at 6.15pm and there is a bit of wait before getting in. But it was worth it. The chapel is beautiful, with stained glass all the way around and the light coming through it, lights it up magnificently. The concert was superb: Bertrand Cervera, the Orchestre Paris Classik and the choir all excelled. Highly recommend.
Worth the visit. Amazing royal chapel. Great stained glass windows. Join it with a visit to the Concergiege next door which was the prison used during the French Revolution.

Gorgeous and interesting place. We bought two tickets to a wonderful concert held in the Chapelle. It was a chamber music concert held in the loveliest place ever. (You can find tickets at classictic dot com and see their schedule there.) Others I spoke with about their experience here complained about having paid their 7 Euros and then being shuffled in and out quickly as part of a scrum...this is a wonderful way to get to spend some quiet time in a unique place AND hear a classical concert too. Costs more, but well worth it!

Huge amount of people and a great show of hypocrisy.. After queuing and going through something like airport security I was expecting great things. Through the hoards of people I could see the chapel was a beautiful building, but in no way could it be explored properly. The stain glass windows are amazing, but I was appalled by the hypocrisy of attraction's operators - there were signs for 'Silence' as it is a religious building, and a guide was often heard asking people to be quiet (that is except the foreign tourist guides who stopped to give their input to their group.) Unbelievably there were also stalls selling souvenirs, taking up one side of the chapel, with traders happy to discuss the transactions. It reminded me very much of Jesus overturning the tables in the temple and sending the traders packing for bringing God's house into disrepute!!
Worth it!. Worth the line. Go see this! Beautiful. Don't get frustrated with the line, you will love seeing the inside of the chapel.

Do not miss this one. Although there was no preference for Museum Pass holders the wait in line was well worth it. Do not be discouraged by the first fllor you enter. Go upstairs and be truly amazed. The stained glass panels are the best I have ever seen.

Stained glass windows galore. A cathedral to satisfy your quota of stained glass windows. Go early or late even with a Paris museum pass. The pass gets you to the head of the ticket line inside but does not help with the so slow security line. These are old windows and unlike stained glass today with colored glass the windows are leaded but the stories of each window are actually painted on the glass. Highly recommend as a top attraction in Paris.

Awesome Stain Glass. Quick easy stop. This is included in the Paris Pass so you can skip the inner lines. The outside line is to do bag checks. There is a really good cheap eats across the street call sac parissiene which has the blue canvas. When you exit from SC, go across the street, walk down 30 seconds and there is a flower market on your left but if you go on Sunday, it is a bird market.

Suprise. This is a very small chapel and at first entry you wonder what thefuss is about. Then you climb a winding staircase and see the most beautiful stained glass windows. Doesn't take long to view butworth it

Gorgeous windows. make sure you buy tickets before you go, we did and skipped a massive line, well worth it!The chapel is simple inside, but you really only go for one reason, and that is to see the massive stained-glass windows, which were magnificent. Loved it.
Absolutely a must see!. Beautiful, breathe taking stain glass windows. Truly, one of the best in the world. Windows have been recently cleaned and restored.

Worth a visit despite the queues. After many visits to Paris, we decided to brave the long queue and visit Sainte-Capelle. It was worth it. Beautiful stained glass windows now fully restored. But if you are expecting to see a huge grand church, don't bother because this is a small chapel used by the residents of the adjacent palace only.

Breathtakingly beautiful. This is the prettiest church in Paris and worth the queue through security. Later in the day can be better for access. Avoid early afternoon as it's closed between 1pm and 2.15. This is when the queue builds.

Religious Paradise. Worth seeking out and the most wonderous chapel you could hope to find. The stained glass is superb and gives the most terrific photos but the vibe in this place is quite spiritual. The best chapel in Paris. Do not miss!

bold colors. it's like being inside a kaleidoscope full of bold colors and when the sun hits the windows the entire room transform into a rainbow of colors. look up and enjoy the magnificient stained glass, and if you are here for a show it's one of the places you will absolutely enjoy - the night lights inside the chapel is fantastic!

Fantastic Stained Glass. This chapel is one of the most beautiful we've seen. We were lucky enough to get tickets to a string octet and virtuoso violist performance in the chapel Thursday night. They performed Verdi's Four Seasons and it was perfect!
Climb up to see amazing light. Well worth waiting in line to go into the chapelle. The light is extraordinary when you reach the top of the stairs. A real gem.
absolutely beautiful. The stain glass it outstanding and tells a story. You can spend a lot of time there if you know your bible stories trying to identify each picture.
Stained glass windows are worth seeing. The architecture is lovely and the upper chapel with its massive stained glass windows as walls...magnificent!

Beautiful!. Don't miss this, not all tourists visit this, but you should! Definitely go on a bright day and be rewarded with stunning stained glass displays. In my opinion, the one of the if not the best I have ever seen, triumphing the Notre Dame.

Not to miss this. Have never seen so many stain glassed windows. And they were beautiful. You enter in the lower level of the chapel but make sure you walk up to the second level... that is the GREAT part.

Stunning stained glass. The stained glass in Sainte-Chapelle is feast for the eyes. Take your time to look at the panels and don't rush through it. The audio tour is very helpful in pointing out some of the highlights although I feel that might diminish those stained glass panels that aren't mentioned. Pick out a favorite section of the old or new testament and locate it and just enjoy. Be sure to take in the smaller chapel down stairs.

Heaven Sent. I have been fortunate enough to travel to many wonderful places, but attending an evening concert at Sainte Chapelle is one of my most treasured memories. We attended a concert that included Pachelbel and Vivaldi's Four Seasons. The combination of the music and beautiful surroundings was something special indeed. As the sun was setting, the chapel turned a golden hue, and the audience let out a collective "awwww." It was magical. If you have the opportunity, IMO this is THE way to experience the treasure of Sainte Chapelle.

fabulous. I was awestruck when I entered. Almost every surface on the inside has stained glass windows, with bible scenes from creation to judgement day. I'm not sure how it stays up. Much more impressive than Notre Dame.

Gorgeous stained glass. Even with tickets we waited one hour in line to clear security. The place is very small, but truly beautiful. The audio tour was helpful in understanding the stained glass windows. It was definitely worth seeing.

Don't miss this.. The first level, where the masses met, is nice but not breathtaking. Climb the circular stairs, and you arrive in a cathedral which is shocking compared to the rooms below. What was dark becomes light, what was drab becomes colorful. The 60 minute wait in line was well worth it.
Breathtaking. unbelievable, breathtaking and stunning. You must, must visit this place. If you're going to Paris, you have to see this place. Go early in the morning to avoid the queues.

Beautiful. Don't miss seeing St. Chapelle. Go on a sunny day for the maximum effect of the huge stained glass windows. There is always a long line to get in, but you can go to the other side of the building from the main entrance and purchase a combined Conciergerie - Sainte-Chapelle ticket, which allows you to skip the line and to tour the Conciergerie. Once you have toured the Conciergerie, you take your ticket to the front of the St. Chapelle line and you go right in.

Beautiful but beware of stairs. There are quite a few steps up a tight spiral staircase to get to the actual room to see the stained glass. This meant my mother was not able to see as she has a bad knee. Otherwise, simply stunning. A little stuffy up there as well. While it was crowded, it was still easy to see everything and get good pictures.

A Complete Jewel. They don't come lovelier than this chapel with its high gothic stained glass windows with its jewel like colors. Go to a concert here; it is the best way to see the place while hearing the music.
Pretty patterns. Quite a small room but beautiful to look at when its sunny. A lot of work has gone into the glass and its nice to appreciate.

Great Concert. The Chapelle offers concerts in the evenings. One can buy eTickets far ahead (online). We attended a Vivaldi Four Seasons concert at the Chapelle last week. The acoustics are fantastic, and we got to see the inside of the Chapelle for free.

Beautiful high stained glass windows. It is a small and fascinating chapel. Once you walk inside, your eyes can’t take off from the 15 high stained glasses windows. Unlike most of the gothic chapels/ churches which give one a dark and gloomy feeling, La Sainte makes one feel delightful and cheery. Highly recommended.

ADMIRABLY. Hidden inside the courtyard of the Palace of Justice is Sainte Chapelle - it is considered as the most beautiful chapel in France. If not in Europe. Less visited, hide the most beautiful stained glass that can be seen. Definitely it's a MUST SEE place in Paris. And another thing ... try to listen to a concert of string....

Awe-inspiring. This little church is one of Paris' best-kept secrets; an exquisitely preserved and restored Gothic church from the 13th century. It is inside the Palace of Justice complex, so not visible from the street, and it's not much to look at from the outside anyway, but that plain exterior hides one of the most beautiful, richly-decorated spaces in the world. Every inch of the interior is ornamented - painted, carved, or made out of stained glass. There are guide cards available (for free) in multiple languages to help you "read" the enormous stained glass windows, but you don't need a guide to appreciate the overwhelming beauty of the space. There is an entrance fee now (8 euro for non-students I think), to support the foundation that maintains and protects the building, and you do have to go through some metal detectors because it is inside a government complex. It is well worth it!

Pretty on outside, irregular hours. Supposed to be open until 6 PM, but it closed at 1 PM. They let in roughly 15 people every 15-20 minutes. Ridiculous. Wasn't a long line, so we stood in like around 12 noon, but by 12:45 we still weren't close to the front. And they decided to close it out of the blue then. Glad we didn't pay to support them.

Best hidden gem in Paris!. Because it's Paris, it's hard to find anything NOT outstanding, so to say this stands out from the rest is an amazing feat! I was backpacking across Europe, visiting buildings unlike any others in every city but never saw any others quite like this one. And the location is so convenient, just a few blocks from Notre Dame, you really have no excuses not to visit it!

Wow!!!. We bought tickets online for the Tuesday, May 12th, evening concert at Sainte-Chapelle before we left home. We were told to be in line by 6:15 for a 7:00 concert. There was no movement until 6:25 or so. Everyone had to have their bags go through security. Then we stood outside in another line until about 6:45 before we were let inside the church. It was definitely worth the wait! The stained glass is like nothing I have ever seen before. It just takes your breath away! The concert started on time, a group of five extremely talented string musicians and a singer. It is a wonderful memory, and I would highly recommend it to anyone. You will not be disappointed!

Simply the best stained glass in the world. This church is not large, but it has the best stained glass you will ever see. This is a must see site in Paris and is worth the wait in line to get into this church. Because it's a church there is not an entrance fee, so the line moves pretty well. If you get to this church when it opens you can beat some of the tour groups and have a less crowded experience. Its close to Notre Dame, so do this one first and then go to there.

Unbelievable Stained Glass. Cathedrals and churches in Europe are often lavish and filled with wonderful artwork, but the centerpiece of Sainte-Chapelle is its overwhelming amount of wonderful stained glass windows. The windows tell the whole story of Christian religion and show the full glory of the artisans who worked to create these wonderful works of art.
Worth the wait. The cathedral has the most incredible stained glass. The hour long line makes it a commitment but I felt it was worth the wait.
Worth the wait in line. The museum pass does not allow you to skip the queue. But even with a 45 minute wait, the relatively short visit was worth it. Very unique and beautiful chapel.

A shrine. A must to do when you are in Paris. Go there on a sunny day before 12am, preferably at 10 or 11am and experience the magic of the sun bathing the stained glass windows of this holy place. I cannot believe I lived in this city 18 years and only visited to the Sainte Chapelle few months before I left. You really do not realise what you have on your doorstep...Lionel B

Peace and beauty. This is a small but charming chapel that attracts hundreds of tourists. It is best to visit when it is less crowded so its beauty can be fully contemplated. Paintings on the walls and the stained glass is a true work of art.
The best stained glass. There is a lot of stained glass in France/Europe, but this may be among the best. If you're in Paris...at the Norte dame...go for it!

More beautiful than Notre Dame. Unlike the "churches are free" that you read on blogs there is an entry fee but it's worth it. The most beautiful is the upstairs with all of the stained glass. There are benches around the perimeter of the interior so you can sit and try to absorb the detail all around you. Reminded me of needing to sit in the Sistine Chapel and just look up in wonder. Don't forget to go outside on the balcony and look in.

Perfect!. A definite must see! The stained glass windows are well worth the wait. Do not miss the second level, the stairway is a bit tight but it was well worth a bit of a climb. You will need to line up and go through security before entering.

Gorgeous Church, Wonderful Concert!. La Sainte Chapelle is an extraordinary treasure of Gothic architecture, and a concert in the chapel is a feast for the eyes as well as the ears. The Sunday night concert at Sainte Chapelle was definitely a highlight of my Paris vacation! Seeing the church and listening to the concert is truly breathtaking! This is a must see - a remarkable combination of color and light. The stained glass windows are some of the most beautiful I have ever seen. Highly recommend!

Worth the stop. The stained glass works are beautiful. We paid a few euro to get the headphones when we went in - I think it was worth it to us, as it helped us better understand the history and artwork.

Stunning.. Our visit to the beautiful Sainte-Chapplle was further highlighted by our attending an evening Concert there. Sitting in such a magical space surrounded by gorgeous stained glass was a highlight of our trip to Paris.

Beautiful!. This chapel's stained glass windows are breathtaking! There will probably be a long line but it's worth the wait. We waited about 30 minutes as it moved along fairly quickly. One of the most beautiful churches in Europe--don't miss it!
Good. Go to Ile de la Cite. It's there. The hole area is worth a good three hours. Use Metro, wear comfortable shoes and look outside the box

a true "must see". Of all the amazing things we saw this was special. It is a like a jewel box of colour and light. The usual queue of course but not as bad as other places. It is not usually the top of place on peoples list to visit but should be. Beware, steep winding stairs no lift.

Literally breathtaking. Two places in the world have caused me to lose my breath - St. Chapelle and the Grand Canyon.
The only other thing I can say is, go when it is sunny - it is most brilliant then.

Do Go to Sainte-Chapelle. Amazing stained glass windows. The wait for this museum/church is almost non-existent and the cost is very reasonable at 9 Euros. It won't take all day but is the whole Bible told in stained glass.
Incredible Stained Glass. This is a smaller church near Notre Dame that has incredible stained glass windows. Try to go on a sunny day to get the most from the windows.

Renovations. I've been to Sainte-Chapelle‬ before, but my boyfriend who hasn't was a bit dissapointed to discover we arrived durring renovations. It's a beautiful place and definitely woth the visit, just make sure you get to see the whole thing!
Vacation 2015. The stained glass takes your breath away as you move from the stairs into the chapel. An amazing place to visit.

Absolutely gorgeous. Have been to St Chappelle several times, but this was the first time for a concert (Vivaldi's Four Seasons). Absolutely magical to sit in this glorious space and admire the architecture and stained glass while listening to the music. Booking tickets online was no problem, Do not bring any kind of knife (will be confiscated at security).
Old and breath taking. Just go. Don't hesitate. The history and the beauty will capture you by surprise. No spoiler here I promise. Just go.

Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. Buy tickets for a concert at Sainte-Chapelle for an evening to cherish. When you buy tickets, not only do you have your space reserved for an hour or more, you get to hear wonderful music while you gaze at the amazing stained glass.

Not rating the beauty--just the experience. My main complaint is the price. €8,50 to get in to see one small room. One breathtakingly beautiful room, yes, but one small room. We waited in line in the freezing rain for 45 minutes (we went on a Tuesday around 3pm) & it took about 10 to see & read everything about Saint-Chappelle. The downstairs portion has a gift shop & a beautiful ceiling, then you go upstairs to the main chapel (what you've seen in pictures). You see it, you take pictures, you maybe sit down & read the info sheet that describes the stained glass, & then you leave--there's nothing else to do or see. You can buy an audio guide for €4,5 but we didn't. Overall, the chapel is spectacular but the experience is rather underwhelming. The glass windows tell the entire story of the Bible in 1,133 scenes & there is some neat symbolism. Definitely something you should see, but try to go when the line is short.
Beatiful but costed. I've visited St. vita Cathedral in Prague which also famous for it's stained-glass, yet St. Chapelle is unique. But it takes time to line-up & the ticket is not cheap.
Magnificent. Magnificent! The history, the beauty...everything! The most beautiful stained glass especially upstairs! Takes your breath away!

Go at sunset. If you go at the end of the day, there is no line AND you can time it to be there when the sun starts to set. It's like being entrapped in a jewel box. It's the kind of place that, well, some guy came and told my husband his life story, then burst into tears. That kind of place.

a wonderful experience. What a gem if your in Paris look it up and go.wall to wall stain glass so uplifting.It takes a bit of finding and security is high but make sure you see it a great half day there is a great café across the road to saviour your reflections after.

Wonderful concert. We found a wonderful evening concert by a well known string quartet and lovely soprano who sang several numbers. The stained glass is exquisite in the upper chapel. A must do in Paris.

Special concert at St. Chapelle. We went for the evening concert (Vivaldi Four Seasons). This was a very nice experience with the beautiful stained glass above and ancient Chapel surrounding us. On the negative side, it was a long wait followed by a long walk to be seated and musicians were a bit perfunctory on their performance. Still better than most "tourist" type options. Ron H.

Amazing surprise in a little chapel hidden in the city. I went to check out this little chapel while in Paris last year, and I was absolutely blown away. It is stunning. It's on the Ile de la Cite tucked back with - yes, it's true - the justice building and a holding jail. Very odd because the entrance to both spots - the jail and the chapel - are through the same gate, which means you have to go through security. But once you get into the chapel and specifically go upstairs, it is breathtaking. Hundreds and hundreds of stained glass windows that surround the entire chapel - it is just lovely and very spiritual. I highly recommend visiting.

maybe more beautiful than Notre Dame. One of tthe most beutiful churches ever seen. Go there on a Sunny day wheen the sun hits the stained glass. Sometimes it is hard to get in, ling queues or something ging on at the court of justice. But is is worth the effort and ne really understands the magic of mediëval christianity.

Incredible Chamber Music Concert. Don't wait in the line to get in to Sainte-Chapelle. Instead, walk across the street to the restaurant that sells tickets to the evening chamber music concert. Buy the early show (7pm) so it is light out and the stain glass windows glow with color. We heard Four Seasons by Vivaldi played by 8 excellent musicians. There is no better way to see this incredible display of stain glass and no better place to hear chamber music! Tickets are priced by area, with no assigned seats (front 15 rows 40E, and back rows 31 on are 16E). Every seat has a great view of the stain glass and the chapel is small and acoustics super.

Sublime.. So, we went to Notre Dame and after posting some pictures in Facebook friends and family starting commenting about Sainte- Chapelle, about hoe=w gorgeous and this and that... next day we went and I have to tell you they were all right. What a sight is to see all those satined glass works of art. Mandatory in Paris.

Small but Beautiful Inside. We waited in the afternoon to see this church. The wait did not wane as the afternoon wore on so we stood in line. The museum pass does get you in but not line skipping like the Louvre. The wait was worth it. The amount of glass in the church is amazing. We found a seat out front looking into the church and sat there with 100’s of our friends looking at the glass. The place is small but you can spend an hour just looking at all the panes of glass. Truly amazing.
Beautiful Windows. This site is really worth seeing on your visit to Paris. The access is a little more complicated than other churches, due to the security checks, but you really should see it.

Overwhelming Beauty. While we were in Paris, there was a concert series at Sainte-Chappelle. We signed up for tickets the day before the concert. We paid something like 16 Euro per person for "VIP" seats in the first ten rows. Non-VIP seats cost something like 12 Euro. We attended the earlier of two concerts. So, it was just before sunset when we entered the small chapel. We were stunned -- quite literally unable to speak and stopped in our tracks -- by the exquisite stained glass windows illuminated by the setting sun. I haven't the words to describe the visual experience. We heard a wonderful string ensemble play Vivaldi, Mozart and Haydn. The music, the windows and the changing sunset illumination were a feast for the eyes, the ears and the soul. Almost too much. Such beauty!

Needs dusting. This is a very small church that is kind of hidden. The line could be easily missed along the main road. Then you go through security and are put out into a courtyard to find your way to the church, which is in the middle of the courtyard. But the church is simple on the outside (meaningful) which means it doesnt stand out from other buildings. Once inside there is a nice fresco room that is also the gift shop. Then you climb a tiny stone spiral staircase in the corner of the room to the second floor and enter the main room with the majestic and famous stained glass. The glass is amazing and if you hold still and take it all in, it made me feel like I was in a kaleidoscope. The room is relatively short though and is not a big church like other tourist trap ones. I would have enjoyed it more if it was dusted. There was a thick and hard to miss coat of dust on everything. This then hid the colors of the wall carvings and sculptures. The place isnt that big and shouldnt be that expensive to keep dusted. Outside they had stones and things piled up, so it looks like they may be doing some construction, but it also could just be cluttered storage. This felt like a forgotten church that was falling into disrepair. I'm glad I saw it as the stained glass was worth it and it didnt cost us anything since we had the Museum Pass, but I hope it comes under new management or something happens and they clean it up some to help preserve the highly ornate inside.
beautiful. This is definitely worth the visit and is right down the street from Notre Dame. After walking up the stairs, your jaw will drop when you enter the chapel. Absolutely breathtaking.

Spectacular surprise. What a surprise after climbing the spiral stairs to come up to the top to see the spectacular stained glass windows. It's not huge but well the effort to go through security. The history of the chapel is interesting and should be listened to either by video or audio tape.
Splendid. If you have the opportunity to go there for a concert in the evening, you will see the changes of light on the marvellous stained glasses.

Great ambiance. This amazing place is truly unique. Stained windows are fantastic, and the place is small to make you feel you're at the middle of everything. The fee to visit is quite small, and free for kids. The place is deeply secured as inside Paris "Palais de Justice" which means bags are cleared as in airports.

Pricey, with literally hundreds of people milling in a small chapel. Not a pleasure. at €8.50 this is not a cheap place to visit for what you get. Had to queue to get into the queue to pay, about 30 minutes waiting in total. The place was packed inside with, I'd say, close to 300 people all jostling to get a view of the stained glass windows in this tiny chapel. You can't see them as there is always someone crossing in front of you, bumping you from behind or sticking a selfie stick in your face. My advice, open longer, don't let pre-pays jump the queue, manage the numbers in the building so that people have a chance to really take in the building

Absolutely stunning! . A beautiful little hidden gem in the heart of the Paris. We were staying near the Latin quarter in Paris and walked here in about 10/15 mins. We queued outside for about 30/40 minutes but was well worth the wait. Truly stunning little church with the most beautiful stained glass windows.

Very Impressive Stained Glass. Located on the Ile de la Cite, this chapel is overshadowed by a church on the same small island in the Seine in Paris, the Notre Dame Cathedral. Unlike the dim and darkness in Notre Dame, the stained glass in Sainte Chapelle allows much more light and is that much more glorious. Make sure you go upstairs to be awed by the incredible walls of stained glass.

Pretty Stained Glass Windows. A very small chapel and you basically walk into it and there's stained glass windows everywhere. Not much more to this church except four "walls/ceilings" of stained glass. It's very pretty, but if you miss this one...not a huge deal. Also, there are line-ups to see this church, so if you're limited on time, visit Notre Dame as your first priority.

Beatiful Concert in Stunning Setting. We did not take the tour though I hope to come back and do so. We attended a concert for which one got tickets in advance and on-line. If you enjoy this type of thing choose to come here. We attended a 7:00 p.m. event and the sun set was lighting up the magnificent rose window and hence the inside of the chapel just gleamed. It was absolutely stunning especially when they played Pacabel Canon. The Other selection was Vivaldi's four Seasons which is obvious a favorite of half the world since it is offered at many venues in many cities around the world. But I digress, We were thrilled we went and it is very convenient to a metro stop.

Fabulous stained glass. I did not know of this church until friends recommended that we visit. The stained glass on the upper floor is fabulous. It helped to be listening to a Rick Steves' podcast explain some of what we were seeing. There is a lot to take in. It is included in the Museum Pass.
Extraordinary. Extraordinary. This is a must not miss when visiting Paris. It is extremely small and can be done in minutes - and it is totally worth it.

Stunning Gothic Architecture. As you climb the stairs of the chapel, you begin to wonder what you are entering exactly, you know it will be historical (built between 1242 - 1248) and sacred, you just don't know how completely jaw dropping it will be, then you see it. Glorious stained glass windows surround you as you enter the chapel, telling a story of mankind from Genisis through to Christ's resurrection. I simply marveled at the history I was viewing. One can imagine the King and his royal subjects worshiping here. It's a place to enjoy in quiet reflection as that is what it so deserving of. I highly recommend seeing this for yourself.
A must see. No matter how tired your feet are, you really must see this. Go on a sunny day if at all possible. Truly spectacular.
finally witnessed the acoustics. it was worth it...the time, the ticket, the appointment and seat there and listen from Bach to Piazzola under the sunset trough the windows, the sound was amazing.

Gorgeous. The towering rows of stained glass is worth the price of admission alone. It is stunning to see and is a bit overwhelming. The crowds can be a bit much, and they close (on days when they're open) between 1:15pm - 2:00pm every day. We got there at 1:20pm and didn't get in the queque....we went across the street and grabbed a bite. When we came back, the line was substantial but it moved very quickly.

Sainte-Chapelle cathedral: triumph of glass windows. Don't miss this gorgeous Gothic church and its stained glass windows. Most of the panels tell the Christian history of the world, and the work is spectacular. For an extra special visit, try and book an evening concert of their string quartet playing Vivaldi as the setting sun lights up the church.
lovely little chapel. Long lines. Your museum pass will not get you any priority access. The stained glass windows were lovely.

Don't overlook this remarkable church.. Not everyone knows about this church, the glass work in this attraction is not to be missed. I find this church more spectacular than te interior of Notre Dame. Try to visit on a sunny day, I didn't pre- buy tickets but if you hate lines it would be worth looking into.

The most beautiful cathedral.. Don't judge a book by its cover. The outside, is, very plain. You walk into what seems like a basement. I was expecting to be overwhelmed by this place, but found it just okay.......until I went upstairs!!! It brought me to tears. So beautiful. Just stand, breathe, try to take it all in.

Glasses tells stories here. Brilliant. Is the least word i can use for this church, On entrance it would look like a small church but once you go to the floor above, the magic unfolds. The splendour of the tainted galsses and the different tales carved on them. The mix of colors, the perfection of art together with the excellent structure of the church makes it a must visit spot in Paris. dont worry about the entrance fees. You will find it wrth it.
Beautiful church in Paris. A wonderful place to visit - so much history. The stained glass windows are amazing, and it is interesting that this church is built on two levels.

Beautiful. The best stained glass windows you will ever see. Also as a big plus, there were information boards in English which I found missing from a lot of French tourist sites! Slightly on the expensive side (for what it is), but wonderful none the less. Highlight of my three days.
Don't miss this!. Sainte-Chapelle is extraordinary! The colors and the detail inside this small building are amazing. It is well worth the wait in line!

Buy your tickets for a concert in advance. There are long lines here most days. Security is heavy because you are next to the Palace of Justice ( think Supreme Court). The best solution is go online early and buy tickets for a concert. Even at 7 pm , the windows are spectacular. We've enjoyed 2 converts here. Musicians are top quality.

Incredible architecture. This church is just magnificent. The church is mostly made of stained glass walls. One wonders how the church stands without falling. The light in the church is luminous and breathtaking. This is Paris monument that should not be missed.

Diamond in the rough. Located in the Palace of Justice complex, Sainte-Chapelle is a favorite of ours. On three different visits we've enjoyed chamber music concerts there. It's visually fantastic and a beautiful place for music. Don't be put off by the security check required to get in - it's well worth it.
Small. Someone else said it as well, but it's way smaller than I imagined. For the wait and the ticket price, I think looking at photos will do it justice

Windows to heaven. The lower chapel is nice, then you climb to the upper chapel with wonderful windows soaring to the top,telling stories from books of the Bible. This chapel is the site of concerts at Sainte- Chapelle, so get tickets if you can - available at the Tabak across the street from the entrance, as well as at the Sainte Chapelle on the night of the concert.

Most beautiful church in the world. Unbelievably beautiful church. Very intimate setting. One of my teens was cranky about waiting in line but when she walked into the chapel was rendered speechless! Absolutely breathtaking. Bring binoculars so you can read the windows---one side is stories from the Old Testament, behind the altar is Christ's life, and the other side is post-resurrection.Note: the area is under construction now---no WC's available. Go before you get in line

Concerts a great experience. It was closed on 1 May, but had a concert that evening. Got tickets through the hotel and it was fabulous. Had time to enjoy the stained glass while listening to fantastic baroque trio... couldnt be better and a great way to enjoy a sight while sitting quietly.

It's UPSTAIRS!. OK. we were rain-soaked and tired and it was only 9:40 am. Oh, and we were also still jet-lagged. So we paid our money (didn't have the Museum Pass with us!) and entered. It's Ok. Trinkets were being sold against the wall, the windows were nice for medieval windows, it's small. It wasn't what we expected. I thought I remembered seeing something pretty cool in a guidebook, but maybe it was somewhere else. Then we saw a small stair tucked in a corner with a sign that said the stairs led up. Hmmm ... No one seemed to be going up, and there was nothing to bar our way, so we ascended ... and entered heaven. GO UPSTAIRS!

Very pretty glass, not as big as expected.. The glass in St. Chappelle is stunning- literally. It feels like there aren't any supports to hold it all in, and it creates a beautiful light in the hall. It's worth a visit for a quick look, but this was actually a lot smaller than my mental picture. It's not a very large chapel, just tall. Museum Pass lets you jump the ticket line, but not the security line. Bathrooms were closed when we visited the first week in May.

Stained glass windows that are just Great!!!. We saw in travel books that this church had stained glass windows. Well, pictures do not do this place justice....the windows are just great with stories to tell. History is shown through out the church.

Highest concentration of medieval stained glass anywhere. There might be more stained glass at Chartres, but you can't see more in such a confined space.The chapel is small; it can't be 5% of the volume of Notre Dame or Chartres. That said, the walls are glass. All glass. Red and blue and yellow and green. No paintings, guilded walls, statues . This is all stained glass.When you enter from the lower chapel, your entire sight is of walls of stained glass. All the walls are just glass. You see Adam & Eve, Moses, the flood, etc.The rose window with apocalyptic images is overwhelming . Any of us could recognize a " horned" Moses or beheaded Baptizer, but the images here are harder. The palette lighter with mild greens and subtler blues.If you want size, buttresses, gargoyles, ribbed vaults, capacity, then go elsewhere . Notre Dame is just down the street. This is a temple and tribute to medieval glass.Get the audio guide otherwise it's too hard to find all the details.What Orangerie or Marmattan is to Monet, St Chappelle is to stained glass.

Sainte Chapelle. I loved the beautiful windows. You must go upstairs to see them. If I had not heard a fellow tourist remark on it I would not have known. It is a narrow staircase but people are kind and wait for you if you must take it slowly.

A small piece of Heaven!. This private chapel on Ile de la Cite is the most beautiful, intimate chapel I've ever seen. The best viewing isn't during the day. The line is long and the space is crowded. It is best experienced while listening to an ensemble playing classical music. You can get concert tickets on-line at http://www.classictic.com/en/concerts_at_la_sainte_chapelle/10055/224297/or you can buy the tickets in Paris that day. Concert tickets are sold at the brasserie directly across the street from the entrance to the chapel. There is a kiosk inside the brasserie with a very helpful person selling the tickets. Don't miss this breathtaking experience!

concert. We were lucky to hear a Vivaldi concert in Sainte-Chapelle. It made for a wonderful night. Go to any early evening concert on a Sunny day and watch the sun set through the stain glass windows, perfection.
Superbe. Need to pay for entry but you will not regret. Worth to visit. An extraordinary medieval Gothic Chapel.

Beautiful stained glass . Do make it a point to cover Sainte Chapelle if you are near to Notre dame. The stained glass is beautiful and is the main attraction here. With the Paris pass you can avoid the queue and see the monument quickly

Be Sure to Go Upstairs . One enters through the lower level where the servants worshipped and some visitors never figure out that you're supposed to go up stairs. Once you do the stained glass is spectacular, but less than half is the original medieval glass as the building has seen other uses over the centuries like Norte Dame, both were an arsenal. Nevertheless if you have time for only one church is Paris this is the one. A small pair of binoculars will come in handy.

BOOK A CONCERT. We booked the Vivaldi Four Seasons concert at St. Chapelle in advance (we were there in May) and what a gorgeous venue for it! My husband hates standing in lines so this was a beautiful way to see St Chapelle in a civilized and spectacular way. Simply amazing.

Surrounded by stunning stained glass!. The interior is rather small but packs a punch in light and assortment of colors... the stained glass is gorgeous, as is the ceiling. There are seats to the sides so that you can take in the scene and savor the colorful sight. This is no longer a religiously active site, but there are musical concerts on some evenings. There is an audio-guide and a little shop downstairs. There is access for wheelchairs, but otherwise expect to take a small, narrow spiral staircase up and down... it is well worth it!!!

Beautiful vitros. The glass windows are really beautiful and worth seeing. Having the Paris museum pass let us directly in avoiding a rather big queue of about an hour. Unfortunately we weren't able to attend a concert in there. Maybe next time.

Stained glass - a quick visit if you near Notre Dame Cathedral. We Visited the Sainte-Chapelle in April 2015. We first went to Notre Dame Cathedral at 08h00 and then at 8h45 we got into the line (about 20 people) as they only opened at 09h00. We spent about half an hour in the beautiful Chapelle. I found this slightly over priced compared to other Chapelle's around the word. However if you are near Notre Dame Cathedral and have half an hour spear then I would recommend the small Sainte-Chapelle and the stained glass.
Wonderful. Fantastic stained glass windows - you could spend hours here just following the stories. We didn't take the audio tour but I'm guessing you should to get the full measure of the place.

You can´t miss, but goes with a concert ticket in hand.. This charming temple in Paris is very easy to find, just a few meters from The Conciergerie. But the best way to make a visit is getting early to watch a concert of classic music. We had a wonderful Vivaldi´s Four Season! Unforgettable!Be aware that you will spend some time in line because of the security procedures as this Church is inside Ministry of Justice. So arrive at least 30 minutes before show time.

Sainte-Chapelle and Conciergerie. Beautiful church very close to the Louvre. Some of the best stained glass you will find. Right next to it is the Conciergerie where several famous "guests" were housed at times. Certainly worth a visit while visiting the St Chapelle especially since you can get combined tickets.

St. Chappelle. A wonderful little church on Isle de le Cite in Paris. We were there last year but was still undergoing intensive restorations. They are now complete, and it is simply breath taking. An attraction worth the wait in the queue!

NOT THE BIGGEST, BUT CERTAINLY ONE OF THE BEST IN THE WORLD. The beauty of this chapel will certainly defy the words you read here. If traveling to Paris, this is certainly in the top 5 must see attractions. Not easy to find, not easy to get into, but the challenges are worth it. Once inside the sanctuary, you will have a sense of peace and pure bliss through the play of lights through some of the most beautiful stained glass in the world. The entry fee is nominal, the time allowed to enjoy is unlimited and your future Chapel visits will always pale by comparison. Absolutely the one to see, savor and enjoy.Cheers and happy travels.

A classic Parisian site. You will find Sainte Chapelle in most travel guides and is all they say about it , I.e., the amazing stain glass windows. So be sure to pay a visit duringthe day.However, if you have the opportunity to attend a concert here in the evening, do not miss it! The acoustics are fantastic for a string quartet or quintet. We were fortunate to hear a very talented quartet play Vivaldi's Four Seasons. What a lovely ( and inexpensive ) way to spend an evening in Paris!
WOW, AMAZING. The vitros in this chapel are truly amazing. Try to time your visit on a sunny day, when the rays of the sun shine through the vitro, it is a wonderful site.

Stunningly beautiful. Built for Louis IX, the moment you enter you realise the chapel is fit for a king. The ground, or lower chapel, feels more like a very ornaye crypt. It has the most stunning vaulted ceiling in deep blue and gold. Every time I see it, it takes my breath away. The first floor, or upper chapel, is more like a conventional church. Again, the decorated walls and ceiling are beautiful. But the 15 stained glass windows are spectacular and tell wide range of bible stories ranging fron Genesis, through the book of Job to the book ok Kings. It is great fun trying to spot the individual stories - take some binoculars if you are really interested as the windows are very tall.Sadly, the wall paintings are not in great state of repair in places.Overall, very well worth a visit. Try to get tickets online as the queues get very long.

Spectacular. Along with Chartres Cathedral, the finest stained-glass windows in the world.
