But...the highlight of any trip to Paris, is to attend an evening concert when the lighting inside is phenomenal and the acustics are incredible. I always return when Vivaldi's Four Seasons is being played. The chapel is small which makes the concert very intimate. Reservations are required during peak seasons.

Amazing!. From my point of view the most beautiful church in Paris. Location is hidden and not very visible from the outside.The church is small but the stained glasses and colourful ceiling are incredible.Entrance is around 8 Euros and queues are minimal compared to Notre-Dame.100% worth visiting.

A hidden gem round the corner from Notre Dame. This church has a dazzling portrayal of the bible in stained glass. Takes your breath away. The first chamber you enter is just a very small taster for the main course.
We arrived at 09.15 and joined the queue. From then it only took 20-25 min to get in.

a concert. a string quartet and a mezzosoprano.in the program Vivaldi,Bach and then several AveMarias(Gounod,SaintSaens,
Schubert...)would you be able not to let tears down?
Ten kinds of awesome. If you appreciate stained glass or just want to be dumbstruck you need to visit this location. Just amazing craftsmanship on display.

If you only see one church...see Sainte Chapelle!. Europe is graced with beautiful historic churches, but my teenage daughter was beginning to feel like they all looked the same UNTIL we stepped foot inside Sainte Chapelle! Thanks to a tip from a local that told us Sainte Chapelle was more impressive than Notre Dame, and the lines were shorter. I've visited nearly 50 historic churches, and Sainte Chapelle is my new favorite!

Absolutely beautiful!. This place was recommended to us by our SANDEMANs guide Harriet and is absolutely amazing. It's a very ancient building, that is going under restoration but as soon as you get in, you get amazed by its beauty. There are tall windows with colored stained glass everywhere, giving the feeling that you are inside a jewel box. The staff was very friendly and since we were travelling with backpacks, they offered to look after them.It is worth the visit!
Gorgous!!. This isn't on the typical tourist trails, but well worth a visit. The stained glass windows are absolutely breathtaking!

Bad organisation of fantastic classic concert at Sainte Chapelle. The quality of the artists and the location has been breathtakingly good. However the experience of the evening was overshadowed by the extremely bad organisation of the event. Due to the fact that there has been only 1(!) security gate (at one of the most wellknown highlights of Paris) for hundreds of people queueing up the one hour lasting concert started with 50 minutes delay. Some people were leaving due to that delay. You better do not plan a timed date after the concert. Due to the very bad organisation of the seating (even in what they call the VIP area) and the disinterest and ignorance of the staff couples and groups could not sit together; we saw one couple leaving due to that. The biggest imposition however was that it has not been allowed to use any toilet before, during and after the concert. 300+ people many of which elder were not allowed to use the visible and close toilets!!! Over a period which lastet nearly 2.5 hours due to the late beginning. Despite various efforts with different members of the staff the use of toilets has been refused. Experienced travellers do not have high expectations regarding the customer orientation, friendliness and quality of France; but this bad experience topped many others. It was a shame not only for the customers but very much so also for the fantastic artists who had to suffer from the bad mood of the visitors as a result of the extremely bad organisation.

worth it with MP. I wouldn't necessarily pay to see this on its own since I went through it fairly quickly, but if you have the Museum Pass, it is a sight to see. The stained glass windows are gorgeous!!

Go Upstairs First. This former King's chapel has some of the most incredible stained glass windows on the planet both in quantity and quality. This is near the far more famous Notre Dame but should not be missed. Stunning to view.

Beautiful stained glass. The stained glass lived up to everything we had read about it. To imagine that all of this was created by hand centuries ago is amazing. The planning and craftsmanship is unbelievable and to see just about every scene from the Bible depicted is worth the visit.

Interesting. It is definitely worth a visit with it's beautiful design but what captivated me most upon entering this chapel was its history. Everything else didn't seem too nice as it is currently under restoration, which made it not as enjoyable as it would have been with drills going off! It still doesn't deserve a bad review and I would recommend anybody in this area to visit.

fantastic. my daughter bought a ticket for a classical concert here and what a big treat-listening to gorgeous music while looking at the gorgeous windows. Best to go to the earlier concert as on a sunny day the setting sun lights up the windows while the concert is going on--beautiful and the highlight of my trip,

Wonderful Stained Glass. Sainte-Chapelle is vey close to Notre-Dame and has incredible stained glass that depicts the entire Bible. It is beautiful and does not take long to visit. If you are passing by, it is well worth it.

Breathtaking. Possible the best Church/Chapel I have ever been in. There. Is a security Check before you enter. But words can not describe the beauty of the building you will just have to visit there yourself.

Don't miss this beautiful & historical chapel.. This royal chapel is one of the world's greatest architectural treasurers. Very convenient to Notre Dame. No trip to Paris is complete without visiting it.
An interesting place, very beautifull. This place is new restaured, some poeple are still working for a few days...buy a ticket in advance, to avoid the long waiting file....
St Chappelle. This is a special place with memories of DDay and the relationship of the local people with the US. The church is beautiful, and there is a special window.

Not to be missed, but still under restoration. We went here about 3 years ago and they said the restoration would be finished by 2014. We went here again Oct 2014 and a lot is still blocked off which is very disappointing. They have to do the work and the restoration so far is beautiful. They have been working on the windows for 40 years (yes, forty years!) It should be finished by Dec 2014 or at least finished very soon now. Whatever you see is well worth a visit here as it is absolutely exquisite. The chapel is run by the Centre des Monuments Nationaux and I don't see on their website that you can pre-purchase tickets. We had a fairly long wait in line. They do accept the Carte Paris Museum Pass. The audio guide in English is very good but runs for a full hour.

Stunning Gothic royal chapel built to house Christ's crown of thorns relic. Sainte-Chapelle is an absolute wonder. I've been to Paris several times, but this is the first time I saw Saint-Chapelle. What was I thinking? If you love architecture and history, Saint-Chapelle should be right at the top of your list of things to do in Paris.In terms of sheer beauty - it is exquisite. As you enter the royal chapel from the staircase from the ground floor you step into a soaring nave made of walls of stained glass, and decorated above by a field of gold stars on a vaulted ceiling.The chapel is itself a reliquary built to house one of the most significant relics in Christendom - the Crown of Thorns. Saint-Chapelle was commissioned and built by King Louis IX of France to house his precious relic which he purportedly purchased at a price that was more than three times the cost to build the chapel itself. Among the scenes depicted in the stained glass is one of King Louis IX receiving the crown of thorns - very significant! Images and carvings of the crown are abundant throughout the chapel. Note that the crown of thorns which Louis IX purchased is no longer housed at Sainte-Chapelle, but at nearby Notre-Dame Cathedral.TIPS: Saint-Chapelle is open every day of the week (except some holidays like Christmas) including Mondays and Tuesdays, days when a number of major museums are closed in Paris.While I was there I noticed that there was a concert (Vivaldi's 'Four Seasons') scheduled that evening. I can't imagine a more incredible place to hear a concert. Worth checking out before you go.

Beats Any Kaleidoscope. With visitors admitted in stop-and-start bursts of 30 or 40, the queue to Saint-Chapelle along the rue de Justice seemed interminable, if no more than half an hour. But the breathtaking blast of color and light at the top of a narrow circular stone staircase felt we'd been shot into a giant kaleidoscope. We could not have divined that this frail Gothic mini-cathedral that the devout Louis IX--Saint Louis--built in the 13th Century as the chapel for his long-gone palace could survived weather, wars and a revolution. There's more stained glass here, 6,458 square feet of it in the richest red, blue and yellows, than pillars and walls, Most is cut into such small slivers recounting biblical narratives that it seems woven of Belgian lace. We paid about $14 each for that.

Secret treasure in central Paris. Only few parisians know this place and less had already visited it!
One of the most oldest and beautyful of the city of Light!
On guidebooky.com you might also discover his particular origins. .
One of the best place to follow a nice tour on paris'center monuments. .

Take a break in the far past !!!. This absolutely amazing place has been built in 1248!!!It is based on Ile de la Cité, the most ancient place in Paris (Lutece in the past).the King St Louis prayed in this place. It is a MUST see in Paris...take time to visit this place. You will never forget it and you will understand it belongs to France Kindom history.And if you have time, try to find St Louis history, it will enrcih your visit.Wellcome in France !!!

Springtime in Paris. Well worth visiting this beautiful chapel,the most impressive stained glass I have ever seen.However be aware of very strict, airport-style security at the entrance, and some rather officious members of staff.

Treasure has gone.... Very nice to see and quite an important place of France and Paris history. However, as the treasure has moved to a Notre-Dame, I think the visit in itself is a bit short. Especially if you take into account all the renovation being done that is making the visit less impressive.
Most Beautiful chapel takes your breath away. This building has the wow factor, as you enter the upper chapel the colours of the windows are breath taking. I have been before but still moves me.

Another "must see" when in Paris.. The queue was no more than 15 minutes and well worth the wait.There can be no more stunning stained windows in the whole of France. Originally the chapel for the King, La Sainte Chapelle is now incorporated in the Palace of Justice environs. It is a two storey building and, after admiring the ground floor windows and wall paintings, you take the narrow spiral staircase to the upper level and marvel at the incredible, huge stained glass windows. Go on a sunny day to see the windows in their full glory.There are laminated descriptions of the windows in many languages and some (few) seats to sit and read the history of the chapel and windows.This is a must see in Paris.

Stained glass spectacle . Nothing can prepare you for the amazing spectacle of light and vibrant colour when sunshine is streaming through the windows. The wall decoration throughout is intricate and delightful. Would go again.

Stained Glass on Steriods. I have been to Paris many times, but this was my first visit to this incredible small chapel. Very close to Notre Dame area and WOW. The statined glass is not to be missed. From the ear a of Louis IX I beleive. Well worth it.

Dazzling holy chapel do not miss it.. Save Sainte-Chapelle for a sunny day to see the wonderful stained glass at its dazzling best. This is Paris's most exquisite Gothic monument. It was conceived by Louis IX to house his collection of holy relics including the famous holy crown (now in the Notre Dame).

Quite Disappointing. I visited Sainte Chappelle in the afternoon after visiting Notre Dame and I was a little let down by it to be honest.There wasn't much to see and I don't think you got as much information as possible out of the visit. Maybe if there was a guided tour it would have helped.As with most of the government buildings if you are under 25 you get in for free so I'm glad I didn't pay into here.

Impressive stained glass windows. As far as architecture, it is beautiful. The stained glass windows are very impressive. But it has been stripped inside.
Note there is usually a long lineup to enter, specially in the summer.
If you have limited time in Paris, I would skip.

Dazzling windows in intimate space. What a surprise to come up the stairs and find light pouring through beautiful stained glass windows all around. This is not a large space, and the effect of so much light and color magnifies it's impact. Sainte-Chapelle is a treasure not to be missed. I just wish that we had been able to attend an evening concert there.

Stained Glass walls. I have read so much about this we had to see it. On the lle de la Cite, close to Notre Dame. 1/2 hour line on a Tuesday. It was impressive but I was a little disappointed based on everything I had read about it. Relatively small. But great windows and dark blue painting with Fleur de lis painted all over. Interesting storyline that it was the King's private church. He could enter from his bedroom. (We didn't see his bedroom/caslte, just the church.

Wow....and I'm not normally a WOW sort. I think the best stained glass I have ever seen. Just fantastic. Next door to the Concierge where the prisoners were kept prior to execution during the Revolution so the two can be combined to save your time

Beautiful. Visited this with no real expectations and walked away absolutely amazed. Mindblowingly beautiful. Recommend visiting first thing in the morning or late in the afternoon, otherwise too busy. Pre pay your ticket!!!

Get there early. The Sainte-Chapelle opens at 9:30 am and the Paris Museum Pass does not afford the opportunity to skip the line at this site. Having a pass, however, at least gets you out of having to spend a few minutes buying a ticket. Get there as early as possible to be one of the first visitors. Sunrise is relatively late in Paris during April and early visitors get to see the sun's rays coming through the magnificient windows of the upper chapel. There is the added bonus of a much quieter group of visitors at earlier hours. Whatever you do, do not miss this. It is one of the world's major beauties.

Unexpected Awe. I wasn't too happy about the long line (it was cold and pouring)....but I was told it was a 'must see.' So, upon entry, there was some construction, and I was impressed by the roman artifacts and stained glass and paintings....but was still wondering what all the fuss was about....and then I started up the stairs to the 2nd floor. Once I walked through a set of amazing, massive doors, I am fairly certain my jaw dropped. The windows stopped me in my tracks. I've never seen anything like it in my life. Ever. And I doubt I ever will. The colors, the size, the room; everything was beyond what I could have imagined. It was worth waiting in line! Stunningly divine.

Better than Notre Dame. Notre Dame is cool from the outside but this place is great on the inside. You gotta go upstairs to the second level to see the stained glass windows. Not very busy and lines are not that small. I pre-bought my tickets online and just walked in.

Standing in long lines is worth it. If this isnt the first thing on your to do list plan to stand in line. This is where the crown of thorns is stored and entrance is included free with the museum pass. Unfortunately the justice palace did not offer a second line for guests who hold a pass so you stand in a long line waiting to go through a security check before you enter. It takes about an hour after lunch. Then we waited in a quick line to enter with our pass at the actual site and walked into see the most beautiful stained glass windows that we saw during our 2 weeks in Paris. This chapel really is a stunner. It helps to have your own guide/tour book but they also have laminated tour information available for free in each room so you can know what youre looking at.

Totally worth the line. This past summer I went to this spot with my family, I had no idea what I was going to see, but from the long line I gathered it was something pretty incredible. I was blown away once I got inside, Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. I know there is an entrance fee, I can't remember what it is exactly, but I do know that it is worth it. I am Christian and the stain glass recounts religious stories, but this is so incredible I would have appreciated it even if I wasn't religious. I was inside for roughly 20-30 minutes, and it was very close to other famous Parisian landmarks.

Beautiful building. This was probably my favorite building in Paris. You begin by entering the first floor. We did an audio tour to get a better idea of what we saw. There are many languages available to listen to. When we went upstairs the site was breathtaking. The glass is overwhelming. The room tells the story of the entire Bible with stained glass. The audio tour got confusing at this point and I did turn it off because I got lost in the view. If I ever return to Paris I will come here again.
Great building, price is too high. It costs 8.5 euros for one room, takes no longer than 15 minutes to see everything, therefore the price is too high.

Beautiful but a lot of work ongoing. The queue to get in takes a long time as they let in a few at a time for security checks and there are also coaches of Chinese tourists that get to skip the line and go straight in which makes the queue take a lot longer. Make sure you read how much it is to get in, as if like us you are and EU resident and are under 25 then you get in for free which is very handy. Once you are in it is clear that a lot of maintenance work is ongoing however when you’re visiting an attraction as old as this is to be expected that there will always be some restoration work ongoing. The windows are beautiful and when you walk in you really get that ‘wow’ moment so definitely give it a visit.
Amazing Windows and History. The stained glass windows are magnificent! TIP: Lookup the meaning of the windows before you go and you will appreciate them more.

Incredible stained glass. We had overlooked it on many trips to Paris but went on the recommendation of some Americans we met at dinner. Go. It won't take long to see, but it houses some of the world's finest stained glass. And St. Louis (Louis IX) had a thing for his mom. Her crest is everywhere. It's good to be the king.

Magnificent. Just a short queue for this one and it's a short walk from Notre Dame, so do them together, on entering Sainte-Chapelle it takes you rbreath away, the colours are stunning and this is well worth a visit.

Wow. The Stained Glass Windows are breath taking. We saw a very nice concert here. What a treat to sit and hear beautiful music while looking at all the stained glass windows. Stay as long as you like see if you can find bible stories in the glass.Word to the wise its very dusty if you have asthma take your inhaler
bad experiance. 1. long wait in the hot sun2. noise and dust due to work of maintenance3. people don't look, they just take pictures!!!

STRIKINGLY STUNNING STAINED GLASS WINDOWS. I have seen many stained glass windows around the world BUT nothing prepared me for the strikingly stunning stained glass windows at Sainte-Chapelle. Waiting in line for our turn to enter this historic old chapel I wondered whether I should stay in the long queue. I guess if it wasn't for my wife I would have walked away. What a mistake that would have been. Once inside the lower ground floor was interesting but nothing spectacular. There is a steep narrow stairway leading up to the next level and when I entered the large room WOW I was blown away by the huge stained glass windows that completely surround this chapel. Photos just don't do it justice. Do yourself a favour and look for yourself - you'll be so glad you did.
Beutiful glass. Take the time to sit and enjoy the stained glass. Lots of meaning in the depictions. The mid-day light is perfect for photography.

More beautiful than Notre Dame!. While Sainte Chappelle is not an active church anymore, the stained glass windows are breathtaking! It won't take you as long to visit, but sit, linger, and see if you can identify the Biblical stories in the glass.
Incredible architecture. This church has the most spectacular stained glass I have ever seen. And to think this was rhe private chapel of the king. It is close to Notre Dame so dont miss either one.
amazing stained glass!. We had been encouraged by friends to make sure we put this on our list of sites for our first trip to Paris. This is a must see! The stained glass is amazing!

Beautiful inside out. It was an amazing experience, visiting this church. We had not initially planned on including a church in our itinerary and it was completely a last moment decision but one that was well worth it. The work especially the stained glass one just makes you spellbound. Along with that the architecture too is breathtaking and when we visited there was only a fair amount of crowd which made it even easier for us to appreciate the beauty of this church.

A masterpiece of stained glass!. Much more beautiful than Notre Dame this is a must see if you are in Paris. There is a line and as of April 2015 the Museum Pass does NOT let you skip the line outside. But it is worth the wait. First you go into the downstairs chapel and it is underwhelming. But when you go upstairs it is a sight to behold. I put this in the top 5 of things you MUST see in Paris.

The best place I've visited in Paris.. This church is for sure the best one I've seen in Paris. It is not that big but the inside is so beautiful it seems unreal. It conquers you. We went there right before it closed. The most beautiful thing is to see how the colors change within the sunlight goes down. It leaves you speechless. My heart still stops beating while seeing the pictures of this incredible place. Must see it.
stained glass. Didn't like waiting in line and trying to find it took forever with the directions I had. Was worth it...stained glass was amazing!

St Chapelle. In the shadow of Notre Dame a lesser known but no less interesting church! They have placards in many languages so you can understand the incredible stained glass. And it is incredibly historic! Do not be afraid of the tiny windy staircases!

One of the most beautiful buildings in the world. This is one of the most spectacular stain glass chapels that I have ever seen. We queued for like 90 minutes to get in but it was totally worth it. You walk upstairs and your jaw just sinks. You are surrounded with the most magnificent stained glass windows. They have a leaflet which describes what each window is about, as each one tells a story. Fifteen huge mid-13th century Windows and a large Rose window. It is very close to Notre Dam, you can just walk over.MUST SEE!!

Highlight of our trip!. We attended a chamber music concert in Sainte Chapelle. It was just incredible! The chapel is like a jewel box and the concert (Vivaldi's 4 seasons) within this beautiful chapel was an emotional experience not to be missed. Even the musicians were in awe of the venue, gazing around at the stained glass windows when they had a pause in their part of the arrangement. I would definitely do this again. Not to be missed!

Stunning Stained Glass Windows. Well worth popping in for a look if you have a pass of some kind. The windows are magnificent and it is intriguing to try and uncover the messages that they contain.
We found the chapel itself to be quite dirty and were surprised it was not maintained to a higher standard. There were clearly some renovations taking place.
Not t be missed. Small and beautifull with great windows these place is interesting and after that visit the conciergerie where Marie Antoinette was in prison as so many others
Stunning. We visited on Good Friday-it was one of the most spectacular stained glass chapels we have ever seen.
Beautiful chapel. Finally the scaffolding is gone. We went at sunset and the light on the stained glass windows was incredible. Highly recommended.

Picky Traveler: Concert at San Chapelle. I was fortunate to go to a classical concert at San Chapelle on a sunny evening. The chapel's incredible stained glass windows glowed in the early evening light. The short (1 hour) concert featured classical top 10 hits (e.g., Canon in D major, Four Seasons etc....). Try and go when it is still light out to really appreciate the space.

Beautiful stained glass. the line is a bit long and security was tight but efficient. The entrance area was a disappointment with lots of shops. BUT go up the steep stairs and you arrive in a gorgeous chapel with stained glass. This is NOT a place easily navigated by the infirm. There are special arrangements for the disabled
There are no toilets
Incredible. In my opinion the most beautifull spot in Paris... and still enjoyable despite the many tourists! Worth waiting in line...

A Pilgrimage Worth Making. This chapel, commissioned by King Louis IX of France, was consecrated April 26, 1248.It was once the home of "Christ's Relics," including the crown of thorns. One of the most impressive features is the huge stained glass windows on the second floor, which in addition to paying homage to King Louis for relocating Christ's Relics to Paris, illustrate various portions of the old and new testament.While the chapel has largely been recreated due to damage suffered during the French Revolution - two thirds of the stained glass is authentic. Whether you go to see the gothic architecture or bask in the colorful glow of the stained glass on the second floor this is a worthy pilgrimage.I do suggest reviewing the warnings on the Sainte Chappelle website. Thorough bag checks are performed before allowing entry. Be sure not to be carrying any restricted items to avoid being turned away.Check the Sainte-Chapelle Website for pricing and hours of operation.Photos from my visit can be viewed by visiting http://www.acevedophoto.net/Portfolio/The-World/Paris. This review was originally posted on my blog - Http://acevedophoto.blogspot.com/2015/04/sainte-chapelle.html
Must visit if you go Paris. I am neither a christian nor a Catholic, but I found the grand colorful windows are amazing. I took a lot of pictures there, it is a treasure in the heart of paris.
Lots of stained glass!. This church was a pleasant surprise. Covered in stained glass. Go in the late afternoon so you can see the sunlight coming in, lighting up the wall of stained glass.

Very worthwhile. We almost skipped this church, but decided to give it a try. upon entering one might wonder if it was worth the admission price, but once one walks upstairs to the main chapel and see all the stained glass, one realizes the price was worth it.

Came here for mass. This is not the most grandiose of churches in Paris. If you want more pomp and circumstance visit the Notre Dame. The 7p mass which I attended had a small number of church goers; they held it on the backside of the cathedral.

Absolutely stunning. Finally we had the opportunity to see Sainte-Chapelle.
Not only is beautiful, it has many historic stories associated with it, and displays the technology of stain glass windows. Amazing that most glass is original, in spite of wars, riots et al.

Very interesting!. Next to the Cistiene Chapel, this church was remarkable. The stained glass windows were magnificent and I am so glad we didn't miss it. The line is very long but moves very fast. Well worth the wait, and the lines are an indicator of the treasure.

beautiful gothic chapel. The Sainte-Chapelle is one of the surviving buildings of the Capetian royal palace on the Île de la Cité.
It retains one of the most extensive in-situ collections of 13th-century stained glass anywhere in the world.
Concert in Sainte-Chapelle. Were able to attend a concert in this wonderful church on Easter Monday. The sound was marvelous and the quintet moved us back in time. An opportunity of a life time.

security control - think in advance about your luggage / for UE under 26 - free. It my absolutly fav place in Paris but each time I keep forgeting about the security control. So bevare, you will not enter with siccors, or wine opener ;)

Well worth the wait.. We made the metro journey over to the medieval island on the river seine to visit this beautiful church and what a mixed experience we had.The queues are off putting, 30 minute wait but the church interior truely breathtaking. The jaw dropping stained glass windows are truely outstanding, the features of the church are just amazing and the vibrant colour of the various windows will live long in the memory.This is a must go destination when on any holiday to Paris,ive been going to this wonderful city for 20 + years and it's my first visit to SAINT CHAPELLE,but it wont be our last.Very easy to locate, jump the metro down to stop, CITE,to ILE DE LA CITE,one of the 2 islands on the seine,and were the city of Paris was founded.Opening hour's are; Monday to Sunday, 9.30am till 6pm.
Absolutely stunning. In a city of beautiful churches with glorious stained glass, this one is exceptional -- the illustrations from the Bible created in light, or so it seems.
13th Century Stained Glass Treasure Trove. We attended a concert here one evening of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. There is no more beautiful place than this to listen to such magnificent music.
Stunning. Well, you'd better like gothique because this is what Sainte Chapelle is about. A chapel for the kings, right at the heart of Paris, and in the midst of Palais de Justice...

Beautiful sight for sore eyes!. We went after a day's walking about; it's on the Paris Pass too. What beauty! You first walk into the lower low-ceiling chapel which, although quite beautiful, has you saying 'is this all?!'. Then a small staircase takes you up to the king's chapel and what happens is that, as the staircase comes up through the floor, you pop your head up from the relative darkness below into a magnificent kaleidoscope - tall stained glass windows all round! Beautiful!

Windows worth waiting for. We waited 45 minutes to get in and were surprised at how small the church was. We then went to the second floor and were stunned by the size and beauty of the stained glass windows.

Worth the wait.. A beutiful little gem although, while we were there at least, there was always a queue. To be fair, it was a beautiful spring day, the line was about half an hour, but it moved quickly and the chapel, once inside was worth every minute spent in anticipation. Stunning - particularly on a sunny day when the stained glass windows painted the inside of the chapel with gem like splashes of colour. Go, be dazzled.

One of thst - if not THE BEST -- beautiful places in Paris!. Sainte-Chapelle is an absolutely beautiful chapel this is even more magnificent now that they've cleaned the windows. The morning light coming through the stained glass evokes the powerful feeling of why light was so important to the people years ago. But it's not just the amalgamation of colored light that is so fantastic; it's the individual frames that are inset in the large windows -- the ones that tell the stories -- that are a delight to view through binoculars.The lines can be long to get in, so using the Paris Museum Pass is a big help -- you'll still go through the security line, but the short wait is worth it.

Ahhhh!!. One can not say enough about the beauty of Sainte-Chapelle. The full ceiling to floor stain glass windows telling the story of Christ is simply amazing. You just stand in the foo and admire the beauty. A must see. Go earily, lines get long.

Stunning. Take the time to visit this church. The lines can be long, and you only need a short-time (30 minutes) for the actual visit. But the stained glass on the upper floor is stunning. Don't miss this sight.

Truly stunning and a must see in Paris. One of my three favourite spaces* in Paris I try to come back here each time I visit the city. It's worth trying to arrive half an hour before opening as a queue had already formed when I went 15 minutes early the last time I visited. Numbers inside are kept at a comfortable level and as you need to look up to see the windows, it's one of the attractions where a crowd does not really get in the way. However, I found the guard at the entrance to be rude and brusk, closing 15 minutes before the last entry time printed on the sign and without really any explanation. When people in the queue tried to query him he simply waved his hand in their faces repeating that it was now closed. His unapologetic attitude and rude behaviour certainly lived up to the stereotype many tourists have of the French. (*the other two spaces are the Lady and the Unicorn tapestry gallery in the Musée de Cluny, and the galleries housing Les Nymphéas by Claude Monet at Musée de l'Orangerie)

A must see if you don't have to wait in line (and that is rarely). I have been to Paris many times and don't like to wait in line. This past fall, it was possible to get into Sainte-Chapelle with only a brief wait so I did it. It is very beautiful, the colours are hard to describe - you have to see it. Architecturally beautiful and interesting. Once in a lifetime is probably enough unless you are a scholar of religious art. Highly recommended if you can get in without waiting. I believe that there are many things to see in Paris that don't require line ups so I always go for them!

Waited for over an hour and a half for a 15 min. look. The wait was insanely long about an hour and a half. When we entered the chapel, the first floor was half under construction. We went upstairs, and yes, the stained glass windows were breathtakingly beautiful. However, that is all there was. To wait that long, and only see that, I do not feel it was worth it. We could have spent an that time somewhere else. However, I did hear that if you first purchase tickets at the Concierge (just down the street where there was no line) and you buy duel tickets, you skip the line.--- in that case it is worth it, however if there is a long line--- skip it.

Stained glass that is second to none. This church has the greatest collection of medieval stained glass. It was built as a reliquary for the crown of thorns by King Louis (St. Louis), who there is a statue of in the basement. Line ques can be long - be sure to arrive early (like most other places in Paris). First entrance is 10am. A Paris Museum Pass includes free admission to St. Chapelle.

The line was long. but worth it. i went on a cold rainy March weekday afternoon, with all that being said, there was a long line for ticketing. i think i waited for 45 mins. i dont think it is necessary for an audio guide, as they have a board inside with some introduction of the church and the stories depicted on its beautiful stained glass windows. They have them in English, German, Spanish..hmm..maybe some more.
Amazing stained glass windows. Beautiful. Well worth the queueing. Never seen such stunning windows! Would recomend. Good guide cards available.
Ok but you only see the stain glass area. Thought we would see more of the place but only the chapel stain glass area is open. Nice but for 8.5 euros free notre Dame is just as good and bigger.

A wonderful concert in Sainte Chapelle. We purchased tickets online long before we actually arrived in Paris, and we were not disappointed. The six musicians who performed Vivaldi's Four Seasons and two shorter works were excellent. Their leader was particularly dynamic, both an outstanding musician and a true showman. It was a wonderful start to an evening followed by an excellent dinner.

lovely windows but not much else. the historic relevance of this being the King's exclusive chapel is very interesting to learn about however the wait to get in was an hour! As an American I was a bit disgusted by the royal indulgence of this. Try to go on a sunny day to maximize the beauty of the windows otherwise it will be a let down

Don't miss this beautiful site!. I'm honestly surprised by some of the reviews I'd read about this site claiming it was a waste of time and money. It makes me wonder if these people bothered to go upstairs to Chapelle Haute, where you see the breathtaking stained glass windows from pictures. Yes, it's true: Saint-Chapelle is divided into a lower chapel and then an upper chapel. If you only visit the lower chapel, you may feel cheated for having waited in line for so long, as it's somewhat dull and not at all what you might've seen from pictures. However, there's a spiral staircase tucked into a corner by the entrance. Ascend these stairs, and then your mind will be blown. I literally stopped breathing when I saw the stained glass windows in the upper level. They are breathtaking. No words can adequately describe how stunning they are. You will be dazzled. I spent over an hour in the upper chapel because I simply didn't want to leave! There are chairs in the chapel where you can sit and drink in the beauty of the place. Be sure to pick up one of the laminated indexes in the back which tell you all about the chapel and the stories in the stained glass windows. This is one place you do not want to miss!P.S. Avoid the long lines by instead purchasing your ticket for Sainte-Chapelle from the Conciergerie next door. Once you do, you can actually go to the front of the Sainte-Chapelle line.
Stunning stained glass. Long line to get in past security. Can use Paris Museum pass. When you go upstairs you feel like you are inside a jeweled box. Just slow down and absorb the beauty

Stunning. Like a hidden treasure! You don't realize how beautiful this church is from the outside because it's exterior is hidden from view where you wait in line. When you walk in, you come into the rather uninspiring lower rooms. When you walk upstairs and into the chapel, you are totally surprised. It is a bit like the Sistine Chapel in its impact. Beautiful stained glass that can't be believed unless you see it.

Don't miss it!. This cathedral is very close to Notre Dame and is often overlooked. It is a treat. You enter on the lower level and then proceed up the stairs. The windows are beautiful. Be sure and grab a card (different languages are available) as this will describe what you are seeing.

Awesome. I don't want to spoil the surprise but if you're visiting you probably came for one thing only and it is presented to you in a grand reveal at the top of the stairs. Wow. Go on a sunny day. More helpfully, go to Le Concergerie, NO QUEUE ever, buy a "combine" ticket with Sainte-Chapelle (only a further 5Euro), take a short tour ending with the cell of Marie Antoinette and the SKIP the queue to Sainte-Chapelle!TIP:Under 26 years go free.

Wow! Worth the wait if there is a line. Absolutely loved the beautiful stained glass windows. Just breathtaking! There are large, laminated cards (in various languages) upstairs where the windows are that you can use to get a description the panels of stained glass. I also used the Rick Steves Europe Audio App (Sainte-Chapelle is described in the walking tour chapter entitled Historic Paris) and it was a great compliment to my visit. The line can be pretty long, so prepare for the weather if it is cold and rainy (or if it's hot in Summer). It will be worth it when you get inside and see that stained glass.

My hands down favorite place in Paris. The beauty of Sainte-Chapelle is easy to miss and hard to over-rate. Stuck in the middle of a large police station complex (the Palais de la Citie), it is a breath-taking sweep of stained glass that makes you feel as if you're living inside a universe of color and light. To get to it, you have to go through a metal detector, so leave your pocket knives back in your hotel. Once you're inside you'll feel as if you've drifted back in time, and if you're like me, you won't want to leave. I missed Sainte-Chapelle the first 3 times I went to Paris because you can't really see it from the street, but it's well worth the trip.

Stunning architecture and windows. I have visited here every time I have been in Paris, and I am always amazed at its beauty. It does not look much from the outside, but inside it is incredible!One tip if you are taking a group, as I was (25 people). You need to book your visit as they have limits as to how many people can be inside the cathedral at any given time and large groups can be denied entry. We were lucky this time, but will remember this if I take a group again.

Spectacular - and a tip for visiting times. This is an absolutely stunning chapel (overused word but completely appropriate here). We were super lucky to join the longish queue just after midday and get to be some of the last people let in before they shut the security screening at 1pm. The queue opens again at 2.15pm after lunch break. Gotta love the French lunch tradition!Anyway, this meant that by the time we got into the building and other tourists raced through to their next adventure, we virtually had the chapel to ourselves to enjoy the amazing stained glass panels in sparkling midday sun. As with most attractions, well worth getting the audio guide to explain all the history and detail of the artworks here, although there was some printed info in various languages inside the chapel.Also if you have time, duck into the Palace of Justice next door on your way out. No additional charge or security queues, but a spectacular building and you can see French justice system in action! Remarkable.

Beautiful stained glass. Always a long line but on a warm, clear day it's worth the wait. Beautiful stained glass windows. We have enjoyed an evening concert of Vivaldi's Four Season in the past. Great to experience the building at night.

Simple but unique. You wait in line, shorter in March I bet, and ultimately get to the main cathedral with the stain glass work that tell illustrates the story of genesis through the apocalypse. This was worth our 30 minute wait.

Absolutely Beautiful - Visually and Musically. I can only repeat all of the glowing reviews of the beauty of this small chapel and its magnificent stained glass windows in the upper chamber. But my most memorable experiences have been the unique concerts that are held here. Depending on the time of year, these often occur just around dusk when the beauty of the chapel turns from bright to dim in the fading light from the stained glass windows. Large church candles set throughout the chapel then bring out the true character of the setting. My absolute favorite concerts are Vivaldi's Four Seasons performed by Les Violons de France, the violin orchestra of France. Concerts are performed frequently in this magnificent setting and if you're in Paris when one is available and fail to take advantage of the opportunity, you will have missed one of life's most memorable events! My favorite site for finding available concerts here is classictic.com. Just search there for "Sainte-Chapelle Concerts".

Fantastic.. I absolutely loved this place. The fact that it was built in the 13th Century is amazing. Please go and see Sainte Chapelle, you will not be disappointed. What I didn't like was the length of the queue, but that's Paris.

Very Nice!. There are loads of stained glass windows here!!! All very beautiful!!! Also a number of stone spiral staircases. The colors in here are awesome! This is a Must See. I think the fee was 8,50 to 9,00 euros. Well worth it!

Step into a room of colored light. This private chapel for Saint Louis is a highlight in the beauty of Gothic architecture. I like to watch my family member's faces when they enter the upstairs room because it is such a startling experience. For an extra special treat, go to one of the concerts that is held in the chapel. We went to a string concert in the evening and so got a beautiful view along with classical music.

Stunningly Beautiful. This is one of the prettiest places and things I have ever seen. We did have to que for around half an hour and didnt spend that long once in but it is well worth the wait. From the outside it looks like any other building but was amazingly beautiful

Wow!!. We waited in line about 50 minutes to get in, but it was worth it. Everyone goes through security, bag check and metal detector, even those who bought a Museum Pass. The lower chapel was for the royal household, pretty but not outstanding. This is where the gift shop is. But walk up the stone spiral staircase, and when you get to the top--WOW! The stained glass windows are fantastic! We were there on a hazy morning, but still the colors are wonderful. You can spend as much time as you want here, and then you go back downstairs by another stone spiral staircase. This is a must see. I think the fee was 8,50 euros.

The one which is a must. It is personal, subjective of course, but this is something you have to see. The entrance fee is high, but worth of it. One tip: if you want to avoid standing in a big que, buy the complex ticket at the entrance of the Conciergeire. It is faster and not as crowded as at the Saint Chapelle .

A must in Paris. So my wife and I went into this church in March, not too busy, but still a good queue. We had read about how this was something that we really should visit and from the outside we thought why? We went inside and were still wondering why this place was so highly rated, but then we went upstairs. Oh my, there are no words to explain the awesomeness of the stained glass in this church. It is beyond belief, we stood there for quite a while in in awe of it. The stained glass goes through pretty much every story of the Bible and it was really fun to figure out what each piece represents. We probably spent about an hour just looking around at the glass in this church.Also, they have official shushers. So when things get a little loud, which is often, someone shushes them. Can't decide if I would like that job or not, or if I even possessed the required shushing skill sets to even obtain a job of that sort.Saint-Chapelle was by far the biggest surprise I have ever had when not knowing what to expect inside of a building. It was simply amazing.

GREAT CHURCH - RUDE VISITORS. The church was a good visit but was ruined by inconsiderate visitors who insisted on taking photographs within when there were signs clearly stating that photography was not allowed.

Stunning and Inspiring.... If you are a stained glass lover you must not miss Sainte-Chapelle. A gothic masterpiece built in the early 13th century and currently undergoing some restoration work. Best viewed on a sunny day, this church will take your breath away with its 15, 50ft tall stained glass windows and star-covered vaulted ceiling.

One of the most stunning places in the world. I can't stress enough how vital seeing Sainte-Chapelle is for a trip to Paris. It is one of the most beautiful places I have ever been. I've been to Paris four times now and visiting the city is not complete without seeing this incredible example of what people can do when inspired. Use your Paris Museum pass to get in quickly as the lines get long!

Beautiful. Sainte-Chapelle is jaw droppingly beautiful. No words will ever describe the sights you will see when you go to Sainte-Chapelle. I would go early in the morning as ques get very long after a while and if you're an EU citizen and under 26 you get in for free like many attractions in Paris so make sure you show your passport! I have don't think I have ever seen something this beautiful.

Not good for a busy day. Avoid to stay in the queue on a busy day since apart from the impressive stained glasses there's nothing else interesting to see and pay 8.5 euro for it. So unless you are a fan of stained glass or there are no long queues (which btw are created because you and your stuff have to be checked on xrays) , stay away.

HORRIBLE employees!. The church might be beautiful but the employees at Sainte-Chapelle are xenophobic, unhelpful, and rude. There are many other beautiful churches in Paris, and I would recommend visiting them instead. Go to churches that still have services. It will be a more fulfilling experience than standing in line just to be insulted by a Parisian who does not understand the connection between tourism and her salary. My worst experience in Paris was going to Sainte-Chapelle.

One of the most beautiful stained glass windows. Yes, there is the Chartres Cathedral (grand!) and many others, but it is especially the intimacy of this chapel that makes it such a special place. Try to go there when the sun shines, depending on the time of day, there will most likely be at least one window that will shine magically in its brilliant colours, because of the sunlight.

"Jaw-dropping beauty!". We visited mid-March around 330pm and there was about a 45 minute wait in line. We had the Museum Pass but there is one line that everyone stands in for the security check. Once inside, go up the narrow winding staircase and prepare for your jaw to drop! The beauty of those windows was incredible! If you were to only view and photograph the stained glass (that is, not read a guide or listen to an audio guide while there), expect your visit to be possibly under one hour. It was a cloudy day but just as we were about to leave, the sun came out and the windows glowed!

A Little Jewel Box!. What a special place. The windows are so beautiful, pictures don't do them justice. We went on a very cloudy day and they were still lovely. I would plan on at least an hour to really see all the glass.

Most Amazing Cathedral in Paris!. Although this is a small lesser-known cathedral, it has one of the most impressive main halls ever. I would recommend NOT googling it (unless you already have), so you get the full first impression that it deserves.

A hidden gem. A magical place, I space across this randomly in my guidebook and so glad I took the effort to go, even though it's only road the corner frame Notre dame. As I'm under 26, I got in for free but I would have paid to see inside, it's a wonderful scene of stained glass masterpiece.

Stunning stained glass windows will leave you speechless.. The usual caveats aside i.e. being careful when to visit to 'minimise' the queues (and it closes for lunch), you will be left speechless by the utter beauty of this building and the truly magnificent stained glass windows. We went on a sunny day, the rich colours and hues of the glass dancing on the stonework within the chapel. You will need to be a very tough and insensitive individual not to be stunned by this one. Just grit your teeth with all the usual issues which attend French tourist hot spots and just admire in wonder all the same.

Beautiful stained Glass Windows. The stained Glass windows are beautiful,we waited about 45minutes and only just got in before lunchtime closure. There is no structure to the queue or estimated waiting time, it could be better organised and have friendly staff organising the crowds into some type of line.
Breathtaking. Don't miss this beautiful little gem! When I came up the stairs and saw this spectacle of stained glass, I was moved to tears. Quick walk from Notre Dame, yet so different.

A glowing gem in Paris. We were recommended to visit Sainte-Chapelle by friends. (It is located close to Notre Damme) The first impressions of this place are not excellent with the queue and security checks however once you climb the stairs into the main Chapelle the stained glass with blow you away. What is most staggering is how old this Chapelle is! I would definitely recommend a visit.
Stunning windows. Perfectly preserved gothic stained glass. Go on the sunniest day possibly to get full effect. Line moves slowly, you can use your Paris Museum Pass but no preferred entrance.

GREAT place... TERRIBLE staff attitude!. The place is pretty amazing, it is one of the highlights of Paris, everybody knows it and I completely agree and I should give 5 stars for that!... but the experience I had was pretty bad and that's when I go down to 2!Went to visit it, it was afternoon and there was, as you would expect, a long queue. Closing time 6pm, last entry 5.30pm. I queue anyway. After over 30 minutes queue I am almost at the front ready to enter. It is 5.20pm, and happy I am able to make it, when an UNBEARABLE and IMPOLITE member of the staff start saying (should say scream?) FERME FERME (or how you spell it!)... "the museum is closed...". Now, first: you have a board along the queue that says "last entry 5.30" (picture attached!). You stop people 10 minutes before that could have clearly had the chance to enter by the fixed last entry time. And, second, you do it screaming and raising hands in hair doing the typical gesture used to send people away. That is frankly a TERRIBLE way to treat tourists that are paying to come to see your place and should be treated as host specially if they have been queuing for a while and they should still have the right to enter as it was NOT closing time.I am sorry that a beautiful place like this (where I had to come the day after!!!!) is connected to such a bad memory. Staff dealing with customers/clients/tourists should be properly trained to do this job and to deal in a appropriate way with them.
Best Cathedral. Sainte-Chapelle is not to be missed. It is by fare the most spectacular stained glass I've ever seen. It is small so it is intimate and also a quick stop that is well worth it.

Impressive stained glass. This small chapel is an impressive display of stained glass, best seen in the daytime for full effect. The chapel is small so lines to get in can be long. It is worth getting there early. The printed guides help translate the scenes in the stained glass, but without a zoom lens, the panels at the top aren't visible. This was worth a visit, but I wouldn't wait for hours to get in.

Hidden Gem. Just don't miss it! Despite the queues - it will blow your mind.My husband was very anti church visiting - still we saw a few in our travels - this is the one he still talks about. The only downside for us was that restoration work was in progress which limited the full impact of the experience..but when you see it you will understand why the restoration is so vital.

Magnificent!. This has to be my favorite chapel. The stained glass is beautiful all the way up the walls to the soaring ceiling. Unfortunately, when we were there construction renovations covered at least a quarter of the inside, but it was still beautiful! We used the Rick Steves informational audio tour as we toured which added to our appreciation of this site. Also, it was included on the Museum pass - a worthwhile investment.

Very pretty, not a must see.. It used to be a must see because the Crown of Thorns was here. They are now at Notre Dame. The stained glass window is Very beautiful. Was nice to see prior to visiting Notre Dame

Absolutely amazing windows - watch out for the lunch time closures.. Dating back to the mid 13th century - originally built as a chapel to hold Relics - the distinguishing feature of course are the amazing windows which surround the chapel with bible stories arranged in 12 groups. The walk up the narrow winding staircase does not prepare you for the amazing beauty of these windows. The lines can be long - not very well marked the individual admission is on the right. Don't get caught up in the group reservation line on the left which often merges with the individual line in a chaotic mess. Also the Sainte-Chapelle line in right next to the door for the Palace of Justice and many people initially got into the wrong line. Also BEWARE of the long lunch hour closure so be sure to check the schedule. Small admission fee - the wait might be longer than the visit.

Fantastic stained glass & arch, but very cold!. There was a moderate wait to get into Chapelle (~25 minutes), visitors should always plan for that and lines would be longer in peak months.Best time to visit is supposedly before sunset when light best illuminates the amazing stained glass windows. We paid for audio guide (5 Euro) and it had a lot of great info. Unfortunately could not finish all the audio bec Chapelle was unheated & very cold, even though we were bundled in layers.This is another thing that visitors should prepare in colder months.

Stunning...though smaller than you'd expect.. An incredible example of the art of stained glass. You have to go through a lineup, metal detectors, and a fairly high entry fee to get to it but it's worth it in my opinion. When you first enter you're actually in the 'basement' where the gift shop is so you have to take an immediate left up the staircase to get to the actual main room (we were thinking "Is this it?!" before we figured it out). To be honest I was a bit underwhelmed at first by the small size of the place, having just come from Notre Dame, but the more I looked up at those windows and came to realize the stories they were telling the more amazed I was. A very special place though I'd think 30 minutes inside would be enough.
Don't miss this one. We went as typical tourist to see Notre Dame, which you must see. Then decided to visit this place near by. The chapel and glass are stunning. Don't miss it.

Royal gothic chapel. Located on the Ile de la Cite, beautiful chapel was built in 13th century. Sainte chapelle is composed of lower chapel and upper royal chapelle.The Sainte-Chapelle is decorated by a unique ensemble of fifteen stained glass windows and a large rose window which form true walls of light. In the mid-19th century, the Sainte-Chapelle was restored in a manner which both re-created the original flamboyant Gothic and created an ideal vision of sacred medieval architecture.
Amazing windows in a small church.. This is a very small church, but the stained glass windows take up basically all of the walls. Worth a quick visit for sure!

Beautiful but make sure you go to 2nd floor also. Wonderful church. Smaller and much more manageable that Notre Dame but both are worth seeing. The 1st floor is being renovated so you will be sadly disappointed if you think that is there is to see. You have to go up the stairs to the 2nd floor where you see about 24 stained glass window showing the history of the bible. Audioguide is good but so much detail it gets a bit boring. Hard to see the details of each stained glass piece since it is so high up.

Awe Inspiring. This is simply the most beautiful building I have ever experienced, even more impressive than the Segrada Familia in Barcelona. Go on a sunny day when the stained glass windows are at maximum brilliance. Do not miss.

Ethereal & magical. Fifteen magnificent 50 foot high stained-glass windows, which portray over 1,000 religious scenes make this a must see experience.The gate in to the Palais de Justice where Sainte-Chapelle is situated open at 9.30am, we arrived at 9.15am and there were only 5 people queuing outside (it was a cold Sunday morning). Once through security.Once inside we headed straight up the spiral staircase to the upper chapel which houses these incredible fifteen stained glass windows. It's worth picking up a storyboard which explain what is on each window. The 16th window - the Rose window or 'Apocalypse' with its 86 stained glass panels was unfortunately surrounded by scaffolding as they are still restoring this area all the other windows have been restored). The lower chapel which was for 'commoners' is also worth looking around.

Well worth waiting !. If there is a line, wait anyway. Beautiful two story church with magnificent stained glass windows. Make the second story too for even more amazing sights. There are stairs, and not handicap equipped that I saw so rest your legs for climbing. All, well worth it !!

Beautiful stained glass windows. After queuing to get in (security checks) was greeted by the most amazing sight. Huge tall windows around all the walls of the church. Well worth the wait to get in. I suggest visitors use the helpful guides provided free which tell one about each window and what is depicted in them. Very uplifting visit.

Worth the wait in the rain for half an hour, an amazing experience. I waited patiently in the rain for the experience of seeing this two storey chapel. The ground floor is impressive in its detail, but when you climb the narrow spiral staircase you are blown away the by the amazing stained glass windows. Considering they are over 700 years old the colour and workmanship is awesome. Please thank Velux for contributing to their renewal and repair

Just incredible. How can the upper part of this chapel stand when it seems to be made of stained glass windows with little stone to hold them together. Even children are amazed at the fantastic beauty of it. Be prepared to queue though... even whit a pre-booked ticket.

A Must See for the Stunning Stained Glass. Although the line to get in took over an hour, this was worth the wait. The chapel is surrounded by some of the most beautiful stained glass I've ever seen. There is plenty of seating, so take a seat and just soak in the sight. A definite must see while you are in Paris!

A hidden gothic gem. It is quite difficult to find the entrance - look for a small red sign on the Palais de Justice on Bvd du Palais. Expect to have to queue but it is very well worth the wait. The upper chapel with all the stained glass windows is simply stunning. Would definitely recommend the audio guides to appreciate the history and what you are actually looking at.

Oh my!!!!!. I was so surprised. This is well worth the extra mile of a walk and more. This chapel is gorgeous. The stained glass is extraordinary and something you will never see again. There are English language details that you must get in order to appreciate all the symbolism and story in each window. If you have a small pair of binoculars, pack them for this attraction!!!! Just sit on a bench and look up. I didn't have binoculars but I really really wished that I had them. The chapel is within the Palais Justice grounds, so give yourself a few more lines before going in. During March, we waited about 30 minutes near closing time. Don't forget to see the outside marvels, too!

Best Stained Glass-Worth It. This attraction does not take too much time, however it will help you get your hourly fix of spectacular beauty. Being in the middle of the City helps so you can see this church on your way to or from another attraction which requires more time.

Well worth the que!. The que might take you 20 min and it costs 8,50 euro to get in. The windows are mostly fromthe 13th century and so beautiful, one window is called the Rose window and is round.You are allowed to take pictures, but you can't light candel offerings. Enjoy!

Magnificent. My second time there and it was just as amazing as it was 15 yrs earlier. The best part was entering the upper chapel with my daughter and watching her eyes grow wide with amazement. Photos don't really do it justice. It really is breath taking.

Stained Glass Par Excellence. Located near the Palais de la Cite, The Sainte-Chapelle offers some of the world's finest stained glass in a royal medieval (13th century) Gothic chapel. Erected by Louis IX to house Jesus' crown of thorns and a piece of the original cross, the chapel is divided into upper and lower sections. The Sainte-Chapelle is available through the Museum Pass. Due to its location and contents, there is extensive security screening to enter.

Not to be missed. This is not a famous site internationally but you will have missed one of Paris' true gems if you don't see it! Don't worry about a line outside, it moves quickly! Upon entering, get your bearings, but this is not the floor you're here to see, Go up the spiral staircase on the same steps used by royalty and guests for centuries and try to remember to close your mouth when you get to the top!

Breath-taking.. First impressions are so important and 20 years ago there was no shop (or continuous construction works) to spoil the two levels of the chapel. The upper area is superb and even with quiet a crowd inside one can find room to appreciate the structure and interior. The Parisians of the time would have been impressed with the erection and construction of Notre Dame and Sainte-Chapelle just after the former was commenced.A combined ticket with the Concierge is recommended and both can be visited over a two hour period.

Impressive but small. This is certainly an impressive church but after queuing for a long time, going through airport-style security then queuing again for tickets and paying €8.50 each to get in we were a bit disappointed at how little there is to see here. The stained glass is very good and worth a look but we were only in there for 30 minutes. I'd still recommend seeing it if you can but expect to be standing outside waiting to get in for longer than you're actually in there for.

Beautiful!. This is a great must see - especially if you have the museum pass. It is amazing that this was built in the 1200s and still has 70% of its original glass. The space is small but breath taking.

A Gothic Jewel. While by far not the place that every tourist knows and feels they must go, this is a small jewel of a chapel that no one should miss. It is a highlight of Gothic architecture, perfectly preserved, and like standing inside a diamond and looking out. It won't take you long to visit, because its very small, but its also very special. Spend a few minutes just soaking in the sheer magnificence and joy of being there.
The most amazing church ever. This chapel is absolutely breathtaking, it definitely outdoes Notre Dame in my opinion. Can't be missed at any cost!
A hidden gem. Found Sainte-Chapelle by mistake and what a surprise! Sadly it was a cloudy day so we couldn't see the true splendour of the windows but still impressive nevertheless. Worth the visit.
Incredible stained glass!. Beautiful church filled with the most stunning stained glass. Definitely worth see while in Paris, on the Museum Pass.

If you go to one cathedral in Paris. ABSOLUTELY make it Sainte-Chapelle. Being inside resembles standing in a jewel box, especially when the sun is getting low and streaming in straight through the windows. As the light changes the colors change and if it's not too crowded, it's lovely to sit on one of the benches and contemplate the changing colors. Right now there is construction obscuring the rose window with the vision of the Apocalypse, but everything else (including the famous Tree of Jesse panel) is visible and ready to be admired! Can't recommend more highly.
fantastic and enigmatic. not possible to forecast from the street to find this treasure in the middle of Paris city... amazing painting and architecture! a place to visit definetly

Wonderful windows. We visited St Chapelle today. The windows are marvellous and are in the process of being restored. The rose window is particularly spectacular. The floor and the panels in the wall have not yet been restored. There are handouts in English which provide some history of the building. We bought a combined ticket to the Conciergerie as well and went there to buy it before going to St Chapelle, thus avoiding quite a queue. There are narrow winding staircases to negotiate in the visit which starts in the downstairs area and then follows in the upstairs church. There is a security check going in so don't have any scissors or sharp,items in your handbag.

This has to be on your bucket list. There is no other place like this in the world. It was built by Louis IX (St. L ouis) who believed he had purchased the true Crown of Thorns and wanted to create a worthy place to keep it. He succeeded. The 13th century stained glass windows shine like jewels on a sunny day. Gothic architects had multiple symbols for religious ideas and people, but they created the interior space of a cathedral or chapel--with its ever-changing lighting, sounds, and feeling--as the symbol for God. Here one can experience that symbol like no other place.

Free Street Theatre: French Public Sector Attitude (don't arrive after 4pm whatever your ticket say). We went to St Chapelle in February, hoping to see the renowned stain glass windows as part of a Paris day trip to see the Picasso Museum. We arrived at 16h10 only to be told a few minutes later that the museum was closed for the day. This was despite the fact that last admissions as per the website and tickets was 5pm. No one wanted to take any responsibility for the decision or discuss with the ~30 people who wanted to go in. Clearly the staff regularly shut early and don't give a f*** about the terms and conditions. A real pity but a good example of the attitude of public sector workers in France ...

Stunning. The place is going through refurbishments and you can clearly why when you step in there. Everything is as beautiful as you see it on google images especially the top floor. Those high stained glasses which wraps the chapel are just wonderful. You feel like in a different world. Definitely a place to visit and not far from Notre Dame Cathedral as well

When Pictures Speak A Thousand Words. The interior of the chapel contains a litany of stain-glass windows that portrays the entire story of the bible. However, despite the religious nature of the chapel and its contents, an additionally compelling part of the location is the detail in the work of the stain-glass windows as well as the architecture of the chapel.It is recommended to go earlier in the day to avoid groups. Also for those who enjoy taking pictures, it is recommended to try to bring a wide angle lens to capture as much of the windows as possible.

Not the best time for a vist. The chapel is incredible, but it is undergoing significant restoration work (as of March 2015). Scaffolding obscures some windows, and others are quite dingy. Still, the stained glass windows are extraordinary.Security is tight - with xraying of bags & metal dector, so leave your pocket knife at home.

Better Than Notre-Dame!. I hadn't heard of Sainte-Chappelle before visiting Paris, but one of our tour guides highly recommended a visit, especially on a sunny day. It is one of the many attractions included in the Museum Pass which we had already purchased anyway so we decided to check it out before heading to Notre-Dame one beautiful morning. Walking into the chapel almost brought tears to my eyes because it was so incredibly beautiful. As our tour guide said, "If you aren't into stained glass, it is because you have never seen Sainte Chappelle on a sunny day." Definitely visit, especially if the sun is shining!

Magnificient. Hello Travellers, this is another perol of architecture its gothic built in mid thirteen century, i went before vitral restauration and it was brilliant, everything is almost mint condition, they treat all of their monuments very well.A must See and its very close to Concierge.Go There!Visited 2006
Work of Art. At first floor you can't get the idea but move up to the second floor and take time to read instructions and try to understand the story of all vitrays.

One of those ooh-ahh-OMG moments. After you have made your way through security and walked through the drab interior of the Justice Ministry campus - you simply are not prepared for what assails your eyes after a short circular staircase climb. Get the sunlight right and you will witness one of the most beautiful colour and artistry displays on the planet. Amazing & heavenly.

Expensive but worth a look. Most of the tourist hotspots are free to enter, and our ticket to the Conciergerie and Sainte-Chapelle were around 27 Euros. A word of advice - the Conciergerie has a very short queue so if you're wanting to see Sainte-Chapelle, get your ticket from the Concergerie as you can smugly bypass the huge queue for Sainte-Chapelle! Sneaky :) The art, stained glass and architecture of the chapel is like nothing I've ever seen - really beautiful.
Window stories. We loved the history in the windows of the church. BUT, if you have knee problems, don't visit here--much walking and climbing, and the wait to get in is long.
Can be skipped. This would be a wonderful site if it weren't under restoration. The only good thing is that the lines aren't very long to get in.
Getting a Facelift. Being refurbished during our visit so it was hard to really appreciate. We will try again on our next visit. For more info: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sainte-Chapelle
Beautiful and different. This is a must-see! The most stunning - and huge - stained glass windows. Do visit this remarkable building!

awe-struck - truly magnificent. Don't let the line for security put you off - they take large groups in all at once. This is a fantastic place to visit. You do have to climb up some narrow stone circular stairs ( about 4 turns around) to enter. It is like being inside a kaleidoscope! The light sparkling just takes your breath away!

"It's like being inside a jewel!" (and it's wheelchair accessible!). As a wheelchair user, you approach the front of the queue and an attendant will take you through the security entrance for the nearby Palais de Justice in order to more easily access Sainte-Chapelle (there was a step into this area which security will help you with). As with most of the museums in Paris, wheelchair users plus a companion receive free entry. Once you've been taken around houses to get to the chapel itself, it really is like being inside a beautiful and most colourful jewel with 15 panels of stained glass detailing the old testament as well as Louis XIV's acquisition of the crown of thorns (now held in Notre Dame Cathedral). They are currently renovating the rose window but you can still enjoy the other panels of glass. The short, subtitled video and the free multi-lingual cards all help to explain the different panels, tell you how best to read the stories and point out the highlights. Definitely one of the best things I've done in Paris and the perfect accompaniment to a visit to Notre Dame.
a spot of Middle Ages. It is one of the very few spots where you can still see the medieval past of Paris, unexpected right in the middle of the busy city centre. Nice and well preserved

Breath taking. Truly amazing once you get inside it, but the ticket/waiting system is just barking and there seems to be more staff wandering around doing nothing/reading a book than actually working!

Colourful Glass. To avoid the long queues in front of the famous Notre Dame, head towards this important church which is just around the corner. The queue is shorter here but the view of the chapel glass is much clearer. And be sure to visit it on a nice sunny day when the sunlight flows through the coloured glass to throw a nice 'stain' on the floor. Take loads of photos with your camera.

Never before have I see such an amazing chapel. The building is still being renovated, but we went particularly to the glass, and what a wonderful experience that is. There is so much of it, and it has been so well cleaned and repaired that it takes your breath away.A real pain to queue up and get in with the high security in Paris at the moment, it was worth it.

Stunning Stained Glass. We visited in September 2014 and the lines to get in were very long. Due to renovations the Palais de Justice complex was closed, but the beauty of the 13th Century Architecture of the chapel was still worth while. There is a small narrow staircase to climb to reach the upper chapel where there is an amazing display of 13th Century Stained Glass, which depicts scenes from the old testament, the oldest and probably most beautiful in Paris. Sainte Chapelle is a short walk from Notre Dame and a visit to both is well worth while.
Magnificent. Visit for the stained glass- so beautiful it will take your breath away. Steep climb up a narrow staircase, so be prepared, but well worth the effort.

Breathtaking. I was walking by with a friend and when I saw it was free for under 25 y.o. we decided to give it a try. I had already heard about it, saying it was really beautiful! When we came into the lower chapel, it wasn't that impressive. We headed then towards the Upper Chapel and we got struck by it's beauty! The whole thing is covered in stained glass and since it was a sunny day the whole place was colorful. I really recommend it. Plus you can buy a combo ticket with the Conciergerie (right next to it).

Beautiful stained glass. Go on a sunny day.. Not much of a line to get thru security. It's in the same building as the Courts. Narrow spiral staircase to get up to see the stained glass. Try to go when it's sunny. There's a huge difference. Sun went behind the clouds during our visit. Laminated placards in 7 languages describing the panels and some of the history. Amazing how quickly, 6 years, this was built. Contrast to Notre Dame which took about 200 years! Highly recommended.

Inside a Jewel.... I still remember the overwhelming effect of entering La Sainte Chapelle for the first time. I was lucky enough to do so on a sunny day, and the effect was magical: it was like walking into the heart of a jewel, with shards of coloured sunlight everywhere. The Chapel was built to house the relics of the Crown of Thorns, and was duly made as magnificent as it could be. The tall windows, full of glorious stained glass and separated by the slenderest of pillars make this a remarkable place. One of the places I always re-visit in Paris, if I get the chance.

Better than Notre-Dame. This is the place to check-out - less busy, great architectural and stained glass features. I think it is becoming more touristy, but that is all of Paris, too. Definitely check it out if your first visit.

The highlight of our Paris trip.. We so happy we made the time to visit Sainte-Chapelle. The place is simply stunning!We do wish we had paid for the headphones and audio to get a better understanding of the history.If I could visit one place in Paris, this is it.

Absolutely Beautful. I used my Paris Museusm pass to see this site. Note to those with the pass it doesn't put you in a fast pass line. There is one line through security. The weekday afternoon I went the line was about 30 feet long. It took me about 15 minutes to get in.There are two levels to this 13th century Gothic church. It was built to house relics of Christ brought here by King Louis IX. The first level is quite lovely and has a little souvenir shop but it is nothing compared to the sight on the second floor. The chapel is under reconstruction so you can't see the rose window but don't let this stop you. The remaining windows are awe inspiring and are all tales from the Bible. The way the light bathes the interior is lovely. On either side of the chapel there are monitors. One is a video and one is a touchscreen that allows you to navigate around the site where Sainte Chappelle sits. It is close to Notre Dame and also the Conciergerie.
