It is worth a few minutes of your time to check these both out.The stairs are steep and spiral up. I did not notice if there was handicap access.

Divine Encounters. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see for anyone who loves Jesus. The stain glass is breathtaking with the entire biblical story represented. The place where the supposed Crown of Thorns was kept is such a sacred place. Even if you are not interested in spiritual matters, it is exquisite.

Granduer of leadlight on a magnificant scale. Visited through what was a long que ( for a winters week day).the scale of the detaied leadligh was a marvel to behold.forgoing the religious nature of the cathedral which is very important to many the detail and scale of the panel was breathtaking.
Amazing hidden historical treasure in Paris. Short walk from Notre Dame. A portion of the exhibit is currently under renovation but the detail of the stain glass is not to be missed.

Great stained glass windows. A must see in Paris. Just around the corner from Notre Dame, it's smaller, but much more impressive. The upper level interior is completely surrounded by its stained glass windows. Visually very effective. Unfortunately when we visited, the rose window was covered in scaffolding due to restoration works.

A little disappointed, Rose window under repair. Finally visited after it being on our itinerary for several Paris trips. Takes a while to get in and inside it felt much smaller than I'd expected. But your visit will be over in just 20 mins and I didn't see how €8.50 can be justified relative to only slightly greater charges for Orsay, Louvre etc.

Must see when in Paris. This jewel box chapel is something that you have to see to appreciate. Pictures really don't do it justice. I would suggest to go early and be the first in the chapel as it does get very crowded. We were second in line and practically had maybe 10 other people in the chapel with us. Take the time to see this..it's worth it!
Unbelieveable Stained Glass. The reason to visit is for the Medieval stained glass. Take a pair of binoculars so you can see close up the magnificent art.

Stained glass heaven. If you are interested in stained glass this place is amazing, it's really like no other church you will visit and is my must see in Paris. The queue is almost always along the street but you can see the whole queue from outside, once you are though that line it is straight through security and in via the ticket point. I've been each of my last three visits to Paris and will go again. It's just a lovely place to sit and absorb the beauty of the building.

Long queue, and Rose window being renovated. There are plenty of better ways to spend time on a short break to Paris. The queuing process was long. Security was more strict than most, and my small blunt pocket penknife (OK for flights/Eurostar) was not allowed! After lining up for over 30 minutes and paying we found out that the Rose window was being renovated. Although the other windows were stunning, the consensus was that it wasn't worth the wait.

Stunning. I was lucky enough to attend one of the Christmas Concerts inside the Chapel and what an amazing experience that was. Granted, the chapel itself it better seen during the day, when the sun shine through the beautiful colored glass, but it's also lovely at night, with classical music being played. It's quite small and not like most churches, but it's the kind of place that takes your breath away as soon as you walk in.

Wonderful Concerts. Vivaldi concerts are performed regularly in Sainte-Chapelle. They provide a wonderful opportunity to slip back in time, enjoy the music, stare at the stained-glass at length and absorb the atmosphere.

Beautiful gothic church. Again, the museum pass doesn't give priority to enter this attraction but the wait was worth it. The main chapel is stunning and the history really interesting. A very pleasant way to spend half an hour.

Classical concerts are worth doing here. Pondering what to do here one evening in Paris, I decided to book a concert here. After all it is difficult to be a tourist when you are working 8 to 7 when in Paris.This was well worth it, not only were the acoustics very good, but you could have abit of a wander around. Go prepared in winter and wrap up warm.The stained glass is amazing. If you happen to think about buying a CD after the concert then do buy one, they are difficult to get hold over when you get home.

Free entry on first Sundays. Entry to Sainte-Chapelle and the Conciergerie next door are both free if you visit on the first Sunday of the month. Get here as early as you can, you will still have to queue for about 40 minutes due to the security. Sharp objects will be confiscated and you have to put all your metal objects including belts in airport style trays.Once through this blockage you are in the grounds and find the main entrance at the back of a courtyard, you will get handed a free ticket as you enter.There are just two rooms, the lower chapel provides a taste of what is to come. The low vaulted ceiling hangs over columns decorated in a riot of red, gold and blue. A spiral staircase leads you to the upper chapel and the spectacular array of stained glass. Each vertical panel represents a book of the bible. Laminates help describe what to look for, it is difficult to see things higher up. If stained glass is your thing it would be worth bringing binoculars or using the zoom on your camera.

Worth the Line!. This is a very special stop. The stained glass is truly amazing. It is impossible to describe - you have to see if for yourself. Our wait was almost 1 hour. I hate lines, but this one was worth the wait!

Amazing.. I love cathedrals with their stained glass. I like to think back to when they were built and try to understand how they were first received before modern technologies made building this kind of thing "easy". We went on a over cast slightly rainy day which helped the line. Usually it was around the block but on this day it was short so we jumped on the opportunity. The light filtered in through the glass and onto the floor and the people. On a bright day I imagine it is even more amazing. Half of the place was covered for restoration but it was still amazing being able to finally see all those beautiful windows.

Stained glass beauty!. I had seen the pictures of the upper chamber of Sainte-Chapelle many times but still had to catch my breath when we first entered the upper chamber. The lower is beautiful in it's own, but as you ascend the spiral stairs to the upper chamber and step out to see the stained glass in all its beauty you will be rendered speechless. Yes they are doing some restoration work including the large rosette window which is covered, but do not miss coming here. Even though it was early and a cloudy morning the glass was still beautiful.

Beautiful - definitely worth seeing. This landmark has the most beautiful stained glass windows in the upper chapel that I have ever seen. Maybe it is just the effect of so many huge windows that basically form the walls of the nave. Stunning. I'm so glad I got to see this.The entry to this site is a little odd and frustrating due to security check. You have to line up just to the left of the gold gates to the Palais of Justis and only a few people are called in at a time to go through security. Be there early in day or the line gets really long. There are guided tours by various companies that might get you in faster.

Beautifully Crafted, but Disappointing. When one thinks of how this magnificent workmanship must have been first viewed it is amazing. We are spoiled by the developments that followed. The problem at Sainte-Chapelle is that the windows are so far away that you can barely make out the pictures. There is a similar problem at the Chartres Cathedral, but the solution is almost perfect. The glass museum at Chartres allows you to look at reproductions up close. You can see the workmanship and read the story in glass up close.We had to wait outside in the cold for over a half an hour to pass through security. Sadly, what we saw was not worth the half morning we spent there.

Superlative!. What can one say about this truly magnificent building, the entrance area alone is worth the visit and then you get to move up the spiral stairs to the most breath-taking place I've ever seen. This was on my husband's 'bucket list' which was why we were there during a two day deluge, but...the sun came out for half an hour whilst we were in the chapel and the stained glass was beyond belief. Put it on your bucket list too, you won't be disappointed. Lots of cafe-bars outside so you can sit and savour the experience afterwards with something to drink/celebrate/warm up/dry out depending upon when you travel.

Amazing Stained Glass. This church, that is across from Notre Dame is an amazing gem not to be missed. At this time its going through a major restoration but you can still see the fascinating stained glass windows, this church is known for. The church is divided into two levels. The lower level is very intimate and hold the statue of Saint Louie. The colors of the ceiling and walls are quite enchanting. The upper level is where the magic happens. The magnificent stained glass windows are towering and colorful. Each panel tells a different story found in the bible. But one is so amazed on how the light shines in and illuminates the room inside. Its breath taking. This gem is not to be missed. Yes Notre Dame is grand but here, in Sainte Chapelle, it was truly a place where the king can pray in all its glory.

Almost heaven. During this trip to Paris I went twice at Saint-Chapelle, the first time during the day, it´s the week-end of Patrimonie, and the visits were free. Saint-Chapelle is very very beautiful, and worth a visit, and I felt the same sensation of amazing and peace from the first time I visit this place many years ago. The second time during this trip I went to Saint-Chapelle was at nigth , to saw an apresentation of a quartet and a mezzo-soprano singing "Ave Maria", every music about this theme and was indiscretable the sound and ligths and the stained glasses, really is almost heaven.
Gorgeous. Just beautiful beyond words. It is a sight to behold. The time and craftsmanship that went into the glory of Gods word expressed in stained glass is unparalleled.

Medieval gem. This medieval Gothic chapel was not on a list of sights that we were supposed to see with our travel agency. It is quite small so the waiting lines are usually quite long. However if one comes early in the morning (as we did) he might get lucky (as we were) and see the interior of the chapel in relative peace and quiet. The place is unbelievable. Small, dark, but full of history.

Slight disappointment but still interesting. It was a beautiful building with expansive stain-glass windows that really looked stunning from the inside, the only real problem was again the queues, for a very tiny chapel had i of known wat was inside i would not have bothered, its worth a look if its quiet but dont drain your day waiting.They also close it for an hour in the day which just makes the situation worse as then you have to wait for it to reopen. But as a side note get a ticket for the conciergerie aswell as you can get a ticket for both in the same place, you might aswell as you wont have any more queuing to do.Overall a mixed bag, a great attraction but hampered by poor organisation of the queues at peak times which renders the experience slightly bitter.

Spectacular. The second floor of this chapel is amazingly beautiful, with some 85% of the walls being stained glass. On the day I visited, literally everyone entering the second floor said, "Wow." You should not miss it. The wait to get through security to get in can be long, however. Go on a weekday. (The chapel gift shop on the first floor is also quite good.)

Beware the entry system for amazing place. The entry system for this stunning place is awful. We got there at opening time and still had to queue in the street for half-an-hour. As the day goes on, the queues get longer. You then squeeze through a security check before buying a ticket which you then have to present to somebody else who sits a metre away. I can see it’s meant to self-regulate the number of people getting into the very tight space of the chapel but a booking system would be preferable. Having said all that it clearly is a 'must-see' and is breathtakingly beautiful.
beautiful inside - well worth the wait. make sure you get to the second floor, where all the stained glass windows are! it's easy to miss the stairway, and it isn't well marked.

Gorgeous windows. This place was so so so pretty. I took the most amazing pictures here. We used our Paris museum passes and by-passed the line so it was fabulous and worth the stop. We didn't stay long, just long enough to take in the amazing windows and snap photos.

Beautiful. Mixed feelings about this one. Firstly it is absolutely stunning, and therefore in many senses well worth a visit. The stained glass is incredible, and I think if you took an audio guide you would learn a lot about the meaning behind the each of the stained glass windows. I'm really glad that we went. But, we had a Paris Museum Card, which meant the costs were included, and if we hadn't it would have been almost 20 euro for the pair of us, and it doesn't take very long to look around so bear that in mind if you are travelling on a budget and need to plan your activities carefully.

Must go here- stained glass is awesome.. This is a must-see!!!! The stained glass windows are so amazing, and you could easily walk by and not see it. Go when the sun is shining bright so you can see the windows full beauty.This is one of my favorite churches of all time.

Sainte Chapelle: A little jewel. The French would say that La Sainte Chapelle is "un petit bijou (jewel)" It is truly a chapel, though very PLUSH. Much smaller than Notre Dame, but very much worth the trip.I went using earphones. Personal guides were also available. The visit takes about an hour. The stained glass is amazing and one of the claims to fame of this church (chapel) is that there is so much glass in comparison with stone to support the glass, so it was a challenge to build it Although I like audioguides, I felt that the commentary was often too long and it is hard to find the exact pane they are talking about in the elaborate windows, so give yourself permission to skip some of the commentary. Recommendation: Buy your ticket on Internet ahead of time (you can print it out) to avoid the line which can be fairly long. You can buy a double ticket to also include the Conciergerie which is on the same street (there is not usually a line for that, but your double ticket is cheaper than buying the tickets separately.)The other recommendation; Read a bit about the history of the Crown of Thorns before you go. They claim that the French king St Louis bought Jesus' crown of thorns and built this chapel to house it. I am a Christian but don't know what I think about "relics" in existence hundreds of years after the fact. Anyway, very interesting. So read about it beforehand and make your own decision. Thanks, St Louis, for building this amazing chapel.

Stunning. This is the most stunning church in Paris! It's not the biggest,but it has the most beautiful stained glass windows. You enter through a lower chapel and climb the narrow winding staircase and viola! It's a vision you will never forget! If I go to Paris a third time I will not leave until I visit San cheppelle!

Beautiful. A compact chapel over two levels, with beautifully crafted stained glass windows, telling a wonderful story. Spectacular colours in the bright sunlight. Some areas are overcrowded due to its popularity, especially the climb up/down the spiral staircase and on the upper floor. Choose a quiet time of day to visit. The chapel needs some restoration work, as funds are available i guess. Interesting souvenirs in the gift shop. You'll need 30 minutes to see it all.
Beautiful art work. Beautiful chapelle...specially the windows glass art work. The construction is another magnificent architectural design from top to bottom.

Stunning. Last time we visited the queues were tremendously long so we passed on by, but this time we decided not to let that put us off, and luckily they weren't too bad. The wait was well worth it, as when we got to the top of the stairs the sun was pouring in through the magnificent stained glass windows. Truly amazing. I would urge anyone to visit this beautiful building.

great chapel but not too much to see because of restoration work.. having lived in Paris and been to the Sainte Chapelle every time a new guest is in town, I was dismayed at the LONG lines to get in, because of security checks which of course are necessary, but only about 1/2 the chapel is visable, the rest shrouded for repairs. The inside was very dark as there were too many windows covered.
A precious jewel. Go on a sunny day to appreciate th splendor of walls of stained glass. Often long lines but really worth the wait. There is literally nothing like it anywhere
a churche not to miss. the most beautiful satin glass windows, in the world. A two level church, small and gorgeous, specially if the sun shine the day you are visiting

Construction interfered with the experience. This is a lovely jewel that I looked forward to revisiting. While the experience was still wonderful, there was construction going on and it was not quite the wonderful experience as previously. The queue is long, but if you visit the Concierge first (also great to visit and around the corner) you can avoid some waiting by purchasing a dual ticket.
One of the top five don't-miss attractions.. I lived in Paris for some 4 years altogether. St Chapelle was very high on the must-see list. Absolutely gorgeous interior takes you back centuries.
Exceptionally large que!. Once we got into the building it was very interesting and a feast for the eyes, with a story to explain each window however, I question if it was worth the 1.5hr wait.

Marvelous stained glass structure. For Bible lovers, you will be especially pleased since the stained glass walls on this towering edifice of about 20 Feet of stained glass windows depict in almost complete entirety the stories of the Bible. There is an info board given to those who wanna check out the important depictions. The church is beautiful and not too large compared to others. There is a long queue to the attractions, but the alter carvings and architecture of the altar are suberbly crafted, overlaid with a golden finish and lighting. Touches the heart.

Not to be missed on a sunny day, and.... this was beautiful with the sun shining in on a February day, not many people there, was able to linger. Wandered into the Conciergerie next door by accident first and was so glad I did. That is not to be missed and not widely advertised, worth a visit.
A Gem in the centre of Paris. The queue is long, but well worth waiting a long time to see this exceptional chapel. The glass is gorgeous. Take your binoculars, some of the best is a long way up.
go early..... we arrived about midday and the queue was huge. It opens at 8.30. Make it your first stop or about 4 pm when the last people are admitted

A must-do when in Paris - amazing sight. We were recommended to visit Sainte Chapelle by the tour guide of the walking tour we did (wego walking - excellent tour) and we were not disappointed. We went quite early in the morning (approx 9:30am) to avoid the super long queues that we'd seen the day before and only had to wait around 20-30 minutes before we got in. The stained glass windows are breathtaking - it's like being in a kaleidoscope. Highly recommend visiting Sainte Chapelle :)

Amazing Stained Glass. Been to Paris 3 times but never stopped to see this amazing place. At one time is was supposed to house the Crown of Thorns Jesus had on his head at the crucifixion. The first floor was OK but the second floor will make your jaw drop. The most amazing stained glass you will ever see. It surprised me to see that a lot of the surfaces and wall ornaments were dirty but it is only 850 years old so I guess a little dirt is to be expected. There was a bit of wait to get in and you have to pay to get in but if you are touring Notre Dame you have to check out Saint-Chapelle

Easy to appreciate. Sainte-Chapelle, in the 13th century, originally referred to the choir (priests and men) who resided in the building, rather than the building itself. By and by, it became both, and after the revolutions became the name of only the building. Still stunning, and not a wonder that it consistently needs restoration.
Even under renovation BEAUTIFUL!!. We were wowed by the beauty of the glass in the lower level. Totally amazed when we made it to the upper level; totally indescribable!

WAY too long of line and large area unviewable. My husband really wanted to see the stain-glassed windows, so we waited over an hour in line in the cold to get through security (they REALLY need a bigger space to handle the security). Once we were finally in the chapel, I was disappointed that the entire back of the chapel was completely covered for renovations. I feel like it was a big waste of time.
Maverlous pice of Restorartion. The restoration work is nearing completion and the place looks great.Once completed it will be a celebrated place by all visitors to Paris.
flashing cameras. our visit was totally ruined by the continual flashing of cameras which was totally pointless in a space of that size

Beautiful gem in Paris. I visited here with my friend and her dad during our trip and it was a great place. The wait is a bit long but it is well worth it. Definitely one of the nicest places to visit in the city.

Unnecessary line up tempts to give up the will to live.. That 2 hour snake of a line up makes you think there is a crush of a crowd to get into this place. No. It is all about a bottle neck of a closet sized security room that all have to pass through to have their things scanned. Easily remedied by opening up several lanes in ample space just right there, but he authorities can't quite figure it out. Once in you'll be glad you stayed the course.
Nice place. Sainte Chapelle is a very great place to visit while you are in Paris, very close to Notre Dame, make sure don't miss it
Don't miss it!. Saint chapel le has the most beautiful stained glass in Europe. It takes your breath away. Hands down, the most beautiful place I have ever been.

Absolutely lovely. My favorite part of this magnificent church is how the light beams in through the stained glass windows. It was a beautiful sight to see. Aside from the light there is not much else to view here. It is right around the corner from Notre Dame so consider both because Saint Chapelle will not take much time.

Cold but glorious. We booked tickets on line as we had seen the queues the day before. Walked straight in. Saw the very beautiful stained glass windows - except the Rose one as it is being restored. Not a huge place and far too cold to linger -2 degrees! Probably colder inside the church!

A piece of gorgeous history. Sainte-Chapelle is undergoing some serious renovations over the past 6 years and will end up looking absolutely gorgeous. This church has the most beautiful stained glass on the second floor of the building. It is one place not to miss!

Absolutely stunning! A must-see. We saw a concert here "a little night music", and i personally thought it was wonderful! The chapel itself has the most amazing stained-glass windows, spanning the full length of the building. When the sun shines through, and even in the evening the whole inside is illuminated. I preferred this chapel to notre dame and sacre-coeur even, it was a beautiful experience!
Go see a concert there. We were lucky enough to visit this beautiful cathedral to listen to a concert of Vivaldi's Seasons. It was very cold and beautiful

Worth the wait, even under restoration.. It's true that this old church has been under various restorations throughout the years. Unsurprising, given its age and the intricacy of its details. Still, it's hauntingly beautiful and I'd recommend going; it was the only thing we waited in line for in Paris.
nice stain windows. It's well worth waiting for 30 minute to visit this beautiful church. The Conciergerie (oldest palace) is next to this chapel and also worth a visit

not totally worth it.. Definitely go when the Rose window is finally restored. Otherwise its a long wait in the cold for a 20 min stay in a cosy chapel with some amazing stained glass. when I was young, I read and saw the glorious Rose window, and was expecting to be floored. I was utterly gutted when I lined up multiple times just to finally get in to see it boarded up. Go during sunny days of course to see the stained glass play under sunlight. Go before 4:30, they say they close at 5:00 but really they close at 4:20, security let me through at ~4:15, but the chapel folks told us they are closed and refused us entry.Avoid going during lunch, their lunch is 1.5 hrs long. not wheelchair accessible, museum pass covers it. don't miss the wall clock on the outside of the palace of justice next to it.
BREATHTAKING DECOR. This wonderful chapel is noted for its glorious stained glass windows; but the painting on the walls and columns is equally awe-inspiring.
What a marvel!. So much history and beauty-Sainte-Chapelle is finally almost through with renovations. The stained glass windows are breathtaking.
Cold wait but worth it. A very cold wait in queue and very cold inside the building but very beautiful. Make sure you don't get caught out in the queue when they close for lunch.
Stunning. just do it beautiful get a Musee Pass to by pass the crowd - the Concierge next door (Marie Antoinette's prison)
Great hidden gem. Located right across from Notre Dame this beautfiul church had very few visitors. The stain glass in Sainte-Chapelle was amazing (far better than Notre Dame). Well worth the stop.

Gorgeous!. I loved visiting the lower chapel and then climbing the spiral staircase to the Upper Chapel with the stained glass. Our guide suggested as we enter the upper chapel we keep our eyes on the floor until we were well within the room, then look up to the glory of the stained glass colors. What a wonderful suggestion as it was magnificent. Even with the restoration work there is a lot of the stained glass showing. It is just gorgeous. I also enjoyed the evening concert so much I went back a second time. The acoustics are amazing. As the violinist danced his way down the aisle and ducked behind the renovation scaffold it still sounded like he was up front. Really wonderful!Do be aware that the security line is for the law courts and other offices in the Justice building as well as for Sainte-Chapelle which is located inside the area. And yes, you have to go thru security for the concert as well.The bathrooms that open onto the courtyard where Sainte-Chapelle is located as well as the next courtyard are yucky. Go to the 2nd courtyard and up the grand steps to the government building and find the bathrooms in there.

Wondrous experience. There is quite a wait to get in. And sadly the rose window is Under renovation. But still toucan experience the full wondrous impact of the huge colorful windows. Other churches has same kind of windows, but these churches are much much larger than this tiny chapel.I really liked it...so gorgeous when compared with more austere notre dame.
Extraordinary. Beautiful chapel, extraordinary glass and a moment to think and reflect. Loved it. Buy the Paris Pass and its included. In fact Paris Pass is a must to see the entire city.

Will take your breath away!. To think they removed and buried the stained glass windows during the war.. amazing! The color and history of the church is just amazing. Surprised at how small it was, but oh so beautiful! Enjoy!
Beautiful but under construction. Stained glass is beautiful but marred by the repair work. Worth a look if you have the museum pass since included. Does not take much time at all.
Amazing views.. great area to visit......Montmartre ....lots of shops, restaurants, galleries etc. fantastic views of Paris.

Stunning Chapel in the Morning Light. Honestly, this is a jewel of Gothic architecture and some of the most beautiful strained-glass windows I have every seen. The museum pass will allow you to cut the line, but it's a small space so it gets crowded inside during the peak hours. My advice is to visit Notre-Dame in the morning when it opens, and make your next stop Sainte-Chapelle (5 minute walk).

Must see when in Paris despite the lines!. We found it hard to get in to see sainte chapelle because we arrived at 4pm knowing that the lasty entry was 430pm but we had the guards telling us we were too late. We waited anyway and were some of the last allowed in and I was so glad that we queued! It's a breathtaking site with lots of information though next time I would like to take a guided tour.

My favourite place in Paris. I love it here, I feel at peace when I am inside the walls of this chapel, the building is just stunning and when you go upstairs the view is breathtaking, last entry is 4:30 pm so try to go earlier when the sun is bright for a better view, security is a bit of a hassle but that's it. Close to the Notre damn cathedral so very central and easy to find.

Amazing hidden gem. A tour guide had recommended a trip inside the chapel, but when I walked in it took my breath away! Even with one side of the chapel having its glass restored, the stained glass was absolutely amazing! It was built over only three years and contains 15 massive panels depicting scenes from the New and Old Testaments. It was a real find! Do yourself a favour, and don't miss this place!
Visit to Sainte Chapelle. You have to pay to visit and i know they are doing renovations right now but it was expensive for what we got to see Go next door Notre Dame is amazing
Magnificent. The stained glass and history of the chapelle is breathtaking. You need to read about it before to get the most out of the visit

Not worth the wait. 8,50€ to see only the chapel (for the consiergerie there is another entrance), after 45 minutes queue with no shelter for rain/sun wind cold/heat. Also, as of January 2015, the rosette of the chapel was still covered and undergoing restoration.Seen better, I suggests you to invest your time in other more interesting and impressive things like the Louvre or sightseeing around the city.Not for accessible by wheelchair due to the spiral staircase.

Breathtaking!. We sought out Sainte-Chapelle based on reviews from trip adviser. I have to admit that when we first walked in to the lower cathedral - I was a little disappointed - I thought that was the whole church. It made the moment even better when we emerged from the staircase into the upper cathedral and my jaw just dropped! I would suggest that you don't look at any pictures of Sainte-Chapelle, just go and be amazed. Beautiful.
Breathtaking. It's only small and doesn't take long to walk round but it's breathtakingly beautiful, well worth a visit and the 30 minute wait to get in.

louis. Built by SAINT LOUIS the king of FRANCE who fought in crusade,it is a masterpiece,a work of art,two level building.It costed two years of FRANCE budget,on that time.Worth to go there,worth to buy books and souvenirs there.
Amazing. It is absolutely worth the wait, go on a sunny day, the stained glass is incredible, one of my favorite experiences in Paris!

Awesome!. We had to queue for about an hour to get into Sainte Chapelle but it is absolutely well worth the wait! This Royal Gothic Medieval Chapel is simply stunning! Much of the original 13th century glass and painted decoration is preserved and is a wonder to behold.The scale of the massive perpendicular windows is incredible and the colours beautiful. When we were there the number of people admitted was limited and so the atmosphere was very tranquil. The whole experience is absolutely stunning! This Chapel must be included if you are visiting Paris.
Awesome!. This place is amazing!Is necessary just 2 hours to visit this chapelle.The tour guide without reservation cost 15 EUR.

A magical and enchanted chapel!. Not far from the "Cathédrale Notre Dame de Paris", you'll find this most precious jewel of gothic architecture: "Sainte-Chapelle". Built between 1239 and 1248 by King Louis IX, it housed holy relics acquired and brought from Jerusalem. King Louis IX was later recognized as a saint by the Catholic Church: Saint Louis, King of France. Amazing legends of a magical and enchanted chapel, home of one of the most extensive and beautiful in-situ collections of 13th century stained glass windows of the whole world. In its interior, the contrast of colors and light will bring you moments of inner peace and self-communion. Organize yourself, check schedules and visit one of the most impressive monuments of Paris. Enjoy!

Less crowded, and the MOST beautiful stained glass windows. It is difficult to put describe the beauty of this church. If you have any flexibility during your visit to Paris, try to come here on a sunny day when the natural light is pouring through the amazing windows. The intricacy of the glass-work is indescribable. The arched ceilings and large ornate windows provide fantastic photo opportunities, and the church is not nearly as crowded as other top attractions in Paris. The history of the church is also quite impressive, but this attraction is one where you don't need to do any homework. Just walk in and be overwhelmed by the windows!

Unbelievable. Kind of a funky attraction being inside the Ministry. The hours are various (check before you go) and the line when we were there was considerable. Once the attraction reopened after lunch? the line moved quickly. It is well worth the "hassle" to see this chapel. There seems to be no walls, just beautiful, intricate stained glass.

the best stain glasses. This chapel is inside the ministry of judiciary building,near to cite metro station and at walking distance from Notre dam cathedral.It is a small chapel ,with two floors.but the WOH thing here is the big stain glass windows. it is simply superb.There are about 24 in number, depicting stories from the Bible.The beauty of the glasses are to be seen to be believed.there is also a video presentation about the history of the chapel and the difficult process of making such good quality stain glasses.really a must see in Paris.

Intricate and beautiful, but smaller than we thought. You can read up about the whole story of Sainte-Chapelle for a full explanation of this site. All I can add is that it is unique, but small. That being said, you might want to opera glasses or binoculars to see the detail of all of the glass panes. We were told that it should only be visited during a bright, sunny day, We visited during the winter, when sun is scarce and always lower in the sky. I think my picture will show it can be inspiring even in low light.

Intricate and beautiful, but smaller than we thought. You can read up about the whole story of Sainte-Chapelle for a full explanation of this site. All I can add is that it is unique, but small. That being said, you might want to opera glasses or binoculars to see the detail of all of the glass panes. We were told that it should only be visited during a bright, sunny day, We visited during the winter, when sun is scarce and always lower in the sky. I think my picture will show it can be inspiring even in low light.

Beautiful church. This smaller older chapel on the Ile de la Cite is stunning with its stained glass windows and vaulted ceilings. Don't miss it. In some ways, it is more inspiring than Notre Dame - probably because the light from the windows seems to surround visitors in a more intimate way.

Amazing windows..... this little chapel is situated right in the center of the Ile de la Cité in Paris, not far from Notre Dame. You have to take the entrance of the Palais de la Justice, but there is an extra entrance for the visitors of the chapel. Remember to leave your metal objects at home, as you have to pass a security control before entering. Either you only go for the Sainte Chapelle (8,50€) or you buy a combined ticket for the old chateau of La Concièrgerie (12,50€). If you want to do both, I strongly advise to buy the ticket at the second place to avoid the queue at Sainte Chapelle.... The chapel itself is a beautiful gothic style, 2 story building: At the bottom you have the ground walls, the souvenir shop and a possibility to rent an audio guide (4,50€). This will give you heaps more information than the free big boards you can take from a box upstairs, when visiting the second level. This level contains the famous coloured windows, which are stunning and a sight you should not miss when in Paris. Every window tells its own story and you can look at them for hours. I enjoy going whenever in Paris, but I always go early to avoid crowds. Really worth going and I also find it a fair value for your money. please note that there is still renovations ongoing. They were supposed to be finalized by the end of 2014, but there is noise, dust and scaffolding, and the first 2 windows are covered up. The signs do not tell you how long this will continue.

Nice old church.... The stained glass here is magnificent to say the least. Be sure to tour through the smaller chapel before you go up to the larger chapel. You will need about 1 hour here. After you take all of your photos, just take some time to view the windows.

Amazing and pre-dates Notre Dame. Sainte Chapelle is worth taking the time to explore. Personally I found it eclipsed my expectations and experience of Notre Dame Cathedral!To begin with, it dates back to medieval times. It is way more intimate, yet its granduer and exquisite architecture are way more impressive than Notre Dame itself.Efforts being made to conserve and restore this ancient gem in the heart of Paris, are also extensive, impressive and can be witnessed first hand during your visit. With so much going on to preserve the upstairs interior as well as all the incredible stained glass windows, the work was not intrusive, but highly informative in relation to dilemmas conservationists face to preserve the original integrity of the building and its contents.Highly recommended!

Hidden treasure. Words really can't describe how beautiful this church is. The most amazing stained glass I've ever seen. GET THERE EARLY! I can't stress this enough. There is always a line...a long one. The Paris Museum Card will get you in free, but the security is heavy due to the proximity of government offices so there is no skipping to the front. It is so worth the wait. One word of warning, there are tight spiral stair cases to the chapel.

Beautiful, but small. We went to Sainte-Chapelle on an overcast day, but still thoroughly enjoyed it. Before going in, you have to go through security, and must stand in a long line outside. Once through, you walk over to buy tickets in front another building, and proceed inside. The stained windows are upstairs, and they have information about the history on both floors. (I think there were English pamphlets on the first floor, but only TV's with subtitles on the second). Sainte-Chapelle is quite small, but you can easily spend an hour admiring the restored glass windows. Even though it was overcast, the windows were still very pretty, and I can only imagine how beautiful it would be on a sunny day. It can get pretty crowded, but people come and go pretty quickly. It's a short visit, but I would recommend stopping by.

Like being inside a jewel box. I remember seeing pictures of this chapel in my university art history classes, and I've wanted to visit ever since. Being inside this space is like being inside a jewel box. It's Gothic splendour at its most perfect. When we were there, the restorations weren't done, so a large section was still hidden behind scaffolding and canvas; even with that limitation and the crowds of people, I found it a magical space.

A Paris Gem!. Our first night in Paris was spent at Sainte-Chapelle enjoying a Classical Christmas Concert. It was a magical way to begin what was a spectacular visit to Paris. This beautiful church made the music come alive in a way that I've never experienced. While the church has that ancient beauty and is quite large it felt intimate. Due to the chilly temps Paris has in the winter we were greeted with lap blankets which were a lovely touch. Fortunate to have front row seats but would have been happy anywhere. Only wish our evening visit allowed us the joy of seeing the beautiful stained glass windows! Next visit.... For our family of four this amazing evening will be long remembered!

Great job with restoration. Very, very nice. They are still restoring upper level, but it is very nice and I think they are doing a great job. We order tickets before going and that makes wait for 20 minutes to enter, if we hadn't bought the tickets in advance we would wait for hours to enter.

Stained glass all throughout.. nice!. The stained glass on the main cathedral is just a sight to see. Excellent to view and it is not as touristy as Notre Dame. The main floor that you enter is just below the main cathedral and it shows some of the church history.

Needs to be a sunny day. It's almost impossible to appreciate the undoubted beauty of these stained glass windows unless the sun is shining brightly and the windows are almost the only part of Sainte Chapelle worth the very expensive entry cost. This cost, however, does include entry to the Conciergerie, next door and that is definitely worth a visit. However save you money if the sun isn't shining and visit Notre Dame or Sacre Coeur or anyone of the nearby museums.

An evening lecture...enriching!. My son and I waited in a very short line for Sainte-Chapelle at the end of the day.... and we were greeted by a special evening lecture that we were able to sit in on just by chance.... don't miss this site... it is a beautiful place of reverence and history. I think of it often... at least every week!

Another church with stained glass. We might be a bit jaded after seeing many sights, and churches, but quite frankly there was not much to this aside from the history value. We had the museum pass so we did't really worry about the euro 8.50 entrance fee but still had to queue for security. If you only have a week or a few days give it a miss.

Nice Visit. My Husband and I visited Sainte-Chapelle as a part of our trip to Paris in August 2014. We did a tour with Easy Pass Tours and they did an excellent job at feeding us as much information as possible. Before this tour we didn't even know a thing about Sainte-Chapelle, however now after visiting we are soo glad we did. Inside is beautiful and filled with stained glass windows however its odd when you first walk through the doors as it feels slightly dungeon-ey-ish. Then you get up the stairs and the sun glisens in through the stained glass and looks absolutely stunning. Worth a visit check out my photos and you will see what I mean.

Absolutely the most stunning thing to see in Paris. The outside of the chapel is unassuming, but the stained glass on the second floor is like walking into heaven. I think it is the best stained glass in perhaps all of Europe. The windows tell the story of the Bible from Genesis on in images of glass. I can't say enough good things about the stained glass in this building, go out of your way to see Sainte-Chapelle.

Amazing stained glass windows, don't miss!. The stained glass windows upstairs are amazing. You don't need to spend lots of time here... an hour should be plenty to look around with plenty of time for standing in amazement looking up with your mouth agape in wonder.Tip: Bring binoculars to view the stained glass. The top sections are very high up.

Half closed for renovations. I took my partner here in Dec 14 as I insisted that Sainte Chapelle had the best stained glasses in Paris. After waiting in line for 1hr 45min and paying €17 between us for entry, we found out the chapel was undergoing renovations. As a result, half of the already small chapel was closed! This included the rose window too. What a disappointment! There were no signs or any indications of the renovations at any point (in line or at ticket booth). We certainly would not have spent all that time waiting to get in had we known about this. This being said, I still maintain Sainte-Chapelle has the best stained glass windows in Paris. I was lucky enough to see the windows in their full glory in a previous visit a few years ago. Just make sure their renovations are completed when you visit!

Amazing Stained-Glass Windows!. The royal medieval Gothic chapel was built in 1246 by the Crusader King Louis IX to house relics of the True Cross including The Crown of Thorns from the emperor of Constantinople. The church is located in the courtyard of the Palace of Justice on the Ile de la Cite in the heart of Paris. The exterior is rather simple despite its decorations. The entrance is through the lower chapel which was originally used by the palace servants. The king and his entourage used the upper chapel. The interior walls are dominated by fifteen beautiful stained- glass windows(612m2). The 1134 scenes(I didn't count them) depict the story from the Garden of Eden through the Apocalypse.The windows are at its best when the sun shines and glow like Chartres blue- and wine-colored reds. This "jewel box" has been a national historic monument since 1862. Be sure to order your tickets on line to avoid the long lines.

Stained Glass extraordinaire. If the stained glass windows at Notre Dame strike you as outstanding, do not fail to visit Ste Chapelle. Also on Ile de Cite, in the ministry of justice building, this small chapel was built in 1250 for the king's use when he resided at the Conciergerie. The extradordinarily tall slim windows are spectacular. Concerts are give there were you may enjoy beautiful music in a beautiful setting.
A gem of a church. This church is stunning - the stained glass is specracular. Worth seeing more than Notre dame in my view.
Can't be described in words. One of the most beautiful, impressive, significant, and awe-inspiring buildings in the world. That's all.

Unexpected treat - amazing. Sainte-Chappelle was not planned but we met a friend who strongly suggested the tour. Amazing stained glass in this chapel that tell a story of Christianity. The chapel was used by the ruling families whenever they were not at the country palace. Located next to operating administrative offices so security is tight. There is a small entry fee but again the stained glass is incredible. Get there early to beat the lines.

NO KNIVES. The French Police controlls you the same way as on the airport when entering the church. All objects that the police considers as dangerous will be confiscated and NOT given back. Not even a Pocketknife or a lighter are allowed. Wonderful church btw

Just breathtaking!!!!. My favourite place to visit in all of Paris,never fails to literally take my breath away, the stain glass is just stunning and I have never seen anything like it. Always make an effort to go here when I'm in Paris, it's a MUST DO!

My favorite church in Paris. Just so unique! On the second floor, the walls are made almost entirely of stained glass! I stood by the little entrance door and I could hear the gasps of the visitors as they emerge from the stairs and suddenly saw! There is a line, of course, and a security point, but it is worth it!

Walking into a Timeless Gem. Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most beautiful spaces you will ever experience. Our previous trip to Paris was at the height of the tourist season and the long lines discouraged us from going in. When we returned for Christmas 2014, there were no lines and we walked right in. The interior is breathtaking - small, intimate and glowing with colored light from the stained glass. It felt more like being inside a Medieval sculpture, rather than in a building. If you encounter lines - WAIT. You will be rewarded for your time by the stunning experience - unequaled by another other building, old or modern. A Must See!

Great example of gothic architecture. I didn't like the line to get to the Sainte-Chappelle. I think we waited about an hour and a half. Tour groups seemed to be jumping the line. Also, you need to go through security much like going through security at an airport because the Sainte-Chappelle is located in the grounds of the Palais de Justice. The architecture was great, and the stained glass windows were among the best in France.

breathtaking. A must do if you like historical buildings full of energy. Its an awesome place since every piece irradiates magic. A walk inside these walls stained by centuries is mandatory! Warning: queue is very long. Is better going at first time in the morning, buying ticket beforehand, and even better if you go with a group. Groups need to book previously, so it arrives and gets in.
Amazing - as always. If you can camp on to one of the guides you will be amazed at what you learn. The french ones are the best - of course, you'll need to speak french to understand them.

Beautiful!!!. This cathedral is worth a visit because of the amazing stained glass. It actually has more stained glass than Notre Dame. Currently some of the windows are being restored but that didn't detract from our visit. It was simply beautiful. We also enjoyed trying to find stories from the Bible in the stained glass.

Great stained glass!. We were pleasantly suprised by our visit to Saint Chapelle; the stained glass windows are awe inspiring! You enter through the old fortress building on Ille St. Louis, now the police prefecture, which is a magnificent building in it's own right. There is a tour guide who describes the church and it's fascinating history. I highly recommend it as part of your Paris adventures!

Concert... I saw an amazing classical music concert here, just the other night. It was Vivaldi and it was very well done. A tip- there is no heat in this place! They did give blankets out, but still...be prepared for the cold. Still lovely 5 star. Just know that at night for a concert you will not enjoy as much of the stain glass (it's dark so the light does not illuminate so much), and it will be chilly. But prepare for unbelievable acoustics and a memorable visit.

Waste of time. Waited over an hour in the line. When we got inside - it was being renovated, so not everything was available to see. Stained glass of biblical depictions were good, but in my opinion the visit was a waste of time & money. Rather go next door to see Le Conciergie - was a better visit and value for money

A must see in Paris!. I've visited the Sainte-Chapelle many times and am always in awe. I love the downstairs with its painted fleur de lys on the deep blues and reds of that beautifully proportioned space, which to me speaks to the time in which it was built. Then, up winding and narrow stairs to the top floor - for royalty - with the Flamboyant Gothic stained glass windows. Magical! Do go …The Paris Museum Pass is useful if there's a line. Nice to travel in December when there are fewer tourists!

Must see but.... The windows are an impressive attempt to tell the story of the bible, but they seem to be overcrowded with art work, and they need to be "cleaned up". it is worth the climb up the stairs, but going through security checks takes a lot of time in line.Still, the wait is a nuisance, but it is worth the wait.

Amazing Gem,. Didn't think much of the place when I heard about it, having not read up on it, but boy was I wrong it quickly became my favourite church we insisted in pairs, so small yet intricate with a beautiful upstairs of stained glass and art adorned walls

Wish I'd had more time and less company. My son and I decided to snatch a glance at Ste.-Chappelle on our way to the Louvre one Sunday morning - and what good fortune that we did so. I was enchanted by the lower level, particularly for its architecture, its proportions, its intricate carvings, its arched ceiling,and was satisfied (though mystified because the windows weren't that impressive). Only then I learned that we hadn't even started! - the Chappelle itself was a floor above, 32 (actually 38) dark, narrow, winding steps to climb to - a thrilling sight. Tall, glorious windows stretching up from the small floor space into infinity almost: the light pouring in just taking our breath away. On a Sunday morning, when entrance is free, there were too many people crowding in to enable any one of us to make the most of the experience, but it is forged beauty if I have ever seen any. We both felt thrilled like we had not felt in the dark, sombre Notre Dame a couple of blocks away.

One of the most beautiful churches in Paris. Sainte Chapelle was built in the 1200s and has the most beautiful stained glass windows of all times. The windows depict the books of the bible. The chapel is small and there are excellent guides in all languages that explain all of the windows. The windows are being restored currently and will be completed in early 2015.

An amazing experience!. We were fortunate enough to see a Christmas concert.The music was outstanding & the venue was equally captivating.The most amazing stained glass windows and a real gothic genre to it. Nearest Metro is Cite and it is just a few minutes walk away. You can also take in Notre Dame very easily at the same time.The Sainte Chapelle offered us an amazing experience.A must see for any Parisienne visit!

Stunning place to visit.. Sainte Chapelle is breathtakingly beautiful. Very close to Notre Dame/ When you go int5o the ground floor - you wonder why youve queued and paid to get in. Very drab. But go up the spiral staitcase to the most stunning sight. Huge stained glass windows almost 360 degrees around you. The difference make your jaw drop. And do but the DVD they have on St C - it has an English commentary as well as French. Take it home and marvel once again at what you have seen. An absolute must.

Beautiful!. Though the entrance line is long, viewing the amazing stain glass is worth the wait. The glass on the lower level is lovely, but the intricate and colorful panels on the upper level are absolutely breath taking. While here, note the posted evening concert schedule. Attending a concert in the evening gives one another perspective of the interior of this church. Hearing "Ave Maria" song by a soloist, while accompanied by a quintet was spectacular.

Breath taking stain glass. Sainte-Chapelle was the first thing we visited and it was amazing. The stain glass has been going through a restoration process and it was beautiful. If you have an opportunity to go, go. It was one of my favorite things that we saw.

Most amazing stained glass. The line was long and the place wasn't that big and we got through it fairly quickly. The stained glass was truly amazing. Never seen anything like it. It was worth the wait.

Beautiful stained glass a must-see!. I think this was one of my favorite places in Paris. From the outside, it doesn't look like much and is surrounded by the Court of Justice so it's hard to get a good exterior view. The lower chapel is a bit dark, but has some very interesting arches in the altar area. You then head up a short set of stairs to the upper chapel. I was not prepared for the beauty of the 15 stained glass windows that stretch up to the ceiling and wrap around the chapel! It is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen and well worth the visit. The large Rose window was covered for restoration so I can only imagine what that adds to the chapel. This is a must see, is part of the Museum Pass and only around the corner from Notre Dame. Don't miss it!

If you are a history buff, go here!. Lines seem intimidating but it really doesn't take that long. Its pretty amazing to see 12th century art on the walls - at least to an American, where "old" is maybe 200 years! Beautiful, and don't miss going up to the 2nd floor.

Beautiful!. A great place to visit when you're on the island, we popped in on the way to Notre-Dame. The interior is absolutely beautiful, despite the construction that was going on when we visited.Take your ID if you are a citizen of the EU and are between 18-26, as entrance is free in that case.

Breathtaking!. Sainte-Chapelle was not on our list of "must sees" in Paris, but be sure to include it on yours. This is possibly the loveliest church in Paris with stained glass windows that soar to a star-covered vaulted roof. Be sure to walk the 30 or so steps to the upper chapel. As you emerge from the spiral staircase, the effect of light and color will take your breath away

Amazing stained glass. After 3 attempts in 3 trips to Paris, I was able to get in finally! There are always long queue outside and I thought that these are all going into Sainte- Chapelle, but it's not! The entrance is shared with people going into the Court of Justice and the queue is due to security checks. Tickets is sold outside at the back. The intricacies of the stained glass is unbelievable! Each panel represents a book of the bible. Glad I was finally able to see it.

The Gothic Quintessential Structure. Though somewhat lessened by the windows renovations, this jewel is still remarkable! Completed in 6 years to house Christian relics (that cost more than 3 times what this building cost), this building is a marvel. It should be on everyone's "Must See" list. And, its main relic, The Crown of Thorns, can been seen yet today the first Friday of every month in Notre Dame.

Great stained glasses. It´s amazing to just go in and look up to the fantastic stained glasses. The walls also tell bible stories and if you are familiar to the stories of the Bible, you will enjoy even more.
Breathtakingly beautiful.. That's what I did upon entry - gasped. The stained glass is breathtaking. The workmanship is incredible. Worth the visit.

Beautifully stunning piece of work.. The colours of the stained glass are amazing, both in the 'servants' area below, and that of the nobility above. For craftsmen to be able to create such beauty with limited materials so long ago is to be much admired.The staircases up and down to the 1st floor are very narrow; be warned.I went on a rainy Sunday in December and only waited about five minutes but I imagine that most of the rest of the year it is pretty busy. If you can, book tickets in advance and sail to the front of the queue.You used to go in via the Palace of Justice; entrance is now to the left of it, as the charming young French policeman will tell you. I think they keep them especially for tourists.

As close to heaven as Paris can offer!. La Sainte Chapelle is often quite a wait, and even if most people go see Notre-Dame without even knowing about La Sainte Chapelle.But it is well worth the wating time. Going to Notre-Dame without a short walk in front to La Sainte Chapelle is missing the most beautiful stained glass you may ever experience.There is so much stain glass there you will wonder how it even holds its roof!And imagine world war 1 and 2, how did it survive all this!Much recommended.Tip! The more light outside the better. Go on a sunny day mid day.Enjoy.

Nice Chapel. If you have time go to this Chapel. It was beautiful with much history. Download the Rick Steve's walking tour and let him give you an exciting history lesson!! Then sit and in the pew and reflect. Very spiritual and relaxing at the same time!!
Go in bright sunlight. This place is not to be missed. Magnificent stained glass panels surround you as the light comes in. You need binoculars to see all the way to the top. Just exquisite.

Beauty Chapel. The admission breaks for lunch at 1.00pm and resume at 2.3pom. So, you need to plan your time properly as the queue can get really long.The chapel is very small and is under refurbishment now. However, it is still one of the beautiful churches in Paris. Don't forget to climb the narrow stairs to the upper storey, the tinted glass windowns are magical.Admission at Euro 8.50per person and child is free.

If you love stained glass, this is the place!. The chapel is small. It is also very old and is being renovated. There are government court buildings on the same premises and you have to go through metal detection, so there can be slow long lines to get in. Make sure you get in the line for the Chapel only. The line is shorter and moves quicker than the Palace line. They both end up in the same place but we got in the wrong line because we didn't read the signs. The chapel is very Gothic and the windows are incredible. It is interesting to learn about the history of the chapel and the relics that were once on display there.
Beautiful Chapel. Beautiful, beautiful place to go, one of my favorite sacred monuments in Paris, really worth seeing.

Most Beautiful Stained Glass Anywhere. This was by far my favorite place to visit while in Paris. We visited the Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame, Arc Di Triomphe and all of the other famous attractions in Paris. While there was construction being done it did not take away from the majesty of the windows. The light just gleamed from the windows and is one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen.
Magical Place. We had the opportunity to go to a concert here. If ever you get that opportunity, do it! It was one of the best experiences of my life! Beautiful music in a beautiful setting!

Under construction . A beautiful chapel with so much history. It will be fantastic when they finish repairing the stained glass windows. There was no sun when we visited but can imagine how beautiful it would be with the sun shining through the windows. A bit pricey while construction is happening.

A mind-blowing experience. The art of stained glass is close to a thousand years old. Throughout its long history, it is best associated with religious (primarily Christian) art and was ideally suited for the windows of churches. The 13th-century Sainte-Chapelle dates back to a golden age of gothic architecture but also takes the art and craft of using stained glass for fill its many windows to an unprecedented level. Built by King Louis IX, primarily as a private chapel to house the relics associated with Jesus's passion, it has a jewel box-like quality with the most impressive treasures meant to be found on the inside. It's easy to use superlatives like stunning and breathtaking to describe the experience of seeing the stained glass windows but even these terms seem to be woefully inadequate. I can only describe the feeling of seeing the light show on entering the upper chapel (via the narrow winding stone staircase) as being similar to being smacked in the face and punched in the gut at the same time - morbid, I know but you'll understand it when you see it. There are a total of fifteen enormous windows that occupy the nave and apse but it's likely that not all will be totally visible due to restoration efforts. Each window contains almost seventy circular scenes on a background of coloured patterns. Look out also for a 15th-century rose window that dominates the western wall.Tickets are required for admission but it's possible to visit free of charge (at certain times of the year) or at a discount - look for the information on the ParisInfo website.
Stunning stained glass. While still undergoing repair work, Sainte-Chapelle has some of the most beautiful stained glass you will see anywhere in the world. Well worth a visit of contemplation.

Beautiful even during renovations. Oh my!!! Loved, loved, LOVED all the stained glass and the history in and around this structure. You can see the years of wear and can just imagine the many, MANY people who must have walked these floors - as you see them working on repairing all of the worn floor tiles and such. Be sure to find out history of this church before going in, or look for a guide who can give you some background on the church. You won't regret it!!!

Under construction. I'm only giving it four stars because it was under construction. Otherwise it is absolutely wonderful. Decent price and the queue was not too long. Best stained glass in Paris. Repairs might last for a couple more years but when I eventually return to Paris I'm sure they will done and I will surely visit again.

Top secret masterpiece. This is virtually a secret place, so often overlooked by visitors to Paris, simply because it's tucked away behind the grand Cathedral of Notre Dame.Being both European and a Catholic, I have seen literally dozens of historic places of worship in many countries. The stained glass windows here top the lot. They tell the story of the Bible, from Genesis onwards. Whether or not anyone chooses to believe that the true Crown of Thorns or part of the centurian's lance were ever found, kept and brought to France is entirely their own business, but that's why this church compound was built; to house the holy relics. It was commissioned and consecrated in the middle of the 13th century by King Louis IX, who was eventually recognised by the Catholic Church as Saint Louis - the only French king so honoured.There's so much more to tell than I can do here, so put it on your list of things to do, whether you are a practising Catholic or simply a lover of beauty and tradition. It's currently undergoing renovation, but it should be complete late in 2015, after several years of skilled work, but the consequent difficulties of access did not detract from our appreciation and enjoyment.

If you want stained glass, check this out.. It's not that big of a church, it's not that impressive on the outside, but Sainte Chapelle must have the most impressive stained glass I've ever seen. The windows are long, I mean from the top of the cathedral to the bottom. Hundreds of feet long. Very impressive. Go on a day with lots of sunlight. It's beautiful. There's not as much to see at Sainte Chapelle like at Notre Dame or Chartres, but the stained glass is the most impressive glass I've seen.

This is a must see. If you are looking for must see locations this is one of them. We thought we would spend just a short time here, but once you get started you have to spend a longer time to really appreciate the works of hundreds of years ago. Well worth looking into. Buy your ticket online before you go!!!!!

Stunning. We saw a concert here, (a little night music) and it was absolutely stunning. I had an incredible time, even though the chapel is smaller, it was by far my favourite of the whole Europe trip.

Breathtaking stained glass.. The story and beauty of Sainte-Chapelle are well worth a short visit. We were admitted free by using the Paris museum pass. The stained glass art design to depict the Old Testament through the New Testament. The chapel itself was built to house relics of Jesus Christ. We did not take a guided tour but used a self-guided tour to go through the chapel. They were in the process of renovating/restoring some of the stained-glass but the tour was still breathtaking. They recommended quick stop on your visit to Paris.

The best. The two best buildings in Europe are the pantheon in Rome and la ste chapelle in paris, not necessarily in that order. My opinion, nothing more.The ste chapelle is totally focused high gothic, with stone work that flies and stained glass to leave you breathless. I visit it every time I go to paris and I go to paris a lot.Decent little recitals there as well, Vivaldi etc. see it ASAP.

Never seen its equal.. It's small and very close to Notre Dame, and unbelievably beautiful. When I visited in Nov. 2014, they were doing some repairs so you couldn't see the windows in 360 degrees, but even so it was unbelievably beautiful. The light just surrounds you in all its color and beauty.
Unique in the world. If you can experience a concert there, in the afternoon, while the sun plays with the stained glasses brilliant colours, you will remember it

Stunning. Hard to describe just how beautiful this place really is, in my opinion its interior surpasses Notre Dame's. It's easily accessible from the Cite metro stop and the entrance is located to the left of the Palace of Justice, there is a small queue line out front so it's easier to spot.You pass through security before reaching admission and when you enter the room is smaller than what you'd expect. BUT! This isn't the main room. There is a small staircase going up to the next level that is easy to miss if you're rushing yourself. Upstairs is breathtakingly gorgeous and everything about it is just amazing, the ceiling, the windows, everything!Unfortunately, when I visited on 11/08/14 there was some renovation work going on and the rose window was blocked off. I'm not sure what the status is now, but don't let that one thing stop you from going!
Superb. This little church melted our hart, went there with my mother. It is absolutely amazing, incredible colors and light coming through the glass, it is stunning. Second floor is breath taking.

Windows without walls. That is the first impression. The colours of the stain glass windows, the proportions the atmosphere , all there is magic. unfortunately this monument is under restauration so you don't see much of its beauty right now. Many cllassical concerts are held inside these days. The acustics are great but don't forget the warm clothes for the show as it's frisky inside.

Glorious. Sainte-Chapelle is only a few hundred metres from Notre Dame cathedral, so it's easy to visit both sites on the same day. First of all, understand that I am totally non-religious. The idea of splendid architecture "lifting my soul into heaven" is a non-starter! On the other hand, splendid architecture of any sort does, indeed, lift my spirits when I consider what man can conceive and achieve. Best I tell you of a visit we made to Sainte-Chapelle with my mother (who was very religious!),..The entry is into the lower part of the building, a small medieval Gothic chapel which served as parish church for all the inhabitants of the palace, This lower chapel is dark with low vaulted ceilings and does not appear to offer much to the visitor, except for it's well preserved state (the whole building is 750 years old). However, upon ascending the short, spiral staircase, one arrives into the absolute breath-taking splendour of the royal Sainte-Chapelle. Had there not been a seat readily available, I suspect my mother would have simply collapsed because the experience quite literally took her breath away. In fact, she sat there, unmoving, for over 30 minutes without saying a word - just absorbing the surroundings.The upper royal chapel is a beautiful example of the 'rayonnant' phase of Gothic architecture... giving a strong vertical feel and yet achieving a sense of delicacy and weightlessness. The chapel is dominated by unbelievably tall stained glass windows with only minimal stonework between each, and every inch of that is, like the vault below, richly coloured and decorated. You wonder how it can stand up on its own!If you can catch it in late morning or early afternoon, you will get the best effect of the sunlight through these amazing windows. Well worth a visit and easily achieving five stars,

A hidden gem. This little church is older than the Notre Dame and sits very near in the grounds of the Conciergerie. You enter on the ground floor and cant help but be impressed by the fleur de lys painting but its when you go up the winding staircase to the upper level that the splendour hits you. TYhe Stained glass windows whcih are massive and are all round the building are amazing. They end up with a large rose window inthe middle. At the time of my visit there were a lot of renovations taking place but it didnt detract from the wow factor. The kids were also really impressed. Definately worth a visit and if you buy a combined ticket with the concierge and see where Marie Anotoinette spent her last days then the queues arent so long.
Beautiful. We went at the end of summer and it was very crowded but still a fantastic place to visit. Definitely recommend it.

Unbelievable stained glass viewing!. The was a beautiful and quick stop for taking photos of the beautiful stained glass! I have some of my best Paris trip photos yet in this location! It is small so it will only take a few moments so you can jump to the next item on the list! I would say this is a must do! We went late and there was no line at security or the front door. It was spectacular!

Good only because of the renovation work. This is a beautiful cathedral just steps from Notre Dame but you would never know it because of the draping over the building and the huge Apple iPhone 6 advertisement. Once inside it seems rather small and dark until you go to the second floor - then the room explodes in beautiful colored sunlight coming through the stained glass windows! Glad we went inside! We were thinking of skipping this cathedral.

Wonderful Gothic Edifice. Amazing stained glass windows on this incredible chapel built for King Louis IX.You can visit in a combined ticket with La Concierge whose entrance is a few feet away. However the best way to visit is by attending one of the concerts that they hold in the chapel. Tickets seem easy enough to get however bring a coat as they don't heat the chapel as it damages the frescoes.

One of the few things you must see in Paris. For me there are two magical places in Paris the Sainte Chapelle is one of them. Forget the Eiffel Tower, you know what it looks like. Visit the Sainte Chapelle and the Rodin Museum, and, if the weather is nice go to have lunch a guingette along the Marne river at Joinville. Chez Gégène is the perennial guingette. But beware, it is not for the food and more for the atmosphere

A gothic marvel. Located within the "Palais the justice" court, you'll have to go through all required police controls to access.If basement is "normal", the 1st fllor of the Sainte Chapelle is a pure marvel of gigantic stained glass windows with a real soothing atmosphere.Can be done single, in couple or family... really worth seeing.

A jewel awaits. After you pay 12 Euros and wallk in the front door, you might feel very disappointed that this is all your 12 euros is getting you. Albeit the area is still very unique.Fear not!! Climb some stairs and you will get to some of the largest and most beautiful stained glass windows in the world. I'm not so much a fan of stained glass windows but I find the upper chapel area beautiful. Do give this place a gander if you have the time.Takes but 30 mins if you need to rush but very pretty.

Beautiful Medieval Church. One of the few Medieval structures in Paris, it is beautiful. Yes there is restoration work going on, but most was still visible. It was covered by the Museum Pass. The windows are amazing. A memorable church.

And this was built in only 6 years?. This chapel is a not...to...be...missed stop on your Paris tour. It's tucked away near the Conciergerie on the Isle de la Cite, and often overlook by it big brother Notre Dame, but I promise you....you will be blown away by the drop-dead gorgeous stained glass, much of it original. If at all possible, try to visit on a sunny day. Absolutely stunning.

Downstairs not so impressive, then go upstairs, wow!. After you are inside, take the small winding steps next to the door to the chapel. The stained glass windows going all the way down it are spectacular.

Like walking into a kaleidoscope. I am always surprised when I ask people what they saw and loved in Paris that so many of them didn't even know about Ste.Chapelle. Built during the time Notre Dame was also under construction, Ste. Chapelle is much brighter and more beautiful than Notre Dame by far.

Magnificent & Inspiring. I had never really heard of this attraction but it is a gem of Paris that seems to be a little hidden. I could have stood there for hours "reading" the stained glass windows that told the stories of the New Testament.

The Bible in Stained Glass. This is a must visit while in Paris. Not as well known as some of the more famous sights, but is well worth your time. When the light hits the windows you have to be impressed. The tour wasgreat and the knowledge of the tour guide was extremely helpful. A fact that is impressive, is thatin at the beginning of WWII every piece of glass was removed and stored for safekeeping.

A kaleidoscope of colours. You enter Sainte-Chapelle into the lower chapel, which has an intricate ceiling and pillars. There is a gift shop selling better than average souvenirs. You then take a narrow spiral staircase to the upper chapel with its famous stained glass windows. There are amazing colours everywhere. At the moment there is restoration work going on, so you cannot see all of the windows. It's still well worth a visit though, especially as it's close to other attractions.

beautiful stain glass windows. This was recommended by one of the tour guides and it was definitely worth the visit. You could make a stop while visiting Notre dame as they are fairly close together. When the sun is shining in through the windows you will see something really special. Each of the pictures are supposed to represent a story in the bible and there are English information cards about the different stories. You have to see this yourself it is really spectacular and words are hard to describe the beauty and serenity of this place. Don't miss it!!

Beautiful Stain glass. Not so well known as some of the other attractions but find the time to go and look at these beautiful stain glass windows some of the best I have ever seen.Remember if you have chidren or are with EEC passorts all museums are free till age of 25 years..
Not your typical church. Near Notre Dame, but so very different!! Worth the time to see a unique and beautiful church. This had one of the best shops around some wonderful tapestries and great gifts.

I still dream of it.... I was there few years back... I had taken tickets for a concert with " les archets de Paris" Classical music of course...a total bliss.. an enchanting concert.. I bought the CD of the quatuor back then ... and every time I listen to it it takes me back to that wondrous gorgeous place... Through the music I can still see and picture all the details of the interior architecture and decorations that make that place so marvelous... Your eyes never rest... Your eyes are filled with beauty, a true true gem of a place... I was so sorry that concert was over. the entire experience was a total enchantment..one of my wishes is to visit it again t=in the same circumstances that I did back then....
BEAUTIFUL. A wonderful chapel with exquisite stained glass windows. I first came here in 1969 but the beauty of it still blows me away. not so much on the tourist trail but worth a visit

Waste of Time. We stood in line for over two hours, paid full admission price, and entered to only then find out the chapel was being remodeled. The entire place was disassembled, the alter, pews, etc., were replaced with flood lights, ladders, and saw horses. It was a construction site with only the lovely stained glass windows to see.I am glad it is getting a face-lift BUT it is terrible to pay full-price to see nothing!That was a waste of my time and Euros.
