There should be advanced warnings AND a reduced admission during construction.In addition, it is a very small space. Ground floor has a few exhibits, all of which can be seen in 10 minutes. The narrow spiral staircase to the actual chapel has very steep steps. 2 people in our group of 4 were unable to climb them. The chapel is also very small.Even after restoration, I doubt that this place merits a visit. The most unusual feature is the architecture of the ground floor ceilings and it's bright colors.

Little gem!. Our first visit to this chapel and it was delightful. Restoration work is happening at the moment so some of the windows are obscured by scaffold etc, but the stained glass windows are beautiful. EU under 25's are free.

Lovely windows and intimate chapel. I visited Sainte-Chapelle as an after thought on a day of sight seeing in Paris. There was a bit a of line but that is to be expected. You enter on the ground level and then have to climb a fairly steep set of spiral stairs to the Chapel. They offer concerts throughout the year. I have to admit I missed a concert I booked and wasn't too terribly disappointed until I visited! The Chapel is absolutely lovely and the stained glass work is out of this world. I would recommended looking in to an intimate concert as I imagine it would be spectacular. Will visit again when I am in Paris next.
Absolutely Stunning. This is a must visit while in Paris. The stained glass and architecture is out of this world. I could have sat there for hours taking it all in.
nice: Stained Glass artistry. I loved the intricacy of the glass designs. what I didn't like was the long queues waiting to enter. so buy a Paris Pass (for fast Track) or go visit early by 9am.

Worth taking the time to view. A stained glass masterpiece you should put high on your must see list - particularly on a sunny day. Found the English story boards which explain the window story most helpful.

WAY better than Notre Dame!. Okay, you have to check the box of seeing Notre Dame but DO NOT MISS seeing Sainte-Chapelle. See if you can do it on a sunny day (it makes the impact of the stained glass even more impressive and moving). And the Paris Museum Pass gets you in quickly. It is a must see from my persective.
string quintet with harpsichord!. amazing venue for an amazing group of musicians. one of the highlights of our trip. if you see a concert advertised at Sainte Chapelle - go!

One of a kind. Standing inside Saint Louis’ cathedral, built to house the crown of thorns and a piece of the true cross, is a mesmerizing experience, no matter how often you do it. Only the Chartres Cathedral has more stained-glass, but the upper level of the smaller Sainte-Chapelle is all-glass and seems more overwhelming. An awesome sight.

A Spiritual and Beautiful Chapel. Saints Chapelle was built to hold Christ's Crown of Thorns. The stained-glass windows tell different stories in the bible. The colors are vivid. This is a site not to be missed in Paris. Entry into the building is into a gift shop. Be sure and take the tiny, winding staircase to the second floor where you will stand in awe of this holy place.

Beautiful stained glass. We didn't have this church on our itinerary but were so glad we stopped and went inside! The stained glass windows are amazing. There is some restoration going on but plenty to see. There does appear to be a line to get in but it moves very quickly, it just takes a while to get through the security to get in. Worth a visit.
Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. We ended our visit to Paris by attending a concert in this chapel. We were mesmerised by the musicians and the beauty of the chapel. Dheer bliss.

What a rip off - restoration spoils he whole experience. This is a very small Chapel with major restoration work going on which spoils the entire visit. We forked out 17 Euro to spent 30 minutes looking at part of a chapel. Even when it is restored there isn't a lot to see for the fee and the wait - the website and reality are a long way apart.there are better attractions in Paris - we will not return
Not worth the visit. Sainte Chapelle was under restoration, there was thick dust everywhere we felt it was not worth the wait in line to see.

Number one spot on Paris, not to be missed. As one of the reviewers here stated "Words have no meaning"--as this site is one of the most glorious in Paris. I have been coming to Paris for many years, first when I was just 20, and now that I am 65 and Paris is still my favorite city I have seen many areas and have reviewed them all with top ratings. I didn't see this truly extraordinary cathedral until a few years ago. But as I think about all the lovely things to see in Paris, this is my number one spot. The light that streams through the stained glass windows defies description. You have to see it for yourself.

Exquisitely beautiful!. With the walls consisting of huge stained glass panels, St. Chapelle is stunning! One feels as if totally surrounded by stained glass. Be aware that some of the panels are in the process of being restored. Nevertheless, it is an exquisite Cathedral!

Art and Soul. We stumbled into touring this cathedral by accident, thinking we were lining up for Notre Dame, a very happy mistake. If you like blue, just look up at the ceiling. Then tear your eyes away to look at the stained glass. The magnificence hushes you. Words have no meaning. The beauty is truly mesmerizing.

Didn't know about the restorations and was disappointed. Sainte-Chapelle was built between 1242 and 1248 at the wishes of King Louis IX, who would later become Saint Louis. Today, the Conciergerie and Saint-Chapelle on Ile-de-la-Cité are the only visible remains of the oldest palace of the kings of France.When you enter, it will be through the lower chapel, which was where the palace staff worshipped while the king and his friends and family worshipped in the spectacular upper chapel directly above. The lower chapel itself is lovely and intimate but it is a pity that there is a small souvenir stand inside which somewhat ruins the atmosphere. They could have found someplace else to put this. The centerpiece here is a statue of Saint Louis. He was born in 1214 and was King of France as Louis IX from 1226 until his death in 1270. He was canonized in 1297.You’ll then take the spiral staircase to the upper chapel of Sainte-Chapelle, which is 33m long and 10.5m wide and normally has 15 huge stained glass windows and a large rose window from the 13th century that contain 1,113 scenes. Supposedly 70% of the stained glass windows in Sainte-Chapelle are original, which is amazing considering they were made between 1242-1248.I can only give "three star" rating right now because many of the stained glass windows in the upper chapel are covered, including the rose window, due to restorations and so you don’t get the full effects. I was quite disappointed but at least I live in Paris and can easily go again. If you are able, wait until restorations are completed to visit. Once it is complete it will certainly become a "five star" attraction again. They’ve been working on restorations since 2008 (on a staggering 10 million Euro budget) and it is supposed to be done in 2014 but here we are mid November already. I don’t know if they really will be finished by the end of the year. It would be worth it to try and check before visiting. Definitely try and go on a sunny day, you’ll see the stained glass so much clearer and it will be better for photographs. Please note that there are no toilet facilities! I went early on a weekday (French holiday, 11 November) and there were no lines and I walked right in, but I hear the wait is long during high season so take this into account.A good tip - buy a combined ticket with the Conciergerie right next door to save some money if you want to visit both.
Wow. Absolutely fantastic. I could sit and look at the gorgeous windows and rose window all day. The stories, the colours. Just magnificent. A 'must do'

Nice Evening Concerts. We enjoyed attending a concert in this venue. It lasted about 1 1/2 hours. There are two concerts each evening, one at 7PM and another at 9PM if I remember correctly. Selections are eclectic and include a large chorus accompanied by a string quartet.

Very Beautiful, But Overpriced. Not much to do here except look at the beautiful stained glass. It's great for about 20 minutes, but then you are ready to go. We did the combo ticket with Concierge, which is a good deal, but 8.5E just got the chapel is overpriced when you can go to Notre Dame and see similar beautiful stained glass for free.

Really Nice. If you are visiting paris your visit will not be complete if you dont visit this.Place is really really old but is very well maintained. its windows are major attractionsYou should visit it
Beautiful Stained Glass. Even if visiting churches isn't your "thing," it is worth a visit to Sainte-Chappelle--a small, but remarkable place--to see the absolutely stunning stained glass.

Renovations still going on. The scaffolds are still there which makes it difficult to appreciate the entire chapel. They have also removed the seats which made it helpful to sit and study the different views of the beautiful stained glass windows. Hopefully things will soon be back to normal.

Superf Flamigerous Gothic Church. Worth the line to visit this small gem of Gothic architecture. Unfortunately now is on restoration and cannot be appreciated truly with the magnificence it has, but the way in which the light goes through the stained glass windows is incredible.
Absolute visit. This small but amazing site has breath-taking stained glass depicting the Bible. It is not to be missed.

Beautiful & breath taking. A little difficult to find but worth the search and admission paid. When you go up the stairs to the upper level, the colors of the stained glass windows will take your breath away.
Several people suggested we go to this & are so glad we did not miss it.

Make sure you go on a sunny day.. It has been four years since I was last at Sainte-Chapelle and I still remember the awe I felt standing underneath the windows. It is one of the most incredible things I've seen. I think though it must lose its lustre on a dull day, which is a pity. I have been in many great churches all over the world, but this is the one that I want to go back to. If there is a line, it is definitely worth the wait. Just down the way from Notre Dame.
What a magical place. When you enter this church, you fely like heaven! My God! Those glasses and the air changes a littler...I was so impressed

Exquisite interior with celestial windows. The Paris Museum Pass covers admission to this exquisite chapel, so it's worth a visit together with Notre Dame. The ground floor / admissions area is rather tacky and the chapel is still being refurbished but the detailed and sparkling stained glass windows are sensational on a sunny day. The exterior is rather dominated by the law courts and administrative buildings.

The "Hit" of Our Visit. Friends told us of the Sunday night concerts at Sainte-Chapelle. We booked reservations a few weeks out, caught an early dinner and made the nice stroll to Ile de la Cite for the show. The space, which is potentially gorgeous at night, was heavily scaffolded for restoration while we were there. I imagine the effect, and enjoyment of the convert, will be even greater when this work is completed.We caught a Vivaldi performance - The Four Seasons. And while the setting and material may sound like the recipe for a very sedate and staid evening, the show was anything but. The personalities of the six violinists were all on display, and the energy and back-and-forth interaction the performers displayed made the concert extremely enjoyable. They clearly enjoyed playing so much you couldn't help but enjoy watching them.The Sunday night concert at Sainte-Chapelle ended up being one of the highlights of our trip. We highly recommend.

A jewel in the heart of Paris. It's like being inside a jewelry box because of the very extensive display of stained glass windows in all walls that extend high up a grand arched ceiling. Although small compared to the other cathedrals of Paris, the interior is decorated richly. When we visited, it was undergoing extensive renovations.

Nice chapel, beautiful windows. Sainte-Chapelle is included with the Paris Museum Pass, so we stopped there one day for a quick visit. There was a lot of construction going on (restoration of the inside and outside of the building), so we didn't get a lot of great photos, but we were able to see the windows and read about the history of this church. There was a fairly long line to get inside when we got there, so we waited for about 20 minutes before going through security. We first saw the lower chapel and then the upper. The whole visit was only about 30 minutes long, but it was a nice stop during our trip.If you're going there, watch for signs indicating where the entrance is. That was a little confusing when we first got there.

Not to be missed. This is now part of the Palais de Justice on the Ile de la Cité. The entrance fee is high, and it is very crowded. It is outstanding and not to be missed. You enter in the ground floor, but the beauty is above with the fantastic stained glass blue windows, which was the chapel of the Kings of France. This is I am afraid NOT TO BE MISSED.
Soaring stained glass windows. One of the first places I visited in Paris, well worth the queuing. Gorgeous paintwork on the walls and the stained glass windows upstairs are awe inspiring.
Breathtaking. So beautiful - the stained glass windows are mesmerizing and very moving. Small enough to make it feel intimate and not too over-crowded with tourists.

History Alive . Fantastic architectural wonder! One suggestion would be to buy the DVD about saint Louis if you don't know his history. It will really add to your appreciation of this magnificent's Chapel.
Not that interesting.. It's old but the inside is interesting; but I'd spend more time another attraction if your limited on time.

Simply amazing. Go on a sunny day. It will dazzle you! If you are handicap, you can skip the line and go straight to the main entrance and as for an escort over to an entrance just down the block where you can gain access to wheelchair ramps and elevators. It's well worth the trouble!
Attend a concert. We attended a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons here one Tuesday evening. Exquisite. how many more characters do I need?

Incredible stained glass. This is the second year we came back. Unfortunately even more of the stained glaa and entry way to chapel was covered. Next visit will have to wait until more restoration is done

Amazing place. Came here to see a classical musical recital that they put on over the year. It was a truly amazing experience. A perfect setting for an evening of baroque music. A wonderful, wonderful place.

Please include in your list!. A beautiful church to visit with the amazing stained glass windows. It's also close to other places that you must visit in Paris like Notre Dame, Ille Saint Louis, Ponts des Arts...so be sure to include it as part of your itinerary.

Little glowing gem!. Sainte-Chapelle had a small line for entrance when I arrived, mostly due to the security check before entering. Although the day was overcast, the windows glowed--breathtaking. Sat for a short while just absorbing the display of color and light.The chapel on the upper level is accessed by a narrow (one person at a time!) spiral stair but unless you can't manage stairs at all it isn't hard to reach and well worth it. A second staircase leads down so there is no traffic jam in the narrow staircase. The windows on the left side were under restoration at present but there were more than enough on display to enjoy. Well worth the bus trip and the bus stop is almost directly in front of the entrance. If you can, visit during a sunny day for the best viewing.

Make the time to visit this beautiful church.. Sainte -Chapelle was not on my list for our weekend. However ,while on our way walking to Notre Dame we decided to enter. I am very happy that we did. The church is absolutely beautiful and the stained glass windows are something to see. It was a great visit.
Stained glass wonder .. Beautiful beyond words .Even the "peasant " Chapel was beautiful . Not crowded at all so we could relax and gaze at the wonder of it all .

Beautiful chapelle, excellent concert. Our hotel package included a concert at Sainte-Chapelle. The chapelle is absolutely beautiful, but unfortunately, we were not able to see light shining through the stained glass windows as the concert was held in the evening.
Beauty!. No queues for us, only 8 euros the entrance, we visit on a sunny day and the atmosphere here is so relaxing, beautiful !

Colours talk. I found this church accidentally , it wasn't on my plan list but faith put me and my friend in front of it and we said yes , the beauty of church can not fit in words . This is a must too for visiting paris .

Amazing stained glass. Arrived just before opening to find a small queue which disappeared as soon as the ticket office opened. Excellent written interpretation of the windows in both the lower and upper chapels. All in all, an inspiring visit.

don't let the long line discourage you. it moves fast. most of the people are waiting to get into the courts, not to see the chapel. this has the some of the oldest and most beautiful stained glass windows. it's up the stairs once you get inside. they have special chairs that lean back so you can sit and look up and enjoy the windows without hurting your neck. definitely worth a visit

The Most Beautiful Chapel in France. The upper part of Sainte Chapelle is a visual jewel. A kaleidoscope of brilliantly coloured stained glass windows, each of which tells a story from the bible.Saint Louis, a highly religious French king built the chapel as a reliquary to house multiple religious relics that he collected at considerable expense. It is said that these relics cost him more to purchase than the cost of building the chapel!Try to visit in the morning when the sun floods the windows with light. The experience is unforgettable. Some restoration works are currently in progress, blocking a few of the windows. The exterior limestone of the chapel has been cleaned and looks terrific.Sainte Chapelle is an unmissable experience.

Sheer beauty. As said by previous reviewers, there are usually queues, but as also said, they move quite quickly and it is definitely worth the wait. Be sure to try to visit on a sunny day to see the 15 magnificent stained glass windows on the upper gallery in all their glory, filling the entire room with celestial blue light. I was totally in awe by the atmosphere here, it commands quietness and respect.As also mentioned downstairs is also magical in a very different way. On my first visit, I was not aware of the spectacle that awaited me upstairs, so I thoroughly appreciated the lower chamber, before my partner led me by the hand with my eyes closed up the narrow spiral staircase and told me to open them only once I was inside the room - breathtaking!
Amazing. You like Middle Ages, gothic art and stained-glasses ? You have to visit this place, hidden on l'ile de la Cité

a real disappointment. we were led to believe that this was one of the great unknown gems of paris. it is not. it was under construction but still fully priced and way over priced in my opinion. your time is much better spent elsewhere.
Gorgeous. Go in the morning when the crowds aren't as big. The stain glass window panels are just stunning... take it in!

Wonderful Stained Glass. Notre- Dame is the only cathedral in Paris, but there numerous churches within close proximity to the cathedral that are almost as impressive. Sainte-Chapelle is one. The stained glass windows are absolutely breathtaking. The churches with their stained glass; pipe organs and architecture are magnificent. Fortunately the French government subsidizes the larger churches for their historic and tourism value.

So worth seeing!. Saint-Chapelle is accessed via the Palais de Justice. Don't be put off by the queue as it moves fast enough.Saint-Chapelle is on 2 levels with the more celebrated floor being the top floor which was reserved for Royalty when the chapel was first built. The walls of the top level are mainly stained glass and it IS beautiful. However personally I prefer the ground floor with it's vivid colours of red, blue, etc The first time I saw it I couldn't believe how 'mad' the colouring was and that they were used centuries ago. I loved it...and you will too!

Eye-watering Beauty. When walking in to Sainte-Chapelle, there is an atmosphere of historic significance. This is wonderful, but, after walking up stairs, the most beautiful room reveals itself in all its glory. Do remember to look down a little as well, though, as the details on the floor also tell a story. Each magnificent window has endless detail and swims in beautiful light. WARNING: the toilets outside Sainte-Chapelle were repulsive. Wait until you get to a café (unless they have improved recently).

Visit if you have time. Sainte-Chapelle has an interesting history and beautiful stained glass windows. All of the windows tell biblical stories. I recommend getting an audio guide for explanation of the windows. It is worth mentioning they are doing renovations, so there were some things we were unable to see due to scaffolding.Lines to get in (we got there around 11am and waited for an hour to enter), try to purchase tickets in advance or go early in the day. Worth seeing if you have time.

Beautiful and a hidden gem. If you're a fan of stained glass this is a must see. It's only a fairly small church, but inside it is beautifully painted and the stained glass upstairs is breathtaking. Free for under 25s from an EU country. Confusing to get in as you go through security and then need to walk round to the actual entrance - the first time we went in we got cleared by security only to find that the actual church had church for visitors so we had to try another day!
Hidden Gem. It does very much resemble a gem. It's just a short walk from Notre Dame. Both are magnificent on a sunny day. Sainte-Chapelle is smaller, but it's still a marvel.

Most Incredible Walls of Stained Glass. It is hard to believe that a church was built for the king that has such impressive walls of stained glass. One of the most beautiful churches that we have ever seen.

Beautiful. It's a bit confusing to enter. You go through security and need to follow signs. When you enter, you are in a gift shop so you are more confused. Then you find a little stairway and you end up in the chapel. It's smaller than I expected but the glass is certainly extraordinary. It was sunny and everywhere you move the light changes the colors of the glass. It's truly remarkable and beautiful. Worth seeing.

Stunning Windows. This is a small church and when you finally get in to the church itself you are blown away by the ancientness of the room you have entered. Then up the stair way and if it's your first time there; well I guess you gape like everyone else. I can't wait for the restoration on the windows to be finished and I believe they will be even more stunning when you see them all.

Unique experience. You enter this chapel at the unimpressive lower level with the gift store. It does nothing to prepare you for the WOW of the upper level. It's like walking into a stained glass box. It was raining lightly while we were there but the light coming through the glass was amazing. I can't imagine how bright it is on a sunny day! There is a major restoration taking place which prevents viewing of the rose window and seven of the windows along the side. I guess we will just have to go back when it's done to get the full effect. (Don't be deceived by the length of the line on the street - that's just for security clearance. There's another line to get in, which you can skip if you have a Museum Pass.)

Beautiful place!. Amazing piece of art, it's a most to visit in Paris, the chapel is inside of a government building so you have to pass security first and the queue might be a little bit long in the summer but the chapel is so beautiful that totally worth the wait. The chapel is under restoration but you can appreciate the stained glass from the other walls.

One of my Favourite Places in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is a medieval, Gothic chapel, situated on the Île de la Citée. It was commissioned by Louis IX of France for his collection of relics of Christ. Built in the 13th century, the chapel has one of the largest stained glass collections in the world. Although part of this collection was under cover and being restored when we visited, there was still a massive amount for us to look at. The most glorious collection of stained glass I am sure I will ever see. Really takes your breath away.
Lead lights. Even though it is undoing restoration work, I think most of the stunning lead lights are visible. It was a sunny day and the colours were amazing. The queue to go in moved very quickly.
Stunning. Small, stunning chapel well worth the waiting line. Under restoration at the time and not all glass Windows visible, still a hidden gem at the Ile de la Cite!

The stained glass windows are a must see. Sainte Chapelle is magnificent, the stained glass is beyond gorgeous and hearing a concert in this place elevates the music. Be sure to go when it's still light outside so the windows are illuminated.

Hidden Gem. I absolutely loved this Church. The stained glass is amazing and we had late afternoon sunshine streaming through the windows.It’s on the Museum Pass route – so it will work out as good value if you get one of these in one of the smaller quieter museums.Definitely worth it.

Avoid until the restoration's finished!. I visited Sainte Chapelle for a concert 10 years ago and was blown away by its beauty. Back in Paris this weekend, I booked another concert and was really looking forward to it. How disappointing it was! The back of the interior is currently covered in scaffolding, and the great rose window and much of the other stained glass is invisible. The remaining walls seem to be covered in temporary wall hangings and the window sills are covered in a thick layer of grey dust, presumably from the building work. The biggest disappointment though was that the visible stained glass isn't lit from outside at night, so you get no sense at all of how spectacular it is in daylight. (Naively, I had assumed that the windows would have been floodlit at night when the chapel is in use.) In short, if you're thinking of visiting, check whether the renovation is still underway and go somewhere else if it is. If you MUST go to Sainte Chapelle at the moment, go in daylight unless you like sitting in dark building sites.

Favorite Surprise of Paris. The church is pretty close to Notre Dame and the river, so it is fairly convenient to get to. The lines aren't as long as at Notre Dame, so you could theoretically allot maybe 30-40 minutes to see the church.So the entry in the lower chapel is beautiful, dominated by wood and darkness. It is a quiet experience, leading to a visit to the upper chapel which is all about glass and light. There is a small row of chairs there- good luck getting a seat, though. However, I could easily see sitting there for 20 or 30 minutes just looking at all of the stained glass. I was lucky to go on a sunny day. I highly recommend this place for the beauty alone.

Very Pretty. The stained glass is beautiful. Having been to many churches through out Europe and many are amazing but the stained glass here is absolutely breathtaking. It was a quick and short visit and we went just before closing so the lines were minimal. If it's a short line and you have the museum pass it's worth it.

Great place to see a concert. Enough can't be said about this venue for a concert. it's intimate, and the acoustics are outstanding. I suggest buying your ticket online, especially if you want to be in the first three rows. From an of those seats, you're about 5 feet from the performers. I've been to many classical concerts in many metropolitan areas. This was one of, if not the, best.

Concert to avoid. We attended a concert in this church and were very disappointed. They played Pachelbel Canon, Albinoni Adagio and Vivaldi Four Seasons plus a short other peace in a total of 55 minutes ! To say they rushed through is an understatement. Also, the 1st violin was not very good. I have heard 20year olds much better. It's a tourist trap.
Intimate and Gorgeous!. One cannot forget a concert at Sainte-Chapelle! Small and marcelous! An ornament which gives peace. I want to visit again and again.

Do not miss!. Try to go here on a sunny day, as the experience is greatly improved. The upper floor is wall to wall, floor to ceiling stained glass windows and on a sunny day, it's glorious. The narrow staircase is fun for kids and the history of the place is fascinating. It doesn't take long to see the whole place, but is totally worth doing. The small gift shop has many treasures, including great tapestry pillow covers. It's close to Notre Dame. A little further down the street at the bird/vegetable market, there's a wonderful shop for Provence tablecloths, and another shop has a huge variety of Christmas ornaments along with wonderfully scented soaps.
Sublime music. The sound of Albinoni's Adagio and Pachelbel Canon soared to the top of the stained glass dome and was brilliant. I would rather not have had a singer as part of the program.

Exquisite Stained Glass Windows. We had read about this chapel prior to coming to Paris and were eager to see it ourselves. The stained glass windows are indeed breath-taking and absolute works of intricate art. They are perhaps seen to best advantage on bright sunny days in order to maximise the visual impact. The windows have been undergoing painful restorative work over the past few years and this should be totally completed by next year. The work of the master craftsman who constructed these windows really glorifies God and clearly depicts biblical scriptures in a wonderful pictorial form at a time when much of the population would have been illiterate to the written word.

Fabulous!. You enter what appears to be a modest chapel and you begin to wonder what all the fuss is about, and it's quite possible to miss the narrow staircase that leads to the magnificent Royal Chapel which features almost floor at once I long stained glass windows. They are in the midst of their first cleaning and restoration in their 800-year history but, if the sun is shining, it is magnificent! The last of the scaffolding should be gone by summer 2015.
Amazing and beautiful. Go later in the day for smaller lines. Amazing stained glass that is centuries old. Special evening concerts as a special addition.

Don't miss this. After many visits to Paris Notre Dame I thought we had 'done' all the churches until I read an article about the beautiful stain glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle! We stood in the queue for a patient 30 minutes, and I'm so pleased we were patient. Despite some restoration currently underway this is a must see. You enter the small church and it is interesting, and you think..... "so what's all the fuss about", then take the climb up a steep, winding staircase......... oh yes, here are the finest pannels of magnificent windows. Stand back and enjoy. Don't misss this lovely church!

Underwhelmed. We arrived a half hour prior to opening....we were first in and immediately went upstairs to the main part of the Chapelle....the stained glass is beautiful but some of it was covered and under repair and the rest was at a height that made really seeing the small designs very difficult to see.....back to the first floor and out.....we along with others were underwhelmed to what we thought would be a breathtaking experience

A hidden gem!. My sister told me to visit this church because it was one of the most charming ones that she's ever been to. And she was not mistaken! It has 15 amazing and huge color-stained windows depicting famous bible stories. And it's hidden inside the Justice Palace, so it would not be something that I would easily see if she hadn't mentioned it.

Magnifient vitraux. too bad half the church was under construction. As a church it is quite different from any other in Paris. This and Notre Dame are the most fancy/ rich-decorated churches. They are near each other too

Beautiful glass and architecture but over-priced in comparison to Notre Dame. The church has beautiful amazing stained glass and great architecture but we found it over-priced (8.5 euro) in comparison to Notre Dame which is free of charge, taking into consideration you will spend less than an hour inside. Its windows are lovelier than the Notre Dame though.

A gorgeous Gothic Jewel. This is a wonderful example of the Late Gothic period of architecture. The stain glass is overwhelming beautiful. If by chance there is a concert here while you are in Paris, you owe it to yourself to go. This is just a glorious space and is not to be missed.

Not what it was.. It's hard to get past how sad it is to see a decommissioned church (which is what this is) but the glorious stained glass made it possible to enjoy this as a secular visit back in the 80s - when I last came. Nowadays, half the windows couldn't even be seen because they are under restoration making the interior dingy. The admission charge remains just as high as if they could all be viewed. Shouldn't this be reduced by proportion.Queuing time for this attraction is horrendous. This isn't due to the high volume of visitors, as much as security arrangements that were completely inadequate for the (quite predictable) numbers. Converting the lower chapel into a shop is insensitive beyond belief. They might as well put a burger stand there while they are about it.

Takes Your Breath Away!. We visited Sainte-Chapelle while in Paris last month. We had already been to Notre Dame and admired the stained glass windows there but when we entered Sainte-Chapelle I literally gasped at the beauty of the windows. To see that much color and light was awe inspiring. I can’t imagine the architectural wonder it took to create this beautiful church. I highly recommend making this part of your Paris experience. The church is currently under renovation but that doesn’t take away from appreciating the magnificence.

Strictly for admirers of stained glass. If you are into religious stained glass, this is worth the pilgrimage. The windows here are larger and more extensive than in any other church or museum I've ever been to, creating unparalleled luminosity. It is just a single chapel, but the walls are almost all glass - more impressive than the Notre Dame's windows, which are high up and separated by large sections of Gothic stonework (leaving it rather dark inside).Queue management is poor, signage downright bad (no notice that it was closed between noon and 2). If you get a Paris Pass, you'll jump ahead of the regular queue, but annoy a lot of people in the process, since the signage is unclear.There is not much else. If you're not into stained glass, it's not worth the wait in line.

Never Ending Color. I loved, loved, loved Sainte-Chapelle. It is a tiny church close to the Notre Dame, but it is equally intriguing. The church was under renovation which took away some of the charm, but the reason for going was still preserved for all to enjoy. When you first go in, it is rather touristy with all the crowds and limited viewing of the incredible stained glass. Then we climbed the tiny staircase in a corner to the main chapel and were overwhelmed. The light shining through the almost total coverage of stained glass was beyond inspirational. Now, I know what heaven must look like. You were totally mesmerized by the panes of glass and it almost brought me to tears. This is an absolute must see, but get a Museum Pass, good for multiple museums and attractions or you will be disappointed in the long wait to get in. We went right to the front entrance and were waved in. The Museum Pass is definitely worth the investment on just saved time.
Lots of Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. The church was a very easy in and out. The Museum Pass works well. There are many beautiful panels of stained glass to take in and see their individual story.

Pretty, but not much to see.. Overpriced attraction. The stained-glass windows are beautiful and magnificent, but that's it, not worth the €8.50 entry fee. Go if you have a Musee Pass because you might as well, but not worth the single entry price.

Breath taking stained glass windows. St. Chapelle amazed me the first time that I saw it as a young girl. On succeeding visits to Paris, I have brought my children and husband to see it. The ground floor has a beautiful vaulted ceiling. One climbs a narrow spiral staircase to reach the chapel. The stained glass windows are truly works of art. They depict scenes from the bible. King Louis, who ordered the chapel built, had bought the Crown of Thorns of Christ. The relics of the Passion of Christ were kept in a structure within the chapel. The structure looks like a little chapel within the chapel.It is still undergoing restoration. Part of one wall was covered. Nevertheless, climbing the dark stairwell and then seeing the stained glass windows with sunlight streaming through them is a special sight.

Stunning. The church is in the middle of a restoration project which has been several years in the making. When you first walk in it’s a very pretty church but nothing spectacular. Then you go upstairs and WOW, it will take your breath away. This is definitely worth a quick stop if you’re in the area. We were in the area to visit La Conciergerie but it was closed due to the set up of a special exhibit so we went next door to Sainte-Chapelle instead. The line to get through security was very long but it moved quickly. The church is very small so you only need to set aside about 30 minutes for the visit (that includes waiting in the security line). We went during the last week of September it might be busier in the summer. Entry is included in the Paris Museum pass. No restrooms inside the church but there are some located just outside (within the judicial compound – Palais de Justice). The horrible stench when you walked by was an indicator of how bad the bathrooms were. My husband attempted to go into the male restroom but opted not to because the toilets were overflowing.

Unbelievable decor. The windows themselves are worth the trip, but It seems that no surface was left untouched. The fact that much of the original structural elements have remained intact is amazing. A must see.

Beautiful - stained glass to die for!. I missed this chapel on my visit to Paris last year but am extremely happy that I took the time to visit it this year. Oh to have been royalty getting to worship in the chapel.

Most beautiful church. Tiny but a spectacular church inside and out. The stained glass detail takes your breath away. Visit on a sunny day to see the majesty of the display. The outside is gothic with much detail. The queue was a bit long, but it is well worth it.

Stained Glass windows to die for.... Sainte Chapelle is definitely worth the trip. It also turns out to be a great place to start on your Museum Pass, since there is usually no line. While currently it is being refurbished you can still see most of the stained glass windows which are amazing for the time period.

Fantastic Stainglass.. This is the second time I have visited Sainted Chapelle. It has been in the midst of the five year restoration both visits. In spite of this, it is a very worthwhile visit. The windows are truly amazing, and the history of St. Louis is well worth understanding.

Beautiful stained glass windows. Not much to see on entry but climb a small flight of winding stairs to the main chapel to see breathtakingly beautiful and colourful stained glass windows. Unfortunatly parts of the windows are under renovation but on completion the chapel will be ever more spectacular. Would have liked to attend one of the concerts here but circumstances didn't permit.

Under restoration. This is a small but beautiful church that we visited as we got out of Notre Dame Cathedral. I was a bit disappointed as it was under restoration, but the interior of the church; the ceiling and the windows were still breathtaking.

Amazing Stained Glass. Sainte Chapelle was being renovated when we went so parts of the building were covered by scaffolding, though it was still very cool. The bottom level contains a museum of sorts as well as the lower part of the church while the upstairs section contains loads of immensely tall stained glass windows covered in different individual designs. It was really nice in the afternoon because the sun was shining through the windows and they lit up very nicely. It was cool to see the difference in the illuminated stained glass compared to the glass in shadow. There is also a souvenir shop as with most Parisian attractions which was a little expenisve but had souvenirs both relevant to Sainte Chapelle as well as Paris. It was also not too busy while we were there.

King/Saint Louis Chapel. This chapel was an unexpected delight. It was built by King Louis as his personal chapel. He bought a piece the true cross and crown of thorns and housed them here. The stained glass windows and utterly breathtaking. When we entered the room, the sun had just come out, and the chapel literally "lit up". It was magnificent...a must see if you like this type of museum.

An amazing experience. This is the one site in Paris which you should not miss! I have never seen anything so extraordinary. The vast expanse of glass held up by incredibly thin columns of stone seems to defy all logic. Built on the orders of Louis IX (St Louis) to hold his collection of relics acquired on crusade, it was damaged during tha French Revolution. The restoration however was carried out sympathetically as the number of prints and drawings allowed it to be exactly duplicated. About two thirds of the windows are original and recent tests have shown that the restored paintwork is actually not as bright as the original!

Under renovation. This church, entered quickly using museum passes, has lovely stained glass windows that are the reason to see it. The church was under renovation but we still could see the lovely windows. Saints Chapelle is an old Gothic church and worth a visit. The stories told in the stained glass are not so easy to read but they ARE remarkable.

No words can discribe it . It is simply amazing! The stories are read from left to right and from bottom to up. The spiritual feeling you get when you read them the connection and peace.You should go after visiting the noter dam cuz it's across the road from it. Take the left and read each window it will simply make you want to stay longer and breath the ancient times.

Beautiful. Beautiful structure, with the most beautiful stained glass windows. It is being renovated at the moment (that's life sometime) so we did not see it at its full glory but it was magnificent nonetheless.

Surprise Winner. Wow. I have seen stain glass windows and wondered what all the fuss was about with St. Chapelle. I was blown away when I went up to the second floor and saw huge, floor to ceiling spectacular stained glass windows. This is a quick visit, but well worth in IMHO.

it's about the windows and the acoustics. The stained glass windows in the upper sanctuary are spectacular. Each tells a Biblical story in vibrant colors which must be seen to be appreciated. Go on a sunny day. Also, concerts are performed many evenings. Vivaldi's Four Seasons is one of the favorites. To hear that piece in that setting will bring tears to your eyes.

Amazing stained glass windows. Get in line early. Although very small, the windows are worth it. Pick up a guide on a card (you have to return it later), and it will explain all the windows and what you are seeing. I went back for an evening concert (buy the tickets ahead on line) and totally enjoyed the music -- there just is not a better setting to hear the classics.

Stunning but No Rose Window. After six visits to Paris, we finally ventured to this little gem located on the Isle de la Cite. The downstairs chapel with statue of Saint Louis is beautiful, but it's up an almost overlooked spiral staircase that the real wonder awaits--a room of stained glass walls. Sadly, the Rose Window which some signs outside indicated was to be restored by 2013 is still hidden behind scaffolding and canvas. Perhaps one should wait to 2015 to see the completed project.

A hidden gem. I visited Paris on a 2 day trip and told my husband that this was a must see during our stay. I think it's underrated compared to the other attractions in Paris. We were blown away by the stained glass. It's unlike any other we have seen before. You could sit there for hours just looking at the windows and "reading" the stories they tell.

Beautiful. Go first thing in the morning when it open at 9.30 am and you won't experience long queues. I think 8.50€ is steep but I guess it goes toward restoration works. Though it is small and made even smaller with the works, it is still very beautiful.

Extraordinary windows. The stain glass windows some of the most beautiful in France....the lines aree very long so it is best to either go with a private guide who does not have to wait in line or purchase tickets on line. Visit the upper level to see the windows. It is located at the palace of justice which on can enter once throu the security check.
LOVELY TREASURE. it is tucked away and you need to work to find it, but it is a treausre and well worth the look. beautiful inside

The Chamber Orchestra Concerts on Monday Nights: No Lines, Good Music,. I had gone to the concert at St Chapelle years ago and it was dull: the few rows of chairs, an uninspired playing for a heard-too-often piece, but a great setting. What a surprise this time to see a full house, an enthusiastic audience - not knowledgeable, but they and everyone was having fun. The soloist was a ham... in the best way. He played to the crowd. The setting is still magical, and you get in with no lines. Why not?

My favorite place in Paris...Stunning. This was my 3rd time in Sainte-Chapelle. Unfortunately, it was under repair this time and although still glorious, I was sad. Do not miss going inside. It is quite breathtaking.

A must see in Paris. Even though this site was experiencing some rennovations, it was still a WOW place to see especially if you love stained glass. Just hard to imagine how something so beautiful could be so old and still so impressive. Don't skip this chapel when you're touring Paris.
Under renovation. This place is beautiful, but unfortunately it is currently under renovation and you only get to see about 1/2 of the glass. To see it in it's entirely would be breathtaking I think.

Simply beautiful. Before we left for Paris, two people independently told us to go here. They were right. You could 'do it all' in 10 minutes, but better just to sit or stand and glory in the beautiful craftsmanship of ages past. Even with about 1/4 of it currently under wraps for restoration (unfortunately including the large rose window) it is just a stunning sight, especially on a sunny day. Note that it's in the grounds of the Justice Ministry and you have to go through security, so leave any pocket knives or similar items in the hotel (as the man in front of us found out to his cost).

Exquisite. A really beautiful jewel box. The rich colours and amazing workmanship are stunning. There are very good guides available but you can get as much enjoyment from absorbing the place whilst there and reading up about it later. There will be crowds, but have patience, just wait and when it falls quiet the sense of place is wonderful.The Paris Museum pass does not give you privilege access, you must queue as you have to go through high security because the chapel is within the Ministry of Justice (for the same reason do not take anything that maybe considered a weapon, you have to surrender the item, we saw a family leave as they all had Swiss Army Knives which, obviously, they didn't want to give up)

Words cannot describe. I have been here once before years ago and still it is under restoration. Any effort is well worth it. This chapel was used to crown the Kings of France. The stained glass is the finest I have seen anywhere. Another Paris must visit.
Sainte-Chapelle. This is a wonderful chapel to visit. If you are able, make the effort to go the upper floor. That is where you will find the treasure of the facility.
Go early before everyone gets there. Very beautiful we took the first tour around 7am but it was worth it hardly any body there , when we got out at 11 there was a line half way around the building.

Irish or Gypsy jig, not Vivaldi, Chopin. An utter disappointment is how I can best describe this evenng's performance at the beautiful La Sainte Chapelle in the grounds of the Palace of Justice. We had previously attended a similar recital two years ago when the musicianship was of a high quality, the commitment to performance clearly outweighed any tendency to showmanship, and the players demonstrated an appreciation for the audience. Tonight (30 September) we had a first violin/concert master who belonged in a gypsy band or a Irish pub outfit; he bowed as if only ever second or third note really mattered, raced at breathtaking speed to get through the program (coffee going cold?), and played as if to a largely uneducated audience (Vivaldi after all is not the most complex classical composer is he). Fortunately the venue is superb and a joy to behold, again and again. Organisers be warned: if you put on a program of Vivaldi (The Four Seasons); Albinoni (Adagio) and Pachelbel (Canon), please ensure you have players who are committed to fijne musicianship, and not to playing up to the crowd. It was like a monkey leading the pack tonight, and they all sadly fell into his line. If the organisers ignore their audience, it will quickly dry up and go elsewhere.

Don't miss the concerts. Sainte Chapelle is beautiful in the late afternoon sun. The windows, floor to ceiling, look like sapphires. There are concerts several times a week. I have heard classical quartets, guitarist, and last time a violin and harp. The acoustics are unbelievable so you don't have to pay for a front row seat, the medium or even the least expensive section is fine. You can purchase tickets across the street at the restaurant or adjacent gift shop. Medium price was 30 euros and well worth it.
Beautiful Stained Glass. Went here as the line for Notre Dame was too long. Loved the sunlight coming through the stained glass, and how we were allowed to take photos.

Shiny Colors. Ooooohhhhh! AAAaaaahhhh! Colooooors! Shiiiiny!Most churches in Europe are free, but this one costs €8,50 and you don't need more than 30 minutes here. But luckily the Paris Museum Pass covers this, and also lets you cut to the front of the line.
Beautiful. One of the must sees in Paris this historic church is lovely and visiting at Sunday Mass was wonderful.

Incredible stained glass windows. Currently, the Chapel is undergoing a restoration and the "rose" window is being worked on. Nevertheless, the other windows are just as amazing. Worth the visit. To understand the painstaking work that was done to produce such beauty is mind boggling. You will not be dissapointed.

A Paris gem.. The church is under reconstruction and access is limited. There was a long queue to go through a security scanner and another queue to enter the chapel. What was available to see was beautiful but the entry fee seemed excessive.
Watch a sunset on the steps here!. Amazing, a must see when in Paris. Romantic, historical and so beautiful. One of the cities most amazing sites.

Wait for 2015. Often referred to as the most breath-taking church in Paris, our experience at Sainte-Chapelle was quite disappointing. Due to the current restoration project, half of the church windows are covered with a tarp, including the most famous window, the Rose Window. We paid the rather steep €8.50 entrance fee to see only half of the windows and leave disappointed. The restoration project is scheduled to be completed by 2015; I would not recommend that you go until then.

Beautiful cathedral!. We especially loved the beautiful stained glass in this cathedral. It was late morning, so there was plenty of light coming through them to intensify the colors. Photography is allowed, so we could capture them fairly well as a reminder of our visit,

Under restoration but so good to see. Did an English speaking tour and this made the visit so much more real. Beauty and the construction is amazing and only really appreciated when considering the height of the windows and the amazing way they are held up. Good to see restoration being done as this Lady certainly deserves to be treated with TLC
Nice. Small church but the stained glass window are wonderful. Currently restoration work is going on. Get the museum pass and dont have to wait in line.

Goose at every visit. Every time we visit Sainte-Chapelle is ends goose bumps up our spines. The lead light is awesome and the stories it tells fantastic. For anyone who enjoys historic churches or lead light, this is a must

Remarkable stained glass windows. The second story chapel of this relatively small church near Notre Dame contains fifteen spectacular stained glass windows that (mostly) date back to the thirteenth century. They are very certainly worth the hour or so you might want to spend at St. Chapelle.
Good,but overrated. The stained glass in this old church really is awe inspiring. However it is small, crowded, has a long line up, and has an expensive entrance fee.

So Beautiful! Wish the Renovations were done!. The stained glass windows are absolutely beautiful. Unfortunately about a third of them were covered as they are doing restorations on some of the panels. Still worth the visit!

Gorgeous chapel, but too crowded!. So crowded! We had to wait in line for security, then discovered that you can go through the Courthouse line in much less time. They come out at the same place. Once we got to the Church, it was wall to wall people. Beautiful church, but would love to see it with less commotion.

Concerts here at the Church are a MUST. Top quality musicians--very familiar classical selections in an outstanding setting. Be aware that significant restoration is going on at present through 2015. Delightful!

Time dated review. Its September 2014, Saint-Chapelle is undergoing a 10 million Euro restoration. its a two year project. Unfortunately you only get to see half the windows, and one of them, the huge rose window is covered. Because of this, it seems extra crowded as everyone walks around the huge scaffolds and fight for the best vantage point to see the remaining windows.Its still an amazing place but they should discount the price as you only get half the view.There are concerts playing at many of the big attractions in Paris such as Sainte Chapelle, Notre Dame etc. They are well worth the cost but book early and go early. We paid for the best seats 40E each, but they have no ushers so we ended up back in the middle of the crowd. We were at least 4 rows into the mid price tickets. Our performance was a string quartet and a very competent lady opera singer, the title was Ave Maria, many variations on this theme, it was fantastic. Oh and by the way you get to see all the same windows!!

More glorious than Notre Dame. This amazing small place is overwhelmingly beautiful. The magnificent 14th century stained glass windows soar ever upward and seem to be without support. The daylight through these windows bends to every color imaginable...this is a definite DON'T MISS IT.....get the museum pass in Paris...its worth the money and helps skip most of the lines

Make sure to check out all the artist in Montmartre. we took the funicular up to visit Sainte-Chapelle, afterwards we strolled thru the neighborhood behind it. Wow! All these artist set up to show case their artwork. This area is called "Montmartre" very cute area with shops! We would have missed it if we hadn't been told about this area. It's kinda of hidden around the back of Sainte-Chapelle.
Renovations in progress here. Several of the beautiful windows are covered because of renovation including the Rose window. Much smaller than I expected.

Awe inspiring. Bought a ticket next door to the concierge which was a little bit of a let down but it was a double ticket to this fantastic chapel next door which had a huge queue to buy tickets for so we waltzed straight in. The decor is so ancient and in your face it really takes your breath away it's beautiful and an absolute must in this city.

Small and Astonishingly Beautiful. We were lucky enough to go there twice, first just to see it and then for a chamber music concert the following night. The main attraction is the stained glass windows. Unfortunately, the most famous of the windows was hidden from view as it was being restored. But this work should be finished by next month, I believe.
Must visit, amazing gothic stained glass. 14th century stained glass chapel, go on a sunny morming. Beautiful. If you like Gothic buildings, do not miss this little gem.

You cannot go to Paris and miss this!!. We bought a four day museum pass so we should not have had to stand in line but turns out we did. For about an hour but it was really worth it. It was being restored but it is still magnificent. I would suggest that you do it like this Notre Dame in the morning and the Sainte-Chappelle in afternoon with a nice long lunch in between. We tried to work the Louvre in and it was just way too much. Do not miss this. I would also advise that you take the tour as you learn so much more!
Looking forward to the completed renovations. Didn't get to see the famous rose window as it is still under wraps.Next time will try to attend a concert here.

Better than average but not very good. It is located on the Seine on the island of lle de la Cite where you'll also find Notre Dame. If your visiting Notre Dame you have should make the effort to visit Sainte-Chapelle. Not quite the big crowds that you get at Notre Dame. You will have to go though security as it is located in the same complex as the central courts. It is very small but with more Stained glass than you see in any other cathedral , church or chapel. As a stand alone visit I'm not sure if it justifies the effort to visit , however based on the fact that you can also visit Notre Dame and lle Saint-Louis while your here I would say it is worthwhile.The chapel is under restoration as much of the Stained glass is very old. For the professional photographers amongst you bring a very wide angle lens and take a photo straight upwards inside on the upper floor ( I used 12mm on FF).

Utterly breathtaking. Kaleidoscopic church windows in one of Paris's few surviving Medieval buildings. Has to be seen to be believed. It blew me away with its beauty. Enormous, enormous stained glass windows that showered the place in pink, violet and purple light.

Disappointed. We didn't find Saint Chappelle to be all that spectacular.At the time of our visit there was a lot of restoration work going on. As a result, large areas of the church were blocked off, and of course the windows were covered.

Most beautiful Gothic chapel. When I first entered this 13th century Gothic chapel, I was a bit confused. I was certain I have misread the information regarding it...then I went up stairs...WOW! it is beautiful beyond words.

Stained Glass Exceptional!. Beautiful stained glass cathedral. If you have trouble with mobility, be aware there are steep circular stairs at one point winding through to the second floor. The cathedral was stunning, so much so that it took my breath away. Get a museum pass for two days, four days or six, depending on how long you stay in Paris.
Breathtaking stained glass. Stunning stained glass on the second floor make this a must-see for anyone in Paris. A short walk from Notre Dame, Sainte-Chapelle will take your breath away.

Amazing Vivaldi Concert!. My husband and I attended a Vivaldi concert at Sainte-Chapelle in early September. It was by far the highlight our our 2 week vacation. When the musicians started playing their beautiful instruments, we both got teary-eyed. To listen to such amazing talent while looking up at the magnificent stained glass windows is something I will never forget. The chapel is such an amazing work of art and should not be missed, even if you can't make it to a concert! But, if you have the opportunity to enjoy a concert at Sainte-Chapelle, you will not be disappointed.

Exquisite Tourist Destination. I have been here many time and always stand in awe at the beauty of the stained glass windows. Take the time to stand amongst the tourists and take in each panel of artwork. They are renovating at the moment but it doesn't detract from the panels that have been cleaned. A big hint: buy skip the line tickets and don't be scared to jump in front of the queue lined up for the security check. The security guards will try to tell you you need to join the back of the queue but you have skip the line tickets for a reason!

Wow. What a great Cathedral and the artisan village around it.
Views from the top are also picturesque. Get a guide to hear about this village.
under renovations. Still the most beautiful blue stained glass I have ever seen. Incredible history and architecture. I highly recommend a visit on your next trip

AMAZING!!! And the windows stream in the most amazing light. If you only have time for one cathedral go to Notre Dame. When you are at Notre Dame though take the time to visit this place, it is right around the corner and WOW, it is AMAZING! It was built to house THE crown of thorns. Read the history and you will be shocked to find out how old it is. I read that they just moved Jesus' crown of thorns back to this church. Yes, THAT crown of thorns. I don't care if it is real, it is history.
Magnificent !. The beauty of the stained glass will take your breath away. Stunning and very spiritual all at once !

The Sainte-Chapelle is a gem. Visiting the Sainte-Chapelle is a unique experience. The gothic architecture is particularly beautiful and the stained glass windows are some of the most colorful and artistic in existence. This was a royal chapel, so it is not too surprising. What I enjoy most is to go there for a concert. This is a wonderful way to hear great performances in a special setting. Highly recommended.

The most stunningly beautiful cathedral anywhere. The stained glass windows of this cathedral are spectacular. We went early in the morning when it was less busy, but it was still quite full. There is restoration going on this summer, so the exterior was covered and there was construction noise in the chapel. Of all the cathedrals we visited in France, this was by far my favorite.

it will be better when the scaffolding is down. we enjoyed the visit and the impressive windows upstairs even though there was a lot of the fenestration screened off. Not too many people thanks to some sensible control.

A must see. Exquisite small chapel which has extensive and beautiful stained glass.We went there to an evening rectal and the accoustics are excellent. These recitals are held regularly on Sunday evenings and go for 1 hour. They are very reasonably priced. You can book online.Don't miss it.

Spectacular evening concert!. My wife and I can't stop talking about Sainte-Chapelle. We had been once before so this time we decided to attend a Tuesday evening concert. I thought I was in Heaven. The violinists made their instruments absolutely sing! How can you outdo the combination of being in the most beautiful church you'll ever see while listening to the most beautiful music you'll ever hear? The performers sold cd's afterwards and even autographed them. I was delighted to purchase one and help support them. If you're in Paris in the Summer, this concert is a must-do.

Catch a concert at the Sainte Chapelle. By far the best way to visit the beautiful Sainte Chapelle is to watch a concert there. The tickets are not so pricy (40 euro full fare, with spare tickets close to the date reduced to half pricehttp://www.billetreduc.com/lieu/paris/la-sainte-chapelle/) and the musicians are amazing! At the strings quartet who I watched played Vivaldi's four seasons were.

AWEsome and AWEaspiring. I have no other words to describe this chapel. Even with renovations going on, we made it in late afternoon and pictures, Rick Steve's Paris do not do this site justice. You must see it in person. From the painted ceiling, to the almost 360 degree stained glass windows you will be moved. I am so grateful Paris takes such great care of their monuments for generations to enjoy and although not religious I can understand how those of faith would be moved having a chance to see Sainte-Chapelle. I have been to Notre Dame and it is amazing but this little Chapel is even more amazing when standing in side with the light coming through the stained glass.

My favorite paris sight. Sainte chapel le is truly the most beautiful church I've ever been in. Sadly it is still under renovation so it wasn't as spectacular as the first time I went, but I know it will be glorious when fully restored.
Spectacular stained glass. The amount of detail in the stained glass panels is incredible. I think it's better to go first thing in the morning. We had the Museum Pass and didn't have to wait at all!

Just a quick visit... Such a remarkable place close to the Notre-Dame cathedral, Its peculiarity is undoubtedly the amazing stained glass windows, that's the main attraction which is worth to come here. Maybe a quick visit is a must and totally necessary.

A gem of Gothic architecture with incredible stained glass. This chapel was built by Louis IX to house relics of Christ's passion. The church was consecrated in the mid 1200's. When we visited there was a lot of renovation underway and the rose window was covered. Admittedly it's hard to envision all of its grandeur but if you look closely at the windows and the rich colors painted on the ceiling and along the walls you can imagine what it will be like when the renovation is finished. The windows tell many stories of the Bible and a little advance planning will enable you to look for familiar stories as the panels are designed to do so. You have to go up and down a narrow circular staircase to see the famous windows. This would not be a good place for someone with mobility issues as the stairs are the only way up and down.

Great idea to attend a concert here!. This is not the destination for someone who is claustrophic. The stairs up to the stained glass masterpiece windows are tight and there is often a wait. That said, I still recommend visiting this lovely, relatively small cathedral. Its history is fascinating and if you're lucky enough to attend a concert here, I've heard it's the best way to enjoy the beauty of the structure, although I would make sure to see the windows with light coming through them. I'm not sure how this works, schedule-wise, because I did purchase tickets to see a concert here, then they were stolen when I picked up my friend from the airport. I only looked away from my bag for a second to fix my shoe/nylons (I had gotten all dressed up to look pretty for my visitor) but when I looked into my bag, my important items were gone including my passport. I know this is a sidetrack, but please learn from my mistake and don't let your guard down. I was living in France at the time and allowed for myself to get distracted, so it was my fault, but still, i was very disappointed. Nonetheless, I did visit Sainte-Chapelle a few times, and enjoyed it for different reasons each time. Do check to be sure there isn't a major renovation going on because it does affect how much you may enjoy your visit. Also, try to go when it's not too crowded. Listen to locals when they share tips of when to visit.

Stunning Stained Glass. Absolutely gorgeous church near Notre Dome. You can bypass line with the Paris Museum Pass. The windows of this church are magnificent. Don't miss this church. Is a fast and easy experience which will overwhelm you with joy.

Classical Music in a Classic setting. We attended a wonderful classical string concert in this beautiful church. It started at 7 pm and we got to enjoy not only the music but the fabulous stained glass windows while there was still daylight

Awe inspiring stained glass. Probably the most beautiful stained glass in one relatively small room than I have ever witnessed . Was EXTREMELY disappointed to discover several windows, including the rose window, was covered for restoration. I do think the admission charge is too high. Try to visit in late afternoon with sunlight streaming in. Long line! Was it worth it? For us, yes. For others, perhaps not. "In the eye of the beholder".

Must see Saint Chapelle. Awe inspiring cathedral. This is a must see. I found it more impressive than Nortre Dame, because it has a unity of architectural form and purpose--light that inspires and informs through the stained glass windows. We spent about 1 hour just basking in the light.

Small but worth it. A tiny private chapel for the king, important for its architecture allowing for an impressive and revolutionary amount of stained glass. Under some renovation when I saw it, so about half of one side and the rose window are behind scaffolding. To compensate, there are some interesting video presentations about the restoration.

Use your Museum Pass for this one. because there's not a lot to see. But it is worth the visit if you like beautiful stained glass windows. It is under construction right now which diminishes the effect somewhat. They are only working on small portions of the glass though and there is plenty to see. The place is a little hard to find because it's in the middle of another building. It sits in the courtyard area hidden from street view. It's near Notre Dame and worth your time to see.

medioeval treasure. If you do not care for ancient art you spend your money better in the La Huchette jazz club or with a beer at the Place de Contrescarpe. However, if you are fond of magnific stained glass windows you will not miss this somehow inside the Palace of Justice hidden monument. What a pity that quite an important part actually cannot be visited because of renovation works.

Disappointing. While the Sainte Chapelle is truly an amazing structure with all of the stained glass we visited during major restoration of the windows so a portion was covered including the rose window. Check before you visit if parts are closed off.

Fantastic, beautiful!. another must-see place in Paris; preferably visit the Sainte Chapelle watching a concert, because the 'astral' to hear wonderful music contemplating this wonderful stained glass chapel is an unforgettable experience!

not worth the entrance fee. The place is currently under renovation and it is REALLY tiny. I didn't believe it at first but after paying and visiting it myself, I would say I spent less than 5 minutes in there. The first level has all these small stuff that most people would just skip. Then up a narrow flight of stairs you will find the stain glass which is what everyone goes to see.However, half of it is covered up.Even without the renovation I would say the place is really tiny...Not recommended, unless you are really into the history of the building.

Beautiful but not much to see. The stained glass windows in this chapel were absolutely beautiful, although I was told it's even better when the sun is out. There really isn't much to see though, I think were were in there about 10 minutes after waiting in line for an hour to get in.

Fantastic - ignore the silly reviews and go!. One of the best things to do on the Ile-de-la-Cite. Better than the pickpocket filled over-rated Notre Dame This little gem is right in the centre of the Ile-de-la-Cite, The admission price isn't that expensive especially if you are young and from the EU. The stained glass is breath-taking and the floors are beautiful. Granted this is a very small place but that only adds to the beauty. It won't take too long to see and can easily be fitted in around a busy site seeing schedule.

Simply stunning. This medieval gothic chapel is undergoing restoration at the moment. It is a beautiful example of gothic architecture and amazing stained glass. We had a museum pass and were able to avoid the queue . One of our favourite places to visit in Paris.
Magnificent stained glass. I like this better than notre dame. This was the church for the royalty. 22000 square feet of stained glass. Attend a concert here when the sunset illuminates the space.

Magnificent Stained Glass. The stained glass in this church is stunning. You could spend hours just studying the intricacies of these beautiful works of art. Walk around this gorgeous structure as there is much to see. Some of the windows are being restored and were not visible at the time of our visit, but there is still plenty to look at.

Hidden Beauty. It is tucked away in the city and somewhat hard to find, but well worth finding! It is small, yet the stained glass windows are spectacular. You just want to stand and view it from all angles due to the way the light enters. Beautiful.

Beautiful!. Absolutely beautiful. The line moved fairly quickly and the inside was well worth the fee. While visiting, construction was going on in the upstairs portion, however, I'm unsure of how long it will continue.

Breathtaking. The chapel is nearly 800 years old, and an amazing relic. It takes you back to another time. Definitely attend a concert there as the acoustics and intimacy make it unique. My 10-year-old experienced Vivaldi's Four Seasons played live for the first time there. As the sun was setting, the light through the stained glass changed. Great concert and children are free (I paid 16 euros).
A jewel. The stained glass windows and the interior of the upper chapel are beautiful.It is nice to attend a concert there and you see the chapel at the same time

Under remodel, but worth the visit anyway.. Located at Ile de la Cite, a tine island in the middle of the Seine River connected through bridges. It is currently under remodel, but open and still worth the visit.

Most beautiful stained glass windows. The beauty of Sainte-Chapelle is not visible from the street. Once you enter the court yard, its a pleasant surprise. It was a disappoint that most of the area was under construction. We were unable to see parts of the chapel. However, the stained glass windows were gorgeous! Worth visiting the see those.

Beautiful stained glass. go to one of the concerts they have in the evenings. they are reasonable in price, only last about an hour and are outstanding! we sat in the first row and the accoustics were excellent
Very pretty. Under renovation, but still worth a visit. Try first thing when the morning light is streaming through the stained glass and before it gets too busy.
Stunning Church. The colors, the glass, the carving and sculpture. This is a beautiful church and one worth visiting.
Saint Chapelle. The stained windows were completely out of this world, the stories they tell, the beauty. My word, Paris and its lovely building. Was a bit of a long wait to get it, but worth it.
Attend a concert here!. This beautiful Chapel is near Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are amazing. We attended a concert of chamber music here that was wonderful. Highly recommended

A Textbook Example of Gothic Architecture. The Sainte-Chapelle experience can't compete with the grandeur of Notre Dame, but this wonderful example of Gothic architecture is more intimate and probably better preserved.

For stained glass fanatics only. If it wasn't such a pain to get into this chapel (hint: it's a chapel not a church so it's probably a lot smaller than you expect), I might have given it a higher rating. The circus tent ceiling and fatal overdose of stained glass are certainly impressive, but truthfully, only for those who really love those things. I think they're nice, but overall I thought this was a waste of my time. Here's why: Sainte-Chapelle is located within the gates of the Palace of Justice. Therefore, the line outside is for security, not admission, so yes, even if you have a Museum Pass you must wait in line. Once past security, there is another line for tickets -- this second line you can skip with a Museum Pass. Also, the chapel is often closed 1-2:15 pm daily. So, if you arrive mid-day, or if you're looking for the ticket line, or if you're looking for the Museum Pass entrance, or if you're trying to figure out which line is which (one is for the chapel, one for the Palace of Justice, another for tours and handicap accessibility), you're out of luck because none of this is straightforward on the outside.There is restoration work going on (much needed on some of the woodwork), and so some of the windows are covered, but again, if stained glass is your thing, this is still worth your while.

Restoration work currently ongoing. We went to Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny afternoon as that is when the stained glass windows are shown to their best advantage. At the moment there is a lot of restoration work taking place and part of the upper chapel is blocked off so be prepared for that. There is a lot of information about the restoration which makes interesting reading. Well worth a visit.
Good. Great Chapel! Very good stained glass. However there are other better chapels in Paris and so if you dont have time this can be missed

Do not miss this!!. The stained glass is magnificent. There is some restoration in progress so some of the windows are covered. Get your tickets before your visit unless you want to stand in line in a sunny area.
Stain Glass Windows.. This place is best remembered for its stain glass windows. If you enjoy the artistry of a craftsman that can tell a story in glass visit here where each window is unique.

Fantastic Stained Glass!. You really must see this if you are visiting Paris. You first enter the chapel at the crypt level and wonder what all the fuss was about until you find the stairs in the corner that take you up to the main Chapel above. Wow!

Renovations beware. The beauty of this chapel is lost currently as many of the stained glass windows are covered up - long queues but disappointing -check first you can see from outside from right direction!

The restoration should improve the experience. A little disappointed. The site is being restored in parts and statues appeared to be covered in dust which impacted their appearance. It was very crowded and quite stuffy so I don't think we saw this at its best. Still worth a visit and I hope the entrance fee will be used to help the restoration.

Do Not Miss This Exquisite Chapel!. Ten-thousand pieces of stained glass windows reflecting in the upper chapel...and a rose oriel window at one end to boot? You cannot beat that. In the summer they even give concerts there in the evenings, so we went back for a Baroque concert that night. Memories forever...
