Worth a visit. This is the chapel of the King, basically entirely stained glass. There is currently restoration being done on about 20%, including the rose window. It is, however quite worth a stop, especially if you have a museum pass!

How About Some Stained Glass!. A magnificent chapel undergoing much needed cleaning and renovations but well worth a visit. The very best way to experience this gorgeous building is to buy a ticket to any one of the many concerts offered in the evening at Sainte-Chapelle. There are only about 100 seats on the ground floor of the Chapelle with fine musicians and it is a wonderful experience and there is plenty of time for a great dinner afterwards. When we were last there we heard Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" which started (Spring) with light streaming in through the stained glass and it ended about an hour later (Winter) with it dark outside, it was a magical experience.

Beautiful. Beautiful stain glass windows. Under renovation right now so about 25 % of windows were covered today. Museum pass not helpful to get thru security but were helpful to get thru separate ticket line. We enjoyed it but enjoyed walking the Seinne from there to the Louvre more!! Tough access. I didn't see an elevator...maybe it's there??
Beautiful stained glass. Prepare for a big queue of waiting and a lot of beauty there! Stained-glass windows are gorgeous and well worth the long wait.

A highlight of our days in Paris. I first saw Sainte-Chapelle in 2008 and was awestruck by the magnificent stained glass windows. This year before leaving home, I organised tickets online to attend an evening concert there and it was a highlight of our days in Paris. We paid a little extra for seats near the front which was well worthwhile. Listening to beautiful music in such a beautiful space as Sainte-Chapelle was a memorable experience.

Beautiful stain glass windows. The amount of detail in the stain glass windows was beautiful. They were restoring the windows when we were there and the difference between the pre-restored and restored was amazing!

Musical magic. We visited this cathederal because we wanted to attend the chamber orchesta concert program featuring Vivaldi's The Four Season. All I can say is "wow". Superb music in a historically important and beautiful place of worship. What a way to end our time in Paris. I recommend this experience highly.

Windows, just say en. Worth seeing the spectacular windows. I thought it was the prettiest of the 3 inside, Notre Dame, and Sacre Coeur. Worth attending a concert there. They have them nightly, but see the windows in the sunshine if you can. Strange structure; enter through a basement like gift shop.

Music. So close to almost everything in Paris, la Sainte Chapelle has stained glass windows to die for. Visit and combine it with one of the many music nights held in this location. This beautiful and delicate attraction with the sound of classical music is definitely an evening delightfully spent.

Do not miss this experience!. Wonderful concert in a beautiful setting. A must for a trip to Paris. You can save money by sitting at the back and that way you get an even better view of the stained glass

Best Church in Paris. This was our favorite church in Paris. The stained-glass was unbelievable. We came right at closing time, but we got to spend plenty of time in the chapel.
They are doing restorations, but the glass is still beautiful. I can't wait to go back when all ofthe stained-glass is restored.

Wait till the restoration is complete. I visited Saint Chappelle years ago and it was incredibly moving, emotionally and spiritually, even though I'm not religious. However if you're planning your Parisian trip be warned they are in the process of restoring seven of the windows so it simply won't be as stunning until that is complete.
Stained glass wonder. Love this cathedral for its size, history and stained glass. Read up on it before you go to understand the statues etc.. I actually liked this better than Notre Dame

Stained Glass under renovation still. This church is still under renovation and there's not a whole lot to see. the glass is beautiful, but the rest of the church is boarded up and pretty dirty. Would not recommend unless you have the Paris Pass.
Great to see, just a lot of restoration going on. A lot restoration had elements covered and difficult to see, but the experience was beautiful and so much history to take in.
Holy Chapel. A Royal medieval gothic Chapel that is designated as an UNESCO world heritage site, known for its stained glass window and easy to link it with a visit to the Notre Dame cathedral.

It may be small but it is wonderful. The Notre Dame queues were enormous so we changed our itinerary and went to the nearby Saint-Chapelle Chapel, We were not disappointed. This is the oldest church in Paris and is being lovingly restored. The stained glass windows are a work of art to be enjoyed and a sight to behold. We learned how to read the stories in these windows which opened up a whole new meaning to them. A very humbling reminder to how things were revered in days gone by. Do not miss this hidden treasure.

Beautiful - hidden gem. Amazing church tucked away just up the road from Notre Dam.This is so beautiful and came highly recommended on our walking tour and we were not disappointed.It was 9 euros each which is pricey, but have never seen stain glass like it, especially when sun is blazing through the windows. Simply beautiful!
Magnificent Stained Glass. Don't miss this outstanding church. More stained glass than five other Paris Church's combined. Easy to find and hard to forget !
Beautiful windows. Work to prepare Sainte-Chapelle for the 800th anniversary is nearly complete. It is amazing that what looks so delicate was created that long ago.

An amazing venue for Vivaldi. Like stepping into a light filled jewel box, Sainte-Chappelle is truly jaw dropping. Having so enjoyed the chapel on a previous trip (it's on the museum pass!), this year we decided to splurge (our last night in Paris) and purchase tickets to a Vivaldi concert - it was worth every euro. This was no staid classical concert- the talented musicians filled the space with amazing sound and energy to a standing ovation at the end. For us this was a spur of the moment treat- walking by the chapel we noticed a sign for a concert that evening- the friendly staff told us tickets had to be purchased (cash only) in one of the listed shops or cafes across the street and luckily there were seats available (but I know friends who had purchased tickets in advance) Note* the chappelle was under construction but didn't detract from the concert- this is a delightful way to view the windows as during a "normal "visit it can get quite crowded.

Amazing Stained Glass. We stumbled into this one... not really planning to see it, and we were very pleased. I don't recall ever seeing so much stained glass in such a small space. We all really enjoyed it.

You must see the stained glass!. If you have the Paris Pass, this is certainly a must see. You can visit this pretty quick, but the tall stained glass windows (each telling several stories) are unbelievable!

Great, Intimate Venue. You are in a 13th century church that was built to house relics of Christ listening to classical music played by a virtuoso on a violin that was made in 1749. What could be better?This concert was a string quartet (Les Violons de France) led by Frederick Moreau. They started with Mozarts "Eine Keline NachtmusikBazzinis "Dance of the Goblins" which showed of his expertise on the instrument. The chapel seats about 200 people so be sure to get tickets early (I used Classictic). The acoustics in the chapel are very good and I think you can hear as well in front as in back. It was a very enjoyable way to spend an evening in Paris.
Peaceful. Another awe inspiring church that typifies Paris .Beautiful and peaceful within the church with magnificent stained glass windows.

Beautiful Sainte-Chapelle. After a tight security entrance check, was a great little Church to visit with lots of relics & history attached. Great photos to be taken & if you can take a guided tour for all the info about this Chapelle.
Amazing glass.. We found out about Sainte Chapelle from a book and here on trip advisor, and I am so glad we went here. Amazing stained glass and excellent photo opportunities.

bach concert. What a wonderful experience, Bach concerts at he Sainte-Chapelle medieval Gothic chapel, located near the Palais de la Cité, on the Île de la Cité in the heart of Paris. Need to book in advance.

Truly Beautiful. Really difficult to find, even with our downloaded Trip Advisor Paris Attraction map. We orbitted the block twice and kept landing up on Quai des Orfevres. It is not in this road. The entrance is around the corner on Bd du Palais. Maybe this is only due to the renovations. And what makes it more difficult is that you expect to be able to see a church or chapel. We saw nothing until we spotted a very small sign by a very long que, so we asked and yes, we needed to wait for what felt a very long time in the mist rain, at least 40 minutes. It is not very full but obviously the numbers are limited and rightly so. A very high security check point was followed by a dark interior of what appeared to be a very low key church in comparison to everything else we had seen in Paris. One can easily miss the tiny staircase near the entrance which leads to an explosion of diffused light. What a beautiful sight awaits you. Unfortunately, renovations are in progress, but don't miss this attraction for that reason. It is definitely worth every effort to find this little chapel. The detail depicted in these windows is unbelievable and the impression of height that cannot be caught in any photo is amazing to experience.
Breathtaking building. One of the most fabulous (in the true sense of the word) buildings you are ever likely to walk into. Go in the afternoon to benefit from the best light

Beautiful. Worth the visit.Have a Paris Pass and entry is free and you don't queue in the ticket line.The best and most impressive stain glass work I have ever seen.Link this with your Notre Dame visit, they are 4 minutes walk apart.

Zaps you to a different time. this place may seem small but it packs quite the punch with the stained glass art. bring to tears the skill and workmanship they had in those times. Made me wonder if anyone could do such beautiful work by hand these days....amazing...

Such a lot blanked off for repair. We were herded in like sheep. While I quite appreciate the beauty of the stained glass and the need for it to be well maintained I think it's a poor do to still charge full price when a lot of it is invisible. This was not made clear on entering.
Beautiful though difficult to find it. Worth to visit if it's a free entrance (that's what I did): not many things to see other than the stained glass. But, the stained glass is magnificent.

Being renovated. Sainte-Chapelle is lovely, but the upper chapel is being renovated and this detracts from the experience, Of course, it is a good thing that it is being preserved for generations to come, but right now it is disappointing because a huge part of the chapel is under tarps and this kind of ruins the experience.
Beautiful. This was my first time to go to Sainte-Chapelle. Small but ever so beautiful. Part of it is under restoration, but still a must see.
lovely. We got there before 9 am and had no wait when it opened. It is a quick visit but worth it..very beautiful stained glass that is from the 13th century

Ancient Paris, at its heart. One thing Americans don't always fully appreciate is how old the cities of Europe are. I know that sounds silly, but it is true. The scope of Sainte-Chappelle and its role in Parisian and European history is humbling.This is also one of the less-crowded historic sites in Paris, and I recommend it as one of your first stops on your visit to the city. You learn so much about Paris's foundations from this very site.

A pleasant surprise in the heart of Paris. I had a few days free on my own after a business meeting and decided to wander Paris with no real plan. I had downloaded Rick Steves audio guide on Paris for my iPhone, and just looked through the list of places he had listed. I'd never heard of Sainte-Chapelle and had no idea what it was. Now that I've seen it, I won't forget it.The lower floor (entry) is decorated ornately and one might think this was it, but when you step upstairs try to keep your jaw from hitting the floor. The best word I can make up to describe this is stained-glass-topia. The entire story of the bible told in stained glass from left to right, top to bottom is laid out above you in vibrant blue, red, green, orange and gold colors. I don't remember how many tiles the audio guide told me there were, but it must be hundreds. The ceiling is cavernous and cathedral style. The tile on the floor is ornate and it's worth kneeling down and looking up at the ceiling to be truly inspired. I'm not a man of any faith so I speak objectively when I say I think people of any faith or none at all can probably find this place impressive and moving either from a historical perspective or a spiritual perspective depending on how you look at it.In short, Sainte-Chapelle is definitely worth a stop if you've got free time in Paris.
Lovely. We enjoyed our visit. Bought our museum passes here. Public bathrooms on site. Stairs to the top are very, very narrow and steep.

"...overwhelmed by the colours of the stained glass windows" ~ Olivier Messiaen. Visitors to Europe will no doubt comment after a few days' that they are heartily sick of the amount of cathedrals and chapels they have to visit, and that they all look the same after a while! Well Sainte-Chapelle, I can assure you, will be very different from the rest. Visitors will be dazzled by the sunlit giant panels of wall-to-wall stained glass windows that give the chapel its fame. Those (such as I) without any religious affiliation and who may not realise the significance of the stories of Christianity depicted in those windows, can appreciate them from a simply aesthetic point of view. The other architectural aspect of St Chapelle that fascinates me is the gold-fleurs-de-lis-on-blue-sky ceiling in the basement. I make it a point to visit this site with each trip to Paris, so I've probably been there at least 5 times, and I won't be stopping at this number. Unfortunately, I found during my visit in 2013 that renovation works ere underway, and a quick visit to their website shows that renovation will only be completed in Dec 2014. Nevertheless, for those who will not be visiting Paris again, it might still be worth the 8.50eur entrance fee. There is also a combo ticket with the Conciergerie (in the same Palais de Justice complex as St Chapelle, but separate entrances), definitely not as beautiful as St Chapelle, much more gloomy in fact, but may be worth a visit for Marie Antoinette fans (this is where she spent her last days before losing her head). The nearby Cite Metro stop may be worth a peek too, as it is one of the few surviving original metro entrances from the early 20th century. There is also a cheery bird/ flower market on nearby Place Louis Lépine on sundays.P.S: To enter St-Chapelle, you first have to go through a strict airport-style security line +/- xray machine check. Sharp objects (and obviously anything deemed dangerous) will be confiscated.

Beautiful windows.. Quite hard to find as it's inside the palais de justice. Very tight, airport type, security to get in. Once inside it has beautful stained glass windows. You go up a spiral staircase to see most of them. It's not very far but could be a little bit claustrophobic for some.

Five stars but for the renovation work. An amazing work in stained glass. The back wall and part of the north wall are covered by scaffolding due to the renovation work that is ongoing. Do some home work to really appreciate the scenes presented in the glass.

A gem. Although about a quarter of the upstairs windows were covered for repairs during my visit, the stained glass windows were amazing. It's such a small chapel that it may be overlooked, but don't. It's worth it - my teenage daughter was pleasantly surprised.

Amazing windows; poor timing with construction. This probably was the least liked experience. We had difficulty finding the entrance, only to find ourselves having to climb a very very steep circular staircase to reach the Chapel. The stained glass windows were spectacular, but the scaffolding was intrusive.

Wow…most fantastic stained glass windows. Charming and lovely small chapel, where the king worshipped. It's a big WOW when you walk up the not-too-long old winding staircase to the second floor where the room opens up into a glorious stained glass heaven. Just amazing. They have chairs up there so you can take your time and look. A real joy!

Forever under construction.. Everyone must visit this lovely church however we were there in 2007 and now back 7 years later and it has been continually in repair making it more difficult to get the full effect.
See once. This is a lovely church and the stain glass windows are truly something to see. However, the lines are very long and it is an attraction that I would only stand in line once to see.
The most exquisite piece of catholic architecture. Don't miss the upper level floor, mostly hidden for the unaware. This is a simple, delicate church, a must see landmark.
A beauty. This Cathedral has the most beautiful stained glass. Enjoy a concert here for a special treat. This was a good place to pick up a museum pass and then start using it right away.

Gorgeous glass!. Such a pretty place. Definitely need to get the Paris Museum Pass, so you can walk right through the side entrance and not wait in the huge long line. Redoing some of the glass, so some of the windows are covered up. Can't believe it's real stained glass.
Breathtaking!. This small chapel is breathtaking & the history of the church is fascinating. The stained-glass windows are gorgeous, I enjoyed learning there meaning. Totally worth your time!
Gorgeous stained glass. This was an unexpected pleasure. The upstairs was a breathtaking moment when you entered the chapel. A must see.
The windows!. One of the best churches in Paris. Not as large as the others, but the stained glass windows - you have to see! Very detailed and colorful.
Wow. We were so surprised to find this special church filled with beautiful stained glass. It was overwhelming in a wonderful way. What a treasure.
Beautiful!. Beautiful. Must see. Unbelievable display of stained glass. Use your museum pass to gain quick easy access.

Long queue but worth it. Beautiful stained glass even on a dull rainy day. No privileged entrance with Museum pass. Very impressive to think how old this stained glass is - survived many wars.....Each window has its own pattern and colours. Well worth a visit.

Always Spectacular. The stained glass windows of Sainte Chapelle have been my favorites since the 1970s. Now most have recently been cleaned, and they are almost done with the rose window. It's just magical. Our 13-year old decided that instead of being a veterinarian, she might become a "stained glass designer". While the windows of Notre Dame are also magnificent, this is such a special jewel - a jaw-dropper! :-)
Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. This site is very close to the Cathedral of Notre Dame. If you like the stained glass windows at Notre Dame, then you will love this place.

Stunning stained glass. The stained glass is amazing. There was a medium length line and it took a while to enter, but the upper chapel is worth the wait. The downside is about ⅓ of the windows are covered for restoration. I wish I had binoculars to really enjoy the windows and workmanship.

Light in full color. Almost a reliquary for a fragment allegedly from the True Cross, this chapel ordered by King Louis is a tour de force of Gothic architecture. Don't miss the 2nd floor, which is almost pure stained glass panels with very little masonry support. A masterpiece!
nice little church. I went there last July, I wanted to see the stained glass work which is very impressived. The church is very small but beautiful and very old.

Waiting for the renovations to be over. I love Sainte-Chapelle, but it has been under renovation for about a decade. When I visited, several of the windows were covered with hoardings and the atmosphere of the chapel itself was marred by the noise and dust of the workmen. Can't wait until it is done and this magnificent chapel is back to being a peaceful location full of beauty.

It's all in the details. Saint Chapelle is a little chapel full of interesting details that have withstood the test of time. Known for its stained glass rose window, it was unfortunate that it was under repair at the time of my visit. Details abound from floor to walls to ceilings...a treasure trove of inspiration for a designer like me. It was 5 years ago when I visited but the details remain in my mind.

Exquisite!. I don't think I've ever seen anything so exquisite, so detailed and rich in decoration and history! This little hidden gem will just blow you away by it's magnificence. So glad we knew to go looking for this, beautiful!
beautiful. LONG LINE! but worth it if you are interested in this kind of thing. Hire the audio guide to understand what you are looking at.

Stunning tour through Bible stories. A very small one room Gothic chapel. It's all about the remarkable 13th c. stained glass. There are no large stone walls- - just narrow stone columns, which look more like framework to hold the huge glass windows. The earliest version of 'crystal cathedral.' The beautiful windows seem to tell the entire Bible, as you see stories in Genesis and Exodus, moving through the Old Testament, then into the New Testament and life of Christ. It is a stunning trip through Bible stories.

fine stained glass. Located in Ile de la Cité, take the métro Cité are enter the Ile de la Cité through Pont Neuf. It is a Gothic Chappel. The visit would hardly take an hour if there is no queue. You could also visit the Palais de Justice next to it. Just go for the sake of the Vitraux - fine stained glass. Each pane has a story. Though not much explanation offered, it was beautiful to see. There is an entrance fee.Free for the handicapped and the accompanying person. They don't even make you stand in the queue to get in. The French are truly considerate and un grand merci.

Gothic stained glass glory. To understand the history, beauty and cultural, religious reasons for stained glass, go to La Sainte-Chapelle. Please dress respectfully - too many tourists there are wearing inappropriate clothing for a religious establishment. The stained glass windows are incomparable - known throughout the world as the most perfect embodiment of Scripture rendered in glorious windows which will leave you breathless.

Wonderful place to attend a concert!. My husband and I were fortunate to attend two beautiful concerts here last May. It is such a fabulous venue to watch a concert....listening to classical music as you look at the glorious stained glass windows is an experience not to be missed. I recommend going to an early concert when the glass windows are most visible in the light of day.
Wow. Stunning church, still very spiritual despite the crowds. I found it very moving and very beautiful.
A great building but the lines.... I cannot enjoy anything after standing in the rain for too long so though it is a magnificent building I would never do it again.

Hidden gem. The stained glass is a not miss. Quite remarkable to see in person and understand some of the history behind it. You will be surprised to find it tucked amongst so many buildings. You can rent the audio guides and they are well worth it and easy to use.

Historical Church. This Church used to house the crown of thorns worn by Christ. The crown is now in Notre Dame. The architecture here is unique with bold colors in paper and marble. It is a quiet place to reflect.

Beauty Beyond Words. Even though a small, much less visited cathedral, I found Sainte-Chapelle to be one of the most breathtakingly beautiful spots ever. Take the time to read the history and story behind both the lower level and then, without doubt, the second floor in order to truly appreciate the magnificence of this special place. Many come and spend the entire day just to follow the story as the sun moves across each stained-glassed pane.

Oldest chapel in Paris. The chapel is beautiful - the stained glass walls are marvelous, and to think it was built so long ago is mind-boggling. The entry price was a bit high for the small building though - but I suppose they need money for renovations.

stained glass is amazing. The colors that envelop this cathedral through the stained glass are breath taking. Unfortunately it is under renovation right now so you can't appreciate just how gorgeous it is. Still worth visiting, but if you will be visiting again following the completion of the renovation, give it a second chance and go back.

Engraved in my heart!. Sainte-Chapelle is just a short walking distance from the Notre-Dame. This chapelle is my favourite jewel! Every time I think about Paris my heart beats faster and I get excited just to think about the stained glass I saw, which are engraved forever in my memory and heart! Stunning beauty!
Gorgeous. The chapel is utterly amazing. It is truly stunning. Far fewer crowds than Notre Dame and much more impressive.

Incredible stained glass and medieval atmostphere. You come here for the medieval architecture and the fantastic stained glass. Ideally, you should visit during a sunny day and then come back later at night to listen to a concert. Of course medieval choir or baroque music, in perfect harmony with the atmosphere.

Absolutely Incredible. This was my favorite place that I visited while I was in Paris. It is just amazing, the stained windows I have never seen anything like it, I could have happily stayed in there all day. I also visited the Nortre Dame Cathedral and this blew that right out of the water. and as a bonus it is much less crowded.I went just after mid-day and when the sun shone through the windows it was simply beautiful. It is a little hard to find at first but it is well worth the effort.
Super pretty but small. It was under renovation when i was there but the stain glass really is amazing as it's advertised. Just that the place is a bit small

Fabulous!. My grandson and I were enchanted by this chapel, with the red and blue stained glass windows. The second floor is particularly striking. My grandson enjoyed watching the tv programs showing how they restored the glass windows and other parts of the chapel. This chapel is a must see on a tour of Paris.

Like walking into a jewel box!. One of the recommended sights of Paris, this is a small chapel tucked away next to the Palais de Justice; the Conciergerie is the large building with the turrets facing onto the Seine. (To avoid the queues, buy your combined ticket at the Conciergerie ticket office - a little more expensive but worth it)The lower chapel is your first taste of the decoration of the interior of the building although there are some incongruous souvenir stalls cluttering up this room.Go up the small spiral staircase in the corner of the room to get to the upper chapel and prepare to be amazed! The chapel is a very tall and narrow room with gorgeous decoration of the lower walls below the tall Gothic windows and with statues and the painted decoration running up between the windows to the superb ceiling of gold stars on an azure background. But this is only part of the decoration as the amazing Medieval stained glass will take your breathe away; the rich colours and design are quite wonderful. (There are free information sheets in various languages to explain the stories portrayed in the windows). Some of the windows are being restored (August 2014) but this should not detract from the overall effect. The only problem is the crowds and the noise; guides talking loudly to their parties, individuals reading from the guidebooks/info sheets and talking to each other and the ever present attendants making more noise by "shushing" people every few minutes!Nevertheless, this is an absolute jewel of a building and should not be missed!

Gorgeous colours!. What a beautiful church this is with its amazing stained glass windows and beautiful light. This is in the process of being restored and is already very special. It will be even better when it is finished!

amazing church. you can get to this site on the hop on hop off bus (follow the crowd to the church past the 5000 souvenir shops) there a long set of stairs up the hill ,for an extra fee you can go into the tower or the sub floor area ,this was a great place to be as it was a hot day when we were there ,worth the effort to get there , extraordinary building but probably wouldn't go back

An absolute jewel. This is a must-see in Paris. We first visited Sainte-Chapelle nine years ago, and we saw it with no obstructions. The windows are currently being refurbished, and therefore some are covered by screens and cannot be seen. This was disappointing, but even so, what can be seen is breathtaking. It was interesting to stand at the head of the stairs and to listen to the awed comments of people as they caught their first glimpse of these gorgeous windows. If you love stained glass, you must see Sainte-Chapelle.

Exceptional. My wife and I visited this church at the recommendation of our local Paris tour guide. We really enjoyed it more than Notre Dame and it is considerably older. Notre Dame is a new church compared to this one .The architecture of this chapel is breathtaking
Beautiful Stained Glass. It was beautiful but really not much to see. We did buy a joint ticket to La Conciergerie which was a little more interesting to me.

Magical. This used to be one of Paris' undiscovered secrets; no longer. Stunning stained glass, superb atmosphere, grand history. Just a lovely place to visit. Try and find a quiet time, maybe first thing after opening as the opportunity of sitting quietly and contemplatively enriches the experience.
Classical concert. Book the classical concert in the chapel. It's only an hour but beautiful sound and atmosphere. We ate nearby and went to the the 8.30 pm concert.

Buy the museum pass, miss the queues and witness this marvellous place.. I'm not religious, but this was one of the most colourful and spectacular man made things I have ever seen. The top floor is literally unbelievable. 1113 stained glass pictures from head height to the ceiling.

Amazing. Be sure to arrive here early, as the line gets very long. I had a Museum Pass but still had to wait in the line to go through security. I thought that I has seen some beautiful stained glass, but these windows were breath-taking. There are over 1,000 scenes in 15 windows telling the story of man from Genesis to the Resurrection. Worth a visit.
Beautiful stained glasses. Definitely worth visiting. We had a two-day museum pass but it didn't save us any time in going in. It just helped us to skip the line for purchasing the ticket.
One of the favorite sites to visit. This is my second time at Sainte-Chapelle. It is much smaller than Notre Dame, but I thought the stained glass was so beautiful You just stand there in awe.

Go. It's small, and it's currently under restoration. Easily lost in the shadows of Notre Dame, but you really need to go. It can be done in as little as 10 minutes if you are in a rush. Stunning stained glass. Security is unusually tight as it's on the grounds of the Palais de Justice, so take that into account.
Amazing. This is the most beautiful place to visit - it is like walking into a jewelry box. The stained glass is just spectacular.

What a cute little thing!. Got there just after it opened and there were already around 50 people standing in line for the security check. That went smoothly though and the visit to the chapel, despite a good number of people, went nicely. The audioguides explanation is thorough and detailed, especially about the beautiful stained glasses. Pity though that part of them were being restored when we went there. Iwas going for the Vivaldi concert in the evening but, because the restoration work is covering part of the walls, I decided not to.
stained glass. I love stained glass and the windows here are just amazing. it is hard to believe it is ensconced between federal buildings once you are inside.

A definite highlight of a Parisian visit. Yes, it's August and we joined hordes of tourists to enter Sainte Chapelle. We had bought the Museum Pass but had to wait in line with others to get through the security checkpoint. Took about an hour to enter. The interior is under construction so we did not see the famed Rose window. However, the interior is an amazing display of stained glass windows. We had a rainy day and could only imagine what it would be with sunshine. Definitely worth the time to visit while on I'le de la Cite.

A must see in Paris but please note..... A famous tour book advises to buy your tickets before and just "go to the head of the line"... That was fine before 2001 perhaps but EVERYONE goes thru security (an unpleasant 1+ hour wait) then you either purchase tickets or go in.Security is similar to the airports save the shoe routine.This is worth seeing but for what you pay get the audio guide (6€ per couple-2 separate devices) as wellYes construction is..... But more than enough to see and absorbEnjoy

A Magnificent Gem. O.K. I am going to preface this with the following; This is one of the Top 5 places in Paris I have wanted to see, and one of the bucket list must items I can cross off. For me as an artist, this once private chapel lived up to its expectations and even more. If you are an artist, have an affinity towards the arts of the period, or just like beautiful things, in particular stained glass, this chapel will astound you. I am both glad and sad that restoration was still taking place, so we were unable to see the Rose window and a few panels, but it makes little difference once you are upstairs in the "chapelle" bathed in glorious transcending stained glass light. For me an experience beyond words. The chapel itself is in among the Conciergerie area and dates roughly to the same period as Louis' chateau. It has weathered the ages fairly, but does need care, restoration, and maintenance. So for that fact your entry admission goes to a worthy cause. On access: Fair warning for bad knees or walking issues it's a steep narrow staircase about 40 steps, has a handrail and is do-able slowly: just no elevators.A magnificent example of gothic art and glassworks, this pearl should not be missed. I can give you a quick mini art history lesson here about it: it is worth understanding that the glassworks in here rival any larger and more popular church/s even The great lady- Notre Dame, that existed during that period and even into today. The chapel itself resonates with light, color, beauty and reverence. And I think would touch anyone.Lastly, I am going to make a point the local Parisians might encore, please respect the fact that a lot of these churches and chapels are still religious spaces or hold religious value, and should be treated as such. It's only respectful to the country you are visiting to be aware that flip flops, cut offs, shorts, and tees ARE NOT appropriate wear to visit these kind places. And, it can totally mar another visitor's experience. I'd go on to add in about taking "selfies" too at the right and place time, but hopefully the majority get it; just Respect the Art and History.You may find this place quite special.

Not my favorite. First of all the Paris Pass does not take you to the front of the line. So you wait!The inside is disappointing as the rooms are in desperate need of TLC and you do see construction going on.I think there's better places to go than this one.Great area though!
Lovely windows but construction going on. It was a pity there was some restoration going on so we couldn't see all the windows but I guess this is a must-see if you come to Paris.
Must go. You have to see the stained glass windows here. Small church as such, near the Notre Dame, and I felt it to be very beautiful and a must do while in Paris.

Breathtakingly Beautiful Stained Glass. Exquisite stained glass. Steeped in history. Built by Louis IX in the 13th century, to house the relics of the Passion of Christ it is positioned at the center of the palace. It is a designated UNESCO as a World Heritage Site. The entrance is tucked away on a quiet street - look for the long line of tourists and you will find it. It is part of the palace, so when you exit, you will see the elegant fence that surrounds the parking lot.

Amazing Stained Glass windows. Never even heard of this place until a friend wanted to go here. The small admission price is not bad. The small underground chapel is cool, but head upstairs and prepared to be amazed. The windows are massive and old and gorgeous. When I went, they were restoring the first and last windows and the Rose window in the back but it was still a sight to see.
Try to book and skip the line!. It's a breath-taking example of how religious spirit can erect perrenial buildings, but the main attraction (the rosette) is still under reconstruction.
Wow. I had to come back. .....it wowed me when I took my son there 7 years ago....and so I bought my new husband for our 1st anniversary. .....still takes my breath away....

Gorgeous Little Church. Marvelous historic building with fantastic stained glass and carved wood interior. Again, our feet were the limiting factors in our ability to take in everything we wanted to. Try to gauge your touring if you are approaching "past-middle-age". But go see this place.

Beautiful. Go there for a concert.. Although it can be very hard to get to during the day due to crowds and line, if you book a concert for the evening, you walk right in. It's stained glass is quite majestic. The acoustics for a concert are excellent. It's a must do for your Paris visit.

Breathtaking Interior. This is the 'other' Cathedral on the Ile de la Cite and you must see it. It is very different than the Notre Dame in that it doesn't have the flying buttresses that surround the older building. Instead Saint-Chapelle has an unfettered exterior and huge stained glass windows. The view inside was breathtaking. This is a must see.

Ahhh. Well we waited in line longer then it took to see 2 rooms. The stained glass windows were beautiful but the major deal was being redone. We have seen beautiful windows in other churches around the world. Just kind of disappointed overall.

Absolutely stunning!. We were fortunate enough to be able to visit this amazing church last week while on vacation in Paris. The queue took approx. thirty minutes to pass through security and have our bags scanned. However, following the check, we were able to access the chapel immediately. There are several stairs to climb to gain entry into the main building, but well worth the effort to climb them.Photos do not do the building justice. The stained glass murals are beyond description and well worth the price of admission. We purchased the two day pass giving entry into Sainte-Chapelle and the Concergerie located around the corner, which was where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned for the two years prior to her execution.
Stained glass windows beyond compare. This is a not to miss site in Paris. The stained glass windows are the finest I have ever seen. Crowds are minimal, impact maximum.

Don't miss this!. If you love old churches like we do, you will not want to miss this! Words, and even pictures, fail miserably to convey what you will see. It is a treasure among treasures! It was on our to-do list from the book "1,000 Places to See Before You Die", and it is truly one-of-a-kind. A bit difficult to find, it is tucked behind a couple of other buildings (and by that I mean they have literally built new buildings that have surrounded, nearly swallowed it.) The Lower Chapel is like many of the older European churches, simply done. This was the Chapel for the commoners. But the Royal Chapel is actually upstairs, and will take your breath away. With more stained glass "walls" than actual walls, each panel is a chapter in the story of the Bible, from the earth's formation until the end of the world. They are constantly renovating in an effort to preserve this world treasure which dates back to Medieval times, so if you expect a little dust and perhaps some portions to be blocked off, you will be less frustrated by this necessity. Indeed, what a tragedy if they were not so diligent about giving this beautiful old building the best of care! The video of how they painstakingly preserve and continually refurbish the stained glass windows is really interesting, don't pass that by. Honestly, it is one of my favorite memories of Paris ~

A surprise for you. When entering this wonderland of glass you are somewhat underwhelmed after hearing about the glorious windows. You enter to see the light streaming through but they are not that tall and is a smallish room. Then you realize you are downstairs and the chapel is up a flight where you get the full effect of the church. Well worth a quick visit when you have a museum pass.

Most beautiful stained glass. I had visited ten years ago and often thought about this church and was not disappointed in my return! The stained glass is absolutely breathtaking! Words cannot describe it. Some panels of the stained glass are undergoing renovation, but it's the price to pay for having this beautiful glass preserved for centuries to come! They also had a great video of the method they use fir cleaning and fixing the glass which was really interesting. We waited an hour at go thru security at ten am.

Another Church. It was another church in Paris. I mean, you can't really go wrong with visiting beautiful churches with exquisite stained glass...and this royal chapel has it in spades. It's like a 15 minute and you're done kind of thing, so just go, see it, snap a few pics (or if you really want a good photo buy a freaking post card for a euro) and then go about your merry way

Not worth the wait in line. The line was very long to go through security check because it is in a complex with the court building. The stained glass windows are undergoing renovation so about 5 of them were covered. Therefore, the overall effect of the church was underwhelming. Also, the bible stories portrayed in the stained glass are not easy to see since they are small and very high up. Perhaps bring binoculars. I'm not necessarily sorry I went but I wouldn't suggest going until the renovation is over at least.

Outstanding place with fabulous windows and history. To me this place beats out Notre Dame any day. The windows with the light shining through are spectacular. A marvel of artisty and architecture. Don't miss this place!!

Awesome. Make sure when you are in Paris to visit. These are the most magnificent stained glass windows I have seen. I highly recommend. When I first entered, I was not impressed, but when I walked upstairs, it was amazing. Definitely make sure you visit!

if you like history and architecture. you have to visit this place. it's beautiful and it's a great testimony of architecture. it's better to visit when it's sunny outside because there are many glass Windows. Many details to see on the Windows.

How to skip the queue. This is a truly beautiful church. The Rose Window is covered for restoration, but the chapel is still worth a visit. Hint: visit La Conciergerie which is beside the Chapelle first. It is where Marie Antoinette was held prisoner before being sentenced to death. It is a worthwhile place to visit, and you can buy a joint ticket for both places. There was no line for La Conciergerie and then we just walked past all the line waiting to buy tickets for Sante-Chapelle!
Beautiful stained glass. Definitely worth a stop if you are near Notre Dame. We visited it the same day as we walked around Il de l'Cite.

Gorgeous windows you can see up close. I didn't understand why my friend wanted to go to this chapel. I definitely found out the second we walked in. While it is currently undergoing restoration in parts the windows are spectacular. You also are much closer to them so you can see the intricate detail involved in each. Go early or late, unfortunately you can't jump line with museum pass. Worth the line! Go when it's sunny to get the best effect from the windows

Pretty Storytelling. Some go for the religious experience, I went for the beauty. The immense stained-glass windows radiate with various colors as the sun shines through them - well, yes, of course - these are stained-glass windows, after all. But these are huge!

Well worth the wait. Having visited Paris several times previously, we had already seen a large number of the 'sights'. One that we had missed previously, however, was Sainte-Chapelle. Sainte-Chapelle is part of the Palace de Justice complex on the Ile-de-la-cite and is easy to miss. Apart from the historical significance, the wonder of the building is the array of beautiful, stained glass windows in the building. It is well worth the visit for those who like things of beauty.

Beautiful music in an incomparable setting. Hard to imagine a flute, violin and harpsichord trio sounding more beautiful than it does in the light of the sun setting through the stained glass windows of the chapel. Get tickets early, and please provide all listeners with a program for your memorable music.

A Glorious Evening. We went to this chapel one evening in June to see a string quartet perform Vivaldi's Four Seasons. What a beautiful chapel and what a beautiful performance. We were treated to 90 minutes of outstanding music performed in a gorgeous setting. I forget how much the tickets were, however they weren't expensive,

Transporting. (Note: the chapel is under renovation and the rose window is not visible.) We saw several churches and cathedrals on our recent visit to Europe. Sainte-Chappelle is, by far, the most beautiful. Even under renovation, it's worth an hour's wait in line. The windows are ethereal, the interior painting and decor exquisite and medieval. This isn't the grandest or largest cathedral you'll see, but unique in its beauty.

unbelievable hidden gem. This church is a bit hidden by the Palais de la Cite. This was an exceptional visit. Pit dates back to 1248 and 70% of the stained glass is original! It is the most extensive collection of medieval stained glass in the world. The panels depict the old and New Testament. The are read from left to right and bottom to top. This is better than Notre Dame in my opinion and stunning to visit. The little chapel underneath has the oldest wall fresco in Paris as well. You won't regret the visit. TIP! We bought our tickets online and printed them and skipped the very long line!

Amazing Church; Amazingly long lines. A remarkable way to tell biblical history - through stained glass! Although the stained glass is a must-see attraction, unless you arrive before the church opens, you should expect extremely long - and slow moving - queues due to the church's proximity to Paris' Hall of Justice (Palais de Justice).Pros: you'll see the most remarkable depiction of biblical history anywhere; covered by the museum pass.Cons: very long lines to get thru security (after which you queue to pay the entrance fee for the church itself); the church will be very crowded; your neck will hurt from looking up for so long at the stained glass; the first four panels of the stained glass were covered for reconstruction.The security line is like going thru airport security, but with only one lane open. Arrive early.

An ornate Gothic marvel. A unique gothic structure in that it has exquisite wallpaper and gold ornamentation. Unlike other gothic structures which feel heavy and oppressing, this chapel is lightened by its vast amount of stained glass.There are long queues but they move fairly quickly.

RAINBOW OF GLASS. Don't be put off by the security checks and queues. The amazing work on these windows is a sight to see, very gothic place full of colour . Not a very big building but worth the visit, we purchased a double ticket to also visit the concergerie close by.

If you only go to one church in Paris, go to this one. Hands down, the BEST stained glass in all of Europe. Breathtaking. Truly Breathtaking. I cannot put into words how absolutely stunning this little chapel is. Yes, you have to go through a LOT of security to get in, but it is worth it. Included in the Paris Pass

3 week holiday to UK. we were advised to go and see but wouldn't rush back. It was ok but a long wait to get in and for the money cant say it was worth it. They were doing renovations at the time so may have made a difference if it was all open to see. Yes it was beautiful but not something to cue for.
Stained glass heaven. The stained glass in this church is amazing. Whiles there are other churches more impressive than this one the stained glass is simply incomparable.
Just fab. Don't be put off by the security checks and the unprepossessing entrance, once you're in it's a Gothic treat! Jaw-dropping.

Heavenly stained glass!. The chapel is small and the stained glass is beautiful. We were able to see a Vivaldi concert here in the evening. To enjoy beautiful music in such a beautiful setting was wonderful!

This cathedral is awe inspiring!. Around the corner from Notre Dame. There are 1000 stained glass windows that tell the story of the Bible. There are many beautiful cathedrals in Paris, but this was my favorite.

A Very Different Sacred Space. This is an interesting spot both inside and out. Located next to the courthouse, the entrance at the moment is a bit clunky and uninviting. If you need a restroom, this is an adventurous moment to find one as they are located down a couple of hallways inside the courtroom building...you'll need to ask directions at least once to find them. Fascinating to see the robed court officials and lawyers in the halls. The chapel itself is beautiful and has its own interesting history. This is included on the Rick Steve's audio guide to the historic city, which I would recommend. Another Museum Pass site.
Stunning stained glass. Well worth the queue and the entrance fee. Don't be deceived , when you get upstairs it's a serious wow factor. The stained glass is the best ever

Absolutely breathtaking. We knew that there are stained glass windows there, but we had no idea! It's under renovation, but there is still more than enough to appreciate the workmanship and beauty of this chapel. We had to wait in line a long time even though we had museum passes due to security check. It was worth it!

magnificent ceiling-high stained glass windows telling stories of the Bible!. Sainte-Chapel seems to be dwarfed by the Notre Dame (same subway exit), but I actually liked this one better. It is a small cathedral but if you go up to the second floor there are these magnificent ceiling-high stained glass windows that encircle the cathedral and visually depict the stories of the Bible. There are about a dozen panes. You read the panes from left to right, and each pane from bottom to top. There are no words, just artwork. If you know the stories of the Bible (starting from Genesis), you will be able to "read" the panes and understand which stories they are trying to depict. These stained glass windows are absolutely amazing! It's too bad that when we visited, the giant circular rose window was under renovation, otherwise it would have been even more beautiful!

My expectations were too high!. I was a bit disappointed. The church has not the whow-factor I hoped for. The rose window is still under restoration, so you can't see it. Entrance fee (8 euro!) is far too much!!!!

Beautiful stained glass windows. We went on a Saturday and it was a cloudy day so there was no line. We got in very quickly after paying at the door and was disappointed to see that the Rose Window and a few others were closed due to renovations. They should have pointed that out before we paid to get in so that we could have made a decision at that time to enter or not. The several window panels which were opened were absolutely beautiful. I just wished the Rose Window was open as well. The renovations are supposed to be completed in 2014... this year but no exact dates were given as to when they would reopen all the windows for viewing. St. Chapelle is a must for first time travelers to Paris once they get their renovations completed.

Arrive Early for great light. We lucked into this. We were headed to Notre Dame and saw a short line for St. Chapelle at opening time. (around 9). We were glad we got in the line. The morning light made the spectacular stain glass windows even better than the photos.

Standing in the Light. I had to see Sainte Chapelle after reading Alice Steinbach's book 'Without reservations'. It was worth the wait (even in hot sun), but I was very disappointed to find out after the screening post that the main rose window and 6 other stained glass windows are closed for repairs/cleaning. Still - this 'chapel' is dynamite, worthwhile to visit

Go late in the day. Before our trip we were told that if you buy the combo ticket for the conciergerie and Sainte Chapelle that you can skip the long lines for sainte chapelle. Well thats not entirely true. You still have to wait in the long security line for sainte chapelle, but you do get to skip the ticket line at sainte chapelle. We were surprised by this, since we were told we'd get to skip both lines. But everyone has to wait in the same long security line, even people with museum passes. By the time we were done touring the conciergerie it was pretty late around 4:30pm. Sainte chapelle closed at 6pm that day for a concert. By the time we waited in the SHORT security line and entered the church it was 5pm - it took us 30 minutes to get through a short line, so plan your time accordingly. We took some pictures on the 1st floor and then we went up the spiral stairs (which are not stroller or wheelchair friendly) to the chapel. The chapel was amazing (it was a sunny day and that really brought out the colors in the windows). Even my kids really liked it. When we got there around 5:20 there were still lots of people everywhere. But by 5:40pm the place had cleared out. I'm not sure if the tours left or people just left to get ready for dinner, but the place was empty. Our kids quickly pretended to be ballerinas and dance around the empty chapel. Its almost magical when you are completely alone in this wonderful space. I highly suggest going late and staying until closing time. In the summer the sun is still shining through the windows at that time and you can truly appreciate the beauty without a thousand people making noise and crowding you.

Restoration Excellence. The stained glass restoration has to be seen to be believed. The pride of the workers is evident. The Concierge is next door and was the first kings palace and later the jail used in the French Revolution. I suggest you go to the Concierge first and get the ticket for Saint-Chapelle at the same time. This will enable you to jump the very long (and slow moving) cues for Saint-Chapelle

Worth a visit. Alighting at Pont Neuf station and crossing the Seine along the bridge which gave the metro station its name took us to one of the two islands in the middle of the famous river, the Ile de la Cite, and the Quai de L'Horloge along which we walked to the Palais de Justice. Here we queued in light rain, puzzled by the total lack of wet weather facilities for tourists, so we could buy tickets (€12.50 each) to visit Sainte Chapelle ("Holy Chapel") and La Conciergerie.The former is located in the courtyard of what used to be the royal palace but is now part of an administrative complex known as La Conciergerie. These are part of an even larger complex known as the Palais de Justice. A medieval gothic building commenced in 1246, it was built to house Louis IX's collection of relics of Christ which included the Crown of Thorns, the Image of Edessa (an image of Christ similar to the Shroud of Turin) and some thirty other items. After passing through an extremely slack security check in the form of a brief glance into my backpack, we stepped into a small, crowded room that was lined with very old looking, painted timber panels and nothing else of much significance apart from a statue. Wondering about the significance of this place, we noticed people ascending some very narrow, winding steps from a corner of the room and followed them upstairs to what was a much larger room with a very high vaulted ceiling and it's highlight: fifteen tall, quite spectacular stained glass windows containing more than 1,100 Biblical scenes as well as a massive, circular 'rose' window. While there's not much more to do than look and take in the craftsmanshipof amazing artisans, I thought the visit worthwhile just from the perspective of connecting with it's history - as you do with most ancient or very old buildings.

Worth the visit to experience amazing architecture. Easy access, not too crowded. Able to appreciate the architecture and stained glass. The audio guide was a plus, however, since some of the art work was under restoration, it was kind of hard to keep track of where the audio guide was at. Good for general information though.
Disappointing. The lead lighting and history within is breath taking, however the main attraction the rose was under renovation. Most disappointed and annoyed that their was no prior notification..

Main attraction for me in Paris. Go there in a sunny afternoon, light will flow through the stained-glass windows, and you will feel as if you were in a magic box. Stunning interior and light.Good advice: buy double ticket in Conciergerie (12 euro), this will save you half an hour of queueing in Saint-Chapelle).
Beautiful chapel. Stained glass windows are beautiful here and it's well worth a visit, even if you only have a short time to do so.

Absolutely beautiful. This place is stunning! It's a feast for the eyes! There wasn't a big queue to get in and it wasn't jam packed! Also if you're under 26 and from the EU IT's free entry! (Provided you can show your passport or drivers licence).

Fantastic windows, but small, covered by construction. The windows are simply huge and detailed and amazing. There are so many biblical stories recorded. However, when I went in mid july there was reparation wor covering about a quarter of it, which was disappointing but probably just bad timing for me.
Stunning (even though under repair) . We loved our visit to Saint Chappelle even though it is under repair currently. I am sure it will be even more beautiful after these are complete.

Stunning!. The stained glass is absolutely beautiful! A very impessive place to visit and I know it will be even better once the restorations are finished. I went in the morning when there was a fairly short queue, although I saw when I left it was a lot longer, so I would suggest going early to beat the queue. Also if you are 18-25 and from one of the EU countries you get in free! There are lots of places in Paris where you get in free, so bring your passport along! For young european backpackers Paris is actually surprisingly cheap!

Not sure it was worth it.... This is the type of place where your own taste and preference weighs in a lot - more than what others have to say. The Chapel is nice, no doubt about it, unique and architecture is old Gothic style. But after waiting for over an hour in the pouring rain, with slow security check point, and paying $10 for entrance, it was a bit underwhelming. The first reaction was - "nice" quickly followed by "this is it"? This doesn't show up at the must-sees in your Paris attractions, but was highly recommended by a fellow traveler, but for me personally it was a let down. If you haven't seen stained glass before, then yes, you will like it, but if you have seen more intricate stained glass through your touring, then this is really not that great, it is just OK. There are far better ways to spend your time in Paris, with far more beauty and art. Mind you this is not a church, it used to be one, it is now only a monument.
Nice stained glass...but under repair. This is not a "must see" until they complete the renovations. Lots of nice stained glass and not far from Notre Dame. Go see it, but it won't take very long.

Beautiful Stained Glass!. The glasswork is amazing and well worth seeing. It is more spectacular than Notre Dame. It is best to see it when the light is coming through the glass. It is not handicap accessible as there is a narrow staircase up to the window area. We stood in the middle and just gazed at each panel. Highly recommend it!
Beautiful!. The amazing stained glass windows tell the story of the Bible from beginning to end. Even though the church is having restoration work done right now it was a beautiful sight.

The Stained Glass tells a Story. Cost: 8:50 Euro for Sainte-Chapelle alone or !2:50 Euro for combo ticket with the Conciergerie. Free under age 18. Covered by the Museum Pass. Hours: March-Oct 9:30 - 18:00, Wed until 21:30 mid-May-Mid-Sept, Nov-Feb 9:00-17:00. We bought a combo ticket here for Sainte-Chapelle and the Conciergerie. There was a long line. I suggest you buy the combo ticket at Conciergerie since there was no line there. This 13th century Gothic chapel was built to house Jesus' Crown of Thorns (now kept at Notre Dame and shown only on Good Friday and on the first Friday of the month at 15:00). It was built between 1242 and 1248 for King Louis IX. The stained glass windows are spectacular. Climb the spiral stairs in the corner of the first level to reach the sanctuary where more than 1,100 Bible scenes are illustrated. These cover the entire Christian history of the world. The spire is Neo-Gothic and was added in the 19th century.There are 15 separate panels of stained glass, two thirds of it 13th century original. Each panel tells a story. You really need a travel book to follow the story in each stained glass panel.It was crowded, but it was worth it. Check-out the outside balcony on the 2nd level. Nice carvings not to be missed. A book with color photos is on sale downstairs with the postcards.
Being renovated as of July 2004, avoid. The stained glass was beautiful but it was being renovated when I went. As a result, it was relatively dark inside. The audio tour was mediocre.

This was one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen.. Sainte-Chapelle was the highlight of my trip to Paris, and one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen (I seldom give 5-star ratings). I am not a religious person, but I am an artist, and when I entered the chapel I was moved to tears (not normal for me, I assure you). Never have I had beauty strike me like that. The beauty in and of itself was spectacular, but more inspiring was that such a work of art and engineering could have been done so many hundreds of years ago, and that it has stayed largely intact through two world wars. Some people might see it as just glass and be in and out in 10 minutes, but if art and beauty have the power to change you, this is a must-see.

Beautiful stained glass windows. We almost didn't go visit here until someone told us it was a MUST. The windows in this church are much more spectacular than what you will see in Notre Dame. Best way to see this place is to visit Notre Dame at 8:30 in the morning and then walk the couple of blocks to Sainte Chapelle and see this place as well.

Classical Concert. The stained glass windows are currently being repaired. When we first visited it was much too crowded in the room and oppressive, but we noticed that there was a classical music concert there the same evening. We went to it and were able to get tickets. The performers were wonderful and it was a truly special atmosphere. We were able to sit in a location where we didn't have to look at the reconstruction area.

Breathtaking!. This little church will overwhelm you. The stained glass windows and altars are unbelievable. There are stairs to the upper level, but they are navigable. When we arrived on the upper floor, my daughter cried from the beauty of the windows! They also have a lovely gift shop on the first floor. Unfortunately, the famous Rosace window was being repaired, but it gives us a reason to return!
Amazing stained glass. Visit in the afternoon when the light is streaming through the stained glass windows for effect. Have visited twice. Get the audio tour.

The windows!. This is Paris, so expect to queue (even with your museum pass), I'd suggest always carrying some water with you, especially in the heat. If you've seen pictures of Ste. Chapelle on the internet, the wonder of seeing them in real life is incredible. as with some other places we visited, the french don't really seem yo do maps or signposting very well, so when you finally get in to the building , you'll see ceilings that are blue and gold and you might think "That's it', but there's a spiral staircase behind an information stand, climb it and you reach the main body of the church and there are those windows!Amazing.

Do you like stained glass???. This is a gem. The most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen!! The final stages of restoration are in progress, I wish I had seen it after it was all done but wow - its amazing even 90% complete. Go in with your museum pass, its a short visit as it is tiny compared to the other churches, but it is simply stunning.
Close to Notre Dame, pretty interior. Undergoing repairs so plan for stairs. Pretty interior - traditional cathedral. Stand in line for security clearance.

Vivaldi Concert in Sainte-Chapelle. Can't recommend this highly enough! It was the highlight of our trip. Beautiful space, musicians were so talented--it was a complete joy. Do not miss it! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xen_QhEyLD4
Beautiful!. Loved the stained glass windows and the story of this being built to host the Crown of Thorns placed upon Jesus prior to his crucifiction.

Do not miss Sainte-Chapelle!. This lovely little cathedral is filled with absolutely amazing stained-glass and all kinds of statues and pictures. Some of it is being restored, but they are doing a good job with the restoration and you can still see a lot of this perfect little chapelle! Don't miss it! And the museum pass doesn't work to go to the front of the line here - you have to wait in line.
Not to be missed!. Although there was major renovation of the windows occurring, it was still a wonderful visit, and it was one place where my teenagers were truly impressed!
Just Breathtaking. Been several times. There are concerts as well but very few can be accommodated so get tickets before hand. The stained glass is truly amazing.

Spetacular stained colors. Sainte Chapelle is quite a spectacular cathedral. I enjoyed it's interior even more the Notre Dames where it comes to stain glass. The line was a bit long and snakes around the building where it could be hard to some to figure out it's exact location.Once you get to the front you can purchase tickets. I recommend buying the combined tickets for the Chapel and Conciergerie for 12.50 Euro each adult and kids free. You enter the chapel at the ground floor, walking past some nice carvings and statues at the door frame and side walls. Inside is a brilliant arched dome ceiling with pillars all painted in bright contrasting colors. A view alone which looks enough of a show stopper; but wait there's more -And if you climb the circular stairwell right now you also get an amazing view of cathedral arched ceilings equally painted in vibrant brilliance and surrounding walls of an elaborate kaleidoscope of stained glass windows. It's truly an amazing place. I would have enjoyed it more if it was not so crowded. Getting decent photos was very difficult. I patiently waited long periods for people to move out of the frame. Out the exit and to the left you should immediately see the line for the Conciegerie.
A MUST for every visitor to Paris.. This hidden gem near Notre Dame is a must for every Paris visitor. The stained glass windows in the upper chapel are the most beautiful in the world.

Most Beautiful Site We Saw in Paris. Once the private chapel of the King built to house holy relics, it is now absolutely stunning. Read some history of this chapel before you go. During WWII, Parisians removed every single piece of the stained glass to prevent losing it in bombing runs, and then re-installed after the war.
Extraordinary. Masterpiece of gothic architecture , heart of palais de la cite , we 've been there to a concert , classic music , absolutely fabulous !!!

Beautiful stained glass and music. My wife and I attended a concert there. If you like classical music, THIS IS A MUST! Gorgeous towering stained glass windows and fabulous musicians. Our concert featured a soprano soloist who was amazing. A great kick-off to an evening in Paris.

Like entering a different world. We toured Notre Dame and Sainte-Chapelle on the same early June morning. The Cathedral was impressive and interesting, but by contrast Sainte-Chapelle was like entering a different world all together. There are no words to describe the beauty of this small and awe-inspiring chapel. It was jam-packed when we visited, but we tourists were quiet and collectively intent on examining this rare jewel of medieval times.
Stunning stained glass. This is so easy to miss - you really wouldn't know it was there - but it is a hidden gem. A 13th century chapel, with the most amazing stained glass. A real must-see.
No Rose Window. It is a beautiful place, but the Rose Window is being restored and we were very sad not to see it. Look up, look down (neat floor), look all around. It's just amazing.

DIVINE - GLORIOUSLY BEAUTIFUL. My favorite place to visit in PARIS. I had looked for it one day and then on another day, while part of a walking tour, our guide pointed it out. Oh i was so excited. i had read about ST LOUIS when i was about 10. The line was not terribly long, especially if you compare the wait for Notre Dame. I SO HOPE I CAN GO BACK TO VISIT AGAIN. The colors are spectacular. The audio guide was very informative. Do not miss the opportunity to visit.

Stunning stain glass windows. It is difficult to image that stain glass windows nearly 1000 years old can still be admired. 70% of the windows are original to the contraction of the chapel. You enter via the lower chapel which in and of itself is stunning but the real jewel awaits in the upper chapel with its 14 stain glass ceiling to floor windows.At the rear of the chapel you will find large laminated boards (available in 4-5 languages) that explain how to read the windows.A worthwhile visit!

Under renovation but still spectacular. I love stained glass windows so this was a must-see on my list. With our Paris Museum Passes we gained immediate entry and saved ourselves about 1 hour of time standing in line to get in. We spent about 1/2 hour there. I read the information provided on plastic cards and found that interesting.
Beautiful...short line too!. The glass here is worth the wait outside. On a sunny July day, we waited 20 minutes to get inside, and if stained glass is your thing, I highly recommend.

Beautiful Gothic Chapel. The main attraction here is the upper Chapelle which hosts 15 huge stained glasses. Currently restoration is in progress. A placard informing the brief history about the Chapelle is available inside. This Chapelle stands for strong ethical senses. You don't need more than 1 hour to see this monument and gather some beautiful pics.
Awesome. Well worth waiting for the French lunch break (1300 - 1400). The stained glass windows were superb despite some of the building being under restoration.

My favorite place we visited. I missed this little jewel in my first trip to paris. So glad we found it this time. Absolutely the best and most stained glass windows in one place. Renovations are ongoing so it was difficult to get the full feel. Paris museum pass works here. We were able to walk right up ahead of those waiting to buy passes. No wait for us. Under 18 was free.

Awesome stain glass. Small chapel, but fabulous stain glass windows. Under restoration during our visit, but most places in Europe currently seem to be right now. However, it was still worth the visit for the windows alone.

Crowd Control Issues. The visit started poorly. The line up to purchase tickets was not well managed. There were lots of people and a fair number of staff but they seemed more interested in chatting among themselves, rather than providing assistance. There was a surprising amount of line cutting by one nationality, in particular. I thought a second revolution might start at any minute and none of the staff seemed to care.The church is under quite a bit of renovation. You enter the lower level filled with souvenir counters and ascend via a very narrow staircase to the upper chapel where the view is breathtaking. It houses some of the oldest stain glass in Paris depicting scenes from Genesis to the crucifixion. The Rose window is stunning.Purchasing the audio guide was a waste of money. Producing a good audio guide is quite the science and art form, in itself. This one was bad - information overload and boring in its presentation. The sound quality wasn't great either. I would recommend doing your own research before you go, maybe make a few notes or highlight your guide book. Like some other churches in Paris, this one hosts evening concerts because of the acoustics but given the limited space, we couldn't imagine where they would take place.

A first - a Sunday Night Concert inside the church. Sainte-Chapelle is a place I have visited on all of my visits to Paris ~ this time we were able to attend a concert (albeit a hot evening) inside the chapel itself. The sounds/the sights were magical. I am not sure how many more concerts their are during the summer but this is a special treat. I think about 100 people can attend, maybe a little more, so it is intimate in attendance and surroundings. (5 persons - 3 violinists, a cello and a harpsichordist ~ wow and I am not a classical concert goer ~

Most beautifull thing in Paris. As the title reads, the most beautiful thing you can visit in Paris, forget about Eiffel tower and Louvre and come visit this. Try to visit this while sunny, the colors of the colored glasses are just incredible!

Concert series is PHENOMENAL experience. 6 piece string concert that was lead with by an enthusiastic, very personable and talented violinist. 3 other violinists, pianist, and cello. Lively music, 1 hour with no break. I will return for other series while living in Paris this summer. The setting at 7pm was perfect lighting. Buy the seats up front to capture the spirit of each professional. Although they move among the congregation during the performance.

Worth of seeing. The uniqueness of this chapel is an atmosphere made by light going through huge colorful stained glass windows and a big rosette window in the center. It's a really amazing experience. There's no place like this.

Many windows, difficult to see everything. We visited Sainte-Chapelle on a Sunday morning after worshipping at Notre Dame and visiting the bird and flower market. It was a beautiful church, with beautiful examples of stained glass. The church itself seemed small and crowded, and does not have the same atmosphere as an active, working church. The tour did not take a long time, so it is worth a quick stop on a walk through the neighborhood. Included in museum pass.

Amazing. Amazing little chapel. Part of the former royal palace, this chapel is worth the low entrance fee. The glass-in-lead windows in the upper chapel are amazing. The lower chapel would be pretty if they hadn't filled it up with these church shops. Such a shame

Pleasure and dissappointment. The Sainte-Chapelle was built by Louis IX, in the 13th century as a prestigious palace chapel. It is one of the little jewels of Paris. Not as important and well known as the Notre Dame but very unique and significant.Don’t miss the upper chapel since this is the main attraction with its 15 stain glass windows and a large rose window. (ha,ha).Originally 15 , its true, but how many can you see because of the ongoing renovation? Do they reduce the price of the ticket as they reduce the number of windows you can see? I think you don’t need my answer.The ground level is attractive as well, but for me a gift shop in chapel or church, always ruins my experience.I’m not religious, but going into a church, or chapel I constantly remember some quotations from the New Testament .“And Jesus entered the temple and drove out all those who were buying and selling in the temple…” "Take these things away; stop making My Father's house a place of business."Obviously Jesus is dead from nearly 2000 years ago, so there is no one to clear out his father’s house anymore.My overall rating of this attraction according to the current situation.

Beautiful stained glass windows. My advice to travellers is to go to the Conciergierie (just down the street) and buy a joint admission ticket. It means you can return to Sainte-Chapelle and avoid the line. A decadent church with incredible stained glass windows upstairs. The renovations occurring when I visited to diminish the atmosphere somewhat

Stunning Stained Glass. Small chapel not far from Notre Dame. Climb upstairs is worth it for the beautiful stained glass.Carvings are interesting as well and it is a nice change of pace from the busyness of other places

Expensive Admission But Under Renovation!. Be aware that a good portion of the chapel is under renovation and cannot be viewed. I was very disappointed considering the very high price of admission. The stained glass and architecture is amazing but it was disappointing not being able to see the chapel in it's full splendour.

Stained Glass Galore. A beautiful but small church (upstairs is where the beauty really is).TIP: Go to Conciergerie and purchase the combined ticket for Conciergerie and Sainte-Chapelle. It's about 12.50 euros I think. Check out Conciergerie (only 30-60 mins) and then head over to Sainte-Chapelle, and skip the long ticket-purchase line outside.

Must see. When you think of how long ago this was created it is amazing. The beautiful windows are created by only 5 colors of glass. Each window depicts a chapter in the bible. Make sure to take in the statues as well as the windows.
Most beautiful vitrals. Comparing to Capela Sixtina in Rome I think St Chapelle is more interesthing,more appealing. Prepare for wait in line.

So colorful. Beautiful chapel with stained glass windows - good to have guide to explain you what you see.
I also loved the interier of the bottom chapel, which was nicely colorfully painted.

Superb stained glass. Superb stained glass, but our visit was affected by queues and renovations.
Inside the windows were so intricate with minimal stonework.

Light of the world..... Simply the most stunning of all the cathedrals in Paris in our opinion. It is small and quaint (comparatively at least) but the stained glass is amazing.
