It was built in only 6 years so the architecture all fits together better than the most of the other cathedrals. If I had to choose one cathedral in Paris to show to someone this would be it.

Paris should be ashamed of rude guards screaming at visitors. If this incident had occurred in the USA, or anywhere else, it would be an immense shame upon the site and could never be accepted. I am appalled that The Centre des Monuments Nationaux could tolerate such disgusting behavior toward visitors.On the afternoon of Thursday, 24 July 2014, my family and I paid a visit to Sainte Chapelle. We had received high recommendations from friends who have visited in the past, and were eager to see the beautiful 13th century gothic architecture and stained glass. We were a group of six American adults and waited in the general line with everyone else for over 30 minutes in the scorching afternoon sun to enter. As we approached security check, a second line began to form. There was a sign reading something to the effect of "Museum pass holders this line" with an arrow pointing to the second line, and at least 30 other people left the general line, thinking that the gate keepers decided to expedite the process to relieve the congestion. If this sign had been so clear, why did so many people make this "mistake"? We were less than 3 meters from the checkpoint and in this chaotic moment, we too left our post to join the other pass holders. As we approached, the security guards began yelling at us that our passes did not grant us special privileges, and that we need to go back to the end of the line. Although both were rude, the taller one (about 180 cm) was extremely belligerent, and began screaming wildly at me, no farther than 30cm from my face. As a 157cm tall 51kg small Asian girl, I felt it incredibly intimidating, disrespectful, vulgar, and insulting to have a 180cm tall man screaming in my face -- not just in English or French, but a third language that I did not know. Since the man had a middle-eastern complexion, I can only assume it might be Persian or Arabic. He was not using reason to explain. He was using size, volume, and station to bully and terrorize us.Since English was our primary language, he stopped speaking English to us -- telling us in English that he did not speak it. We tried to get back into the general line where we were, but all three guards refused to let us pass through the metal detectors without going through the entirety of the line again. We asked to speak with the supervisor, and one of them rudely told us that he was the supervisor (he was clearly not) and continued to insult us. When we asked to speak with the police, the gendarme who came was also extremely rude and would not listen to reason. Other people who got back in line were not turned away. Perhaps it was because we were from the USA and spoke English, or perhaps three of the six members of our group were East Asian (Chinese). Whatever the reason, we were the ONLY group that were denied entry at that point, and I am convinced their racial discrimination played no small part. As a first-time visitor to France, this experience gave me the most unsavory sentiment that the French --especially the gendarme -- have the least amount of class and respect out of all of the countries I have visited. If this is not true, Parisians should be more than ashamed to have men like these in their midst.
If concerts in Paris are your thing.... This magnificent gem is world famous - best enjoyed during a concert. Book in advance but be prepared to be dazzled.

Breath-taking. perhaps the most outstanding stained glass in the world. Some renovation taking place to the windows at present, but 4 out of 16 at a time, so bearable. Go early to avoid the crowds which had built up greatly with long queues around id-day.

Sainte Chapelle. If you can only do one thing in Paris....this is it....and to get the full impact of this tiny masterpiece of stained glass...attend the concert given in the evenings....the combination of the visual and the music in incredible....

Glory covered by scaffolding. This is another of those medieval masterpieces that needs to be seen to be believed. But maybe not right now. An entire section of the chapel, including the famous rose window, is covered by scaffolding, and the sounds of the restorers echo through the entire structure. So I might check ahead of my visit and see it another time.

Breathtaking!. Sainte-Chapelle is just stunning. The stained glass is like nothing I had ever seen before. How wonderful it was to see how they are restoring some of the stained glass....bit by bit. Put this on your list for sure!

Breathtaking. Didn't like the long line and 8.5 euro fee (to cover renovation cost), but it's worth it. When you walk in you go 'Huh' until you discover the little stone staircase at the back and wind up to the upper level and go.....well, do it yourself and see. The windows are mind-blowingly impressive. Unfortunately, rose window at back is covered for repair, but still worth it.

Unbelievable. Of all of the sights we saw in our 4 days in Paris, this was perhaps the most amazing. And it was raining so you don't need it to be a sunny day. This stained glass must be seen to be believed. And loved having a museum pass so we could walk right in, by the long line of people waiting in the rain to buy tickets.

Petite- but stunning. Sainte Chapelle wouldn't be on my "must do" list, but it is nonetheless a beautifully-designed chapel and can be seen in its entirety in less than an hour. If you aren't so into architecture or stained glass windows, perhaps it is better to make sure you see Notre Dame and save this for another time. That said, if you have the time, you will not be disappointed!

A Little Short Of Expectations. I hope not to offend with this review. I still gave this iconic chapel 4 stars. There was quite a long line to get in and there is no shortcut for the Paris Pass. There is a lot of construction in and around the facility. Nevertheless I felt I needed to see the Sainte-Chapelle interior. I did. I was surprised how small the large stained glass chapel seemed. The workmanship was sublime and remarkable for it's time. I had just come from the Famiilia Sagrada in Barcelona and it's stunning interior and I think this led to my let down. My apologies if I have offended.
Vert Nice. We had read about Sainte-Chapelle on here and were glad we went its very beautiful well worth a visit.There was a short line on the day we went but nothing like Notre Dame,Louvre

Concert!!!!. We saw a concert her on our honeymoon 20 years ago and went again with our two children this time. It was amazing!! The sound was fantastic and the musicians were amazing. Worth every penny. You have to go. You can book online at st. chapelle concerts.

Beautiful glass windows..... It is a nice handcraft work from 1240s, a small chapel but withrich decoration, it is worthwhile to pay a visit, maybe you may spend more time in the queue than in the interior, the secutity check is very slow . Very close to the Cite station.The glass windows are beautiful, the interior of the chapel is very detailed too. If you appreciate the interior work of a chapel and history, a good place to go. A 8.50 euros for on spot tickets. July 2014.

Worth the ticket price to go in!!. This was such a beautiful building!! Completely worth the entrance price as you will not get the true feeling or beauty of this building by just looking at it from the outside.

Magical. Have you never been inside a jewel box? Then you need to go to the Sainte-Chapelle. Acres (hectares) of stained glass with only slivers of wall separating them. Incredible recreated polychromatic paint scheme that will change your conception of Gothic church interiors.

Only go if you're REALLY, REALLY, REALLY into stain glass. I was looking forward to seeing a grand abbey...what a disappointment. It was €8.50 to walk into a chapel that was 10 metres long with some stain glass. You then go upstairs to see another room with LOTS of stain glass. Sometimes a lot of 1 thing is never enough. In this chapel it is the opposite, there is so much stain glass it just looks...yuk. That was all there was to see! Very disappointed, Considering we had earlier visited St Sulpice, that was free to visit and really good.

Lines are horridly slow, but it's lovely. You have to go through "security" here due to its location, and museum cards won't get you a line jump. ("Security" consisting of one xray and two metal detectors, one of which wasn't turned on but they acted like it was. Annoying.) The chapel itself is beautiful, and it's a great stop for history and art junkies. Many of the windows are covered right now due to restoration work, but we enjoyed our time there.

Oldest Part of Paris. Look for the original address numbers painted high on building walls, before the advent of number plaques. Look for everyone's favorite ice cream. Great hidden tea salons. Quiet and lovely for people who like to feel they've gone back in time.

Better than Notre Dame. Notre Dame is dark and foreboding inside. Sainte-Chapelle is light and airy. Unfortunately, several of the windows are undergoing restoration, so there is covered scaffolding in a portion of the chapel. Since both churches are close, you would probably want to do both, but if you only had one to choose, for visual impact, I would choose Sainte-Chapelle.

Leave your Swiss Army knife at home!. This is a lovely Cathedral and well worth a visit. Amazing stained glass windows nearly finished from a great restoration. You still can't see the main large circular window which was a pity. Leave knives at home as I had to hide mine outside behind a post as they will not let you in with one! No queues when we went!

Under renovation. The renovation works are a detracting feature while the works are taking place. Also, this place is relatively small and I do not consider it worth the entry fee and the time spent (money and time which could have been spent on other attractions in Paris).

A little night music. Attended Vivaldi concert in the glory of this wondrous stained glass gothic cathedral. Yes, they do the concert most nights but the musicians perform as if you were the most important audience they desired to impress. Fabulous and memorable.

Don't miss this. We almost didn't stop in -- what's one more church with stained glass, right? Wrong! The stained glass is truly amazing and worth the time. It was worth it even with some windows covered for restoration.
Wow. Wow! Just wow! You have to do it! try to go before noon, 'cause the light in it is so amazing! Unfortunately, we went when it was in restoration, so some of the glasses were hidden!

Vivaldi: The Four Seasons, at La Sainte Chapelle. My wife and I spent a wonderful evening at a concert in La Sainte Chapelle on 22 July. Summer in Paris is characterised by many wonderful concerts in a variety of churches. The concert we went to at La Sainte Chapelle was Vitali's "Chaconne pour violin"; Pachelbel's "Canon" and Antonio Vivaldi's "the Four Seasons". It was performed by Classik Ensemble who are world class performers. They played beautifully, engaged with the audience and appeared to be thoroughly enjoying their work, which in turn rubbed off on the audience. We found about about the concert on Sunday morning, bought our tickets on Sunday afternoon and attended the concert on Sunday evening. The next day we found out about a piano recital that was to be held in Eglise Saint-Julian-le-Pauvre, which is one of the oldest if not the oldest Church in Paris, on the following evening. The programme by Jean-Christophe Millot included works by Beethoven and Chopin. We bought our tickets at the Church a half hour before the performance and had another wonderful evening of superb music. Any visitor to Paris during the Summer season who is at all interested in going to wonderful concerts in astonishing venues should look for them in advance to take advantage of them. We paid 25 and 23 Euros respectively for our tickets which we considered to be wonderful value for what was presented. At both venues were were within 3 to 5 metres of the performers. Web sites that have information about concerts are www.euromusicproductions.fr for concerts at La Sainte Chapelle and www.concertinparis.com for concerts at St Julian Le Pauvre. Classical music concerts in Churches in Paris are also being held this Summer at Eglise Saint Ephrem in Rue des Carmes, Eglise de La Madeleine in Place de La Madeleine, Eglise St Germain des Pres off the Boulevarde St Germain and in Notre Dame Cathedral on the Isle de Cite.
Magnificent!. In many ways more beautiful and easier to tour than Notre Dame!We hadn't planned on seeing Sainte Chapelle but our private guide recommended it - beautiful and more intimate than ND.

Wait til the work is completed. I went to see the magnificient stained glass windows but was disappointed that many were under reconstruction. With a significant part of the windows covered it is difficult to follow the guided tour. I would recommend you wait until the work is completed. There's a lot to see in Paris

Beautiful stained glass windows . The Sainte Chappelle is very beautiful on the inside due to the stained glass. The second floor especially is visually appealing. The line was 15-20 minutes when we went (9:30) buy were smaller when we left at 10:30.They were making renovations on some of the glass when we were there but you could still see most of it. They also had a video of the renovation process which was interesting.
Stunning. Undergoing renovations to the exterior, but this tiny chapel is colorful and breath-taking. There are several other points of interest within walking distance

A true gem!. This was my second visit to Sainte Chappelle...such a gem of a church. Some of the stained glass is still under repair but the rest was just as stunning as I remembered. The lower chapel was lovely, but the upper chapel is gorgeous. I highly recommend a visit to anyone in Paris.

If you want to know what gothic means.... ...than you should visit the Sainte-Chapelle. Make sure there are no clouds and having the sun in the right direction. At that moment you can experience what gothic means. This is THE example of this medieval building style.

A definite go! But not the concert, if.... As honkrattlecrashbeep said - forget the lower chamber and go straight to the upper chamber with the most amazing stain glass windows - there are 15 huge (it is a Gothic chapel afterwards) panels. Couple of the panels and the rose window are covered as they are undergoing restoration now.As to the handicapped access - honkrattlecrashbeep is not completely correct - Sainte-Chapelle is part of a bigger complex that is the French Palace of Justice - there is a special elevator cabin in the same building that would take a wheelchair right to the upper chamber floor.We also went to an evening concert in the chapel by the group called "Euromusic". Tonight it was Vivaldi "Four Seasons" and two other pieces. If you are a serious lover of classical music and have a discerning ear, don't go to these concerts - it felt like the group just got together for specific purpose to make you suffer. However if many wrong notes, terrible dissonance of the players and absolutely untrue to the score rendition of the piece will not disturb you, then enjoy the gorgeous chapel under accompaniment of unknown to you sounds...

Don't let the fact it is hidden behind a nondescript building fool you, a must see.. One of the 3 must see churches in Paris and it is near Notre Dame. It is a unique design with breath taking stained glass. Many people miss it, because it was a royal chapel and is hidden behind the walls of the old fortress which has morphed into a government building. You can only see the steeple peeking above.

Stained glass miracle. Though I was short on time, I had to make a quick detour just to check out the famed stained glass work. Half of it was closed due to restoration work, and it was interesting to actually learn how the painstaking process works. It's just around the corner from Notre Dame, so drop by if you can!

Go Upstairs For The Real View. The line for Saint Chapell was shorter than the one for Notre Dame so we went in. I had heard about the wonderful stained glass; it was on my list of must-sees for Paris. The lower chapel was a disappointment. It was quite dirty, under renovation (but you don't know that until you have paid the 8 euros) and had an obnoxious gift shop just inside the entry. We took a look around and headed to the door disappointed, Then we noticed a tiny spiral staircase as we were leaving. Up 33 narrow steps and WOW you are in the main chapel with magnificent stained glass.(Photos attached.) As with all Paris attractions, if you are handicapped you are barred from Sainte Chapelle unless someone carries you in and up the stairs, which would not really be possible due to the size.

Beautiful, but currently under renovation. Initially had thought that we would run out of time before getting to Sainte Chapelle, but after seeing a miniature version of it at the Paris Architecture Museum, decided that we could not miss it, even though it would be closed soon. We had walked around it a few times, and it turns out that the reason that it had not made much impression initially was that a lot of it was covered in scaffolding and drapery as it's undergoing a major renovation. Because of this, be prepared that you will get to see the Lower Chapel, and you'll be able to see a very small portion of the Upper Chapel, but most of it is closed to the public. On the plus side, there is a nice video of how they go about painstakingly preserving and refurbishing the stained glass windows, which are spectacular, even in the limited view of the chapel. If you are traveling under the Paris Museum Pass, you don't mind that you are only getting to see part of the church, since you are not individually paying for tickets anyway.

Would love to return after the renovations. We lined up for about half an hour before going through security. It was good to read a little bit of information about the renovation process, but it was very disappointing that we couldn't see the rose window. Even though we went on an overcast day, there was still plenty of light coming through so that the scenes and colours were clearly visible. It would've been great to have a little more seating though, especially to sit down and read the information cards about the different windows which were in several languages.

What a terrible experience!. I have visited Sainte-Chapelle before and found it a fantastic place full of historical significance and beauty. That was 30 years ago... Now, however, somebody has permitted the desecration of the place by building a completely tasteless souvenir shop smack in the central isle. I simply didn't believe my eyes! GET THAT SHOP OUT NOW!!! The two start review is for what is left of the fantastic place - certainly not for the Sainte-Chapelle the way it looks now!

More interesting than Notre Dame!. If I had to choose between visiting Notre Dame and Sainte Chapelle, I'd go for Sainte Chapelle.This has been a place of worship since Medieval times and the art work is truly extraordinary, as are the current efforts to preserve its treasures for prosterity!It was recommended to me by my French teacher and for good reason.Make a visit a priority for a very different church to the big cathedrals full of renaissance work and later.This goes back to way earlier times and traditions!

must see church in paris. The glasses on the church are so beautiful. It is undergoing renovation but still worth the visit to see the church. There is a line up and it is common in paris for all attractions.

Better than Notre Dame?. While not as historic, I'd say pretty confidently that the interior of Ste. Chapelle is easily more gorgeous than that of Notre Dame; and is the second-most-beautful church I have ever been in (behind the Church on the Spilled Blood in St. Petersburg).Even the 'commoners'' chapel downstairs is plenty beautiful! But then one goes upstairs and has one's mind blown by gorgeous stained glass everywhere.

Beautiful but Renovated!. The upper chapel of the Sainte Chapelle was beautiful. The tall stained glass was amazing. However, it was under renovation. It was dark in the chapel because it rained outside. It is best to visit on the sunny day. We had online tickets to avoid the long lines.
lovely. This is the most amazing chapel I have ever visited. The upper chapel took my breath away. Well worth the price and the wait.
Speechless...magnificent. As soon as you walk up the spiral stairs and enter the hall, it's mesmerizing. One of the most beautiful sights in Paris for sure.

Stained glass perfection. Unfortunately restoration prevents the enjoyment of all the glorious panels when I last visited. It, however, allowed my focus to remain on what was unobstructed. And, I still found myself in awe of the work.

Second best stained glass in Europe. Ste Chapelle is sometimes overlooked because many tourists visit Notre Dame and are unaware of Ste Chapelle. Apart from Chartres (south of Paris), Ste Chapelle has the most stunning stained glass in all of Europe. The scale is awesome, and the colors are magnificent. The chapel architecture itself is lovely, but for me, this is all about the fantastic glass. Ste Chapelle also hosts numerous classical music concerts. If you have time and inclination, I recommend seeing a concert in this unique and beautiful venue.

Not your typical chapel. This chapel is not your usual chapel and is well worth the visit. Unusual in that it two floors with two separate places to worship. Great history. Stain glassed windows in the upper chapel are remarkable.Warning - undergoing some renovation but does not really take away too much from the visit. Also line was long when we visited in a July. I would suggest that you enter through the nearby Concerierge.

Lovely concert - too bad it's being renovated. The concert was a great way to experience Sainte-Chapelle. We ordered via billetreduc.com which worked perfectly - had middle seats for 23 Euro a piece. Our daughter didn't need a ticket at all at age 4, nor a reservation. Just brought her along. It was fantastic to look at the beautiful stained glass windows while enjoying a concert. Unfortunately about a quarter of Sainte Chapelle is covered by scaffolding etc and cannot be viewed at all. I was just as glad we hadn't paid full admission price to just look at the Chapel.
Read the history. This was on my list of places to see. Lovely architecture and paintings. Long lines so reach early. Used Paris Pass but no separate line for entry.

Simply amazing colours. An amazing place. Be prepared to queue, as ever in Paris in summer. Still it was worth it to get there early and wait in the shade of beautiful big trees. You enter the lower part of the building and have to take the steep curving stairs besides the door to get up to see the fabulous windows. It was a bright sunny day outside so the glass being hit by the sunshine simply sparkled. The only down side is the ongoing renovation to the glass meant that not all the windows were visible. Definitely worth seeing and not a place where you have to wander and wander. No getting lost here. Just grab a seat (if you can) and sit and marvel.
Fantastic stain glass. The stain glass windows are great, but they are renovating the rose at the back of the church. They also have some evening concerts here.

Such great skill. Our first tourist inspection in Paris where, having watched many people go past us in the queue, we purchased a Paris Museum Pass that became so worthwhile thereafter. Having not seen anything so old before, it was astounding to see the skill of the early engineers and the breathtaking stained glass windows.

Never loses its wonder. This glorious small chuch is intimate, delicate and imparts a curious sense of mystery. It is top of my list of must-sees every time I go to Paris. The narrow stained glass panels and the Moorish-influenced brightly painted columns on two floors, set it apart from any other church in the city or in Europe. It is unfortunate that those responsible for Sainte-Chapelle have allowed more commercial enterprise within the church. It takes away from the sanctity of the space. the construction underway in the spring of 2014 means part of the chapel is unavailable to visitors but it is still well worth a visit. If you plan to attend any church concerts in Paris, this is a wonderful space in which to do that.
Amazing vitraux. This unique, well preserved chapelle will take yor breath away.Could not see all the vitraux because it was some maintenance works under way.Don´t miss the sainte chapelle!

Nice place to stop. If you get the Museum pass you can skip the second line - there is one outside on the street you cannot skip. Once you get past the wall, you can skip to the front.Nice stained glass windows. Nothing too special. Go see it, but if the line is more than about 20-25 min, skip or come back later.
Beautiful Stained Glass. These stained glass windows portraying bible stories are amazing. It was disappointing that the rose window was being worked on and was not available for visitors.

Beautiful Church. First off, there is a bit of a line to get into this church, but not even ¼ of the size of line for Notre Dame. That doesnt mean it is less beautiful, in fact it was more beautiful! The stain glass windows are marvelous and depict Bible stories, which are well-described by the provided information boards. Worth a visit!

Best all around site in Paris!. Just one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. Wow, the stained glass depictions are simply stunning. If you look closely, you'll see that almost all major biblical events are depicted in the windows. If you're a fan of stained glass this is a must, and as a fan of stained glass, this is the top site in Paris in my eyes.

Sainte-chapelle. One of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen. The stain glass windows, that tell the story of the Bible from creation to revelation, was breathtaking! It doesn't take long to see and should not be missed on your visit to paris.

Go for the concerts and the stunning stained glass. This 13th century church is small compared to many more recent religious buildings in Paris, but its interior has to be seen to be believed. The stained glass which fills the interior with multi-coloured light has to be seen to be believed. There are regular evening concerts held here which, although not cheap, are a real must: the accoustics are every bit as good as the intricate windows and walls.

Concerts in a great space. A stunning place! My first visit years ago during the day, after a long time in a line, was unforgettable. But since then I have discovered the evening concerts! I can sit down and enjoy the place quietly, and then a quartet plays Vivaldi!! Wow!!

Stained glass wonder. The intimacy and great beauty of Sainte-Chapelle draws us back to a time and place where such opulence was only enjoyed by the aristocracy. I am grateful that treasures such as this are open to all to enjoy.

Worth the long lines. You will probably have to line up just to get through security. Then you will have to line up again to buy your tickets (in our case for 30 minutes) and remember, the rose windows are not even on show, they are being renovated.But these little disappointments are completely forgotten as you wend your way up the circular staircase and feast your eyes for the first time on the most beautiful stained glass windows imaginable. The colours are strikingly vivid but it's the scale of the thing that inmpresses. 270 degrees of soaring colour and brightness. Worth the wait!

Breathtakingly beautiful. Sainte-Chapelle has the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. This is my favorite church in Paris. We got to go to a concert here. I highly recommending searching with Google to see if there are concert tickets available while you are in town.

Sainte Chapelle - absolutely amazing!!. Sainte Chapelle is a small royal chapel, around the corner from Notre Dame. The stained glass windows in the upstairs chapel are incredible - the vibrant blues, reds and gold are extraordinary. There is an enormous rose window at one end and the other walls are beautiful panels of the most mind-blowing stained glass. It has an air of peace and tranquility, despite the many tourists. Although the queue usually looks long, it moves fairly quickly. This is definitely one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen. It is not grand, but rather it is quite personal and therefore more meaningful. Not to be missed!

Breathtaking!. I don't know there aren't more visitors to Paris running around and raving about this place. Once inside the upstairs chapel, one is surrounded by fifteen or so gorgeous stained glass windows, each focused on a different section of scripture. The effect of the late morning light streaming through those incredibly colorful relics of 800 years or so was absolutely incredible. Unfortunately, the rose window was undergoing restoration and we were unable to view it, but I can't imagine it being any more breathtaking than it was when we experienced it. In addition to the stained glass, try to get a good look at some of the other ornamentation on the walls - there are small paintings, carvings and enamel or porcelain work throughout the room that really need to be looked at. It is remarkable to me that this structure has survived the years in such good condition. Don't miss this.
What a wonderful chapel!!. This is the most beautiful chapel I have ever seen! The stained glass panels in this glorious site is amazing. This is a must see!!

Transfixed by its beauty. We just left Notre Dame where I thought we had seen the best. My wife says I want to See Sainte-Chapelle. I say "San what?" Who am I to say no... so we marched over to the place and waited in line for about 20 minutes. We paid our 8.5 Euros apiece and entered a small dark church with really nice stain glass windows and a gift shop. Okay... is that all there is? I knew that something was amiss when my sweetie volunteers to climb a spiral staircase to something called the "upper chapel". She hates spiral staircases. At the top was an unbelievable church with absolutely fabulous stained glass surrounding it's entire perimeter. Very little space was wasted with stone buttresses and mullions. I was transfixed by it's beauty only to learn that the piece de resistance, the rose window, was blocked from view as part of a restoration. Guess we'll have to go back next year after they celebrate the 800th anniversary of this wonderful church.

Favorite Paris Cathedral. Sainte-Chapelle is small and often overlooked. Near Notre Dam, who wants to see another church? But well worth a look-in. The stained glass windows are most beautiful; the pained walls and columns show you what the medievals saw when they went to worship.

Stained glass windows. I am not really sure if it is actually a must see in Paris. Surely, if you enjoy stained glass window in churches you should visit St Chapel, otherwise I am not sure you should bother to spend your time or your money for the ticket. There is usually a long line, except if you are lucky.

Magnificent. The Cathedral Sainte-Chapelle is stunning with stained glass windows completely surrounding you. Make sure that you go when the sun is shining to accentuate the beauty of the windows. There is some renovation going on as of July 2014, but it doesn't diminish the visit. Beautiful.

An Absolute Must. Skip all of those other must see sites and start here. It is so gorgeous I can't even describe it. And on a rainy day at that. Small waiting line and 8.5 Euros. All the other tourists are standing in the rain for 2 hours waiting to get into Notre Dame. I've been to both and there's no comparison, Sainte Chapelle is the winner
Always beautiful. We never tire of the beauty of the glass windows and their story,it is a do not miss on your trip!The location is close to Norte Dame,about two blocks .

Stunning stained glass windows. Although the main rose window is under renovation, the stained glass windows that you can see are truly stunning. It is like standing in a jewel box or a kaleidoscope of multi colors! If you have time, take a moment to read the info cards which explain the details of the windows, the stories that the are illustrated in each section of the windows. Really breathtaking!

Breathtaking!. Bought a joint ticket beforehand when we visited the Conciergerie so didn't have to join the long queue. Amazing chapel with the most stunning stained-glass windows - a shame some of them are covered over due to restoration but this is due to finish this year. A must visit place.

Stunning, want to see it post-reno. Saw a concert here and what a gorgeous setting. Unfortunately maybe 1/3 of the windows were covered, so will hopefully be able to see it some day in all its glory. Time your visit for a sunny day for most impressive effect. If you want to get a concert ticket do NOT line up, they sell tickets (starting at 25E) at the Tabac across the street. Decent string orchestra, but played for less than an hour. Would recommend.

Head up the stairs. first floor is nice but the really beauty is upstairs. Plan some time just to absorb all the colors and the stories each panel tells. Try to get a card describing each section. The English box was empty until just before we left. Be prepared for long lines even if you have a museum pass. SECURITY check points are the reason. Don't try to be an "ugly American" by going to the front of the line just because you have the pass. Most of us had the passes but we waited our turn and understood the reasons for the security concerns all over Paris. We did not learn of the terror plots until we returned to the states in early July. So be forewarned and patient about long lines in most places.

Truly amazing. It was suggested that I go here by a friend and having just toured Notre Dame I was thinking of passing on this. Glad I didn't. Most amazing stained glass you will ever see. Note you must go up a narrow staircase to see it. We almost missed the second floor which is simply beautiful. I was told the glass depicts the entire bible frame by frame. It does not take long to go through (30 minutes for me) as it is a small cathedral but worth visiting.
Staggering beauty. This is my favorite place in Paris. It is almost a spiritual experience being there. I highly recommend one of the daily concerts held on summer evenings.
Sainte Chapelle- best stained glass windows. Although the queues was 100m long it moved very quickly. Part of the windows were under repair but still most was exposed for incredible viewing.

Amazing. Well worth the visit just to view the incredible stained glass windows and architecture. We returned that evening for a violin concert that was a trip highlight. The line can be long, but moves reasonably quickly. Advance tickets do not seem to be of much value as the ticket line after security is not long.

Just gorgeous!. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see while in Paris. Although damaged during the French revolution, and restored in the 19th century, it retains one of the most extensive in-situ collections of 13th-century stained glass anywhere in the world.As previously mentioned, the lines for Sainte-Chapelle are long, but with the Museum pass you get to skip the line and go directly to security. However, the security line is not advertised so most just stay in the ticket line. We decided to wander around the ticket line and found the security entrance with no line at all!!! This can make a huge difference in your valuable time in Paris, lines are long everywhere, great perk with the Museum pass.Sainte-Chapelle is part of the Conciergerie and le Palais de Justice. Once inside head directly to the second floor and be amazed! The stained glass is breathtakingly beautiful! There is renovation work but you still can see most of the glass and it is all worth it.

If only they didn't sell sovenirs inside the church. This is worth seeing and the lines are quicker than at the Notre Dame cathedral nearby. The stained glass windows are really beautiful, not as big as in Notre Dame but then this is a fairly small chapel not a cathedral. I was surprised to see souvenir shops inside not far from the altar, Pity Christ was not there to throw them out like in the New Testament. However, we saw similar stalls in the Notre Dame just they aren't so conspicuous because the cathedral is so much bigger.

The Most Beautiful Chapel in the world. I'd heard about St Chapelle but was not prepared for the interior of this jewel.As you reach the top of the steps and enter the chapel you're speechless. The light coming through the stained glass is indescribable. Pictures of the interior are like pictures of the Grand Canyon, they don't prepare you for the sight.I've taken people into St.Chapelle and always want to be first through the door so I can see their face when they walk in the first time. Everyone is awestruck. You will be too.DO NOT MISS St. Chapelle.

Gorgeous Little Chapel. Sainte-Chapelle is a small but gorgeous chapel. There are two floors, however, the ground floor is really just an introduction and gift shop. The real beauty is upstairs. There are 15 stain glass windows and a large rose window. The chapel was built in the mid 13th century to house the relics of the passion of Christ. Unfortunately, they were doing renovations so there was scaffolds covering up the large rose window and a few of the stain glass windows. They did have a video showing the renovation and it was cool to see all that goes into it. I think it is still worth the trip as the place is beautiful. There is an audio guide that provides fantastic information. It is truly needed to fully understand the beauty all around you. Sainte-Chapelle opens at 9:30 and I would be there when they first open. Unfortunately they only have one security check point and it moves very slow.

Wonderful Stained Glass- A must see!. This quaint, small church is an easy walk. Located on the on the Île de la Cite and built by King Louis IX to house the holy relics. The architecture and stained glass is unbelievable! Well worth the wait in line!

Fiat lux. "Let there be light".. From the outside this is not much of a site. It sits cheek by jowl with the Palais de Justice so security to get into the area is tight. This could make for long lines unless one goes early in the day. The ground floor entrance is rather dark but that only makes the experience of the main room that much more spectacular. There are a pair of circular stone stairways that lead up to the main space. And once you are in, the light overwhelmes. Overcast days are best because the light evens out. The stained glass is simply marvelous. One word of caution though. The chapel is undergoing restoration so expect scaffolding both inside and out. Not all the glass panels are obscured, just be aware that this exists. There are toilets to your left after going thru security and i would advise using them as public toilets in the area are rather scarce. I didn't give this highest marks because of the work going on. I want to see it once all that is completed.

Don't miss the windows. It was a bit of a disappointment as we went at the time when the chapel windows were being renovated; however, it was absolutely lovely to see the rest of the stained glass windows. These windows are just amazing. Actually, we almost missed the stairs going up to the part of the chapel with the windows so don't miss it! The stairs are very small and are right next to the entrance of the chapel. The ground floor is basically just a huge gift shop already.For me, just the windows are "wow." it's ranked #2 for me after the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona.
Wonderful. Fabulous experience to see the glass windows. Unfortunately part was covered up by restorations but still wonderful., Make time to visit Marie Antoinnette's prison next door.
Sublime. My favourite Parisien chapel - a must see - get there early for no crowds in summer - can buy Ickes that let you into other attractions for a discounted rate

How to avoid the lines. Buy a ticket for a concert. We knew the lines would be huge so we had given up the plan to visit but, walking by in the early evening, we saw a few people walking in and were able to buy tickets to a concert in the upper chapel - an excellent baroque trio (not the ubiquitous 'Four Seasons"). After a dull day the evening sun came out to light the wonderful stained glass windows. At the end, when the audience streamed out the two of us were left alone in this awesome place!

Excellent. Charming chapel, space-wise the building is not very large, but the immaculate detail and architecture covers every inch of the structure. Was not very crowded either! If you are looking for an attraction in Paris that isn't packed with tourists I would visit here. You may still have to wait in line to enter and run into tour groups but it will not be as crowded as Notre Dame. During my visit in April the building was under construction which is why it may have appeared to be so small, but you may need to ask for an elevator if you are arriving with a wheel chair. Worth the trip, and was so nice to see a "small" church in a big city!

One of the best buildings in Paris. The building and it's floor to ceiling stained glass windows are stunning. It is actually smaller than I had imagined.We booked tickets for an evening classical music concert, which was primarily Vivaldi's Four Seasons, which was excellent even though it's not my usual choice of music. Booking the concert tickets also meant we didn't have to join a queue to get in, just the queue with the other concert goers.

The Gem on the Ile de la Cité. No trip to Paris is complete without a visit or two to Sainte Chapelle, the small church sharing the Ile de la Cité with the better-know Notre Dame Cathedral. But Sinte Chapelle is a masterwork of its own with extraordinary, building length stained glass that bathes the entire inside in a multi-colored glow. Try visiting either in the early morning or later in the day when the intensity of the sun isn a little weaker and the colors of the windows even richer. And if possible, attend one of the frequent chamber recitals or other musical presentations offered in the evening (tickets required) which are a magical event in this jewel of a church. As always with stained glass, bring binoculars to see details in the higher reaches of the windows.
Beautiful. Beautiful church. It is undergoing some renovations but there is still much to enjoy. The stained glass is just gorgeous to see.

Better than expected. There was a short line to get into this church at about 10:30 in the morning. We walked by at about 9A on the way to Notre Dame and the line was about the same length, so I don't think getting there first thing in the morning is very advantageous. I don't usually wait in line, but it was moving quickly. We waited about 15 minutes. There system to get in was a little irritating. There was more security to get in than into Notre Dame. There was a slow moving metal detector line that everyone has to wait in....including those with a museum pass (no cuts on this attraction). Once pass security you go inside the church...where they are selling stuff and there is some stained glass. You go up the stairs....and I was expecting some neat stained glass windows, but I was surprised HOW cool the glass was. It was better than I thought it was going to be and worth the 15 minute wait. They were making some repairs on some of the glass, but it was still really neat.If you have the museum pass and the line is pretty short, pop in. It's neat.

Sainte-Chapelle. Beautiful chapel with amazing stained glass. We missed some of the stained glass due to refurbishing and some of the windows behind the altar were difficult to see. But overall, the experience was very positive. I would highly recommend visiting this amazing site.
Beautiful. The stained glass is so beautiful you could stand and look at the stories depicted for hours. Go early to avoid lines and have more room as it is a small chapel.

Went for a Concert. We decided to visit Saint Chapelle combined with a concert. Vivaldi's Four Season's was playing during our stay and we bought tickets in advance. Seating is open and you can choose where you want to sit. The Chapel was under construction while we were there so it was good that we did the visit in conjunction with the concert. It was amazing to sit and walk in the exact space where the Kings and Queens of France had been.

Beautiful Stained Glass. We had the Paris Museum Pass, so we did not have to stand in the long ticket line. We were able to walk right in. The church is undergoing major renovation. They are restoring and cleaning all of the stained glass a window at a time. Lots of scaffolding on the outside, but we were still able to appreciate the beauty of the church. I have never seen so much stained glass. Just gorgeous.

Stunning Stained Glass. The stained glass and decorations are just stunning! Under 25's are free to go in and also there is renovations being carried out in the main part which makes it hard to get decent photos and walk around.

Join the Minority! And join on a sunny morning.. Sainte-Chappelle is "the other cathedral" on the Isle de la Cite. It's a little hidden by the Prefecture, and most American tourists overlook it in favor of the more famous Notre Dame.NOT YOU!Everything about this cathedral is lovely and uplifting.The towering stained glass windows suspended between thin stone columns bathe you in cobalt-blue light when the sun is out, and the "new" (19th century) paint job may not appeal to some historical purists, but it is breathtaking. If you are lucky enough, attend an evening classical concert and lose your heart.

A Treasure. This small chapel is surrounded by the courts buildings, so you have to go through a security check. But it's worth it. Built as a home for a relic of the true cross, this chapel contains some of the most magnificent stained glass work in the world. Not to be missed.
Totally worth a visit!. I chanced upon this attraction and I am glad that I walked in. The collection of stained glass is beautiful. Each tells a story. It is truly an art.

A magical place for a meditative break from the city. Attended an evening concert here, just one of many wonderful islands in Paris that let you jump out of the tumult and bustle that the city carries you away with. Contemplative, meditative, with exquisite stained glass that is newly renovated and restored.
so-so. If you're strapped for time, it's not a must see because it's small compared to other sites and there's an admission fee. But the stained glass is stunning.

Breath taking stained glasses. The regular queue is rather fast moving. If you have the Paris Pass, you could skip the queue. The tall stained glasses are amazing to just take in. While there I heard someone saying "It's not worth it to pay that amount for this!" Well, I beg to differ. There is information (located at the back of the 2nd floor) about the various panels. The iconographies are quite interesting on the first and second floors. You can easily spend 1-2 hours in there. For stained glass enthusiasts, you could easily spend half a day in there.

Great Venue for a Concert. This church is now used for concerts. We had a lovely evening here in the summer of 2013. The acoustics were marvelous. Can't think of a better place to listen to classical music.
Beautiful - Moving - Historical. Best gift shop around! Gorgeous stained windows! DO climb the many little stairs to the top floor exhibits. Never too crowded. Good staff

Try to go to a concert here. Vivaldi's Four Seasons at 7 pm for an hour in this magnificent chapel. The doors open at 6.30 but I decided to get there at 5.50. I was second in the queue and had a set in the front row. Wonderful experience. Highly recommended

More intimate that Nortre Dame, and beautiful. The more human scale of St. Chappelle makes this church a wonderful place to consider the faith that inspired its construction. Morning light through the windows can make photography challenging, so consider afternoon visits if you are a photographer!
Renovating but still so amazing. It is worth seeing all the stained glass beautifully preserved. Impressive from the inside but plain on the outside. Less queuing than Notre Dame.

Beautiful stained glass windows. This is a lovely small chapel with stained glass windows depicting the books of the Old Testament. Loved the intimacy of this chapel compared to much large cathedrals.

Gorgeous!. I thought this place was AMAZING! I hadn't heard much about it, but I now consider it one of the top places we visited in Paris. We almost missed this amazing chapel. After visiting Notre Dame we decided to stop in as it was so close. After waiting in a lengthy line, a museum worker put out a sign saying that the chapel would be closed from 12:30 - 2:00 for lunch (not sure of exact times posted, but the sign was put out after we had been waiting about 20-30 minute). The line seemed to be moving along, so we decided to chance it and continued to wait. We got in before 12:00 and entered the lower level of the chapel, which was interesting, small and very pretty, but you needed to go upstairs to see the amazing stained glass. We saw others heading for a staircase and followed along. The second floor was incredible!! I love to see beautiful stained glass and this was just amazing! I loved this chapel and would highly recommend taking the time to visit. I would put this site high on my list of Paris sights not to be missed.

Like Being Inside A Jewelry Box!. The stained glass windows of Saint Chappelle are so exquisite that pictures can not do it justice. We got an audio guide that explained the stained glass bible stories. The Rose window and a few other windows were covered due to the final stages of restoration. Very inspiring!!

Stunning Stained Glass. We have visited Sainte-Chapelle for early-evening concerts twice and thought it was the high-point of our Paris visit. Best in spring or summer when it's still light outside so the stained glass shows up.

spectacular!. what an incredible jewel! currently under renovation, but do not let that stop you. buying tix on line is a good idea. get combo with entry to the Conciergerie too, which is pretty interesting.

Stunning!. Incredible stained glass, unlike any I have ever seen. Please visit. There was a line but it lasted less than 10 minutes. If you have a museum pass, you can go past the line and walk right in.

Plain. The average rating does not refer to the stained glass, but rather the ground floor. I took so many photos, but they are just a colored blur. It was actually more interesting to look at the outside of the building as well as watch the lawyers walk by in fancy dress.

Beautiful - Don't Miss This. Sainte-Chapelle may be the most beautiful place I have ever visited. There is a bit of restoration going on at the moment so you don't get quite the full impact. Plan to visit on a sunny afternoon so the stained glass windows are at their most beautiful. You enter into the lower church, which is lovely, but when you walk up the circular stairs and enter the upper church, the site will take your breath away.

Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" at La Sainte Chapelle. For anyone who loves stained glass, La Sainte Chapelle is one of the best places to view this art at its finest. The small chapel enhances the slender windows as they ascend in graceful arches, flooding the grey stone in rich, translucent color! I make a point of going there whenever I am lucky enough to be in Paris. Last April, we were very lucky. As my sister and I walked toward the chapel, I saw a poster announcing concerts being held at Sainte Chapelle in the evenings. Reading closer, I realized Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" Concertos were being performed that evening. We decided to attend, and after having yet another wonderful dinner in this great city, we bought our tickets for about 15 Euros each and took our seats in the small pews of this exquisite example of Gothic architecture. Imagine light filtering in through stained glass windows as the first notes of Pachelbel's "Canon in D," which opened the concert, engulfed the room. It was so beautiful, beyond words. There were only 5 musicians, all playing stringed instruments, and I couldn't believe how much music came from 5 instruments, they played the entire "Four Seasons," and with the amazing acoustics, filled the church with delightful music! At one point, the lead violinist strolled up the aisle as he played, smiling pleasantly! Truly, this was a once-in-a-lifetime experience, combining beautiful visuals with rich sounds. I highly recommend an evening of wonderful music at La Sainte Chapelle! You will find info online, for 2014, I found events through the end of the year. This is a memory I will cherish forever, and hope you are able to have a similar experience at one of the upcoming concerts.

It ain't much to see from the outside.. And once you get in the lower chapel, it is a bit disappointing.And then, the STAIRS. We almost missed the main event by not climbing the stairs.Inside, the stained glass is STUNNING. Photos or video CANNOT do it justice. But folks keep trying. There are almost 1300 photos on this page as I'm doing this review.You MUST see it.

Great Church to View / Great Stained Glass. If you have time before or after Notre-Dame, this is a must see church. Make sure to not only view the chapel on the first floor, but the much larger chapel on the second floor. The stained glass in this church is as good or better than Notre-Dame. But, note there is restoration going on the second floor chapel currently until the end of the year.Regardless of the restoration, I would highly recommend going. If you do, this is also on the Paris Museum pass. Although there is no express line for the initial screening of the church since it is a part of the current working courts in Paris, once inside you do get to skip the ticket window.
Stunning. This was one of the most breathtaking churches I have ever been in. Well worth the visit! It was slightly expensive at 8.50 euro, but worth it. Simply beautiful!

Lovely. Gorgeous! My first thought was, "It's a giant film strip!" (Yes, that dated me.) I found a giant laminated card which came in a variety of languages that confirmed my thought. You can read the glass from left to right and then bottom to top. It was absolutely beautiful. The line through security was quick and the line for tickets was about 20 min. I thought it was worth the price since as the only Adult I paid but the kids showed their passports and entered for free. There are about 30 spiral steps up into the chapel and I don't remember seeing an elevator. Considering that it was summer vacation for many, I really was surprised how small the crowd was.

The most beautiful Chapel you will see in Paris. Many tourists miss this out, however I would put it onto the top 5 things to do in Paris. You will be overcome by the beauty of the stained glass windows and the history of this very beautiful Chapelle. It is very close to Notre Dame so you can do both quite easily.
Stained Glass Everywhere!. Only worth it if you already have a Paris Pass. It is beautiful and amazing - remarkable even. The line for security took longer than we spent in the chapel though.

Fantastic Stained Glass. Unfortunately still under restoration but walking into chapel and seeing the stained glad windows was a WOW experience. You do not know where to look first, handy to have English information sheets to read as you look to each panel. Look at big wooden doors with amazing bolt and handle, a picture must if you are into doors!Highly recommended. Buy a ticket to Conciergerie then onto Sainte-Chapelle, for quick entrance(you not have to line up with others).

Unbelievable stained glass windows. Took about 30 minutes to get tickets and to gain entrance, arriving on spec (nothing pre-booked). It was well worth it. The spectacular windows are upstairs in the Church, so be sure to go up the stairs! It does not cost extra, and one might easily miss it. We visited in the early afternoon in early June. Crowds might be lighter in the morning or evening.

Sainte Chapelle. Be sure to visit Sainte Chapelle on a sunny day. The magnificent 17th century windows will not disappoint. Located around the corner from Notre Dame and behind the Palais de Justice, this chapel should be on your must do list. Try attending a concert here. The acoustics are amazing. You might also want to fit in a Sunday afternoon organ concert at Notre Dame
OLD AND WONDERFUL. the stained glass and gothic arches are beautiful and colorful. I also liked the tiles on the floor.

spectacular. Included on the Paris Pass. This is a don't miss. The stained glass is the most remarkable that I have ever seen. The history is wonderful and the exterior is very interesting as well. Worth the time.
Very pretty chapel. Great to see the restoration going on. Will be a sight to see when it's finished. The stained glass windows are a sight to see.

beautiful church - but scaffolding at present. Here for a Vivaldi concert last night which was wonderful, a very memorable visit with the late afternoon/evening sun highlighting the magnificent lead light stained glass windows. Acoustics were amazing, highly recommended thing to do.
If you love stained glass..... I am so happy I did not miss Sainte-Chapelle. The windows are lovely. Worth the trip up the stairs. I have seen true beauty in the windows of this place.

The genuine chef d'oeuvre of the french medieval Gothic architecture. After the Notre Dame Cathedral in the core of ancient Paris,i.e. on the island Ile de la Cite, I've seen another jewel of the stupefied gothic art. Not only with its exterior appearance in the Boulevard du Palais, in the heart of the Palais de la Cite, but also and above all, in its interior with overwhelming every living person in the world by the stain glass windows all around You.And when You look up to the dome of the church with all these constructive ribs that extend high above You to support whole building, there is some feeling of weightlessness, You can't resist.It was King Louis IX of France who commissioned the erection of this amazing edifice in the first half of the thirteenth century.He was known among the people and was proclaimed as Saint Louis de France, very respected as a ruler at his times.I recall now the great artefacts pertaining to Sainte - Chapelle, as the chapel's rose window, the stone sculptures of many saint men and women, the statue of King Louis IX.The extraordinary holy place beside the Notre Dame Cathedral and close to it on the Ile de la Cite.

Beautiful, beautiful vitraux!. The inner dome of the chapelle is very impressive, colors are insatiable and so perfecetly mixed! The vitraux make you want to gaze at them over and over again! Absolutely beautiful vitraux, perfect workmanship and amazing reflections on a sunny day! Don't miss Sainte-Chapelle! You'll love it!
Breathtaking. The most amazing display of stained glass I've ever seen. Quite small and gets busy so get there early.

Beautiful! Vivaldi concert. We went here specifically for the concert. I was overwhelmed at the beauty of this church, as I didn't know anything about it. The concert was unbelievable - a true highlight of our trip to Paris!

A tiny gem. DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE. stunning, and that is even with the scaffolding. You GOTTA go upstairs!! I did not, b/c was very tired, but when Hubs did not return from up there, I hauled myself up the stairs. And WOW, so glad I did. The windows are truly masterpieces, and worth the neck dislocation from looking UP for so long.

Well worth a visit. This is worth visiting and is close to Notre Dame so visit both on the same day. The windows are beautiful, make sure you follow the stories using the hand outs. If you are an EU citizen and lucky enough to be under 25 take some official id and you don't have to pay.
Must See. The stain glass windows are the only reason to visit, but they are worth the wait in line. They now have handicap access.

Not to be Missed. Having done some planning before we went to Paris, we did not have any difficulty in finding Sainte-Chapelle. The restoration is still in progress but it did not deter from our visit. The stained glass windows are beautiful and should be seen by all who visit Paris.

Unparalleled!. I have a friend who does and studies stained glass. She was in tears during her visit. One of the world's premiere places to see stained glass. A gorgeous and ornate chapel - of a grandeur and beauty unequalled!

Stunning Windows. The windows are the reason to visit and do not disappoint. The rose window and three others are in renovation and cannot be seen but those you can see are magnificent. Choose a sunny day for your visit if possible. As usual get there early and be prepared for a long line.

Get tickets ahead of time but be ready for a line. Purchasing your ticket ahead of time will not get you in early. There are court facilities in the same complex so you have to go through security and there is no fast line here. Make sure you go upstairs, the stained glass windows are impressive and are a must see for everyone.

Most beautiful church ever. This is the greatest church we ever visited. Full of stained glass widows, worth the little line time and all the bureaucracy on the entrance. Be amazed by the architecture and all the details.

What an amazing church!!. Very very beautiful,amazing church I've ever seen in my life!!!
メトロかもノートルダム大聖堂からも近い距離にあるこの聖堂は私が今までに見た中で一番きれいなステンドグラスでした。ノートルダム大聖堂も素敵ですが是非ここも行ってみてほしいところです。

Stunning. Very nice to see if you have the time, don't forget to look up at the entrance! I didn't go up the stairs but did look at the artefacts. It has a wonderful ambience and is close to other attractions.

Never miss this!. Although it's a little harder to find, we always go as it contains maybe the most stained glass windows in the world. Currently, they are in the restoration process, but it didn't dimish the experience. It's a must see. P.S. you enter via the first floor gift shop, don't forget to go upstairs to the amazing chapel.
Book the concert!. We enjoyed a lovely Vivaldi string concert in this heavenly space. No crowds. All of the delight of a singular jewel of the French capital. A definite highlight of our Paris visit.

The Kings Chapel. This small chapel is absolutely stunning and a MUST see when you go to Paris! The inside of this beautiful building is decorated to the max and is so Different from any other church or chapel. You may have to line up for a while to see it but it Is well worth the wait! If you are in Paris make the effort to find it and wait in line and pay the small fee to visit this wonderful chapel of the king, make sure you learn the history of the chapel too.....very interesting.
Beautiful!. A lovely chapel near Notre Dame, quite well hidden! It is famous for its stained glass windows. The main rose window is currently being restored but don't let that stop you going.

Was built to impress. The Saint Chapelle was built 1242-1248 by Louis IX, famous for its high vitraje windows - it is under renovation during the last years [appears like renovating process takes longer than it took to build 770 years ago! It is worth staying in line to see it!

Magical. Visit to Saint Chapelle for a concert "Vivaldi's Four Seasons" is a must. You can get tickets across the street at a tabac - directions in a billboard in front of St. Chapelle. We went late afternoon, around 6pm, and the sun shining through the stained glass was awesome and the musical group was great.
Choose a sunny day. This little gem is awe-inspiring. The second floor's windows are just marvelous. If you are a stained glass maven, this is the place in Paris!

Magnificent capel with its glass windows. Yu cannot go to Paris without visiting the Ste Chapelle. They are renovating the glass windows.which are sp huge you wonder how they engeneered that in Royal Times. King and consorts and the Court would go to this High ChapelThe acoustics is excellent due to the shape of the high chapel( the lower one was for ordinary people). Magnificent

WOW. Absolutely stunning! If you have any appreciation at all for medieval churches and/or stained glass, you must see this. They are currently restoring several of the panels, so part of the chapel was scaffolded and covered (a bit disappointing), but a minor issue in this beautiful place.

Always My First Stop in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is so incredibly beautiful and unique. Visiting it is a must. Easily combined with a trip to Notre Dame and Ile St. Louis. The stained glass is all-encompassing. Do not miss!

Magical!. The Sainte Chapelle and its wall of stained glass windows should be visited on any sunny day but for a truly magical experience, buy tickets to an evening concert when Vivaldi is being performed. As the setting sun illuminates the stained glass windows, the notes soar! The acoustics are fantastic! You can either buy tickets online or across the street from the entrance to the Ste Chapelle at the small tourist shop. You can usually also buy tickets at the door but not always. You should get there about an hour before the concert starting time since seating is first come first serve in three sections, depending on how much you have spent for your tickets. Remember that you have to go through security before you are allowed in. For concert schedules, Pick up a copy of Pariscop at the newsstand on Wednesday to find on what is happening that week. Although it is in French you should be able to figure it out.

This place was incredible . I was blown away by this cathedral! The stained glass told biblical stories, and the architecture was beautiful. I found myself just standing looking around for several minutes in utter astonishment. One note: the line can get long and this is one of the few places you can't skip the line if you have a paris city pass because everyone has to go through security.

Thwarted. Tried 3 times to visit. The first time we found huge queues in the pm. Thought we would try next day at opening time. Found it wouldn't be opening that day. Returned early next day. Found a long line waiting half an hour before opening. We gave up!

Not worth the money. Because you are right next to Court Justice buildings you have to go through a long line and then bag security. When we got in we were grateful for having a museum pass as the cost was just not worth it. Stained glass was attractive but not value for money.

Spectacular Cathedral. Worth waiting in line to see. Unfortunately some of the windows are undergoing renovation so they were covered, but it was still worth seeing. The stained glass is most impressive.

Stunning. If you love stained glass work, this is the place to visit. I was awestruck by the level of detail in the glass panels here. They have been so meticulous about preserving the beauty of it. Truly majestic.

A MUST!. This is one of the most beautiful churches in France. The rose windows at sunset must be seen since there is no way one can describe their beauty. The church is nearly finished with a multi-year repair which will only add to the experience.The church hosts many stringed quartets and quintets and attending one of those recitals is a unique and wonderful experience not to be missed even if you don't fully appreciate classical music since the setting is so beautiful. You feel like you have stepped back two hundred years.This is a real must in Paris
You won't see more beautiful stained glass anywhere.. The windows in this church are simply breath taking, you won't better anywhere else. This is a must see if you are in Paris.
Beautifully intricate design. Every corner of this tiny chapel is covered in intricate design motifs. It is a special treat to hear a concert held in the chapel.

Just Beautiful. Even during renovation the stained glass here is just stunning but there are queues and security to enter which detract. The numbers even out of peak season are large but still worth the effort.

beautiful, however dirty. One of the musts when in Paris is a visit to St. Chapelle. Both the top an d the chapel on the groundfloor are worth seeing. It brings you back in a great part of the French history. It does need renovation, the building was dirty, but still worth visiting. see the enclosed pictures.One is of course mainly attracted to visit the Chapelle because of the relics altar and above the tallest glass in lead windows in the world, at least becaus the are made in the Middle ages

My Favourite Church. I had read that visiting St. Chapelle on a sunny day was like being inside a jewel box. A most accurate description, the sunlight streaming in through the stained glass windows that filled the space between the structural ribbing, a beautiful light and airy effect. Definitely worth a visit, try to make it a sunny day.

An exquisitely beuatiful medieval chapel.. The stained glass and interior painting of this 1000 year old chapel is unique and breathtaking. Be prepared for sections to be closed or covered for restoration.

Magnificent stained glass and tile. My husband insisted we go visit Sainte-Chapelle and I'm glad we did. Even the kids were fascinated by the intricate windows. There is also wonderful tile work, and other decorative painting and figures to enjoy. This is the sort of place that the more you look, the more you see. It is included in the Paris Museum Pass, so if you have one, be sure to use it here to shorten the wait.

A hidden jewel one block from Notre Dame. Miss this at your peril. A magnificent royal chapel dating from the fifteenth century with the most exquisite array of towering stained-glass windows. Best on a sunny day. Surprise someone by just taking them there without giving too much away. Extensive renovation work in progress blocks one end of the chapel for the remainder of 2014. But still go!Avoid the long queues by entering for the Palais de Justice - and take this opportunity to first go and look at the beautiful Palais de Justice gates from the inside and then return back to the Chapel. A museum pass will also reduce entrance time at the Chapel (but not out on the street).

At last Sainte-Chapelle!. I have been in Paris many times, but never been in Sainte-Chapelle. Now at last In February 2014 I could almost walk in without queueing at all. Unfortunately this beautiful heaven was under the restoration. In spite of that the beauty of the church is stunning.

Incredible!. This site is not to be missed. If you see the beautiful windows in Notre Dame, Sainte-Chapelle is Notre Dame on "steroids." While there is major restoration work being done to the Rose window, you can still climb the narrow circular stairway to get to the main chapel where you will be nearly surrounded by massive stained glass works dating back centuries. Be sure to visit here on a sunny day to enable you to experience the full color and beauty of this marvelous structure.
Betters are in Istanbul Turkey.. Time consuming. I advice visiting La Conciergerie instead of this Chapelle if you have lmited time, or visit Istanbul to see the better glass works.

Sainte-Chapelle, a pure gem of architecture not to be missed!. The Sainte-Chapelle is located in the courtyard of the Palais de Justice - Paris Law Courts, on the Ile de la Cité.It was built in the 13th century for King Louis IX (St-Louis).There are two chapels, the lower chapel used by the king’s staff members, and the upper chapel, St-Louis’ private chapel that contains the True Crown of Thorns.Both chapels are simply stunning!You’ll find a wealth of carved, painted and gilded walls, ceilings and columns and an astonishing set of stained glass windows that seem to be suspended in the air.A true feat of architecture, and beauty at its best!You access the Sainte-Chapelle on Boulevard du Palais.Queues can be very long during peak season as the Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most visited sites in Paris.I suggest you buy your ticket online before hand, that will allow you to use the prepaid channel.However, even this channel can be a bit slow during peak season as more and more visitors tend to buy their tickets online.Most people visiting the Sainte-Chapelle want to visit the Conciergerie which is also located in the Palais de Justice, but has a completely different entrance.If you do so, I suggest you buy a dual ticket Sainte-Chapelle-Conciergerie, as you’ll get a discount and won’t need to queue for the second site.As the Sainte-Chapelle is located inside the Law Courts, there are very strict security checks at the entrance. You have to open your bags and have to walk under a portal, so don’t carry any metal objects (scissors, pocket knife etc…) as they will be taken away. You’ll be able though to recover them after the visit but it would be a bit of a hassle!Be aware that you will not be able to take full picture of the stained glass windows of the upper chapel as it is under restoration until the end of 2014.Be also aware that they are narrow staircases involved to go up to the upper chapel.This might prove a challenge for people with physical mobility issues.You get there by Metro, get off at the station ‘Cité’ on Line 4, it’s just opposite the law courts.

Beautiful Chapel - limited views. The inside was beautiful - nothing like I had ever seen before. However it was quite pricey and no discount was offered despite more than half the windows being blocked and under construction. That was very disappointing. It took a long time to get to the front of the first line - but that was just the security line. Once you pass security you have to wait in a line just as long which you are not warned about. Check waiting time with staff before waiting and how many windows are actually visible.

Beautiful stained glass. When we were there, many of the windows were being worked on so you couldn't see them all but for the ones you could see, they were beautiful. Archtiecture outside of the building was also beautiful. We had the Paris Museum pass so the cost was covered. It's another can't miss church in Europe.
Worth the visit. Very pretty, wasn't planning a visit but it was recommended to us And we had the Time as Norte dame was closed that afternoon. Very glad we did.
Upstairs. The main level is nothing to write about, but the upstairs with all the stained glass is awe inspiring. My jaw may have actually dropped when I came out of the staircase.
Not worth the money. There were renovations going on in the entire church and a lot of the windows could not be seen when we were there. Very expensive considering that you couldn't see anything.
A very beautiful chapel.. Although the entry price seemed a little excessive, my wife and daughter and I thought the chapel was amazing in its presentation of stained glass windows.
Concert Venue Extraordinaire. Whatever you do, be sure to experience a concert here. It. Is. Incredible. Such a memorable experience - wonderful acoustics, beautiful environment, so delightful.

Enchanting! Don't miss this. Stunning and indescribably surrounds you in history...it was a cloudy day when we visited and the stained glass was heavenly...i can only imagine what glory the windows would have shown with the sun shining brightly through....it's a hidden gem!
Breathtaking!. The stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny afternoon is absolutely breathtaking - do not miss! We found the security line to be fast moving and the crowds inside manageable.

Excellent concert in the evening!. The church is beautiful to visit but the terrific classical concert in the evening was a highlight of our trip to Paris! This small group of musicians presented a beautiful program showcasing Vivaldi and Handel. Try to schedule the concert online ahead of time. We took a tour of the church at 5 and had a small break before lining up for the concert.
Beautiful stained glass. A beautiful place, not to be missed. Try to get tickets for a musical event here, it is such a perfect venue.
Worth a visit. If the queue is very long don't wait, but its worth a half hour wait to view the stained glass windows.

Vivaldi in the Heavens. As part of my recent trip to Paris, I booked a concert to be performed on a cool Sunday evening at Sainte-Chapelle, that masterpiece of Gothic architecture in Paris on the Ile de la Cite built by Saint Louis in the heart of ParisThe show was a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons performed by the leading solosits from the Orchestre of France led by the rather talismanic Paul Rouger.While there are never-ending queues during the day to admire the chapel and its stunning stained glass windows, our queue was discrete and short, with the concert starting an hour after public hours finished.The location was heavenly as we sat amidst the splendours of centuries past.The music was inspired and the 90 minutes or so just slipped away as the dynamic end came all too soon.A wonderful venue for an intimate concert.

Do not miss this in Paris. An exceptional church beside the Palace of Justice on Ile de Cité, the stained glass windows which are being renovated are, not to be missed, The church becomes alive with the light from them, and this with some of them still shrouded in renovation garb!!We had attended an evening flute concert there by an Australian flautist, whose immaculate renditions seemed to float down from the highest reaches of the vaulted ceiling; pure magic. It is the best accoustics these ears can remember hearing. I understand that in the afternoon there can be long lineups to visit the church, hower, from opur observations, these lined moved very quickly.

Pay full price for half the attraction. Unfortunately, this chapel is getting restored and was supposed to be done a year ago, but it still isn't. The rose window is covered as well as many of the stained glass windows on the left side of the chapel. This was quite the disappointment after standing in line for an hour and paying full price. I would have waited for my next visit to see the beauty of this chapel.

Long wait for not much. We got there at 9:00 because we'd heard that a lot of people went and one had to line up before the 9:30 opening. We were close to the head of the line, but it didn't open until 9:50. The Sainte-Chapelle is now (June 2014) under restoration and construction. We saw only a very small part of it, after that long wait. I recommend that travelers wait until the construction is finished before using precious travel time for this place.

Jeweled Stained Glass. So many people don't even seem to know about Sainte-Chapelle - but this is one of the most gorgeous and unique cathedrals I have ever visited. The glass seems to rise up to the sky and is just so beautifully held by the slender ribs - the colors are constantly changing at different times of day. Attend one of the classical concerts if you can - you will never forget it! You will enter through the lower chapel then climb the narrow winding stairs into the masterpiece of Sainte-Chapelle.Yes, there is some restoration going on but I was able to photograph around it and still get beautiful shots.
