Great Visit - Still Under Renovation. Second visit here. Renovations will be completely by the end of this year. Despite the renovations the stained glass is spectacular.Get there early, otherwise you will waste a lot of time standing in line. Be patient, take your time and enjoy the views.

Magnificent stain-glass windows. This small chapel has the most incredible windows I have ever seen. They are wrapping up a multi-year renovation this year so we were not able to see the central rose window, but it was very worth the visit. They have descriptions of each window that you can carry as you view the beautiful chapel.
A Disappointment. Expensive entry fee; scaffolding covered a good part of the interior. Not much of a line to get in but understandable. There are better choices.

A little piece of heaven on earth. Let's face it - most all cathedrals are beautiful, but Sainte Chapelle is beyond compare. The stained glass is incredible and the printed guides they provide for "reading the windows" are terrific. Don't miss the scenes in the stonework on the balcony. Also lovely.

Worth seeing.. Walk over here from Notre Dame. IT is different enough to warrant a god visit. And it is very historic.
Beautiful glass.

More spectacular than we could imagine. Can't recommend this gem enough! I was expecting to be impressed by the dazzling stained glass windows, but was unprepared for the experience. It is being renovated currently, but that does not diminish the effect. Well worth the wait through the security line (which is unavoidable, pass or no pass); a good place to arrive when it opens in the morning.

Glorious Glass!. After four trips to Paris, I never tire of the thrill of seeing the heavenly stained glass at Sainte Chappelle. Even the light slightly changes the intensity of the colors, so it is a photographer's dream.They host classical concerts on some evenings.Be advised it is closed after lunch, and that the Paris Museum pass does not give you "Front of the Line" priority, so it gets crowded in the afternoons.

History told by stained glass. Finally had the opportunity to visit this ancient church. Due to always having long waiting lines of tourists wanting to visit, I have postponed this visit many times before. The church is famous for the glass-stained windows, currently under construction and we could only see a few of this spectacular windows. Will go back when its done in 2015. Just a note: they have strict security regulations, I had to turn back on our first day due to a knife that I have just bought. Second day after standing in the queue again, they objected to a CLOSED bottle of wine in my handbag! They suggested that I leave it with a cafe opposite the road. I was sceptical about this suggestion, but the cafe did not blinked at my request! After the visit, voilá, I was reunited with my wine!

Restoration in progress. The stained glass is truly remarkable; however, the effect is diminished in that a large section is completely covered while restoration of those panels are restored. This is a worthwhile project for the future of Saint-Chapelle meaning I will have to return once it is complete.I had a difficult time following the story being told in the stained-glass panels even with the visual aides supplied, but, hey, I am a knucklehead.

Under renovation. There was a lot of construction underway. You were unable to view the magnificent rose window though most of the other stained glass windows were visible and beautiful. It would have been beneficial to go with a tour for more detailed information. I would love to go back when the restoration is complete as this was definitely a disappointment.

Currently Under Renovation, but Still Worth a Visit. Time your visit; perhaps the best time to go is early morning or late afternoon. Sainte-Chapelle does close for a mid-day break at approximately 1-2 p.m. We went at 5 pm, an hour before closing, and the security line and number of people on the 2nd floor were manageable. We had plenty of time to see the Chapel without feeling that we were rushed. The famous Rose Window is under renovation; hence boarded up - you won't see it. The Gothic interior and other stained glass windows are stunning; particularly in the late afternoon sun. Sainte-Chapelle can be accessed "free" with a combo-ticket purchased at Le Conciergerie or the Paris Museum Pass. There are two evening concerts of classical music, held at 7:00 and 8:30. Advance tickets are available on-line, but honestly with the on-going renovation and the chance of getting a "gloomy" night, I don't know that the expense is worth it. Many reviewers have raved about the experience; I'm just not as sure right now with all the plywood! We went on an impromptu basis; the light was perfect and the people were few! Renovation is a GOOD thing and in spite of the temporary inconvenience, Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely a MUST-DO in Paris!

Don't Miss It. Many tourists might be tempted to walk past this destination, in favor of the larger/more famous Notre Dame (which is right nearby on Isle de La Cite). Do yourself a favor and make sure you stop in. Now you might be tempted to just go as early as possible in the morning to avoid the entrance queue, and I get that, (believe me) *but* if perchance you go mid-morning/early afternoon, you might be lucky enough to catch it when the sun is streaming through the amazing stained glass windows that make up the entirety of the front of this chapel. It is like being inside a giant jewelery box. It is *so* beautiful in there. Definitely take the time to go and see this hidden gem.

Special little gem.. Covered by the Paris Museum Pass. The security lines held us up a bit but moved quickly. It is well worth a trip. The chapel is small but the stained glass is the most beautiful I have ever seen.
A little jewel. Do not miss the Sainte Chapelle, the stained glass work is absolutely amazing and in bette condition than the ones of Notre Dame.

most beautiful cathedral in Paris. With few exceptions,if you have seen one cathedral,you have seen them all.Most were built to compete for the biggest in Europe.This one is different in that it was built for the Royal Family. It is small but magnificent. They have been restoring it for years and are almost finished.

Magnificent. The stained glass windows here are one of a kind and it is so amazing that the majority are original to the church. A short walk from Notre Dame Cathedral rewards the visitor with a chapel of light. I especially enjoyed the floors in the upper chapel.

Wonderful experience. It's really lovely and quite different from most of the churches you can see all over Europe. The windows are fantastic, but also the decor and the colours are enjoyable.If you like history buy a combination ticket and see the Conciergerie as well - go there first, and you get to skip one of the queues to get into the Chapell.

The most wonderful place of light. Go and let you fly through the light!Advisable to be prepared with tickets in advance to avoid long queues but even without booked tickets the waiting for entering is worthing.No words and no review was able to describe what I saw and felt there. Take your time while visiting and you'll have the chance to get a moment of almost your own. Then you'll enjoy the most. It is under renovation but you can see the most part of it.

Didn't live up to the hype.. I've heard about this place for years, but have never really been eager to throw down money to see stained glass as most churches you can see for free.There was a bit of a line up and a spiral stair case to go up to get to the chapel and then once you are there it's just packed with people taking picture after picture with their cameras that are probably inadequate for the low light.If you've run out of things to do, check out Sainte-Chapelle, otherwise, find any other local church and look at it's stained glass.There were also repairs going on when I was there, so that might have taken away from the experience.

Worth the line...if its sunny. Saint Chapelle is a beautiful sight, but the lines are long. Go first thing and wait in line, but only on a sunny day. The effect wouldn't seem as impressive on a cloudy day. Check the forecast for the days you will be visiting and pick the sunniest time to visit this church.

The hidden gem of Paris. Anyone who ever comes to Paris should go there. This is Gothic grandeur at its best. Go for the concerts if you wish but that is not required. Just being there - in whatever season, but preferably when you can see the stained glass well, is a true treat

Beautiful two-level chapel with stained glass windows. This jewel is on the ile de la Cité, a short walk from Notre-Dame. Go early before the lines get long but, regardless of the wait time, it is well worth the visit. Built during the reign of King Louis IX (also known as Saint Louis) in the mid-13th century, it was located in what was then a royal residence and complex. It is now part of the complex that houses the Palace of Justice. The King returned from the Crusades with religious relics (a piece of the Cross, the crown of thorns, the blood of Christ etc.) he wished to house in this royal chapel. Once you get through security, you enter a courtyard housing the Sainte-Chapelle and legal courts (another reason for higher security). You enter through the lower chapel (for those who served the King) with columns and beautifully painted walls before going up a narrow, medieval stone staircase to the upper royal chapel with its famous tall stained-glass windows and columns, each bearing at its base a statue of one of the 12 apostles. Take advantage of the seating along the perimeter and the explanation cards in several languages to read the explanations for each of the windows. On a sunny day, and if there is no scaffolding due to restoration work obscuring them, they are breathtaking and speak to you across the centuries! Please note there is a small staircase to get to the upper chapel one floor above but no elevator.

The Rose Windows are amazing. Go upstairs (try to go as the sun is going down) and spend a few minutes upstairs in a room suffused with a rosy glow from the stained glass windows. Its an experience you will never forget.

Hidden Jewel. This jewel is just a few blocks from Notre Dame. Even though a major restoration project was underway, it was still absolutely breathtaking. Everyone looked at the altar and the stained glass in the chapel with astonishment and said "Wow!" Absolutely gorgeous and a must-see.

Light and sound. We timed our audio guided visit for the last 1.5 hours open for visiting so we could also stay (at extra cost) for a strings concert. Given the long days of June, the chapel was illuminated by natural light for both our visit and the concert the concert was sold out but we were lucky to buy tickets at the last moment. The small space was divideD into three section, differently priced. Seating within the sections is first come first serve. Beautiful space and sublime Vivaldi.
The line was so long!. I have seen St. Chappelle before and it is very nice to view, if you can get in. The lines were so long we chose not to wait on this trip.

Don't pass up, it's well worth the time. Many people walk in and out not knowing that there is a chapel up stairs. Best seen on a day with light the stain glass is awesome. The outside architecture is expressive as well. Not considered a major attention, but it is well worth a day time visit. Hint: the interior is dark if you have a choice 1.8 camera lens is a good choice.

Beautiful Stained Glass, but Under Restoration. Had gone on a free walking tour of Paris and this was one of the guides suggested visits. We like stained glass and thought we would enjoy it. We had been to see the cathedral in Chartres a few days before and although this is lovely didn't really feel it measured up, especially when you take into account that it is under restoration and the Rose window can't be viewed.There is an entrance fee here. Churches on the other hand are free to enter and see.

Stunning. We visited Sainte-Chappelle by purchasing tickets to attend an evening concert with chamber music. It's a wonderful way to experience this stunning space. (The music was fine--I've certainly heard better chamber music--but you cannot beat the setting.) I'd heard of Sainte-Chapelle and seen pictures, but this is one of those places where pictures do not do it justice! The windows are just amazing; it's a kaleidoscope of color and the detail is amazing. The chapel was under renovation during our visit, so the rose window was blocked--a reason to return! It's wonderful to see that they are making every effort to keep this gem in pristine condition. So beautiful.

Beautiful chapel. Buy your ticket in advance on line. You can pick it up at the Paris Tourist Office on rue des Pyramides. We did this and went immediately to the front of the queue, bypassing 200 people!

Beautiful stained glass. This is a relatively quick attraction to see, perhaps 45 minutes to an hour, but the stained glass is spectacular. A portion of the glass was covered up for renovation, but you still get the awesome experience from this chapel, about 800 years old. We did not wait very long to get in, and it was definitely worth it. Bring your camera and ultra-wide angle lens

Impressive!. What an impressive display of stained glass in this 13th C medieval Gothic chapel on the second floor! With the sunlight illuminating the biblical scenes one truly felt to be in the presence of God. Located in central Paris it is within close walking distance of Notre Dame.
Beautiful church. If you like to see old churches do not miss it. I almost miss the second floor. Very detailed stained glass. and amazing restoration. Included in the museum pass ...no lines.
Awe inspiring stained glass. Part of the chapel was under draped cloth for restoration but what we did see was amazing. Beautiful beyond words. A must see.

Number 1 must see & so often missed. I love Paris and really one can just wander and have a great time. The art and architecture is constant eye candy. However I think this is the one place everyone MUST see. I stained glass here is ethereal. One barely notices the walls. It is as if color and nothing else exists in this space. I think too many people come to Notre Dame just a short walk away and miss this hidden gem. IF I had to choose between the two I'd pick Sainte-Chapelle. And when looks at the length of the lines most people I think are making the wrong choice.

Windows are "woah". Thinking I might miss something in my visit, I purchased a walking tour which wasn't great. The base level is dark and has a few things to see but the best part is the second floor where you see the windows! It was an overcast day so no sunlight was shining through into the room, but I could imagine how amazing of an experience it would be. Pretty impressive stained glass windows. There was a long line to get in but once you got inside walking through was pretty quick, I only spent maybe 45 minutes inside and was able to get out and move onto other sites in Paris.
Beautifully underrated. We went for an evening of string quartet. Very beautiful setting for it, amazing stained glass windows, not a very big chapel, so it is quite charming.

Magnificent stained glass. When we first entered the church after reading about the stained glass I was a bit disappointed until we went to the second floor. What a beautiful sight with the sun pouring through the glass. A must see in Paris. We also went to a concert in the evening on the 2nd floor which was great. My opinion is, if you go to a concert, is don't waste your money on the expensive tickets up front. The venue is small and you can hear the music just as well from the back.
Beautiful. While walking thru this cathedral I could not believe all of the stained glass windows. They were stunning. I must have taken 25 pictures of the inside! Loved every minute

Great concert. Book a little in advance for the string quartet concerts in the evenings. A short concert of only one hour or so which is a good thing because the chairs are tiny and rock-hard. The concert in the Chapel is outstandingly beautiful and you're free for dinner afterwards.

under reno. Waited in line to see the chapel's famed stained glass, and while what we could see was impressive, it lacked given the renovations going on. Without the massive floral glass anchoring the other glass it was a relatively quick visit. Would suggest waiting until renos are complete....it is interesting to see the detailed work involved with the glass rejuvenation however!

Heavenly. Get there early or late in the afternoon when the lines are much shorter. This is perhaps the most beautiful church in the city. The stained glass is amazing, inspiring, stunning and worth any time you waited in line. If you love exploring old churches, this one has to be on your list.

Nice stained glass but nothing else. This church really isn't that great compared to other churches in Paris. The stained glass is very nice but almost all churches nowadays have stained glass. There is nothing else in this church worth seeing other than the glass.
Glorious Concert in a Glorious Setting. Listening to a concert in Sainte-Chapelle really made the chapel come alive! The acoustics and surroundings were magical.

A must see. Great and a must see in Paris. We suggest to take the Batobus to get there which will also allow you a great view over the Seine as you travel.Entrance is free but there is a fee for visiting the "treasury" which we could not see the value of spending.Hint: If you want to visit the tours, be advised that you do not have to queue outside the main entry as these have a different entrance on the left side of the Church and require an 8 Euros entrance fee.

under reconstruction May 2014. Almost half of the stained glass windows are blocked and you cannot see them now. Otherwise, well worth the trip. Heavy screening including metal detectors for some reason.

Unequalled stained glass. Sainte-Chappelle is glorious. You see magnificent 13th century glass at its very best. It was not busy and we had all the time we needed to enjoy it. A satisfying culmination to our visits to a number of great French cathedrals.
Awe inspiring. The stained glass windows in this church are astounding. When you climb the stairs and view the windows for the first time, it takes your breath away. Truly beautiful.

Beautiful stained glass windows, catch a concert at Sainte Chapelle!. First we took a short tour of the pretty church with lovely stained glass - 8.50? for adult , children free. However, I recommend you catch a concert there if your schedule allows. We saw evening show with a lovely soprano singing 3 versions of Ave Maria and a string quartet with Bach and more. A little pricey at 30? per adult and 16? per child but it was worth it!
Beautiful glasswork. You should definitely try to make a trip to this place. Its a tiny chapelle with beautiful stained glass. Waited in line for about 20 mins but was worth it !

Incredible church!. The most amazing medieval church in Paris. A must see!Get their early so you do not have to wait in a long line. This is part of the Paris Pass but my husband and I opted not to purchase this since we had been in PAris a few years back.

Outstanding Stained Glass but much Construction. Loved the church on this return visit but heavy construction in the upper chapel marred our visit. The entire rose window was under construction as were quite a few panels of the side walls. Excellent audio guide commentaries.

Into the Light. The experience of visiting Sainte Chapelle is extraordinary it's only historic venue I have seen that really punches through with its own 'big reveal'. Crammed in the heart of Paisian government buildings and with no edifice visible from the street , Saint Chapelle does not proclaim its importance or incredible status. A truly unique building and World Heritage site , you enter and discover the spiritual heart of the great French Medieval kings. The private chapel of French royalty its interior is full of the powerful and unfaded richness of Medival colour and pigments that were afforded by kings.With colours we have forgotten how to make let alone name , the Chapel ground floor is like stepping into a Knights Treasure chest  But all this is dimmed by your next encounter with the astonishing Medieval glass windows of St Chapell on the buildings first floor. Entering up a tiny stairwell your head emerges at floorboard height and your neck cranes to see the hurling reaches of the incredible and truly beautiful stained glass windows made by artistsans that time has forgotten . As window jewellers to the French kings these people were clearly the best craftworkers in Europe and understood the religios importance of their work.I know visiting churches can seem boring but this is an extraordinary exception and gives the viewer a direct insight into the spiritual life of the most powerful people in Europe- don't read the historical tracts on the walls just step up and experience the light..It's emotional ...!

Very special stained glass windows. Today we visited Sainte-Chapelle and really enjoyed the lovely windows. It's true some of them are closed for renovation but I wouldn't say half, maybe one third; most are open although the sun is obviously not shining through all of them at once. We used the Paris Museum Pass and were able to walk right in with no line. It is small but the windows are impressive and very different from other churches like Notre Dame. They are very tall and contain the stories from the Bible. I thought it was a very special place.

Definitely go and check it out. This was one place that really surprised me by just how magnificent it was. The glasswork is amongst the best I have seen anywhere, the stained glass windows stretched upwards and upwards. A far better choice than a trip to Notre Dame.

A mind blower. We lined up on a cold wet May day as the final visit to a tourist spot on the final day of our stay in Paris. And are we glad we decided to divert our walking in that direction!.This place is amazing. After first getting in and inspecting the bottom floor it was OK but nothing spectacular. We then, almost by chance, noticed some very tight winding steps near the enterance to the building and decided to go up and see where it leads. Exiting the steps at the top leads you into a large cathedral style room that takes your breathe away with the intracecy and immensity of the staned glass windows. It is overwhelming!. Just sit down if you can find a seat and take it all in. It really capped off a great visit to ParisDont mss this!!

A hidden gem, not to be missed. Tucked inside the Palais de Justice is Sainte-Chappelle, a must see. The windows are spectacular. Don't hesitate at the narrow spiral staircase leading up to the real star of the show, it's stunning.
Another Incredible Chapel!. Another incredible and amazing church/chapel to visit in Paris. If you like church architecture, you'll be amazed in visiting this one. Worth the visit!

Mixed review. You can't really see St. Chappelle from very far away...it is tucked in to the left of the very huge gold trimmed Dept. of Justice. Because of that security is super tight...the security line is long with no bypass for the museum pass. The first day we went, my husband had inadvertently left his swiss army knife in his pack so we were turned away. We ran across the street to a café where the waiter took 1 euro to hold the knife for us. At 5:15 we ran back but were told we could not get in as they closed at 6 and stopped letting people in at 5:30, which was not in any of the guidebooks. We returned another day and it is lovely; however, it us under renovation so the famous rose window is covered up and several of the other windows as well. Some people did not realize that the main windows are upstairs...the main floor is nice but just a taste of the best. It was cloudy and rainy the day we went...try for a sunny day to see the light coming in the windows. It must be spectacular. It's a gorgeous space, gothic arches etc.

Beautiful. We arrived early on a Sunday, the stained glass was wonderful, there was some renovation work so unable to see everything. Was included on our Museum Pass. Well worth a visit but did see very long queues later in the day.

One of the most beautiful churches anywhere. A most beautiful chapel. The only downside is the security line to get in, even with a museum pass. If you can, come back in the evening for classical music by a string quartet. The concert was wonderful, and the setting just could not be beat.

Despite work you could still see the beauty. There is a lot of work going on at the moment there, however you can still see the beauty of the craftmanship. Whilst the Pantheon is about massive sher scale the Chapelle is about ornant detail. If you want to see something exquiste and fine work in detail and constant awe then head here, you will not be disapointed.
Lovely. Beautiful quaint little Chapel. Excellent stained glass windows with a fantastic restoration. Unfortunately the rose was partly covered due to restoration but still great.

Paris Gem. Easy to miss as it is tucked in behind the better known Notre Dame de Paris. Simply walk across the large park-like area in front of Notre Dame and voila. The stained glass windows on the upper level are magnificent and a one-of-a kind. As was the custom of the day, the windows tell the story of the books of the bible for a population, many of whom could not read. Well worth the wait in line. You might want to check-in first and get a read on the quietest time of the day for a visit later on that day.

Best night in Paris. Boom one of the evening concerts-magical night sitting and listening to Bach & Vivaldi and others played in this ages tic setting. Seeing the Sundays through the glass while hearing Ava Maria being sung is a memory of Paris that I will treasure

Beautiful main Chapel !. We waited for 20 minutes to get inside the Chapel for security check. As we had the Paris pass we did not have to buy the tickets, their is renovation work going inside the Chapel so lot of it is covered. The main Chapel is beautiful and the work on the windows is breathtaking ! It has no walls but stained glass windows on all sides. We went on a cloudy day and hence were a little disappointed as could not see the full affect of sun light on the glass.The lower level has the intricate architecture and souvenir shops which is crowded with tourists.There is no lift so one has to take the spiral staircase to reach the main Chapel.
Wow. Worth standing in line and security check. Blow you out of the water stained glass windows. A treasure.

OMG. One of the most incredible sights I've ever seen and probably my #1 pick for Paris! The downstairs area is beautiful and full of tapestries and paintings. The chapel upstairs is nothing short of breathtaking. The colors! The natural light! The alter! The sheer scale of it all! I could have spend half of the day in there tinkering with my camera trying to get the perfect shot of the stained glass and just sitting and admiring the stunning chapel that's been around since 1248! Do yourself a favor and visit. I would have gone a second time during my week in Paris had time permitted.

Beautiful gem hiding by the Notre Dame. I hadn't heard of Sainte Chapelle on my previous trips to Paris and was delighted to find this smaller chapel once belonging to King Louis IX. The chapel has two levels, both with beautiful architecture and impressive detailing in paint and stained glass. Not a big facility, so easy to visit for an hour or so.

Make sure you go up the stairs to the main chapel. It was about a one half hour wait to get into Sainte-Chapelle on a Friday morning. You enter a room with a relatively low ceiling surrounded by stain glass windows full of tourists and souvenir stands. This is not where you want to be. Go back to the chapel entrance and climb the 30 or so winding stairs up to the Haute Chapelle. This is the spectacular room. It must be truly magnificent when the sun is shining directly onto the windows. A different winding staircase leads back to the ground.

Unbelievably beautiful. I had been to Sainte-Chapelle years before, but brought my kids when we were in Paris for five days. They were skeptical of any churches or museums as we were in the midst of a 6-week tour of France and Italy and they were already getting tired of both. Plus, there was a line that meant a wait of about 45 minutes. When we came out, they all gushed that it was TOTALLY worth the wait. It really is beautiful. A must see. I'd go there before Notre Dame. It's truly unique and striking.

Visit day & night. Gothic architecture is stunning.. If you can take in one of the concerts at night. You enter into the upper chamber of the chapel through the justice building. Lit up at night the experience is warm and intimate & the music delightful. A day trip allows you to access the lower chapel from the street and gives you the full blown affect of the gorgeous stained glass, lovely floors & gothic decoration. The climb to the upper chapel is not for the faint of heart but if one takes it slow it is well worth the journey. It made it easier for me thinking that ladies once made these stairs with heavy skirts. The trip down is far easier. A must see when in Paris.

Magnificent!. Had to queue 40 mins to get in and church still under restoration but wow was it worth it! A fabulous church with amazing 14th century stained glass windows...comparable to Sistine Chapel. You must see it!

You love stained glass.... The most famous features of the chapel, among the finest of their type in the world, are the great stained glass windows, for whose benefit the stone wall surface is reduced to little more than a delicate framework.At the entrance a very small royal chapel is a nice to see... Don't worry about the queue outside, you get inside very fast
Love it!. I think both the outside and the inside of this chuch are spectacular--love that stained glass! And the view of Paris is also spectacular--highly recommended!

Beautiful. Went to a Vivaldi string performance at Sainte Chapelle which was a good way to see the stained glass . There was plenty of time to admire and scrutinise the windows whilst listening to the appealing Four Seasons.

Not worth the cost. The first bit was that you had to go through security to get into the chapel, which when bag is full of sarnies and cameras is a bit of a pain. Then you had to pay 10 Euros to look at the chapel.To be fair the stain glass was beautiful and I have been in hundreds of Historic churches, but it wasn't really worth the effort, queue or money, unless you were really interested in this kind of architecture and stain glass. When time is at a premium it might not be worth it.

Stunning. My wife likes to visit the old churches. Nearby Notre Dame is the king, of course, and you get awed by the scale of it if nothing else. Saint-Chapelle isn't that grand. In fact, the ground floor is a little underwhelming. But when you go up the stone spiral staircase... wow. Massive stained glass floor to ceiling depicting numerous scenes from the bible. The big rose window is under restoration but even with that covered up, it is amazing. Very small, but people just kind of stand around in awe of the light streaming through so much beautiful stained glass.If you are at Notre Dame this is a VERY short walk and highly recommended.

Beautiful stained glass worthy of a visit. I would suggest getting up early and heading to notre damn before the crowds then getting to sainte chapelle for opening. We purchased tickets for this and another attraction next door. I suggest doing this as it was very good value. That way before 1/2 the day has gone you've seen three attractions and beat the crowds.The Chapel is smaller and darker than I was expecting and in need of some restoration but this didn't stop you from seeing the beauty of the gorgeous stained glass. We arrived before the doors had opened and still had to wait about 20minutes in a queue.Allow 20-30mins once inside.If you are at all clostrophobic don't attend - there is a narrow stairway to get to the top level.

When is Stained Glass Strained Glass?. By far the most stained glass per wall you will ever see. The history of the chapel and the survival of the original stained glass is remarkable. The content in the glass portrails is overwhelming.The long lines to get into the couryard combined with the long line to get a ticket to get to be pushed around a crowded floor all looking up to figure out wat we are ll looking at, for me was a bit frustrating . This chapel would should produce a video with closes up of various pictorials and explaining storied in the window stories so observers can build an appreciation for the importane of these windows in religious history.

Still magnificent even with the conservation work. I'm giving it four because of the conservation work but it is still magnificent and worth the visit even though not all of the stained-glass is currently visible. We purchased our Paris Museum Passes here which worked well as the lines weren't long and it allowed us to skip much longer lines at other venues.

Don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. Sainte-Chapelle is a beautiful chapel not far from Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are amazing. We attended a classical music concert there. Wonderful acoustics. Check online for when there are concerts. When I went to get tickets at the kiosk across the street they said there was no concert the night we wanted to go though on the internet they said there was. The hotel phoned and sure enough there was a concert so be sure to check more than one source. A concert at Sainte-Chapelle is not to be missed.

A hidden jewell. Some people have a hard time finding la Sainte Chapelle as it it hidden behind the wall of the Palais de Justice. La Sainte Chapelle has the most beautiful stained glass windows. I have taken my American students and my children there at various times

Stained Glass Windows of Insanity. This is another of my MUST DO recommendations for Paris. This is a relatively small church just up the street from Notre Dame, but if you are a fan of stained glass you cannot miss this. If you are visiting any museums, you can get a Paris Museum Pass and that will get you entry at Sainte-Chapelle too. You don't get to skip the line... at least not really, so try and arrive early. The only downside is they are currently restoring some of the windows, so a few of them are blocked from the inside. But still go, it's still worth it.

a little gem in the old city. even though this is busy, there is a tranquillity about this place the soaring windows create a powerful play of light in the tiny chapel. The painted walls are of particular interest, definitely worth the queue and the wait. Suggest however to come early even though the best light is at noon, but then thats when the line snakes right outside and along the street!
Building covered.. Unfortunately the Sainte-Chapelle was being restored/renovated in april 2014. We hope to visit it next trip.
Stained glass beautiful. A lovely old building hidden away behind the law courts making it all the more special. Loved the stained glass and everything about it.

Holidays in France. The chaple of the Miraculous Medal is by far the best church in Paris. Don’t miss going there regardless of your religion. The great life story of St Catherine Labore who was Nun here at Rue De Bac is sentational. Go into the web site of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal and you will fully appreciate the history and story of St Catherine and the Blesed Virgin Mary.
if you like stained glass and historic places, do not miss.... Well, this is one of the highpoints in the world for Stained Glass if you like that. An amazing historic space
Awesome. Our second time here and always breathtaking. The lead light windows are like nowhere else. The history of this chapel is amazing. A must to see.

Incomparable medieval cathedral. A don't miss in Paris... The stained glass sanctuary upstairs is something worth the trip to Paris. Don't let the government buildings surrounding the church fool you.
Sainte - Chapelle. Amazing, the stained glass windows were incredible, well worth going to. It is included in the Museum Pass and we didn't have to wait long to get in. Highly recommend

Always Special. One cannot go to Paris without seeing Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass windows are truly amazing so try to go on a sunny day. There is a lot of construction going on right now so it was a bit disappointing not to see the whole chapel in its glory, but it is understandable that repairs, etc. are necessary. You will still be in awe of the beauty of this place.
Wonderful. Go to see the performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons there at night. It is a great concert in a fabulous setting. Great way to spend a couple of hours.
Lovely place. Very long waiting line. We avoided it by attending a concert in the evening. It was a wonderfull great experience.The chappel itself is one of my all time favourits.

Windows are spectacular. If you're wondering where they are… check upstairs. I almost missed them, until I saw a video with beautiful windows. I asked and was told they were upstairs. Would have misssed them if I hadn't asked.

This is a must see. Even if you've seen many big cathedrals, Sainte Chapelle will fill you with awe the first time you see it. Maybe even the second time as well. Try to get tickets for a concert there. They can be booked ahead online. Sitting in the middle was recommended by a local for the best acoustics.

Hidden treasure -- put it on your list.. I heard about Sainte-Chapelle from a fellow tour-attendee, and am so glad I followed her advice to go. Precious, beautiful place, chock-full of history. Well worth the time to go.

Vivaldi Four Seasons in heavenly chapel. In April I went to an evening performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons in Sainte-Chapelle. It was glorious. The surroundings are sublime and the one hour concert gives you plenty of time to see the wonderful stained glass in detail while listening to a fabulous piece of music. While not a bargain at approximately $65 it was the highlight of one of the things I did when in Paris.

Real History. We just came back from a three week vacation in Paris and while in Paris the Sainte Chapelle was just one of the sites we visited. The entry was 8.50 euros per adult. We should have taken an audio tour as we, I am sure, missed a great deal of historic content. Also, there was a great deal of renovation going on and a lot of artifacts were covered, not their fault. You may never see so much intricate stained glass in your life time with such historical content. The location of the Chapelle is located in a very historic location with lots to see including The Notre Dame Cathedral. Bring good shoes as there are a great deal of sites in this location but you will be using the Shoe Leather Express a great deal!Rich and Dr. Linda W

One of the Most Beautiful Churches in the World. Friends kept recommending that we visit the Sainte-Chapelle and we realize that they were right. The Sainte-Chapelle was originally the royal chapel and has 15 three story stained glass windows (some are being repaired) that are remarkable. With any natural light Sainte-Chapelle glows. We have not seen an equivalent to it. There is a lower chapel which is very attractive and then you must climb a narrow staircase to the upper chapel where the stained glass is located. The Sainte-Chapelle also hosts chamber orchestra concerts. The orchestra played Vivaldi in the chapel for over an hour and it was an inspired evening for us. Tickets for the concerts can be bought for cash at the main entrance or the nearby Deux Palaise café. They sell out quickly. A ticket at the back of the chapel (still a great view) costs about $25. We cannot recommend the Sainte-Chapelle enough.

beautiful and nearly all renovated. The Sainte-Chapelle is a must in Paris.
The windows are so beautiful, especially now that they are renovated.
Take a guided tour in order to understand the meaning of these pieces of art as well as the history of the building

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Lovely chapel! Each time I visit I am in awe of the work and beauty of the stained glass windows in the upper chapel. The stone work and even the floor have gorgeous detail. It gets very busy, so go early. Use the Museum Pass!

Stained Glass Delight. This is a small church, the lower church for the servants and upper for the royals. We used our museum pass here too. The museum pass is a great savings. We loved the quiet cool beauty of the sun streaming through the stained glass

Humbling and colorful. The stained glass tells all the stories,better to be viewed on a sunny day because of the reflection it makes on the stained glass.If you have a long lens or zoom it's worth taking pics to see details in the glass.

Be Prepared to Stare. The stain glass windows are beyond comprehension! How did they make them so many centuries ago. Now the windows are being restored, quite an interesting process. Again, be prepared to just look & look at these wonderful & beautiful windows.
Overrated. Expensive after a long queue. Stained glass windows were impressive but most of the chapel is still a building site. Not worth the wait.
A Gem. Take the stairs up! Marvel at what these people built! The stained glass windows alone are worth the trip. I liked it better than Notre Dame.
A Real Beauty. Well worth a short visit, the stained glass windows are beautiful. If you have a Museum Pass, don't miss it when you visit Notre Dame.

Magnificent. My 3rd or 4th visit, and it is no less breathtaking with each visit. No one can say they've seen more stained glass in one place! Even my cynical companion was stunned! Another must-see in Paris!

the most beautiful cathedral in Paris. Read the history of this cathedral before you walk in the door. A king who spend a fortune on what he believed to be the actual crown of thorns worn by Christ on the cross and the king built this cathedral to house it. Stand in the beautiful downstairs where the "people" (that's you and me) were allowed to worship and then climb the stairs to the glorious sanctuary where the aristocracy worshiped. It's a religious experience. Go when the sun is shining.
Great concerts in a fabulous location. Classical music concerts in the early evening there with great acoustics and amazing location. Buy tickets at the door.

A Small Don' Miss Chapel. This is a very small church on the property of a government building and police station. Lines can be long but move and it closes for lunch. There is a cost but the stain glass is well worth it.
Beautifull windows. Very much worth a short visit. Get a museum pass to skip the queues otherwise you can be waiting for ages for your short visit

If you can get to the concert, do!. We booked an early concert at 6.00 and it was a great start to a wonderful evening. The setting is gorgeous. The satined glass windows absolutely awe inspiring and the acoustics are really good. String quartet plus soprano... just lovely.

A glory of light and colour. One of the greatest beauties in Paris - the kings chapel - hidden in the interior of the law courts on Il de la cité. The chapel is tiny by comparason with its counterpart Notre Dame but in my opinion is the real gem of the two. You start downstairs then climb a narrow staircase and are confronted with the most wonderous stained glass windows that appear to be holding up the immense edifice. Each of the 13 windows tells part of the holy story and is illuminated by the sun as it moves around the chapel during the day. Truly breathtaking and should not be missed if in Paris even for a short time.
Not as Famous as Notre Dame. We waited about 10 minutes to get in, while the line at Notre Dame was wrapped around the cathedral. A very beautiful cathedral with impressive stained glass windows.

A Gem!. Not only was this the most beautiful part of Paris but this was the most beautiful thing I saw on my 5 country trip through Europe. The ceilings and the stained glass windows were stunning! The chapel is small and will only take an hour of your time and with it's proximity to Notre Dame you have no excuse not to visit. Entry is also included with the Paris Pass. Make sure you go upstairs for the floor to ceiling stained glass windows, it's magical. You will not be disappointed!
Gorgeous.. It may not be as grand as other chapels and churches but what's inside will take your breath away. Buy the double ticket for entrance to the Conciergerie next to it.

Up. This is said to be one of the most beautiful gothic architectures. Its effect of vertical space is striking, though not so much from a structural point of view as from the point of view of the interior, which is very light, coloured and aerial.

It's an uphill climb. So I know the Montmartre visit is not complete without a visit to Saint Chapelle... But I rather spend the time elsewhere. It has great religious and historic value but so does the rest of the outdoor museum called ... ParisSkip this one and spend more time walking through the winding streets of Monmartre
A Jewel. Worth whatever wait you have to endure. It is breathtakingly beautiful, the stained glass is unparalleled, and the art is gorgeous.

Stunning!. This chapel is absolutely gorgeous and can be visited using your Paris Pass too. Make sure to head upstairs to get the best view of the glorious windows: the light shining through is beautiful beyond description. You just have to experience to understand but it's one of the most lovely places I've visited in Europe.

Worth your time. It would be a pity to make it to Notre Dame and to then not walk the short distance over to Saint Chapelle. Notre Dame is fantastic and impressive, but the upstairs chapel at Saint Chapelle is like being inside a jewel box. Some of the best stained glass in Europe.

Exquisite!. This was one of the highlights of our Parisian trip. It is utterly breathtaking!Yes there are yet more queues (is there anywhere in Paris that doesn't?) but persevere and you will be rewarded with one of the best sights in Paris! What a miracle that this 13th century gem has survived intact.The chapel has two storeys. The stained glass on the ground floor is impressive, but this was for the ordinary people. Upstairs the chapel was for royalty and the court ,and is all coloured light, it is more glass than wall and I can only describe it as like being inside a kaleidoscope or an exquisite jewelled lantern. Not only is the glass impressive but also the painting on the walls. Currently the chapel is coming to the end of an extensive restoration and the rose window and some of the tall 50 feet windows remain covered but there is still more than enough to make the visit worthwhile and the restored and cleaned windows absolutely sing and probably look as good as they did 800 years ago. I can only hope that the authorities include restoration of some of the beautiful painting that is being very badly damaged on the narrow staircases.
concerts are outstanding. Go if you have the chance! Very moving, perfect venue for a classical concert. Sun was setting through the stained-glass - just magnificent!

Stunning. It's tucked away, near the justice building (therefore security is tight), but with the museum pass, we waltzed right in! The downstairs sanctuary is dark, but beautifully somber. However, go upstairs to be amazed. The stain glass, filled with the light of the sunny day, is breathtaking! Each panel tells a different story from the bible. I can't even fathom the hours of artistry that went into such a creation. Worth checking out.

A Must see. This chapel, that used to be the private chappel of the king of France, situated inside the ministry of justice (close to the Notre-dame) is a absolute must-see. The glass stained windows are without the slightest doubt some of the most impressive in the world. Simply go there and be awed!

Stunning stained glass. We were there about 9.30 so a very small queue for the security check and then we were inside. The first chapel was very small and dark and I thought I'd got the wrong place until we found an unmarked side door that led up to the main chapel. Absolutely breathtaking! Almost floor to ceiling stained glass and a flood of light and colour. Be aware the security check will confiscate things like nail scissors if you carry those with you - it's a bit like an aircraft security check. I would recommend buying a museum pass as entrance is about 8€ and that soon mounts up in a couple of days - a 2 day pass is 42€ I think.

favorite stop in paris. The most beautiful and spectacular landmark in Paris it is a must see for all ages. It is tucked away in what I believe is the palace of justice but once you get in and see it you will be in awe. See this over Notre Dame or D'Orsay.
Beautiful church. We were blessed to attend a service which started just as we arrived at the church. Made the visit especially unique!
Vivaldi's Four Seasons in a magical setting.. Too bad the sun wasn't shining through the gorgeous stained glass windows. Arrive early, tight security check point like airports.

Could skip if you do not have museum pass. It is under renovation when we visited, the chapelle is still open but there weren't any relics of the Passion of Christ (main reason why we visited). It is great example of French Gothic architecture
The overall view of stain glass windows were very nice, however each tell a story of the bible but was not any easy to read.
best windows i ever saw. Don't look at too many pictures before you go, just arrive and be astounded by the stained glass. Sunny day recommended!
Awesome. Beautiful little chapel hidden within the palais de justice worth a look see if you are on the ile de la cite and have the time.

Beautiful. Only small but so beautiful. The colours in the stain glass windows are breath taking. Some renovation work taking place at present. EUR8.50 entry. Although not on the outside board, did shut for lunch from about 1 to 2 (no notices) so had to queue for a little while - but worth it

Unique place!. I've been visiting the chapel several times, because I simply love the stained-glasses, the way the sunlight / sun rays come inside of the place. I find solace in this place just by looking towards them and almost seeing the presence of a superior power protecting us, whatever this might be :)
Defintely a must see in Paris!

Excellent Stained-Glass Saturated Cathedral. In conjunction with seeing the Notre Dame de Paris cathedral, see nearby the Sainte-Chapelle cathedral. The glowing colors on display are worth it, illuminating books of the Bible in multiple sections of glass art.

Sainte-Chapelle. The little chapel with the most awesome stained glass windows I have seen. You have to go through a metal detector so the line takes awhile to get through. The windows were floor to ceiling and very intricate. The problem right now is the restoration going on so half the windows are covered, otherwise this would be rated excellent.

Absolutely fabulous. The architecture is amazing, the decoration over the top, and the history reverberates from the walls and passages. If you can, catch a concert at Sainte Chapelle - the acoustics are sublime. Finding the entry can be a little difficult, however.
Not to be missed. Beautiful, amazing and just incredibly wonderful. Not to be missed for the unique stained glass windows...

An Incredible Piece of Art. Had visited St. Chapelle before, but the beauty of this little church hasn't diminished. The only thing I found different, was the winding stairs to the upper floor. Didn't remember them at all, apparently, that's what aging does for you. BUT don't let the steps stop you. This church's windows are incomparable. Just take your time.

A breathtaking little church. A small, but spectacular church. Breathtaking stained glass. A lot of restoration work at the moment, but very much worth a visit. We did not see the prison, but would add that on another visit.

Small Cathedral with nice ceiling and stained glass. When I arrived at Sainte Chapelle, am abit disappointed, the exterior is going through some restoration/ construction, couldn't get a nice picture.Thereafter I enter flashing my museum pass and when I stepped in, it's very crowded in late morning and i just followed the crowd and finally made it to the the tip to see the stained glass. The cathedral is really small as compared to Notre Dame, its uniqueness would be the stained glass and its structure. Overall, the experience is pretty average and noise level was very high as there were school groups visiting that you just want to snap some pictures and get out. It's a been there done it attraction for me.
Beautiful. Every bit as beautiful and interesting as Notre Dame! Not as well known but certainly worth the effort to locate and visit. Lines were not long.

go very early to avoid lots of other visitors. Not the friendliest of personnel running this historic locationBut the glass windows are magnifientWould have been nice for some "please keep noise down" as the amound of of very loud chatter spoilt the visit.

Pretty Cathedral. Looking at the stain-glassed windows are breathtaking, but the Notre-Dame across the street outshines this church. The windows and place itself are truly gorgeous but no more than a half an hour can really be spent there. Crowds can also build up by mid-day. Unless you are on a very tight schedule, try to see the Sainte-Chapelle.

Vivaldi Four Seasons Quartet. If you love this chapel by day you are going to love the atmosphere and the evening light on the stained glass windows when hearing the four Seasons. A must on any cultural visit to Paris or to start an evening of late night wining and bar hoping. It all melds into one in Paris!

Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle is just stunning. Unfortunately there was a lot of scaffolding up when I visited, but there was still plenty of stained glass to see. You need to climb up a narrow staircase to get to the chapel which may be confronting if you are claustrophobic, but it is manageable and well worth it. This is definitely worth visiting when in Paris.

Beautiful Stained glass windows in 12th Century Cathedral. Magnificent stained glass windows in cathedral dating back to 1248 built for Louis IX. One of the most interesting sites we saw in Paris. Long lines for security but once inside you have ample time to look around & appreciate the beauty of the cathedral. A real jewel.
OK. If you like big stained glass windows, this is a must, if not, no big deal---I went it was OK, If I did not have the 4 day pass, I would have skipped it. But that's just me...

You really need extra stars for this one.. Here are the basics.It's a cathedral well worth your effort to see it.It is going to be a real problem, seeing it. The crowds of the high season are monumental.While we happened by one evening and walked right in for a concert, you may not be as lucky.You can go to the official site: http://www.sainte-chapelle.monuments-nationaux.fr and go to Sainte Chapelle information.It is INSIDE the walls of a working Paris police station. I suggest you leave backpacks, large bags and so forth at home, as you will go through an airport like security station including xray.It is just a little way down from Notre Dame, on the Ile de la cite (the island in the Seine where Notre Dame is located). There is only one small sign, that I've seen, pointing to the entrance.A nearby Metro station is St. Michel. This is perhaps a five minute walk to the entrance.I highly recommend you attend a concert if you can. They are about E 25 to E75 depending onthe seating. Personally I think the cheap seats are just fine.When last I saw St. Chapelle, in early May, there were over 100 people in line to see it.

My favourite place in Paris. The stained glass windows are something to behold. They are incredibly beautiful. Unfortunately there is a lot of scaffolding inside at the moment blocking a lot of the gorgeous windows, including the rose window. What a shame. Still I would say don't miss it!! So many people overlook this chapel when in Paris. If you have the Museum Pass, do it!!

Forget the Notre Dame queues. This little Chapel is just magnificent. We were recommended the Chapel and never imagined just how good it would be... the windows superb, the history astonishing and the queues in peak-season not as long as her sister's (Notre Dame) down the road.Do bear in mind it sits oddly within the Palais de Justice (Law Courts) so you will endure some very thorough searching (don't bring your picnic lunch utensils).One guide says choose a sunny day .. I think just avoid an overcast one. Beautiful....

the large rose stain glass window is under repair. wait for this one. Visit here on a sunny day. Warning. Not cheap. I would have given more stars if the big window repair was complete.There are concerts here in the evenings, used to be 5 franc, now 40 euro.

A Lovely Evening. We went to a Vivaldi concert at Sainte-Chapelle during our recent week in Paris. The cathedral, even under construction, is simply amazing. The 13th century stained glass is beautiful and the acoustics are really good. If you get a chance, buy Sainte-Chapelle concert tickets in advance at classictic.com.

Breathtaking!. Don't miss this chapel. Here is an example of great Gothic architecture and some of the most beautiful stained glass windows. It is quite close to Notre Dame so just take a short walk here and enjoy!

Just watch your children's jaws drop!. I have been to Paris several times but never been here. We were able to bypass the queue with the Museum pass, and enter a small doorway just within the Palais de Justice complex. At first you enter a rather non-descript crypt - historically interesting but hardly awe inspiring. But then you climb a spiral staircase to an upper floor - filled with the most gorgeous light coming from all directions from high gothic arched stained glass windows. My 9 year old was transfixed - we had chosen a sunny day and she said that the play of the light from the windows on her was like "being covered with butterflies". Few things make any of us say wow any more - this is a sight you will truly enjoy.

WOW!. A must see, especially if you have the museum pass. The glass in this one out does Notre-Dame. I was so glad it was sunny to see the true beauty. So hard to believe that this was over 600 years old!
woww!!!. we took like half an hour to find it, but it was worth it. amazing example of gothic architecture, don´t leave it for and other time, you have to be there and see it with your own eyes.

Awe inspiring!. This little chapel is amazing... I think almost everyone who walked through the door gave an audible gasp of exclamation. The beauty of this place is simply incredible and like no other church/ chapel I've seen. Having toured many many churches in Paris and the UK, this is the only one I can clearly remember. Many of them become a blur because of various similarities, but this is totally different. It is not just another church! If you can at all manage a visit here it is well worth it. It's only a few minutes walk from Notre Dame and is quite small so you can easily fit both into the one day... With time to spare. An absolute must see in Paris!

Classical concerts at Sainte-Chapelle. If you like classical music, plan to get tickets for a classical music concert at Sainte-Chapelle. The chamber music concerts are at 7pm and last about an hour. The music was absolutely beautiful with the perfect acoustics that are afforded at Sainte-Chapelle. You are close enough to see the string players' fingers fly! The next day when we passed the line to get in to Sainte Chapelle, we were glad we took advantage of the concert - no line! You can find information on the concerts online and can buy the tickets before you go. Get there at least 15 minutes early so you can sit close to the musicians.

Stunning. For what it lacks in size, it makes up for in power. During my vacation to Paris and Italy I stepped inside more beautiful churches than I probably ever will again my entire life. Sainte Chapelle was, hands down, my favorite.The feeling you get when standing in this church is indescribable. I was there in January so the crowds were thinner than normal. I would recommend getting their early or before closing so that you have a chance to be in the church with few other visitors or, even better, alone.

HD Experience without screens and projections...Worth the wait and the entry fee. Yes the queues are long, yes it is one of the most over priced entries that you might end up paying for in Paris, from outside, it might not look extraordinary and yes renovation work is also going on, but after so many turn offs, if someone still tells you that this is one of the best places, must see attractions of Paris then believe me it is something special!The entry might be low profile but then, what suddenly stands before you after entering is nothing but a grand jewel. The tinted glasses couldn't have been brighter and the designs couldn't have been more evergreen. The hall makes you feel that everything is HD. And please don't miss the narrow staircase leading to the 1st floor which is even bigger and better. Photography options are aplenty and if you are lucky enough to visit the place in a sunny day then you probably would never forget the first sight of it ever in your life like me!

Just Spectacular. This is a must see. Even after visiting Notre Dame, this is worth visiting. The downstairs servants chapel is nice, really beautiful, but going upstairs and see the windows, well, you have to see this. I can't really describe the beauty and color and the reverence you feel there.

Magical concert. We received a flyer from the Eva (guide of WalkingTours of Paris)for a random concert at Sainte-Chapelle, and decided to go.What a beautiful place! Lots of security to go in at first and thena magical concert in this gorgeous chapel. Vivaldi, Schubert, etc.

ALWAYS my first place to go in Paris!. We would never think of going to Paris without including Sainte-Chapelle. Without a doubt, it's one of the most wonderfully stunning creations of Man. Although I've been there several times, its beauty still takes my breath away. It's like walking into a precious jewel. Usually, after I've been there for a few minutes, I'll go and stand by the entrance to hear people's reactions (gasps) as they enter. If you want to experience true beauty, indeed, to be surrounded by it and enveloped in it, include Sainte-Chapelle in your itinerary.

Long Lines Make it Hard to Enjoy. You have to be persistent, or go on off days and hours to avoid the long wait for this center of French History.Blue stained glass windows create a special mood and are worth the wait.

Okay - better use of time. While the stained glass was amazing - didn't feel it was any better than at Notre Dame. Otherwise this didn't have anything else to offer. I would believe you will have better things to see than this in Paris and would not return.

Really Amazing but..... This should be visited on sunny days only if you want the really oooh and aaah experience. As with most Paris attractions you will probably have to wait for an hour or more before entering and this together with the entrance price and the crowd around you is compensated only when the glasses are well lit. Those with a sound knowledge of the bible do not need the guide...

Restoration Work going on.. It was along que even though we had museum passes. Once inside we found a whole wall blocked of for restoration. Fair enough, it has to be done sometime. But the windows are lovely and when you consider the history it makes you stand and stare a little bit

Sainte-Chapelle. Like Notre Dame, everytime we go to Paris (14 times) we have to visit Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass windows are magnificient and the history of the Chapelle is fascinating. But it is mainly the beauty of the windows that keeps drawing us back.

Exquisite. We were originally a little underwhelmed, work was taking place on the building and whilst lovely was not what we expected. Sainte-Chapelle had been suggested to us with rave reviews. We were on our way out of the Chapelle when by the off chance we saw the door to the right and curiously had a quick peak. Of course this led us upstairs to the real marvel of Sainte-Chapelle. I wonder how many people miss the full beauty of this Church. Make sure you don't miss it!!

Really Nice Concert. We had a nice evening event listening to the concert. The music was wonderful with really good artists and the ambience with the stained glass was memorable. A little quirky with 3 seperate waits in 3 lines til allowed to enter.

Fantastic glasswindows. In Gothic style, the Sainte Chapelle is a part of the Palais de Justice, where Marie Antoinette was emprisoned. Visit is at noon, because it is the best time to admire the vitraux. If you have time, attens a concert there, it's a beautiful experience. It is located at Ile de France, very near to Notre Dame church.
Amazing stained glass. Parts were under renovation, but still an incredible take to just stand and take it the glory of the scale of this room. The artistry, colors, and light are just spectacular
Breathtaking. When you walk inside and see the stain glass windows...it is the most breathtaking sight ever...the colors are so vibrant...its a magcial expierence

As beautiful as a jewelry box!. Paris was crowded, and it took us about 40 minutes just to go through the security check point. We got the Paris Museum Passes, so we could go directly into Sainte-Chapelle. Without the pass, you had to be in the queue again for the tickets.
Stained Glass. Beautiful stained glass windows surround you in the chapel. The windows have been beautifully restored. Restoration continues.

Finest in Gothic Church Architecture. Long lines await your entry into this wonderful facility, but the wait is certainly worth it. The stained glass in the upper chamber is to die for, when one considers that the facility was completed in only six years. Amazing for Gothic times. You will be amazed at the beauty and the abundance of picture-taking opportunities.

A hidden beauty. We were fortunate to visit this special chapel and see not only its rare and beautiful stained glass windows but also to experience a wonderful performance by very talented violinists and an young opera singer who took our breath away. What a wonderful evening!

My favorite church in Paris. The Sainte Chapelle was designed to welcome the relics (a piece of the Holy Cross) brought back from the Crusades and was thought as a jewel box.Even it is in the middle of the horrible Palais de Justice and even if you have to queue on a busy boulevard, it is worth the trouble. The first floor with these beautiful blue stain glass windows is one of the most beautiful thing I have seen in my life.
Sainte-Chapelle. Beautiful place. We attended a concert here one night and the acoustics was great. There was nothing to dislike

Not Worth It. I left this church feeling cheating out of my money. Yes, the stained glass is cool, but aside from that it offered no other significant attraction. There are plenty of other old churches that you can visit for free and feel very comfortable that you are not missing much. In fact I appreciated the stained glass at the Cluny Museum more than I did at this place. Spend your very valuable travel time elsewhere as this sight is not all that great.

Not worth the wait or ticket price. The line to get in is not nearly worth the payoff. SC shares grounds with another official building so everyone passes through the same security line, and it seems to regularly be a 45 to an hour wait. If you happen to stroll by after visiting Notre Dame and there is no line (and you have a museum pass) stop in. The chapel is beautiful when all back lit by the sun. Currently it is under quite a renovation, and if the sun isn't providing light, the panes will look like "shades of lead". Not worth your time with so many amazing things to see in this city.
Not to be missed. Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most spectacular churches I have visited. Words can not describe the beauty of the stained glass.

Beautiful glass. This church was small but had one room with beautiful glass all around it. It probably ended up looking better in our photos than in person! Unfortunately half the room was under renovation so we couldn't get a good full room photo. A bit pricey though for what it was,

A Must!. If you are wondering which church is worth going inside and which isn't you HAVE to go inside Sainte-Chapelle! Its such a beautiful sight! We didn't have the museum pass so we had to wait in line, first for security and then to get in. All-in-all it took about 30 minutes (when we left there was no line for either!).

A magnificent site!. I was in the Saint Chapelle in May 2014 for a violin concert with members of the National Violin Orchestra of France. The Chapelle is magnificent, the windows are just a piece of art, the floor is another one too. It is been restored so having a concert in it only makes it more attractive and a magnificent gift of art to anybody.

Awe inspiring. Long securty lines to get into the square that gains entrance to The chapel. Once inside not very crowded. The lower section is nice but the upper chapel with all the stained glass is incredible. I think it's worth your time. Museum Pass accepted.

Like no other church in the world. Breathtaking, like standing inside a jewel box. Go on a sunny day to get the full effect. Also, they frequently offer concerts and the acoustics are superb - what a great venue for a Paris concert!

Hidden gem. Used access with our Paris Pass - don't know what cost is. We lined up about 30 minutes before opening. Be careful not to join the other queue which is going into the law courts! You might up next to the defendants! This is an amazing gem with the audio guide provided. Take your time listening to audio guide and you will learn so much. If you get there early before crowds then your photos wont have a sea of people in them.

Booking problems. I have tried on numerous occasions over the past few weeks to make a group booking. The Centre des Monuments Nationaux website keeps telling me they have received my email and they will respond soon, but this never happens.I'm hoping our visit next week will be worth all this effort.

A Gem of Gothic Architecture. Built between 1242 and 1248, Sainted-Chapelle is composed of two sanctuaries one built on top of the other. As a result the are many narrow stairs not easy for those with mobility issues. The 15 stained glass windows in the upper chapel are well worth the effort to view as the intricacy and brilliant colors (try to go on a sunny day) are extraordinary. There are 1113 scenes in the windows that depict the biblical story of man from Genesis through the resurrection. Written Guides in a variety of languages explain how to read the windows from left to right .

Stained Glass Windows Divine!. One place we recommend to all our friends is not to miss Sainte-Chapelle while in Paris. Get there early because lines grow quickly. You will marvel at the stained glass masterpieces and know you are in a divine place.
The windows omg. I hadn't looked up about this chapel and wished we had explored the concierge nearby more. Sooo beautiful an must
Charming church. We enjoyed looking round this beautiful ancient church. A good second choice after seeing the queues at Notre Dame. If you are in that area definitely worth a visit.

Still my favourite site in Paris. St Chapelle was my favourite site in Paris when I first visited. 22 years and a few visits later it remains my favourite. It does not look like much of anything from the street, especially with all the construction barriers that are currently there. Inside is a royal chapel that will take your breath away. The stained glass windows come alive in the sunlight. Simply magical. Don't miss it!

Stunning. Wow, the stained glass windows here are absolutely stunning. We bought a combined ticket with the Conciergerie which was also excellent. A lot of restoration work is going on here and there are excellent videos running which explain what is being done and show the experts at work.Don't miss this.
Best stained glass in the world.. This place is not too impressive from the outside but the inside is so worth it. It has the biggest and best stained glass in the world. A real wow factor.

Restoration Dulled the Effect. During our visit, Sainte-Chapelle was in the midst of renovation, so it was impossible to get the full effect of the place. The lines were very long as the day wore on, and, frankly, I did not think the place worth the lines during renovation.

A Jewel Box on the Island: Don't Miss It. This was absolutely the high point of our one-week, first trip to Paris. A comparatively tiny cathedral near Notre Dame, the French kings worshipped here, and used to keep various religious bits and pieces (piece of the Cross, the Crown of Thorns, etc.), but that's been moved to the Notre Dame Cathedral. Never mind: It's the stained glass that's the wonder here: 360 degrees of beautiful panels many meters high, astonishingly beautiful in the afternoon light.

Always awesome. With our Museum Pass we avoided the long ticked line and started our tour in the basement. Very beautiful but you have to walk up the tight spiral staircase to the main chapel. When you exit the staircase you will say "WOW" (this was the third time I said "WOW"). I always come here on my trips to Paris -do NOT miss it. The towering stained glass windows will blow your mind. Even though there is some restoration proceeding - the beauty of the chapel is a true work of art at the peak. It could be overlooked from the street-look for the signs to enter. A well hidden secret treasure.

Incredible. Incredible stained glass with 1000's of panels. There is some construction going on May 2014, not sure how long it will last. Everyone must stand in same security line, but then museum pass will allow you to bypass ticket purchase line.

Beautiful but a little run down. I will never forget the first time I visited the Sainte - Chapelle, really the most stunning floor to ceiling stained glass I have ever seen. It's sadly looking a little tired on my last visit, they are doing renovations so there was a large area under scaffolding. There also seems to be a lot of souvenir stalls on the lower half of the chapel which spoilt the effect a bit. Still highly recommended.

Under construction. Again we thought we would get faster access with a museum pass but this was not true. You still wait in all the security lines with everyone else. What we could see of the windows was amazing but the back half of the chapel is closed and under renovation.

Concert in Ste Chapelle. What could be better than a Vivaldi performance in the chapel of Ste Chapelle surrounded by the most exquisite stained glass in the world? Really felt like a privilege to be there.At our visit, a restoration was underway so that the crown jewel of the chapel, the Rose Window, wasn't visible, but breathtaking nonetheless.Tickets available at the souvenir shop across the street, about 30 euros admission.

TRULY DIVINE BEAUTY. On my books, this is the most stunning church we have ever seen. Most churches depress me: they are built to make the human feel small and insignificant and that is not my idea of us. This one, Medieval Gothic, elegant, graceful, endlessly pleasing to the eye, even though it’s going through a renovation of the huge rosette window, is like a ferry-tale.  Staunchly devote King Louis IX built it in 1929 to host Christ’s Crown of Thorns, which he had managed to buy from the impoverished Latin Emperor in Constantinople. The purchase price of the holly relic was about three times what the building of the church cost to His Majesty. It was built next to the King’s Palace so he can step directly from His Kingdom into the antechamber of the Divine One. Ironically, the Palace was destroyed but the Church stayed. The irony is that the Crown is not even there anymore, it’s in Notre Dame…So much for historical preservation. Converted into administrative offices during the revolutions (Barbarians in all places and times are quite alike), it is now back for us to see and enjoy immensely.  Two lines to get in La Sainte Chapelle, one through security (it’s adjacent to the Ministry of Justice) and one for tickets. The first one moves fast, the security gate is not working, but they don’t care. The guard wants to know what’s the red air duster in my photo bag, I tell him “a hand grenade”. Guard does not like that and pumps the duster, then lets us go trough.

Must see beautiful stained glass windows!. The Sainte Chapelle is close to the Notre Dame. Is one of the venues that is included in the museum pass. This will allow to skip the line and be able to go in quicker. It's a medieval church with impressive stained glass windows giving account of Bible passages at the second level. At the entry level there is a small chapel with a statue and interesting wooden gilded ceiling. At the second level the beautiful stained glass with vaulted ceiling leave the visitor in awe. It will require some time to appreciate the details of the different glass panels. Also, there are medieval religious paintings on the walls and some doorways. There are also some wooden carved images around the room. Can also appreciate the intricate wood carved frames on doorways, windows, walls and arches.To get to the second level, needs to go up through a spiral narrow stairway. Take care when coming down. Can spend as much time as needed to admire the artwork around the the interior.

Magnifique!. To bypass long lines- buy a combo St Chapelle and Conciergerie ticket next door.See the less crowded Conciergerie first - the prison of Marie-Antoinette ( See separate review.Must do if you are there ) Then go through security to enter the church.Really can't avoid it.The church is small but breathtaking!It was built in 1242 in a mere 6 years by King Louis IX to house the supposed Crown of Thorns of Christ.The interior is a heavenly light filled space.15 separate panels of stained glass,cover 6,500 sq ft.There are more than 1,100 different scenes depicted from the Bible.The Altar for the Crown of Thorns sits high above.Now it is in the treasury of the Notre Dame and is shown only on Good Friday and the first Friday of each month at 3pm.Simply astounding stained glass art.Must see.

Stunning Stained Glass. A lovely spot in the heart of Paris. The stained glass windows depict the entire Bible and are absolutely magnificent. A section is under construction, but it is still worth the visit.

The best stained glass windows in the world!. This is a gothic chapel, smaller than most but the glass is just a once in a life time experience; many people lay down on a pew or the floor to see the windows, which extend to the ceiling. It is a good place to use a ipad to take pictures so you can just flip the view to opposite and take pictures over your head. It does not look like much from the outside but we found it much more beautiful than Notre Dame which was gothic; big , cold and like a tomb.
