Beautiful cultural treasure, but renovation this trip cut off half the view. Sainte-Chapelle is stunning if the light is right and the crowds aren't too thick, but on the partly cloudy day we visited with renovation blocking a third of the windows and obstructing half the view, the effect was not as spectacular. I think the price is a bit steep for the shortness of the view (you have two levels) although I used my Paris Passport. It was an engineering and architectural marvel when it was built but amazingly cost less than the relic it was built to house. For me, the Conciergerie - on the same grounds as Sainte-Chapelle, was far more interesting. See both.
Precious!. Breathtaking! Such a beautiful chapel. A must see in Paris. Be prepared for the stairs and lines, though.

Cautionary Tale for the Mobility Challenged. I reviewed Sainte-Chappelle two years ago, and everything I wrote then still stands. I need, however, to add a new wrinkle. When I travelled in 2012, it was with my "kid family" and easy movement by foot is no issue. This time I travelled with my "parent family" and I suddenly realized how hard it is to get into Sainte-Chappelle. You see, in 2012 I had been so awed by the beauty of the stained glass that I carried away no recollection of the tight spiral staircase that leads from thenentry floor to the upper level. Honestly, I don't know what I was thinking! How else was one going to get from level to level in a 14th-century church? But sure enough here I was encouraging my mom and sister up the 30 or so steps to the upper chapel ... and then we had to come down again. It was not a good thing! What should have been an awe inspiring moment at the top of the stairs, was simply a moment of relief that the ordeal was temporarily over. Her comment? "Is this all there is to see?" I was so sad! It should have been an experience of awe and wonder, but instead it was disappointment. I had genuinely wanted to share with her what had been a transcendent experience for me two years ago, but crucially, I neglected to calculate the stairs.So this is my warning: do not take someone to Sainte-Chappelle if they cannot easily handle 30+ tight circular stone steps!Other than that, how was it, you ask? Beautiful, but not quite as radiant at 2012. The restoration now has the rose window covered and this really disrupts the light. On the other hand we were amongst the first to be allowed in after lunch, and we virtually had the place to ourselves, and I have to say it felt oddly intimate.If you can tough out the line and manage the stairs, then do not pass up Sainte-Chappelle ... and then schedule yourself for a return trip when you know the restoration is over.
Jaw dropping!. The most beautiful little Chapel in Paris! I was lost for words very beautiful! Gorgeous stained glass - loved it!

Beautiful! Enjoyed this more than tours of large cathedrals.. Go and see the amazing stained glass. This place is so beautiful and right-sized. It isn't so large that you feel like an ant as in many of the larger churches. Pictures can not show you the experience of being in the stained glass sanctuary bathed in colored light.

Long wait. The chapel is beautiful, but still being renovated after 7 years. Lots was still blocked off. We did not have a pre-booked tour, and had to wait in line for over an hour as big groups sailed in ahead of us. Not sure sight was worth the wait and price.

A gem. Most tourists will miss out on Sainte-Chapelle. It has one of the most amazing collections of stain glass windows I have ever seen. It is included in the Paris Museum Pass (a must if going to ≥3 sites). Definitely worth a visit.

The best medieval stained glass in the world!. You will probably be faced with a fairly long queue to get in but preserver - it moves quickly and you will not have seen such stunning stained glass anywhere else. A magical place.

Do attend a concert here. It will be one of the most memorable parts of your trip! And Paris is so far west that the sun sets very late: you will be able to see the stained glass with natural light even at night!

Day 3 First time in Paris Diary. Part 1- St. Chapelle. It was not a good day to visit the St chapelle because of the restoration work. The church is located inside a government compound. So, all people going in workers and tourists pass by a security check. This may extend down the street if the queue is long. Using the museum pass, we got in the ground floor.After locating the narrow spiral staircase, which can be quite suffocating, we finally got to the main church where the stained glass is. About 25 % of the church is closed off which was disappointing. The glass was detailed and very colorful. But it is too high making it very hard to interpret the story of the bible without a guide and without binoculars.This church is indeed beautiful. It might be wise to do research on the story of the panels before going and to bring binoculars.

Intricate stained glass work from 13th Cent.. It was well worth the wait in the queue to see the Gothic chapelle (perhaps 20 minutes wait). Each of the over 1,000 scenes depicted in the stained glass work is unique and also very intricate. The start of the stained glass is from Genesis in the bible and then it goes on to scenes from the new testament.

Stunning. This was a short trip but WELL worth it, the ground floor of this was truly stunning and light up so softly. We got upstairs and our breath was taken away by the amazingly stunning stained glass windows....we were very lucky when some sun came through and the colour of the floor, this was just gorgeous

A little jewel box next to the great dame of Paris. The stain glass windows have to be seen on a sunny day to fully appreciate their beauty, Wish I had thought to bring binoculars, since each window tells a story and is full of details. Use your museum pass to bypass the ticket line. You still have to go through a security line first, since it's next to the Palais of Justice. Be sure to visit the Conciergerie on the same block.

...the History!. It is amazing to me to see all the beautiful building in Paris & the seeping of History in them. Sainte-Chapelle is a very lovely place with beautiful stained glass windows. Don't miss the place that Marie Antoinette was held before her execution, in the building next door.

A must see!. This is one of the places that you must see. It is one of the spectacular cathedrals (Chapel) in France and a special one at that. I won't go into detail but just to say that you must go there and see this place.
A treasure!. Stunning stained glass windows, winding stone staircases engendering tremendous respect for those generations before us who created such beauty centuries ago.
Fantastic. We went twice, once for the daytime tour, once for the evening chamber mucks recital. The latter was worth every euro. The stained glass is amazing.

Beautiful!. The stained glass windows are beautiful. It is a small church, and quick to go through. The line outside goes quick, and is covered by the museum pass, and very close to Notre Dame. Not to be missed!When you enter you are in the downstairs of the church, you need to head upstairs to see the gorgeous panels.

See a concert here!. We went at night to 2 concerts at Sainte-Chapelle and it was one of the most magical nights of my life. The audience was small and the artists were inspiring. This tops my list of favourite things to do in Paris. Tickets were 30€ (approx.) and you can purchase them on the net prior. This is a once in a lifetime, bucket list type of experience.

Not your typical church. Though the stained glass windows are still being restored (one by one) you can still spend an hour or two looking at the incredible scenes on those that are completed. Get a guide or search the scenes and match them with your bible memory. The detail is simply amazing.

Small but beautiful. Since we had museum pass, we paid nothing. The line was 25 mins but well worth it. YOu are in and out in 30 mins but that is a good thing...use your museum pass to move on to the next thing.
jewel box. Much smaller than we anticipated but a glittering beauty. Long security lines went very quickly . Don't be intimidated by them!

Stunning. Went to Sainte-Chapelle for an evening concert (was referred by a friend) - sensational. We got our tickets across the road at the Tabac a couple of days prior so we wouldn't miss out and it was everything we had heard and more, loved it. The stained glass was beautiful (although there was renovations being done at the time). This is one attraction/concert not to be missed if ever in Paris.

Hope the renovations wrap up soon.... Unfortunately the renovations cover some of the most beautiful parts of the church, so the experience is lacking from when it's in its full glory. However, I still think it's one of the best places to visit in Paris!

Concerts in the chapel - a truly remarkable experience!. My friend and I stopped here at the advice of someone else who had been and am I ever glad we did. The stained glass was breathtaking. As we were leaving I noticed a tiny sign about concerts in the chapel. WOW!!!!We bought VIP seats to an evening performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons €40 (I think it was €30 for mid-seats and €20 for the back of the room). What an experience! While it wasn't the best performance I have heard (some may disagree) it was absolutely well worth the price and a truly wonderful experience to hear and see such a performance in a room like that (one that had already been around for some 475 years before Vivaldi wrote Four Seasons). I could imagine kings and other dignitaries hearing similar performances hundreds of years ago in the very same spot). I highly recommend attending a concert here. Even with VIP tickets go early to secure the seat you want.
I must see in Paris. This is one of the three churches in Paris you must see, it also has the best looking stained glass of any check I have been to in the world.
A jewel. Small chapel that you can not miss if visiting Paris.Beautiful. We were amazed by the incredible vitrals.

Wonderful stained glass - but a percentage is being restored. A queue, of course, to get in - and note that pre-booking a ticket makes little difference, as the wait to get through security seems to affect everyone alike. The glass is indeed stunning, but the rose window and three others are currently being restored, the space covered in scaffolding. The guidebook gives lots of general information, but is a bit short on specifics in the reading of each window, so unless your Biblical knowledge is extensive you may have difficulty in making much detailed sense of the narrative of each window.Binoculars (or a good zoom lens on a camera with view-finder) make it more possible to see the higher windows.But an unmissable attraction.

Ethereal when sunny. This 2-storey chapel was built at the golden age of the gothic period, the main floor for the servants and the top floor for the king and his family. The colourful stain-glass windows draw patterns on the floor when the sun hits them.

Awesome Stained Glass. Next to Notre Dame and built for the royal class, Sainte-Chapelle's structure and its artistry is mesmerezing. It is adorable. The fee is 8.50 Euro and there is a 2 Euro discount for young teens and teachers only.
The day light was illuminating through the stained glass and it was a delightful chapelle to visit.

Don't spend your time on this place. Looks big in pictures but in fact so small and not impressive for the average tourist.
Recommend you to just walk near the river or in the narrow streets of this neighbourhood.
Breathtaking.. We visited San Chapelle on a glorious sunny Paris day and it literally took my breath away with its beauty. The space is small, but the windows are gorgeous and worth the wait.

Most beautiful stained glass ever. On your trip to Paris, Notre Dame is always on the "to do" list.....but only a few blocks away is Sainte-Chapelle cathedral. Definitely add this to your list of places to see. Notre Dame is indeed grand, but the stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely breathtaking. Ordinary on the outside, the chapel will astound you with the intricate panels of glorious color.Well worth seeing, we spent more time here than Notre Dame. Fascinating!

Absolutely stunning. The stain glass is so vibrant and beautiful. This was one of my favorite places we visited and should not be missed. The stain glass panels encircling the chapel tell the entire story of the Bible. It was truly amazing when the sun shined through!

Rose window completely covered by refurbishment. . The stained glass interiors are very impressive and magnificent but as soon as you reach the floor of the chapel you are greeted with a obnoxiously large scaffolding and construction noise. The most iconic piece of glass art in the city is completely covered. We waited in the security line for thirty minutes and paid almost twenty euros to look at the church for about ten minutes. I wouldn't go until reconstruction on the rose window is complete

Sainte-Chapelle - An Underrated Jewel. When visiting must see sites in Paris, Notre Dame is normally the top of everyone's list (as it should be). But within a ten minute walk is the jewel of Sainte-Chapelle with its beautiful stained glass windows. The church is rather pedestrian on the outside because it lacks the ornate sculpture and architectural beauty of Notre Dame Cathedral. But step inside and you can't help but be overwhelmed by the ornate and elaborate stained-glass windows that are even more beautiful with the late afternoon sun streaming in. Although the church is in the midst of a multi year restoration effort that limits the view of some of the windows, don't let that dissuade you from this visit. The Paris museum pass covers the admission charge.

Stained Windows. Sainte Chapelle is one of Paris oldest and most significant monuments. Built by Louis IX, it was meant to house relics he had acquired during the crusades. The most striking feature of the Gothic chapel is the stained glass above the actual place of worship, well worth braving the long queues here.

Restoration work. Fabulous place, well worth a visit but might be worth waiting until they have finished the restoration work as much of the upper chapel was hidden. Good idea - they had cards to walk around with in different langauges.

A very nice short visit. We visited Saint Chapelle near opening time on a Saturday morning. I had read that there can be queues here but we got in pretty quickly. The floor to ceiling stained glass windows are quite spectacular. Half the room was blocked off for renovations but there was still enough for us to see. We did not need to spend too much time here but it was worth sticking our heads in for a look.

Beautiful. One of the most beautiful buildings I've seen. The stained glass windows are incredible however four star because due to renovations you can only see half the room... and I wanted to see the rose window yet it was all covered. I would've been ok with that if they charged a discounted fee since you don't get to see it all but that really frustrated me. It'll be amazing when it's finished.

Fabulous windows spoilt by renovation work. This is a spectacular building but it was marred by the work going one which meant only part of the windows could be seen - also quite expensive and had to go through airport like security. Only one main room with lower room below. Our expectations were not matched by the reality.

Beautiful, vibrant colours. Stunning stained glass windows, the colours were spectacular. Some on-going renovation work means that a couple of windows were cordoned off, still worth a visit but I would like to go back from 2015 when it will be all done.

Awesome!. A little difficulty getting in, because, despite signs that indicated free entrance for under 26s, the lady wanted to charge us. Thought downstairs was lovely until realised that the amazing show was upstairs. Spectacular! 4 instead of 5-stars due to no bathrooms anywhere nearby (except one messy one with a half-hour queue).
Restoration in progress. Some of the most gorgeous stained glass windows I have seen.It will be outstanding when redone.With the restoration it is tough to really enjoy it as much as it merits

Restoration in Progress!. Arrived too late to be admitted, so returned the next day. Only church with an admission fee (8.50 Euros) tho' technically no longer a church. Half the upper chapel was covered and un-viewable due to restoration work The rest that was in view was mostly covered in dust! What's left was amazing: stained glass windows that tell the stories of the Bible. It's a small area made smaller due to restoration work- it's basically one tall room! IMHO the admission fee should have been reduced to 3 - 4 Euros during restoration.
Amazing.. Just amazing. The artistry, craftsmanship, and engiineering....Amazing. One of a kind. The story of the Bible in 15 stained glass windows, 50 ft tall.

Beautiful. We went to an evening concert which was a real treat. Vivaldi 4 seasons, Pachabel Canon and Albinoni concerto for organ and strings. The quality of playing was exceptional and I would strongly recommend this concert. It was played in such beautiful surroundings ...sublime!
It really is a unique space and well worth the visit. A must see on your trip to Paris when you are near the Notre Dame cathedral. It is such a beautiful spot with amazing stained glass.
Concert at Sainte-Shapelle. The concert is a must. It was easy to get tickets on line before we went to Paris. It was sold out the night we went so very glad we already had our tickets

Wow. We went first thing in the morning before the line got too long. They are refurbishing the rose window so there was some scaffolding that hid part of the interior. The stained glass was gorgeous and I couldn't get over how high it was. Truly amazing when you think of when it was built. I would like to see it again when they are finished with the refurbishment. Definitely go first thing if you can.
A sparkling gem. Thise windows are just shimmering--with such biblical stories to tell. A shining star on the Paris tourist sites
Splendid stained glass.. The stained glass in this former church is outstanding. The colors are awe-inspiring and the sheer area of stained glass is unsurpassed in my travels. Very much worh a trip.
Magnificent. Amazing stained glass windows. Takes your breath away. Very special and a must see visit while in Paris.

A beautiful little gem. Between all the stained glass and all the ornate gold decorating this little church, it is quite a site. Unfortunately, during our visit, they were doing some internal renovations which took away from the overall view. Nonetheless, it was very much worth the visit.

Restoration still ongoing but doesn't get in the way any moe. I first visited Sainte Chapelle five years ago, and at that time restoration covered the rounded far end of the chapel, spoiling the view entirely. However now the restoration is almost complete and so is only at the rear end of one side it doesn't actually affect your visit at all. Plus, the restoration has clearly been a success as now the windows look absolutely spectacular and have a real beauty to them. The lower chapel is also lovely, if slightly spoilt by their insistence on putting a shop in it. The only real downside was the queue which is unavoidable in Paris but sadly here the museum pass didn't allow you to skip the line. Nevertheless a truly wonderful and worthwhile visit.

Go to a concert. We went to a Violin Ensemble on the Saturday night. If you like Music, grab yourself a ticket. What a great start to an evening out. Only an hour but well worth it and to hear music in such a place makes the hairs stand up on the back of your neck. You won't be disappointed.

Try to find a quiet time.. It's sublime but having been back a couple of times it seems to get packed and hectic despite the efforts of the staff to keep loud or shrill visitor voices down. The height the stone the windows are fantastic. I have been trying to discover whether there are any public concerts up here but not yet found one during any of my recent stays in the city. This is a can't miss place.
Under repair but still open. This is a beautiful church and is not to be missed. Just beware it is currently having some of the windows repaired including the rose window at the church entrance.
Stunning. We were lucky to visit on a sunny day, so the stained glass windows were so beautiful, the colours truly amazing.

Amazing concert. Attended a one hour Vivaldi concert in the evening in the chapel. Listening to the music of the violins while letting my eyes wander and take in the beauty of the gothic architecture and stained glass was so transfixing. The lead violinist was also quite a showman and thoroughly entertaining. This will forever stand out as one of my beautiful memories of Paris.

Sainte-Chapelle - promise of good things to come. Sainte-Chapelle is a beautiful small chapel, great for a more intimate concert or musical performance. Fascinating design of the world-famous stained glass windows but be warned, it is under renovation and only parts of it can be seen while others are still a little hard to see completely due to years of build-up of dirt. However, when it is finished, it will be spectacular.

An absolute must.... In spite of queues, in spite of the cost, you cannot miss it. Try to visit it during a sunny day, around midday, so that you can enjoy the full glory of the stained glass windows...

Amazing Windows. The level of detail and colour in the windows is incredible. The rest of the chapel is average to be honest. But the reason you go is for the windows. Some of them are being renovated so you won't see them all, but some have already been completed and you can really see the difference and it has made the colours amazing.

worth the money. Don't be fooled by the cramped space on the first floor. There are stairs to the side for you to see the experience breathtaking beauty. The 2nd floor walls are covered with stained glass. This will take some time in observing each. Get ready to really crane your neck!

Stunning Gothic architecture and stained glass. We have visited Sainte-Chapelle on previous trips to Paris and toured it again in March. The 13th century architecture and the stained glass are worthy of a visit, and if you have the Museum Pass (available for a fee) you can avoid the extremely long lines.
Wonderful. A very beautiful little chapel. I recommend to go there before 10 am, then you only have a very short waiting time.

Under renovation. The stained glass windows are incredible and worth the price of admission. But please be aware that the site in undergoing renovation (covered on the outside with a GIANT ad) and that the renovations continue inside. Perhaps not the best time to visit unless this is your first and last trip to Paris. Close to Notre Dame, so an obvious add-on for the day.

Pretty and an excellent lesson on stained gladd. We happened on Sainte-Chepelle as we were wandering around. It was very much worth the stop. The stained glass is quite dramatic. More interesting, though, at least for me, was the extensive discussion on how the glass is being preserved and restored.
Lovely . The saints chapelle is fantastic. The audioguide is worth it as it explains the windows in detail. Has a real Wow factor!
Jewel box. Skip the big brother cathedral next door and visit Sainte Chapelle. The stain glass windows will knock your sox off. Gift shop also has some nice original type items.

Accidental Visit. I actually didn't seek out Sainte-Chapelle on my visit but was fortunate enough to stumble upon it during a rain storm! I was walking around and trying to find the subway when I came across it and knew I had to go in. I was happy that I did as the photos I captured were some of my favorites.

Stained Glass Art. Was curious what this attraction had to offer, so we went and paid 8 euros. While it was a bit interesting, there wasn't much of a collection, just how the intricate stain glass art was done. I thought it cost too much because entrance to the Louvre only cost 12 euros.

Great stained glass. This is a very nice cathedral with beautiful stained glass windows. It's being restored/under construction right now so you can't see much of anything from the outside. Inside, you'll first see a lower level with smaller stained glass windows then go to another level where the main attractions of large, beautiful stained glass windows are just incredible! Entry is covered in the Museum Pass and is worth it. Plan ahead for the security check to get in which everyone must go through since this is located in a government area. We were told it could take an hour or more to get through but we arrived on the earlier side and it was about 15 minutes to get through. This is a nice place to visit in combination with Notre Dame which is nearby but far busier.

Very Nice. The architecure, stained glass & paint scheme of the building was very nice. Small cathedral near Norte Dame worth this visit. Restoration is going on to bring the buildings glory to light, you can see the difference between the B-4 & After very different

CONCERT UNDER STAINED GLASS. Probably because the venue is within the compound of the Justice Ministry it takes 1/2 hour to get through airport-style security, then join a long line and finally shuffle into the chapel. Was it worth it? Oh yes: The magnificence of the stained glass windows that surround you with every window telling a bible story and a high vaulted ceiling drawing your eyes upward as well as around are a true joy in such a small building.. Unfortunately ours was an evening visit so the true technicolor effect was partially lost. Building works which must have hidden much are drawing to a close so the building is nearly in full view.Against this background we enjoyed a delightful recital of works by Vivaldi and Pachobel performed by a talented group of string musicians which provided a relaxing end to a day of sight-seeing.TIP: I purchased ny tickets online from Classictic.com and feel I may have over-paid. Try to contact St. Chapelle directly if you can.

The holy place. It is seen by thousands every year, and wasn't quite as I expected. By the way, you go through the same security checks as if you were attending the Palais de Justice, so be careful what you are carrying!!
Disappointed. Disappointed as restoration work going on, after paying the entrance fee expected more of information. The leaflet is not well organised.

Humongous stained glass. We had the museum pass which included Saint Chapelle. We were glad we visited as the stained glass must the biggest we have ever seen, Each panel is supposed to tell a story from the Bible hence the size and intricacy of the images. Very impressive, colourful and beautiful. Worth the visit.

Like a Fancy Hogwarts. The small cathedral may not be as famous as the Norte Dame, but is just as stunning. The cathedral is small, so not a lot of time is required for the visit, but the stained glass is amazing! In February 2014 it was being restored, so we couldn't get the full effect; even so it was one of the most memorable parts of the trip for me! Good discounts with a valid student id (under 26).
Beautiful but quite expensive. This little chapel is really beautiful, with amazing glass-work on the windows, but 8,5€ is quite expensive in relation to the price of other monuments

4 season of Vivaldi concert. we've been advice by a friend not to miss the daily concert at 7.00 p.m. and we do not regret it... specially now with the summer light you can admire the stained glass windows during the concert.. and without the big crowd during the visit hours...
Just about worth the queuing. The windows are impressive but are still undergoing renovation so the full impact is lost. Longish queues unless you have one of those pass things.

would have been great without the renovation. My second time (first was in 2013) and it's still under renovation. You can't see all parts of the church but still can see the beauty of it. Prepare about 45mins-1 hour for the visit, this is a small place. Should also combine it with Conciergerie, great price if you buy the tickets altogether (12,5Eur for both as opposed to 8 Euros for each).

Best stained glass in Paris. The stained glass is spectacular. Our tour guide gave us a good overview, and there was still some renovation work being carried out, but all in all we're glad we went. We only waited in line for 15 mins, and it was a 'free' museum day, so we didn't pay entry fee. Free museum days are the first Sunday in every month. You'll only need half an hour here as the church is quite small.

Magical - walls of colour. Stop and stare in awe at the floor to ceiling rainbow of stained glass in the upper chapel. The stairs up aren't obvious; I'm sure people must leave after only seeing the lower section! Some sections are currently under repair so not all windows are visible. It's quite a quick place to visit, but well worth it (more so than nearby Notre Dame, for example).

Beautiful stained glass. As long as you're going to Notre Dame, you may as well walk to Sainte-Chapelle too. It has a small chapel downstairs that is quite impressive on its own, then the big cathedral upstairs that surrounds you with stained glass windows. Well worth a stop!
Beautiful. It was magnificent. If you enjoy history and beauty you will enjoy this site. Make sure you go to concierge to see where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned.

Most Beautiful Chapel in Paris. This chapel is glorious! Small but absolutely the most beautiful in Paris. I am so glad I went here. the stained glass is heavenly! Projected to finish reconstruction in Nov 2014. Close by is the Conciergerie-and totally worth a visit/see where Marie Antoinette was held before her execution.

So that's what beautiful stained glass looks like.... We waited in line for a good 30 minutes, any more would have been pushing it in my opinion (as others have said, you'll really only be in there 20-30 minutes). That said, very remarkable stained glass. Something I'll always remember for sure. I'd advise going when there's plenty of sunshine outside, it really makes it all the more striking (although I only went the one time so can't really compare to a time, say, if it was raining and cloudy outside). The renovation is a little distracting but not a big deal...when I was there it was maybe 1/8-1/10 of the room/the panels. Definitely worth doing but if the line is extensive stop by another time, not worth an hour or more wait.

One attraction to skip. My boyfriend and I waited in line for only about 10 minutes to enter. The tickets are 8 or 9 euros and we were inside the chapel for maybe 20 minutes. The stained glass is beautiful, but the church is very small and there was a lot of construction going on. While it is very pretty, it doesn't seem worth it when you can go to better museums or attractions for the same price.

It'll be nice when it's finished!. The high chapel is currently having some conservation work carried out and apparently has been since the 1970's. As a result three or four of the 15 main windows in the upper channel are under cover. The two chapels are absolutely stunning but don't look too closely or you might notice some worn tatty wallpaper and a few missing wall decorations. You're unlikely to spend more than 20-30 minutes inside so I might have baulked at having to queue for 2 hours to get in. Fortunately we only had to queue for 20 minutes around noon on a Saturday.

Absolutely beautifull church undergoing renovations. We visited this church in the evening listening to a Vivaldi concert. It was absolutely perfect.The architecture being restored and the colored glass windows are superb. This is a must see.

A hidden gem inside the Palais de Justice. Save this visit for a sunny day so that you can see the entire small chapel bathed in the light streaming through the stained glass. The chapel's stained glass is currently being restored so the back half of the chapel is covered in scaffolding, but it doesn't matter. This place always takes your breath away.

Beautiful Gothic "jewel box". This has to be seen to be believed. The chapel is painted throughout but appears to be mostly perpendicular stained glass. Very tall narrow windows. It is not huge but is exquisite. Sadly some of the glass is still under restoration but I can't wait to see it when they have finished.
Outstanding place. Really good hidden gemSo happy we found this place, the stained glass windows were breath taking. One of the highlights of our trip :)
Love. Absolutely beautiful. The stained glass windows are gorgeous. I bought a necklace that was stained glass. It was quite expensive but very pretty and worth it.

Beautiful and Perfectly Formed.. A hidden gem, this small and wonderfully decorated chapel is definitely worth a visit, or two. Unfortunately restoration was underway when we visited but we were still in awe of the beautiful stained glass windows and the colours and decorations on the walls was marvellous.
Concert in Sainte-Chapelle. Take the advantage an buy a ticket for a concert in Sainte-Chapelle. You never can visit this place in better circumstances.

Worth the stop!. It's not the best-kept secret anymore like it used to be, but it's still not so crazy busy you can't get in. Worth the stop - but make sure you find out the hours before you!The stained glass windows.....amazing!

Still under heavy renovation. The stained glass of this building will take your breath away. And the interior was very royal and very colorful for a church. But unfortunately it was under heavy renovation on my visit. We only able to visit two rooms at the time. We only able to sit and admiring the stained glass for a while. Looking forward to have a quick pray in the church, but no cross or praying spot that can be usedMy suggestion is to wait till this building finish the renovation to pay the visit. You probably will have better experience in 2015 when the renovation is scheduled to finished

Lots of Stained glass, Not much else. This chapel is beautiful, but there is very little to see other than the stained glass of which there is a tremendous amount. It is a little difficult to get into because of its location within a government facility. I would not pay the price to just see this. Since I had a Paris Museum Pass that got me into most of the Paris museums, this was a very easy one to visit after seeing Notre Dame. It is only a few blocks away and next door is the Conciergerie and the Crypte Archeologioue is also nearby. It is an easy day to see all in a short visit and stop by the open air flower and bird market as well. This will take in four of the sites included in the museum pass and only take 2-3 hours. So if you buy a museum pass, I would include the chapel. If you don't buy a museum pass, I would probably skip this one for better sites to visit. There are quite a few stairs to climb to get to the upper chapel. Lines to get in can get very long because of security.

a magnificence of light and color. Most of the windows of Sainte-Chapelle had been recently cleaned--you could see the few that hadn't yet--and the effect of light and color pouring through those windows is truly magnificent. If you can, go on the first Sunday of the month when the crown of thorns is on display.

An absolute gem!. Tucked away in the Palace of Justice, Sainte-Chapelle is an incredible building. The history of the building is rich, and the stained glass windows are unbeatable! The sun shining through the beautiful blue and red glass in unmissable. It is best to go in the mornings (around 9:30am - 10am) or afternoons when there aren't as many people because it is a very beautiful and peaceful place. At the moment there is a lot of restoration, so a lot of the chapel cannot be seen. Be prepared to miss a lot of the upstairs chapel if visiting in the near future.

The most beautiful place in the most beautiful city. Celebrating its 800th anniversary this year (2014), and the 40-year restoration of the glorious stained glass windows in the upper chapel will be completed in time for the festivities at the end of the year. In the meantime, even though the north side is boarded up for the final touches of its restoration, you absolutely MUST see this gem when in Paris. In fact, if you do only one thing, do this!The engineering and the artistry of this chapel cannot be overstated. The windows, impossibly tall, seem barely to be supported by the thin stone supports between them. In fact, you can almost imagine the entire chapel floating in air, as if it is a real-life slice of heaven. Get a copy of the materials explaining the meaning of each of the sixteen panels, and linger as you study each one. In fact, have a seat on the floor, gaze up, and in 15 minutes you'll be in a state of contemplative bliss. Truly the most awe-inspiring man-made structure I've ever been in, and also the most spiritual Warning: the lines to get in can take hours and hours, especially in summer. Three tips to avoid the lines: 1) see it off-season, e.g. in January. On a sunny day it's every bit as spectacular in winter as it is in spring and summer 2) go on a rainy day. Rain seems to keep the crowds down, though not completely away, of course 3) best bet: wake up early and queue up an hour ahead of opening (that would mean arriving at 8:00 November-February and at 8:30 March -October. Bring a croissant and a coffee, and enjoy the early morning vibe on Ile de la Cite!! It's worth the effort!!

Be ready to be awed. This is one of the sights not to be missed when visiting Paris. Built by Louis IX - Saint Louis - the chapel is located next to the Palais de Justice and contains two levels, the lower one was for the worker and servants to worship and the upper one reserved for the king and his acolytes. The many sixteen stained glass windows that run from floor to ceiling create a lighting show that is simply marvelous! It is definitely a sight to savor!

Glorious stained glass. This lovely little church, hidden amongst the justice buildings, is a true gem. the stained glass is magnificent. Note that 7 of the windows are currently being restored and are covered by tarps and scaffolding.

Glorious Towering Stained Glass Windows. Sainte-Chapelle is intimate royal chapel built in France by Louis IX and features a truly exceptional collection of stained-glass windows situated at the heart of the royal residence, the Palais de la Cité. It was built to house the 'relics of the Passion of Christ'. The upper level which was designed for the King & royalty is adorned with a glorious collection of glass panels and a large rose window forming a veritable wall of light. The lower level which served the gentry class offers no windows but is bursting with amazing color! Intense blues & reds accented with gold accents throughout. Sainte-Chapelle is an excellent example of French Gothic architecture. A Must See!

on a sunlit afternoon. I ran over to Ste. Chapelle when the sun broke through the clouds in the afternoon...we are staying on ile st louis, so that was easy. I have been there probably twice before...but today was magical. The place glowed like the inside of a gemstone...so fantastic and airy and beautiful it was indescribable.PS the wait to get in was about 45 minutes even late in the day!

WOW! Don't miss this!. We have traveled all over the world and this chapel is at the top of the list. The stained glass is the best we've seen....simply breathtaking. The information card and video about stained glass is very informative. There is a lot of restoration work in process and access is a little challenging....but take time while you are in Paris to see this. You will never forget it!
What a gem. This kind of hidden gem of Paris is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen, an it left bigger impression on me than Notre dame or Sacre Coeur.. Go there..you wan't regret!

THE church to visit in Europe. This incredible chapel - made for Kings and Queens alone is a must see in Paris. You enter through the basement, climbing up a stone spiral staircase that is big enough only for single file.......with the steps worn down by the many centuries of footfalls upon them. Then you enter into a glorious, amazing opening of stained glass walls. There are virtually no walls, only thin ribs holding up the glass that goes up several stories above you. The sheer fact that this place survived not just 1 but 2 World Wars is amazing and a testament to the French people who lovingly sandbagged the glass to protect it from the bombings. If you are fortunate, the sun will come shining through the glass - but it truly does not matter if it does not. The place is so awe inspiring even on a cloudy day! And do remember it is still a church. When people become too loud, they have people there to remind you of that fact and provide the proper "shhhhhhhh" to be quiet. Truly, do not miss this place. Worth seeking it out as it is not obvious unless you look for it. Enjoy!
Best Little Chuch in Paris. Well worth the wait, Sainte-Chapelle had the finest stained glass windows we have ever seen (which includes St. Peters).

Unbelievable. The stained glass windows are wonderful and are so impressive. There was considerable maintenance work going on a one area of the window and it looked like an ongoing situation but an information film showed the actual work in hand, fascinating.

Delicate Gothic. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see, because in this work of architecture the dream to create massive stained glass windows, that create an otherworldly experience, was realized. There could be a ques-line, so be prepared to wait.

Favorite church. I loved the bright colors used inside. It looked like tapestry. I was amazed at the tiles in the upper chapel that were of course wearing off. The stained glass tells stories of the bible in order. Very interesting to figure out what story the glass was telling. We purchased the extra ticket to go to Marie Antoinette's jail cell. It is outside across the street in another building so don't search for it like we did.

Breath-taking!. What a beautiful place! The stained glass was gorgeous! We actually went to a Vivaldi Concert one night we were in Paris. A MUST DO if you love classical music! A night I'll never forget!
Hidden Gem. Small chapel with amazing windows. When you first walk in you dont realize that you have to climb a windy staircase to actually get to the chapel. Once inside it is breathtaknig!

Go Early. There is often a long line here. Go early or late it is worth it. You do have to go through security, This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen in this part of Europe. the windows are worth the await.

Remarkably intact. Given the age of this chapel, it is remarkably intact and the stained glass is brilliant. Try to visit on a sunny day to get the full effect. Price was a little steep, but it's worth seeing.
Small but very dramatic. the colour and stained glass are absolutely stunning it is an absolute must see, the only drawback is space when it is busy try to go early.

Breathtaking.. If only the sun had been out when we were here... and if half of it hadn't been under construction... but still so incredibly beautiful and ornate, this is an absolute must! You walk in on the base floor, which is stunning, but not the piece de resistance. Walk up the tight spiral staircase and behold Saint Chappelle! Look up, look down, look all around - it is so beautiful!There's also a terrific souvenir shop on the bottom floor of the church. If you're going to Notre Dame, please go by here too.We had the Paris Museum Pass. Once you get through security, don't stand in the long line - it divides in two as you round to the front of the church. Trust me and just walk right up.

Amazing, maybe my favorite chatedral. incredibly beautiful and harmonious church, this is an absolute must!This is my favorite place in Paris! I even had the chance to hear a classical music concert inside!

Gorgeous!. This is a very small church just around the corner from Notre Dame. If you have read the Devincy Code is was mentioned in the book. The building is so old and well preserved and you can relate to the symbolism from the book. WE went as soon as it opened and access was a breeze. Easily seen in 30 - 45 minutes

"A Must see in Paris". I wonder if since this is a block from Notre Dame that people miss it. But its well worth to see it. Its included in the Paris Museum Pass but I think its 8 or 10 Euros to go in. The stained glass is really magnificent and they are renovating now and cleaning it which seems to be a time consuming and exhaustive undertaking.I have been here before but its still awe inspiring to view again.And they do have a small gift shop with some nice things that you won't find in other gift shops.I felt that by spending some money I was helping the cost of the renovations and restorations.

Amazing glass, a work of art, a must see.. We entered the chapel and thought, wow this is amazing but it's not until you go upstairs that the real magnificence/brilliance of this place is seen. The massive stained glass windows are amazing, you have to go.

It Takes Your Breath Away. Combine a visit to this chapel with the Conciergerie next door. Competed in 1248 it offers a view of stained glass at its finest. It's small with a lot of people but you're still able to see its splendor. The lower portion with a low ceiling was for commoners to worship. Upstairs was for royalty. There are printed guides in various languages that tell you what the windows depict and you can make out a few figures but you really want to take in the overall view. There is construction and renovation inside and outside but it's still enjoyable. Don't miss it.
Breath away. Incredible Saint Chapelle, hidden behind the Palais de Justice.A renewal of the architecture that let the light to enter this church.It's worth the line and the price, definitely.

Beautiful. The stain glass windows inside are exquisite and I feel that this is a must see attraction in Paris. There was no queue, however there was renovation work taking place which somewhat ruined the ambiance. Remember if you are 18-25 and an EU resident you can get inside free of charge so bring along your passport or driving licence!

a must see. The best stained glass in the world, a must see. This is the peak of stained glass making. Truly unbelievably beautiful. Although Sainte Chapelle is a big tourist attraction it is worth the visit, go in the early morning or late in the afternoon when the sun is setting to see the light thru the colors of glass. And keep in mind all was made with out electricity powered machines.

Small but wonderful stained glass. A major restoration project is ongoing so exterior and interior views are marred. The lower level of this small church is wonderfully decorated but up the narrow spiral staircase the stained glass is breathtaking. Sainte-Chapelle is very close to Notre Dame so it makes sense to see both together if you don't worry you'll be Gothiced out.
Another Hidden Gem. Even though this is small in comparison to the Notre Dame, it makes up for in beauty, the stained glass windows are stunning.

Breath taking but very small. When you come here please expect it to be short. It isn't a huge basilica like other religious places. The stained glass is simply spectacular and pictures can't do it justice. We went first thing in the morning because even if you have a Paris Museum pass you can't bypass the line due to security. And there is security... Had I waited in line for a length of time, I think I would've been miffed because it was such a short stop on our journey. Go and enjoy the beauty but go FIRST thing in the morning.

Stunning. As others have said, go when there is plenty of daylight. We entered from below, up a tight and dark spiral staircase and I have to say... that when I entered the Chapel, emerging into the lights of the sun streaming through the stained glass, I literally took a step back in awe and almost lost my balance at the top of the stairs... yes, the first view almost "knocked me off my feet." Sadly they were doing maintenance during our trip and about 1/3 of the windows were blocked, but even so this is a dramatic and awe-inspiring place that will not disappoint. So glad we made the time to visit, and you should too!

Unfortunately restoration work in progress... The place is interesting, ok, but restoration does not help to feel its charme. Not enough seating places to rest and admire the very complex window mosaics.
A hidden jewel in the heart of Paris. Go when there is plenty of daylight. The stained glasses that surround the chapel, with almost no walls, is a marvel worth visiting!

Go in winter. For what it's worth, I was practically the only person there when I went to the Sainte-Chapelle last January. The great, high walls of stained glass shone like paradise in near-silence. No queue to get in either.

Sainte-Chapelle One of 10 wonders in the world. I have been to Sainte-Chapelle in Paris many times and it remains one of the most awe inspiring Cathedrals in the world. Of all the places I have seen and been to, it ranks in the top ten. The sheer majesty and impact of the massive stain glass walls - they are basically not windows as all the walls are really a stain glass structure - must be seen to be believed. Usually there are queues but the time is worth it. Best to be seen on a sunny day when it really is at its best.

Beautiful but small. The stained glass windows were amazing and beautiful but where's the rest of the church? My wife and I had the museum pass so we got in free and the stained glass was cool to see. If we had paid full price we would have been disappointed. If you don't have a museum pass stick with Notre Dame or Sacre Cœre. If you have the museum pass it's worth a quick stop.
Fantastic small Gothic church. Unbelievable stained glass and flying buttresses in bright colors adorn this cathedral. Worth a visit

Beautiful décor.. We added visiting into our schedule as our entry fees were covered with our Paris Passes. It's a beautiful building with its stained glass windows (especially when the sun shines in through them) and tiled floors. It's a quick visit (we were there for about 20 minutes). Photos are also allowed inside.

Breathtaking windows. This was worth the money just to see the upstairs windows! We combined this with a visit to the conciergerie, during the only rain we saw on our February trip. Both worth a visit

Stunning. In order to get in to the Sainte Chapelle you have to go through a security check. The Chapel is actually situated on the grounds of the Tribunal de Grande Instance and the Cour de Cassation. It was the only time we had to stand in line during our 5 day stay in Paris. But it was definitely worth it. The Chapel is absolutely stunning. Make sure to visit the two levels. The windows are just unbelievable. And the history of the construction of the Chapel is fascinating. Interesting to see normal french judicial life going on as tourists enter and exit the grounds...

Definitely worth a visit. The stained glass here is magnificent, worth the trouble of finding the place--it's not visible from the street, you have to go through the gates of the entrance to the police prefecturate, so it's kind of confusing. There are chamber concerts here at night sometimes, and even without the benefit of the stained glass at night it's a moving setting in which to hear music.
greattt. Excelentttt!!! go with someojne that u like i will recomend anyone that want to have a nice tome in family or with a couple to go!!

Beautiful, but badly organized admission. A must-see, but at this moment (early 2014) the scaffolds inside for repair works are seriously impacting the experience. Also, to get in, you need to pass through a security checkpoint and have your backpack x-rayed (airport-style), because the Chapelle is inside the court of justice, which is a high-security complex. This leads to long lines even on a low-season weekday, and that somewhat spoils the experience.

Breathtaking stained glass. The beautiful windows are worth the wait in two different lines. You really don't need to spend very much time in the chapel to see it all and appreciate it. We were in and out in under 30 minutes, so you don't need to budget a lot of time for it. There were two lines we had to wait in before going in, one at security and another to buy our tickets. Both went fairly quickly, however this was a morning in early March, not at the height of tourist season. There was good information contained in a pamphlet, printed in numerous languages, to help you understand what you are looking at.

Beautiful stained glass. Travelling throughout England and France I came to appreciate the beauty and splendour of the many cathedrals, abbeys, basilicas, and churches. The stained glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle were unique and breathtaking. Definitely worth going to. Had to wait in line for a bit, and there was restoration being done on one end of the chapel, but it was still amazing. Very close to Notre Dame.

An eye for excellence. The reviews I have been reading disgust me. these people have no sense of beauty or history. I wonder why they bother to travel. I havevisited the St Chapelle three times and am about to take my granddaughter for a visit in April. This venue is one of a kind and its beauty excells any other thing in Paris. Forget the long lines, the rude tourists, and settle back for a marvelous experience.
Two fantastic churches for the Price of One. Its simply a fantastic genuine attraction, real history, no gimmicks. Genuinely impressive decor and windows.Lovely
Stunning stained Glass windows. You dont need long here - but the sight of all of the magnificent huge stained glass windows should not be missed.
Worth a look. Just beautiful, you have no idea what to expect until you walk inside. we had a Paris pass so this fast tracks you into most places rather than lining up for ages.

Unparalleled stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle is a hidden gem and has the most beautiful stained glass windows and from floor to ceiling. This museum is easily visited in an hour and can also be coupled with La Conciegerie next door. Just ask for a combo ticket!

Amazing Place. Yes there is Notre Dame which is amazing, but not to far from there is an wonderful cathedral Sainte-Chapelle. This is one of the most beautiful cathedrals I have seen. The stained glass windows here are amazing. I had seen pictures and read about this cathedral before I went to Paris and made a point to go, and was not at all disappointed. I would recommend going early in the morning or late afternoon when the sun moves through the windows.
St Chapelle. Beautiful windows! Some of the interior is being restored, but that did not take away from the beauty of this place.

Good under renovation. Another stunning chapel a short distance from Notre Dame. Not to be missed but currently is having some of the windows restored which meant the left hand side of the chapel was boarded over. I believe the restoration will be done by the summer.
stained glass art work. saint-chapelle offers wonderful examples of the ability of stained glass artists. not so big an area but time well spent in appreciation of those artictic masters.
Stunning!. The last surviving edifice from the original Royal Palace, now hidden away within the grounds of the Palais de Justice. Seek it out - you won't be disappointed.
By far my favorite. This was by far my favorite attraction in Paris. The stained glass is breathtaking. Go on a sunny/ clear day and it will be even better.
Mezmerizing!. Words fail to describe the beauty of the Sainte-Chapelle in Paris. Magnificent stained-glass windows all around. Meters high. We were mesmerized. Photos are only but a poor reflection.

A Gem. What beautiful windows it is like stepping into a Gem Box, we were lucky did not have to queue, security was quick and got the tickets straight away €8.50. Part of the Chapelle is under restoration and is slightly dusty but it didn't spoil the overall visit. It's a must before or after Notre Dame when in the area.

Magnificent chapel. Beautiful chapel built by Saint Louis, the highlight is obviously the stained glass windows on the first floor of the chapel. During our visit, part of it was undergoing restoration and therefore covered up, but the remaining glass windows still an amazing sight. It isn't a big building at all, quite small frankly, but we spent more than an hour inside admiring the windows in awe. Should pay a visit , definitely well worth your time and money.

What a wonderful French treasure!. We were so glad to find the time to visit this church. The downstairs chapel is dark but the history and stained glass is wonderful. I don't like the souvenir stands against the wall however and that's why it only gets 4 stars - no church, working or not, should be used to hawk their wares. Do go upstairs and behold the beauty of the stained glass and alter.

The Windows Wow!!. Small, compact, and somewhat crowded. Part of the chapel is under renovation so it is a partial view. Once again the Museum Pass saved us a wait in line, but everyone must clear security.

A beautiful Chapel. The glow of light coming through from so high and on all available sides (part of one side is covered as It is renovated) is stunning. Such a treasure! Big impact visually with out being a huge space.

One of our most loved places in Paris. Sainte Chapelle, situated on Ile de la Cite is a stunning example of Medieval Gothic architecture. The lower chapel was built for the people, but the upper and more ornate and magnificent chapel, was built for royalty only. It houses exquisite 13th century glass windows. It is small, but the detail in the gothic architecture, the painted walls and the stained glass windows is mind blowing. You need to queue and go through a security check to get in but it is worth it. Go back at night to listen to a classical music concert – experience how the royal chapel feels at night and soak up the sounds of baroque music. Goose bump stuff. Book online for concert

A stained glass jewel-box. Without question, one of the most wonderful religious treasures of our universe. It was built by Louis Xlll to accommodate his Holy Relics, many of which are likely to prove valueless. More than 30 in number, including fragments of wood said to be parts of the True Cross and the Holy Lance, the most revered is the Crown of Thorns thought by some to have been worn by Jesus at his crucifixion. The Children of the Revolution didn’t have much respect for the relics or the chapel. Parts of the latter were destroyed, and the former were dispersed, although, some have regained safe keeping in the nearby Cathedral of Notre Dame. It really comprises two Chapels: Upper and Lower. The latter is dedicated to the Virgin, of whom it contains a very attractive statue. Its low vaults are supported by 12 pillars each containing a medallion of one of the 12 apostles. The ceiling is star-spangled to represent Heaven, while the floor contains tombstones beneath which rest the remains of ecclesiastic personages associated with the Chapel. The Upper Chapel is a marvel of light sharply-pointed arches forming a dramatically inspiring tracery reminiscent of King’s College Chapel, Cambridge, but these are complemented by some of the most superb stained glass windows of any church I have seen, and the wall-space filled by glass vastly surpasses that of wood or masonry, so that the entire interior is filled with a joyfully spiritual multi-coloured light that is nothing short of breathtaking. There is also a dramatic and contrasting Rose Window facing West. The 12 Apostles feature here, too, but in the form of beautifully carved statues. The whole gives the impression of an enormous jewel-box, fitting for the so-called religious treasures over which it stood guardian until their dispersal.

My absolute favorite church in Europe. I love this little gem. It is wonderful. We love to visit churches for the art and architecture, and out of more than 75 we have seen in Europe, this is my favorite. I love the stain glass windows upstairs. I love that they preserved them so diligently. A must if you love art.
Beautiful. small but amazing! The windows are just beautiful. Interesting to see the restoration process as well
Breathtaking. Even if you do not enjoy visiting churches, Sainte-Chapelle is worth the trip. It's ornately painted and its stained glass is remarkable.
Not to be missed. A beautiful, quiet atmosphere. The colour of the light coming through all of the stained glass is is very peaceful. Well worth a visit.

The most beautiful church in Paris.. The most beautiful church in Paris. The stained glass windows are the most glorious of all of the churches that I have seen in the whole of Europe. It is not a large structure compared to other churches but do not let that deter from going to this church.
Give yourself at least one hour to fully enjoy this church.

Amazing Chapel. Just down the road from Notre Dame and in my opinion the more asthetic by far. Visited on rather a grey day in Paris, a sunnier day would have made the amazing stained glass even more vivid. A must if your in the city.

Stunning!. La Sainte-Chapelle (The Holy Chapel) is a royal medieval Gothic chapel, located near the Palais de la Cité, on the Île de la Cité in the heart of Paris, France.Constructed around 1246 the Sainte-Chapelle is considered among the highest achievements of the Gothic architecture. Its erection was commissioned by King Louis IX of France to house his collection of Passion Relics, including Christ's Crown of Thorns - one of the most important relics in medieval Christendom. Although damaged during the French revolution, and restored in the 19th century, it retains one of the most extensive in-situ collections of 13th-century stained glass anywhere in the world. Sainte-Chapelle stands squarely upon a lower chapel which served as parish church for all the inhabitants of the palace. This chapel, which is rather plain, is dedicated to the Virgin Mary. The most visually beautiful aspects of the chapel, and considered the best of their type in the world, are stained glass windows of the upper chapel, surrounded by delicate painted stonework. Fifteen huge mid-13th-century windows are in deep reds and blues and illustrate 1,130 figures from the Bible. The large rose windows with Flamboyant tracery added to the upper chapel in 1490.We waited in long line to get inside and after were another line to buy tickets. But it was absolutely worth waiting. Highly recommend.
Beautiful!. I stayed for a very long time contemplating the architecture, I was very fortunate that there were very few visitors and I could take my time looking around.
A hidden treasure. The most beautiful church I have ever visited, truly beautiful. A real moving experience I recommend to all.
Not much to see but worth the trip. It very small but the craftsman ship in the chapel is breathtaking! It is different from the usual sights in Paris and really worth a look.

A Must See - Very Family Friendly - Free with Museum Pass. My wife and I visited Paris in February of 2014 along with our 4-month old baby boy. Trying to navigate a new city and language can be difficult but become a bit more difficult with a child. We stopped here because it was free with the museum pass and we were not knowing what to expect. However, it quickly became one of my favorite sites in Paris.First, it was extremely easy to navigate where to go to skip the ticket queue and we got right into the lower level. Right away, a guide saw our stroller and directed us to the stroller storage area (roped in, secure and under supervision from theft) and had us put our stroller in.Second, when you exit the stairs into the upper level you will immediately be stunned by the quality of the stained glass. It is unlike anything I have ever seen. I am not an "art" fan and am rarely stunned by art but the amazing mix of art, architecture and engineering that went into the creation of this stained glass is simply stunning.You could stay for an hour or be in an out in fifteen minutes. Either way, Sainte-Chappelle is a must see in Paris and I will surely be stopping back in in the future.

The beauty inside takes your breath away.. We went for a concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. The chapel is unbelievably gorgeous. You are surrounded by very tall stain glass windows. The acoustics are amazing. One of our best travel experiences ever. Don't sit too far forward - you want to be able to see the stain glass windows as well as hear the music.

Spectacular. Not to be missed!. A small, intimate chapel with the most astounding stained glass... Go on a sunny day and enjoy the light show from the sun streaming in the windows though the multi-colored glass.
Magnificent!. Unique and beautiful! Absolutely worth a visit!!! A perfect addition after visiting Notre Dame! Definitely worth a visit!

Excellent, you will be amazed.. You must visit Sainte Chapelle, it is amazing with the most beautiful stained glass windows. We found it easy to understand the information describing the history and found it helpful as it is in many languages.
Beautiful!. Just awestruck by it's sheer beauty. It is quite easy to get to past the love bridge and surrounded by some great restaurants. Wish it was opened later however.

Beautiful church, beautiful music, unforgetable experience. We booked the " Four seasons" concert here and it was great to listen to the works of Vivaldi expertly played in this church. The stained glass work is superb !
A tiny unexpected gem. So close to Notre Dame and yet few tourists seem to visit this beautiful little chapel. It is well worth a visit.

Eye opener!. I could probably go on and on as to how amazing this place is. A must visit place. Too bad, the lighting was blocked by the portion under renovation. However, it did not disrupt the rest of the beauty of the place. I would strongly urge all travellers to give notre-dame a skip and visit this place instead. It might be small, but the hidden message behind all those stained glass is mind-blowing.

Beautiful!. Sadly, there was construction every where as they work on refurbishing this historic church. We were able to enjoy the beauty of this historic church through the stain glass window displays on the upper floor....a must see!
Must see the windows!. Must see the beautiful windows! Visited in Dec. 2013- even though chapel is under renovation it did not inhibit the experience! Truly amazing!
Stunning. Really beautiful chapel, worth visiting but unlike other beautiful attractions such as sacre couer and notre dame there's a fee to enter and it's much smaller.
Most amazing church. This is probably the most beautiful church in the world. The stained glass windows are amazing. A must-see every time I'm in Paris (and I'm not even that into churches!)

amazing. Amazing stained glass. Saw it for the first time and was amazed.at the beauty of this church that is located within the walls of the Palace of Justice. Go, especially if it is clear weather to see its beauty

Should be a huge fan of history or take a guide . We went there on suggestion (high scores) from Tripadvisor. If the entrance would had been free of charge, no problem. Maybe a story from a guide would have made the difference. But wondering around on your own in not worth the price you pay.

Prepare for security screening!. We were looking forward to seeing Sainte-Chapelle because of its stained glass. When we arrived at the site, it was closed for lunch. We decided to grab a sandwich nearby and return as soon as they opened. We waited in line for about 30 minutes and discovered once we entered the building that there was a security screen to enter the church. You could not take any "weapons" or alcohol into the church. My husband had a pocket knife and our friend had a sealed bottle of wine and a corkscrew. We were told that we could leave those items with the guards but would not be able to get them back. There was no mention of these restrictions in any of the materials we had read nor was there anything posted at the site. I could possibly understand about the knife (although it was no problem at any of the other places we visited) but a bottle of wine??!! We were disappointed and a little angry that we had wasted 2 hours of our precious time in Paris.

It is worth. I went there in Feb. 2014 and it was under reform. No doubts that it is a must see attraction in Paris. I think that the price could be less expensive than it was. ANW it's near Notre Dame and you won't regret to go there. You'll spend less than 1 hour to visit Saint Chapelle.

Hidden jewel. This is the oldest church in Paris. It is not so recognizable in the Paris skyline (like Notre Dame), as it is settled in the center of the Royal palace complex, with Conciergerie on Ile de Cite, the nucleus of Paris.It is unique by two chapels which stand one over the other. The lower one was used by ordinary people, while the upper one by royal family and aristocracy. On the upper chapel there are most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen worldwide. Tip: Buy a combined ticket for Saint Chapelle and for Conciergerie. It is cheaper, and you get extra 3 euros off with Paris Visitee card.

Surrounded by heaven. Well, you just have to see it to believe it! Built by Louis IX to house the Crown of Thorns it is one of most exquisite tiny places on earth! Completely surrounded by ancient, beautifully crafted gothic stained glass, it's a miracle of construction. Helpful guide charts available in the major languages. You enter on the ground floor where there is a gift shop. Be sure to take the winding stairs up into the Chapel and prepare yourself for a glorious experience!
Breathtaking. The chapel is a must to see. We have been before but the stained glass is a must to see when in Paris. We have been before and will certainly return again.
incredible. If you go to Paris, it's a must visit. The are renovating but that can be understandable. The stained glass is colorful and unforgettable.

Beautiful. The stained glass windows are so beautiful -- if only they weren't renovating. Visited in April and again in October and they were still working on it. Got to see all of it, only not at the same time! The wait was not terribly long - line seemed to move pretty fast. You have to go through security and cannot use your museum pass. Visit the Conciergerie next to it.

Spectacular stain glass chapel. Being inside this chapel...which is situated within the police complex next to where Marie Antoinnette was imprisoned--is like being inside a huge crystal flashing with the blue, greens, yellow and reds of the floor to ceiling soaring over 20 ft high. Pick a sunny afternoon for best viewing

A magnificent piece of ancient history. Saint-Chapelle was built between 1242 and 1248 and most of the beautiful stained glass is original! It is rather overshadowed by Notre Dame, and concealed by its restoration work, but I am so pleased that we made the effort to find it because it is magical!

Beautiful!. My girlfreind brought us to this chapel a few years ago while we were in Paris as a wedding present. Try to see a concert at this church. It was a memorable experience. The stain glass is awesome, even compared to Paris standards. We went to see a harpest and violinist perform and I still think about the experience to this day. I think either a daytime or evening visit would be equally as pleasant. Sainte Chapelle is very special.

Beautifully Restored. It is a little hard to find on Ile De La Cite but worth the search. A four year restoration project is nearly complete and it shows. The beautiful wood and stained glass in this old church are gorgeous and very photo-worthy.

Restoration in Progress. Major Restorations are in progress. The stained glass is being cleaned, removed and replaced. I enjoyed the Sainte Chapelle as an opportunity to view it as it might have been when it was being built. Please forgive the noise, the dust,

Stunning stained glass. If you are a fan of stained glass, you have to visit this place! There are 15 windows in the upper chapel that will take your breath away as soon as you enter it. I have been to many, many churches across Europe and found this so unique and ornate! Beautiful!
A real gem close to Notre Dame Cathedral.. This is a small, royal chapel in Gothic style. It's medieval stained glass windows and gold trimmed woodwork are gorgeous.
Renovations. We were waiting for two hours to get in. And it cost a lot. It is beautiful, but small and you couldnt see half of it because of the renovation.

Best place we visited in Paris!. The artistry of the stained glass in Sainte Chapelle is absolutely amazing, just about the most beautiful creation outside of nature we've ever seen. The architecture of the chapel is, in itself, stunning. To think that all this was created almost 800 years ago is staggering. A treasure for the entire world.Sunny days are, of course, the best for a visit.
I literally gasped as I walked in. This is a lesser known cathedral and I didn't know much about it before visiting but I am so glad I didn't miss it. It was astounding!

Renovations hinder enjoyment. The stained glass chapel is beautiful but appreciation of this is hindered by the renovation that is in progress. Thus, it is expensive for what you get at the present time.

Average church. Beautiful church with some stunning stained glass but what is so special about it? Many churches have stunning stained glass and you even gotta wait in a loooong line in order to get in and for so much money!!! Not worth it really. It is quite average. I wouldn't waste my time again.

My Favorite Chapel. The stained glass in here is absolutely stunning. My friends and I got in free because of a holiday, but usually there is a fee to enter. It's worth every penny! There is also a cute souvenir stand on the main floor where you can buy some of your own stained glass, which you will want. This chapel is an absolute must-see, and is very close to Notre Dame. (and better, in my opinion)

Often Overlooked. Try to come on a sunnier day if possible and do not forget to go "upstairs" to the upper level as some hurried and jet lagged tourists seem to do. A jewel that must be seen from the inside.

Stunning stained glass. This chapel has the most incredible stunning stained glass that fills the upper room with multicolored light. The building is nothing in size compared to the Notre Dame but is spectacular in its finish. It was created to hold holy relics (since moved to Notre Dame) and was used by French royalty and the powerful for hundreds of years.
The windows!. The stained glass windows are amazing but if it's a dark day you will miss their magnificence. Come back when the sun is out.

Another NOT TO BE MISSED Architectural Experience. Beauty, history, one-of-a-kind atmosphere, reverence!TRULY one of if not THE MOST AMAZING and BEAUTIFUL stained glass experiences in the world! A hidden site and a true hidden gem that you have to know how to find - literally just blocks away from Notre Dame - BUT in another world of it's own as far as architectural / religious art and stained glass.

Absolutely lovely!. We enjoyed a quick visit to Sainte-Chapelle. The interiors were beautiful and it was definitely worth a visit. We purchased Museum Passes and this was included on the pass. It is not a far walk from Notre Dame.
Very Different Church. Impressive and not standard european church. The art is a little different and that it makes it worth seeing.
a must-see. i have missed seeing the stained glass each time i visit because of the lines, but in November it was no problem in the early afternoon. Even on a gray day it was beautiful.
Jewels. The Chapel is just beautiful. I felt as if I was in a jewlery box. The colors stand out now. It was restored about 5-6 years ago, and it shows.

Stained glass, anyone?. This Gothic marvel was overwhelming to me. Even though the clouds obscured the sun, the inside of this magnificent abbey glowed like there wasn't a cloud in the sky. The windows are a feast for the eyes...only 5 colors were used in them...yet they look like hundreds were used. Just down the street from Notre Dame, don't miss this one...!

Breath taking...... Having missed this the first time we visited Paris, I was determined to see it this time. The 'commoners' chapel was beautiful but when you go up the stair to the 'royals' chapel - it takes your breath away - especially when the sun is coming through as it was for us.The complaining reviews amaze me - I researched about it before visiting and knew the cost, the fact that there restorations going on, the possible queues (where don't you have to queue in Europe!!). People need to do their research before they go if they are going to be so picky.

Absolutely magical (even with the jack-hammering going on).. Nestled among the buildings of the Palais de Justice, Sainte-Chapelle is worth searching out and in many ways holds its own against the larger cathedral on the island. Built between 1242 and 1248, the chapel was originally meant to house the relics of the Passion of Christ that Louis IX purchased in the years before its founding. Adding to the prestige of both France and Paris, the relics also obviously added to the significance of the structure that housed them; after two visits here in four days it is easy to see why. There are two parts to the visit: the lower chapel and an upper chapel. The former also functions essentially as the entrance with audio guides available for purchase and the usual assorted souvenirs. It is worth a few minutes to look around as a statue of the Virgin Mary greets visitors at the portal and the ceiling has impressive openwork struts linking the aisle columns to the lateral walls. A winding staircase on the left leads to the upper chapel which is “a truly monumental and sumptuously decorated reliquary” as the free printed guide says and for once I must say this isn’t hyperbole. Fifteen stained glass windows up to 50 feet high depict no less than 1,113 scenes telling the story of mankind from Genesis through to the Resurrection. The great shrine at the apex of the chapel is the area where the relics used to be displayed and there are statues of the 12 apostles between the windows that add to the general atmosphere. An impressive western rose window rounds out the major highlights of the interior. A video in French describes the ongoing restoration work and plastic descriptive boards are available for free at the rear. Overall this was a worthwhile visit even with the restoration work, without which this easily would have been a 5/5 attraction. I was the first person through the door on my second visit and had about 30 seconds of precious solitude in the upper chapel…. until the jack hammers started at the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd windows. An obvious necessity, the restoration work does detract a bit from the whole experience but you can also use that as a learning tool to study the techniques of period refurbishment, right? The audio guide wasn’t really valuable as it often made reference to windows that were too high to see from a ground vantage point, and much of the information was found on the free material available at the entrance.
