By no means should any of these quibbles discourage a visit. The sheer beauty of the interior of the upper chapel make up for any (well, at least “most”) drawbacks of the restoration. Anyone coming to see Notre Dame should stop here right afterwards. Thumbs up.
Stunning Stained Glass Windows. My friend insisted we go there and I was not disappointed. Small place when compared to Notre Dame, but definitely worth stopping in to see all the stained glass work.

A JEWEL THAT WILL STUN YOU. This little chapel is not a treasure of Paris -- it is a world treasure. Next to Chartres Cathedral, it is the most stunning exhibit of stained glass to be found anywhere. Try to visit on a sunny afternoon when the windows are like jewels. Many like to bring binoculars. Getting in is a bit of a hassle because of security checks (as in airports) but the experience is well worth the small inconvenience. (You'll need your passport for entry.)

Gloriously beautiful. The French government is in the process of restoring the magnificent stained glass windows on the upper level of la Sainte-Chapelle but that will not interfere with your enjoyment of the visit. They have finished approximately 80% of the windows as of January 2014, by my estimate. Where the windows are still being restored, there is a panel illustrating what they will look like when they are done. This is one of my favorite places in Paris and we visit each time we are there. Words can't really describe the beauty of the stained glass windows. If you are a fan of Gothic architecture, this place will capture your heart and soul.

Amazing view but ticket too expensive. I was with a group of friends and some felt the ticket was too expensive to see what we could see. One entire wall and a half was covered for restoration. Also, the staff is extremely rude. We don't speak French (their English was just as bad), the instructions were not very clear and we were not treated nicely when we didn't know what to do. Don't get me wrong, the view of the stain glass of the chapel is amazing. Also on the plus side, no guide is needed to understand the works inside the chapel as there descriptions in all languages. My recommendation would be to read what we you are going to see beforehand so that you don't get this bitter feeling of "I paid too much to see this"

a story in glass. A small but beautiful chapel hidden away next to the palais de justice. Both floors have a story to tell, with the upper floor boasting over 1700 pieces of stained glass. Well worth a visit.

Intricate Stained Glass Captivates. Sainte-Chapelle is easily overlooked in Paris. If visiting churches in Europe is your thing, don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. The stained glass has truly kept up over time. Don't forget to go down below and see what it was like for the commoners.

most beautiful place in Paris. After (or before) checking out Notre Dame, definitely do yourself a favor and go over to the Sainte Chapelle. This is for me the most beautiful monument in Paris, a masterpiece of the middle ages, a monument to the beauty of stained glass. The moment you step inside is incredible, a burst of blue light. Take the time to check out the stories depicted on the panels. A different experience depending on the time of day you visit. Absolutely do not miss

After 3 previous trips to Paris I finally got there.. On my last visit to Paris I finally got to see Sainte-Chapelle, they were doing a lot of restoration work but I was just thrilled to be there, the windows are the main reason you go and I was not disappointed even with all the scaffolding, though only on one side. If I get to Paris again I will go back. I think the Stained Glass Windows are the best I have seen and I have seen a lot.

Okay. Waited in a very long line to get in. They weren't allowing museum pass holders to bypass the line like other museums do. When we finally were able to get in it was a bit underwhelming for the wait. The stained glass is awesome. I just don't feel it's worth the wait.

Wonderful place. Go there when there is any presentation.. Besides being a wonderful architectonic place with all the vitrals you should go there when they are performing something to enjoy the internal sound.
Breathtaking. This is one of the most beautiful places in the world. The stained glass windows are breathtaking! You have to visit here while in Paris.

Surprise on top of a masterpiece visit. We've always like Saint-Chapelle - but this time we were fortunate to learn there would be a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons by String Quartet and Harpsichord. Of course we booked the tickets immediately after our tour of the church and returned that evening. Hard to imagine a more elegant experience

So beautiful!. This Chapelle was closed for a while. Now it's open, and I had the chance to visit it.It's so beautiful!!!! You feel in heaven inside. It's a must to visit "The Chapelle" when you go to Paris.

Surrounded by Color!. This is no longer a working church, but a part of the Justice Ministry, and it is kept open for the public....to rave about. After entering the area, just across from the Left Bank on the Ile de la Cite, you see a beautiful stone entrance to this grand place. Once you are inside you are faced by almost wall-to-wall stained glass...and is it impressive. Take your cameras. There is also a gift shop where you can pick up souvenirs. One more "magnet" when visiting Paris!
incredible. if you can have a tour, do it. This is a beautiful gothic church near the conciergerie which is also worth seeing.

two things to visit every time.. There's Matisse's La Danse and there's the Sainte-Chapelle, two greats in a city of greats. La Danse is Paris' great altar - so great that it makes a church of the Musee d'art moderne. Sainte-Chapelle on the other hand changes every moment, with the light - it's always worth another, fresher look.

Breathtaking stained glass. I will never forget the first time I saw the stained glass windows of Sainte Chappelle. They ares stunning and it is mind blowing to think how old they are. You feel like you are swimming in some glorious rainbow colored underwater world when the sun shines through them. They have been undergoing a restoration for 3 years which is due for completion soon. Then all 15 windows will be resplendent again. Even the little chapel below is delightful and the queues are not too long.

Best Stained Glass Windows in Paris. If you want to see fantastic stained glass, the windows in this hidden church are as good as it gets. Currently work is being done on the north side but the south facing windows get full sun and are beautiful. There will be lines to access the church so get there by 9:30 am. Paris Museum Pass saves money and time.
Wow! What a find!. Didnt even know about this place and wondered in almost by mistake, but it was incredible. Never seen windows like it and it should not be missed.

One of the highlights in Paris. On a whim we decided to visit (aided by the Museumpass which allows you to cut the line). The ground floor was remarkable, but the second floor was stunning. We went to a lot of churches and this one was a close second to Chartes and more beautiful than Notre Dame. Definitely worth the visit

Go early. Your visit to Sainte-Chapelle should not take more than an hour. GO EARLY, VERY EARLY. We were in and out by 10:00 and went across street for some coffee. Maybe a 5 minute wait to clear security. By the time we finished our coffee, guessing the queue to get in was over an hour and it only gets worse.

Breathtaking stained glass windows. The Chapelle itself is small(er), the top flor being the one you do not want to miss out on. The stained glass windows are trully one of the most beautiful I've ever seen. However I was dissapointed on the cleaningness of the chapelle. It could use some serious dusting, especially as far as statues and the not so much observed windows are concerned.
Amazing. This for me was one of the best things to see in Paris.The large windows have so much detail and once lit up look amazing.A must do!

Sainte Chapelle is an architectural masterpiece. Saint Chapelle is a 13th century building of gothic and medieval design that is an absolute masterpiece of its day and age. It is often referred to as one of the most beautiful standing buildings from this time period. Saint Chapelle is located on the Western side of Ile de la Cite, just a few minutes walk from Notre Dame Cathedral is very much worth visiting. Entrance is €4.5 per adult and the attraction is included as part of the Paris Museum Pass. Saint Chapelle is actually a small attraction with only two main chapel halls to visit. The downstairs chapel, known as the Lower Chapel, was created as a place for commoners and servants to worship. This room is well decorated with low vaulted ceilings and makes a nice place to look around before making your way to the celebrated Upper Chapel. The main reason for visiting Saint Chapelle is to see the Upper Chapel, which houses 15 large stained-glass windows, made up of over 1100 religious scenes, created on individual panes. When the sun pierces through, it creates a kaleidoscope of colour and spectacular sight bound to impress even those with the least interest in visiting historic churches. Overall, Saint Chapelle is a historically and architecturally important attraction and a remarkable place to visit in Paris. For first time visitors to the city, we would highly recommend adding this to your must-see list of places to visit. Hint: You can comfortably visit in 20-30 minutes but don't underestimate the time spent in queue to get inside, particularly during late morning to early afternoon when the sun is higher in the sky. Do consider obtaining a Paris Museum Pass, which includes entry into Saint Chapelle, in order to reduce the time you must queue to see this attraction. Hint: Make sure to bring the brochure, available in the Lower Chapel, which highlights the 15 different windows in the Upper Chapel. This will help you identify what you are looking at when upstairs. Hint: If you visit the Musee du Moyen Age, you can see some of the original panes from Saint Chapelle on display. This provides a great opportunity to view and inspect panes up close, something you can't do at the chapel itself.

Worth the stop. I read about this little chapel in a travel book, and I'm so glad we got to stop at it! The stained glass windows are enormous.. It's such a beautiful site.. like nothing I had seen before.
Exquisite!. This chapel is absolutely incredible. The stained glass is like nothing you have seen or will ever see again. Was free on first Sunday of the month :)

Breathtaking.... With so many opportunities to visit churches in Europe, it’s easy to fall into “seen a few, seen them all” mode, but this one is NOT TO BE MISSED - it’s exquisite! Three generations visited together, and no one left disappointed!

Absolutely Beautiful. This chapel has some of the most stained glass windows in all of Europe. The arches in the lower chapel are so colorful, and truly magnificent! The upper chapel is equally beautiful. A visit here is well worth the 30 min wait in line. Once in and just past security you can use your Musee Pass to move to the front of the line with the special Musee Pass line. A must see if in Paris.

Exquisite Stained Glass. We visited Sainte-Chapelle recently for the first time on a quick trip to Paris. This is a gorgeous, but small, chapel on the I'll de la Cite only a couple of blocks from Notre Dame. The stained glass here is famous and it truly is exquisite. I wish I had read a bit more about it before going as the stories told in the glass are elaborate. Definitely worth a visit....

Easter Evening concert at Sainte-Chapelle. We visited Sainte-Chapelle for a classical concert on Easter. The church itself is beautiful with amazing stained glass windows. The problem was that it was a blistery cold evening in April and the church has no heat. Everyone in the church was dressed head to toe in winter gear and still shivering. The atmosphere and music were truly exceptional but the cold made it difficult to sit and really enjoy it all. We know a lot of older buildings in Paris are without heat or air conditioning but you're usually moving about. Just sitting for an hour in the cold was tough. I would recommend that if you're going for a concert, go in late spring or early fall. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see either way.

Beautiful stain glass. The history of this church is worth the trip. The stain glass is even more amazing. If your in Paris and you feel like you did "all the major things" come check this place out. For about 12 euros you will see very a beautiful church from within
Amazing!. Loved every part of this wonderful church - the architecture, the history, the works of art and the stained glass windows.
beautiful chapel of stained glass. beautiful and breath taking and much less tourists than other parisian sights. stained glass panorama on top floor where french kings were enthroned

Beautiful, but small. Sainte Chapelle is beautiful from the inside, with its bright glasswork, and colours. However, I felt that it is a bit expensive considering its limited viewing scope. I would not recommend it as a must-watch, but definitely worth considering once you are done with the prime attractions in Paris. In fact its only about 5 minutes walk from the Notre Dame Cathedral, hence, difficult to overlookLocation: Adjacent to the Cite metro station (RATP line #4)

Stunning. Beautiful doesn't begin to describe this place. Some of the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. Some work is being done on it right now so a bit of the upper chapel (the part you really come to see) is covered with scaffolding. Still an awe inspiring place

Stunning. If you want to stand in the middle of a medieval chapel, this is the place. It was amazing, built by St Louis, with tall ceiling, very large stained glass windows, etc. The audio guide is worth getting. The interpretative history is great
under renovation. The stained glass windows are truly beautiful but it is a very short visit. there are shops downstairs.

Incredible!. This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. The Bible done in stained glass is incredible!! Search to find out if there are any concerts here while you visit. If so, take advantage!! You will not be disappointed.

A real gem. If you can only visit one church in Paris then make sure you visit Sainte-Chapelle - mostly for the stain glass windows but also for the history and the size, which means you feel so close to history itself. There are free guides that describe all the windows, which tell a story, so take the time to understand what they all represent and why the chapel was built etc. The ambiance is just exceptional. Better than any of the main tourist attractions.

Ditto LouisfromLondon Review!. Ditto the review from LouisfromLondon. Went because of Rick Steves partner recommendation. Waited for over an hour, only spent 15 minutes inside. Photos of inside make it seam larger than it is.

Well worth a visit. The stained glass is amazing. Only 35 steps to climb but They do have an elevator for anyone with reduced mobility. They were very helpful in escorting my 82 year old father to the second floor. we were there on a saturday around 11 and the Line was not too Long.

An absolute must see!. Its amazing how many people come to Paris and never visit this attraction. You will not see a collection of stained glass windows anywhere else that compares, plus the Gothic architecture is by itself most interesting. Very centrally located, not much of a detour from a number of other nearby attractions. Doesn't (yet) have the crowds of some other attractions. Don't miss it. This is a small chapel, not a huge cathedral, so the time that you need to allot is not that much.

stunning place!!!. A beautiful place visited 3 times during a 2 week family holiday, so much to see and do makes for. Wonderful day out, don't forget your camera!! Don't miss the markets on Saturdays and Wednesdays.

stained glass. the stained glass windows are beyond impressive, but since the windows are so high and the church so narrow, you really cant see whats on top. other than the windows there isnt much else. pricey admission for what you get

Simply amazing. Truly our favourite place we went to in Paris. Yes, it is small, yes, there is a line and security to go through, yes, it is €8 admission.. But it is so worth it. Upon entering the chapel, I literally gasped at the sight of these stain glass windows. Extremely vibrant colours and beautiful details. There are boards/guides in many languages which explain the scenes. With such a rich history, this chapel is just amazing. Fantastic photo opportunity. An absolute must.

My Favourite Church in Paris. When I first visited Ste Chappele it was 1990. It was only open on Sundays and not many people knew about it. Now its a bit more well known but for a simple wow factor its my favourite church in Paris. Its cheap and whilst currently being renovated (due to finish mid 2014) its still got most of the stained glass windows on display (I think at any given time three are out of action). The downstairs is dark with little to recommend unless you are in to architecture of religious buildings. But the upstairs is three quarters stained glass. With a huge rose window and almost floor to ceiling panes as well. On a sunday day its breathtaking. Its situated in the law courts near Notre Dame but for a short walk this will reward you.

Beautiful but.... I adored the Sainte Chapelle because I love stained glass and the building is like a little jewel box with incredible windows... the 'but' comes with the warning that it is fairly small and is priced as a unique example of a building - making it relatively expensive for an ecclesiastical experience in Paris, where so many of the churches are free to enter. You also have to queue for quite a long time outside, and queue again in the courtyard. I would say that non window junkies in your party might be better giving this one a miss.

Breathtaking. This is a must see. It's hidden away among other buildings, but is absolutely beautiful on the inside. Imagine being surrounded by stained glass from floor to ceiling. Words cannot describe. There is a very tight spiral staircase you must climb to reach the chapel but it is all worth it once you step inside.
Most Excellent. Simply a great building of window glass art I have ever seen. 3 of the 4 walls had these types of "glass murals" from top to bottom.

A hidden jewel in Paris. We visited Sainte Chapelle on both our trips to Paris. It is much smaller than Notre Dame, but it is exquisite. We would recommend this to anyone! It dates to the mid-1200s (I think). The stain glass is beautiful!

A Gem. This beautiful little church is tucked away where you have to look for it. Close to Notre-Dame, but not just right out there. This is where the crown of thorns is suppose to be being kept. The beauty of the place is like a jewelry box. This is another must see if you can.

small but beautiful gothic cathedral. the main attraction here is the amazing stained glass work. restoration is still under way on some panels but impressive nonetheless. for 8 euros it can feel a little steep for how quickly you can get through it all but if you like gothic cathedrals this place is worth it. they also have a great gift shop (unlike notre dame next door) where you can buy souvenirs of the cathedrals.
Waste of Time & Money. Shame on you France for making people stand in line for over an hour and taking €8.50 just to see a tiny chapel with nothing more than stained glass in it.

Beautifull glasswork. Typical old Chapel with beautiful glasswork and peaceful setting. However I do recommend that you do not plan to much time for this, as it would not keep you busy for more than around 30 minutes.

Awesome. When I first saw it there was no scaffolding, just awe inspiring architecture. Yes the stained glass windows are magnificent, but for me the vaulted crypt with its intricate gilded detailing was the most wonderful aspect - the colours are exquisite and the spiritually intense atmosphere, if you are lucky enough to go at a peaceful time of day, is incredible. Just love it and go there for a quick fix every time I visit Paris.
one of the jewels of France. This is a must for any sightseer. It is a real jewel of Franceand an added asset are the concerts performed there duringthe spring, summer, and fall.
Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Although Sainte-Chapelle is small, it is more beautiful than the Notre Dame (in my opinion). Come early, because the entrance line was long when I went.

Stunning Windows. Not much to the visit-- but just the opportunity to see all the incredible stained glass made the trip worth while, since the stained glass and the stories they tell were beyond description!

Sainte-Chapelle Paris. This is a little jewel in Paris. It is the king's chapel and is small and hidden but its stained glass is exciting, vivid and covers much of the space. The wall decorations too are very intense in colour and style. Don't miss it in Paris

Too expensive. The church is undr renovation so one can see only half of the huge vitrage windows. The light was also blocked because of the works.
8.5 euro is way too much, at least until they finish the renovation

Wow... truly medieval. If you want to stand in the middle of a medieval chapel, this is the place. It was amazing, built by St Louis, with tall ceiling, very large stained glass windows, etc.
The audio guide is worth getting. The interpretative history is great

Find peace of the world. Paris contains more history and beautiful monuments than anywhere in the world. One of the most beautiful places in Paris is Sainte Chapelle, which is on historic as well as religious side.We have hired a guide to conduct our tour as well as give information on that site. This church is amazingly designed complimenting the culture of Paris. This is the most peaceful and serene place. Moreover, our guide was excellent and has adequate knowledge about history, informative about all sorts of things, i.e, tips about to eat and more. He was the one how tells us about the Latin Quarter life. He was the fun loving person and creates the ambience of comfort and luxury for us. Highly recommend this place as well as the guide.
Story Windows. The stained glass and the stories they tell were beyond description. There is a reverence and awe emotional response when on enters the building.
Vivaldi in the Cold. The chapel was very cold, so it was the fastest performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons I've ever heard. But it was lovely.

Stunningly beautiful!. If you can visit on a sunny day, make this a priority for that day. I was lucky and stayed in Paris for about 16 days so was able to choose a sunny day to visit. Light through the stained-glass windows creates an experience unparalleled! Magnificent! That alone is worth the admission cost. Be sure to visit the lower level as well, though, if you have time. Read up on this fabulous gothic church so that when you visit, you can just soak in the beauty and the faint but imaginable medieval intentions and experiences lived by people in this place long ago that lie just beyond our grasp in the memories of time. Truly worth every moment you spend here. Will visit again!

Stunning. Not much to the visit-- but just the opportunity to see all the incredible stained glass made the trip worth while. We couldn't get to Notre Dame because the line was too long, so we headed over to Sainte-Chapelle and were in awe. The stained glass is so intricate-- def a must see.

Too often overlooked. This place is a must visit; it gets overlooked by the usual grimly determined 'we're going to march from one guidebook spot to the next till we collapse' types. This cathedral is simply stunning, and what it might lack in size compared to other european cathedrals, it makes up in quietly dazzling beauty.
Beautiful!. Wish it wasnt being renovated when we went.. but still amazing gothic architecture! Its very small so its something quick to go see.
Exquisite building. There is a charge- 8 euros for this place but well worth it as the architecture and design is outstanding

Lesser known but worth seeing. Others have reviewed this place well. The stained glass is amazing, take your time and enjoy it. The only thing I would say is this is probably not a place to go with younger kids, they will get restless quickly and there isn't much for them to do. Would like to see it after the renovations are finished.

Go early or late. Breathtaking stained glass. Go early or late in the day for the best light. Allow for a short wait to get past the security - it is located inside the walls of a government building.

Exquisite - absolutely amazing!. This was my absolute favorite! There was renovation going on but it was still stunning. I was speechless. The line was long but I skipped on thru with the Paris Museum Pass. Don't miss this amazing place. If I am ever back in Paris, I'd spend more time here, maybe with no renovations.

Worth visiting both day and night. Daytime it's all about the ceiling on the lower level and the stained glass in the main chapel above. Seating round the edge of the lower chapel has been roped off, presumably due to damage - a shame. Night time is for concerts, we saw a 6 piece ensemble playing mainly Vivaldi's four seasons. Brilliant. Pricey for just over an hour but well worth it.

Live Concert in Amazing Setting. The Sainte-Chapelle or 'Holy Chapel', in the courtyard of the royal palace on the Île de la Cité (now part of a later administrative complex known as La Conciergerie), was built to house Louis IX's collection of relics of Christ.With the Palais de la Cité, today called La Conciergerie, the Sainte-Chapelle is one of the surviving buildings of the Capetian royal palace on the Île de la Cité. Although damaged during the French revolution, and restored in the 19th century, it retains one of the most extensive in-situ collections of 13th-century stained glass anywhere in the world.We attended a live concert intitled "A Little Night Music" on Sat November 16. Walked from our hotel in the cold and waited in line briefly. Then through a bag check and then walked across a small courtyard and then into the building where the Chapel is located. We took out seats and had time to absorb all the details that the chandeliers hanging over heard illuminated. It was very cold inside and poofs of white floated on the air as all of us breathed in and out ….. At the Alter area were the chairs for the Musicians. Hearing Pachelbel's Canon played by 3 violins and 1 cello was the highlight for me but credit must be given to the Opera Singer as well.If you can, check the website for future concerts and Go!

Beautiful stained glass. We visited in Sept 2013 and there was some renovation taking place but we were still able to enjoy some of thermoset detailed and beautiful stained glass I ever saw. A very worthwhile place see. We used our Paris museum pass

The more beautifull. Stained glass with incredible colors. For king religion first. fantastic. A lot of tourist dont go inside because of the queue. The place is limited inside but so beautifula must to see

Stained Glass Awesomeness. If you're on the way to Notre Dame be sure to swing by Sainte-Chapelle. Entry is about €8.50 from memory but well worth it when you walk up some spiralling stairs and discover a striking display of stained glass windows. If you're lucky there might be a tour group you can listen in on for free.

Worth a visit. The chapelle is smaller than I expected and there is building work covering one side.They charge
8.50 euro entrance fee.So its worth a visit ,but for me, not a 'must see'

A place of generations of prayer. By far, my favorite place in Paris. This tiny chapel was for the kings and queens in French history. The blue ceilings and tiny stenciled stars, the beautiful wood and stained glass are all soothing and demonstrate a place of reverence. Lovely and peacefully breathtaking.
Sainte-Chapelle. Worth a look, but don't forget to check out both levels. The stained glass windows are worth seeing and you could spend hours viewing each window.

Sainte Chapelle evening concerts excellent. We recommend the concerts offered at Sainte Chapelle in the evening.A couple tips.Spring for the highest priced seats. The concert is dark so you feel the wonderfulsurroundings in the chapel but you don't see a lot of detail. That's why focusing on themusicians and singers is important, and they are hard to see from the cheap seats. And the price is fair.And yes, if it is winter dress warmly, the chapel is cold. But the concert is only an hourand in our case the holiday music was so good that is past quickly.Walking out of the chapel and looking around after an hour of inspiring music on aDecember night in Paris is special.

Beautiful stained-glass. Small, intimate chapel. A must see in Paris. Stain-glass is beautiful dating to the 13th century. It doesn't take much time to see the chapel, it is small, but one of the most beautiful stain-glass I have seen.

Stunning windows. Try and go to Ste Chapelle on a sunny day when you really get to see the "stars" here, the stained glass windows...shine. It is a lovely chapel, and the stained glass windows are breath taking. Worth a short visit, which is all you need to admire them.

This may be the best thing you see on your trip. We've visited this magnificent church on three different trips to France, and without question, Sainte Chapelle is our favorite cultural attraction in Europe. We were fortunate to visit in 2008 before the scaffolding went up for the long term restoration project, but even with portions of it behind the canvas, this is the most spectacular stained-glass display you will ever see. Actually, work on the last section was just getting underway when we visited in October. If you're planning a visit for late summer in 2014, maybe you'll get lucky and you'll have 360 degrees of brilliant stained-glass artistry. Although nobody ever mentions it, the lower chapel is pretty impressive on its own. Spend some time here before you go up and you'll be especially impressed. Nothing else will impress you after you visit the main chapel. Here are some things to remember. Buy the Paris Museum pass, and you'll get to skip the ticket line. You WON'T get to skip the security screening line which can move slowly, but once you get through, you won't have to stand in another line to buy tickets on site. One way to avoid this (or at least minimize this) is to arrive early. Don't arrive late. If the sun goes down before you get inside, you'll miss out on a lot. If you're planning on shooting photos of this place (and you will) bring your widest angle lens. The inside is smaller than you think, and you'll be frustrated if all you have is the usual zoom lens that comes on most DSLRs these days. Most point and shoot cameras have a very wide angle setting that will work just fine. Camera phones, of course, have nothing but a very wide angle lens. Most people think you have to have a bright, sunny day to get the maximum effect, but in some ways, a cloudy-bright or overcast day works better. The lighting is more even. But don't pass it up just because it's a beautiful sunny day. In fact, get ready for an astonishing sight.Don't forget that Sainte Chapelle hosts a number of evening organ concerts. That's a good reason to come back for a second visit after dark.

beautiful. A bit hard to find, with a line through the metal detector, and a steep entrance fee for essentially two large rooms, I probably wouldn't have bothered if my friend hadn't really wanted to see it. Definitely don't go at the height of tourist season.

Breathtaking. Nothing can prepare you for the visual effect of this chapel, it is breathtaking. We hired the audio guides, but unless you are interested in the detail of each window they are not necessary.
A must see!!!. Jaw dropping as you walk to the top of the small spiral staircase, prepare to be amazed at the beautiful windows!

Incredible. Its hard to describe how good this is - its basically two chapels on top of each other.Chapel one beautiful example of medieval art and early Catholicism.Upstairs is breathtaking - the light is incredible - don't want to give to much away but worth it.My partner and I got this on a two for one deal with the concierge next door (once again sorry re spelling).To get in its the public entrance to the palace of justice

Just let go and take it in. What can I say but "the glass, the glass, the glass". Take time to read the guide material inside. And also take time to look at the lower chapel. Many people seem to think the lower chapel is a gift shop.

If you like stained glass, this is a must-see. Ste. Chapelle is a very old Cathedral that is located just blocks away from Notre Dame so it very easy to get to. As all have said in their reviews, the stained glass is spectacular. Get a brochure that helps describe the stories depicted in the glasswork. That makes it not only beautiful, but interesting. There is some restoration going on, but there is still plenty to see. Do yourself a favor and go enjoy it.

Beautiful!. An amazing place to see, although a little difficult to truly appreciate because of the number of tourists. I was lucky enough to attend a Vivaldi concert there one evening, what an incredible experience!

Stained Glass Nirvana. This ancient church is sublime, covered in brilliant flour de is and then climb the tiny narrow stairwell to see the upper floor, the stained glass upstairs will knock your socks off. Currently under some restoration so go buys ticket and support the endeavor to preserve this place. A must see.

Neck craningly beautiful. If you are interested in stained glass this is a must see. The entrance fee is not cheap and it is not that easy to find but the wow factor is there. There is almost more glass than stonework. Currently undergoing restoration but there is still plenty to see.

Nice to visit. Church was under renovation so one complete wall was behind scaffolding and completely blocked. I was expecting more, but its not all that magnificent. The stained glass is beautiful though. Free with the museum pass which is a no brainer.

Bonne. Lots of tourist so difficult to have a quiet visit. In any case if you like Arts and HIstory, either you are religious or not Is a place that totally worths a visit....Something preserved from medieval times, with atonish vitrals that survived WWII bombings

A must see.. We were told to go here to view Paris as opposed to taking the lift to the top of the Eiffel Tower. We are glad we did. It is free and there is an incline plane for those that can't take the stairs which is included in any day train passes you have purchased. The view is wonderful. The inside of the church gorgeous. The streets were fun to experience around the area. And an added bonus for us was a harpist on the steps. It moved me to tears.

Touching. Lots of tourist so difficult to have a quiet visit. In any case if you like Arts and HIstory, either you are religious or not Is a place that totally worths a visit....Something preserved from medieval times, with atonish vitrals that survived WWII bombings

Magical! A treasure.. Absolutely stunning. The stained glass is something beyond breathtaking (even on an overcast day). A small part was under restoration (which has been ongoing since 2008 I believe and will be completed in 2014) but that wasn't a major distraction. In fact, it was interesting to see video of how "the glass master" was carefully cleaning and repairing the centuries-old glass. Definitely spring for the audioguide. It walks you through each window (most of which portray stories very ambitious for depiction via stained glass windows, like entire books of the Bible). Takes about an hour or so to listen to all the commentary. An absolute must see.

Spectacular. Not as impressive from the outside, but it makes up for it on the inside!!The stained glass windows upstairs are simply beautiful. Even downstairs, the place has a special feel to it, the ceiling painting looks & feels velvety somehow.I would definitely recommend a visit.

Skip Notre Dame for Sainte-Chapelle. Most of the attention on Ile de la city is given to Chapelle's neighbor, Notre Dame. And yet, the windows and architecture in Chapelle rival its massive neighbor. It's a small space, and there is certainly time to visit both places, I highly recommend you do.

Beautiful even without sunshine. Visited today and as it was cloudy there was no sun shinning through these amazing windows! Still worth visiting and as it was the first Sunday of the month it was free! Please note that there is a narrow circular staircase that you must navigate to reach the main chapel and some may find this difficult.

Serene. I traveled with my vision impaired mother in a wheelchair. The people here were great in getting her in. It is not as easy in a wheelchair as other places in Paris.It was definitely worth it once we were in. Plan to spend a bit of time to just sit and take it all in.
Wow! Get there early tho. Beautiful interior! The stained glass is unbelievable. Get there early, the line can be slow as you will pass thru security checkpoint.

Always awed. Once again, Sainte Chapelle has inspired and awed me. This time I find it under renovation which is good because there is quite a lot of explanation about the stained glass process. To see this magnificent 13th century church, one has to pay a fee and it is worth every centime.

A jewel box. We arrived and a guided tour was starting. The guide gave us a lot of info on the history of the Church. Very interesting. Visiting the chapel is like being in a jewel box. We were lucky and did not wait long, only 20 minutes. It is better if you arrive early. The security is very tight.

Amazing. This is the most incredible stained glass cathedral. It goes back over 1000 years and the technique is amazing. Just standing in a room surrounded by stained glass on a bright is a sensation that is breath taking.
Just gorgeous. My third visit here and it still amazes me - some refurbishment taking place so about a third of one side is covered in scaffolding.

Very. Stunning. This is a very tall interior space with a very small floor area. The walls are amazing because they are almost completely glass. Stained glass. The glass is being restored and it is interesting to see the process and the remarkable change in the overall appearance. This is definitely worth seeing but I would say it should not be on the top of the list of things to see in Paris if you're short of time. You certainly will be glad to you there, and it is very beautiful. But there are other things to see. Also, there is a longer wait because they don't have museum pass priority entry.
Took my breath away. I have to say hands down this was my favorite church in Paris. It's beyond beautiful, I could have stayed there so long just staring at the intricacies of the glass.

This one is "Wow" Attraction. Without giving too much away, this one made my mouth drop open. I literally kept saying "wow" as I looked around. Even the entry on the first floor was impressive. If you're into details, you could spend a couple hours here trying to look for all the stories from the Bible that are visualized. If not, just appreciate the the wonderful colors and craftsmanship on display, which is what I did. Don't miss this one.

Truly remarkable. A long review wouldn't do justice to Sainte-Chapelle. The chapel is quite large by chapel standards, but obviously can't be compared to the grandeur of a cathedral. Once inside, the comparison becomes irrelevant. The stained-glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle form a wall of glass around visitors and bathe them in a sea of rosé light. I've travelled extensively, but I've never had an experience that quite matched this one. Very memorable.

Beautiful Stained Glass. We visited Sainte Chapelle on a Sunday morning and walked into security with no line. Once we got to the church we waited maybe 5-10 minutes to buy tickets. Museum pass holders went right in without waiting. We had a cloudy day but the windows were still bright and beautiful. I was worried about this as I heard you needed to visit when it's sunny but that really wasn't the case. The upstairs chapel is beautiful even with the left side covered in scaffolding. It's neat to see the video of the painstaking effort taken to restore the glass. You can see the difference when you look at both sides of the room. The downstairs chapel is also very nice with the columns and decor. Overall it was less then an hour visit but well worth it. We also went back to Sainte Chapelle to hear a concert at 7:30pm. Honestly I wouldn't recommend it at this time of year. It was so brutally cold inside and with no light the windows look dull and the lighting was very low in the church. The music was beautiful but we could have been listening to it anywhere. We were very anxious for the hour to end so we could warm up. If you do decide to go make sure you have a hat, scarf, gloves, warm coat and maybe a small blanket to put over your legs. Also you can buy tickets while you are in line and if you buy online don't worry about what tickets you get because it's open seating anyway.

Go to a concert here. If you are travelling to Paris during summertime, you can go to a classical music concert in this beautiful chapel and still get to enjoy the stained glass which is magnificent. Late afternoon / early evening is ideal for viewing the windows as the sun streams in.Book for concerts online, you will still have to queue to get in but it is worth the wait. The concerts are short and sweet with plenty of time to dine afterwards if you go to the early session.

Go twice. A stunning Gothic building with the most amazing stained glass this is a must see.Go twice. One time must be in the day to see the amazing windows ( being renovated at the moment) but if you get the chance, go back at night and attend one of the evening concerts. A magical experience in stunning settings

Never fails to inspire. Even though restoration work causes a portion of the chapel to be draped, the amazing stained glass and the relative peace of Ste. Chapelle make it worth visiting any time you are in Paris.

Go early. Best time to see this beautiful church with it's impressive stained glass windows is early in the morning, before the line for admission becomes too long. Or better yet, go to an evening concert. This allows you to enjoy the interior while listening to classical music, but you can't really appreciate the stained glass this way.

Beautiful church in middle of town !. We were just walking and came upon this gorgeous church ! We decided to go in. Am I ever glad we did !! Wow! Amazing . We happened to get there just as an English tour guide was beginning a tour and thoroughly enjoyed learning all about this awesome place and all the windows!! The windows will take your breath!! Another must see !
Express ticket didn't work. Wanted to go in and had bought the skip the line ticket but they would not let us use it. Said we had to go in the regular line which was way to long. :(

Beautiful. We were there recently so be warned the walls are under restoration and there is scaffolding up. That really did take away from the experience. That and the hundreds of other people. It is beautiful and you should see it but expect crowds and no sense of spirituality/peace.

an amazing little known spot.. A co-worker and I were traveling on business and I told her my plans to visit Paris.She told me to go to Sainte-Chapelle I'd be amazed. It didn't seem to be as well known as Norte-Dame (just down the street) but we went and Holy Moley if you are into amazing stained glass she was right you will be amazed. Do not miss. The lines are way shorter (and cheaper) than Notre-Dame. They were in renovation process when it is done it will be above amazing!

The Private Chapel of Light. Originally built inside a castle [now the French Court], this was a chapel for Louis. And, he spared no expense is building a house of lights with all of its stained glass windows.You will enter on the lower level - originally for the commoners in the castle to use to worship - and be completely underwhelmed. Then, you can climb the circular stone stair case to the upper level - the king's level. Glass, glass, glass - a chapel of natural light. Unfortunately, when we were there, a major restoration was in progress and one side of the chapel is nothing but scaffolding, tarps, and workmen. So, it is hard to get an adequate impression of what the chapel would be like on a sunny day - other than that it would be magnificent.

Renovation almost complete. While small, this is definitely a site worth seeing.Currently the rear left quarter of windows have been removed from the upper chapel for restoration... But it is still worth a visit.

So close to Notre Dame, but so much less crowded.. I was very surprised at how little traffic this chapel gets, given it's wonderful interior. The story of the survival and restoration work on the stained glass windows is really unique and interesting. It doesn't take that long to visit, but is well worth seeking out.

Most beautiful church I have ever seen. This is the most beautiful church! Make sure you have your camera. The stained glass is unbelievable. It is very near the "prison", I can't remember the name, which is one to see too.
a lovely site for a concert. There are classical music concerts at 6 and 8 pm in the main chapel. The musicians were first-rate and the experience memorable. The church isn't heated, so dress warmly.

If you like stained glass windows........ This is, of course, a remarkable church with the beauty of the stained glass as its centerpiece. Many say it is their favorite cathedral in Paris for this wildly colorful and ancient display of storytelling from Bible in glass.As a building itself it does not overwhelm as many of the large cathedrals would, but this We were there on a rainy day in early November, when the crowds were sparse and the audio guides worked really well for us. Tough to spend more than an hour or so, but worth going for sure.
fantastic piece of history. Make the effort to this place it,s amazing and the windows truly splendid! If you can avoid crowds all the better for the experience.

"The Windows!..".yes windows. The effect of stained glass windows is wonderful. The colours blend so well with sunrays passing through them. Beautifull scenery and yes!..you can take as many pictures as you wish, its allowed inside the chapel

Truly enjoyed Sainte-Chapelle. Missed this on our first trip to Paris 5 years ago, so it was high on the list this time. It did not disappoint. They allow photos inside fortunately...... I'll let the pictures speak for themselves.

Concert was highlight of our trip. We heard a string quintet play Vivaldi's Four Seasons here our first night and they were incredible. We didn't get to "tour" the chapel itself much otherwise, just able to enjoy this concert.

Wonderful stained glass. The windows and the effect of the stained glass is marvellous. Unfortunately, there was work going on in the chapel and the north wall was covered in scaffolding. Nevertheless, the effect on the east and south walls of the colours and the sunlight through them was magical.

Great. The security line was not too long when I visited. The first floor was not as impressive as I anticipated it being, and the second floor was absolutely gorgeous with all of the stain glass windows. However, almost half of the second floor was under construction, which took away some of the magnificence. I can only imagine what it would have looked like had the whole second floor been completely open and unobstructed by the construction.

Unforgettable Glass. Most indoor sites can be saved for a rainy day, but to get the most out of the peerless stained glass of Ste Chapelle visit on a sunny day when the colours will be at their most vivid.
Gorgeous windows!. Unbelievable stained glass windows. The windows make it worth the visit. Longer than usual security line.

A little gem!. Somehow I have missed this treasure on earlier trips to Paris, but I now rate it as one of the best attractions in Paris. The stained glass on the second floor is spectacular and the sense of antiquity inspiring.

Don't waste your time. Went there in November on a clear day as advised by guidebooks. The day was beautiful and the expectations were high. Queued up, paid up and entered the hall. Nothing more than a tourist trap. The stained glass was nice, but we just came from the Sacre Coeur. The stained glass there was spectacular, beautiful colours and 3 dimensional. Besides, one quarter of the tiny Sainte Chapelle was under restoration. The visit was over in 10 mins. We waited longer in the queue. Not worth the 8.50 fee at all. Go to the Sacre Coeur or the Notre Dame instead. Best of all, you don't have to pay to enter.
Fantastic!!!!!. Amazing to know that the majority of the stained glass is original. Biblical scenes in stained glass windows.

Very Beautiful. This is a crowded chapel, but very pretty and worth the effort and wait. The crown of thorns is not located here but on display at Notre Dame on the first Friday of the month. Still very inspiring. Walkable from Notre Dame.

Very Nice. Worth a visit for the stained glasses.The Climb to the top floor of the chapel is quite steep and narrow,but the spectacular stained glass takes your breath away.Makes for nice Photos,though work going on during our visit,marred some opportunities.However,the small area is covered quickly and there is not much to see beyond that. The lower section is occupied by souvenir stalls giving the place an overtly 'touristy' feel,not befitting the Chapel.

Incredible. Sainte-Chapelle is a medieval jewel built by Louis IX in the heart of Paris. Though damaged in the Revolution, as many churches were, it has been continually restored since the 19th century. The stained glass is world famous and takes the breath away. We were lucky enough to be there when the experts were restoring a window. Highly recommended. Note: I don't think it has any handicap access.

misleading?. We did our research before we visited and knew that there was some restoration going on but we did not expect to find that quite a few of the "original" stained glass windows were actually stickers applied to plate glass. Also, when we asked why the stained glass was peeling off the glass we were told that ii is not possible, stained glass does not peel...We know that, that is why we asked. It was many many feet over head but clearly 1/2 peeling off exposing a large clear window. Other then that, the visit was nice. The stairs were neat.

Best concert ever. Sainte-Chapelle is a lovely place to visit under any circumstances, but even better when attending a lovely concert. We have attended many over the years, but Les Quatre Saisons and other pieces we recently saw performed were in a league of their own. I know that Vivaldi's Four Seasons is popular in Paris and one can find it being performed somewhere at almost any time, but the performance by Classik Ensemble with David Braccini was beyond great. His violin is so light and animated that he makes other performances seem boring by comparison. My biggest regret is that I did not buy a CD on my way out and if anyone knows where I can get a copy, please get word to me through this site. Aside from the concert, the chapel itself is a place of remarkable beauty and should be seen during daylight to appreciate the light through the stained glass.

Absolutely wonderful!. Right by the building of the Palais de Justice, this chapel is famous for its spectacular stained glass. One of Paris's most incredible jewels. Also, try to go to a concert there. They have them practically everyday.

incredibly beautiful. Pictures will never be able to do it justice. Be sure to get a pamphlet that explains the stories on the panels on the upper level. They were restoring part of it when I was there; and I hope to return again. This is a must-see for any visitor to Paris.

Be sure to go for a concert. You will want to tour Sainte-Chapelle to see the beautiful stained glass windows and decorations. But be sure to find out when they are having a concert. We heard Vivaldi's Four Seasons.....breathtaking!

Stunning stained glass. This is a small church located near Notre Dame but the stained glass is breath-taking. The upper level was reserved for the king, family and friends. It has an intimate feel compared to many churches in the area. We were fortunate to go when there was no line but it is worth the wait.

Sainte-Chapelle Concerts - A Hi-lite of our Trip to Paris. There are probably about 200 hundred seats at these concerts and it is one of the special "gems" that Paris has to offer. We attended Les Solistes Francais concert and they performed some pieces from Vivaldi. The sound that filled the chapel from their few string instruments was breath-taking. It was one of my most memorable experiences that I took away from my trip to Paris.

Gorgeous, and an easy visit compared to Notre Dame. So incredibly beautiful. I won't even try to describe the experience of standing in this place. If you're visiting Paris and you've never seen it, see it - and check out the laminated guides describing the windows. They really enrich the experience and are available in several languages.A Museum Pass would've been nice to have when I visited, but the line wasn't unbearable - 30 minutes to get through security and ticketing on a weekday in October. Remember that a Museum Pass won't speed you through security, and that does make up most of the entry time.

Royal. I can see why this was a royal palace. It really has some outstanding design and good location. I suggest walking all the way around the outside to see all the different aspects of the architecture, which was really amazing.

Interestingif you have a museum pas. Our visit to Sainte-Chapelle was time well spent if you have the museum pass anyway. It is a fairly short experience, but the stained glass really is beautiful. It is very near to Notre Dame, so if you are in the area I would include a visit here. The steps are fairly steep and not uniform, so if walking up stairs is a problem you may want to skip this.

Such History. We just loved this. The history just blows you away - and the feel of the whole church is quite magical. Having been to MANY churches and cathedrals on our Europe cruise, you tend to be 'churched' out a bit - but this is truly worth the effort. Again, lots of steps to climb but very, very worthwhile. A very spiritual church - if that makes sense.

So pretty!. The stained glass windows here are breathtaking on any day, and particularly if you are lucky to be here on a sunny day. This is a pretty quick stop as you walk around the area and relatively easy to miss, which would be a shame.

Definitely worth it to see the glass. My wife & I are 62 and had a museum pass. Gaining access is highly secured since this church is inside the government facilities. Once in, the line looked daunting except.. we walked right by with our pass and entered. No wait.The first floor is nothing so we climbed the spiral stairs to the church. We were disappointed that scaffolding was covering many windows and of course, covered some of the windows being discussed on the Rick Steves audio tour. However, the glass is remarkable given the time of course. Other than the glass, nothing really impressive. They do have concerts here and you can pay extra for the first few rows.. don;t bother. The church is so small, there is no value in being up front.We spent 30 minutes or so...

It is a lovely chapel. The stained glass as noted is awe inspiring. However it was a little disconcerting to walk in under a large "SILENCE" sign and listen to workmen using large and noisy power tools as part of the reconstruction/ renovation that is currenly going on. I think that had I arrived on a day without that I would be more impressed. NOTE: After getting to the front of the line up you will see a 8.5 X 11 inch paper identifying objects which are not permitted within the chapel and which will be confiscated and discarded should they be found upon your person - this includes, among other things, cutlery. Since we nearly always carry our picnic pack, that notice facilitated a return trip the next day without any of the forbidden items.

Sainte-Chapelle beauty in Stained Glass. While Sainte-Chapelle would appear to be overshadowed by Notre Dame, and everyone has to see Notre Dame, this chapel stands on its own as something that must be seen. The scale, it is a chapel, makes the incredibly beautiful windows all the more spectacular. Be sure to go with a guide. The information provided ties it all together beautifully, from the more simple chapel downstairs to the gorgeous one upstairs.

Sainte Chapelle with Les Quatre Saisons Concert. We took the metro to the St.Michel stop, crossed the bridge, and walked a block up to a very impressive building with huge stairs and definitely a police presence. I looked to the left to see a line of people walking into a small entrance and asked if this way the way to the concert. All smiles-it was one of the performers. Security is tight here. We followed the people and walked up a flight of stairs and walked into one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen. The sun was setting and we watched it wane over exquisite stained glass windows. These 13th century stained glass windows are the best and oldest examples in the world. The small chapel was commissioned by King Louis IX of France to house Christ's Crown of Thorns.Because it was built in less than twenty years, everything is very symetrical and coordinated. The chapel is under renovation so parts are a bit dusty and some covered, still the beauty shines through. Next we sat to ready for the concert. The lights dimmed and the performers came on stage and began. Absolutely fabulous. The lead violnist is superb. He walked up the aisle and my sweetheart who rarely is impressed clearly was. Vivaldi could not have been performed better. If the weather turns, bring a coat. Keep in mind that central heat was not available even to kings as far back as the 13th century. Look at YouTube to find clips of the performance.

Beautiful stained glass. This chapel near the cathedral Notre Dame is in the process of being restored. Never the less it is well worth visiting. It is very approachable as it is not the enormous size of many of the other churches in Paris. What is so impressive is the beautiful stained glass windows and the decorated walls that so perfectly complement the glass. For the best effect, go on a sunny day.
Go see the Sainte-Chapelle stained glass. The moved fast to get inside. The small chapel is beatiful. I felt the glass was as pretty as the Notre Dame. Lots of narrow stairs to climb.

Fantastic Stained Glass. This is not one of the Paris top ten - but in my opinion it should be
A beautiful place, with fantastic stained glass windows - Truly breathtaking
There are also evening concerts here, which must be fantastic - Unfortunately we did not manage to take one in during our time in Paris

Absolutely breathtaking. When entering I simply couldn't believe my eyes. The sheer height of the stain glass collection is impressive but also the many different depictions of saints that they display. The rose window at the back is a must for all Paris visitors. Each pane is different and the size is very impressive. Be sure to go between 11am-12pm when the sun is in its highest position and so lights up the glass to make the experience more formidable.

The little-known church with the STUNNER. This small chapel is located in an off-the road place. Does not look like much from the outside, but as popularity grows, the lines do too! The stunner is the upper chapel. It is a stunning display of stained glass that takes your breath away. Not to mention you come up a small, spiral staircase and are greeted to brilliant reds and blues. The Blue in the stained glass cannot be reproduced, though some have tried, and found no place else on earth. Especially a treat if they have a choir singing. Once can't help but feel holy in such a beautiful place.

Outstanding. This small chapel is under renovation but still open to the public. Truly a site to see and merely sit and meditate about the history of the chapel.Careful, for the entrance and exit is a old spiral staircase.

Extra Special Site. Extraordinary Stained Glass surrounds you. It is a bit overwhelming. There is a small winding staircase that you need to climb to get into the chapel. The Bible in stain glass!. A nice place to just sit a while and take in the experience

Breathtakingly Beautiful. This is a must-see. The chapel has original stained glass windows that survived world wars and were all but forgotten when it was used as a storage facility for governmental paperwork. The windows are vivid and tell many stories in picture. Also, the ceilings and walls, with fleur de lis designs, are enchanting. It was the chapel of the kings.
a must see. only negative is that it is currently being renovated which must happen but it really distracts from the visit.
Stunning! A must see!. Sainte Chapelle is one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen. It's small but the stained glass windows are breathtaking!

A beautiful chapel on ile d Cité. Go there, enjoy a chapel(church) consisting of 2 floors. A small one at the ground floor and a somewhat larger on the 1st floor. Coloured glasswindows unbelievable beautiful.
Beautiful. The most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen. It should not be missed. Some Restoration work and cleaning of the glass is in process, and that was very interesting to see.

stained glass is beautiful. With the Museum Pass, admission is covered. Although you can skip the line with the Museum Pass at most other attractions, here you must wait in line to go through security with everyone else. The chapel is next door to the Palais de Justice so be prepared to open you rpurse and go through a metal detector. Once through though, you are free to roam. The stained glass is beautiful and it is massive. Each piece seems to tell a piece of a much larger story and the longer to stare at it the more details emerge. To be honest, we rounded through fairly quickly. We did go upstairs to the upper chapel and enjoyed the beauty and tranquility of the space.Since this was covered by the Museum Pass, I felt that it was worth the trip. However, if I had to pay separately for admission I might have reconsidered. It was easily visited before or after a trip to Notre Dame because of the close proximity.
Awesome. It is still being renovated, but still awe inspiring. The stained glass windows, ceiling, statuary and paintings are all architectural gems. Went for a Vivaldi concert. Perfect venue.

The most beautiful Chapel in the world. Sainte Chapelle is an extraordinary place.The entrance is through the Palais de Justice and you need to climb a flight of stairs to reach the chapel.The chapel is formed by large walls of stained glass representing some bible passages. The work and the colors of the stained glass windows are unbelievable.The ceiling of the chapel is also worthy of being observed. The decor is minimalist to not compete with the designs of stained glass.Recommend that visits the Chapel are made during daylight, to be able better appreciate the wonderful stained glass.Visitation Chapel is interrupted between 11:30 to 13:00 in the morning.We had the good fortune of watching a concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons in Sainte Chapelle. The meeting of classical music with the magic of the chapel, was unforgettable ...

Stunningly beautiful on a sunny day. This amazing structure was an unplanned "add" to our recent tour, and we were so rewarded with a brilliant, sunny morning and very little crowd. You are fooled into thinking "well, what's so great about this?" upon entering the lower chapel. While lovely, it so pales in comparison to what awaits at the top of the winding stone stairway! The narrow, yet lofty upper church (now "retired" and used as concert and touring space) is a rainbow of wonder. The details in the stained glass and the color depth are simply mind-boggling. A treat for the eyes. I would have loved to have attended the Vivaldi "Four Seasons" concert that was upcoming. Sitting in this beautiful space, surrounded by beautiful music--that would have been perfection for the evening.

Just when you thought..... You'd seen it all! There is a guide who walks you through the history and discusses the nuances of this beautiful historical space. Personally, the sacred songs of 17th and 18th century flooded my mind as guided through the chapels. The upper chamber will blow your pre existed expectations beyond the stained glasses!

Unbelievable!. Unlike it's nearby colleague Notre Dame, this chapel is tucked away & not as well known but is as stunning. There are two chapels. The lower is your basic French chapel with stained glass & archways. Climbing a narrow spiral staircase to the upper chapel brings you to an unbelievable 1,100 biblical stories set in 15 stained glass windows almost floor to ceiling. There is still a great deal of renovation of the glass going on but even the dust can't detract from it's beauty.

stunning. one of the most stunning, if not the most stunning building i've ever been in. the amount of windows is incredible. go on a sunny day for sure. pay the entrance fee and splurge on the audio guide. just go. when i first went 12 years ago, in 2001, my cousin took me and i had never heard of the place. it was practically deserted and was run-down. just went again last week and there is a lot more activity and a lot of current restoration. just as amazing now as it was then. hard to believe it's held up this long. the relics of the passion of christ are now in notre dame, which is not far. go to saint chappelle first. then notre dame. then continue on behind notre dame to ile st louis and wander. have an ice cream for sure at the amazing ice cream shop. even the vanilla is spectacular. all 3 can be done for about 15 euro unless you pay for notre dame to go up the towers, which i have not. then go to sacre coeur (for free). not a bad day. they're all so different you can do 3 in a day if you have to. saint chappelle is a place you will talk about for the rest of your life becuase you will never see anything else like it.

Impressive Stained Glass. The chapel was small but the stained glass was beautiful. It was difficult to pick out the scenes in the glass. For the price and the wait, I wouldn't spend the time or money to see this again.

Concerts in the chapel. We heard a classical concert in St. Chappelle. Brilliant. String quartet playing Mozart and a contemporary Parisienne composer's work. Although we couldn;t see the stained glass at night, it was still magical.

Stunning stained glass windows. This church is located inside the Palais de Justiz and has a 20 minute security line before you can get in another 20 minute line to get into this church. So be prepared. The church is magnificent. It has 2 levels with spectacular stained glass windows. They are best seen on a sunny day.

Scaffolding still there. They have been working on Sainte-Chapelle for years. There is still quite a bit of scaffolding, but once they have completed the work, it will be even more magnificent than it was before. The stained glass windows are beautiful.The line to get through security is better organized than it was previously. Before, you had to wait in line with all of the people who were going to court. Now there is a separate line for visitors to Sainte-Chapelle and those who have court business.

worth the wait. The Museum Pass gets you no shorter line here. Just line up on the street with everyone else to go through the electronic check point. Then you are on your own and free to gaze at the windows. Even with the work proceeding on windows 1 and 2, the rest are accessible. Take your time, read the plastic info sheets available at the entrance to the upper chapel in several languages. There is a lot to find out about the biblical stories in the windows, and the political propaganda purposes they served for the king. There are a few seats along the sides of the chapel. Photos are allowed. Even the small lower chapel has appeal with its relative modesty and quiet.

A facinating jewel of French history. Despite the line-ups for tickets, Sainte-Chapelle is well worth the wait. Built as the personal chapel of Louis IX, there are really two chapels: the lower one for palace folks and the upper one which was the private domain of the king. Built in the 13th century, a resoration was recently completed. The stained glass is incredible and most of it is original. The upper chapel is reached through a narrow winding staircase and can get crowded but is spectacular.

Just Gorgeous!. The Sainte-Chapelle is a 13th Century Gothic gem, built to house holy relics acquired by Louis IX. There are actually two chapels: the lower one, where the staff would have worshipped, is ornate and beautiful. But you must ascend the spiral staircase to the King's chapel, where you'll find the amazing stained glass windows, depicting Biblical scenes. Current renovation work does, unfortunately, detract from the experience, but look on the bright side: not being able to view all the windows this time means that you've got the perfect excuse to come back and visit again!
Glorious. What a beautiful site to behold. The stained glass is amazing. Most people don't know about this attraction. Be sure and check it out.

Music!!! do not miss their concerts. Loved the Saint Chapelle concerts!!Bought the tickets online (classitic), securing excellent seats in the front row because I like to watch violinists playing but the acoustic is so good that you an seat anywhere and have an unforgettable experience. Although these tickets are inexpensive, the quality of musicians can be exceptional - you may want to check the season information by searching on the web but I know you will love it!!

My favorite. This beautiful 12th century structure has it all--architecture, paintings, sculptures, tight spiral stairs and tall stained glass windows. I wanted to return for a classical concert in the evening, but ran out of time.

THIS is the cathedral to see. Of course you don't want to miss Notre Dame or Sacre Coeur, but for true breathtaking beauty, do not miss this gem. The windows feel more structural than decorative. To me, this is the most beautiful church of all I've seen.

Amazing stained glass.. If you are going to visit Notre Dame, take time to visit here. The stained glass windows are absolutely beautiful!!! I wasn't up on stopping here, but my wife talked me into it. I am glad that she did. The stairwell is a little tight getting up to the chapel, but worth the squeeze! It is a must see!

A real gem. When we arrived, there was a queue outside. Everyone was being security checked. It was worth the wait, Sainte Chappelle is on two floors. Ground floor was impressive but the upper floor was just awesome. You climb up this narrow winding staircase and suddenly you are surrounded by the most beautiful stained glass windows you will ever see. It's a feast for the eyes.

Stunning Windows. I made a point of going to see the stained glass windows. To be honest I was not as blown away as I expected to be. It is difficult to get up the steeps to the main part of the church. It was very crowded, but I would deffinately go if I was nearby and it is so close to Notre Dame Cathedral that it is well worth a quick visit. The church itself is not much to look at though. especially having visited Notre Dame before coming to Sainte-Chapelle

Rude people. Went to a music concert at the Sainte Chapelle and couldn't believe that there were people that recorded the concert on the iPad and iPhone. So instead of looking at the musicians, I looked at someone's iPad as he held it up. Saw an iPad, a mini iPad and iPhone being held up. I feel that the staff needs to put a stop the recording. So rude. Really ruined the evening for me. I know I should have said something to people, but I did not and I tried to get up to move to the back, but it was too crowded to get out on the side. Was sort of stuck in my seat. Beautiful place and beautiful music. Just don't get it.

Very special jewel. The Ste. Chapelle is in the middle of the police station and sometimes the security lines can be daunting and very long. The stained glass windows in the upper chapel (there are two) are beautiful and mostly original. The glass is currently being restored, but the restorers only work on a few windows at a time, and all of the others can be seen. Be sure to bring binoculars. In fact, don't even think about going to Europe without binoculars.

Don't Miss This. Although undergoing restoration, the Sainte-Chapelle offers stained glass windows that are simply magical. Notice how the colors change as the light outside shines and fades, and imagine yourself a member of court when kings ruled France. A visit to this monument is especially welcome if you are unable to visit the Chartres or Reims cathedrals.

This is small but well worth the visit. It has amazing history and we loved how they discribed the pain staking method in which they are repairing the ancient stain glass. The stain glass is what you are there to see. The down side to the experience is that it is very much under construction and so vast portions are being worked on. But I would highly recommend including this on your tour in Paris!

Windows magnifique. The colours, magnificence of this chapel. Could be missed, as it isn't easy to locate. Be there early to avoid crowds, and be prepared to walk up narrow staircase, but worth every moment.

Museum Pass - You don't get to skip the line!. We passed the exterior of the Saint Chapelle but unfortunately the line up was long and my husband was unwilling to wait in line. The photos I've seen of the interior look great and I wish we could've seen it. As a warning - having the Museum Pass does not allow you to skip the line for this attraction (unfortunately). :( This church is near the Conciergerie (where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned) and Notre Dame, so definitely worth including in your trip while at the Île de la Cité.

Breathe takingly Beautiful. We went to an evening concert in the Sainte-Chapelle. It was the best of both the performance and the surroundings. If you have never been in the Sainte-Chapelle you are in for a treat. It is breathe taking to see stain glass windows rise 140 up to let in a heavenly light. Between the setting and the music it was a truly inspiring evening. If you can make arrangements to attend one of these performances it will be well worth your time and effort. I got tickets by going on classic ticket for Paris. Don't miss this church especially if you can go during a concert.

Its amazing .... The stained glass here is some of the most beautiful we have ever seen. It is an astonishing experience. Given the choice I would recommend walking around the outside of Notre Dame to enjoy the architecture and then visiting Sainte Chapelle to enjoy the wonderful interior.

Favorite Place on the Planet. Sainte-Chapelle is the most beautiful church I've ever seen. If there's a long line, wait, because it's worth it. It's not as flashy as most other churches, but it's peaceful and easy to digest as it's mainly the stained glass windows you want to see.
Restoration. They are presently restoring the old testament stained glass windows so it took away from the marvel that I can only imagine St. Chapelle is when it is in its glory.

Just even better than it looks in the books.... This won't take you long to visit... it is two chapels... one on top of the other and both stunning... the upper chapel is basically a tall thin chapel with walls made almost entirely of glorious deeply jewelled glass.... it takes your breath away when you go in.... good idea to get up early and queue to be the first in...

Go to earlier concert instead of 8pm show. I made the mistake of booking a concert in Sainte Chapelle at 8pm. I wanted to see the inside and thought going to a concert would be a good way to both listen to beautiful music and see the breathtaking stain glass. I mistakenly thought it would be more lighted inside the cathedral and it wasn't. There was a lot of construction material on the ground besides the chairs and you couldn't see the colors in the windows at all. The music of Bach was beautiful (solo violinist) but otherwise nothing to see. Go to an earlier concert booking where it seems you'll get the illumination of the last light of the day. Buy tickets at the trinket/souvenir shop across the street from the entrance.

A site to behold. Being located in the hall of justice, the Chapelle seems out of place. The site is in a sad state of repair but is clearly being restored. The experience of coming out of the stairwell into the Chapelle itself was like walking into Heaven. The stained glass windows give the Chapel area a heartfelt spiritual feeling. Well worth the short wait to enter.

Awesome stained glass. We hadn't intended to stop here, but my sister-in-law highly recommended it so we did make time. I am very glad we did. A brief check through security, then walk over to the church -- the stained glass is just amazing. They are in the process of cleaning it and seeing the cleaned side, then the dirty portion, and watching the video on the process is just great. This ended up being one of the highlights of our visit.

Breathtaking. Even if you're not into stained glass windows or Gothic architecture, Saint-Chapelle is an absolutely stunning place to visit. Saint-Chapelle was built as a private chapel for King Louis IX (who was later canonized as Saint Louis) to house various holy relics he brought back to France following the Crusades. Since the chapel was designed to be the personal royal chapel to the King and his family, the whole place itself is quite small, but the stained glass windows are truly a sight to behold. You can rent an audio-guide for 4,50 euro, although simply reading up on the church beforehand will probably be enough for most visitors.I have only rated this sight as a four out of five because there is a lengthy wait to pass through security before you access the ticket counter at the chapel. The chapel is situated on grounds shared with a major courthouse in Paris. All visitors, even those with the "skip the line" privileges of the city Museum Pass must wait in this security line. Thankfully, the line moved fairly smoothly when I visited (I waited approximately 15 minutes), but I would imagine that the wait-times would be much busier during the summer.

Incredible stained glass. We are so pleased to see that Sainte-Chapelle is being renovated and refurbished! Be aware that the last entrance is at 5:30pm, which we missed by 5 minutes our first time but came back the next day.

One of my "must sees" in Paris. I dragged my mother all over Ile de la Cite to get to Sainte-Chapelle.
