I agree with another reviewer who said the entrance was difficult to find, as the chapel is in the middle of a government complex and can't be seen from the street. You will have to go through security to get in, then there's another line to wait in to get into the chapel. (Although our museum pass allowed us to go right in. We got some nasty looks from people in the regular line.)This chapel is one of my "must sees" in Paris. The stained glass windows are breathtaking. When we were in the highly decorated downstairs, my mother didn't quite understand why I wanted to go there. But when we climbed the little spiral staircase and came out into the upstairs chapel, and I turned to her and said "THIS is why," THEN she understood.I also agree with the reviewer who said the audio tour drones on and on and on about the windows. I don't need to know what each panel of the window describes. And with so many windows in the chapel, we would have been there for hours listening to the complete tour.Renovation work is being done on some of the windows. I found it to kind of spoil the effect of the upstairs chapel, but when restoration needs to be done, it needs to be done. (We found that in early/mid September, many places were starting restoration work.)

Stunning to see. I had read comments before our trip on the stained glass in the chapel. I expected it to be beautiful. But, I was not prepared for how overwhelming the chapel was. My husband and I were able to get tickets to attend a concert of Vivaldi performed in the chapel by a chamber group. When we walked through the door, the stained glass was catching the last of the day's sun. It was truly breathtaking and I think I held up the line as I tried to absorb the impact of the windows. The several hours we spent inside the chapel surrounded by the beauty of the glass and listening to Vivaldi was wonderful, certainly one of the highlights of our stay in Paris. Even with the renovations (and I ended up seated beside a big pile of construction equipment), the chapel is a not-to-be-missed stop in the city.
confusing to find. Well worth it, but the entrance is combined with the Hall of Justice, looked like we were in the wrong place. Absolutely beautiful

Very unique chapel in Paris. Stained glass windows in this museum are truly unique. Since the restoration work was going on, unfortunately we couldn't enjoy it in its full glory, but it was still worth the visit.

Glass windows are stunning.. Beautiful church, glass windows are stunning. Beware that the best view is from the second floor and the way to get up is thru very narrow spiral stairs, the # of steps are not that many but is still hard on some people! one lady got taken away by paramedics because the stair were too much for her and my parents were also feeling a bit dizzy after they got to the second floor since the stairs are too narrow and if there is a lot of people it feels like there is no air left to breath. Nevertheless, is a must see when in Paris, don't skip it!!

A Place We Always Visit when in Paris. We find this an inspirational place to visit. This time when we were in Paris, in addition to a visit during the day, we were also able to take in a baroque concert in the early evening as the light of the day faded. In addition to being in this beautiful place for an additional hour, we were treated to some spectacular views as the light dimmed into the evening's darkness. Even without us attending the concert, this is a beautiful and spectacular place to visit.

Stunning!. If you like stained glass or arched ceiling, this is a must visit. The lower level has beautiful lines in the ceiling with arches trimmed in gold and ceiling in midnight blue with stars. Upstairs you will find gorgeous stain-glassed windows that reach to the heavens. This is so beautiful I visited it twice.
Sainte-Chapelle atmosphere, music. One night we truly enjoyed a small chamber concert whose instruments filled this historical space with the most beautiful music; this was magical for me.

Too much scaffoling. Ok, so it sounds petty because restoration work has to be done. I stood in line during the free weekend in Paris( mid Septmeber ) and afterword questioned my use of time. It is lovely and the stained glass is beautiful ( even if three pieces of the rose window are fake) but the hand set explaining all the panels just drones on and on. Never even saw an entrance for the stairs, it might have been closed off because of the weekend event.

Wow! You can see it quickly-so worth even a peek. I've been to paris several times and this was my first time at ste-chapelle. Stunning piece of architecture. Ground breaking for the time as they were able to have stained glass cover a larger area than the supporting structures. There is over a mile of stained glass in this small chapelle. Get the audio tour because it makes the experience so much richer.

If you can't make it to Versaille . . . .. If you can't see Versailles, this is a great peak at how the French kings lived and saw their place in the world. (This was the king's personal church, with only limited access to the rest of the hoi polloi.) Here are a few tips, mentioned by others here. The great room is up the little staircase and is not the room you first enter, as interesting as that room may be. Also, the headsets can only be rented at the ticket booth (no signs that I recall), and not at the actual headset booth inside St. Chappelle. Also, as with most Paris museums, skip the long wait for tickets by purchasing a multi-day museum pass and skipping to the front of the line. Yes, right now it is under renovation but it doesn't matter. It's still awesome.

Surprise Up a Tiny Staircase. Thanks to Rick Steves, we were guided to see this 1248 year old church. The stained glass was told to be awe-inspiring. Upon entering the dark church, we did see some beautiful windows around us, but didn't locate the ones the descriptions and postcards conveyed.Puzzled, I finally asked a woman sitting on a small stool to the left of the main door. She was nearly unnoticeable, in contrast to the many stalls of religious articles to buy, unfortunately, within the former nave and sanctuary area.She said in her French inflected English, "did you go up?" Only then did I notice the tiny winding stairs and see that she had some headsets. My husband and I climbed these narrow stairs and our mouths hung open as we indeed came upon the awe-inspiring second floor room of floor to ceiling stained glass. Get the headsets or use Rick's book to help you know what you're looking at. But don't miss this beautiful design masterpiece.

Stunning!. A very beautiful, small chapel that has been a highlight of my two trips to Paris. The stained glass windows are the most beautiful I have ever seen. The downstairs level is lovely but I always enjoy seeing the amazement and surprise on visitors faces as they reach the top of the narrow stairway to the second level and see the unbelievably beautiful windows that surround the entire room. The Rose window at the far end of the chapel is magnificent. Be sure to pick up one of the informational brochures that they have explaining the theme of each set of windows. Just stunning and a wonderfully moving experience. Highly recommend! Currently closed on Tuesdays so check their schedule as you don't want to miss this experience while in Paris!

Beautiful. Saint Chapelle was beautiful but I was a little disappointed as there was so much scaffolding with renovations being undertaken. It is still spectacular to see but expensive when you consider it is 1/2 covered up. Do go when the sun is shining for most effect.

Outstanding Stained Glass Work. My husband was the one who told me about Sainte-Chapelle Cathedral. As we walked into the cathedral I said "is this it"? not knowing that there was a second floor. It is truly breath taking!!!!

Far better than Notre Dame. If you like stained glass, this is far more impressive than Notre Dame. It would be spectacular on a sunny day. It's hard to believe that it was built in such a short time and for far less money than it cost to buy the (probably fake) relics it was meant to house.
Spectacular!. I had seen pictures before and was already smitten, but nothing compares to seeing this masterpiece in person. Absolutely beautiful!

Spectacular Surprise. Friends had told us to visit Sainte Chapelle and so on their advice we did. The queue was quite short, by Paris standards, and wandering around in the Palais de Justice was quite strange. The entrance fee was modest and we entered the chapelle which was quite dark with lovely small stained glass windows, but was this what all the fuss was about? We noticed people disappearing up stairs in the corner and followed up the spiral staircase to next floor. Wow!!! it is quite indescribable, massive expanse of beautiful huge stained glass on all four sides in a relatively small building. It has to be seen to be believed. I stood by the entrance stairs for some time and the response of everyone as the they enter was of Wow or a sharp intake of breath. Spectacular.

Enchanting Experience. Whenever we visit Paris we make a stop at Sainte-Chapelle and renew our appreciation of this space. However, during our last visit we attended a concert in the chapel and it was magnificent.It was romantic,enchanting and an overwhelming experience. The architecture,stained glass windows and intimate scale of the space make it a special place !

Ornate and Colorful. The stained glass on this church is unlike anything I'd ever seen. Unfortunately, they are currently doing restorations so an entire wall of it had been removed. Even with this being the case, it was worth a visit. The line was insanely long and it was one of the only places where our Museum/Monuments Pass didn't grant us access to skip the line. It was worth it once we got in, though, and you can feel the history in this small church.

Breathtaking!. This small chapel, built quickly for Louis IX (Saint Louis) was built while Notre Dame was being constructed. The upper chamber is breathtaking when the sun is shining through the wonderful stained glass windows that make up most of the walls. Often missed by tourists with limited time in Paris, it is a must-see for those with time.

Masterpiece. A gem of design with light soaring vaulted ceilings on ground floor in total contrast to the most stunning stained glass upstairs, nearly 360 degrees. have to go in daytime for the light effect but stay into evening for a concert as there are many on, most nights...Vivaldi, Bach etc. Sublime!

A little disappointing...... The day we went they were having work done in the chapel and the banging and construction noise was terrible!! Plus one whole side of the chapel was covered up. They should have charged reduced entrance fee while this was going on. I could hardly hear the audio guide!!

Beautiful Stained Glass. This had been on my to-do list for a number of years but we never got there, so this trip, which was to celebrate our silver wedding anniversary, it was one of the top items on our itinary.As a wheelchair user, entry is free, but I had read that they request advance notice where possible, so I emailed ahead with my intention to visit on 31st July, and was sent a reply explaining that we enter through an alternative entrance and that the guards on that day would be aware we were coming.On the day in question, no one seemed to know about our visit and we were sent forwards and backwards several times before someone let us enter, and then left us to find our way to the entrance, which we did but it was not obvious.To get upstairs we then needed escorting most of the way back that we had come and then through the court building next-door, no biggy but it was a little confusing.It was worth the to-ing and fro-ing though, as the glass was spectacular. Altogether, excluding waiting time, 20 minutes is enough time out of you schedule to enjoy the view and the ambience of the chapelle; I was a little disappointed that all the relics that the building was built to house are no gone (some housed in Notre Dame) but it is still worth the visit.

Being Restored. Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely breathtaking! It is under restoration and the true beauty is not evident. When we were there only one side had been completed. Even so, it is not to be missed. I highly recommend getting the Paris Museum Pass.

Contrast this against Notre Dame. As one of the tallest gothic cathedrals in Paris, if not the world, you'll appreciate the amazing engineering that made it possible. The stained glass windows soar over you with explosive colors. If you can, try to visit this right after you see Notre Dame which one of the earliest, and hence, darkest cathedrals. Not to be missed!

Awe inspiring. Sainte-Chapelle is nearing the end of a restoration and unfortunately the scaffolding was still in place but that didn't diminish the beauty. We waited in line for about 30 minutes to get through the security but the wait was worth it. Choose a sunny day if you have that luxury to see the colors explode.
Breathtaking. So beautiful and full of amazing history!! One of our favorite sites in Paris. Some of Christianity's greatest artifacts were kept here.
Best of the best!. Even if they are not all available to view, the stained glass here is not to be missed. Just one of those "must-dos" when in Paris!!
Go early. Amazing stained glass. Then walk around Ile St Louis. Close to the Louvre. or just walk along the Seine
Stain glass was beautiful. If u want to see beautiful stain glass windows....this is the place. They were cleaning them up when I was there in may.use your Paris pass

Not worth it. There's not much to see and it's still under restoration with scaffolding in the main chapel. Would be better off waiting until it's finished. The stained glass that was restored was beautiful.

My favorite place in Paris. Years ago, on my first visit to Paris, a fellow traveller told me that his favorite place in Paris was Sainte-Chapelle. I had never heard of it before. Everyone knows of Notre-Dame, of course, but Sainte-Chapelle is, to me, the jewel of Ile de la Cite. The surprise on entering the upper chapel, after emerging from the dark spiral stairway, is breathtaking. Stained glass windows that are amongst the most beautiful in the world.I visit Sainte-Chapelle every time we go to Paris. It is a mandatory stop on our visits to that wonderful city.

Gorgeous stained glass. The word Chapelle is a bit misleading. It is on the order of an old Cathedral. Not too long of a line but worth the wait no matter how long - beautiful stained glass - the loveliest I've ever seen!
Beautiful church. Awe-inspiring gothic, but as of Aug.2013, there's restoration work going on and not all the windows can be viewed in the proper light
A Jewel. This museum is a jewel. Very small but beautiful. Stained glass is magnificent and you can see it up close. Some parts are being renovated but should be finished soon. A must see in Paris.

Stunningly gorgeous, but.... This tiny, jewel-like chapel is really one of the most beautiful spaces in the world, but currently major work is being done on the interior and fully half of the chapel is blocked with scaffolding, and it's hard to appreciate the serenity of the place with all the hammering and clanging going on. If you can, keep checking and wait to go after the work is finished. Also, be aware that because it shares an entrance with a government building, you have to go through a security checkpoint to get in. Not a big deal, and the guards were some of the nicest we encountered, but still an bit of an aggravation to empty pockets, show ID, etc.

Don't miss this beauty!. Truly one of the most beautiful and moving places I've ever visited. If you love stained glass then please plan on seeing this gem! Restoration was going on but didn't take away from the view! Make it earlier on a sunny day if at all possible you'll be amazed!

D&J Paris Adventure. A beautiful venue but the pleasure was diminished by the renovation taking place so that not all ofthe windows were visible. More could be done by way of a handout or placards describing the windows.
Amazing older chapel. From the outside, it would be easy to pass it by, but inside was amazing. The stained glass windows were so beautiful. The sense of history was appreciated.

La Chapelle of Louis IX. Easy to pass by if you're not looking for it. Just 2 blocks from Notre Dame. The stained glass is awesome. Well worth the 20 minutes to stop by and see when on Ile de la Cite!

Absolutely stunning.. There are many beautiful churches in Paris but this is in a class by itself. Miniscule in scale compared to Notre Dame and Sacre Coeur but overwhelming in beauty of the stained glass. We go every time we're in Paris. On first trip there with our then ten and thirteen year old boys they were actually stunned into silence coming out of the staircase.

Outstanding Stained Glass. The richness of the colors in the stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle just took my breath away. I simply had to take pictures of every single one of them. We visited early on a Sunday morning, & the queue was fairly short at that time.

Dazzling!. If you go on a sunny day, being upstairs in the main chapel is exactly like being able to stand in the heart of a huge diamond.
Take pictures of all the windows, but don't forget to just enjoy the sensation of the reflecting and refracting colors.

Still a Wonder So Many Centuries Later. Our visit to St. Chapelle was early on a Friday evening, as part of a Vivaldi "Four Seasons" concert at the venue, following our visit to Notre Dame nearby. What a beautiful, serene setting, literally fit for a King. My family and I enjoyed the concert as we gazed up in amazement at the stained glass. The artistic mastery and dedication, and religious fervor and devotion on display is nearly without equal. Read up on its history before you go. Highly Recommend.

Heavenly light. Impressive mostly original stained glass windows make Ste -Chapelle glow with ethereal light. Visit on a sunny day for best effect. Restoration of the windows is ongoing, so you may not get to see every panel. Video displays show how restoration is being done by artists.

How do they hold the place up with all this glass?. We only had one day in Paris and this was the one thing we missed last time that we had to see this time. The chapel was smaller in size than I remembered, but the stained glass is dazzling. And when you learn how old it is, you appreciate it even more. Restoration was going on, so there was a fair amount of scaffolding, but it was still possible to enjoy St. Louis' chapel.

A hidden gem. This wonderful chapel, locked inside the palais de Justice, is well worth the visit. Get there at opening time to avoid the queue, as they can build up if a bus load of travellers suddenly arrive.Inside it is quite splendid, with wonder full high stained glass windows upstairs, and the more intimate space downstairs. This chapel on two levels is quite surprising.

Always Great. Came here for the first time 41years ago and I keep coming back. So beautiful. The restoration is almost complete - last 3 windows. Went no a Sunday when the workers would be gone. All those blue and reds coming through the glass is magnificient. Need to come on a day when the sun is somewhat shining to get the brillence. I perfer winter - less crowds and it can get warm - the area of glass far exceeds the wall area. Come and enjoy - take your time.
Not to be missed. Best stained glass in the world. Do not miss. There is a line and you may spend more time in line than in the chapel. However, it is worth it.

A terriffic surprise.. I had absolutely no prior knowledge of this site. What a pleasant surprise. After reading all the positive reviews from others, I can't add anything else, other than to say - even with the partial restoration going on - DON'T MISS IT! - it is absolutely beautiful.

Please take the time to see and understand this gem. I learned about Sainte-Chapelle in a high school art history class and was thrilled to be able to see it in person many years later as an adult. Some structures overwhelm you with their size and power. Ste.-Chapelle is intimate but powerful due to the sophistication and lightest of the stone work that holds up so much glass. Definitely worth visting first then going to the larger and heavier Notre-Dame. I suggest you will get more out of your visit if you do take a little bit of time to study why the construction of this church was/is so remarkable and to compare it to Notre-Dame.

Don't miss it!. We went twice in a one week visit: once to hear a fine evening concert and once to admire both chapels during the day. The acoustics are remarkable and the setting intimate and human. I am not a stained glass person but could not help being overwhelmed with the beauty and artistry. The line outside looks long but moves reasonably; they no longer give preference to Museum Pass holders outside but do so at the ticket booth once you reach it after security. The downstairs chapel for the plebeians is as interesting as the upstairs one for the king, and much less crowded; don't miss either one.

Undergoing repairs so stay away for next few months. We got charge a fll ticket price but half the place under repair so a bit random why it's open. Half the stained glasses cannot be sighted but a beautiful chapel . Price should be reduced whilst maintenance ongoing and would suggest stay away for next 12 months.

Gorgeous but Museum Pass Holders must wait in same line. This Chapel is gorgeous. The stained glass windows completely fill all of the walls. Some were being restored when i visited and I believe that work will be finished soon (although it was interesting to see as well). Museum Pass Holders must wait in same line so plan ahead. They also close for lunch(!) so the line can be massive. Everyone must be security checked through one station so the line wait can be for hours.

St Chapelle. Needs no further introduction or recommendations to travellers and there are always long queues. I wondered why. One afternoon late, I got in easily and then I realised why. It is something between a Cathedral and a Church. Yes, its more a Chapel but larger. Inside it is just magnificent. It is very different to other churches. Highly recommended.

Sainte-Chapelle, a must. A visit to Sainte-Chapelle is a must. It is relatively cheap to visit and the stained glass windows are awesome. Visiting either eary or late in the day will mean that there is plenty of room to move about. If you can visit on a sunny day the stained glass windows will not disappoint.
Brilliant. Walking into this chapel was amazing. Never seen anything like it. The glass panels were huge and each one different. Absolutely stunning. Definitely worth while going to it.
stained glass windows to die for. A tiny chapel, but the stained glass windows are outstanding, and cover nearly all the wall space with their detailed beauty. Arrive a 9 to avoid the queue.

13th Century Beauty. Dating to late 12 hundreds Sainte-Chapelle is considered among the highest achievements of the Rayonnant period of Gothic architecture and contains one of the world finest in situ stain glass collection dating to the 13th century. It was smashed up a bit during the French revolution but renovated in the 19th century. Its massive high cathedral like ceiling with big gothic spans have some weird acoustic value that is seen to be believed. Being Australian I cannot believe the sophistication of this place 500 years before Australia was even discovered.Tip is to go early before the tour buses get there which is around 10am to 2pm. If you do get in with the tourist just blend in and listen to their tour guide walk through.

A beautiful church with incredible stained glass. This was a beautiful church which I had the priveldge of seeing on a beautiful sunny day. The stained glass and the reflective colors is a spectacular site. Don't miss the opportunity to see this Church.

Renovations and Event Equipment.... This is an amazing church rightfully famous for its stain glass windows. Sadly, between the scaffolding for renovations and the sound and lighting equipment for after hour activities rendered this a disappointing visit. Increasingly, European monuments and museums are being used for filming, state events, concerts and rentals. Visitors who come on these days find areas closed or covered in scaffolds and/or sound and lighting equipment.A real disappointment...
Sacred space. A beautiful little chapel with a rough history. The windows when you come up the stairs from the servants' chapel take your breath away. Worth waiting and enduring the crowds.
astonishing stained glass. Museum pass a must to jump long queues - but what an treat once inside. Such old history and such astonishing glass windows.
One of the most famous church. If you see this church you see all churches in Paris. It's very impressive and deserve some of your travel time.

Disappointed. We had visited Sainte-Chapelle 5 years ago. It was beautiful! We were in Paris with friends last week and insisted that we all go to Sainte-Chapelle. Long line and long wait. After we bought our tickets we found out that nearly half the windows were covered for renovations! What a disappointment. The audioguide was not helpful as we could not find where we were (and we could not see many windows anyway). Wait to visit until the renovations are complete. I'm sure it will be wonderful again.

Beautiful!. One of the sights of Paris. But queues are not fun! Do what we do...book an afternoon or early evening concert and then you get to appreciate the stained glass windows surrounded by music. Obviously a night concert defeats the purpose as the windows are not visible. Just a tip!
Truly spectacular. I loved all the glass stained windows and the Gothic architecture. Although they were doing maintenance it was still worth it. It felt so beautiful inside, definitely worth seeing.

Stchap. The place is stunning with its stained windows. Really beautiful which I think not many people knew about the place. There was a queue but on a small scale compared to others. One side of the Chappelle is under refurbishment when we visited however to sum it all it's an amazing little place.
breathtaking work of art. Not to be missed when you visit Paris The stained glass windows were truly magnificant and the skill of the craftsmen of that era never ceases to amaze me

Aboslutely beautiful. This place is a little underestimated really.I wasn't sure I really wanted to spend the time but I was so glad I did. The stained glass is amazing! I have never seen so much of it, and it is so so beautiful. It doesn't take a lot of your time and they also have some special performances on there at night which are well worth having a look at. This place is beautiful.

Amazing. This was recommended as a "to see" site and although it was under renovations. I was indeed a beautiful piece of history the story that is depicted by the glass artwork (New Testaments) is amazing.I would definitely go again

Wonderful. Great visit to this very old cathedral. Windows are in the process of being cleaned and restored and the "before and after" experience enhances the beauty of this large but somehow intimate space. Not far from Notre Dame and make for a wonderful comparitive yet very different double header.

A work of art. This church is very old and has some amazing art work given to the windows is jaw dropping. We must say that we was very lucky that we had a museum pass it saved a lot of time because
this is a very popular place. The whole area is a must.

Almost impossibe to describe, so beautiful. This must be seen to fully appreciate the beauty. No photos could do it justice.
The only downside was the chatter of tourists. this deserves a bit more reverence and respect.
A must see. The window of the chapel are stunning. One has to visit the upper chapel to fully understand the time period. The crowed aren't too bad. This a must see stop in Paris.

Smaller than Notre Dame but more intimate. If you don't want to queue for Notre Dame, visit here. It's beautiful and far less crowded. Very interesting window and we had a free tour with an English speaking guide.

The marble staircase. Don't be cowled by the entrance line, it moves quickly... The stained glass jewel-box dome is, of course, best enjoyed when the sun is shining. If you have a cane or other walking device you can go to the front of the line and get a ride in the elevator instead of having to attempt the very numerous steps.
Nice little Chapel. it's a 2 level gothic chapel, it took a while to get in but made it at last. the chapel is famous for it's glasses, and you can tell it is really old.

Vivaldi's Four Season at Sainte Chapelle. Based on reviews from this site, I took a chance and booked my husband and I VIP tickets to see / listen to Vivaldi's Four Seasons concert at Sainte Chapelle on October 4th 2013. I'm so glad to report that the experience was AMAZING! Chills! If you're looking for something off the beaten path for your trip to Paris, I highly suggest this concert. The chapel is under renovation and is a bit smaller than it appears in the photos, but it truly is beautiful. What a wonderful setting for an intimate concert. I thought the acustics were very good, though I've read reviews stating otherwise. Possibly my ears just aren't that trained. Additionally, we were sitting close enough to witness the wonderful back and forth action between the musicians. The first violinists performance took my breath away! We had no issues finding the entrance to Sainte Chapelle and the concert kicked off exactly on time. Sainte Chapelle is very close to Notre Dame and the entrance is accomodated through the Ministry Building, which is beautiful as well.

It's all in the glass!. The Sainte Chapelle ought not be be standing any more. It was sold for the worth of its construction materials during the anti-religious French Revolution. But the buyer was very disappointed, what he expected to be stone walls turned out to be glass, of no worth to him, so he let it stand.Thanks to this, one can visit this wonderful chapel, well worth the long wait for entry, and the climb up the flight of stairs. The result is a treat, with gorgeous stain glass and a wonderful ceiling. But don't expect the grandeur of Notre Dame. This is a chapel, not a cathedral.Still, no visit to Paris is complete without a visit.
the very best. This chapel is incredible. I go to see it every time I am in Paris and take with me whomever I am with. I hope to see it many more times in my life.
Stunning. The chapel is absolutely beautiful, and the view from the top is even better. A bit pricey though for one room.

K & S @ Saint-Chapelle. This exhibit is covered under the "Paris Museum Pass" and shouldn't be missed. Conveniently located on the island with Notre Dame at the other end. The church exterior and surrounding Conciergerie are what is left of the old palace from the 10th century. It was confusing to find, as the scaffolding during restorations hid the church itself. The chapel on the second floor was our main interest. There are fifteen panel windows of hugh stained glass from the 13th century. The story is told from left to right in the windows, however, they are so very tall, it is hard to see all the way to top. We just stood, enjoy the light coming through and absorbed the beauty. You can wonder through the rest of the church and the outsideareas, seeing many exposed ruins.

Magnificent Gothic Chapel. This must be Paris's most beautiful church. Very plain from the outside and hidden by the Palais de Justice, but once inside - well - just wow!! There is so much restoration going on at the moment, but you can still see the painted walls, the fantastic vaulted ceiling and magnificent stained glass windows illustrating scenes from the old and new testaments. Be sure to see both churches, the downstairs church was for the palace staff and the upper church for the royal family which is, of course, much bigger. The Conciergerie where Marie Antoinette was kept was closed until November. We will definitely go and see this church again when the restoration has been completed. Well worth the visit.

Breathtaking. This church is an amazing contrast to the nearby Notre Dame. The windows seem to soar into the sky and the detail is incredible. They were working on four of the windows while we were there, but there was still plenty to see.Don't forget to visit the commoners' chapel below!
Beautiful stained glass. Worth the visit. A bit hard to fine. Located within the ministry building. Only a few places to sit, no chairs/pews inside.

Exquisite. Perhaps the most beautiful site we saw during our visit. The chapel is currently undergoing renovation and there was a fair amount of noisy hammering going on and scaffolding obscuring some of the windows however even that couldn't destroy the atmosphere. The stained glass is unlike anything I have ever seen before - read the information cards about how the glass was crafted, it just adds to the awe. The level of detail is outstanding and the windows just glow with light. The chapel is not big and it's not a site that takes hours to see however definitely worth a stop in. The history and architecture are also fascinating. Just stunning.We went early, there was perhaps 20-30min wait in the line till opening. There is a security checkpoint and no priority line for pass holders. When we left - no line.

A beautiful treasure. This was my first visit to the Sainte Chapelle, and it was worth it! The beauty does not escape the fact that there's a lot of damage to the walls caused by Father Time. Work is being done to repair the vitrines, and it is quite reassuring. Don't let this stop you; you will see much to love.I would have hoped to have a friendlier clerk at the ticket office. The woman could not provide a smile or say something as simple as bonjour or merci.

Don't miss this small but beautiful church. Not one of the larger, more well known churches in Paris, Sainte-Chapelle nevertheless is a fascinating study. With its two very different sanctuaries (one on top of the other), it is a treat not to be missed. Next to the Conciergerie on Ile de la Cite, it is best visited on a sunny day, but worthwhile even if it's cloudy.
beautiful. This is a beautiful cathedral know for its stained glass windows. It is not far from Notre Dame, so you could easily see both in a morning or afternoon.

Walls of glass!!!. The exterior of the chapel was being restored while we were there. The exterior seems plain and modest. Going into the chapel on the lower level was awesome.....the indigo colors of the ceiling and the gilding are awesome.......THEN you walk upstairs and, WOW!!! We were there in the afternoon when the sun was coming in the west windows. I wondered how the walls were standing up as the chapel felt like it was made of glass. This might have been my favorite church in our three-country European tour!!!

Beautiful Stained Glass. Absolutely beautiful stained glass church along with multilingual cards to read as you walk around the church. The only downfall is that it costs money to enter approx €7 a person (I can't remember actually) especially when most, if not all churches are free to enter. All in all it was worth the cost.

The Jewel of Paris. Of all the sites which we saw in Paris for me Sainte-chapelle was the most beautiful. The exquisite stained glass as well as the lovely architecture truly make visiting this an amazing experience.

Hidden beauty.. This beautiful chapel is not easy to find, but is a must see if you can. The light inside is indescribable through windows that seem all but hidden from the outside. Peaceful and beautiful.

One of the most beautiful places in the world. This is really one of the most beautiful places in the world. The windows just glow (try to go on a day that's sunny). Gorgeous architecture, and details on nearly every inch of the walls. Definitely make time to go here!

great widows, but half is closed. Beautiful widows, filled with small details, that are difficult to appreciate without binoculars. Half of windows are under restoration and can't be seen. During repairs they charge lower entrance fee. Line was bearable - 15-20 minutes.

A lot of trouble and expense for a short visit.. I love ancient churches, so I enjoyed this--especially since it reportedly has the oldest stained glass in existence. HOWEVER, it's a bit of trouble to get to see (you must first go through security since it's on the same grounds as the court system) and it's 8 Euros. Plus, if you are claustrophobic, the narrow winding staircase might be too much for you. HOWEVER, it is beautiful and very close to Notre Dame.
Amazing lead light windows. A must see in Paris, it's basically 2 rooms, but 2 very intricate amaing rooms. This is a quick visit, but well worth it!

Go for the view AND the concert!. We attended a Saturday evening concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons in the beautiful glass covered chapel. The surroundings are stunning and it's good to get there early to take in the beauty before the concert begins (and the sun sets). We bought tickets in the first 10 rows --- highly suggested as we were able to see the musicians easily and feel their love of the music and performing for us. Highly recommend going to a concert here!

Gives Stained Glass a New Light. This church, albeit small, is extra, extra extraordinary with its stained glass windows...which more fairly explained are stained glass walls. The color, precision and vastness of the stained glass really shed new light on what it means to decorate churches with stained glass. It's a quick visit and a must-see in Paris.

Sainte -Chapelle restoration doesn't dim its brilliance. As of September 2013 one whole side of Sainte-Chapelle is under scaffolding, as part of a long term restoration project. That's ok, for that side of this incredibly lovely chapel is in shade anyway, as it abuts the wall of the adjoining building. Go anyway, just making sure, if you can, to go on a sunny day, when you'll get the best bang for your admission buck.

Like being inside a jewel box. One of my favorite places in Paris. They are cleaning the windows, so it will only improve. The walls are all stained glass, and every inch is decorated. Be sure to go up the corner stone stairs! You enter below the chapel proper, and some don't realize the "show"is above.
Restoration work is amazing. Still an amazing building with unbelievable stained glass. Should be on everyone's list of favorites in a beautiful city.

hidden treasure. Went to St Chapelle for the Vivaldi concert. Just an amazing setting for 1 hour of culture. If you are going to visit go to the early concert then you can admire the beauty if this building.Hint pre buy your tickets and be there at least .5hour before as the seats are not allocated.There is currently work being done inside and therefore it is not as grand as it would normally be but you must accept that these things need to be done

Excellent Sit, but still under renovation. 4 Stars only due to current renovations. Sainte-Chapelle is still well worth the visit, the stained glass windows, particularly upstairs are magnificent.We found, whilst it can get full and is a lot smaller, it's not as noisy or crowded as Notre Damn and personally I prefer the stained glass at Sainte-Chapelle.If you go to Notre Damn, it's only about 5 minutes walk away, don't miss it.

Amazing windows. When you enter in the lower level - don't worry - these are not the windows you came to see....look for the signs on the side and follow the winding staircase up to the main attractions. Even though some are under restoration and we happened to visit on a rainy day they are just incredible. There is a video showing some of the restoration work that is interesting - it highlights the work on the rose window. I'd love to come back on a sunny day when the restoration is done. They also offer concerts in the space for a reasonable price.

Glorious!. It is difficult to describe the absolute beauty of this wonderful building. The stained glass windows rise in majestic splendour and an array of vibrant, almost luminous, colours within lacy stone surrounds. The whole glory of Saint Chapelle will only be revealed when the extensive and long winded repairs to the windows have been completed - and that will add further to the uplifting experience of seeing such beauty.We attended a sunset concert at Saint Chapelle and whilst the concert was rather ordinary, to be able to watch the changing shades of the windows as the sun set was delightful.This is one of the most beautiful places in one of the world's most beautiful cities.

A jewel on the Ile de la Cite. This is not to be missed.... the most beautiful stained glass windows anywhere. This was built by Louis IX to house the relics of the Passion of Christ. The chapel is incredible and the stained glass windows leave you in awe. A must.....

All about the windows. The reason to visit is to see the windows. It was originally part of the royal apartments. There is a project to restore the windows, so three were missing, but still many left. They are restoring because of accumulated dirt/filth on the windows, so easy to see the difference of what has been restored and not.

Concert music at Sainte Chapelle. We bought online tickets to hear Vivaldi's Four Seasons at Saint Chapelle. The concert began as the sun was descending, so the stained glass windows that framed the musician was beautiful and constantly changing. A wonderful experience, and the tickets were reasonable.

Amazing windows. Be careful - the stained glass windows you see here will ruin all the others you see in Paris. Notre Dame underwhelmed us after seeing Sainte-Chapelle. This is a beautiful little church incomprehensibly encircled by a modern building.Sadly there is a lot of renovation needed here, and the one side of the chapel is completely covered up - it must be quite the sight when all the windows are visible. Make sure you visit in the afternoon if you're in Paris before it's finished, as the sun is behind the windows then and lights them up.
Beautiful church, a "must see" in Paris.. You have to go inside to see wonderfull stained-glass work on the second floor of the church. There is a little queue but it's worth to wait.

Hidden gem. We only discovered this little gem after a discussion with our taxi driver when we arrived in Paris. It's is amazing and despite there being some renovation at the moment we loved it. Definitely worth a visit.

Under renovation. I can't say I would highly recommend going out of your way to see this chapel. It was under renovation, which may have taken away from our experience, but it just wasn't a favorite part of our trip. Would spend more time at Notre Dame if you have the choice.
A disappointment. Too expensive for the long wait and rather little to see. Very disappointed to see them hawking souvenirs inside the Chapel. A turn off.

Wonderful Architecture. This was an amazing structure! They have kept it up very well! You can see the coloring on the walls and ceilings which really brings it to life. The stained glass is so beautiful! Truly a beautiful experience!

Vivaldi's Four Seasons.. Listening to great musicians in this magical setting playing wonderful music should have been sublime. Instead, it was sub-par due to a very high pitched loud whistle from an audio system. The performers heard it, but simply plowed ahead, rather than delaying to fix it. Thus, for at least the performance on 28-Sep-13, what I got for my 40Eur was a headache in a beautiful setting. Color me disappointed and a bit angry about the time over quality ethos of the production.

Hidden gem.. We had read about Sainte-Chapelle before arriving in Paris and were determined to visit. Luckily we got there early and it was not at all busy. Stunning to see although there are renovations being completed at the moment. Really worth visiting and not like your normal cathedral or church.
Beautiful Small Chapel. The bright colors adorning the pillars and beautiful stained glass windows were captivating. We were charmed.
Wow!. this was my 6th visit to Paris and I had never been to Ste-Chapelle.. it has to be Paris' best kept secret..if you like stained glass, don't miss it! it's a short walk from Notre-Dame

Stunning. A must in Paris, fewer people than Notre dame, but the Vitreaux collection is amazing. You are amaze by how the built this in the 13th Century !! But anyway dont miss it, even if the are restoring the left side of the windows, still an amazing place to go, not that crowded, and a beautiful representation of the King's power. A masterpiece not to be missed. The 8,50 E entrance is totally worth it.
Amazing. It is so beautiful and has so much history amazing but it was still under construction next to the congress.
You MUST see these windows!. This tiny gem is the most amazing example of stained glass work I've ever seen- worth the line and the climb.

Spectacular. We saw this while listening to Vivaldi's Four Seasons played by a five piece string group. The combination of the music and the incredible stained glass windows was truly awesome. A great way to experience Sainte Chapelle.

Stunning stained glass. If you've made it to Notre Dame, make the extra effort to go to Sainte-Chapelle. You have to pay a bit to go in (though it's included if you have a museum pass).The stained glass "walls" essentially, are amazing. Reading the literature about how they clean, repair and maintain them is out of this world. So time consuming and intricate.All the panes - as well as the Rose Window - tell an ornate story.Unfortunately when we were there some of the panes were in the process of being restored so the chapel was resplendent in what I can only imagine would be its full, sumptuous glory, but what an amazing thing to behold nonetheless.Where the interior of Notre Dame leaves you wanting, the Sainte-Chapelle does not.

Stained glass galore!. I agree that this church was indeed a little gem. How I didn't go to it after five visits to Paris is a mystery to me! Yes, it is tucked in the Department of Justice and you do have to go through security because of this but all that is worth the visit and the €8.5 admission fee. It amazes me that they built something like this in the 13th century. The stained glass (especially on a sunny day and the sun shines through) is simply beautiful. Even more amazing than the Notre Dame where it is even more crowded and dark inside. Yes, they are doing a bit of restoration on the left side and sure, that doesn't give you the "full" experience but they plan to complete it next year in time for the 800th anniversary. Can you imagine cleaning up every single piece of glass?! Still worth the visit :)

Saw a Concert Here. Gorgeous environment with intriguing history with a spirituality. Painted wood extends the designs beyond the stained glass windows. Downside: trinkets for sale with in the chapel entry.
a gem which i enjoyed even more than Notre Dame. the best stained glass windows in the world.beautiful atmosphere and relatively thinner crowds than notre dame.

Small, stunning and a wee bit over-priced. Don't get me wrong, It is truely stunning, a work of art, and ah-mazing. BUT I cant help feeling a little ripped off by paying €8.50 when you can only see half the church, and it is not a big church... I think it would make sense to lower the price a little while the rennovations were going on. The half of the curch that you could see was beautiful and magical and I would definitely reccomend its worth a visit.

Sainte-Chapelle. Waited in line probably an hour on a rainy day against my wishes.But.....worth every second. The stained glass inside is out of this world. A must see.Don't forget to look at the outside of the church as well.

They were renovating a part of it, but breathtaking nevertheless!. Everybody talks about the splendor of the stained glass inside Sainte Chapelle and, indeed, it is breathtaking. We were so lucky that there were just 2 persons standing in line in front of us, so we entered immediately. I had the Museum Pass and my husband had his press card, so we both entered free of charge. The chapel is not very big, at least not as big as Notre Dame, but it is impressive nevertheless. Next to it there is the Palace of Justice, but we decided to give the latter a miss.

A "hidden" gem. Hidden, in that it doesn't appear to be one of the "big name" attractions" in Paris. Not as crowded as some of the others, very view stairs to climb, and amazing stained glass. Well worth the time to see it and the couple of Euros that it costs for admission.
Stunning. It is a true masterpiece. Renovation work going on, but still definitely on the must do list. We missed it on our first trip, but so glad we got to see it on this trip.

If you love stained glass this is a MUST see!!!!. This is the most amazing place to experience stained glass!!! It's on the museum pass so you can bypass the line waiting to pay to get in. You enter in the bottom and think, is this all there is? Then you go upstairs and are surrounded by an entire room of tall floor to ceiling stained glass. Be sure to pick up one of the helpful guides that explain each window...they are in many languages which make them even more helpful! If it is a sunny day your smart phone pictures will come out beautifully. Enjoy!!!

Beautiful Stained-Glass. There's something weird about getting to the Sainte-Chapelle. I think it's in the Palais de Justice, which is closed at weekends and securely patrolled on a Monday morning. They were repairing the fabric of the building, when I went; that was December, 2012, so the work may be complete by now. The beauty of the Chapelle lies in two things: its seemingly impossible, soaring architecture and the astounding stained-glass windows. The architecture is easy: the architects, who hadn't a clue about scientific architecure, just happened to get the details right, but the glass is another matter. It is utterly glorious: similar to what one can see in Notre Dame, but the visitor to Sainte Chapelle can appreciate the colours, the message and the detail far better. British stained glass of this era perished, I think, in the English and Scottish Reformations (if not then, in the Civil Wars of the 1640s). If I go back to Sainte Chapelle, I'll take a small pair of binoculars, to view the higher panes. There are good guides available.

Hidden from View... GO!. I had missed Saint Chappelle on previous Paris visits. Now is will be on my not-to-be-missed list.A two level church with mind blowing stained glass and a great story behind it as well.Don't be put off by the security line outside. Once inside you can also enter the Palace of Justice and roam around to see the French court system and grand halls worthy of many photos.
A must to see in Paris. The stain glassed windows are incredible.Try to go on a sunny day for the best effect. There are also lovely concerts many nights.

Unquestionable landmark. A must see for the tourist coming to Paris, a place anyone would come back to for a dose of beauty. A bit too crowded in summer and losing some of the serenity it deserves, it will for sure become one of your favorite memories of Paris. Better choice than Notre Dame de Paris, for sure.

Beautiful stained glass and strings. I had been told the best way to spend time inside Sainte Chapelle was to enjoy a concert and chamber music inside the Holy Chapel. I was there on Thursday, Sept 12 and Paul Rougon and Solistes Francais were magical with Vivaldi's 4 Seasons. I took a mid-range price seat (24 euros I think) and it is not reserved seating, bought at a booth in the restaurant across the street. My seat was good, but could have been better if I had been there 20 minutes or so sooner. No matter, I was there to listen, and close my eyes and feel the music. Magical. I bought DVD after the performance. Would definitely recommend. Stayed after most people left to walk up and closer look at wood details. Some of the stained glass windows are under renovation, but did not impede magificent feeling.
Disappointed. Part of the Chapelle was being renovated and it was dark inside and hard to appreciate the wonderful windows. Not worth the cost to enter.
ok. Because of the refurbishing going on, I found the Sainte Chapelle a bit underwhelming, but still enjoyed the stained glass windows and architecture

Jewelry box of Paris. Inside is like being in a jewellery box. They are in the process of cleaning the stained glass windows, and you can see a vast difference where windows were already cleaned. I also attended a music concert in the Sainte - Chapelle, a really special experience.

Spectacular!. Not much walking required in here, but your neck could get tired from looking up! The height and detail of all the stained glass that surround you is jaw dropping. The 15 large windows are filled with individual scenes from the Bible, starting with Adam and Eve. Over 1300 scenes. I went in the morning around 0900 and the wait in line was pretty short. Be prepared to go through security .No sharp objects are allowed inside

Let there be light!. Breathtakingly beautiful stained glass windows. One of, if not my favorite, spot we visited while in Paris. While still partially under construction until 2014, this is a must see. The stained glass windows simply took my breath away. If possible, try to go when it's sunny!
Spectacular glass. A treat of a church well worth an hours visit. The glass is truly marvelous. Under renovation until 2014 but still a great place
Verdi concert. I was fortunate to go to a Verdi concert inside saint chappelle which was outstanding, the surrounding's were wonderful and the music was just magnificent!

Beautiful Stained Glass...but not much else. Since my sister and I had the museum pass, we decided to go to Saint-Chapelle church. We enjoyed the beautiful stained glass windows which is worth visiting itself. However, I do think there are prettier churches in Paris.

Beautiful. We weren't going to see this attraction, but we went with our brother And sister in law and they had been before.,it is a bit pricey around 11 euros just to see it.... However when we went to the upper chapel, the Kings chapel we saw more stained glass than we have ever seen before and each window tells a story. I loved that they were biblical stories, set in The 12 and 1300's. knights jousting, the king sitting with a courtier etc.

Small and Breathtaking!. Very small little church but oh so worth the visit. The stained glass is amazing...go on a sunny day to get the most out of it. The steps down are not easy to navigate for Seniors. Be patient if you are behind one. The steps are narrow, steep and circular. There is a handrail though...just go with patience.

Unique stained glass windows. Unfortunately, I had to use my vivid imagination to recreate a considerable part of the cycle of biblical stories depicted on the astonishing stained glass windows of the Holy Chapel due to present restoration works. Apart from this inconvenience, the Holy Chapel is to be visited. It was located in the courtyard of the then medieval Royal Palace (today, an administrative area) and built to house some precious relics of Christ. Nowadays this building remains one of the most striking example of Gothic architecture. In the lower Chapel the statue of Louis IX, in addition to the immense rose window and the walls dominated by blue, red and gold colours, can be admired. The second floor is brighter and all architecturally projected towards the sky in a metaphorical attempt to reach God. The rooms are quite small and the presence of many people can make your visit less enjoyable.

Great area. We were so luck there was a concert going on so there were food and music. We climb the stairs to the top...(Warning if you are claustrophobic or not in good shape do not attempt, my husband and I are in good shape and had a hard time, but once you get up there is no words, well worth it. cost 9 euros each
On a Concert ... Vivaldi Four Seasons. A must !!! Excellent place and a beautiful string quartet played a very beautiful concert. You should be there to enjoy a beautiful place & concert.
Beautiful area, well worth the walk.. Just strolling this entire area and taking in the Beauty that is Paris is a life moment. BEAUTIFUL pictures at this monument.

Don't Miss. Don't miss this--somewhat difficult to find--museum/church. It has the most wonderful stained glass windows. They will take your breath away. Get the museum pass which will allow you to avoid the ticket lines.

Just brilliant. What a great place to have a concert. We listened to Vivaldi's Four Seasons - pure bliss...what a great environment...amazing stained glass telling the detailing the Bible both the Old & New Testament...sunset through the glass is a unique experience.

Awe Inspiring... Breathtaking.... After about a 30 minute wait, we got inside. The main floor was interesting and reading about the church and the cleaning of the glass was educational. But, climbing to the second floor and seeing the floor to ceiling stained glass was truly inspiring. It was a wonderfully sunny day and the glass just shone perfectly. It was as near to a religious experience as I have had in a long time. Words and pictures don't do it justice. Well worth seeing.
Small Chapel for stain glass. there is some construction in the chapel now, so you really can't see the stained glass on that side of it.

Stunning. Stunning does not give this place justice. Admittedly, 12.5 euros is a little steep for combined La Conciergerie and Sainte-Chapelle, but well worth the visit if you go with an open mind and plenty of imagination. Don't expect furnished rooms or art on the wall as the spaces are large vast and pretty empty, except for all the visitors. Go early in the morning to avoid the queues.

Five windows out for reconstruction; long lines. Sainte Chappell is one really tall hall flooded by sunlight filtered through acres of soaring stained glass. There's nothing else like it in the world. Spectacular, yes -- but the long-term reconstruction of windows along one wall rather substantially reduces the effect of the glass, which is the only real reason for visiting. The lines -- first for security, then for tickets -- are long and slow.

Be sure to go upstairs. We almost missed all the beautiful windows on the second floor - which is the main exhibit. There was some written commentary about the windows. I would have preferred an audio or guided tour about the history and placement of the windows. I found out after the fact that the windows were removed and hidden all over Paris during the war.

Amazing experience. My kids - teens - were enthralled by the approachability of this church, and felt the magical vibe of centuries of travellers before them. This attraction is a quick visit if the line is short, and was well worth it. Climbing the well-worn steps can be a task for the less nimble, but wholly worth it. There is a feeling of solitude in the chamber of the church, and we felt something more cohesive about this than we felt at the grand churches. The building exudes a combination of intimacy and gravitas. We had a lovely afternoon respite here after visiting Notre Dame, and I highly recommend it.
Stained glass extraordinaire. Incredible number of stories of the Bible depicted in huge windows surrounding all 4 sides of this old cathedral.

Jewelry box indeed. The renovated upper chapel at Sainte-Chapelle is such a surprising treat! You don't expect much as you enter the lower level of the church, and then as you climb up a spiral staircase you are ambushed by this colorful, majestic enclave!

A quick visit. We visited the Sainte-Chapelle and were a litte disappointed. Part of the windows in the upper church were under repair and it was difficult to see the relic by the altar. It is a nice place to visit, but a little overhyped and for the short time spent there, I would suggest going to see other sites.
Beautiful concert and breathtaking windows. Attended a wonderful chamber music concert while looking at the most beautiful stained glass windows.
Beautiful Windows. This is one of the most beautiful buildings I've ever been in. However, part of the struture is closed off for repairs. Would like to have known that in advance,

It was worth it. Free admission during the heritage weekend (Journee europeanne de patrimoine). The stained glasses were incredible, they tell biblical stories. Make sure to go on a sunny day to really apreciate its beauty.

hefty admission but stunning on a sunny day. I have visited here several times before so didn't get the audio guide which I believe is very good. The late summer sun was at a perfect angle to illuminate the beautiful glass in the upper chapel and there were not too many people there. I found the audiovisual display in one corner very distracting and could have done without it, but most of the other visitors made a bee-lilne directly to it so I am obviously in the minority. It is the glass most visitors come to see but the gilded statues are interesting and the carvings on the upper door are stunning and really well preserved. Tthere was restoration work ongoing which meant several of the windows were boarded up and there was constant background noise - the price for preserving such a beautiful place and ensuring we can still be visiting in twenty years! The shop downstairs is quite good and has some nice things strangely cheaper than other sites!

A jewel of Paris. Sainte Chapelle is a jewel of Paris. It is on the Ile de la Cite at 4 boulevard du Palais. We visited this gem during an early evening concert of Vivaldi and Pachelbel. With the flowing light of the stained glass windows and the charming music, we were transported to an enchanted world beyond the hustle and bustle of the early 21st century. It is best to combine a visit with an early evening concert to enjoy both beauties of visual and aural art. The concert is only about 10 euros more than the general admission. Do not pass up this 13th century wonder of Paris.

Beautiful venue for Vivaldi. I went to a concert held here and it was excellent. Make sure you visit the chapel during the day to see the beautiful stained glass, as in the evenings you cannot appreciate the full beauty of this beautiful historic building.
Stained glass. Astounding stained glass windows. They are in a 5 year process of repairing them and the amount of work and skill involved is huge.

stained glass bible classics. If you love stained glass & all the Bible stories depicted in the stain glass, then it truly isnmust see
If not enthralled with stained glass wall to wall then skip it
short lines
not crowded because it is small & folks don't spend much time in there

Beautiful but not worth $17 euro entrance fee per person.. Not worth $17 euro entrance fee per person. As we had limited time in Paris we decided to see Sainte- Chapelle after our visit to Notre Dame and was annoyed with the entrance fee that we thought was expensive and would have chosen to go elsewhere.

Sainte-Chapelle located in The Conciergerie. I love this small, Gothic-style chapel located beside the Conciergerie, a short walk from Notre Dame Cathedral, for its beautiful stained glass windows, well-known for the fact that there is little space between the frames that hold the panes of stained glass, thus creating the effect that you are enclosed in stained-glass majesty. So, I was disappointed this visit to see that only half of the windows is visible because restoration and cleaning is currently underway on the left side as you face the altar. The side that is open to viewing appears to be clean and in good shape. I was just disappointed that I couldn't see the entire stained glass display, since the cleaning is enclosed in a wooden box-like structure that obstructs the view of those windows from the public. If this is your only chance to see Sainte-Chappelle, then consider your options. The bookstore inside Sainte-Chappelle does offer many materials that contain color photos of the complete interior, so this can amplify your actual visit during the cleaning process.

Most exquisite stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle is undergoing renovations so you will need to walk around quite a bit of construction on the outside to get to the inside. Parts of the interior will be covered also, but what is not covered is glorious. The stained glass is exquisite.

A glimpse of heaven. This was somewhere I had wanted to visit for a long time and it did not disappoint. Do try to go early in the day as it is popular and the chapel is small; more people means less opportunity to stand and soak in the glories of the stained glass. The audio guide is excellent. Be prepared to get a stiff neck looking up at the glass; binoculars or opera glasses are useful!

Beautiful stain glass windows. Located next to France's Supreme Court , one has to go trough metal detector and security before being able to enter the church . It was built in the 1200s, for King Louis lX, the only king who became a saint. It is said to have once held the crown of thorns that Jesus wore when crucified.After entering the modest sanctuary, turn left and climb up the spiral staircase to then Chappelle Haute, to see the amazing stain glass with 1100 different scenes. It is just beautiful and bright!

Awesome. The stain glass panels in the magnificent chapel are spectacular. In the busy heart of Paris, one will find peace and tranquility amongst the beautiful hues. One does not need a long time to visit but it is essential to visit the second floor to appreciate the wonderful art of an earlier period.

Spectacular!. The radiating beautiful stained glass is spectacular. Only wish we got to see the true wonder of it all since half the windows are under construction. Be sure to pick up an informational brochure near the exit, not the entrance. Worth a visit using the Museum Pass.

Gorgeous. Seriously? From inside the main hall, the stain glass windows are unreal. Currently (Sept 13') under renovation, they have cleaned the first half and are cleaning the second. At 7pm, the sun was shining through in multicolored art. The line was a bit much, but we saw a Vivaldi Four Seasons concert.

Interesting Chapel. This chapel is very interesting and has a place in history that is fascinating. World renowned for its beautiful stained glass windows Sainte-Chapelle is small and easy to do in a short period of time. The first view of the windows is breathtaking and in its self, worth a visit.

Worth the effort. You don't need to spend a lot of time at Sainte-Chapelle, but the stained glass windows of the upper church are often overlooked amongst all the other great things in Paris, and this is unfortunate.

Best way to see this. You can visit Sainte-Chapelle during the day and it is a wonderful its. Some of the most wonderful stained glass (and if you want to see where some of the originals went when they were renovated, go to the another of my favorite places in Paris, the Cluny (Musée national du Moyen Âge). But to really appreciate this wonderful little chapel go to an evening concert there. And the big not-so-secret is that you should choose a concert that begins before sundown. To be able to sit inside, with the ending light of the day coming through the windows, while you experience wonderful chamber or similar music, is about as good as it gets. And you get to experience Sainte-Chapelle as it must have been when used as the King's chapel -- not with a bunch of people walking around but with all the people sitting down and contemplating. And, since Paris has wonderful late night dining, after the concert you can go enjoy the wonderful food.

Amazing. We visited Sainte Chapelle a few years ago. Beautiful stained glass windows which narrates stories from the Bible. Expect to take lots of photos!! Not far from Notre Dame and right next to the Conciegerie. The lines to get in isn't usually too bad. Included in the museum pass which is great value for first time visitors to Paris.
Kaleidoscopic!. We liked the fact that there were 2 distinctly lovely levels and that there is SO MUCH square footage of stained glass brilliance!!!!
Check out the concerts!. If you have the opportunity, seeing Sainte-Chapelle after hours and listening to a concert of classical music (or opera) is a wonderful way to end your day.

Breathtaking stained glass!. Visited Sainte Chapelle after visiting Notre Dame, and was equally blown away by its beauty! It is a much smaller cathedral but has the most gorgeous ceiling on the first level where you enter, and then when you go to the second level you will be awestruck by the tall stained glass windows all around. Do not miss it!

Skip notre dame in favour of this. Heavenly. If you like stained glass windows you'll be stoked here. Make sure to visit when there is good external sunlight. The museum pass will not allow you to bypass the security line. It's only little but it's beautiful and completely different to other churches. Like there are many churches that don't feel that different to notre dame but this one is utterly individual.One of my top 3 things in Paris after a week here: along with musee d'orsay and les jardins du Luxembourg.

Incredibly Beautiful. This is the first place that we visited when we arrived in Paris. I cannot put into words just how gorgeous this church is. The stained glass is amazing. Make sure that you climb the small spiral staircase to the second floor. GORGEOUS!

Stunning glass windows. The stained glass in the church is amazing!!! It's a short visit because the church is not big. But you'll definitely want to spend some time admiring the stunning windows. I'd highly recommend it!!!
Glorious. Skip Notre Dame in favour of Sainte-Chapelle. Wondrous, magnificent, astonishing. Sunny mid-mornings are best, to see the stained glass in all its glory.

The worst experience ever. I planned to visit this place during my summer vacation in Europe and here is what happened.On June 29th around 1:00PM I was at the entrance of Sainte-Chapelle at the security check in point of the luggage and I have filled the boxes with my personal items – phone, backpack, DSLR camera and my wallet. This should be available to check on security cameras too.After passing through the security check, due the negligence of the security stuff, the box containing my personal items fell on the floor resulting in serious damage to my DSLR camera – body and lenses.The security stuff advised me to send a letter as soon as possible in the attention of Monsieur le Secrétaire General de la Cour d'appel de Paris, having the equipment invoices attached, with the assurance that I will be compensated for the damages.The camera model is Nikon D7000 with the lenses Nikon 18-105mm f/3.5-5.6G AFs VR DX. After the incident I checked with the security stuff the equipments and concluded the damages.I asked if it was necessary to give them the equipments as a proof, but they advised me that sending the letter with the printed invoices would be enough.I attached to the letter my personal details, address and contact information.Nothing happened since then, not a single phone call.So, this is how the things are working in France, especially near the Cour d'appel de Paris - where Sainte-Chapelle is located (what an irony ...)

Stunning small stained glass cathedral. Church contains the crown of Christ, available for viewing once a month. Various classical musicians perform private concerts at dusk, a beautiful way to appreciate the church. Tickets available on line at digitick.com.

Pretty stained glass. The stained glass in this church is so beautiful! It just shines and the colors are brilliant, just fabulous to look at. They are located on the second floor and there are about 30 steps to trek up but it is not too hard of a climb. The stained glass depict the stories of the Bible and because it was done in glass it was a real accomplishment for that time period and a "first" for a church to have "walls of glass"... It was a modern wonder for that era.

Don't miss the evening concert!. We went one evening to the quartet string concert...absolutely beautiful in an intimate chapel setting...as the sun was setting and the stained glass went from colorful to dark. Went back the next day to see the stained glass in full sunlight. Had a wonderful free tour by a guide who was very knowledgable ...her second tour in English and she was great. Pretty gift shop too.

Amazing stained glass. The stained glass in this church is spectacular!! The line can get rather long but we arrived in the morning before it opened and were near the front of the line. It's not a huge place so your visit can be rather short, then walk over to Notre Dame which is very close.

Exquisite Church. This church is so beautiful, the glass windows are really stunning. It was very crowded when I went though, which was in the evening, which is rather odd given most crowds have thinned out by then, so I suggest making sure you look up the best times to go. I'd highly recommend it though, but if you only have time for one cathedral in Paris, make it Notre Dame.

Beautiful Stained Glass. Gorgeous stained glass - marred for us this summer by renovations that blocked half of the windows, and prevented sunlight from spilling into the church. Because of this, we did not have the jaw-dropping experience others have had in the past. It was also very crowded. Will have to try again on another trip to Paris.

The most beautiful stained glass in Paris. This was our first visit to Sainte-Chapelle. We had wanted to go on previous trips but the queues were so long. This time, the queue was minimal and so we went for it and discovered that it is worth even a lengthy queue. I would recommend getting the audio guide since it is very informative. The only thing we were missing was a small pair of binoculars - I would strongly recommend bringing some so that you can see the detail of the stories told in the most beautiful stained glass in Paris.

A Gem in Paris!. The small area of this "upstairs" chapel created lots of beautiful colors coming from the walls that are practically filled from top to bottom with stained glass. You must climb a very narrow stone circular stairway to experience this unusual sight. We tagged onto an English-speaking tour guide and heard a lot about the bible stories that are represented in all of that glass.This is a piece of Paris that should not be overlooked!
Stunning chapel. what a wonderful chapel to see the magnificent windows and then to hear a concert is just hard to describe.
Beautiful stained glass. Tiny church with beautiful stained glass...even on an overcast day. You need to walk up a narrow spiral stairway to experience the beauty.

Incredible stained glass windows. Even dough the place (building) is impressive by itself, it is the stained glass windows that make this church unique.
The best time to visit is during summer in a sunny day when the spectacle of windows truly show their magnificence.

Glorious experience. Visiting this historic site many years ago is more of a memory of a distant magical moment. I remember to this day the wonderous feeling of coming into this small round chapel and being surrounded by intense bright and radiant color. This memory has never left me since the time I was priviledged to see a bit of Heaven.

Awe inspiring!. Always a line, but the wait is worth it. Be prepared for airport-like security as the chapel sits with the supreme court. Once inside the courtyard, signs will direct you to the chapel entrance where you can purchase tickets. Even with a long entrance line, there were few people inside the chapel making it an enjoyable experience. You will need to climb stairs to enter the main hall with the stained glass. Half of the window are currently undergoing renovation/preservation, but the remaining half are breathtaking. The first sight after entering the main hall is amazing! Be sure to pick up a placard near the opposite side of the room (near the exit) that explains what each window is about.

This Church is awe-inspiring. Can't help but say "wow". So this church was built by Louis the 14, just to house the crown of thorns "relic" he bought for more than the cost of the building. (the relic is still displayed periodically, but not at this church. you have to go to Notre Dame to see it...) The 1st story has a very ornate, low, vaulted ceiling, and it's got some things to see, and a gift shop. Once you go upstairs, though, you come out of a spiral staircase, and are struck with the huge stained glass walls, starting at about 8 feet up, and continuing to at least 30 feet from there. Most impressive. This space is worth the trip to Paris by itself!The entry is covered by the Paris Museum Pass (highly recommended).

Deceiving At First. Upon entering, you see a nice but simple area. This is where the servants would worship. Once you go up the stairs, you see the full splendor of St Chapelle...it's simply breathtaking...beautiful stained glass windows.

Glorious light. This Gothic chapel has glorious stain glass windows that are best appreciated right after the site opens and on a sunny day. The 15 stained glass windows are the oldest in Paris with two-thirds of them dating from the 13th century. Going early we had 30 minutes to appreciate the windows in the upper chapel before it became crowded with visitors. Only after waiting on line to pass through security can people use the Museum Pass to avoid the line to purchase a ticket.

A real jewel box. Prepare yourself to be blown away by Saint Chapelle! If there is line to get in, do not be discouraged! The two sections, upper and lower, are both astonishing! If I were given only 3 places to go into in Paris..this will be one of them.

My Favorite Church in the Whole World!. This little Church has more stained glass in one place than I've ever seen before. The walls are totally glass and enable you to visually 'read' the Bible from beginning to end. If you only have time to visit one Church in Paris go to this one.

Renovating. The Sainte-Chapelle is under renovation but we went there for a concert. They have concerts all the time, and the tickets are available for purchase at the door. It's a perfect place for a concert because it's so small and the acoustic is perfect. The left walls of the chapel were covered for the renovation but it's still definitely worthy it a visit.
Breathtaking. The museum pass will save you time at the entrance. We tried for a sunny day, but it was cloudy when we arrived The stain glass amazing, and when the sun came out well worth seeing.

VerY busy a bit seedy. Very busy and very hectic.
Bit of a seedy atmosphere around there. I wouldn't rush back A few pick pockets there

long wait. We waited in line for over an hour and didn't really think it was worth it. Very very small and yes the stained glass was beautiful but with the amount of people in such a cramped space it was hard to really take it in.

Stunning jewel of Paris. If I could pick only one place in Paris to visit again, it would be this stunningly beautiful chapel. Located right near a Metro stop, this chapel is filled with panel after panel of floor to ceiling stained glass. It is absolutely breath-taking!
