Generally, although it has it's challenges, Paris will draw you back time and time again even if the tourism and site authorities need to get their collective acts together.

exquisite stain glass windows. Eveyone needs to experience the spiral staircases and view the amazingly tall stain glass windows. Despite being under renovation, I found the upper room well worth the walk to visit. It is breath taking to see in person.

Yes, it is worth it!. The wait to get into the Sainte-Chapelle is worth every minute to see the phenomenal stained-glass windows and intricate friezes! Although under restoration during our visit, the rest of the visible windows were remarkable. Avoid Blue Shuttle at all costs, they abandoned my family and I at the airport and refused to refund my prepaid fare. Air France caused us an 8 hour delay and lost our luggage for 6 days, ensure you pack necessities in your carry-on!

Beautiful for its Stained Glass. This is a small High Gothic church built in the mid 1200s to house King Louis IX's relics, including (allegedly) the Crown of Thorns. The price King Louis paid for the Crown of Thorns greatly exceeded the cost of the church itself. This relic is now in the Notre Dame museum and presented to believers for veneration on the first Friday of each month. As other reviewers have noted, a good part of the church is currently being renovated but it was still a worthwhile visit especially if you appreciate Gothic architecture and awesome stained glass windows. The gift shop was better than most; I bought several lovely medieval style tapestry pillow covers there.
The best stained glass windows anywhere. The stained glass windows are the reason to see this. Use a museum pass to avoid long lines. Rick Steves' free audio guide was perfect.
Wao. Small and hidden away but worth the detour. The first floor stained glass window are the most extraordinary sight. The artistic and craftsmen skills are amazing.

Extraordinarily beautiful on summer evenings with concert. We attended a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons in in the cathedral on Tuesday and it was a magnificent experience. An exalting experience to be in this exquisitely space, with the stained glass columns all around glowing in the setting sunlight, a virtuoso violin performance, and incredibly good acoustics.

To Expensive and pourly worth the Money. If you visit Paris, do not bother to go to Saint-Chapelle - other churches are worth,, but not this! 8,50€ for the entry and only some windwos to look at. Realy disapointing and not worth the money!

Breathtaking. Take the Metro to Cite Station and you're basically there.We didnt have a museum pass and we waited about 20 minutes total to get in. This was at 10 am on a Monday.It's small, but the windows are awe-inspiring. When you consider when it was built, it's amazing.It's only 8.50 Euro per person and under 18 is free. If you combine it with a ticket to the Conciergerie, it's 12.50 Euro. There's a security check, so leave the scissors and sharp objects at home.Definitely take the time to see Saint-Chapelle.

Wow!!!. Sainte-Chapelle is such an engineering marvel. Built in the early 1200´s it is a glorious example of French gothic architecture. It is a small building, originally built to hold religious artifacts owned by the king, and is sumptuously adorned with painted walls and ceilings that complement the beautiful stained glass windows. If you come into the main sanctuary from the undercroft you are visually transported into the holy. I enjoyed watching the faces of others as they came into the upper room - almost everyone said WOW! and all had smiles. It is that kind of place. Please note too that there is a series of concerts at Ste. Chapelle (ticket purchase required) that might be of interest.

A must see after Norte Dame!. I say it's a must after Notre Dame, bc most people are hurrying to Notre Dame bc of its notoriety. Sainte-Chapelle is a gorgeous cathedral with stunning stained glass windows. It is so open and airy feeling after being in Notre Dame. A good investment is the museum pass. You can get into this cathedral on it, otherwise there is a fee to enter.

A hidden gem…catch it late in the day. Don’t be fooled by the exterior buildings near this church. It is hidden behind some more modern government buildings. Go late in the afternoon (we went at 5:00 pm) so the sun hits the west wall of stained glass. The upper church windows were amazing. Most people’s first reaction is to the lower church, but once you go upstairs (especially on a sunny afternoon) you’ll see what I’m taking about. Definitely worth a stop.
Breathtaking. Peaceful and wonderful!Not my first visit, and it amazed me again.It doesn't take too much time to visit it, and you can combine it with a longer visit to Notre Dame cathedral.

Find out if there are any Concerts and go - it is amazing!!!. Friends told us to check whether there were any planned concerts at Sainte-Chapelle and if possible to hear a concert in this beautiful chapel. We were lucky to hear Vivaldi's Four Seasons - it was wonderful and very intimate (less the 200 people). The chapel is beautiful with stained glass on four walls, The stained glass/windows are being restored (until 2014) so one wall was covered and the affect of light was not quite as dramatic.
Nice. I feel it's just a smaller and an extension of the Notre Dame Cathedral that features stained glass everywhere.

Amazing history...beautiful sight. This was a surprising sight for my visit to Paris as I didn't really know much about it. But the amazing stained glass windows and history of this shrine was well worth the visit. A lot of restoration underway at this time so it was a little distracting but not a problem. Quite interesting history from the beginning enshrinement of the relics from Passion of the Christ and through the French Revolution.

Possibly more beautiful than Notre Dame.. There, I said it, it's more beautiful than Notre Dame. The twelve 20' + stained glass windows that ring the chapel are so unique...I've not seen them in any other cathedral. The tile floors, the altar, outside balcony and Fleur d'lis ceiling add to the richness of the architecture. Again, a museum pass came in handy to skip the lines. It is a little difficult to find, but remember it is housed inside the Palais de Justice. The Concierge next door houses the prison of Marie Antoinette, which is an added attraction.

Sainte-Chapelle. Beautiful medieval church, with beautiful colors and designs. Had the Paris Museum Pass-did not have to stand in line can advance in the church to side of the line, once you pass security.
Best stained glass. This small church is not to be missed. It is absolutely the most amazing stained glass representation I have seen. Small, easily accessible, the best
Stained glass wonders. Stunning walls of stained glass. Have never seen so much in one place before. Not a lot of information given, but the beauty makes up for it. 30 minutes tops, in and out.

Gorgeous Windows. We stopped by Sainte-Chapelle one afternoon, the line was short and we walked right in. The windows are just stunning and we spent maybe 30 minutes just walking around. This is when the Paris Museum Pass really comes in handy. I'm not sure I would have spent the money for a half hour visit but since we had the pass it worked out great. Definitely worth a visit.

You will gasp when you see the windows. I have been here more than once, and I still gasp when I look at all of those amazing stained glass windows. On my last visit, there was a Vivaldi concert performed, and the venue was not only beautiful, but the acoustics were phenomenal. It is only steps from Notre Dame, which you surely will see as a tourist, so while you are in the vicinity make sure to stop at Sainte Chapelle (if only for 5 minutes) to experience its visual splendor.

My wife's favorite place in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is a chapel but there are two floors to it. The floor below is nice enough but the one you must go upstairs to see is incredible. To get upstairs you go up a narrow circular staircase and when you get to the top and see what's there, well, wow! We had been there a couple of times before so we knew what to expect. We started watching people when they got to the top of the stairs and how they reacted. Their mouths were often wide open and eyes wide open as well at all the colored stained glass. The glass extends all the way around the room. Not just stained glass here and there but all the way around a rather good sized room. The idea to build this special chapel was the idea of well known king Louis IX and it was all built in only three years in the 1200s. Amazing! However, right now part of it is under renovation so that about one third of it is blocked off to view. There often is wait to get inside. The Paris Museum pass gets you inside for free and you are often able to shorten your time in the line. It's also very close to Notre Dame with perhaps a five minute walk from the middle of the Ile de la Cite to the eastern end. The Conciergerie is also quite near. One bit of advice- go on a sunny day to really do justice to seeing the stained glass.
Great!. Good find a little off the main touristy stuff. See it if you have time but don't sweat it if you don't
A bit of heaven on earth. There's nothing quite like the small Sainte Chapelle to fill you with wonder and solace in the middle of busy Paris. Absolutely beautiful.

Totally Worth the Wait. If you like Gothic architecture then don't miss this little church in the middle of the Justice Complex. The first floor is so-so but go in the afternoon when the sun hits the stained glass and it is magical.

Small but illustrious. You can see this chapel in under 30 minutes, head straight for the 2nd floor to see the beautiful stained glass work. It's gorgeous. The line is very long and they close for lunch - from 12-2pm. Got there at 1pm and waited for one hour, still lots of people already ahead of me in the queue.
A small place, have to wait a lot in the line before entering. small place, not Highly recommended. But nice place to visit.There is a huge French court near it, which is beutiful and amazing!

Do not miss this!. This is a beautiful chapel near Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are huge and wrap entirely around the room. It is exquisite. Even my 14 year old twin sons were breath aken with the beauty.
There was a small line but this is worth waiting to see!

Astounding stained glass. This is a Medieval treasure, with entire walls made out of stained glass and a great example of architecture. But wait until it is restored. A large part of the windows are covered for restration, filthy dirty, and marred by temporary repairs.There are huge crowds.

Went to a concert. I had been to Sainte Chapelle two years ago and thought it was just sensational. This time we went to a concert starting at 7.00pm, so it was still very light outside which is essential if you are to see the stained glass properly. If you do nothing else in Paris, visit Sainte Chapelle

Beautiful little church!. This church has some of the most amazing stained glass windows I've ever seen. It is a very small church so it doesn't take too long to see everything. It was quite crowded on the day we went and we had to wait in line to get in but the line moved pretty quickly.
Wow!. You cannot fail but to be impressed - go on a sunny day and be prepared to be bowled over by the spectacular stained glass.

Just gorgeous. go early in the morning before it gets too crowded and be prepared to go "oooh - pretty!"you'll get more out of it if you do some research first - so it was built in the space of 5 years (1243-48) by Louis IX f France who later became a saint. it was built to hold the PAssion Relics - ie the Crown of Thorns and bits of the true cross. it's covered in Medieval propoganda about how great the Kings of France are and how the French should allow Louis to go on Crusade to fight the Infidel. There's so much more to tell, so look it up!

Magnificent. Well worth the wait to get to see these most amazing windows. Although two of the windows are blocked off as they are being cleaned, there is enough to see to appreciate how magnificent they are.

Kaleidoscope. This place is awesome, Since it was a sunny day it looked like a kaleidoscope inside with all the stained-glass. they are restoring some of the glass currently and it was still amazing. The ceiling at the main level was amazing. We use the Paris Museum pass to access this attraction.
Attended Ave Maria concert. Exquisite string quartet and soprano Concert Ave Maria at Saint -Chapellle , beautiful church and intimate concert

Would have been great, except for restoration work. This is a chapel with a ring of amazing stained glass. I can imagine without the restoration work, which took up over a quarter of the chapel, it would be spectacular. I understand they need to restore it. It just really ruins the effect to have so much of it covered up. Wish I had saved it (and my money) for a later visit when the work is done. Signs said it was supposed to be finished in 2013.

Book an evening concert and avoid the day time lines!. I went to the evening "sacred music" concert, which was beautiful. Tickets can be bought on the day, ranging from 25-40 euro. The ticket office is located across the street at a bistro ( go inside, they have a ticket booth), or else you can buy them online. Much better than waiting with the crowds during the day - I saw the line for museum pass holders and it looked like it would take at least 1-2 hours. Other churches in Paris also have concerts - look at www.classictic.com
Lovely stained glass. Love the stained glass in the second storey of the chapel that tells the story of the bible from Genesis. Coolios!
Musical highlight. Went to the "Vivaldi Concert" which was much more than that. Ave Maria by Shubert was very moving in that space. One of our most magical moments.

Historically fascinating. I have visited a few times, but this time booked concert tix to a sacred music evening. To sit in this beautiful place and enjoy the superb acoustics was a new way to experience it. Just wonderful!

Surrounded by stained glass. Everytime I visit Paris, I make time to visit Sainte-Chapelle. It is included as a monument on the Paris Museum Pass. It will help with the ticket line, but you still have to line up for the entrance. The gift shop on the first floor is full of goodies from tapestries to sealing wax. Upon ascending the spiral stairs, you emerge into an amazing splash of color. The huge stained glass windows tower over the floor below. Sit and take it all in.

A highlight of our Paris trip!. Beautiful with one of the most extensive stained glass collections in the world. Currently under renovation so be prepared for half the church to be covered up. But it is stunning and worth a visit!

Memory will stay with us forever. This is a small chapel. The lower part is nothing special, but the upper chapel is full of stained glass windows. It is an amazing sight to behold all at once. It takes your breath away when you walk in and although photographs are allowed. No photos can recreate the impression of the stained glass from every direction. Well worth the line and the 8.50 euros to enter. Also, be aware silence is mandatory throughout the church.

Magnificent. Well worth a visit. Lines were long as everywhere in Paris. My suggestion is to have the Paris Museum pass because you go straight in. The stained glass windows here are awe inspiring but don't just look up. Take a moment to look at the floors as well. They are beautiful too. Sainte-Chapelle has two floors, lower and upper. The lower floor is beautiful but does not hold a candle to what awaits you on the upper level. As you ascend the stairs you are confronted with the most magnificent stain glass windows and your jaw can do nothing else but drop. Even though it can be crowded take the time to soak it all in. The circular window tells a story of it's own. Make sure you get the audio guide. It is not expensive and will give you a good explanation of everything around you.

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Since you must go through the Palace of Justice to enter this cathedral you need to go through security first. It is well worth the wait and the price of the ticket. Upon entering the cathedral you need to go upstairs to view the amazing stained glass. The glass is breathtaking as you are surrounded by stained glass pictures of all the bible stories. There are cards in English and French that describe each window. Try to visit on a sunny day as that is what helps to illuminate all the windows. We only waited about 15 minutes to enter the church, but that was probably because there had been a thunder storm earlier. Luckily the sun came out just as we entered the church.

Wow!! must visit here. wow!! was not expecting such a beautiful building totally awe struck by the stained glass size and beauty, got one of those ear guides you can buy for 4 euros was good bet as it explained whats what in all the stained glass panels very helpful

Church Needs attention. I stood in line for over 1 hour and then parted with €8.50. There was only one lady selling tickets and then a guy who took the tickets and 2 others just standing around, not very efficient. Yes the windows are beautiful and impreessive but the rest of the Church is in an appalling state. They really need to start restoring the columns, walls etc inside the Church. You can see just as beautiful if not more beautiful stained glass windows in other areas of France. I was very disappointed with this visit.

Stunning. At first this chapel is hard to find because it's surrounded by other buildings, but it's right by the court and Congiergerie. There's usually a 40 minute line to get in, but it's worth seeing. The lower part is extremely beautiful, but it's nothing compared to the top part of the chapel. Stained glass windows take up most of the walls - it's breathtaking. Unfortunately they are under renovation until around 2015 so some of the windows were covered. We spent about 30 minutes there, not including the line.

The most intense display of stained glass you will ever see.. If you took time to study each window, you would surely develop a stiff neck from looking up. The stained glass art here has to be seen. No amount of good photography can duplicate the experience of being surrounded by the colors of the stained glass.
Do it. Lovely place, loved the glass. They are doing some restoration work, but it is in fairly good nick. The ceiling is spectacular as well. A real surprise, spent more time then we expected here.

Beautiful sight to behold. Costs 8.50 euro to enter, which is pricey, but it is great to see that restoration work is taking place. The large stained glass windows, of which one fifth is currently covered, are fabulous and depict books of the Bible. The info card near the entrance sheds a little more light on the windows, or this attraction risks becoming no more than another photo fest for tourists who like to have Paris bragging rights. For another 4 euro (purchase of a combined ticket), the conciergerie is also very interesting and kept my husband enthralled when I chose to continue gazing at the beauty of the large coloured glass panels in Sainte-Chapelle. Lined up for around 30 minutes, first past security check, then the ticket purchase queue. You first see a shop in a small chapel, so go up the spiral staircase directly to your left to experience the craftsmanship and beauty of the stained glass windows.
If you´ve got nothing better to do !. Part of the former roayl palace , with magnificent painted windows, now being restored to former splendor- and that´s it !

Impossible to understand from the outside what lies within.... This has to be one of the most impressive displays of stained glass in the world. You go in the ground-floor level and admire a beautiful sanctuary, then go up a spiral stair-way to see unbelievable 4-story windows and a Rose window! Concerts are performed there, and we were able to get tickets for a wonderful concert (1st & 2nd violin, viola, cello, bass, and soprano) which was made even more delightful by the setting. Christian believers will be in awe of the many stories portrayed in glass. The Chapel is located within a military complex and bathroom facilities are sketchy!

Beautiful church and stained glass. A bit difficult to get into. The church is inside the courtyard of the Palace of Justice, so you have to go through security. But it is well worth the bother. Beautiful church.

best stained glass. This is a relatively cramped cathedral (compared to Notre Dame, which is right around the corner from Sainte-Chapelle). The stained glass windows are amazing and make this a treat to visit. They are doing some work, so several of the windows are covered over. Those that you can see are breathtaking.
Beautiful. Amazing stained glass windows, but note a large area is under repair. You might consider attending a concert here also
Go early. We arrived early and beat the crowds! The lines are incredible so be prepared. But it is worth the wait.
Marvelous and well maintained. This is a must visit. The stained glass windows are breathtaking. One gets a wonderful feeling for this medieval space of such import. Really worth a trip.

Impressive. This is a breathtaking Gothic place with amazing glass. I would put excellent but they were doing renovations so we couldn't see all the beauty. I recommend you to buy tickets for a concert in there. Those two combinations are just perfect!

Indescribable!. You can't read about this place, you have to visit it to understand it. Yes, it's the former resting place of Jesus's perported Crown of Thorns, and the windows tell all kinds of Bible stories (too high above you to see, but there are large free placards in a dozen different languages if you want to understand what you are seeing in the stained-glass window designs). HOWEVER, this place is the best example there is of the medieval piety of the French, and the then-king Saint Louis, and you go here to be transported to another place and time - and it is magnificent.Don't worry about the cleaning of the windows, they are being done only 2 bays at a time, and there are 16 bays, so there in PLENTY to see. French school-kids come here with their teachers and drawing pads - they are the lucky ones, they can come there to learn about their history and culture any time - most of us get only 1 chance to visit Paris, so don't miss yours - SEE THIS!!
Breathtaking stained glass. Worth the visit. Once you get to the sanctuary on the second level, you will be blown away by the beauty.
Amazing. My favorite thing to see in Paris. The chapel is a brilliant display of glass you should not miss. They just don't make them like this now...

Stained glass to wow. Always a stop on our Paris visits, this Chapelle is finishing their window restoration and the cleaned and reset glass shines in the sunlight like never before. The entry and lower level is a bit like a train station for a church given the noise and crowds, but the chapelle is awe inspiring and always a favorite.

Beautiful. This is a truly beautiful place. The stain glass windows are unmatched. The only bad thing is that it is (and has been for some time) undergoing renovation and you can't we the whole church. It is still worth it.

Sublime, breathtaking. The beauty of this place cannot be overtstated. If you are interested in mediaeval and/or Gothic architecture, this is an absolute must-see. We found it almost literally breathtaking. Choose a day and time when it is likely to be less busy for the best experience - we have visited on Sunday mornings and found it a good time.

We were told it was a "must do" and they were right. Once you reach the top of the stairs, you will be overwhelmed with the beauty and size of the stained glass windows. Yes, some renovation is going on currently, but there is more than enough to see to be impressive!

Magnificent, but be aware of the renovations.. Probably the most beautiful stained glass windows in the world, but be aware that 2 of the 15 meter high panels are currently undergoing significant renovation and I suspect they'll be working their way around the chapel.

Not much to see, but pretty church. Did not like the souvenir vendor INSIDE the church. I realize it's not used for worship any longer, but it seemed really disrespectful to see that in the actual church. The windows were beautiful although we only saw part of them as half were under reconstruction. Don't recommend this as a top site unless you are just looking to fill some time.

Repairs Underway That Limit View; Concert Big Disappointment. Attended a concert last night (sacred music) and was very disappointed by the experience. Half the stained glass in the chapel was covered for restoration. The music program was primarily vocal supported by a four-piece string ensemble. Acoustics were poor. Despite having reserved tickets for any of the first nine rows of seats, a very officious young man would not allow us to sit forward of the eighth row...sorry those seats forward are reserved. Note that if you want to sit close to the performers, get to the site extra early. For my money, I would not do this concert (e.g., Four Seasons) again. Have seen much better performances in London and Venice for half the money.

In renovation until 2015. It is awesome but you can only see half. And for 8.5 euros it is a bit expensive. You cannot be more than 20 minutes in it . If you want to help and make a 8.5 euro donation it is worth it. It is beautiful though, don't get me wrong, but of you are watching your euros you should pass for now.

Breathtaking. This small Cathedral is a gem! The most gorgeous and impressive stained glass windows of any Cathedral, and they tell stories. I happened by this while trying to kill about 2 hours before my train departure and I am certainly glad I did. It doesn't take long to tour, but it is beautiful and worth fitting in.

Soaring stained glass. Although a bit of a hassle at entry (extra security measures because the cathedral is located next to the court house), well worth the extra time. The soaring stained glass is awe inspiring. The windows are undergoing an extensive restoration project that is really paying off.

A wonderful evening. Me and my wife went to Sainte-Chapelle in a Tuesday's evening of June, 2013 to enjoy Vivaldi's "The Four Seasons" Concert, played by "Classik Ensemble" group, directed by David Braccini. I think that this is one of the many wonderful experiences that someone can attempt in Paris. The beautiful architecture of Sainte-Chapelle, with their magnificent stained-glasses windows, combined with a music that seems come from heaven. Highly recommended!

Stunning. We arrived early so there was only a short queue. At first I hesitated about climbing the circular stone steps, but I am glad I did. The stained glass windows are beautiful and even the fact that they had part of it screened off as they are replacing/cleaning/repairing some of the windows did not spoil the effect. The boards provided in several languages are helpful. Allow an hour for this attraction. You can buy a ticket for St Chapelle and the concierge combined which makes it a little cheaper.
Beutiful. Currently undergoing a major restoration project but areas are all open and views are not disturbed.. All the stained glass windows are absolutely beautiful!

Stunning - just bear with the queues and security. There is very little to say about this wonderful place. It is all about the stained glass: nothing else. Do not be put off by the length of the queue. Make sure you are carrying nothing that will be rejected by security checks - knives and so on. Do not fall into the trap of thinking that the lower (entry level) chapel is all there is. The real magic is up the spiral staircase (not altogether friendly for people with restricted mobility), but once you're upstairs, stay for as long as you want - it is stunning. There is no other word for it.

La Sainte-Chapelle. Beautiful small chapel lit by tall, beautiful stained glass windows built in early 1200's. Close to Notre Dame so an easy walk. It's breathtaking, especially if the sun is shining.

Loved the stained glass. I really enjoyed the stained glass windows, but I was a little disappointed that that was all there was to the attraction. We were lucky enough to have the earphone guided tour provided to us, a feature I would highly recommend as absent that I am not sure I would have appreciated the attraction nearly as much.

Awesome and intimate - all at once. Glad I did not miss this jewel of a chapel. To me, it's Inspiration & delicacy were crowning achievements of royal church architecture. Not so huge as the cathedrals - but awesome in it's height & intimacy. My mind stretched to imagine how the builders could achieve this "jewel-box" of stained glass and stone.

Don't miss the stained glass. This is one of the lesser known sights, but one you shouldn't miss. The stained glass windows are simply amazing. You can look for hours and see the stories of the bible unfold.

Amazing stained glass. A must see.. This is a hidden gem of Paris. The stained glass is out of this world. They do allow to take pictures, although I thought that 8.50 admission was a bit too much, however it needs to get restored, so I didn't mind paying. It's worth seeing as unlike big churches, its stained glass windows are impressively large and truly take your breath away. You can't help but be impressed and dwarfed by the history while standing inside of this church.

Beautiful.. We were there in April 2013 and got there early in the morning. It was about a half hour wait. You cannot buy advance tickets or skip the lines with the Paris Museum Pass. It is beautiful. Go on a sunny day to get the full view.
Stained cathedral glass delight!. Fabulous floor to ceiling stained glass windows. Not much room to sit. They prefer to keep tourists moving.

A fantastic place for a concert!. This was our second trip to Sainte-Chapelle for a concert, and it was as fantastic as the first. This trip we had the privilege to listen to a performance of Vivaldi- the four seasons -on flute, harpsichord, and violin. It was outstanding- It's a small house, so I would recommend that you buy your tickets on line, as far in advance as you can.

The Medieval Jewel of Paris. Quite by accident, as we were strolling towards our bus stop in the Ile de la Cite we happened to notice that unusually, there was no endless queue to visit Ste. Chapelle. Across the street we walked and entered the security scanning room (the police ignored my liquid perfume purchases and also a small pocket knife) and in we went. What a revelation! This building is absolutely straight out of the Middle Ages with its marvellous stained glass and painted walls, tight spiral stairs two and from the upper level and not to mention, the dust of worshippers ordinary and Royal from France's historical past. We considered ourselves very blessed indeed to have seen this marvel.

Awesome stained glass chapel. This church is breathtakingly beautiful! The stained glass work is unbelievable, especially considering when most of it was made. There is a very slow moving line to go through security, apparently to prevent defacing the stained glass, but it seemed like overkill to us. Once through that line, the entry line moves more quickly and the atmosphere inside the chapel is much more amenable to viewing and reflection than Notre Dame as the crowds are much less.

Gorgeous!. This was a really beautiful place to visit. As a tour guide in London, it is great to see the contrast in stain glass. I often talk about how Wren liked clear glass because he liked light, and this place helps to set that contrast. But it was gorgeous! The entire visit took about an hour, so it is good to do on the way to/from other things.

Renovations!. I was first here in this church in 2006 before the renovations started. It is a bit of a hassle to get in, having to go through the Palais Justice. But the stained glass is incredible. When I was there in April of 2013, only about half of it was visible because the other half of the church was being renovated. If you want to see the windows at their best and hear a cheesy classical concert, go to one of the early evening concerts they have there regularly. For the price, I expected a better performance. I don't want to sound like a musical snob (but maybe I am), but the classical music performed was done pretty badly. Technically, it was played well. Artistically, it was terrible. There is a difference. Regardless, seeing the church windows at sunset with the light shining through is worth putting up with bad music! This is a masterpiece.

Work being done. I was traveling with my mother who had been to Sainte-Chapelle before. She was very excited to share it with me, as on her previous visit it had taken her breath away. Unfortunately, on this trip, half of one wall of stained glass was covered while repairs were being done and loud hammering, etc. interrupted the peacefulness. It was still beautiful, and I could imagine how it must have looked to her the first time. But, it was disappointing, especially after standing in the security check line for a long time. Perhaps they could have advised us in advance of the repairs??

Renovations Ruined the Visit. I have been to the Sainte-Chapelle many times, and think it is one of the most beautiful sites in Paris with beautiful stained glass windows . However, many of the windows were blocked because of renovation. I would suggest waiting until the renovation is complete before paying money to visit.

Wonderful concert in a beautiful setting. For 25 euro each, we were treated to live music, including Ave Maria. I was disappointed that they are remodeling the cathedral, but listening to beautiful music with the late afternoon light on the incomparable stained glass was an amazing experience. If you see that there is a concert happening at Sainte-Chappelle when you visit, you should definitely go.

Perfect concert venue. Attended a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons at 7 pm on a sunny Sunday in June. The musicial performance would have been wonderful in any venue, but was so much better in this exquisite jewel box of a space.

Fabulous stained glass. Visited here not really knowing what to expect. Got there early to avoid the queue which builds up because of the security checks. Athough the access is up a fairly steep spiral staircase, once inside the stained glass is breathtaking. Well worth the 8 Euros.
Extraordinary Stain Glass. When you first walk in, you a fooled by the small size of the room and no windows. But once you go upstairs to the actual church, it will take your breath away.

Divine, Sublime. If you can make the chance, go to a concert in Ste. Chapelle. The setting is divine, the music was sublime. And when you go, definitely go to the early performance when the sunlight still illuminates the west windows. The musical program was a mélange of classical with some very good vocal pieces to keep things pleasantly enjoyable.If you want to spend a little over an hour at peace in the chapel and adore perhaps the world’s most beautiful stained glass windows, this really is necessary. (This is a classical concert in an old church…do you really think it appropriate to take children who cannot both sit still and stay quiet?)

Worth the time. This church is less visited and talked about than Notre Dame but well worth the time and very nearby. You enter the small downstairs chapel first and while it feels like many you may have visited in the past, be sure to go upstairs to feast your eyes on some of the most magnificent stained glass you've every experienced. What is unbelievable is that it tells the entire story of the bible in 1113 scenes in 15 windows. The building was built in only 6 years. It's a quick stop with other worthwhile stops very nearby, like the prison where Marie Antoinette was held and a collection of awesome gardening shops.

Incredible stained glass windows. This is less well-known than Sacre Coeur or Notre Dame but well worth a vist for the Gothic stained glass windows, which are under renovation. They show a fascinating short film on how they actually clean and renovate the glass. It's very beautiful church.
Glorious stained glass. A lovely place to be- even better with music- worth the wait. Regular concerts are held here and they are well worth attending

stunning. Every year during our time in Paris, we attend a concert here. My favorite group is Les Solistes Francais, a string ensemble who transform Vivaldi's Four Seasons into a transcendent experience. The music, the setting and the history all combine for the most amazing concert. Buy your tickets ahead at classictic.com; splurge on VIP seating up front, just a few euros more. Sixty minutes of pure bliss even for non-classical music buffs.
Amazing Glass Windows. Not sure why they charge to enter. Just a bunch of windows to stare at. If you think it's worth $8 then go for it. Tour is short.

Try and see a concert. This is a beautiful chapel on the Ile de la Cité and well worth a visit. We went to see a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons (booked online beforehand although tickets were available on the day) which could have been really corny but was great fun and fabulous value for money.

Amazing!. The windows are very beautiful, and colourful and amazingly crafter. However it is only one room with windows in it that have stained glass and it was a little over priced. It cost 8 euro to get in and yes it was amazing to see but we were in there for 2 minutes took some photos and left. Lined up for 40mims prior to it as everyone said that it is rooms full of stained windows and each one different and amazing. Wrong. One room with windows and yes amazing but average. I can say I have done it been there.

Amazing windows. The most spectacular stained glass art you'll ever see. And unlike most cathedrals, you'll be able to get close to it and see details. Expect a line and some extra security (it sits in the courtyard of the Palais du Justice) but it's worth it.

Hidden Gem. We attended a Vivaldi concert (booked via classical.com) it was exceptional. A beautiful setting and I would highly recommend seeing a show inside for the thrill of it. There are great bars and restaurants near-by

so unexpected. You see other peoples' pictures - but the experience is so unique in person. There is a pretty chapel downstairs but then you go upstairs! It is like being in the middle of a jewelbox - the windows are beautiful (even with some blocked for cleaning) and the chapel is so unique - I've never seen anything like it. There are cards upstairs that explain the theme of each window which is nice (and they have english available).There is no toilet (I did see a sign for a toilet but there was a metal gate in front that blocked the entrance, so maybe this is open some days) and the queue is VERY long - so find a toilet prior to going. Also - you do have to go through a mental detector / through security so just plan accordingly.
It will take your breath away. It may not look like much on the outside, but the inside is amazing. Make sure to check out the second level.

Beautiful and amazing!!. I went to Paris to see two things. The Eiffel Tower and Sainte-Chappelle. Neither disappointed and this church was beautiful inside. I kept trying to get a picture to capture its beauty but ended up taking a video to get it all.

Magnificent. It doesn't look like much dowmstairs, but once you head up you are bathed in a flood of multicoloured light shining through magnificent glass windows. The windows ate undergoing cleaning so the effect is fantastic, with colors and shapes restored to their original glory.Visitors should be aware that as Sainte Chappelle is inside the Palace of Justice, pocketknives, scissors etc are very strictly disallowed. You can deposit them at the conciergerie desk before entering though.

Beautiful!. It's hard to believe it was built in the 11th century. It will take your breath away. Be sure to visit both floors. We almost missed the small stairs in the corner of the entrance level. The big windows are upstairs.

You must see the stained glass windows of Saint-Chapelle. While a fairly small church, I find it more interesting that Notre Dame. The stained glass is mostly original and hundreds of years old. Spend some time looking at the panes and seeing the stores they convey. We attended a concert in Saint Chapelle and seeing the changing light of the setting sun through its glorious windows while hearing wonderful classic music was one of the highlights of our time in Paris.

Beautiful!. Gorgeous chapel with an impressive array of stained glass. Even after visiting MANY churches in Paris, this was our favorite, beating classics like Notre Dame and Sacred Court. The line was VERY long, get there early!

Incredible chapel with the most beautiful stained glass. We were here 2 years ago and we did not get a chance to see this charming chapel on Ile de la Cite near Notre Dame. Both my wife and I were overwhelmed with the amount of different shapes, colors and sizes of stained glass that told all the major stories of the bible and Christ's life,death and resurrection. If you like stained glass do not miss this treasure!
A Must See. You will be overwhelmed at the stained glass windows. Nearby are the Conciergerie and Notre Dame. So you can't miss it. Try to go on a sunny day if you can.

Wow!. When you walk into the church with the windows, it just about takes your breath away. Some of the windows were in the process of being restored making the view be blocked by some large barriers, but this is still a must see.

Much more than I expected. Well worth the visit! It will not ate you very long to tour, but it is a great gem. The. 2nd floor has beautiful stained glass which depending on the light I think can be more impressive than the glass at Notre Dame. They are currently about half way through a restoration process on the lass so you cannot view all of it.

Stunning stained glass. The stained glass restoration is stunning, and not to be missed. There is not a ton otherwise to see in this small chapel, but the glass is breathtaking, as is the sculptured walls.

The jewel in Louis's crown. Built to hold relics of the true cross, this jewelike structure is just a masterpiece of Medival stained glass. you do not have to be religious to have a religious experience here! A must see!
Stained Glass Everywhere!. There is no greater place to see architechture and stained glass co-existing in such a beautiful place!

amazing. The Sainte-Chapelle cathedral is truly spectacular. It is in the middle of the Justice courts and has strict security and long queues, but well worth the effort! We entered the bottom chapel, which includes the shop. Walking up a spiral staircase leads to the main chapel....stunning stained glass windows soar all around. Not to be missed!
DIsappointed. NO priority is given to Paris Museum Pass holders and we did not have the time to stand in the lengthy queue to get in.

Beautiful Windows and Terrific Concert. We went in the evening at 20:30 primarily for the Vivaldi concert. There was no line for tickets although there was a security check like the airports. This is because you are also entering the Hall of Justice grounds. Sainte-Chapelle itself is small compared to others in Paris, but the stain glass windows are beautiful. The concert was Euromusic strings for Vivaldi's Four Seasons and was terrific. There is a charge for tickets but well worth the price, so go if you can you will truly enjoy if you like music. After the concert we took our time in the church and admired the art work.
Worth seeing. Beautiful stain glass and interesting chapel. A little disappointed out how dusty it was. It would seem they would manage cleaning. We are glad we visited.

Hidden Jewelbox. They are working on the outside and have a portion of the inside stain glass covered to restore, but it was so beautiful, that I cant imagine being there on a sunny day the the sun would stream through the stained glass how much more beautiful that it would be. Unbelievable. Magnificent. Loved it.

Sights are Stunning. Waited in line for 30 minutes, and then paid a fee to enter. The fee is used to finance the restoration. There was also the security station similar to airports to enter as the entrance is also used for the court system. Entering is at the lower level, kind of dark and lots of souvenir stands to choose from. Once upstairs in the main chapel, the sights are just stunning. There are numerous cards available in various languages to explain the stories depicted in every stained-glass windows. The beauty is that starting at one end and following the viewing to the other end, the whole Bible is depicted in pictures. The sad part is that we would need a pair of binoculars and a day or two to complete the review of this Bible in pictogram. Otherwise, with the sun shining through the windows, the sight is quite spectacular. We recommend this visit and would return again.

The second floor will surprise you. Amazing Church Building and absolutely the finest stained glass that tells the story of the bible. The statues have impact....all amazing. Make sure you take the self guided audio tour as it will add a better understanding of what you will see...don't miss this one. As good as Notre Dame is....this church is special!

Jewel of gothic architecture. The small Sainte Chapelle was worth the 30min in the line to get inside(Museum Pass holders be aware: there's no special line). The lower part has beautiful painted celing and walls, and the chapel itself has the amazing stained glasses with scenes from New and Old Testament. It is amazing how this chapel that was part of the Capetian royal palace has survived more than 800 years.

Stunning Stained Glass. Line was 45 minutes wait but well worth the wait. Just stunning. The windows each telling a story from biblical times depicted through images in the stained glass. There is a lower and upper level. Both beautiful. The place itself is not that large so this is a good 1 hour thing to schedule into your itinerary (not including the line we waited in). Recommend this!

World's greatest stained glass. The second floor of Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely breath-taking. The walls seem to be made of entirely of glass, and, of course, the colors are stunning. We were there once in the daytime, and again one evening for a concert, as the sun was setting. I'd rank this as a "don't miss" visit in Paris.

If you only see one thing in Paris, this should be it.. Sainte-Chappelle is a must-see. It's incredibly beautiful and will increase your appreciation for the architecture and craftsmanship of the period.

Amazing. The Chapelle is small and the line moves slowly but it is breathtaking. Absolutely stunning. There are usually events held in the evening though so the best time to go is in the late morning.

My 3rd visit and 2nd concert.. Last year I experienced Vivaldi's Four Seasons. This year, Ave Maria. It was absolutely lovely and my friends that came on my advice loved it as well. Well worth the visit. Do pre-book if you want to go. You will not be disappointed. One warning - in August, it was very hot. In May, we were freezing. Come prepared to weather the weather as the site is not equipped with modern heating and cooling.

Amazing Stained glass. You could say "seen one stained glass window, you've seen em all" but that would not be true with Saint Chappelle. The windows here are phenomenal even when 1/3 of them were covered with scaffolding and such. A definite on your Paris list.

Beautiful stained glass. The line was long for tickets. Could you buy ahead of time? But it is worth the wait to see the beautiful stained glass. Read the history in your guide book while waiting in line.

Slipping?. Maybe it's because I've been there several times, but this visit was not memorable. Crowds of people, mainly students, simply rushed the ticket line and pushed there way in! A completely blasé staff allowed this to happen. Once inside workmen had covered much of the viewing area. This was my last visit to St. Chapelle
a must see in paris. This is a must see visit when in Paris. Full of history and just a beautiful place to visit especially if it is sunny.
Unique!. It's worth the trip inside to see the unique ceiling on the main floor and the gorgeous stained glass window panels (with scenes from the Bible) upstairs.

Crowded but worth it.. Did not like the long lines but found that we went to the Conciergerie first (no long line)and paid for a ticket for both and therefore skipped the long line for the Sainte-Chapelle. I loved just being able to hang out and observe whatever I wanted without being rushed. It was crowed but I could wait for folks to move on and then experience it at my leisure.

Beautiful Chapel. The stained glass windows are marvelous! Some side wall is under temporary construction, so we didn't get the full effect. They were having a Vivaldi Four Seasons concert there on Sunday evening. That would have been an awesome experience. It is not as big as Notre Dame, more intimate setting.
Magical. This is one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen. The light coming through the huge stain glass windows made me feel as if I were in a kaleidoscope. A must see chapel.

Beautiful stained glass. Visited on our final full day in Paris, after deciding not to bother earlier on due to length of queue.Was still a queue (mid-late morning), however this moved steadily until we got inside. This queue was in fact security screening. Once past this, we walked around to entrance to Sainte-Chapelle itself - no queue there - and bought tickets. Kids were free - always a good thing.Entered Lower Chapel first - thought this was beautiful, colourful decorated wood panelling etc, very ornate, and a number of stained glass windows, plenty to absorb.Then up a narrow circular staircase, to the Upper Chapel. Wow. You are immediately hit by the colour from almost continuous stained glass windows in this area. Very beautiful indeed. Again, lots of other decoration as well, so it is very sumptuous. At the moment there is an area covered up for renovations along part of one side only, the other side is unaffected, as is the front of the chapel. There is a small balcony area where you can retreat and view through the doors - also plenty of carving here.Not a huge area, but a lot to take in. Back down other circular staircase to exit to Lower Chapel again, with gift shop area along one side.Would certainly recommend as worth seeing, if you have the time.

Must See. This is a must see to anyone traveling to Paris. It is small, but stunning. Totally worth the time to go in and look at the gorgeous stained glass. Because of the size, it gets crowded, but go early and you can usually miss the crowds. So absolutely stunning!

Concert at Saint Chapelle was experience to cherish. Sitting in this beautiful church and hearing Canon in D, and Vivaldi's Four Seasons was something I will always remember. We actually did this on our former trip to Paris, but the concerts are still on, with posters for them advertised throughout the city, as well as online. Don't miss this.
Beautiful windows. Beautiful windows, much more magnificent than expected. Small and quickish to visit (<1hr) - included in the Museum Pass.
Beautiful. Still as beautiful as I remember from 24 years ago, though I don't like how the concessions have crept inside.

A Paris Must. We went to two concerts during our Paris visit. It was cold and rainy outside and chilly inside but the fabulous music and beautiful church with wonderful acoustics made one forget that.Any time I go to Paris I take in a concert here. I can make no higher recommendation.
My Favorite attraction in Paris. Love this place. No trip is complete without going to Ste Chapelle. If you have time, get tickets to Vivaldi Four Seasons Concert at Ste Chapelle

Loved the stained glass. Hadn't visited this before. The stained glass is just spectacular!We also attended a concert in the chappel in the evening which was great because you could just sit and gaze at the windows while enjoying the music (Vivaldi's 4 Seasons (for us)). Beaware that they have airport-like security -- your bag will be X-rayed and you have to go thru a metal detector. Nothing sharp is allowed into the church. This will take some time.We used Rick Steve's Audio guide and it was nice to have some explanation of the windows and how to read them.
Just grogeous. Beautiful chapel and definitely worth the visit, even if your in Paris on a short trip. Definitely go an see it

Paris's Jewel box. This church is a must-see. The upper floor is surrounded by stained glass windows that glisten like jewels in the sunlight. Just sit and enjoy the beauty. Be sure to go on a sunny day to see the best display of light.
Beautiful!. An absolute gem! Very beautiful! They are renovating the stain glass, so part of it was covered. In any case, it is spectacular!

What a window. Wanted to see the windows in Sainte-Chapelle but it was closed for a musical event taking place that week. Undeterred we booked for Vivaldi' Four Seasons the following night. Arrived to find that it was not to be "Four Seasons" instead it was "Ave Maria"; for me a major disappointment. Concert was OK. We had to wait quite a while to get in, then lead through a maze of corridors before arriving at the chapel. There was renovation work being done on one wall. But once inside the famous windows were all that I expected and were worth the other disappointments of the visit.
Pretty, but small. The stained glass windows are very cool but the chapel's pretty small for the 8 euros admission. However, I see it as a contribution so it's all good.

Lovely. Sainte-Chapelle is absolutely beautiful and a hidden gem that's just minutes from the more famous Notre Dame. There is a longer wait to get in and you have to go through security because it's in the same area as a government building. But it's definitely worth the wait because the church feels more initiate and bright than Notre Dame.

Incredible. When I entered I thought the ground floor was it! And i couldnt see what l the fuss was about. That chapel is very small. The rich blue ceiling only makes it appear even smaller. The stained glass windows are lovely but are not the best I have seen in France. One wall on the inside has become a shop which further closes in the space.Fortunately there is MUCH more!When you get up to the main Chapel - OMG! Huge stain glass windows - these the best I have seen anywhere! Note: There is a major renovation going on (2008 to 2014) and about 20% is covered up at the moment. It looks like 60% has been completed, and these windows look great, and 20% remains, and these look very 'dirty'.This attraction is a great experience and I recommend to all.Info: We got a combined ticket with the Conciergerie for 12.50 Euros, normally 16.50 if purchased separately.
Vivaldi at the Sainte Chapelle. Vivaldi Concert was an extra special treat! Even though the chapelle was in the process of being cleaned, it was still a great treat to visit.
A must see in Paris. A truly remarkable site with vistas of the city, check out the crypts if you dare! It is a working church so visit with respect, no pictures are allowed.

My Favourite Cathedral. I like this cathedral's stained glass and ceiling and wall art more than Notre Dame, Paris. Well worth a visit. entry pass does not allow quicker entry, but the queues are shorter.
Beautiful Stained Glass!. The stained glass is a must see. Each of the 16 sections represent a book of the Bible. Definitely worth a visit. Thought it was a little pricey though.

A true jewel. Although there is some maintenance on the stain glass windows one can still observe the magnificent beauty of the stain glass windows.
The chapel is small but truly inspirational. A must see in Paris.
It's the windows, stupid. Enough said. These windows are like a triple decker cake of glassy delight. See it. Well worth the price.
Beautiful Stained Glass. The line moves fast and its very worth while. One line for everyone. Make sure you go upstairs. Buy a book. It takes time to absorb the experience.
Just beautiful. Although it may seem very small from the outside, the glass windows are stunning. You can get a sort of card telling all about the different symbols, what technique was used etc.

Light Explosion. Sainte Chapelle is an immensely beautiful chapel inside. The light coming in through the stained glass window is an explosion of colors you probably have never seen in your life. How were people back then able to piece together such an extraordinary array of colors? Through painstaking work. These guys were masters of elements; they had to mix sand, wood grain, and elements such as cadmium (yellow) or cobalt (blue) to get the correct colors. What is more is that each stained glass panel tells a story of the bible, from creation of the world to the end of the world! So you can imagine there are a lot of panels. Just amazing and so much neck cramping.
Worth the wait. This beautiful little cathedral (I don't know what else to call it) is so spectacular, with it's beautiful blue stained glass. It's not to be missed, especially on a sunny day.

Breathtaking. This is much more beautiful than Notre Dame and is a must-see in Paris. The narrow winding staircase to the second floor is unique, and the stained glass is so beautiful it literally took my breath away. I will visit this every time I am in Paris.
Amazing!. We went to a Vivaldi Four Seasons concert here and were blown away with the ambience, accoustics and beauty of the Sainte Chapelle. Would definitely recommend.

Wait for that perfect sunny day. This church I believe is the true hidden treasure for Paris. The stained glass works in the main hall are tiredly not to be believed. It is not that large of a place but with the noon day sun streaming in, everything is awash in colour.all the stained glass panels tell a story and there is a map inside to direct you. It's not a long tour but you'll find yourself spending more time in there than you would think. A true treasure,Designated world heritage site by UNESCO it's another must see.
The most beautiful stained glass!. The stained glass windows are spectacular here. One side of the church and all it's windows were under construction.

An almost-hidden gem. There was a 20-minute wait to get in to Sainte Chapelle, in the rain, and it was worth it. At first I wondered why it is famous for its stained glass, but then climbed the stairs. Oh la la! Amazing.

Stained Glass Beauty. While visiting Notre Dame on Ile de la Cite in Paris, walked just a few blocks away to a little jewel box of a medieval chapel called Sainte-Chapelle. It was commissioned in the 1200s by King Louis IX to house holy relics including Christ's crown of thorns. The upper chapel has one of the most extensive collections of 13th century stained glass having survived the French Revolution. Chairs are provided for soaking up the atmosphere and just gazing at the amazing stained glass. Plan to spend a couple of hours here. There can be fairly long lines to enter so either come early or go through the line for the adjacent Justice Building which is usually shorter and allows you to go through the chapel as well.

Absolutely Fabulous. The stained glass is gorgeous - just breath-taking. When we first entered, I was disappointed, because the windows are rather boring. But then we reached the upper level, and I understood what all the fuss was about. The windows are just beautiful. We also attended a sunset concert of Bach violin music, which was a fabulous idea. Very intimate setting, and watching the colors shift in the windows as the day faded was an exquisite experience, as the warmer reds dominated early in the evening, shifting to blues dominating after sunset. Wow!!
A surprise. The stained glass windows lived up to expectations - just beautiful! I was surprised to see that the lower chapel for the non-royals was not plain and drab.

So pretty. This is such a lovely place to see...the stained glass is just amazing and they are renovating it so one half of the building looks even better while no disruptions were caused by the work still being done to the other windows except for a section that was being worked on was hidden behind boarding.

Beautiful, but use the other line in enter. Much quicker. We saw the building and it was gorgeous. But just go right to the second floor. The waiting was not that great since it was raining hard and cold. Two suggestions about the line: 1. Get there a little before they open back up at 2:30. There is practically no line. 2. When entering, go through the other line for the juctice building which is very fast and short. It exits the same place as the Saint-Chapelle line. In fact, towards the front of the line the security guard asked people to go through it to make it faster.

Forget Notre Dame. This is hands down the best Gothic church in Paris. Built in the 13th century, the design was forward thinking for the period. The walls so none existent people wondered how the roof stood. This lack of walls allows for an amazing array of beautiful stained glass windows. Despite damage during the French Revolution and in an ill-advised retrofit for use as an archive depository in 1803, two-thirds of the windows are original, and thus the program for the narrative of the windows can be discerned. Commissioned by Louis IX to look like a reliquary, the windows use biblical stories to portray a model of kingship and warnings of bad kingship. Whether or not you understand medieval narrative or iconography does not matter, the sheer beauty of the interior is breathtaking. It is small compared to Notre Dame, but so much more beautiful and inspiring. Worth a trip for this alone. It is one of the only things I regularly visit when I come to Paris.

Beautiful stained glass...especially with the right light.. St. Chappelle is beautiful - and if you are there at the right time of day - the way the sun shines through the windows is spectacular.The chapel itself is actually fairly small - but it is gorgeous. St Chappelle is on the Musee Pass - avoid the lines!

Worth the long wait. This is definitely a "not to miss" place in Paris. We had to stand in a long line but we were so glad we waited. The stained glass windows were beautiful!! They had wonderful charts that explained each window and what they represented.
Dazzling!. I've been to Sainte-Chapelle three times now, and each time I enter, my breath gets taken away by the dazzling stained glass windows.

Blew My Mind. OK....I walked up the stairs and my mind was blown...top went right off. This is a little slice of heaven that is worth the line and security. Part of it is under restoration, but it doesn't detract from the beauty. A must-see!

Lots of repairs going on and a little pricey but amazing Windows. Sainte-Chapelle is undergoing a lot of renovation.
When you first walk in, your reaction is "I paid a lot of money to see a little broken down church".
That all changes when you go to the next level - the glass windows are really beautiful.
There is also some nice presentations on the reconstruction efforts and what it actually involves.
BUILT FOR ROYALTY. Built in the 12th Century in 9 years, the walls are windows of Stainglass. A small cathedral and most often overlooked in favor of Notre Dame.

Close to Heaven at Sainte-Chapelle. Yes this is another church to visit in Paris, but it is so worth taking the time to visit. The stained glass windows in the second floor chapel are stunningly beautiful. Be sure to go on a sunny day or at least not too overcast so that you gain the maximum effect of the light through the stained glass. I also went to a performance of Vivaldi's 'Four Seasons' by a string quartet at this beautiful chapel - brilliant!! breath-taking! but freezing on a chilly Paris Saturday night. I was so glad I took a travel rug! Also be aware that your Paris Museum Pass does not allow you to skip the line at Sainte-Chapelle. Go early if you don't have time to queue up.

Not to be missed!. Only a few steps from Notre Dame this magnificent church is unique in that there is a whole wall of stained glass windows that start just above eye-level. If the windows aren't enough the light streaming through them makes for an awe-inspiring sight.
The Best. This was the best of everything we saw or did--beautiful stained glass, less crowded than Louvre, Notre Dame, very ethereal. . .

Breathe taking. Small but exquisite. Worth paying to see despite the queue so plan your trip carefully. The stain glass is stunning but at the moment there is some restoration work so not as impressive as it will be when it s finished. The colours and textures all combine to make a truely breathe taking experience.

Time for a tourist strike. It's been apparent for some time that Paris has a tourist problem -- not too few, but too many. Far too many. It is also apparent that the tourist authorities have no idea how to handle them, except endless line-ups, endless in both length and duration. Nowhere is this more apparent than at Sainte Chapelle, near Notre Dame. After several attempts, in what is supposed to be a down season for tourism because of cold and rain, we simply gave up. Our idea of a vacation is not to stand with the other sheep in the rain -- we can be damp, cold and miserable at home. The piece de resistance was a sign informing those foolish enough to buy the Paris Museum Pass, which is supposed to put you in another, shorter, lineup, that the Pass was being disregarded. Get in line and shut up. For those dumb enough to buy the Pass, Beware. It may (somewhere other than Sainte Chapelle) abate your misery, but it will not solve it. We cooled down (figuratively, not literally, because it was 10 degrees C and raining) by doing a walking tour of the adjacent parts of the city, which is still to be recommended. But for those who propose to visit any of the overpopulated Paris "tourist" sites -- don't. What is on display is the tourists, not the site.

Great surprise. I was just out walking and discovered it is open on Wed. eves till 8:30. Went in- there was a conference on on the restoration in progress. Fascinating chance event.
It is an incredible place an needs to be seen.

Not to be missed.. Well worth getting in line early, Sainte-Chapelle is a masterpiece of gothic church architecture. They open at 9:30, and if one is in line from about 9 AM one can get in before the crowd overwhelms the limited space. A museum pass also speeds the entry process. Once inside and upstairs in the main worship area, the lighting is magical. Do not miss it!

Gothic at It's Best.. Though on the same Island as Notre Dame, this Church should not be missed !. Lighter, airier a tad smaller; but, almost unbelievable Stained Glass... wrap-around. The Lower Chapel as well. Check out the detail of the wooden sculpture, mosaics, marble floor inlays, carved columns... an absolute Gem... puts Notre Dame to shame ( we liked it though ). When they finish restoring the glass in the Upper Church, I may even return to Paris just for that.

Interesting. If you are into History the Chapelle and Palace and prison are worth standing in the line. I actually found the Palace of Justice more interesting as this is where over an 11month period during the revolution that people were sentenced to the guillotine

Vivaldi's Four Seasons. I booked a Vivaldi concert on line before we left for Paris. The Concert was on May 23, 2013 @ 07:00pm in St. Chapelle. You could not have asked for a better location for this concert. Sitting in the church surrounded by all the stain glass windows. It was magical.

Skip the Lines at Notre Dame. A visit to Sainte-Chapelle is like standing inside a jewel. You are completely surrounded by stained glass in this historic chapel. Lines are reasonable compared to Notre Dame and more beautiful.

Wonderful - An Icon. If you visit Paris without visiting Sainte-Chappelle, then you really did miss something. Look it up online before you go and you'll see why this is a must-see.Sainte-Chappelle (built around 1240) means The Holy Chapel. It is a royal medieval Gothic chapel, on the Île de la Cité in the heart of the city. The architecture is amazing and a visit there will greatly enhance your visit to Paris.
Spiritual and beautiful. You should see it. With no excuses! The view from there is amazing and worth it. The Chapelle itself is cousy and light from inside, and gotic from outside.

Ultimate Stained Glass. This is an amazing chapel where you are nearly completely surrounded by stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle is on the same small island as Notre-Dame so you should definitely include it to your plans when in Paris. There are some stairs to climb to get to the chapel, but nothing too bad. A couple of the main sections of stained glass were be restored when we visited. The restoration project is amazing and there is a good video that explains what they are doing. Here is my tip for you visit. Take a small set of binoculars. In addition to the beauty of the stained glass, they obviously tell the story of the Bible. I would have enjoyed it more if I could have seen the details of the higher panes. Also, there is a lovely flower market to the northeast of the chapel. It's a great diversion.

Amazing Medieval Stained Glass. This chapel is the home of the most awe-inspiring medieval stained glass I have ever seen...and I've seen a lot. They are restoring it section by section, which didn't deter at all from its magnificence. If anything, it was amazing to compare how much better it looked after the restoration.

A true gem of Paris!. Stunning! If you enjoy stained glass and gothic architecture, a visit to St. Chapelle is a must! We went to a Vivaldi concert in the evening and one could not ask for a more beautiful setting!
Simply Spectacular. It is the single most beautiful place to which I have ever been. Your soul cannot help but be moved while the light shines through those windows.

The place of high stained-glass art. I never saw such beautiful stained-glass windows like in this refined imponderable chapel. It's a perfect example of Flamboyant style. On a sunny day it's a place you shouldn't miss.
A masterpiece. The beauty of this church is difficult to describe. I went to an amazing concert (Vivaldi) and it was quite an experience. Vivaldi's Four Season's and the setting were unforgettable.

Unmissable. Go early in the morning to avoid crowd.
The best way to avoid it, is to get the Museum pass, valid 2 days
Beautifyl. We enjoyed visiting Sainte-Chapell despite a longish wait to get in. If you enjoy stained glass, it's worth a visit.

Beautiful stained glass windows. Like many reviewers had said, the stained glass windows at Sainte Chapelle are simply beautiful. The chapel has two levels, a smaller chapel below, a larger one on top with high ceilings. There's a restoration project going on now until 2014 I think, so one side of the window was blocked when I was there. Despite this, I think it's still worth a visit. The queue for security clearance (because its surrounded by the Palais de Justice) and tickets can be quite long, so try to go early.

gorgeous. The stainglass widows were amazing, this is a must see, I'm not sure if it is very good for wheelchair users as you have steep winding staircase and I didn't see a lift so maybe check before hand.
Marvellous. I went to a marvellous concert in Sainte Chapelle. The music was wonderful and the setting just spectacular. The windows and statues etc are really worth seeing.
Very special place. The vitrals are wonderful! The Church itself isn't very big or imponent as Notre Dame, but it's definitly worthy a visit!

Unbelievable. The first time we were to travel to Paris, a distant cousin said that we absolutely must go to the Sainte-Chapelle. She said, "I'll say no more - just be sure you go." Of course, that intrigued us. It's not the easiest place to find, and on busy days the wait in line could be long. We were fortunate to go on a day when we had no wait. We were in awe when we were in the lower-level. In fact, we couldn't believe that there could possibly be anything more beautiful to be seen on the upper level. Of course, we were wrong. We were stunned by the magnificence and beauty. We didn't visit with a group so it meant we could take all the time we needed to truly enjoy this experience. I'm grateful that we had information about the building given to us so we could read about exactly what we were experiencing. Don't miss it.
Stained Glass was Amazing. Beautiful and make sure you pay the 4 Euros extra to see the treasury there. Very opulent and impressive.

May be of interest to some, but not me. My wife & I visited mid-May 2013. Unless you are fascinated by stained glass windows, this place is a waste of time and money. Cards are available in English (and other languages) to explain what you are seeing. However, we found that we couldn't see sufficient detail to match the printed explanations.If you must go; but the combined Saint Chappelle ticket to save a few bucks
OK but overpriced. The famed stained-glass is worth half an hour of anyone's time and shouldn't be missed but compared to other historical attractions the experience is probably over-priced.
Stunning. I've never been so affected by the atmosphere given to a room as when entering this room. The light effects given by the windows stopped me in my tracks like no other experience.

Disappointing. I was most disappointed with this cathedral. Considering the 8 Euro entrance price, I was expecting much more. The stained glass windows were beautiful, but some were being repaired and others, so dusty that it spoilt them. Compared to all the other cathedrals that were free to enter, i feel this was quite a rip off.

Average? I know but one has to compare.. I need of much restoration. I would not put this high on your list if you have limited time. It doesn't take long to go through the audio guide is okay but if you go look for the lamenated sheets near the wall they are just as helpful at explaining things. If you have no idea what you are seeing then I would get the guide.

Dust and dirt everywhere. I had imagined a different feeling here. The first floor is dark and paint is peeling everywhere. The floor where the Rose window is was covered in dirt and dust! It was so obvious even though we were standing far below the windows and window sills, etc. I was truly underwhelmed.

Four Seasons in a beautiful church. Saint-Chapelle hosts small concerts on a regular basis. At the time of our visit in June 2012 we were lucky enough to catch a concert featuring Vivaldi's Four Seasons.The lead violin was charismatic and very talented and sitting in a beautiful chapel, with sun streaming through amazing stained glass windows, and seeing the smile on my girlfriends face while we listened to the music is something I will always cherish. It was just beautiful.We only found out it was happening due the seeing a flyer posted near our apartment - and literally had 30 minutes to get there in time for the show. So we had no idea if we could get tickets at the door or not...luck was with us and we found we had no trouble getting in and finding a seat. Anyway - it was a really great experience - I'm not big on classical music but to end a busy day of walking about Paris with beautiful music in an amazing setting was just about perfect.

Stained glass -wow. The stained glass windows on first floor are beautiful and I personally preferred them to Notre Dame Cathedral windows. The chapel is small but lovely. The panelling and windows in particular are remarkable especially on sunny day

Incredible. Sainte-Chapelle is a must see while in Paris. It has the most incredible stained glass you will ever see. It quite literally wraps the entire room. Some of the stained glass is currently being restored which did change the effect some, but when you see the difference the restoration has already made in the overall experience you will have no complaints!It is best to have a museum pass for fast entrance to this site. You will still have to wait to go through security, but once you are in the court yard you can skip the que and go right in to the cathedral.
A must see!. A beautiful jewel box of a chuch near Notre Dame in the complex of a government building. It's small but the stained glass walls are magnificent. Worth the wait in line to see it.

Worth the difficult lines and security!. A friend had said that Sainte-Chapelle had some of the nicest stained glass in Europe. This was the UNDERSTATEMENT of ALL TIME! Tour books said to pass through the" relatively plain lower level." This, too, is an error.First of all, that lower level is only plain in comparison to a Bernini-decorated Baroque church in Rome. Don't run past the lower level en route to the upstairs! You've waited a long time in line, so don't by pass this.There is no way to adequately describe the upper level. More window than wall, the structure is very nearly luminescent. Even from the outside it doesn't seem possible that the roof can stand on such slender pillars with no visible arches or buttresses or support of any kind. As we came up the small spiral stairs from the lower level, the sun suddenly came from behind the clouds and I went absolutely weak in the knees from the beauty. Even with several windows blocked for renovations, the light was complete.A word about the lines -- I know this is very difficult for the authorities because Sainte-Chapelle sits in the courtyard of the Supreme Court and Department of Justice. Permitting access at all must be a tremendous challenge for security of all the spaces. There are several steps to the security, and once inside there are few facilities. I'm just saying that the access and visiting is really hard to negotiate, but even with this you simply must allow time and patience to see Sainte-Chapelle. It's a miracle that it survived the Republic! It is a gift! Enjoy!

Bad bad security line. The windows are the best in Paris. A must-see. Security line is the slowest in Paris. Can't say why. Really slow and exposed to the weather. Once beyond security, ask for directions to the front door of the cathedral. The direction of the door is not obvious and there are no signs.
Too many spiral steps to see satined glass windows. Admission price does not include any explaination or help w/questions.On your own in every church, etc.

Magical night. Attended an evening concert in the Chapelle which was lovely and worth booking in advance. Seats not terribly comfortable but the beautiful surroundings made up for it. We were there in early May 2013 and there was some preservations going on some one section of the windows was boarded up but it is definitely worth a visit. Entrance is through security across a courtyard and up stairs but it is worth the trouble

A little disappointing. Maybe we missed something here.....while the stained glass on the second floor was beautiful, the chapel is quite small and we did not think the tickets good value. If you have made the trek out to Chartres to see the glass, you might be disappointed here.
