It was an overcast day when we went, so that may have had an impact on the view of the glass, and it was very crowded.

Astonishing. On the outside, there is clear evidence of large structural members that hold up the small building. On the inside, the most resplendent stained glass makes it seem almost as if those structural members have disappeared in a sea of luminous color. This is the very essence of the Gothic architectural metaphor of light transforming gross material into insubstantial, spiritual being. The building is thus a late medieval thesis on religion. It is tiny, and you won't likely be there for long, but it is utterly jaw-dropping.
One of a kind church. This one is worth climbing the steps to see the 12 magnificent floor to ceiling stained glass windows that depict Bible scenes.
Beautiful. Make sure you go upstairs...We almost did not see the whole reason to visit...until we saw someone coming down the stairs..

Excellent music; incomparable setting. Before leaving for Paris, we visited Ste. Chapelle's website and purchased tickets to one of the evening concerts offered in the main second-floor chapel in the summer. The young string players and vocalist were exceptional, and NOTHING can equal the beauty of Mozart resonating through that glorious space. Plus, if you book a 7:00 concert, you get to be there as the evening sun shines full on the magnificent Western windows. You must present your tickets and ID at on-site security a half-hour before the concert, but this is a minor inconvenience to enjoy a once-in-a-lifetime sublime experience.
Don't miss it. For me, this was the standout of our trip, along with the Musee d'Orsay. I'm a sucker for the medieval and this was my idea of heaven on a stick.

Small but special. Had a long wait,but on recommendation from a. Fellow traveller waited.Truly a stunning experience once you climb. the spiral stairs.The Stained glass was beautiful.went late afternoon ,so sun was shining through.breathtaking.

An Exquisite Gem. Truly one of my favorite places on the planet. Tucked away on the Ile de la Cite, it is well worth the modest admission fee. You may encounter a slight line as you wind your way up the narrow staircase from the ground level (where the gift shop is located) to the breathtaking main chapel, with its walls of spectacular stained glass windows. High Gothic at its best. A very special place indeed.

Simply stunning. Unlike any other church in the world. Whilst there was building work going in it didn't detract from the stunning environment. The queues for this tiny church are crazy so come with a ticket or expect to queue for hours

Definitely worth a look. Sainte-Chapelle is currently being restored to it's full potential. However even in it's current state it is nothing short of breath taking. I absolutely loved it and I'm so glad we took the time to check it out.

Gorgeous.. This place is worth the visit just to see the stained glass. It was under restoration when I was there, but it didn't take away from the experience at all. Some of the stained glass is on display at the Cluny.

So beautiful. Sainte Chappelle is so beautiful and a hidden gem. I have been to Sainte Chappelle several times and marvel each time at the intricacy of the stained glass and the history in each of the pieces as they tell the history of the Bible. Just awesome. The church is under renovation and each piece is being painstakingly taken out, cleaned and restored. Part of the chapel is closed off as this is being done but the remainder is still open to viewing. I believe the renovations are set to be completed late in 2013. It is worth the visit!

Beautiful. But glad we saw it with the Paris Museum Pass. Be sure to get in the right line if you have the pass. Saves a lot of waiting in line. They are restoring some of the cathedral at the present. Be aware you have to climb stairs to get the full effect of the chapel. There is a second floor room that is stunning.

Four season concert. We went to a concert here in the evening. We enjoyed a small group of musicians playing the Four Seasons while the colorful windows went from dusk to night. It was very restful and beautiful. Dont wait to book at the last minute and dont be afraid to get the cheapest seats as the area is small. Dress warm in the winter

Disappointed. This is a run down cathedral and all it has going for it is the stained glass windows...we expected more after waiting on line for 30 mins to get in..museum pass not valid to cut the line...have to wait in line like everyone else but you dont have to pay if you have the pass...

surprisingly touching. Commissioned by Louis IX, later to become St. Louis, this "little" chapel continues to have a sense of reverence and prayer when you step inside. Make sure you go to the upper chapel-the stained glass is amazing!

8.5 euro entrance fee is too much, but included in our museum pass. so paid a visit. even included in museum pass, but you can not bypass the line, we had to line up for nearly 40 min. stained glass windows are great in this sunly day. god blessed. it is only about 5 min from notre dame, so give yourself 1.5 hours more to include in this lovely chapel.

What you see is restoration in the making. There really is not too much to see, other than the restoration, which is very intersting. There are only 2 rooms that we could go into. One downstairs that was like a gift shop. Do not bother spending the euros for headphones because when you go upstairs, up a narrow spiral staircase, there are reading materials in many languages which explain everything that is already on the headphones. The newly cleaned and restored windows are brilliantly bright and beautiful. 70% are original.

Must be one of top 10 churches or chapels. I have always loved the Notre Dame de Paris cathedral. This was my first to Sainte-Chapelle and it has spoiled Notre Dame for me forever. Sainte-Chapelle is a small chapel. Though it is very close to Notre Dame and they are both Gothic architecture, they are quite different. Sainte-Chapelle is a small jewel in comparison to the hulking Notre Dame. The beautiful light pouring through the ancient stained glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle dominates the interior. Much of the glass in Sainte-Chapelle is original to the 12th/13th century and is extremely bright and colorful and tells an intricate Biblical story, whereas most of the glass in Notre Dame is much more modern and much less colorful and beautiful and is just somewhat boringly patterned. The walls and ceilings in Sainte-Chapelle are beautifully painted and decorated. There is a good chance that Notre Dame was beautifully decorated in the past when it was built but much of that decoration is now gone. Sainte-Chapelle has very little stone structure to it as seen from the inside - it seems to be mostly glass - whereas Notre Dame, though a Gothic cathedral and thus glass rich, has comparatively much less glass. Sainte-Chapelle is now undergoing restoration of its stained glass windows so a large part (maybe 1/4) of the windows were covered and not visible. That was disappointing but it will ensure that the beautiful glass will endure and be visible long in the future. Also, the interior painting could use restoration. In many places it had blistered and peeled off. Hopefully, someday that will also be restored as it was a couple of hundred years ago to make it look new again. Sainte-Chapelle was well worth a visit and I probably will never pass it up again when I visit Paris.
Beautiful. Traveling around Europe you se SO MANY churches. This one really stood out to me because of the amazing stained glass windows. Definitely worth a visit.

Loved this. This was my 4th time visiting this location. I love the history around every corner and the stained glass is so beautiful. We attended a classical music concert there as well one evening. Very reasonable price and great music. See all you can when you are inside the gates.
Beautiful. The Stained Glass was incredible. It was a great place to visit. Very cool. I would definiatley return. But buy tickets on line instead of waiting in line.

Slightly tired but still magnificent. St Chapelle by the standard of the cathedrals is quite small but is exquisite in much of its decoration. Even where the plaster has come away, you can easily see the work as a whole. The stained glass is beautiful. The church is on two levels, the lower level being accessed by an internal staircase. The stonework and sculptures on the outside are stunning and the gargoyles are great.
Lovely!. Don't miss seeing these floor-to-ceiling stained glass windows - truly lovely. It's hard to tell from the outside how genuinely beautiful it is!

Stain Glass and Structure. I entered this chapel and was overwhelmed. The construction is amazing. The stain glass windows are unimaginable. Each tells the story of the bible in the most brilliant of colors and artistic care.
surprise. The stained glass windows are like nothing one can imagine anywhere. Breathtaking. Felt there was a lot of missing sculpture. Definitely worth a visit.

Sacred space. We have had the privilege of visiting Paris three times in recent years. Finally, we got the chance to visit Sainte-Chapelle. The light coming through the stained glass windows was truly beautiful. The windows depict stories from the books of the Bible. We didn't do the audio tour but there were explanations of each. What I appreciated was the respect and reverence of the visitors so that the experience, while shared, was lovely.
Gorgeous Interior. Being inside on a sunny day is pretty spectacular. A very old chapel, with the most amazing stained glass you'll probably ever see - don't miss if you love stained glass!
gorgeous but tickets a bit overpriced. Really enjoyed it but compared to the other attractions in Paris the ticket is a bit overpriced. Doesn't take longer than 40/60 mins to visit if not less

Gothic jewllery box. It was a long and cold wait out on the street to get into this place, but it was worth it! Restoration work is currently underway, but most of the church has been completed with the huge, brilliantly colored stained glass windows surrounding you from all sides. While the church is not huge it is still large and an overwhelming, exhilarating space to be in.
Stunning. We attended a wonderful Vivaldi concert made all the more special by being able to view the wonderful stain glass windows and marvel at the structure.
Even with renovation. If you are going to the Notre Dame this is a must see attraction. It is just a short walk away on the west side of the island behind the Perfecture of Police.

Stained Glass Masterpiece. At Sainte Chapelle, when buying a ticket, we opted for the combo ticket to include the Conciergerie which is nearby and worth it. The Stained Glass at Sainte-Chapelle is a marvel and tells stories of the Bible from Moses to Jesus. Unfortunately while we were there, some construction was ongoing and some of the Stained Glass was blocked from view. Still so many beautiful panes to see with rays of light streaming through. A true Masterpiece!

Its an icon. I have seen it befor and it is an interesting place, and part of the central history of Paris. It will always be crowded and there were street kids hasseling people out the from, so keep your valuables safe.

A must see. This place was a little hard to find as it is inside the justice building, however we saw a huge line up and realized where it was quickly. It's a small little cathedral, but the real treasure is once you get inside and see the stain glass windows, unreal! And to think this level of detail was done so long ago. It's a short visit but a must see if you are in the area and visiting Notre Dame.

Stunning!. I love Sainte-Chapelle and wouldn't consider a trip to Paris without a visit. It sort of sneaks up on you, because you enter through the the lower floor and that is so beautiful you might think "that's it." Then, going up the spiral staircase into the main room, you are stunned by the beauty and colour. It's a small room, relatively speaking, so you may need to wait a bit to get photographs of the main altar area, but it's well worth the wait to get something that shows all the details of this amazing building. I spent a lot of time photo-capturing details of various elements, like the stained glass windows, the carvings of the saints, and so forth. It's almost too much to take in all at once, so richly is the room ornamented.If you are visiting several museums, consider getting the Paris Museum Pass -- it definitely will save you money.
Spectacular on a sunny day. It should rank very high on the list of must-sees for Paris visitors. The array of stained glass is amazing and especially radiant in full sunshine.

Stunning. Go on a sunny day to get the best effect of the stain glass. Be prepared to wait for a long time in line to go through security. If you have a museum pass, you can bypass the line. The is one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever been to. It's relatively small size makes it more intimate and not as overwhelming as some of the larger churches.

Ultimate Reverence. The church history is just fantastic.The glass windows are truly one of a kind, works of art.Depicting Biblical stories, the stained glass windows are the history of the Bible.Is is difficult to imagine the work that went into this church.Viewing just gives one a feeling of ultimate reverence.

Stunning, breath taking, beautiful... We were staying on Ile St Louis, so it was an easy walk over Ile de Le Cite, past Notre Dame to this stunning chapel with such incredible history. The queue only took about 5 minutes and through a security check. When you first enter the chapel it is lovely...but wait...walk up the spiral staircase to be AMAZED! Truly breath taking - don't miss this small but stunning chapel.

The most beautiful building for a classical performance. We saw and heard Vivaldi's four seasons performed here. It was one of the best experiences that I have ever had as a tourist. The chapel's stained glass windows are amazing. The musicians played with emotion and perfection. It was worth purchasing seats in the front rows.
Absolutely Stunning!!!. A must see and experience. The stained glass is absolutely breathtaking. The history and beauty is very rare. Absolutely splendid. A bit crowded but worth it.
A Gem in the middle of Paris. A gem in the middle of Paris. The 40 metre high stained glass windows were fantastic and the round window depicting the apocalypse was so beautiful.

Remarkable gem..not another gothic cathedral!. We arrived at 9am for the 9:30 opening, so were among the first in line. We also had Paris Museum passes...well worth getting in advance of a trip to the city. A policewoman warned the people in line of pick pockets working the area. We'd also been warned in the Musee D'Orsay the day before about thieves. We immediately went upstairs (a narrow, stone circular staircase) to take in the bejeweled light from the amazing stained glass windows surrounding the chapel before it became crowded. Beautiful! A reverent experience once restricted to the aristocrats. The people prayed below on the ground level. A nice gift shop awaits tourists now. Well worth a visit!

Stained-glass wonder. This site "lives up" to uts "pub". There are twolevels, with the upper one showing the world-famous windows. Be sure to get a written or oral guide to help with the history.
The security line includes EVERYONE - even those with a museum pass. There CAN be a long wait, but it's worth it, if you have the interest.
Don't miss. This little church is within the walls of France's supreme court. The history and windows are fantastic. Close to Notre Dame

Beautiful, go on a sunny day. There are two queues to endure: first, a line to get through a rather intense security check; second, a line for tickets. Having a Paris Museum Pass let us bypass both lines, although we were waiting in the security line for maybe 15 minutes before a security guard came outside, saw our passes and ushered us into a priority line that was just set up. There is not always someone outside watching the line and setting up a separate priority line for pass holders, so be prepared to wait even if you have a pass. Once we passed the security check, we were luckily able to skip the long line for tickets, which was just as long as the first line.It was an on-and-off rainy afternoon, so our visit would have been better timed on a more sunny day to fully illuminate the windows. The stained-glass windows were still impressive, but it was disappointing that maybe one-fifth of the windows were covered while undergoing restoration, and we could hear construction going on. Still, considering that our Museum Passes lessened our waiting time in line and paid for our admission, visiting Sainte-Chapelle was definitely worth it, and I knew I would have regretted missing it if we didn’t go.

splendid. I went here a few years ago and would recommend everyone to see it at least once. The windows are extremely high and there are many of them. Such a concentration of beauty is rare. Also notice the floor with many beautiful illustrations.
Highly recommended.. Recommended by a friend and was worth the queuing in the rain. It's on two levels and both exhibit loving care and high skill levels.
Long queue, not worth it. A very basic chapelle, an overrated attraction. Expect a long queue and a disappointing visit. It's better to see la conciergerie right next door.

Disappointing. Despite the quote of this tourist spot in many guides found the poor attraction and honestly I was disappointed. Returning to Paris would not lose my time in this attraction. Anything interesting, except the ceiling and his painting

Awe inspiring.. One of my top 3 favorite things in Paris. It's under renovation right now and that might account for the inches of dust on this amazing building. The whole thing is stained glass, the colors are still bright and crisp. The long wait through security is worth it. By far my favorite church I saw in Paris.

A lot of people.. Hard to get any good photos here, so make sure you pick the time that you go. I went just after lunch and this small Chapelle was packed, so it was really hard to get anything good, but regardless, it's worth a visit!

A Gothic Jewel Box. Too many people blow by Sainte-Chapelle in their hurry to Notre Dame. Slow down and see this fabulous little Gothic jewel just a short distance from Notre Dame. The security line doesn't take long and your Paris Museum Pass will give you admission.
Great concert in splendid surroundings. Listening to Vivaldi as the evening closed around us in Sainte-Chapelle. A memorable Paris experience!
Brilliant. So glad I went. Worth the queuing. The stain glass windows are something else. Recommend it to anyone.

Surprisingly Disappointing. I've been to Paris 10-12 times and have never visited Sainte-Chapelle but have been told by others its a must-see, so I went. I'll leave it off the itinerary next time. We went towards the end of the day but plenty of daylight to see the stained glass. I was surprised at the cost - 9.50 euros to get in. Definitely not worth it. Although half of the chapel was under construction and the windows on that side were not visible, even if they were, I don't think it is worth $13 dollars. We walked in, nodded our heads a few times and were done. Frankly, the stained glass windows in Notre Dame are as good or more grandiose. I also would suggest that they provide some sort of signage to guide you where to go after going through security. With how many visit, you would think you could find the chapel without having to ask where it is. Again, perhaps some people really like this, but for the price, I don't think it is worth it.

Stained glass paradise!. The stained glass in this church is freshly cleaned (they're almost done with the restoration) and amazing! Definitely worth a trip, but keep the lines in mind. It's included with the museum pass, but there's still security to get through. They have airport standards, so you may not get your pocket knife back. Trust me, it's worth your Swiss Army Card.

Stunning, incomparable, inspiring. I visit Sainte-Chapelle every time I come to Paris. The stained glass windows are incomparable. Because the chapel is so small, one feels immersed in their splendour. It's a very different experience from visiting the large cathedrals (though I'm a fan of those as well)

Stunning!. A marvellous medieval stained glass ex Royal Chapel, which on a combined ticket with Conciergerie is a way of avoiding longer queues for admission. The Conciergerie is fascinating, well presented and deeply moving - the former royal, political prison. Marie Antoinette's Cell is re-produced exceptionally .
Sainte Chapelle. This is simply an amazing building. Went to a concert in it and the acoustics are superb. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful. Some restoration is underway which impacts with the total effect. The concert was wonderful and I was lucky to been there on a sunny evening so the light made the windows stand out as they should.

Concert in St. Chapelle. St. Chapelle is another hidden place in Paris which not everyone knows about. We attended a string quartet here, and it was absolutely the perfect spot for this type of event.

Don't miss. Wow is an appropriate word as you enter. Do not miss. Get the double ticket at 11 Euros and visit the Concierge next door first, which was the prison. When you come out of there go to Set Chapelle BUT don't get in queue as your ticket allows you to walk straight in.

Masterpiece title deserved. After a day spent queuing in nearby Notre-Dame, I dreaded getting to the Chapel as I could see an extended queue from the street. The queue moved fast, the price tag is quite heavy (8.50€) for two small chapels that are currently undergoing heavy refurbishing. The lower one is quickly visited, the restoration works are very unbalanced with a splendid ceiling but poorly maintained painted murals. The top floor is much more impressive with its very high and narrow stained glass windows and rose, but about one third of the windows were undergoing refection and are not visible. Whereas in other historic sites the invisible area is covered by a copy of the artwork, the whole area here is boxed in white planks and the logo of the sponsor, and that is quite a terrible thing to see in one of the holiest and most emblematic places of worship in Europe. I would recommed you'd pass until the restoration works are over and buy instead postcards of the chapel as its most beautiful.

Well worth the trip. Getting in was a drag with all the usual "security" checking. But once you're inside this is beautiful. Trying to imagine how medieval Parisians viewed the soaring stained glass is a challenge. Don't only look up though. There are stunning views on the chapel's stone floor of hunting scenes and animals.

See when the sun is out. Beautiful collection of stained glass windows telling the Biblical story starting with creation on the left and continuing around. But even if you are not into "Biblical" stories, the colors are brilliant and the detail is unbelievable.

Very unique church. The long queue was worth it.Less than an hour. (Museum pass holders have no separate line). It is a very unique church with it's stain glass as main attraction. It's amazing. And you'll definitely wonder how long took them to finish those grandiose stain glass.

Underwhelming. We waited nearly an hour in line and paid 17 euros to see Sainte Chapelle about which I had read and had high expectations. When we finally got inside I confess that the experience was a real let down. The stained glass windows which are being refurbished were muted and dull. We climbed the spiral staircase to see the rose window and it too was being refurbished....several of the glass planes were very light in color and not natural at all. After 20 minutes we left regretting that we had stood in line for an hour to have the experience.

amazing old church. the stain glass windows are absolutely beautiful. unfortunately they are restoring on whole side of the chapel, so we didn't get the full effect of the walls of stain glass. Still, it is worth seeing.

Beautiful church-amazing craftsmanship. It is amazing that people made those windows-the craftsmanship that it took to do them is beyond compare. In a perfect world not line would be great, but it moves fast.

Fantastic. We did queue for the chapel - about 30-40 mins in total. When we first arrived on the ground floor we did wonder if it was worth it, we then went up the narrow stone staircase and gasped, it was absolutely gorgeous.The windows were beautiful, one of the best churches I have ever seen.Definetely worth the queue.

Definitely worth it if you have a museum pass. I'm not sure i would have laid to see it, but my husband and I had museum passes and this was included so we could skip the line and not pay a separate admission fee. We listened to the free Rick Steve's audio guide tour so we got more of the history and it was amazing. The stained glass is beautiful!

Rick Steeves recommended this in his book Thumbs Up. THis was in Rick Steeves Paris book on his walking tour and it was amazing. I recommend stopping here - it isn't expensive but worth the stop. It will open your eyes.

An artistic and architectural gem. This chapel was built by Saint Louis to exhibit his crown of thorns (since moved to Notre Dame) but the real show is the stained glass. It was a feat of gothic architecture to move the weight of the roof via flying buttresses to the ground and so free the walls to be thin enough to be mostly stained glass. The colors of much of these windows were a trade secret which even modern science can't replicate. Go even if the line seems long; it moves quickly, and for god's sake do not let them know you are more than a group of 4 (spread out a little if you have to) or they may refuse you admission. This is free the first Sunday in each month and also to kids under 18 with international student ID. Another pointer, don't be put off by the room as you enter, as it is only the basement, the real show is upstairs via the spiral staircase!

Must do!. I remember learning about Sainte Chapelle's magnificent stained glass in 8th grade French class decades ago and finally saw it first hand. Singularly the most amazing stained glass I've ever seen - and I do search for it everywhere we go! The architecture of the lower level of the church is also very pretty, but somewhat dark. Others have commented on the stairs being an issue. I don't remember having a problem with them and I have a bad knee. I am not claustrophobic so maybe that is the real issue. Regardless, well worth the climb to see the windows. Hint: There was a huge long line earlier in the day but we went at 5:30, one half hour before last admission and it seemed they were only admitting people with the Museum Pass at that point. No wait and not a huge crowd inside.
Great concert, but too cold. We went to a concert in April, the performers were good, great music but the church was extremely cold, we had to leave before the end.

Vivaldi's Four seasons a real treat. We had the privilege of attending Vivaldi's Four Seasons at St Chapelle during our stay Paris. it was magical with the sun setting and illuminating the awe inspiring stain glass and great acoustics and talented musicians. We will never forget this experience.

Saint Chapelle Windows. This is a smaller church than the Notre Dame or the Sacre Coeur, but it is a must see in Paris for its stained glass windows, which are absolutely stunning, and if you manage to visit on a sunny day, you will see lots of coloured patterns created on the upper floor of the building.
One of the best. Breathtaking stained glass. This part of Paris needs time and is best explored on foot and without a tour group. So much to see and it all starts here

Classical music concert was breathtaking. We got tickets for the Vivaldi 4 seasons at the Sainte-Chapelle and it was absolutely incredible. We chose the most expensive tickets since it was a special occasion, and since within the ticket categories the seating is first-come first-served, we ended up with front row seats! I was thrilled. The players were lively and the music was beautiful, as you would expect it to be. A few additional pieces were played in addition to Vivaldi's, making the concert about 1 hour long. I would really recommend this to classical music fans - it is one of THE most beautiful places you will go to see a concert!One note - no heating or A/C in the chapel, so dress for the weather (hat/gloves or small hand-fan, etc).
Breathtaking stained glass. Your breath will be taken away by the beauty of the stained glass windows. They are absolutely awe inspiring! This is a stop you don't want to miss while in Paris.

Spectacular visit with concert. This has always been one of our favorite places (not just in Paris), but we were fortunate this time to see a concert perfomance on a recent Saturday night. It was a small group playing but it was one of the best things we have ever experienced. The church is great in and of itself but adding the beautiful music was wonderful.

Stained Glass windows worth viewing. Beautiful old church with stunning stained glass windows. Chapel felt a bit stuffy which when crowed could be uncomfortable. It is quite small so one of the easier sites to see in Paris

Under construction. The windows are fantastic to view but doesn't take long and some of the windows are closed due to cleaning. From the ones that weren't done yet, they sorely need it. But the ones that have been done are beautiful.

Amazing. We did wait a bit to get in, but it was well worth the wait. You can use your museum pass, which if you plan to visit a few museums and/or cathedrals, that is the way to go. We bought our pass here since it was the first place we hit, but it would be smart to buy your pass at one of the other museums first since we could have went right in and not have to wait in line if we had the passes first. The chapel is on the grounds of the justice palace, so you do have to go through security and there are sign everywhere of what you cannot bring in. Leave your forks at home or else they may be confiscated. I was worried about my cork screw (as I always have one in my purse), but they never took that. You enter on the ground floor. It is a bit dark, but the colors are amazing. They have their souvenir shop right in this area which distracts a bit from the beauty of the chapel. Once you have viewed the downstairs, you can take the spiral staircase to the top. It was not that difficult of a climb and there were a lot of older people that made it up to the top. Breath taking. The stained glass is incredible and it is hard to take it all in as there is so much to see. Each of the stained glass windows tells a story, but if you have any ADD, you will have difficulty focusing to get to that story, well, at least I did, anyway. I think if there were not so many people there, I could have stayed there for hours. They are restoring and cleaning the glass, so one of the panels was completely covered. You can see where they have and have not cleaned yet. I imagine if you time your visit right and get there when the late afternoon sun beams through these windows the reflecting light must be spectacular. It was breathtaking when we were there and it was a cloudy day. Once you exit, you leave through the justice court yard. The gates here are amazing too. Worth a photo or two.

Stunning…………….. La Sainte-Chapelle is a gem that I first learned of when preparing for this trip to the British Isles and the Continent. If you visit Notre Dame Cathedral, by all means take a walk a couple of streets to the West and find La Sainte-Chapelle. We were there on a sunny day in May, and there was a line, but it moved fast and there was no charge. At the entrance around back, notice the Biblical carvings of Christ, Noah’s Ark and others. Looking at such an array of depictions, it was very nearly the Bible told in stone. As we stepped inside, there were people just standing and gazing up toward the high stained glass windows. We soon followed suit. No one can help being in awe of such a colorful setting. You can take your time, as there was no time limit. La Sainte-Chapelle is on the island of Ile de la Cite in the Seine as Notre Dame Cathedral.

Oh....the stairs. This is a beautiful church but you have to climb up this horrid circular staircase with uneven steps and no windows to get to it. The stained glass is fantastic but the climb was hard and clausterphobic.

Expectacular. Read the history and simbols first and them go to this place. Dont forget the neir places around.Recomiendo ver la historia primero y luego ir a verla sin dejar de lado los alrededores de la misma.
Conserve your energy for this treat. Those who manage a very steep, twisted staircase are rewarded magnificently with views of the unique, glorious stained glass windows. A definite must see.

Most Amazing stained glass I have seen. The stained glass in this church is amazing - most of it has been slowly restored and there are some areas that are yet to be done but overall it is amazing. Worth the wait in the queue. Access is limitied up and down a narrow flight of spiral stairs.

Go and face the Music. The glass is amazing and I agree with Annandale2 that its worth going to a concert. We went to Vivaldi's Four Seasons. Cold evening and a bit draughty in the cheap seats at the back but could hear perfectly well because of the amazing acoustics

A tiny church with a big WOW!. If the lines are not too long, stop in this church for some impressive stained glass. This church has one of the largest stained glass displays I have ever seen. A big WOW.
Awsome stained glass. The entire chapel is beautiful but the stained glass will take your breath away. The more you know of the story behind the glass the better you will enjoy your visit.

Music!! at Sainte-Chapelle. As others have written, the church is a wonder. But do a little research and try to attend a concert there; it will be a long-remembered highlight of your trip. We thoroughly enjoyed a wonderful evening of Saint Saens (The Swan), Massenet (the "Meditation" elicited tears), and many more. The acoustics were excellent and the evening came to an end too soon.

Wow! Beautiful Stained Glass!. St. Chappelle some of the most beautiful stained glass that I have ever seen! There was a steep spiral staircase, so you may want to check into this if you are mobility impaired. We bought the combo ticket which also included the Concierge (prision which detained Marie Antoinette). There was a long line at St. Chappelle. May be a good idea to buy the combo ticket at the less popular Concierge to avoid this line. Close to Notre Dame. Well worth a visit!

Those stain-glass windows!!!. We never tire of looking at the stain glass windows at Ste. Chapelle! The iconic rose window is amazing. They're finishing a major restoration project of the windows and they look great.
Glorious. The afternoon sun coming through the stained glass is not to be missed. Amazing and inspiring. I only wish there was a place to quietly sit and soak in the feeling of peace.
Don't miss out on history. Sainte Chapelle gives great insight to historical roots of France. It is awesome to walk into history dating to 13th century. Like Notre Dam this is a must

Beautiful ..... This is a must see little church. Different in scale to others but just as breathtaking. On the upper floor you are very close to the glass which is still magnificent despite some being shrouded under repair. We didnt get to a concert here but I think it would be fabulous.

Beautiful Upper Floor. When we went to Saint-Chappelle, you first enter into the ground level, which has a few original relics and small stained glass but is basically just a gift-shop. Fear not, this isn't what you pay for.Upstairs, the stained glass is phenomenal. At first, due to the massive box covering half of the walls, I was a bit disappointed. However, I'm glad I got to see pre/post reno stained glass. There is a video playing showing the process each piece of glass goes through and it gives you an incredible appreciation for the already-finished pieces and what they are currently undertaking. This place is a gem, and it is located just a few blocks from Notre Dame and close to other places like Pont Neuf. Definitely worth detouring over to if you are already planning on going to the area.

Impressive Stained Glass. A little difficult to find the entrance, we used our pass again to go through the church. It is inconceivable to me how these buildings are constructed and how the stained glass is made. We did not use an audio guide or do much research, and if we had, perhaps we could have given this attraction a greater review. Nonetheless, we were in a hurry but did appreciate the size and composition.

Still renovating. The last few times we have been here, much of the upper floor has been under renovation. Although not all the stained glass is available for viewing, the windows that are viewable are cleaned and brilliantly shining; on a sunny day they are absolutely breathtaking. I enjoy the rich colors and decor on the ground floor, but upon emerging from the winding staircase, the light in the chapel is other-worldly beautiful. This is not the first sight tourists think to visit in Paris, but it is worthwhile and takes very little time to visit once past the security lines.

Magnificent stained glass works. The beautiful stained glass works are magnificent. The church is presently undergoing restoration which to some degree detracts from the experience. However, definitely worth the time to visit and admire.

Under repair but still wonderful. Currently Sainte-Chapelle is under renovations but it is still open. To truly appreciate the Church, buy tickets for the Vivaldi or Baroque string quartet that is held several times a week. It is an amazing experiences

Mind Blowing. Heard about this from a friend in country Victoria. So as it was only 5 mins from our hotel ,an amazing find of beauty and historic interest. Not well known or publicised .well worth entrance fee and que to get in

One of the most pleasant experience. I get recomendation from my friend to see Sainte Chapelle. We went there with my wife and we both agree that it's amazing and beatiful chapelle we ever see. I recommend to see it, and if possible go there by morning as there is a big queue for security check. It's worst to wait couple of minutes. We spent there more then one hour and I took a lot of pictures.

See a concert here.... The place is beautiful. Don't just do the tourist trample here. Come in the evening and enjoy a classical concert here. You will listed to professional musicians while marveling in the beauty of this chapel.

So beautiful! Attending a concert here was magical. We were lucky enough to get tickets for a 7:00 pm concert in the chapel. The music was wonderful, as were the chapel's acoustics. Seeing the chapel's stained glass illuminated by the setting sun, while listening to Vivaldi was truly magical. If you get the opportunity to attend a concert here, do it!
A real "Wow"!. Really worth a visit to have a look at the gorgeous windows. Get the Museum Pass to skip the lines. T

We are so glad we chose to visit Sainte-Chapelle. We found the lines into Notre Dame too overwhelming so went to Sainte-Chapelle and were very happy we did. You have to go through the security inspection for the Courts that surround the cathedral, but the line moved quickly. The whole Palace of Justice area is a magnificent site. The lower level of Sainte-Chapelle is a gift shop. Then you climb ancient winding stairs to the chapel with the famous windows. When I was almost at the top of the stairs, I could actually hear the 2 people in front of me each gasp as they entered into the room. The windows are stunning. The renovation is a distraction. Our cameras were inadequate to get a photo to show the height and beauty of the windows. I would love to return when the renovation is completed.

A gem not to be missed!. One of the few things we did on our own not on a tour. I happened on it by accident in 2006 while visiting Paris with friends and insisted my daughter had to see it. We waited in line 45 minutes and she found out what a gem this little church hidden away inside a labyrinth of other buildings is. Built by Louis XIV to house his purchase of a religious relict, the 'crown of thorns' from the crucifixion (now at Notre Dame). The ground level is all hand painted in beautiful colors and is where the common people worshiped. Up a winding little staircase to the second level is a grand chapel painted in light streaming through a multitude of stained glass windows where the rich and royal worshiped. They are currently restoring the church and the last window is nearly done. Then they will begin the painted work downstairs. Even with the construction it is worth seeing.

Put your fingers in your ears and just keep looking up.... The restoration works currently ongoing are deafening and certainly spoil a visit, but if you stand with your back to them, you'll still be able to appreciate the beautiful stained glass. Surprisingly breathtaking.

Will surprise you. We went over while passing the Île de la Cité without even planning to get in there (we had planned it a few days before, but it was closed at that time). The line was not as long as most people tend to state it is, so we decided to try it out. As EU citizens under 26, we did not need to pay anything for the tickets. But even if one has to pay to enter, it is definitely worth it.The security seemed tight, but the people working there were nice and it was not a bother. But they would take dangerous stuff from people trying to enter and would never return it, so be advised if you wish to have a kitchen knife or something like that (for what ever reasons). The bottom floor was not too special. I have to say, as a person who had not done much reading about the Chappel, I was a little bit disappointed at first. But once we got up to the next floor, it got breath-taking. It was easily the most beautiful Church I had ever seen (and I have seen quite a few). The only downside was the fact that the windows were in the process of renovation. Most of them had already been cleaned, but a few were covered (because the glass was taken out for cleaning) and some had not been cleaned yet. So it was not as amazing as it could have been. But that was a few months ago, so I guess it should be finished by now.P.S. Before you leave the area, make sure you enter the Palais de Justice. Going through the security for Sainte-Chapelle is the only way for unauthorized personnel to enter the palace. It is not exactly a tourist attraction, as it is actually a working court palace, but the sheer size of it and the architecture is something worth seeing. Especially since it is free.

A Brilliant Bijou. The lines are long. You'll wonder if it's worth the wait.Hold on! Sainte-Chappelle's is definately a wonder. As you climb the spiral stairway and enter the upper chapel you are blinded by a kaleidoscope of brilliant monumental stained glass windows. The 1,113 scenes depicted in the 15 windows illustrate books from the bible..Genesis through Christ's resurrection. Just trust me on this one and go take a look for yourself....Prepare to be awe-struck!

The gem of Paris. This is the most exquisite church I have ever seen. Beyond description--one simply has to go. Security is extremely tight and I would advise purchasing tickets ahead as there will still be a long and very worthwhile wait. Notre Dame pales next to St-Chapelle!

Astonishing!. Absolutely beautiful! Now under partial restoration of the windows in the upper church. Nonetheless an absolute must-see. The visit itself doesn't need to take long, but since the Chapel is inside the courtyard of the Palace of Justice you w.9ill need to go through security check. There was a pretty long line, but, as said, absolutely worth waiting

Stunning stained glass!. Stunning stained glass, this place is such a treat! From the outside, one would never guess the beauty inside! We attended a concert here on Easter - lovely, BUT there is no heat and is was COLD. (The violinist kept tucking his hands under his arms between songs.) The bathroom was atrocious, but that shouldn't talk you out of visiting. Don't miss out on this incredible place - just make sure to use a bathroom elsewhere first...

Unbelievable. This place is totally unbelievable. It would have been better if there was not construction going on inside and outside of the building but it was never the less breath taking. It cost 8 euros to get in. Go later in the day or the off season to avoid long lines.

Fantastic!. We Were first in line. Security check required as chapel is in the justice complex. This causes wait time in line up to be a bit slower.Stained class walls of chapel were simply awesome. I would say a must see.
You really need to see it.. My Mum said "You HAVE to go there" so we did, and we were very glad. What an amazing place. Make sure you go upstairs because that is where it will take your breath away.
Europe Trip 2013. A must for all visitors. Hidden away in the police station near Notre Dame. Stained glass wonder. Absolutely beautiful. It even enthralled our grandkids.

Magical. This little Chapel is a magical experience. The stained glassed windows are the best I have experienced and whilst the chapel itself is small - it is the hand-painted glass windows that make it huge... A must-see on your list of things to see when in Paris

Beautiful. Go for the Stained Glass alone. The jewel like splendor is incredible. This little chapel in the heart of the Ile de la Cite is surrounded by the functioning justice system of the capitol. Lots of history here. and that ceiling!!

Spectacular Stained Glass. Pictures really don't do this former royal chapel justice. You have to see this one in person. At the moment they are restoring and cleaning the glass. You can see a huge difference when you look at a panel of cleaned glass and one layered with the grim of centuries. You will have to pass through airport like security to enter the lower and upper chapels in this must see Paris attraction.
waw. if you are in Paris you must not miss this small but impressive church. The windows are amazing when the sun is lighting them up.

Stunning windows. Queued for about an hour. Sainte-Chapelle comprises of 2 smallish chapels. The lower is pretty much devoid of light but the intense decor and colour is impressive. The upper chapel is where the stained glass resides that everyone raves about. It is impressive and vast but there is little else to see if stained glass is not your thing. I think three of the windows were being restored as part of an ongoing project while we were there and were completely covered, so we did not get the full effect.
Lovely stain glass windows. This is small but included on the Museum Pass. Some windows are being repaired. Go upstairs to see the most beautiful windows.
beautiful. Hard to describe how beautiful the windows are. Must see attraction. Under construction to clean and refurbish windows.

A must see while in Paris. We saw many different cathedrals and churches while in Europe. This chapel one of the most memorable-- particularly if you desire to see beautiful stained glass windows. You could spend hours admiring the architecture and design of the building itself, and then looking at these windows which reflect many, many books of the Bible. It would take days to decipher them all. Very intricate and beautiful!
A hidden jewel. This is truly an amazing little chapel that few people visit. Many Parisians have never visited. Glass windows are amazing!!
Not worth the entry fee. Great little place to visit, but only go if you have a museum pass, otherwise the fee is far to steep considering what is on offer!
Concert at Saint Chapelle. We ordered tickets on line for concert here although there was room for others. No heat so dress warmly. Wonderful place to hear music.
Beautiful spot to see and rest a bit. Enjoyed visiting this church in Paris. Music was being played and we enjoyed a rest and to get out of the rain.

Mind-blowing stained glass/ soaring roof.. If you only see one thing in Paris- make sure you see this. Outside as depicted in Les Tres Riches Heures (June), on the right hand-side of the skyline (with pinacles).
very expensive!. This was very ancient and very beautiful but very small! It took about 3 minutes to walk around and cost us 18 euros for the 2 of us!

Stunning Stained Glass. The stained glass is awe inspiring. The chapel stands alone in its beauty and historical significance. Notre Dame may dominate but Sainte-Chapelle is quite charming and a must see.

Absolutely stunning!!!. This small church near Notre-Dame is a must see!! The stained glass is amazing! We would never have known about it, but my cousin recommended it. It is hidden behind modern walls, but once you step up to the second floor.... Prepare to be amazed!! Try to go on a sunny day if at all possible.
Stain Glass Heaven. Beautiful! Don't miss this amazing Church. You won't regret it. Lines aren't too bad compared to other sites/museums.

Such a lovely set of windows inspiring. The windows in this church are amazing. You have to go upstairs to get the full picture, and the stairs are very winding but the windows are worth it. Use the guides to explain the windows or even better download Rick Steves guide. It is true the windows fill in the skeleton of the church, they take up more than 80% of the wall space. It is such a pity that unenlightened bereaucrats built out the light for about 1/3 of the windows. But do go when the light is good to get the best effect
Stained glass. This is the most amazing chapel. A Paris must see. It is not far from Notre dame but cost about E8.50 to get in.
Lovely church but not sure if the wait was worth it.. Beautiful stained glass and architecture. But very, very small. You could go in and out in under half an hour with your museum pass.

Not to be missed. Ancient church built by St. Louis. Must be seen on a sunny day or don't even waste your time. This is on a joint ticket with the fascinating Conciergerie. Highly recommend the Parius Museum Pass to Cover both of these as well as all the other great Museums of Paris. Eliminates the waiting on line!!!!! Purchase it at the Tabac Souvenir stand across from the Conciergerie. It seems expensive but when you start walking past the others waiting in a 45 - 60 minute line you have just enriched the time spent at these unique places

Security is slow, and Sainte-Chapelle is small, but lovely. This beautiful Chapel is quite magnificent. The stained glass windows are quite lovely, and are best seen on sunny days. We waited in line for entrance through security longer than any other place in a week in Paris, but I'd do it again.

A special place. We hadn't booked, or got a pass so we queued to go through the metal detector. There was a notice to say that those with passes had to queue with the rest anyway. That obviously is variable! About a 20 minute wait for the metal detector - none at all for the ticket booth.The under-chapel was full of rich colour, but not a lot of light.The main upper chapel was different! Sadly, it wasn't a sunny day - that might have been spectacular - and two of the 15 bays are shrouded in scaffolding as part of the immense task of renovating all the fabulous stained glass.We hired the audio guide which I would score at only 5 out of 10.

Worth the wait in line. A couple lines, but worth it for the cool stained glass and fancy building. It was neat to see the seating arrangements inside -- one for normal folks, one for VIPs -- connected by twisty narrow stairs. A neat old church.

Go here only if there is no queue!. We queued for an hour, the security here held up the whole queue, and when we went in, we were there for only 10 minutes, our museum pass didnt allow us to jump the queue!
Stunning!. Awe inspiring beauty. Go here. The lines are not too long and it's near Notre Dame, so if you are intimidated by the lines there then come here instead.

Spooky. I never tire of visiting the Ste Chappelle. Stained glass is unbelievable on a sunny day. Wait for bright sunshine to visit if you can. A lot of the windows are currently being restored - not sure when that will be finished. This detracts considerably from overall experience, but still worth a visit.

Mon dieu! The windows!. Even with a Paris Pass, you have to queue outside in the freezing cold (or other weather) to get through security. Once inside, you can skip the next queue if you have the Pass. The actual chapel is stuck in the middle of the Defence buildings, hence the security. In the chapel itself, you have to climb some narrow spiral stairs to get into the main Chapel, where you are met with THE most incredible stained glass you will probably ever see. Incredible stuff. One wall is being renovated, but the rest are all there in their ancient, shining glory. Amazing.

Let the Sun Shine In. Ok, after the metal detector check point, go around to the front of the line if you have the Museum Pass - they don't learly mark that there is a separate line for the pass holders, but there is, so just go to the front. It is beautiful colored glass with the sun streaming through.......a lovely visual, religious experience.

Hidden Gem. We decided to come here based on review from Trip Advisor. We came here very early in the morning before it opened and only had to wait 15-20 min. My Dad and I, while our wives were in line, walked over to one of the cafes and picked up some bread and juice for breakfast which was nice to eat while we waiting. It is very small but make sure to go to the upper room. There are some small stairs to go up and then BAM there are these beautiful stained glass windows that are stunning. Again some people gave some bad reviews but that is really the only reason to come here. If you aren't into this then it might not be your cup of tea. Plus the morning sun was coming in and it lit up most of the windows. My Dad creates and build stained glass windows so this was a treat for us. I am not sure but I believe this may or may not be on the Paris Museum Pass. I apologize but double check if it is.

glorious stained glass. this chapelle have the most bueatifull stained glass art windows i have ever seen and i have seen a lot ,notre dame,cathederal,stpauls in london,st peters in rome,mont st michel i france,canterbury cathedral,st marks in venice ,st georges in england nd wesminster abbey to name a few,the sunlight through the glass is breath taking,this was a vist to remember,if you buy ticket for chapelle with conciergerie ,you wont have to join long lines to get in.

Vivaldi concert. Just had an awesome experience attending the concert of Vivaldi at Saint Chapelle. The acoustics were phenomenal...what an awesome way to experience this beautiful structure. The "blues" were so, blue, yet the vibrancy of the colors in the stained glass images pierced like a knife...the word,"beautiful" comes to mind, but that word is really an understatement. Saint Chapelle is a must see and a concert within, is definitely a "should see."

Vivaldi concert. Just had an awesome experience attending the concert of Vivaldi at Saint Chapelle. The acoustics were phenomenal...what an awesome way to experience this beautiful structure. The "blues" were so, blue, yet the vibrancy of the colors in the stained glass images pierced like a knife...the word,"beautiful" comes to mind, but that word is really an understatement. Saint Chapelle is a must see and a concert within, is definitely a "should see."

Little gem in the midst of court buildings.. Gorgeous stained glass windows - but you need to go upstairs to see them. Be aware that the stairs are quite steep. This church is in the middle of some courthouse and/or jail buildings, so you have to go through security before you enter the grounds - so don't bring a pocket knife or other sharp object. It closes for lunch so check your timetable. Very close to Notre Dame on Ile de la Cite.

Beautiful, but with long lines. We visited Sainte-Chapelle but only got to see the outside of it. They charge 8,50 for entrance inside and the line was long and not moving well. The outside of the church is gorgeous though, and you can see the stained glass windows from the public area outside. I think the next time we go to Paris we will bear with the line to see the inside, it seemed worth it.

time waster. If you really dont have any idea whats to do in Paris thats for you.After waiting 1 hour in queue it was really disappointment for me.Lot of old windows and small church inside,thats it.After no more than 5 minutes go to exit with sad expresiion on my face.another waste of time.Just dont forget to pay for for ticket with access to consigliere aswel so you can save couple of euros

Stained glass heaven. As the tour books suggest, this site is a must see for chapel and stained glass enthusiast. Do your homework before you show up and your experience will be even more significant. Each panel overs a glimpse of some biblical theme. They do provide some literature that helps, but wish we had more details during our stay. Also was a bit disappointed by the massive scaffolding that obscured one entire side of the chapel.

A JEWEL IN THE SKY. The title says it all - beware to be bedazzled by this stained glass masterpiece. When brightly lit by one of those beautiful Paris days, feast yourself on the colors that dazzle and sparkle the eye. A must see and one you will never tire of.

Stunning. Well worth the queue (approx 20 minutes when we visited) and the obligatory security check. The stained glass is amazing, as is the interior in general. I would suggest buying a guidebook before you visit so one can fully appreciate the stained glass and interior. The long, narrow and winding staircase to the impressive upper chapel can be something of a bottle neck, but the spectacle of the stained glass is well worth any minor inconvienience.
Paris. a must to see and just looking at all of the stained glass windows is so beautiful go on a sunny day
An absolute jewel. See it during the day, but go back in the evening for a classical music concert. Always an important part of my visits to Paris.

very Breathtaking Saint-Chapelle. While my husband and I were in Paris, France, we went to Sainte-Chapelle and it was breathtaking! After you climb up the very small, winding staircase, you come into the Chapel and the stained glass windows take your breath away! It was one of the best churches I have been in. We went to Notre Dame Cathedral also and it was very beautiful, but so touristy and huge. This was so much more intimate and well worth the wait in line thru security. A must see in Paris!

Worth the visit. This chapel is worth the visit if you like beautiful stained glass windows. It is off the beaten path and not very crowded (when I visited). It makes a difference if you see the windows in the sunlight as they are magnificent.

Joint ticket. Very impressed with this place. Make sure you buy the joint ticket with the Concierge as that is also well worth a visit. Good 2 to 3 hours needed to appreciate this place. Good on a Saturday as an alternative to the queues at Notre Dame
Long wait. This was a very, very long que the leadlights in the chapel were lovely but would not do again sure there are many beautiful churches in Paris.

Beautiful Stained Glass. When looking to enter, there is only one line for everyone to enter. It's only the security search, once inside there is another line to purchase the tickets to enter. Make sure you have your museum pass to bypass the long line. The stained glasses are beautiful to see and you can get some great pics. You may not spend that much time inside since the space you are allowed to enter is not that spacious.

It's all about the stained glass...wow.. At first I didn't understand what all the hype was about...another church! Well, once you walk into the Church you understand why - it is all about the stained glass. It is absolutely break- taking. We did wait on a long line to get in due to the high security and the visit was short since there is not a whole lot to see. But, the parts you can see are well worth the wait in line. You can just stand there and be mesmerized by the stained glass - it is colorful and plentiful. With the sun shining through it is a great sight to see.

Gorgeous! A must see in Paris.. Ensure you visit in daytime on a sunny day. We visited on a Saturday. What a juxtaposition with Notes Dame (which is still an active cathedral). There are concerts in St Chapelle which would be awesome.

A beautiful church. This is a beautiful space, and I was amazed at the stained glass, especially considering the age. It is also a nice place away from the big crowds at Notre Dame, as it is a small intimate space. It is worth the time to go check it out!

Go at opening time to avoid the long and slow lines. Since it is in the Palais de la Justice, this chapel requires strict security checks, but the stained glass windows are worth the wait. Evening concerts are held here -- ask for a schedule.

Stunning!. Sainte-Chapelle is the most beautiful place we visited in Paris. We had the Paris Pass, which helped us avoid one line, however we still had to go through security, so entrance took a while. Words cannot really describe this chapel. The bottom floor was beautiful and we were able to take our time and enjoy every aspect. As we followed people up the stairs we heard exclamations of "Wow!" and added our own "Wow"s once we reach the top. The stained glass was magnificent and you can follow the stories of the Bible on individual panes. I could have stayed here the entire afternoon. This beat the Louvre hands down for me!
BEAUTIFUL!. The stained glass is truly stunning. There was construction on one wall while we were there, so that was a little sad. But I would love to visit again.
Unbelievable. Do NOT miss the stained glass windows...stunning. Look for a concert there as the acoustics are wonderful and the setting is like no other.

reno..... The Sainte-Chapelle was under a lot of renovation. Half of the vitraux covered by tarps but still the same access price. Cold in March, probably not heated. The other half was still very beautiful

Stay in queue. Not far from Notre Dame, it is a most attractive piece of architecture to see in Paris. In MHO it is the best small gem of the medieval architecture. Spend half an hour in queue. It worth it. Other objects in the palace of justicia are not as attractive as this one.

Nice place. We had to wait about 20 min in line... if it'd been longer, I would 've left probably... still, a nice church/chapel and the stained glass is cool to see on a sunny day, with the reflections and all. But it's not a must-see in my opinion, if you have enough time to spend in Paris, do go there. If you're on a tight schedule, you can skip it...

Worth the Money for the Visit. I was hesitant at first to visit this church because there was a charge to go inside, but I was not in the least disappointed! Huge stained glass windows greeted me when I entered this church! It is an amazing site in Paris, simply not to be missed! Also, the ticket includes the Consierge next door so its worth the price for two! Go and enjoy!

I was very underwhelmed. Clearly a significant feat for it's day but it was anticlimactic for me. Ok, a lot of stained glass... Make sure you get a museum pass so you don't spend your day in a long line for this.

Undergoing renovations. Its very nice but under no circumstance is this the finest stained glass ever. Firstly the crown of thorns is now housed at yhe Notre-Dame. Secondly its undergoing a major renovation. Catch a classical concert here which would be magical.

Exquisite stained glass windows. This is a lovely find -a chapel on top of another chapel! The lines were not long and it was worth every moment. Covered in stained glass panels, each window represents a different book in the Bible, from Genesis and Exodus through the Passion of Christ.
Spectacular stained glass. Beautiful old church with spectacular stained glass. Currently the last section of stained glass is being restored. Magnificent beauty!

Mind blowing stained glass windows. It is well worth finding this chapel to see the expansive stained glass windows in the upper chapel. There is a nice little gift shop on lower level. Be careful of the winding staircase if mobility problems.
Beautiful - Must See. The most beautiful stain glass windows in Paris. Currently restoring the last set of stain glass windows. But a must see when in Paris!

It was glorious. The windows are being restored. It's unbelievably, jaw-droppingly beautiful. We came back to attend a chamber concert. I can't really recommend it as a concert venue (it was really cold, and the acoustics are kind of awful.) But gosh -- to sit in that beautiful place and hear great music? Even if it wasn't perfect, it was still amazing.

Beautiful Sainte-Chapelle. We were at this beautiful site on Easter Day. No service at the time.. a bit of a line but not bad to get in. I almost missed the main attraction: there is a tiny circular stairway inside the main door to the right that has 36 stairs that lead up to the most fantastic display of stained glass I have ever seen.

Well worth the long wait. On our first trip to Paris eight years ago, we skipped this church because of the long line. I am so glad we toughed it out this time. The stained glass windows are spectacular and a definite must-see. In addition to the awe-inspiring experience, we got some excellent pictures that we plan to frame and use as artwork in our home!

Didn't go because.... We were sick of lines - We realise you can't avoid them all however when you pay for a 'museum pass' and are let in to a lot of other places by passing the ticket line it's disappointing when at Sainte Chapelle they make you stay in the ticket line even though you have effectively already bought your ticket. If it was a line to just get in after having already bought a ticket (like versaille, we still waited for an hour) I would understand.

Unbelievable find. This is a definite must!!. My fiance and I, visited Sainte-Chapelle on Easter Sunday. The queous were slightly long, but it was more than worth it. This is such an unbelievable find. People go to Notre-dame, but should defintely visit this. And its only a 5 min walk from the Notre-Dame.This is just too unbelievable to describe. The church has the most beautiful vitro glass depictions that are just huge. The Apostoles and its statues are also something that takes your breath away. Please, please visit.Only drawback, is its not free. We paid 18Euros, but the place is undergoing some restoration, so the money is needed for thar

Beautiful little chapel being renovated. We went to Saint Chapelle to see the stained glass windows, but many on one side were covered and in the process of a renovation, which was a bit disappointing.

Most superb church. As a culture historian, I can only say one thing: visit, visit and revisit. By the way, it's one of the buildings on the month of June page of the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry

Amazing vitrage. The lower level seems deceiving, and you might wonder what was everybody talking about, but the second floor goves the "wow" effect.The windows are amazong, and some people stay for about an hour exploring each vitrage.

Try to catch a concert at Saint Chapelle. This is one of the prettiest and oldest churches in Paris. One of the ways to avoid the lines is to reserve a seat for an evening concert. The church is not heated so dress accordingly.

Almost unworldly. Ste Chappelle is a two-level chapel built by the French royal family in the middle ages. The ground floor level (for the commoners) has some stunning frescoes, but is the upstairs royal chapel that really takes your breath away. The walls are almost entirely stained glass, extending right up to the vaulted ceiling, and with only narrow columns between. As mentioned by other reviewers, restoration of the glass is taking place, so a good quarter of the windows is hidden behind a screen - this does detract from the sensation, but it is still well worth seeing. We went on a dull, overcast day, and I would suggest that (as all the illumination comes from outside) a bright sunny day would be even better.We also attended a concert which was excellent, but very very cold. Make sure you are rugged up in winter, and try to get there early for the best seats.On your way out, take time for another look at the ground floor - everybody is in a hurry to get upstairs to see the glass, and the exquisite quality of the little chapel is often overlooked.

Great, but under construction. So you do not see the one side. This is probably one of the most important gothic examples in the world and one of the most beautiful glass stained windows ever made. The line can be long, so better get a paris pass.
Stunning. This is something you really need to see if you are in Paris, it's breathtaking, even while under reconstruction.

Magical windows, try to catch a concert. We attended the Easter concert with classical music (string quartett and eight singers). It was an amazing way to catch the evening light in the stained glass Windows and study the details that I would certainly have overlooked. The concert took a Little over an hour.Here are three things I would have appreciated knowing beforehand:1 No heating so wrap up really warm (bring a hat, no dress code)2 The chapel is part of the ministry of justice, so the security check meant a 10-15 minute line for getting onto the compound (they wait for all to get in before they start)3 about 15% more tickets were sold than they had available chairs - we had to sit on the church's side benches, very cold stone. so either go early or bring a cushion (I sat on my handbag) Here is the link where we got our tickets:http://www.classictic.com/en/search/?country=france-4&city=parisEnjoy!

Attend a concert. This is a gorgeous chapel next to the Notre Dame cathedral , the visit is definitely worth it but i would highly recommend attending one of the many weekly concerts there, two birds with one stone deals, the acoustics are formidable, and you get to look at all the details of the interior from the comfort of your seat while listening to great music. A little tip, if visiting during the winter wear a good coat as the chapel is not heated.

Overpriced, only great on very sunny day. We visited the Sainte-Chapelle on a day which was dry and with weak sunshine. The stained-glass windows are not all that impressive with less than optimum sunlight. Also the left side is fully covered because of renovations. The line was long. The price of admission is relatively high (8.50 euro, almost the same as the super impressive Musée d'Orsay). When we were there, the air in the upper chapel was filled with dust because of work being performed. The line was about half an hour long to get in.I would advise tourists to only visit Sainte Chapelle on a very bright day and to wait until the restauration of the left-hand side stained glass windows is complete.

Beautiful destination, lackluster organization. The stained glass windows are amazing. It is hard to believe that people could conceive, design and construct this gem in the Middle Ages. It is perhaps equally hard to believe it survived through so many wars and revolutions. It loses a star as a tourist attraction not for any shortcoming in the work of those artists and builders, but for the way it is run. The admission cost is a bit high for such a one-dimensional attraction, although I suppose the long lines mean the market bears that price. The vaunted museum pass does not get you ahead of the long line to get inside, although it can save you time on the second line once you get through the first. A dedicated entry for museum passes would be preferable. The concerts are wonderful (we attended Vivaldi's Four Seasons; the musicians were excellent and the venue is, as noted, beautiful) -- but they are fairly expensive and are marketed in three price tiers to snare unsuspecting tourists into paying up to 15 Euros extra for essentially the same seats, given that the venue is so small that no seats are that far apart. Finally, there is no mention before you pay that a huge scrim is blocking a quarter of the beautiful stained glass walls, which are under restoration -- and this certainly must be a relevant factor that should be disclosed when they are using the beauty of the venue to induce the expensive ticket sales in the first place. That doesn't mean I wouldn't go anyway -- I'd go again, for sure -- but I don't see the purpose in leaving me with the feeling that I've been a little bit taken, when I could have been left with the feeling that I'd been treated well. Anyway, that's my story and I'm stickin' to it.

Small yet significant. Beautiful stained glass work is a sight to behold. There was some restoration work going on at the time so we could not appreciate the full chapel, but were quite impressed with what we did get to see. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful jewel of a chapel. Ste. Chapelle was once the private chapel of French royalty and it shows. The lower level houses the gift shop and has beautiful deep blue and gold ceiling but the upstairs is not to be missed. The walls are almost entirely stained glass and overwhelmingly gorgeous. This was our second trip to Ste Chapelle and I was as overwhelmed this time as the last.HINT: before you enter the courtyard where you purchase your ticket, there are two security lines, one for Ste Chapelle and one for the Palais du Justice. They both empty into the same courtyard so pick the shortest and go with it! We probably saved an hour by doing this.

Hmm.... I'm not sure if it was because it was absolutely freezing outside (we had a weekend of snow) or because we had spent the entire day navigating the Ile de la Cite, but of all the attractions in Paris this wasn't great. We weren't overwhelmed - yes, the stained glass windows were beautiful, but one look was enough to satisfy us. I'm glad we didn't have to pay to get in, otherwise we would have been quite disappointed (it was free if you were under 26)

Don't miss this...especially upstairs.. Not on the top of many lists, you shouldn't miss this amazing building with the world's finest collection of religious stained glass. Despite its going through an ongoing restoration, the chapel is worth a visit to better understand the importance of the church in 13th century France, and just for the aesthetic appeal.

Exquisite!. There are some places you must see before you die. This is one of them. Words cannot do justice to its almost impossible, fragile beauty. The stained glass and the frescoes are so richly coloured that it takes the breath away.
So wonderful do not miss!. Near to notre dame is saints-Chappell. It is stunning. The stained glass is wonderful as are the statues and vaulted ceilings in deep blue and gold. I loved it
Amazing stain glass. Not as crowded as Notre Dame. About 10 minute walk from there. It had a good crowd, but it was quiet indeed. So bright compared to Notre Dame

Jewel of a church. When in Paris, I visit Sainte -Chapelle, my favorite church, not to worship but to ponder man's ability to envision beauty. The outside does not reflect the glow of the stained glass surround inside. There often are long lines, so I suggest acquiring tickets to one of their many concerts. Tonight, once again, it was Vivaldi's "Four Seasons", played with gusto and expertise. Unfortunately, it is a Gothic cathedral, and, while magnificent, central heating is/was not an option, and tonight was particularly chilling. I brought a scarf and wrapped it around my head. If you go, even in spring, wear boots, heavy socks, etc. Believe me, it is worth it!The church was damaged during the French Revolution, but managed to retain a lot of the stained glass. They are renovating some of the inside, but even with that distraction, I highly recommend this stop on your Paris must see list.

worth the wait in line. This small church is definitely a highlight of our time in Paris. The stain glass windows are incredible- and worth the wait in line. If you have a museum pass for Paris - you might have to wait to get your bags checked - but then you can bypass the line inside the gates to get inside the church faster. The museum pass is worth every penny if you are planning on visiting many museums while in Paris. Check it out online to see what's included. Small church - so your time inside will be short. A definitely must see.

If you have the time - do it!. Saint Chapelle is quite hidden away and overlooked due to being so close to Notre Dame - but I say if you do have the time you should do it. They are currently fixing some of the windows which doesn't ruin anything but does spoil the effect a little bit! It's always busy but you don't spend very much time in there really - so I would say try and go earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid a long queue. As with a lot of other places if you are a EU citizen aged between 18-25 you can go in for free - personally I wouldn't have paid the 13 euro (I think!) to go somewhere for ten minutes.Having said that, the stained glass windows are stunning, and when you walk in it is most definitely a 'wow' moment. If you have the time and extra cash you should go!

Cold, dark, under restoration. One wall is under restoration. There's no place to sit and everything marvellous is up. Prepare yourself for a crick in your neck. We went to an evening concert where the indoor temperature matches the outside - without windchill, thank God. Couldn't see the details in the glass at all after sunset.

Timeless beauty. This is a lovely place just to sit and read or contemplate life as well as to admire the lovely architecture. If you're lucky you might hear the delicate sounds of a choir or a peale of bells. A charming example of traditional Parisien atmosphere as much as it is architecture or religious pilgrimage. Nice casual cafes nearby too.

favorite church we visited in Paris. We went on a Friday afternoon in late March. The line took about 20 minutes to get through. The first floor which is the servants' chapel is lovely in and of itself, but the royal chapel on the second floor is indescribably spectacular. Even my 17 year old son was genuinely impressed. Stepping off the stairs and into that chapel is truly inspiring. Also, once you are inside, the visit needn't take longer than 20 minutes or so depending on how much you want to drink it in. If I could only visit one church, this would be it.
Heavenly!. This small chapel that you almost can overlook, is BREATHTAKING! Has to be most beautiful one in Paris! The stained glass windows can be admired for hours!

wait 2014 to visit it. The chirch windows are under reconctruction till 2014 - 1/3 of windows are covered so when u are inside you can see only part of stained-glass windows and sunshine cannot help you to see even half of Chirch beauty
