One place we recommend everyone goes. Try to get here on a very sunny day....the windows are unlike any you have ever seen. Plan on spending an hour or so there. Not far from Notre Dame

My favorite place in Paris!. The first time you emerge on the second floor is a once in a lifetime experience. I have sat here for more than an hour at a time, just soaking it all in. Don't miss this place.

Wait until it is restored. Having been here before it was a disappointment to discover it was being renovated - lots of dust and scaffolding, with a number of the windows behind sheets. Very busy too - much more so then when I was last here a few years ago. Doesn't anyone visit a beautiful and historic site without wanting to make noise and take photos from every angle - as long as they are in it? Just sit back a soak it all up - so much more rewarding.
Magnificient Windows. Yes ... it is worth the half-hour wait (even with a museum pass). It's a quick visit and totally worth it.
Perfect stained glass. Nobody can miss the most beautiful stained glass of a gothic church on earth. Must see if you are at Paris.

Great even during restoration. Even with one entire exterior covered due to restoration of the glass this is a beautiful place to experience. We noticed many people left not knowing the greatest part is the upper chapel. The door is hidden in the corner by the gift stall and the sign cannot be seen very well. Don't miss it.

Breathtaking. When you take your first step into the main chapel and see the magnificent stained glass windows you cannot help but stand there, jaw dropped to the floor, in awe of the beauty. The windows are unbelievable, just go and take it all in. I wish I had a ladder so I could have seen every piece, every detail, every design because the windows really are astonishing. It certainly is well worth the price of admission, and if you happen to have a paris pass, well, even better. The line is a bit long, but well worth it! Of course I wish I had seen the windows in their entirety, the renovations are a bit obtrusive, but you can turn your back to them and still be staring at an entire wall of glorious stained glass windows. I honestly don't understand how people could have a negative thing to say about this site. Yes, the line can be long, and yes there are renovations ongoing, but just go, take in the beauty, think about the age and construction of it, and be amazed. This is an absolute Paris MUST SEE! I cannot wait to return to Sainte-Chapelle once all of the renovations are complete!
Nice but over-rated!. Definitely not worth spending 8.5 euro's to spend them in a small room of the entire chapel. If you want to go, make sure your admission is part of a city museum pass.
Gorgeous chapel a few blocks from Notre Dame. Beautiful chapel but it's under-going a big renovation and the security check took a long time. It's a long wait for a small site.
A Jewel of color and light.. Not to be missed, like being inside a kaleidoscope. Nice gift shop. The lines can get a bit long to see it but well worth it. More intimate than Notre Dame.
wonderful. Be sure to buy a Museum Pass. It will save you lots of time everywhere you go. This is a wonderful place. Go in, take your time and enjoy.....

Under rennovations. We stood in line for 1 hour in the cold and rain to get through the security checkpoint to find the site under renovations. Very understandable. i think we would have made another choice with our limited time in Paris if we had known.

Heavenly beauty. The interiors of this chapel gives u a heavenly feeling... this is the most beautiful church i have ever seen. Unfortunately this is no more a place of worship (i guess) and is open to public as a tourist spot.
If you visit Paris, you must must visit Saint Chappelle

Spectacular Stained Glass. When I read about this place, I didn't know what to expect. Built in the 13th Century and very plain on the outside, I was prepared to be underwhelmed. Boy was I wrong. The stained glass windows are among the most spectacular I've ever seen, particularly considering when they were made. If you're in Paris don't miss this.

Renovation... Unfortunately, we were very li tied because of the extensive restoration. Most if it was closed but we did see one side and one end of the amazing stained glass. I decided to make the best of it and keep my back to the area being restored and look up and drink in the beauty of the stained glass. I hope to return and see the restored areas.

Stunning!. I recently had a last-minute trip to Paris and had not read up on things to do there. I was trying to get to Notre Dame when I accidentally came across Sainte-chapelle. I have to say that this was one of the most beautiful churches and certainly an unexpected bonus! I think what makes it so great is that is is very different. The almost floor to ceiling stained glass windows were beautiful. If you want to something truly unique and not swamped in tourist, put this on your things-to-do-list!

Beautiful location make sure you book the right concert!. We saw a poster for 'vilvadi's four seasons' here. We turned up 40 minutes beforehand and paid £25 a head. It was only when the concert started that we realised we were at a 'baroque' concert and 'vivaldi' was later the same evening -poster was confusing. Enjoyed what we saw but will check next time that we've got the right tickets! Beautiful location but really cold in the evening as no heating!
Stained glass galore. This church is amazing. A must see for the stained glass enthusiast. One walks away asking how this was accomplished so many years ago.

Magnificent History. This is a must see. The tourists flock to Notre Dame, but hoenstly, this is so much better. Tall walls of stained glass. this is set inside the police precinct of Paris. Best Bet? Go to a concert there, and appreciate the space without all the tourists taking pictures
Must see!. The most beautiful thing I've ever seen, can't wait to go back and see after all windows are restored.

Stunning and worth seeing, but not for the price.. What can I say?... Something you should to see and admire. However, there are so many places you can go for less expensive or even free and spend hours. St Chapelle is something that you walk-in, your jaw drops from the beautiful stained glass windows and then you are like 'OK, what am I missing for the admission price I just paid?'. Looks to me like they are ripping off us tourists to help pay for renovations. It should cost 2-3 Euros or be free. I spent 15 minutes inside and was trying to find reasons to stay longer to make me feel better about spending as much as I did.

Cristal Church. Sainte-Chapels's cristals is what makes it special. This cozy church is, for me, the most wonderful one in Paris. The only downsize is the X-Ray and the big lines to get in, but it sure is worse waiting.

My favorite chapel after 4 months in Paris. I studied abroad in Paris, and my host family recommended Sainte-Chapelle to me as the "little jewel box" hidden in Île de la Cité. They were right, of course! Sainte-Chapelle is like a smaller, lighter, more joyful Notre Dame. Its 360-degree, floor-to-ceiling stained glass windows are awe inspiring. Don't miss it!

Very impressive old church. Not much more to say really....! Worth the trip if you're in Paris. Walk around Mont Marte while you're there, the check out the Moulin Rouge and red light area - just for a look of course!
Under renovation. Still worth a visit but shame that two of the large stained glass windows are covered over for renovation.
A wow site. This is my favourite attraction - The windows are fantasticThis site is overlooked so make sure its on a must see after the Notre Dame

A jewel and worth the effort. Because it's located within the Justice Courts, you have to go through a security check which is a bit tedious, slow & confused many fellow visitors. The chapel is a medieval jewel which just blows the mind. Worth every bit of the 8.5 euros.

Just Ok!. Though the church has gorgeous stained glass windows, this is definetly not a must do if you are in paris for less than a week. The audio guide is useless and the lines are very long. And if you have visited the churches in Italy and spain you would definetly not appreciate the hype this church gets.

Precious way to jump into the past and enjoy its glory!. Certainly one of the most exquisite monuments of Paris, this Chapel was founded under Louis the Saint and has two distinct floors both of which are exquisite. A great tip not to queue for hours before visiting it is to purchase a combined ticket with the adjacent Conciergerie as well. First of all this will allow you to see a middle-ages palace and one of the most poignant testimonies of Queen Antoinette who was to be beheaded shortly after her stay there, but also you will skip the queue thereafter.

Great windows!. The entry level is richly decorated and impressive but the real show is one spiraling staircase up - the famous 13th century stained glass windows. Note - these are being repaired for a few months now so there are some blocked windows at this time but the site is still impressive.There are reduced fare combo tickets with the Conciergerie so if you plan to visit both, be sure to purchase this.

Over hyped, Not Sure Worth the Time. So I visited this "must see". It is undergoing renovations, so much of the glass has a tarp over it. But I went to see the relics of Christ, which it turns out aren't kept there. They are at Notre Dame Cathedral in their treasury. Apparently per the pamphlet, " 22 relics..., including the fragment of the Holy Cross and Crown of Thorns used to be displayed,... but were melted down during the Revolution". The stained glass is nice, but I'm not sure it is worth 8.5 Euros. I spent more time in line than reviewing the fresco and dusty statues. Also, you can purchase an audio guide for like 4.5 Euros or download the app from the App Store. Don't do the app. They have a weak WIFI signal, and it would have taken an hour just to download the images, so I gave up after 20 mins.I did not see a concert, was not an option when I was there. The water closet is near the exit and only one works. Needs a good cleaning in there too.

The Jewel of Paris. I thank Rick Steves for identifying this gorgeous church as a must-see. Truly stunning in its voluminous, original stained-glass. Just imagining the king peaking through a panel at his ornate creation to house the supposed crown of thorns gave me chills.
Great but......... Grat but............ in this moment undergoing works so half of the magnificient glasswork was hiden.

Beautiful stained glass - take time to visit. The Sainte-Chapelle is a small, medieval, Gothic chapel in the center of Île de la Cité - near the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Don't overlook this hidden treasure in Paris. The stained glass is amazing, and they are currently cleaning it which makes a huge difference.

The Four Seasons at Sainte Chapelle. Even though the windows on the north side of the church are being restored we went on-line and bought tickets to a 7:00 pm concert. The church is absolutely beautiful inside and out and the acoustics are perfect for musical performances. We expected a predictable concert and we were thrilled that it was far from predictable, it was exceptional and memorable.

Sainte-Chapelle / Palais de la Cite. A delightful,breath taking little chapel, set behind the walls of Palais de Justice /Law Courts on the island Ile de la Cite. Don't be put off by what you see downstairs, climb the stairs, and be prepared to have your eyes opened to an astonishing sight, once you've reached the top. Colours will leap out out you, take time to read the imformation leaflet, the histroy of the Capel is interesting. Linger and allow your senses to take in the beauty of the place, it is truely amazing. Allow yourself time to full in love with this special place.

Stained glass. What a superb experience when the light streams through this magnificent example of stained glass.A really interesting video on the current re-leading of the windows.Two floors but well worth the spiral stairs to enter onto the first floor and be totally overwhelmed by the sight in front of your eyes.

OK, so what is the big deal?. I was ready to be overwhelmed and I wasn't. Yes, the stained glass was beautiful. Maybe it was the construction and the snow and cold. More likely it was that we had just spent four glorious hours at Musee d'Orsay and were ready to be lifted higher on our cloud. Neither Sainte Chapelle nor Notre Dame did that. My non-religious spouse was more moved by the soldier's church in Les Invalides.
Breathtaking. This is a stunning little chapel that is not to be missed. We waited in line for about an hour, but it was well worth the wait. Don't miss it.

Concert. We attended a wonderful concert here listening to Vivaldi's Four Seasons and Pashabel's Canon. The acoustics were amazing and it was a memorable evening. Also, the stained glass windows are awesome.

Highly Recommended!. You might not be drawn to this chapel if you just see it from the outside. But it was highly recommended by our guide on the bike tour as a "must do." While the line was a little long, the chapel was well worth the visit. The ground floor level was interesting, but when you get to the second floor you really understand why this is a "must see". The stained glass windows are amazing and basically tell the biblical story starting with Genesis.

The greatest place to be in the world?. Definitively worth a visiti'm always going back there every time i'm in Paris.Can't miss the feeling of the incredible light going through the stained glass windows from the XIIe century!Especialy at the end of the day, when the sun hits the windowpane directly. When you get inside, in the upper chappel (the most wonderfull place!) sit on the bench right beside the stairway that you came through. Sit and wait... Enjoy the light. And after some 10-15 minutes of pure bliss, start watching the faces of the people climbing the stairs, the look on their face as they discover the chappel for the first time in their life. Their hapiness will magnify yours!

Well worth the visit!. We used our museum pass to get in - the entry fee was a bit steep for the time you will spend there, but however you pay for it, it is worth doing if you have some Euros spare.The bottom part of the chapel is dark and enclosed and has an almost crypt feel to it! And then you walk upstairs.... All I can say is WOW! The windows are large and light spills into the place from all angles. Just amazing and does take your breath away - I think all I said for about 10 minutes was wow! Well worth doing.

Don't expect antiquity, but see it anyway. The great windows of Saint Chapelle reflect 19th Century restorers' tastes as well as those of Louis IX who had it built as his personal chapel in the 13th. But it's still a fascinating lesson in Gothic architecture whose ground floor vaults support giant second-story walls of leaded glass. Nice too, to learn about the life of Louis.

Beautiful chapel well worth the visit. This chapel took our breath away. It is hidden, you need to go up some narrow, winding stairs, but the colour and the enormity of the windows takes your breath away when you finally enter it.Having been around Europe and seen a million churches I would rate this as a must see, which really makes you apprciate the art of stain glass and the incredible beauty it can cast when the sun is behind it.
Fantastic. I went to watch a concert at this venue and it was a truly amazing experience. Sainte Chapelle is a beautiful example of medieval architecture and well worth visting.

Don't Miss. I didn't really appreciate ancient stained glass until this spectacle. Originally built to house Christ's supposed crown of thorns (now in Notre Dame) this shrine to the crown (the king's that is) is in tact and authentically restored. Stepping inside feels like stepping back in time.

Small but charming. It is a very small chapel, but it is the most colorful and unique that I have ever seen. The stained glass is exceptional It is definitely worth going to and is close to Notre Damme. I definitely wouldn't miss seeing this. TIP: Do not have a swiss army knife or anything sharp in your purse or on you. They will check and not allow you to enter.

Great first destination!. We stopped here as our first place in Paris, and it was definitely wrth the visit! It has short lines (definitely the place to buy the Paris Pass), only needs an hour or so to go through, and is centrally located. If you want to see my experience and some pictures, you can read about it here:
http://katherinabryan.blogspot.com/2011/07/ahh-paris.html

MUST DO. This chapel, is breathtaking. The entrance to the church is a bit hidden, but located right beside the Palace of Justice entrance. Upon entering the church, and walking up the stairs, you are immediatly welcomed with floor to cieling, wall to wall stain glass. It was unreal! I recommend also taking the free tours inside the chapel, there is so much interesting history to be learnt about the building! Fun Fact: During WWII, they removed all of the stain glass and stored it beneath the Pantheon for protection. Once the war was over, they brought the glass back and reinstalled it exactly the same way in the church.

When you'll get to the 2nd floor, you'll understand! (Need to visit in the summer-time). I'll explain why this location got a 4 and not a 5:The first floor is basically nothing, and all it has is memorabilia / gift shop stands. It's really annoying that what this is what it comes down to.Regarding the 2nd floor... After you go up there, you understand why you spent money entering this place. When there's a strong sun, the views should be amazing. We got only a glimpse of it, since we visited during the cold winter.Still, it's a short stay, and it's near Notre-Dame, don't think about it... Just go there!

Nice, but long queues and too expensive. While checking the top rated attractions of Paris on tripadvisor while planning my trip last august, I saw Sainte-Chapelle was rated very high, somewhere in the top 5 Paris attractions (I think it was in the top 3 in august), so I though it must be a must-see attraction. As far as I'm concerned this was one of the underwhelming attractions in our 3 days in Paris as my expectations were probably too high (maybe seeing the top 3 position on tripadvisor in august 2012 made me expect too much). The queue was long enough to be annoying (40-50 minutes), the price quite high for such a short visit (about 8.5 euro for a 20 minutes visit) and the experience was not a top one. To me it seems like this is not a top 5 Paris attraction. I really loved Paris, probably the most from the cities visited so far, but neither Notre Dame, Saint Chapelle, Sacre Coeur or Madeleine interiors succeeded in leaving me a strong enough impression, at least compared to some italian (and other) churches. And at least Sacre Coeur and Notre Dame have better settings and are much easier to admire from outside than Sainte Chapelle, which is crowded between other buildings (otherwise the outside architecture of the chapel is beautiful) . Don't get me wrong, the upper chapel with its stained glass is quite nice (but did not seem as nice as I've seen it in some pictures), I just feel the queues and the high entry fee (compared with length of the visit) spoil the experience. I wanted to give it a 3 star rating based on my experience/impressions, but objectively I think this is a 4 stars attraction which is dragged down by some negatives.

Disappointing. So much construction, so many students sitting on the floor and so dirty, we expected so much from this site and we were disappointed. The stain glass was fabulous but that couldn't compensate for the layers of dirt and dust over everything. I kept wishing I could wheel my Dyson in and give it a good dusting. I'd recommend looking at the pictures in the guide book and skipping the long lines to get in. Doesn't seem reasonable when there is so much to see in Paris to spend more time in a line to get into a place, than you spend visiting the place.

Ethereal. Wow is all I can say. Next time, I want to be back when the renovations are finished (2014 I think?) and at sunset. I can only imagine how gorgeous this would be with that kind of light streaming in the windows. It was breathtaking even in overcast February skies.

Darker during renovation but still beautiful. Worth it for the stained glass windows. When we visited in February 2013, windows on one side were blocked due to renovation, and one side was still dirty (plus it was winter) so there was not as much light inside as hoped. We did not find the audio tour helpful.

Pleasant Surprise. We walked to Sainte-Chappelle after balking at the 2 hour lines at Notre Dame. Sainte-Chappelle was much less crowded. Since it was a sunny day, the stained glass windows really stood out. We are looking forward to going back when they are finished cleaning all of the windows.

Well worth the queue and admission fee. Sainte-Chapelle is easily accessible, being across the street from the Cite metro stop. If you are planning to see Notre Dame, I would see them together since they are so close. When I saw the long queue for Sainte-Chapelle at 1pm, I considered skipping this but I am so grateful I went inside. Both the downstairs and upper chapel are beautiful. I took many pictures, but doubt any of those photos could capture how beautiful this chapel is. I only wished that it was not so crowded. As the main attraction is the stained glass, I agree that a sunny afternoon is a good time to visit. Nevertheless, I noticed that before 10:00 there was no queue. Please note, the inside of the chapel can get VERY cold.

A must, at least once.. La Sainte Chapelle exudes history. The glass work is out of this world. If you are a history buff, you can spend days there. After 4 hours, I still did not want to leave. There are free guide tours (in French), otherwise you can rent an audioguide (which is very helpful). You may need to brush up on your history and religion classes before coming here, or come back again and again. At this moment, a small section is closed for restauration. A MUST.

OMG - a must see. What Notre Dame was not, Sainte-Chapelle was. The stained glass on the upper chapel is stunning. They are in the process of restoration, so you can see the difference that the cleaning makes. Even on the cloudy day I was there, the glass gleamed.
stunning chapel. the tickets are not cheap but the chapel is worth it. There are pamphlets with explanations in several languages which was also helpful

Go at the right time.. sunlight is key.. I've been twice and let me just say that it is an exquisite and beautiful place! This is what you must know though...the time of day you visit is imperative! The first time I went was in the afternoon and it was gorgeous because the sunlight shone through the stained glass chapel... which is the main attraction.. the glass! The second time I went at noon and it was nowhere near the same experience! The room was very dark and gloomy because the sun was straight in the sky at the time. I felt very sorry that my friends could not see it in its splendor, and will remember this next time.

Breathtaking. Absolutely worth the visit, even if you have already seen a lot of churches on your trip!. This might be my favorite church of all of the ones I visited in London, Paris, and Rome on this trip. I knew little about this church other than it was one my husband wanted to see based on guidebook reviews. It is in a government complex that houses courts, so there is a security screening on the outside of the complex. After we got through that, we used the Paris Museum Pass for entry and walked right in through the downstairs entrance. Once inside I thought, "okay, this is a pretty little church, lovely windows and altar with a nice little gift shop. Not that big of a deal." We looked around for ten minutes, took a couple photos, and turned to leave. Then, as we walked to the back of the church, we noticed two small staircases on either side leading upstairs. To the upper chapel. Duh.A few short steps up and we understood what all of the fuss was about. Over sixteen hundred square feet of panoramic stained glass in vivid color. Just gorgeous. Even with 1/8 of the panels covered for reconstruction work, this chapel had our jaws hanging open. When done at Ste. Chapelle, you can take a look inside the Justice building also in the complex if interested. As for Conciergerie on the shared ticket with Ste. Chapelle and also on the museum pass, I would only go there if you had nothing else to see that day, as we didn't find that particularly interesting.If you do want to see the Conciergerie, you have to exit the complex security gates and go left about half a block to get to that entrance. Don't bother looking for signs inside the complex to direct you to the Conciergerie, as there are none.
stunning stained glass, less of a tourist trap than Notre Dame.. Absolutely amazing stained glass in this medieval chapel near Notre Dame.Worth the €8 entrance fee.

Great glass take binoculars!. Get the audio guide and take binoculars if you really want to study the glass. They are doing a multi-year cleaning restoration of the stained and painted glass; which is longer then the 33 months it took to build it originally! The overall theme is The Passion of Christ, but in the over 1100 scenes show everything from Adam & Eve to the Last Judgment. This Gothic chapel was for the royal family and must have appeared to be "magical" when light shone through the window when it was built. Today this is one of the jewels of the Gothic era.
A jewel!. This wonderful church was built to house relics very sacred to the medieval French kings and is remarkable. Thank goodness it survived the occupation of Paris!

My favorite place in Paris. Every time I go to Paris I go back to the Sainte-Chapelle. It's not as well-kept a secret as it used to be, though the entrance through the Police prefecture makes it a bit of a trek to get through. The stained glass windows are incredible, as are the painted walls; however, I was disappointed this time around that a large section of one wall is covered in scaffolding for window restoration. Unlike many restoration projects, where the scaffolding is just on the outside, this scaffolding is also on the inside of the chapel, contracting the already small space and limited the amount of light that streams in through the windows. It's worth it, of course; the restored windows are absolutely stunning. It's still not to be missed, but if you haven't seen it before, make sure to come back in a few years when the restoration is complete!

The depth of colors is spectacular. The most impressive deep colors of the stained glass windows is stunning. There is no other place in the world like it. In the next three or four years the renovation of the windows will be complete and then you will experience a sanctuary that the king's were in awe of 665 year ago.
Best stained glass. Great light and windows. A true gem of a place. It was not crowded when I was there. The price was OK. If you are in Paris for a visit...this is a must see.
Must See!. The stained glass is astounding. A trip to Sainte Chapelle won't take long... if you are going to Notre Dame then be sure to walk over for an hour or two visit.

Prettiest in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is the un-sung hero of Parisian churches, chapels and other holy places. I'm not even religious and I loved it. I think it is much more beautiful than Notre Dame. Get there early ( about 10 minutes before opening) and there will be hardly any queue - any later and you'll be in line for hours.The first floor was really pretty, but the main part of the chapel upstairs is breathtakingly beautiful. It's somewhere nice to just sit for half an hour and just take in how stunning it is.

The stained glass windows are amazing!!. Took my three trips to finally get into Sainte Chappelle and it was worth the persistence. Very old and musty but when the sun shines through the stained glass windows it's all worth it!!

Must See!. Beautiful Gothic medievel chapel located at Palais De La Cite. The Chapel is very well preserved and features impressive stained glass art work. built some time after 1239. Worth a visit if you have gone to the other major sites.

The most beautiful chapel I've ever seen!. What a magical place this is. Well worth the queue and security check. The stained glass is the most wonderful blues and reds and as the sunlight shines through, the whole top floor of the chapel is bathed in jewelled colours - has to be seen to be believed! The ground floor has painted, vaulted, ceilings covered in thousands of golden stars - you are transported to a fabulous place in history when the French Royal Family used this chapel as their own. Do not miss this hidden gem! The gift shop inside is also first class with a great selection of gifts.
Beautiful vitro. If you have the time to wait in a line for 30 to 90 minutes you will be able to look at those very bautiful vitro windows on thw upper floor.
Long line, but worth it.. Even in the middle of February the line was long...but the views inside are definitely worth it! Amazing stained glass!
A fabulous gem. Well worth buying the double ticket for Conciergerie and Sainte Chapelle. Absolutely breathtakingly beautiful even on a wet day in February.
A gem!. One of the oldest remains on the Île de la Cité. Renovation is going on, but this should also be on your short list.
Best day. We visited the church briefly but the best part of our Paris stay was the concert on the steps and the performances of the street artists on the walk through the town.

Mesmerizing. Sainte-Chapelle is a very small chapel and the lines are usually pretty long to get in. You also have to pass through a security check before you get to the ticket office, But once you do get inside.. wow! The colorful stained glass windows are absolutely breathtaking. The entrance fee is 8,50 euros, a bit steep, but definitely worth it. One of my favorite buildings in Paris!
Beautiful Stained Glass. Does not take much time to see this site, but the beautiful stained glass windows are worth the visit.

Cute. I booked two tickets to a classical concert there for my partner and I. It wasn't really our thing but it was a special day. The music was more medieval than what I was expecting but the experience was great.The stain glass is beautiful but we could not fully appreciate it because the evening/night drew in early.It gets quite cold so bring something warm to wear. Also, the entrance was a little difficult to find (entrance to the law courts). We thought we were running quite late but the concert had not started before we arrived.
A Sacred Place. Find a place to sit and let the sublime floor to ceiling stained glass windows overwhelm you. A little hard to find but worth the search.

Amazing. Get the museum pass as the lines to all the historic sites are LONG. But this is well worth seeing - absolutely amazing stained glass and the gothic architecture is superb. You enter the lower chapel, which was used as the everyday church and walk up a rather winding staircase to the upper chapel. Do go - it is not something to miss in Paris. Personally, although substantially smaller than Notre Dame, it is vastly superb in terms of beauty.

Beautiful Stained Glass. This cathedral was highly recommended so being my first time in Paris we lined up to visit it. We had a pass so didn't have to buy tickets, but the line was very long & didn't move very quickly at all. There is lots of security to get into this site, so be prepared for an hour wait. Kind of frustrating and once in the church itself is not huge. The massive stained glass windows are truly beautiful.
Amazing stained glass work. This is a must see! It is situated close to Notre-Dame cathedral. The entrance fee is definitely worth it! I have never seen such an amazing stained glass work.
Exquisite. This is a delightful spot. Don't miss it. Try to go on a sunny day. It is my favorite place in all of Paris.

So many windows!. For a small fee of 8.50 Euros, you'll get to see an amazing view of the stained glass windows. A portion of the church is being restored so some of the windows were covered when I visited.

WOW!!!!!!!!!!. I am not religious at all, but I fully appreciated this chapel!! We were walking past it and thought we would have a look, I had never heard of it before. It is breathtaking! The colours are amazing, and no camera can capture the beauty of this chapel. Could have spent all day in there, and it is a MUST SEE!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Beautiful stained glass. Situated in the grounds of the Palais de Justice, on the île de la Cité, there is a security check before entering and then a ticket office afterwards.There was only a very short queue for tickets of around 15 people early on a February morning. Holders of the Paris museum pass get to jump this queue. We bought the double entrance for Sainte Chapelle and the Conciergerie which is 50 metres further down the street on exiting.You enter in to the lower church and go up in to the stunningly beautiful upper church via a narrow spiral stone staircase.A small section of the stain glassed windows (by no means half as previously stated) on one side were under renovation but despite this there is an enormous amount of beauty left to see. Try to visit on a sunny day.

Hidden treasure. A bit hidden, but a magnificent place for a short visit with impressive stained glass windows.Pity about the renovation going on but I understand that in order to preserve these delicate windows, it needs to be done.

Go to a concert. We returned for a Vivaldi and Pachabel concert in this jewel of a place. Unfortnately it was in winter and the stained glass was not illuminated - if you can go on a summer evening as we have done once before you will really appreciate this wonderful building.- a must see in Paris
Disappointing during renovations. Given the entrance fee, I felt a bit short-changed when half the main chapel was covered for renovations. What remained was indeed beautiful.

Most beautiful chapel in France. The stained glass windows will absolutely take your breath away. This church is tucked back next to the Judiciary building, but it is completely worth the visit. It is absolutely gorgeous inside. When the light hits the stained-glass, you get a little view of what heaven will look like one day. P.S. EU students get in for free with ID.

Go on a sunny day, beware it is being restored. Breathtaking stained-glass windows are what this chapel is all about, of course. Try your best to go on a sunny day to get the full effect. Beware that the windows are in the middle of being restored, and a few may be blocked off during your visit. But the restoration is worth it, as the windows already completed are vibrant and stunning. Entry price is a bit steep for what you get at 8.50 euro/person, though, but I guess it's going toward the restoration.
A must-see. Amazing stained glass windows...a must-see! I thought there wouldn't be a fee, but its worth paying for it!

The JEWEL of Paris. This "small" chapel is defined by the glorious stained glass. The building is a beautiful gothic structure which houses magnificent stained glass "walls" - NOT TO BE MISSED. Stunning. 10 minutes walk from Notre Dame and often overlooked which is unfortunate as it has some of the most beautiful stained glass on the planet.

The stained glass is absolutely wondereful. The painted walls and columns so unique.. The only negative was the lineup to get in and the crowds inside; however the experience was well worth the wait and the crowds. I enjoyed that I could spend as much time as I liked examining some small detail and not being hurried along. Great visit.

Glorious and stunning mediaeval gem. This was the highlight of my recent trip to Paris. Saint Chapelle is a stunning Gothic masterpiece of architecture and stained glass. The effect on your senses as you climb the stair from the lower chapel is just breathtaking

An Evening Quartet. Went with a friend to hear a classical quartet at Sainte-Chapelle during the 2012 holiday season. Seeing Sainte-Chapelle as a day tourist is one thing; attending a sacred music performance takes the experience, with the wondrous beauty of the cathedral employed to it's original intent, to a higher level.

OK, but only that!. The stained glass windows are fabulous, no doubt about it. You can see them in pictures and get the idea. When we were there this week half were covered for restoration, but there was no reduction in the ridiculous entrance fee of 8.5 euros plus another 5 for audio guide. Go to Sacre Coeur or Notre Dame, they are free and you don't feel ripped off like I did at Sainte Chapelle!

Under Construction and Underwhelming. Sainte- Chapelle is a unique sight with terrific stained glass, but unless you are a religion buff, it doesn't offer too much to explore. It's one small room almost entirely walled in beautiful glass art, but currently, half of which was under construction. It's worth a look, but is it worth 10 euro or a long wait in line? Probably not.
Amazing. The most fantastic stained glass windows and amazing arches, certainly one not to miss, don't miss out, make sure you take a trip up the stairs, it's so beautiful
Cold. Beautiful inside and there was a service when we visited. The only detraction is the amount of beggars and souvenir sellers so close to the church.

So you'd thought you'd seen stained glass!. If you had to choose between Ste. Chapelle and Notre Dame interior, choose the former. We went near opening and had virtually no lines to view stunning windows and architecture and interestingly tiled floors.

Beautiful but difficult to enjoy. The chapel is incredibly beautiful! The windows are fantastic and so are the paintings and the atmosphere. Take your time to read the references of the images on the windows and you will appreciate them as a comic book. The colors are glorious and have been recently restored. Unfortunately it is often very crowded and sometimes the long line can make you so tired that you don't enjoy it. A sad experience there was seeing the employees closing the entry before closing time after having waited in the cue, so make sure to go there early if you can.

Amazing Grace. This medieval, gothic chapel on Ile de la Cite, in conjunction with la Conciergerie, is totally worth the visit! It houses the most extensive in-situ collection of 13th century stained glass in the world, and they are really stunning pieces of art and religious history.It was a bit tricky to find here. You don't enter through the main gates to la Conciergerie, but from a tiny, pretty unnoticiable entrance on the side, a bit away from the main gates. There's a line for the security check, but nothing too long, and if you appreaciate stained glass art or are a religious person, am sure it would be worth the waiting even if the lines were long. Notre Dame can't compare to this because this is more intimate (smaller) and the stained glasses are closer to the visitor than in Notre Dame.

Unique place.. Though you might be surprised that you waited in a long queue and paid almost 10 euro just to get into small chapel for several minutes, don't be sorry, this place has a history and is really beautiful. Maybe a little too many shops for such space, but hey, they need money to renew all of it, right?

Stunning. Sainte Chapelle is well worth the wait and the entry fee. There seemed to be a large queue to enter, but it went by rather quickly. I'm grateful we persevered because the architecture, stained glass windows, and gorgeous artefacts are stunning to behold. I've been to several churches throughout Europe (including the Vatican) which are all gorgeous in their own right, but Sainte-Chapelle is stunning in its own way. Every time I find myself in Paris, I will be visiting Sainte-Chapelle.

Look, these are the best stained glass windows in the world, but . ... You can't get in if you have a pocket knife the size of your fingernail. The security processing is more restrictive,and less courteous thjan the worst airport you have ever been through.

Glorious, go in the afternoon. The windows that have been cleaned face west and south, and if you go in the afternoon, the light is coming through them beautifully. It is a LONG wait in line for tickets, so this is one, if you decide on a combination ticket, would be a good choice to do that way. The only thing you can do while there is marvel. This place, the GLASS is hundreds of years old. Overwhelming, the artistic and spiritual energy that vibrates everywhere throughout the very small space. Totally wow.

"Pictures Can't Capture It's Beauty". Have to admit we found this church more by accident than well planned event! So glad we stopped in. The stained glass is breath taking...unbelievable! Had just the best day in Paris! Sad to take the Chunnel back to London at the end of our day!
Awesome. This is a beautifull place to visit, there is so much interesting history if you like that sort of thing, if you don't the beautifull stained glass windows will surely take your breath away.

Beautiful and full of history. The price may seem a little steep considering how small it is, but I didn't feel like I wasted my money. It is a beautiful piece of history that was definitely worth seeing.
An excellent chapel. The stained glass windows have to be seen to be believed. Just stunning. We also attended a concert here at night. Amazing.

Loved the rich colors!. I came here right after visiting Notre Dame and loved Sainte-Chapelle more by far. The rich blues, burgundies and golds really look striking. Plus, I liked how it was much more intimate and less crowded compared to Notre Dame too.

Exquisite gem. The windows are amazingly beautiful. I've been here several times and the queues go quickly. Sainte-Chapelle is one most wonderful places in Paris. A timeless treasure of religion, history, and art.
If you love stained glass. do not miss this. It will make you ooooh and ahhhhh. It's a small place so it doesn't take much time, and don't be put off by the queue. It moves fast.
Nothing special. I had paid 18 euro for 2 persons just for 30 minutes. Its beautiful but i could use the 18 euro much better

Church with Gorgeous Stained Glass. My fiance' and I were here in October. We may have waited up to 20 minutes in line to get in but I think it's worth it. It's hard to believe how old this church is. They continue to replace and fix the stained glass so it still looks beautiful. The stained glass here is like nothing I've seen before. The glass depicts all of the stories from the bible and is absolutely gorgeous in it's detail.

magnificient. wonderful church dating back from 1248. It is by all means a masterpiece. We also attended a classical concert within the church - these are organised very often; ask at the information desk if interested. But it is totally worth it! An unforgettable experience!

Long lines and a price for the atmosphere. The architecture is beautiful, but the lines outside and the crowds through the whole church detract from the ambiance and make it more difficult to appreciate the space as a whole. Felt a little more like a museum than a holy place.

Breathtaking blue and gold. This has become my favourite place in all of Paris! You may have to queue for a while - and it sometimes closes for the lunch hour (and a half) ... but it is absolutely worth the wait! This tiny chapel was built to house a relic of the crown of thorns - and no expense was spared. The upper chapel has full-length stained glass windows that make you feel as if you are in a box of jewels ... and every surface is painted in ethereal blue and gold. Some panels are behind screens at the moment for restoration, and the space is smallish, but there are chairs along the side and if you can, sit for a while and let the beauty inspire you.

Do not miss this gem!. This often overlooked building has a unique history and is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen. The windows are incredible. It is a quick trip in, so don't miss it before you go into Notre Dame.

Stunning stained glass. We went on a really hot day in August but luckily the line up did move very quickly before we melted away. The church is very stunning. But that being said, we were in and out within 15 minutes. There were just so much more we wanted to see in Paris.

Don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. Sainte-Chapelle is an often-missed attraction in Paris because it is hidden inside the police compound, and is not a very big structure compared to nearby Notre Dame. But you MUST go in, because there is nothing else quite like it. It is a 13th Century jewel box of stained glass! Downstairs is a small chapel with a patterned ceiling, and upstairs is the chapel itself. The columns and buttresses that hold up the roof are so thin and the 85 windows of glass 50 feet high are so vast and beautiful that colored light seems to be born in the room.Since Sainte-Chapelle is just across the street from Notre Dame, it is very convenient to visit. You can also visit The Conciergerie at the same time. The latter was a palace turned into a prison at the time of the French Revolution, and many condemned people spent there last nights there before being taken to the guillotine. The Conciergerie has various related displays, including an old guillotine blade.There are stairs leading to the upper chapel of Sainte-Chapelle, and I don't remember if there is an elevator for people in wheelchairs. There is a gift shop with some very nice books on the chapel, post cards, etc.In 2012, the entrance fee for Sainte-Chapelle was $9 USD, but if you buy a Museum Pass when you arrive in Paris, you can visit as many of these sites as you want over a week-long period and not be concerned about entry fees or standing in line. We have never been to Paris without stopping in to have our breath taken away by Sainte-Chapelle, and we have never taken anyone there without them being grateful.

Glass Stained Windows are divine. I've never seen such magnificent glass stained windows than in Sainte Chappelle. The workmanship was spectacular, one will have to stare in awe. It was just mesmerizing to me. A must see!

The windows take your breath away!. La Sainte-Chapelle is a royal medieval Gothic chapel, located near the Palais de la Cité, on the Île de la Cité in the heart of Paris, France.Begun some time after 1239 and consecrated on the 26th of April 1248,[1] the Sainte-Chapelle is considered among the highest achievements of the Rayonnant period of Gothic architecture. Its erection was commissioned by King Louis IX of France to house his collection of Passion Relics, including Christ's Crown of Thorns - one of the most important relics in medieval Christendom.With the Palais de la Cité, today called La Conciergerie, the Sainte-Chapelle is one of the surviving buildings of the Capetian royal palace on the Île de la Cité. Although damaged during the French revolution, and restored in the 19th century, it retains one of the most extensive in-situ collections of 13th century stained glass anywhere in the world.

Don't miss so much beauty !. . Well hidden behind the court of law, it must pass strict controls before entering this beautiful and historic building . The stained glass is extraordinary huge and colorful almost magical way. The atmosphere is unique. What a pity that visitors often do not comply with this place worthy of silence for contemplation.

A Religious Experience. Do not miss coming to the most remarkable church I have ever seen. Pictures do not do this place justice. The stained glass windows are truly divine. And the painted columns complement them beautifully. Do not forget to look down, however. The intricately tiled floors are equally astonishing and it's a shame really that one can even walk on them at all - they are magnificent. (One downside were the bathroom facilities in the courtyard outside the church - they were just this side of serviceable.)

A lovely surprise. I was told by a veteran traveler not to miss Sainte-Chapelle. She wouldn't give me details because the surprise when you have walked up the stairs is too stunning. Go twice, once on a sunny afternoon and then to one of the concerts held at night.

beautiful windows. The chapel is a beautiful sight but the average traveler should be forewarned that there is a strict security checkpoint before you enter. Ii had to lose my swiss knife in order to get in and they do not give conficated stuff back when you leave.

Breathtaking stained glass. After a lengthy wait, we were not disappointed. The lower level is a little narrow and crammed, but once you reach the upper level, the stained glass is magnificent. Crowds are expected, but despite this, the view is just fabulous. Take and read the guide indicating what the stained glass represents - there are guides in many different languages.
Breathtaking. Amazing stain glass windows.... Breathtaking! Make sure you have your museum pass ready so you can skip the queue.

This is a must-see in Paris. This chapel built back in the 1440s by Louis the 9th to house the remains of the thorne crowne of Christ (no longer there...) is absolutely fantastic - and you have to see it to believe it... The lower chapel is not so interesting as it has more or less been converted into a shop, but climbing the spiral stairs to the upper chapel will make you doubt what you're seeing. The stained glass "everywhere" is out of this world - and you just have to see it for yourselves to understand what I'm meaning...

Fabulous. ...and very cool to see the work-in-progress on the stained glass. The contrast between the restored panels and the ones still needing restoration was remarkable. Don't let the construction keep you from visiting!
Beautiful. WOW. Make sure to visit the upper chapel. The stained glass is amazing as is the way the chapel is painted.
Likely the most Beautiful Cathedral on the planet. Lives UP to all the hipe... REALLY a DON'T MISS... and DON'T miss a concert inside if at aLL possible...!!!

Interesting to see but not on the top of my to-do list. Every 1st Sunday of the month many museums in Paris are free. This is the reason why we visited the Sainte-Chapelle. It was very pretty and the windows on the 2nd floor were very impressive BUT we were happy that we didn't have to pay for the visit. Overall it took us less than 30 minutes to see and read everything, so we left we the feeling of it not being worth full admittance.

Amazing!. This place is amazing! The only reason I give it 4 out of 5 is that they are doing restoration right now and there was a huge banner covering one side of the chapel. Even with that it was still amazing!

Royal Riches. We visited La Sainte-Chapelle while two or three windows were in restoration. You enter the lower chapel which was for the ordinary folk and climb up a steep winding stair to the upper chapel where used to be the shrine for relics from Jerusalem. The overall effect of the tall thin stained glass windows is memorable. Most of the glass is original and important for its early date. But some of the lower panels are reproduction. The scenes in each smallish oval panel are difficult to read without binoculars and some kind of guide is essential. These glass walls are definitely something to be seen but strangely it did make me uncomfortable that these gorgeous treasures were so exclusive and solely the preserve of the King and his court.

Beautiful!. Wonderful stained glass windows. Small, but well worth a visit, can be seen in less than an hour (15 min if you're speedy). There was some restoration work being done while we visited (Jan 2013) and there was a video that displayed some of the restoration being done. Quite interesting. You can tell the place needs a little restoring. Would love to see one of the concerts they put on in the chapel someday.

Chopin piano recital surrounded by stunning windows. I was SO lucky to be able to get a ticket for a Chopin piano recital in the beautiful Sainte Chapelle. The windows are rich, colourful and stunning however the queues during the day are horrendous - even on a wet or cold day people are in a queue to get in! Check to see if you can buy tickets online!!
Beautiful Stain Glass. A must see if you love stained glass, which is exquisite. The chapel is a bit smaller than expected, but worth the time to visit.

Pretty Stained Glass Windows. This place is very small and not as ornate or as grand as Notre Dame, but has very pretty stained glass windows. There was a very long line to get in which took over an hour and there is an admission charge in contrast to Notre Dame, which was free. But it was nice. You walk into this room which looks like a museum. I almost missed the narrow stairs in the corner which lead to the room with the stained glass windows. You walk up a narrow winding staircase and there is a large room with the windows. They are really beautiful with a lot of colorful detail and arches.

An exquisite jewel. The history of St. Chapelle is fascinating. The stained glass windows really tell a story. The Ave Marie Concert I attended was fabulous. This is the perfect venue for performances. This is the third time I have had the pleasure to attend a special program there!

Amazing find!. We didn't know about this little gem until we arrived in Paris, but it was totally worth finding and walking through. Some of the most beautiful stained glass that I have ever seen, wonderful history, very nice docents. We went on a day that was extremely uncrowded, so we were lucky. It's a fairly small space, with steep stairs to gain entrance, but entrancing and totally worthwile.
Golden Gothic. This is a fabulous church to contrast to Notre Dame, but the narrow, winding stairs may make it a challenge to the over 50 group. Try to go upstairs -- the glass is fabulous.
The Windows. Well worth the long wait.. The windows are remarkable with the light streaming through the stained glass.

unbelievable!! but.... must say, the stained glass windows are unbelievable! left me just sitting there, staring wide-eyed in wonder. it'll help if you read the information provided. they come in different languages, and depending on the day, you might have to wait for your language to become available. it's also advisable to come in mid-day, to see most of the windows lit. if you come too early or too late in the day, you'll only see half of them in their splendor. really it's unbelievably detailed. but that's about it. don't expect more than seeing large stained glass windows. if you don't think the price of admission is worth it, don't go.
Beautiful !. this is just beautiful..the only bad part was standing in line so long to get in. But the wait was worth it.
better from the oustide. a tiny little chapel with some interesting history. although you could be in and out and seen it all in 15 minutes.
beautiful. Worth waiting in line, the beauty of the windows is amazing. Sunny days are the best. Don't plan to eat nearby, all touristy. Walk across the bridge north and then east for some good food.

Beautiful rose windows玫瑰花窗很漂亮. The windows are nice and extraordinary. It's really close to Notre-dame so think of it as a bonus. When we were there so many people were waiting in line but i think it's not as amazing as Notre-dame. So if many people were waiting outside eager to see the windows just skip it, unless you have a thing for those delicate windows in a rosy color.客观讲挺好的，就是人太多了。圣母院更佳。若是人没这么多，我想我会更偏爱它一些～
Magnificent!. To me this is the most beautiful church in Paris. Go on a sunny day - the floor to ceiling windows are amazing.

Watched a string quartert. Amazing stain glass windows from 10th century. Beautifully intact. Had a moving experience listening to classical music in such a beautiful building. We just loved it. Tip: try catch a classical concert in the grounds

Very beautiful inside different from other churches. There can a queue but not long, in January no queues, quite a few people inside. The church is different to others in Paris, not very big but very beautiful inside, also church has very interesting history. Outside hardly can be observed.

Long Waits. Ridiculously long line to get in here, followed by airport-style security, as it is adjoining to the French courts. I have to admit we were underwhelmed. We preferred seeing bits of the restored glass from this chapel in the Musee du Cluny. It was better appreciated cleaned and up close. In the chapel, it is dark and so high up, you can't really appreciate it.
Book a Concert. The acoustics and the interior of Sainte-Chapelle transform a violin and string chamber music performance into a transcendent experience.

no trust. I thought the price of admission was too much and the woman selling me my ticket would not believe that I am a student of art history. I went in because I wanted to see it but not a very nice experience. They should familiarize themselves with how foreign universities signify their students. We do not receive stickers on our id cards stating we are art history students from my university. It was beautiful to see the stained glass but terrible encounter with staff.
Very beautiful but huge lines. Go early in the day if you want to spend a lot of time waiting. We visit every trip to Pais and it never fails to impress.
BEAUTIFUL. Soooooo beautiful... wow!Went at 9.30am Sunday... good time, not too busy and the light was in just the right place!
Sainte Chapelle definitely worth a visit. Beautiful stained glass windows of light. Not really easy to find, hidden away almost inside la Conciergerie. A good history lesson .

Good but not sure what all the fuss is about. Love the windows although they must show better on a sunny day. I was there when it was cloudy. I wouldn't wait in a huge line for this but if you can get in quick, go for it.

One of my favorite churches in Paris. We got lucky that there was no wait and very few people when we visited in November. The chapel is very small, but incredibly beautiful, even with some of the restoration going on. Don't need a lot of time here, but definitely worth a visit.

Stained glass beauty. Sainte Chappelle is an amazing sight to see. The initial room is mainly just the gift shop, you will need to climb the staircase which is slightly hidden in the corners of the main room. Once you get to the chapel, you will understand. It is made up of almost floor to ceiling stained glass windows covering every wall. On a sunny day, it is absolutely breathtaking. Even on not so sunny days, the windows are just gorgeous. I visited with my family when I was in High School and knew I wanted to go back and see it. My memory hadn't skewed my perception of it by any means!

Stunning among the sea of cathedrals. It's breathtaking. I had heard much about the stained glass but was still not prepared for the moment you enter the main sanctuary. They could do an entire fundraising campaign based on photos of the looks on people's faces when they first enter the space. I second a former review about accessibility as there are many stairs - understandable as this is a historic site but definitely something visitors should be aware of.We came back later for a concert - overrated as the musicianship was fine but nothing spectacular. Buy the Museum Pass and come midday when the sun will be shining through the windows.

Plan ahead for security check. The former church of the royals it sits in a courtyard of what is now the justice center and police. This is why lines are long you must go through security you are entering a secure area. Its similar to the airport security. Walk through metal detector and pocket stuff and carry items go in bins to be x-rayed. Knowing this the line will go faster if you have pockets emptied and everything ready to go in a bin. Tip: The restrooms are in a building to the far left with an underground entrance. If they are closed you can turn right and go in to the courthouse for restrooms on the main floor far right. The wait is worth seeing what is truly the most magnificent stained glass in the city. All the years I had seen this jewel box of a place on TV it didn't prepare me for the overwhelming feeling of seeing it in person. The main floor is the gift shop area and your first glimpse at the beauty of the painted walls. You then climb a small winding staircase to be met by immense windows. We were the last tour of the day so we watched the sun start to set and the room grow darker. The building is under a major restoration and conservation. There will be a section blocked off as they work around the room until 2014. Its a learning experience to see the work rather than a deterrent to see this beautiful piece of history.
average. Yes, the stained glass is great. Yet the place seems too crowded, too cold and too small as well. 30 minutes is pretty much the average time you need to see, listen and photo everything.
under renovation but still a great site. The Church itself is as beautiful as advertised. It is being renovated but still worth the price to go inside and see the windows!

Treasure of Paris. We weren't planning on seeing this on this trip, but stopped in with our teenage daughters and were pleasantly surprised by the unique beauty and wonder of this lovely church. Amazing stained glass, simply stunning!
Definitely Not to be Missed. It may not look like much on the outside, but the inside is amazing. Make sure to check out the second level.

Don't miss it. We have been to Sainte-Chapelle several times on past Paris visits to tour it and see the famous stained glass windows; this visit we went at night for a Christmas concert of Vivaldi's Four Seasons; what a beautiful place to see a concert; highly recommended.
Wow!. Inside the Palais de Justice, the private chapel is as important to see as Notre Dame Cathedral. In pre-revolution France, King used to pray for God's guidance in this tiny private chapel.

Outstanding. This is a church to visit even if you are bored from visiting too many of them. The interior is striking with its walls of glass - just like a Tiffany lamp. The fact that it is over 800 years old is staggering - the beauty of this building and its craftsmanship makes it worth lining up for. The line is for X ray security - it moves reasonably quickly.
Beautiful. The chapel of the kings for France, it is one of the few surviving parts of the castles of the original kings of France. I would call it a gallery of stained glass. Use the museum pass.

Chapelle with huge and beautiful mosaic windows. It was beautiful but since we visited late afternoon and raining during winter months, we didnt really enjoy much and I think the entrance fee is too high.

Beautiful. Even though standing in the line to get in and go through security is annoying, it is so worth it when you enter into this small but glorious church. The stained glass windows are so beautiful.

Beautiful, go by day!. This is a beautiful church, specially during the day. It's worth the price! They're not many tourists who knows this, so it doesn't has a long line to wait to get your tickets. Also, you can buy a double ticket to the Conciergerie as well.

A real gem. Although I visited Paris many times this was the first time I entered this church, undoubtedly the most beautiful of all. It was worth the waiting just to climb to the first floor and see the wonderful windows, the vitrages , part of them still under restaurantion.
Skip it. Long lines and if you have been to churches in Europe- not impressive. It was under renovation, however, still not worth the security check and 30-40 minute wait- with the Paris pass

Ice-cold Concert in magnificent atmosphere. We listened to an animated Christmas concert in the chapelle. The interior was lovely and the sound of the instruments resonated beautifully in the church. It was however incredibly cold (beyond what can be reasonably expected in a church, even an old one) and there was a big part of the seating area blocked off by an ugly construction curtain which I managed to ignore. We were glad we had gotten 'VIP' tickets in the first 8 rows because further in the back the experience was probably not so great.

Most Impressive Stain Glass this side of the Vatican. I was dubious about going here, I was tired,hungry and had about had my fill of both churches and museums, I was ready to go home to Boston when our friend Ann suggested we go here. Our policy is to always go where one of us wants to visit. This church is very old, it looks mid evil both inside and out. It has a fantastic stained glass widow which should not be missed it is very different, it is wonderful

An amazing surprise. When I first heard about a church with a lot of stained glass, I was not impressed. What church doesn't have stained glass? When you see the glass there in Sainte-Chapelle, you change your mind real quick. First, there is usually a line to get in as the church is on the grounds of Ministry of Justice, so there is extra security. Then, you head over and out to the church where you pay and enter. You enter the gift shop, which you usually see at the end. It was nice with some good looking items, but I still had no idea what to expect. As you head up to the chapel itself, you can see why it is so very impressive. There are cards which explain the panels in many different languages so you can get the most out of the visit. Don't just walk in and walk out, but take the time to really see the details, to really look at this masterpiece. This is a must see when in Paris.

Nothing more beauitful at sun rise.... We arrived just in time to see the sun rise through the beautiful stainedglass wondows. The stairs up to the chapel is narrow and steep; however, they are easy to climb. If you visit no other Chapel, visit Sainte-Chapelle.

Beautiful!. Sainte-Chapelle is very close to Notre Dame, but doesn't get the coverage of the world-renowned cathedral. Take the time to listen to the history of this gorgeous chapel. The stained glass windows, on both sides, are most beautiful when the sun is out and you can appreciate the full beauty as the light streams through them.
A Surprise. The Sainte-Chapelle is unbelievable. When visiting you have to climb the stairs to the upper level and see the amazing stained glass spanning the entire area.
So beautiful!. The medieval colors, the stained glass windows, the altar, etc! Magnificent. A must for the walker in Paris! Then check out the muse Cluny!!!!!
Long Lines. Beautiful stained glass. Too much to take in when crowds are there as there is not much room.If you have the Paris Museum Pass, you can skip the lines and go right in. Well Worth Having

Breathtaking stained glass windows. Even with a museum pass, everyone has to wait in line to go through the security check. The hour wait was well worth it though, as when you finally quit going up the spiral staircase your breathe will be taken away by the beautiful view of all those stained glass windows. When we were there one wall of windows were covered and I assume being refurnished but otherwise - it's one of those not to be missed places.

Simply, One of the Most Elegant and Beautiful of Chapels. We visited Sainte-Chapelle the first time seven years ago, and have been going back every time we visit Paris, every other year or so. This perfect little Gothic chapel is known for its breathtaking stained glass windows. They soar so high and surround the space so thoroughly, that on a sunny day you are baked in bright colored light from every angle. The sheer beauty of the place will astound you. This is a place not to be missed if you are in Paris.

Million colors. Highly rated, the Sainte-Chapelle is a spectacle. Once we walked in, we thought it was some sort of a joke: the room was dark, with very small windows.... We were very surprised, until we realized we were in the underground part... So we ascended to heaven... And heaven it was! It was like walking into something from a dream: the entire chappel was surrounded by 20 foot or 6 meter tall stained glass windows re-telling biblical stories in multicolor splendor.Even better, the chappel is being completely restored, making the stained glass simply divine. We spent an hour with our mouths wide open... There is nothing like this out there, and we have been to a million Cathedrals.Not to mention that the French claim that the real Crown of Thorns is held in the chappel.

Wow.. This church is breathtaking once you get inside. Even if you aren't religious or interested in this type of site, I still suggest you check it out. Pictures don't do the beautiful stain glass windows justice. We waited in line for a few minutes, but it was mostly to get through the security to enter into the area where Saint Chapelle is located. It was worth the short wait!

Go for a concert. There are two ways to appreciate Sainte-Chapelle. Go on a bright sunny day and see the light streaming through the windows or go at night an hear a concert (usually baroque), or even better, do both.
Simply spectacular. Can not be missed by anyone visiting Paris! This chapel is the prettiest religious building I have ever seen.
Awesome. . Totally worth the wait, but you'd best be early. Free for European Union citizens under 26. Score. Nice breakfast place across the street. 10 euro breakfast.

A bit of a let down. This family chapel is stunning for what it is but generally a let down in size after seeing Notre Dame. We're glad we didn't spend money on the entrance fee, but instead visited it on the museum pass (which is a great deal, if you have the time to use it fully).

Wait for renovation to be completed. We went for a concert and a day time visit. A large portion is closed off by a renovation wall which detracts from one of my favorite attractions in Paris. Still worth going if you have never seen it however.

A Gothic Gem. Befor or after visiting Notre Dame, walk a few yards and be awed by the beauty of St. Chapelle. The colors and huge (over 40 feet high) stained glass windows are breathtaking. Stand and take in the colors, beauty and angles carved everywhere and transport yourself back in time.

Most Breathtaking Place I have ever been to.. We were standing there debating on whether we should go the line was moderate going fast and me and my friends weren't sure it was worth it. The main reason everyone was so skeptical about this is because you had to pay a fee unlike the other churches we have explored. Finally we decided to pay the fee and go in. The first floor was alright very decorative. They had the gift shop on that floor as well. But the second floor was absolutely stunning the stained glass windows were huge and well worth the wait. It was just something you will keep with you forever theres also a balcony in which you can sit on. Pictures are more than welcome. When we went there was one side under construction but it didn't ruin our visit.

Tucked away GEM!. The Sante Chapelle, quite near the Notre Dame, was a little tough to find, tucked away inside a government square, but was so worth the small effort. The stained glass is amazing and there are cards in several languages to help one get situated with descriptions. This is more a musuem than a cathedral - that's why there is a fee - but it is a must see in Paris!

The most beautiful room in Paris. The stained-glass is incredible, and this is well-worth the price of admission. Be sure to read the information on the cards in a stand near the exit staircase. They do a good job explaining the windows. I wish that I had done more homework before I went.

Unbelievable stain glass church. Church was in the middle of Dept. of Justice building. Just got in time before it closed. Unbelievable stain glass. Spiral staircase - be careful specially coming down.

beautiful site. visited this site in november. unfortunately one side was being renovated so we were unable to see all of the stained glass. that being said it is still very amazing. i love stained glass and there was plenty to be found here. the detail is captavating. they had a video explaining the history and the stories found in the windows. the also described the renovation process, which i thought would put me to sleep but after listening for a while i found it very interesting. Its a good site to visit if you are in the area but dont have a ton of time. It can be done in a short amount of time unlike some of Paris' other main attractions. I believe that it is covered by the MUSEUM PASS. I would say it is totally worth your time to make a stop here.
Glorious. Important and stunningly beautiful Gothic gem. It is easy to get to and to access and well worth the time.

Give the inside a try?. I didn't get to get inside, I was drawn to this church by pictures online. Sadly, I arrived after dark and viewing hours. The church has scaffolding up right now and is tucked right up against the justice building so from the outside its not much to look at.

better than Notre dame. A jewel of mediaeval architecture..........a good source of design inspiration for embroiderers illustrators etc; When you have done, have a Blanche beer at the cafe over the road people watch.The Marche aux Fleurs is just round the corner, one of the last in Paris.

Concert. I went to a violin concert featuring Vivaldi music. It was a magical experience listening to Vivaldi in a chapel. I will never forget the experience. My hotel got me front section tickets on no notice for $50 (Relais Hotel Vieux Paris) which is just a walk away from the Chapel. This place is awesome and not to be missed
Noel Concert in December. Brilliant, outstanding string quartet and vocal ensemble. Sound acoustics were amazing and it felt like we were listening to a 100 voice choir. Amazing!

Amazing light. Visited twice - once in the day with the stunning light through the stained glass and again at night to see a chamber orchestra play - both special in their own ways but as a music venue it was stunning and something to look out for as evening entertainment if visiting Paris

This is a must see when in Paris!!!!. This is an amazing church and you have to see it!! Some very amazing architecture! The church says to hold the original crown of thorns. It has some glass work that will blow you away and it is one of those places that makes you feel like you are in the presence of something truley divine. A very moving place. Don't miss this beautiful place and witness something truley amazing!
Must see. My mother described it as being inside a jewel. The most beautiful church I have ever seen. When the light shines on the windows, the colors are spectacular. Go.
don't miss this one. I think this one of the sites that should not be missed.even in the rain. had to see this . just remember that it's next to the courthouse
Saint Louis' dream. Go and check this church, no matter how much you think you should visit Notre dame in the inside, if to choose in between them, go to Saint Chapelle

Incredible. I learned about the Sainte-Chappelle by reading about it in one of Rick Steves' guidebooks. Rick had rated it as a must-see attraction and he wasn't wrong. For my money, the Sainte-Chappelle blows Notre Dame out of the water. It's much smaller and not as much of an architectural feat, but its beauty cannot be understated. The stained glass reaches from floor to ceiling and goes around 360 degrees. This is a must see in Paris.And don't be fooled when you first get there by what's on the ground floor, you have to go upstairs to see the stained glass.

Breathtaking. As with a number of attractions in Paris, you have to go through a security scan to get access to Sainte-Chapelle since the church sits within a complex of judicial Buildings. The minor inconvenience is worth it however. The ground floor of Sainte-Chapelle is interesting enough as a spectacle, even if it is a bit dark, but the real significance of the building lies up the winding stairs in the corner of the ground floor room. On coming out of the staircase you enter a magnificent room that is dominated by massive floor-to-ceiling 360 degree stained glass windows. It was overcast the morning we visited but the light in the room was still breathtaking. One can only wonder what it would be like to see it all on a sunny day. It must be truly magnificent. The crowds may have been along the way at Notre Dame. We were with the discerning few enjoying the stunning beauty of Sainte-Chapelle.
Amazing stained glass. This church is one of the most beautiful in the world. The gothic structure combined with the stained glass is incredible. Not too crowded either.
re thinking. they charge a lot just to get inand to see the church. i would not do that again as the tour is just not more then 30 min.

Gateway to Heaven. If you ever wondered what it would feel like to live inside a precious gem, visit Sainte Chapelle. You will be dazzled by the floor to ceiling, 360 degree stained glass windows of rich ruby, sapphire, emerald, amethyst... This is the most magical human-made space I have ever experienced. Even if you are not a religious person, you will feel a sense of awe and spirituality here. It simply is impossible to be disappointed by Sainte Chapelle—just make sure to go to the second floor. This is where the actual chapel is. I’ve seen people who mistook the first floor as the chapel, and they walked away angry. Don’t do this! Climb the spiral steps; and when you make the final turn of the spiral, you will emerge into a breathtaking piece of heaven!TIP: The chapel is a little more difficult to find than most Parisian landmarks as it is hidden inside the huge justice complex. There are small signs, however, to point the way. You will also have to go through some serious guards and a metal detector—since this is an operating court. Once you are inside the complex’s courtyard, there will be bathrooms in a little sunken area to your left (I believe)—take your own toilet paper and purrell, just in case! You’ll likely see the line leading to Sainte Chapelle on the opposite side of the bathroom area. I advise that you get to the church as soon as it opens. The light filters in most beautifully through the morning angles. Plus, the empty church allows you to soak in the beauty a little more deeply. You might also revisit the church at night during one of its many concerts. The windows will be dark, but the atmosphere will still be divine.
Link. A particular sensation of being connected with Divinity could be experienced when visiting this important history and Art Patrimony site.
Should be #1 in Paris IMHO. On sunny day, it is incredibly beautiful. Everyone should visit. Don't let it's low profile and entrance via a government building with metal detectors put you off.

Breathtaking Jewel of Stained Glass. Sequestered amidst government buildings, it took a few minutes to figure out where the entrance was - use your Museum Pass and save the wait on lines. While the first floor has wonderful painted columns and ceilings, the walk to the 2nd floor reveals a truly breathtaking chapel surrounding you with blazing jewel tones of detailed stained glass and outstanding rose window. We visited about 10:30, when sun was streaming at an angel through the windows - beautiful both in the sun and when clouds passed by. Worth the visit!
