It was absolutely more beautiful than stained glass that I had ever seen elsewhere.Plus, this museum is located about a one minute walk from the Consergerie - where Marie Antionette was kept until she was killed. If you are visiting Notre Dame, it's about a 5-10 minute walk. It's gorgeous and also convenient to other sites. Don't miss going to Sainte-Chapelle.

Totally Stunning. This place for me was the most unexpected "WOW!" moment in Paris. The church itself you can't really see from outside and it doesn't really look that impressive. The chapel when you first go in is a nice little place which looks pretty but no more so than a dozen other Parisienne churches. What separates Sainte-Chapelle from those other churches is what awaits at the top of the spiral staircase, as soon as you come out from the top step you are just hit with the most amazing stained glass windows, it's pretty awesome!! The one down side would probably be the queue but to be honest, I thought it was worth it!

Violin Vivaldy Concert. With the ambiance of the venue and the performance of the 3 violinists , the cello and the piano , playing Vivaldas four seasons plus two other classical pieces this was over the top . BEAUTIFUL

A must see in paris. as the main place you usually go in the ille de la citè, is Notre Damme, you must make an stop over and take your time to admire the vitraux workings in this chapel. When you get in in the ground floor you think that you are in the wrong place but as you find the little door on the left of the main door and go upstairs you feel that this is glory, if you are lucky and go in a sunny day the sun going into the vitraux is breathtaking. It´s incredible

MAGICAL CONCERT. This chapel is one of the most beautiful in the world. This was our third time to attend a concert there and it is always a must in Paris. Wonderful violinist and strings for Vivaldi"s Four Seasons. Reservations are necessary, can do on line. Do not miss this.
Must see. One of the highlights of my visit was to listen to a concert in this wonderful building. Truly a must see and worth the queuing to get in - not long just disorganised!
Beautiful Stained Glass. These stained glass windows are works of art. If you visit in the afternoon you get the benefit of the natural sunlight coming through the windows. Absolutely stunning.

I was expecting more. This is the only church (actually a chapel) that charges an entrance fee (8 euros). While the main chapel's stained glass walls/windows are impressive most of panels are still under restoration and appear dark if not dirty. There simply wasn't that much more to look at. I would skip this and visit many of the other beautiful (and free) churches throughout Paris such as Notre Dame, Sacre Coeur, St. German de Pres, etc.
Most Beautiful Church in Paris. The Stained glass at this church is breathtaking~(the upper chapel is were you want to go) A great place to visit after or before Notre-Dame
Beautiful stained glass windows. Amazing stained glass window displays and centuries of history to learn about. Combine it with a visit to Notre Dame which is just a short walk away.

It is worth queuing in the rain!. It was definitely worth the wait in the rain to get into this beautiful chapel. The stained glass is truly amazing. Be aware though, that given its location, you will have to undergo stringent security screening. So if you have a lot of 'just in case' gadgets in your bag eg a leatherman tool , then leave them at home that day.

Beautiful chapel. We saw a concert there one evening. I was sort of surprised that there wasn't more people that night. Best part of Sainte Chapelle are the stain glass windows, which I saw back in the 90's.

Currently under renovation. Waited in a security line for over an hour because during renovation, Saint-Chapelle shares an entrance with the local court who get priority in the line. Only 1/2 of the beautiful stained glass was opened that day.
A must when seeing the Notre Dame. This small church is very close to the Notre Dame. The windows at the first floor are extraordinaire, and something you must seen if you have spare time

Amazing!. I had been to Paris 3 other times before finally going to Sainte-Chapelle on this trip. I cannot believe that I had allowed myself to miss it. There are 2 levels to the chapel - the bottom (entry) level is where the common folk would be allowed to pray, and it is still gorgeous and dramatic, with a beautiful medieval arched ceiling. But it's the upper, royal level of the chapel that takes your breath away. It is the most dramatic display of stained glass I've ever seen, reaching from the wainscoting all the way up thirty feet or more, on all 4 sides of the narrow building. The stained glass is undergoing a much needed cleaning and restoration, which is really the only good thing about missing it all those other visits, since the unrestored section doesn't yet have the jewel-box brilliance of the restored sections. There is intricate detail on every surface from the floor to the ceiling, on the altar canopy, over the doors, etc. I am not a religious person, but this building is a testament to mankind's artistry and engineering skills. Do not miss it! It is well worth the wait in line to get in. (Be aware that they check very carefully for anything with sharp edges and will confiscate anything that could be damaging, like penknives and tweezers, etc.) You can combine a visit to Sainte Chapelle with a visit to the Conciergerie, which is worth the visit if you are at all interested in Marie Antionette and/or the French Revolution.

Most beautiful stained glass ever. Even though half of it was walled off for renovations to their stained glass...just what was showing was the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. Magnificent! Be sure to get the Paris Museum Pass so you don't have to wait in the horrendous lines...just wait in line for security then go to front of next line with pass.

Amazing church. It's a little bit claustrophobic to wind up the stairs from the entrance before you get into the chapel itself, but then you are greeted with a truly stunning array of stained glass windows depicting biblical stories. Going to a concert there in the evening can be surreal.

Oh so beautiful. Even if you are not a history addict or classical architecture aficionado this is a MUST see. This hidden gem of a tiny church not far from Notre Dame de Paris is mostly stained glass window with little else to hold it up - how it has stood up all these centuries is quite astounding but the effect is breathtaking! Most nights there are classical music recitals performed here and we enjoyed a one hour performance by a string trio and opera singer. The acoustics in the church are wonderful and the whole experience was outstanding. Sent shivers up my spine. Go along as even if you are more into rock music than classical you will definitely find this place a stand out - truly!

Wow. We were so surprised by this little gem. The most delicate of churches. You get surrounded by stained glass. We got in line about 10 minutes before it opened and by opening time there was a long, long line. In same complex as courts so strict security- no pocket knives, scissors, etc. the scale is small compared to Notre Dame, intimate and beautiful. Sun came out while we were there, gorgeous. Nice little gift shop too!
Beauty in the Details. If you're a fan of stained glass this will blow you away! The detail in this windows, the history, the stories, so much to absorb and so beautiful!!

Great for concerts. We loved Ste Chapelle for the historical relevance that is has, but we also attended two concerts of Les Solistes Francais and that was one of the absolute highlights of our time in Paris. Tickets are readily available online and I would highly recommend taking advantage of this magnificent venue

Most beautiful place in Paris. Do not miss this jewelbox treasure. When the lines are long at nearby Notre Dame, come to Sainte-Chapelle and find either short or no lines. The reward in seeing the world's greatest stained glass windows is priceless and breathtaking.

The Crown Jewel of Paris. Tucked away inside the Palais du Justice, Sainte-Chapelle is a magnificent example of High Gothic Architecture. When you ascend the spiral stairs to the second stage you are dazzled by the lightness of panels of stained glass from floor to ceiling depicting the story of the bible. Most tourists gasp on first view of this remarkable chapel. The windows are 49 feet high, and have 1,134 scenes, of which 720 are original glass. The structure was built in the 13th century and is truly remarkable. I have returned often to Paris ever since I was stationed there in the U.S. Army, in 1955-56, and always return to Sainte-Chapelle!In season there may be a long line of tourists, and it is advisable to arrange an early entry pass if possible.
A gem. You enter from the basement and climb the sairs to the main floor where you are blown away by the amazing light filtering through the stained glass. Not to be missed.

The stained glass windows can be spectacular. Unfortunately, we visited this time on an overcast morning and several of the windows are currently being restored, but if you ever have a chance to visit on a sunny day, these windows can be quite dramatic.

Words Cannot Describe.... Visiting Sainte-Chapelle is like entering heaven encased in a jewel box of stained glass. Arching panels upon panels of glass describe the story of the Bible, from Genesis to Revelation, in rich colors and sumptuous detail. The sheer height of glass gives one the impression of looking up into eternity. The cathedral is right across from Notre Dame, so you might as well come see this also-the super long line is worth the wait.
Absolute gem. This smaller chapel is absolutely exquisite. You must see the upstairs as well. Listening to a live chamber music concert there, is an unforgettable experience.
Superb stained glass. The restorations have made these windows shine. Best seen on a Wednesday evening in summer, when the light shining through the windows makes them spectacular.

Beautiful stained glass. This is some of the best, and most interesting stained glass work in all of Paris. The 15 windows that light the central portion of the church tell the story of the bible and the history of the holy relics that the church was built to house.This is covered by the Paris Museum pass and takes about an hour to enjoy.
Surprising gem near Notre Dame. We actually went to see Notre Dame, but hit this first and we were pleasantly surprised. It was quite beautiful and a nice contrast to Notre Dame.
What a surprise. What a pleasant surprise was the Saint Chapellle. It gives you goosebumps to see the beautiful art work of the stained glass and the colorfull walls. Pure art. A must see.
well worth a visit. We actually visited as part of a classical concert. Very atmospheric and acoustics great. It is amazing

Beautiful stained glass. A lovely church with tons of fantastic stained glass windows. Well worth a visit, but be prepared that you have to go through security to get in to view the church as it is connected to government buildings.

Worth the visit!. Breathtaking! No other words fit, we were lucky enough to visit on a day that was cloudy with breaks of sun, so we got a chance to experience the windows in both lights. Pure heaven. Worth the queue.

Enjoy a Concert Here. While an hour long concert costs anywhere from 20 euros and up, the nighttime atmosphere in such a splendid locale is worth every penny. You just sit, listen and view the sublime setting.

Amazing. A breathtaking chapel.. Well worth the queue.
The second level is remarkable and the history of the chapel is fascinating.
Worth the visit. Standing in the main part of the church and looking at all the stained glass is amazing. This is definately worth the visit

Beautiful Church. Such a lovely church with beautiful stained-glass windows. Absolutely worth the visit. This was my second time there and I am glad that I took my husband to see it. I recommend photos without the flash to get the best colour in teh windows.

A masterpiece - but be aware of long security screening.. Sainte-Chappelle is a must-see - my favorite of the many great cathedrals, churches, chapels. The newly restored, cleaned windows are magnificent and the work is still underway (so you can not see all of the windows. The floor and the painted interior are not to be overlooked. BUT be aware that Sainte-Chapelle is entered through the courtyard of the Justice/Courts building and has the most rigorous security screening we encountered. There is no "express" line and the lines were long and slow. But worth the wait.

Stained glass temple. Went twice, once to view the chapel during the day, and second time in the evening for a chamber orchestra concert. You hve to go through a metal detector to get in because this is in the same complex as the French Supreme Court.

A Pleasant Surprise. Had to wait in a que for about 15 minutes but it was worth it. The lovely stainned glass windows and painted ceilings.We hadn,t planned to visit but were told to go, a pleasant surprise.

One of the most beautiful churches in Paris. For the best example of stained glass windows and an awe-inspiring atmosphere visit this small church on Ile de la Cite.Having circumvented the long queue with our Museum Pass (note that you can use the 'Group' queue if you have a pass), we were immediately entranced by the beauty surrounding us inside. A narrow staircase takes you to the next floor where the most beautiful glass windows in the world are found.Yes, you have the grandeur of Notre Dame and Eglise Madeleine, however, this is far smaller church and therefore allows a much closer view of the best stain-glassed windows I have ever seen!To get there take the Metro to Cite and make it part of your visit to Notre Dame and La Conciergerie. If you go on a Sunday then also visit the markets close by - they are an eye-opener with flowers, birds and other animals being sold!

Dazzling stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle's superb stained glass windows are rightly famed worldwide. We found the crowds somewhat off-putting, and much of the building was covered with scaffolding, so this visit was not as pleasant as one I made years ago. I'd recommend waiting a year or so for the renovations to finish.

Breathtaking. Although I was in Saint Chapelle at the same time as many others on a busy Sunday, it is impossible not to marvel at the light streaming through the many stained glass windows - somehow the other people seem to fade into the background. I visited twice in one week and will return.

Jawdroppingly beautiful. A bit of a queue because of a security check which everyone has to go through - so your museum pass will not gain you speedy entry here (it will at the ticket office inside). But none of us were prepared for the beauty of it - although some of the stained gladd windows were being restored (and therefore covered) it was amazing. For our next visit we would love to attend a concert here. Do go, it is one of the highlights of Paris. (Would be great if they did not have the gift shop right at the entrance ...).

Worth the line. This was a very beautiful place. The security line looks a bit intimidating however it goes quickly once you commit. There are stairs to climb to see the upper level with all of the stained glass. So much history! Notre Dame very close by.

Long line but moved fast. Beautiful chapel and worth the long line to get in. We waited about 30-40 minutes to go through security and then buy tickets - if you have the museum pass you still must wait in the line. We saw several people try and bypass it but since it was security first and then tickets second the long line was actually for security. But as I said - it moved pretty quickly. The chapel is lovely and looks different then the other cathedrals. Even though there is renovation going on - you hardly notice the side that's being worked on (which is covered) since there is so much stained glass around you.

Sr discount. Be sure and use a senior discount if you do not have the museum pass. the windows are breathtaking. The location is on a beautiful hill and be sure and check to see if there is a concert that night.

A lovely religous place. Built in the 13th century, with very nice glass work which contains so much religious significance.There was souvenir stalls inside the chapel which in my point of view is not good at all and they should be relocated out of there.One entire wall was fully blanketed off for restoration work so it would be worth a second look to see the whole chapel one day when no work is taking placeThere was information sheets in different languages outlining the significance and meaning of each of the stained glass works with reference to the bible, very helpful.I found this tour expensive for what it was compared with others such as the towers of Notre-Dame, but also understand it must be very expensive to restore and maintain such a place.Sainte-Chapelle is a place you must see when in Paris.

A Nice Surprise. I wasn't sure what to expect after waiting in line to enter the Saint-Chapelle. But it is indeed beautiful. The stained glass panes were undergoing repairs so not all were visible. Would love to return to see all the stained glass in its restored glory!
Must see!. My husband and I filled one of our days in Paris sightseeing different churches in the city and Sainte-Chapelle did not disappoint. It was incredible. The stained glass is a must-see!

Ancient Paris meets Marie Antoinette. The cathedral dates from the 1200's and it is adjacent to the Conciergerie aka the prison where the Queen was held befor her execuion. Both locations are included in the Museum Pass and are highly recommended for all they have to offer. The extremely large stained glass windows in the cathedral would take hours by themselves to absorb (there are about 15 of them, 2/3 of which are original) and the stairs allow you to ascend to the top of the structure. Back on earth, Marie Antoinette's cell is faithfully reproduced and a journey through the prison, with the exhibits and stories that accompany them, tell a chilling story and put a human face on that personal suffering.

This relatively small church is really quite special.. The stained glass windows cover almost every wall and go from floor to the ever-so-high ceiling. The light filtering through the stained glass windows at sunset is really a wonder to see. Also, the church frequently hosts concerts and it is a terrific venue for that purpose as it is not very big. My wife and I heard a concert given by five violinists, beginning just after sunset. It was most memorable. Don't miss it.

well worth the extra effort. Take some opera glasses and go on a sunny day. Plan to just sit quietly reading all of the stories. There is usually a long line to get through security because you are entering the main court house at the same time. Just be patient.
Must see. We almost didn't visit Sainte-Chapelle, but very glad we did not miss this beautiful church. The stained glass windows are a must-see.
Awesome.. If you just go one place, go here. It is literally awe inspiring.I don't want to spoil the effect, but if you like stained glass, go here. It is definitely worth the price of admission.

Breathtaking. There is no shortage of beautiful stained glass in Paris or France or anywhere in Europe for that matter, however, Sainte-Chapelle is the creme de la creme of stained glass. It is worth the wait if there is a line up or go early when it first opens and walk right in.

Beautiful colours. If you have the museum pass, you can by-pass the line but not the initial security check.The outside of Sainte-Chapelle is not pleasant or picture worthy however it is worth a 15 minute look inside where you can see beautiful stain-class walls!
A must-see. The most amazing stained glass windows you will ever see. We had a 20 minute queue in September, probably would be longer in Summer
Amasing!. Please don’t miss. Impressive and fantastic unique windows. We spent 40 min in a cue but it was worth that. It is the most beautiful gothic church.
Stained Glass Heaven. You will be in awe of the stained glass-choose a sunny day if possible so that you get the full effect of the colors. A must not miss.

A sight to behold. A must see on your visit to Paris. A small chapel with breathtaking stained glass windows in the top portion of the chapel. Winding staircase to reach the top but well worth the climb. No elevator access to the top but wheel chair accessible on the ground floor. The wait in line is usually long. There is a small gift shop located inside on the ground floor.You must bring a camera to capture the beauty of floor to ceiling stain glass windows as well as the blue and gold painted ceilings.We went n a rainy Thursday afternoon and still enough light shone through.

Truly Stunning!. It is really hard to describe how incredibly beautiful this place is. It was built to inspire and amaze and it succeeds brilliantly. Definitely one of our very favorite spots in this city of so many amazing sites. Should go straight to the top of any visitor's list.
Magnificent.. In my opinion better than Notre Dame. Stunning edifice and superb stained glass. Make sure you visit.

Glorious chapel!. Sainte-Chappelle, built by Louis XIII to house the Crown of Thorns allegedly worn by Christ, is a jewel--literally! The lower chapel, where the staff worshipped, is lovely itself, with royal-blue ceiling covered with gold stars and a gorgeous altar. However, then you walk up winding stone staircases to a breathtaking view of floor-to-ceiling stained glass, seemingly unsupported by walls. It is simply magnificent!
Concert was amazing. We bought tickets in advance for the evening classical concert, one of the highlights of our trip. Unforgettable setting, a one hour performance.

Only word to describe is "stunning". I went on a Monday afternoon, and waited 45 minutes. Saint Chappelle is not very big- the main part is basically only one room. But it's one room of floor to curling colorful, detailed stained glass windows and when you come around the corner it really is breathtaking. If you can go on a sunny day, all the better for sure, but that can be tough in Paris. I think it'd still be worth the trip when the sun isn't shining through.

More Beautiful than Notre Dame Cathedral. The St. Chapelle Cathedral is a must-see for anyone with an interest in Gothic architecture, stained glass, or the history of the Catholic Church. Built in the 12th century, the towering stained-glass panels are some of the largest in the world. Panel after panel tell the history of early Christianity. Before you go, read up on the history of the building. While there, don't forget to stop and really appreciate the effort it took to build such a monument. I often find myself so busy taking photographs, I miss taking in the beauty of the moment.
Beautiful stained glass. We entered Sainte-Chapelle with our 2 day Museum Pass. It was worth the visit to see the gorgeous stained glass, some of which is currently being restored.

Beautiful Sainte-Chapelle. Breathtaking beautiful stained glass Church. The Stained Glass windows are stunning when the sun shines through. If you can go to a concert in the church. The acoustics are wonderful and the music will send chills down your spine.
Little Known Church. Although this is a small church, hidden by the Palais de Justice, it is brilliant find. If you only had one church to visit in Paris, mkae it this one

Indescribable beauty. This chapel, built under the auspices of King Louis IX, is one of the most majestic and beautiful places I've ever seen. The stained glass windows are breathtaking. It is well worth the wait in line and the security checks to visit this wonderful chapel.

Breathtaking.. When we entered on the first floor and saw the inside I thought this is nice, but when I climbed the stairs and entered the second floor I thought this is amazing. It is incredibly beautiful. The stained glass windows are spectacular and this place is well worth the wait. Although we did not have to wait too long.
Stunning, beautiful. A highlight of our trip to Paris. This little chapel is small, but the stained glass is so beautiful that you'll remember it forever

Beautiful glass work. Best tip: get there early. The lines get really long, really quickly because of tours, and they limit entrance after they've filled to capacity and then you have to wait longer. Audio guides are helpful, but not absolutely necessary. Stained glass is absolutely beautiful, especially considering it's used to tell biblical stories.

Breathtaking. We went to an evening concert here. The church is jaw-dropping. But when the music started I got chills. The acoustics are incredible in the church and the atmosphere makes for a very unique and memorable concert experience. We didn't go to Notre Dame because we had such a short visit in Paris, but my sister who had spent more time in Paris recommended the Sainte-Chapelle over it.

Stunning Beauty. Sainte-Chapelle is stunningly beautiful! The beauty of the stained glass is spectacular, particularly when the sun shines through. If you have a chance to attend one of the evening concerts in this wonderfully intimate space, it will be an experience you will never forget!
In restoration. What a beautiful church! Please note that the left half is under restoration of all the stain glass. It was started in 2007 & will be finished in 2014.
In restoration. What a beautiful church! Please note that the left half is under restoration of all the stain glass. It was started in 2007 & will be finished in 2014.
Breathtaking.. Nothing like it on a sunny day! It doesn't look like much from the outside but head up the stairs and WOW!

Slightly better than average. Lower chapel had a nicely painted blue roof, but was filled with souvenir stalls (not good for a church), upper chapel was spectacular but at least two glass panels were hidden for a 6 year refurbishment until 2014 at least. Very crowded all day and there are two slow lines to wait in before entering the venue.

The most amazing of many amazing attractions in Paris. A most recent review did state that part of this is under renovation BUT this chapel is amazing/fantastic. Whether you are a Christian or not, the scope and beauty of the stained glass is stunning, the entire Bible in a stained glass form. The "rose" of Revelation. Wow! An intimate setting which can a significant wait is worth it my opinion. Visually, the highlight of my trip to Paris.
Breathtaking. I believe the renovations end this year and we will be going back!! A must see on your trip to Paris!!

Stained windows!. This place is amazing! The most wonderful stained glass I have EVER seen anywhere ( and I have seen a lot in my long life) The stairs to the upper area are steep so I asked my son to go see if it was worth the climb. He said yes definitely and boy was he right. The higher room is BREATHTAKING. and the stairs to go DOWN are separate from those to go UP so no one has to pass on narrow steps

Awe-inspiring and breath-taking - dont miss this!. Just close to Notre Dame this can only be described as an awe-inspiring and uplifting experience. You may have to queue to get in if you don't have a museum pass card. We waited for about 20 minutes on a Sunday morning - it costs 8.50 Euro or is free if you are and EU citizen under 26. Louis IX had this Gothic masterpiece built in the 13th Century to originally house the relics of the Passion of Christ. You start in the lower commoners' chapel, dark and richly decorated with intricate columns and arches but nothing prepares you for the King's upper chapel surrounded by soaring stained glass windows (over 6000 sq ft) that seem to defy any rules of architecture. They are dense and richly coloured and depict every story in the bible with the famous later 15th century Rose window telling the story of John's revelation. The audio guide was Euro .5 and went into extraordinary detail of each window if you are interested. There is a marvellous film about the restoration of the windows, which is going on at the moment and covering a section of the chapel but I think is additionally interesting rather than detracting from the beauty.Even on just a weekend trip, this would definitely feature as a MUST-DO - it's extraordinary.

A disappointment in its current state... We spent time in a special lineup to enter this church and saw such a small part of it, that I could not believe that was all there was to see. The gift shop and the high chapel was all we could visit. A serious waste of my time, and considering the great security delay and check, it seemed so odd that I still wonder if we saw all there was to see. Perhaps we missed something here.

One of the highlights of any first trip to Paris. On Ile de Cite a few blocks from Notre Dame cathedral, this church should not be missed. The stain glass in the cathedral is not to be believed. While we were there, they were also playing a wonderful video depicting the renovation effort. It was very interesting. We found this to be much more impressive than Notre Dame.

Medieval splendour. If you can recall when your mind first registered Christmas by the bright lights on the tree, the feeling when you reach the upper chapel will be ten times that when you set your eyes upon the glorious colours of the stained glass with the light streaming through them. This is the only time on the trip that my phone crashed and I couldn't take pictures but I hope the memory is firmly nudged for a long time (or I'll be back soon...) I don't think a static image could faithfully reproduce the awe anyway. The chapel is an integral part of the Palais de la Cité, originally the Palais de Saint-Louis for Louis IX who had it built and went on to become a saint. He bought the relics that were once housed there, in 1239, for the "considerable sum of 135 000 pounds" which contained Christ's crown of thorns. It's a veritable joy to find yourself within the chapel's walls.

Stained glass you wont believe!!. Overshadowed perhaps by the local Notre Dame Cathedral, Sainte Chapelle turned out to be one of the most memorable visits of our trip to Paris. It was built to house the supposed relics of the 'Passion of Christ' and is completely surrounded in huge stained glass windows which tell the entire history of the Bible. Central on one end is the famous 'Rose Window' which tells the complete story of Johns Revelation. A truly awe-inspiring work of art, this site is not to be missed.

Concert in the Chapel!. We got a ticket to a chamber music concert at St. Chapelle. I'm not a huge classical fan, but it was beautiful music in a truly stunning atmosphere. Well worth doing, and the concert is brief - only about an hour or so. Then you can wander out for dinner!

A must see. This was our 3rd trip to Paris, 4th visit to Saint Chapelle. The lines are long, but worth the wait. Although most people say you must see it on a sunny day, I've seen it both sunny and cloudy, and actually prefer less intense light as the stained glass seems even more vibrantly colored then, less washed out than it does in full sun. Just mho! They are beautiful any way, as are the colors in the pillars and arches downstairs. During this visit, September 2012, a portion of the upper chamber (1/4 or a bit less) was covered for renovation work, unfortunately. The rest is so spectacular, tho it's unfortunate, it doesn't really diminish ones experience.

Awesome. It is the best and most ornamented church in Paris. The entrance is a bit confusing though, you have to go through the Conciergerie next to the Palais de la Justice. So, you can't really see the Chapelle when you're walking on street. It's actually a very small two story Chapel. It's mostly famous for its stained glass windows depicting specific scenes from the bible. The colorful richness and the exceptional artistic detail of the windows are really unique to the Sainte-Chapelle. In a way it's an over-expression of the Baroque style, unlike the more common Gothic Cathedrals of France.

Stained glass to the heavens. The stained glass in Sainte-Chapelle is amazing. It seems to go up to the stars, with the height of the ceiling. The wait in line is super long, but it's worth it. I also attended a concert in the evening here, and that is something I highly recommend. It's kind of touristy. They play easy listening baroque (Four Seasons, Pachelbel Canon) so you know the musicians are slumming it, but they were spectacular even so and gave it there all. You can buy tickets at the door, which is cheaper than paying online or through your hotel. We bought the 30 euro seats, which is right behind the front VIP section. Oh, be warned, right now in September, half of Saint-Chapelle is under renovation, which blocks half the stained glass. So you may want to wait a while before going. The concert in the evening is fine, though.

Beautiful Stained Glass. This small chapelle has amazing windows, especially when you consider how old they are. Tip - get there early becauses the lines can be long and the Chapelle is rather small. It is included in the museum pass but there is not a seperate entry for pass holders.
Beautiful church. Beautiful old church with amazing stained glass windows. Well worth a visit? Close by note dame so do both at the same time
great. it was one of the most beautiful places we have ever seen. the bright colours of the windows is one not to miss

What a surprise!. We wandered around the downstairs for a while wondering why this venue was so highly recommended. Then we walked up the small circular staircase (not so much fun) and then we saw what the buzz was all about. A site not to be missed -- staircase not withstanding.

The heavenly Jerusalem. This stunning chapel was built for royalty to preserve what was said to be Christ's crown of thorns and relics of the Passion. The design was relatively small in size but expansive in artistry and no expense was spared to create a building designed to transport occupants to the 'heavenly Jerusalem'. Instead of walls, stained glass windows stretch skyward, each illustrating stories from a book of the Bible. The chapel is seen to its best advantage in the morning as easterly sun streams through the sanctuary windows. There is also a spectacular rose window at the western end.

Beautiful. This chapel was amazing. We attended one of the evening concerts. Vivaldi playing as the sunset came through the stained glass windows was unforgettable. Probably not worth a long wait just to walk around inside the chapel, but the concert was well worth it.

not to be missed. Some of the stained glass is currently undergoing renovation, but you can still have a wonderful experience. First you will walk into the first floor where there is a book store. Take some time and give the area a good look. Then you will climb a circular staircase to where the huge stained glass windows are. Most people seemed to open their mouths in amazement when they first saw the sight. I did.

Holy place. If you like church history, then this place is worth the price of admission. St. Louis built it to house the relics of the true cross. The stained glass panels tell the whole story of the bible and are close to 9 centuries old. Quite impressive.

Gem. This beautiful old church is a small gem! Beautiful architechture, magnificent stained glass windows and phenomenal acoustics.We were able to catch a concert here and thoroughly enjoyed it! Check the schedule of concerts before you go and if available, don't miss the opportunity to attend a performance here.

BE PREPARED TO QUEUE. The chapel itself is stunning. Read about it. BUT as it's so close to a major govt building (Courts) you have to go through security checks. This involves queuing. THEN you have to queue for a ticket which seems to take for ever and we couldn't work out quite why. People also get to push in if they have a combined ticket with the nearby Conciergerie or a Museum Pass.Windows are being restored, so be prepared to have a bit of scaffolding around, however this is due to finish in the next year or so and should be well worth it. try and go on a sunny day when the light comes streaming through the windows. If it's dull and raining, it's not nearly so good.

Well worth the trip. Sainte Chapelle may not be as famous as Notre Dame but the former Royal chapel is well worth a visit. You won't need a ton of time to complete your visit - the building itself is fairly small - but be sure to take some time to take in the beautiful stained glass that surrounds the chapel.Sainte-Chapelle is located in the middle of the French judiciary headquarters (basically the Department of Justice) so you will have to go through a security check to get in - leave yourself enough time if you are on a tight schedule. Its covered by Museum Pass but the pass will not help you with the security line - you can skip the ticket line but that is rarely long.If you don't want to spring for the Pass, think about getting the dual Sainte-Chapelle/Conciergerie ticket.. Both are worth the visit (they are next door to each other) and you can save yourself a few euros by buying a combo ticket.

Under re-construction/cleaning!. First we were waiting in he line for so long to get in, then we have been told that the facade is under cleaning process. As they were cleaning, we couldnt see the windows which were the reason we came at first place! Check out before going there!
Stained Glass Wonder. Unbelievable stained glass windows. Best I've ever seen. Bring a long telephoto lens or opera glasses to really appreciate.
The most beautiful monument in Paris. You have to experience this beautiful church. The first floor is gorgeous with all the gilt pillars, but the second floor is breath-taking.

Nice Chapelle but bad security management. There are two lines next to eachother when entering the Chapelle. One for the Chapelle and another for the museum of justice or similar. The que for the chapelle was long but not for the museum of justice. However both ques get you inside and there was no reason for standing in a long line for the chapelle when you could have entered through the other security lines. Irritating. And not signs or nothing giving a clue. The Chapelle itself is well worth a visit. The artwork of the windows is amazing.
Nice Church. Nice ornaments, just like another common church. Not too big to explore more. But i like the statue of Saint Louis there. :)
beautiful. Had a lovely evening of chamber music. Vivaldi. Very special. Worth getting tickets if such a performance is available. Very intimate concert.

Stunning stained glass. Sainte-chapelle is stunning, the stained glass is beautiful, I would highly recommend this stop, it's not far from notre damn, and will take no more than 30 minutes to go through!

Too small. For the amount of security checks and the long line, the tourist site was just a bit too small to be worth it. Having said that; if the line is short, go for it! The portion of stained glass that has been restored is amazing and you can see how magical it would look when the light is able to shine through all of Sainte-Chappelle. Restoration works are still in progress, quite fascinating to read about.
Beautiful Church. This had to be one of the most beautiful churches we've seen. The stainglass is so amazing - I was left in awe.

Pretty, not very reverent.. Really beautiful in the afternoon light. Gift shop on the lower floor and then walk up some narrow stairs to the chapel. I wish there were a few more benches to linger and admire.

Beautiful Windows. The "tour" was really just one room, and it was all about the stained glass windows. Beautiful, tall, glorious color, but really seems like a lot of fuss with the security and charging to enter.
fantastic stained glass windows. If you have the museum pass (highly recommend), I'd definitely set aside a half-hour to see this. The stained-glass windows are lovely.

The perfect chapel stop!. St Chapelle is intimate, plain (well, not quite!) and when visited in off season( fewer visitors) or at the right time of day, when the sun streams through the famous windows, it is magical. For those who don't like church visits or are "cathedraled out" please plan a visit to St Chapelle because it is unlike anywhere else in Paris. It is unfurnished and is justly famous for the beautiful stained glass and starry ceiling on the second floor. I stop there every time I am in Paris and it always strikes a chord in me. Allow it to do the same for you.

If you only see one church in Paris make it this one!. This was hands down the most beautiful and well kept church we saw while in Paris. I could have spent all day just admiring all of the gorgeous windows based on various books of the Bible. If you get the Paris pass, once you're through security, you can bypass the line to get into the actual church. This saved us at least 30 minutes of waiting in line. Since this is located right next to the Concierge, I'd recommend a quick stop into the old prison too.

A Voir! - Must see. Words cannot describe what your eyes will see in Sainte-Chapelle. A royal chapel - you enter the lower chapel where the colours are rich and the history is tangible...but you haven't seen anything yet. Climb the narrow stairs to the top chapel to see high, continuous stained glass walls that give a feeling of space and wonder. It feels like standing in the midst of a jewel box. If the sun shines, even better, but this sight is a big wow! The Joshua window is currently being refurbished which means that a small section of the chapel is currently screened off, but you'll still be glad you went there. One not to miss.

Beautiful, Lesser-Known, Treasure in Paris. While this church is smaller and costs a few euros to visit, it is absolutely beautiful inside. The stained-glass windows are exquisite and the artwork impeccable. I find this church to be more alluring than Notre-Dame or even Sacre-Coeur.
Sainte-Chapelle. There was beautiful stained glass. But I was expecting the over all experience to be more aw inspiring! The line to get in was very long, our wait to get in was about an hour or so.
Beautiful..... Too bad this church is not in the middle of a park or other open area. Its beautiful, does not take a long time to visit and the Metro is close by.
Vivaldi concert. What a spiritual experience to listen to Vivaldi amongst the stained glass windows. Try to attend one of the concerts.

Beautiful Stained glass.. Long slow line and added security. The admission is 8.50 Euro.The extensive stained glass in the upper sanctuary tells many biblical stories and is undergoing an extended renovation of the where the windows are taken out cleaned and repaired. They are doing this slowly and carefully and will be an ongoing project. It is a beautiful and impressive visit. They offer classical music concerts certain days of the week. The acoustics are amazing.
The best stained glass windows in the world?. Absolutely spectacular windows. We haven't visited it for a few years, but it is a must-see if you are in Paris. Tends to get crowded.

Gorgeous Stained Glass. To get in, you need to go pass security and have your bag ready to be xrayed. Once through, you can head over to the Chapel which is surrounded by the public buildings, so you can't enjoy its architecture outside as much. But inside, you see how beautiful it is - the painted ceilings, the stained glass panels, the statues, etc. It is a short walk through but beautiful. The ceiling of the lower chapel is gorgeous with its painted surface. This is simply one of the finest chapels in Paris.

Visit for the stained glass windows. A visit to the Sainte Chapelle ties in well with a visit to the Notredame as they are on the same island (ile de la cite). The monument is included with the musuem pass. Having the pass also allows you to bypass the queue once you have entered the complex/premises. The Chapelle is nothing much to speak of from the outside. But the stained glass windows in the inside are stunning!!

A long wait!. We had to queue for 40 minutes to go through the security in order to visit Sainte Chapelle. I think it was worth it, although some of the windows are undergoing restoration. The sun shone while we were there and the whole thing is quite stunning.

Gorgeous. Loved seeing the stained glass in this church; it's absolutely breathtaking. However, I wish we had invested in the Paris Museum Pass, because this is included. It was a little pricey to get in and I don't want to say it's not worth the price, but if it was a part of the full pass I would have felt even better about it.But you will enjoy the stunning stained glass...it's exquisite.

Beautiful. At the moment half of the stained glass is under restoration, but even at that, this is a stunning church. Try to go on a sunny day, when the stained glass will really be wonderfully lit up.

Use your museum pass!. It is beautiful. BEAUTIFUL! The stained glass is amazing, and even though they are in process of restoration, you still see a great deal of it. However, it costs 8.50 euro to get in. It's included on the Museum Pass, so if you get that, make use of it! It does not take long to see all there is to see so you can squeeze it in on a busy day. I just thought it was a bit pricey for what you got, considering the Lourve costs 10 euro and you could spend days in there.

Too Much $$ and long lines. it is a beautiful chapelle, but it cost 9 euros to enter and you have to go thru the hassle of a metal detector, since its inside a govermental building. Not much history and they are constanly remodeling and covering half of the stained glasses.

jewel box. small, yet so inspiring - the gothic arches and stained glass are just so fabulous, on the 2nd floor especially, you feel as if you are inside a jewel box. We arrived 1/2 hour after they opened - the queue was not long and the place not all that crowded - there was a nice video showing the painstaking detail of the stained glass restoration - worth the watch - and that stained glass - wow!
Will be great when repairs are completed. Beautiful, old cathedral with wonderful windows, but they are under a major renovation and half the windows are covered with cloth.

Get there early. If you are looking for a hidden gem, go here. Small, but worth seeing. Make sure you get there early to avoid waiting in line. Amazing stained glass windows. Every single window pane is unique. Great to see.

the mosaics. So the lines for security is a drag, but I liked this church a whole lot more than notre dame. you can really imagine what it was like to be King Louis and how he worshipped in this church

awesome stained glass. a little disappointing due to renovations but then, what centuries-old landmarks don't need refurbishing. i would recommend doing some advance study or reading about the panels before visiting as they are mounted so high you will not see much with teh naked eye
Quick tour to see Paris history and nice architecture. On the way to see Norte-Dame, stop by Sainte-Chapelle to absorb some Paris history and nice architecture. Museum pass get you in free.

Concert Overpriced. My wife and I attended one of the night-time concerts at Saint-Chapelle for 25 Euros each. It was a solo violin performance of some Bach partitas. The violin performance was fine, however, instead of the concert being in the main sanctuary, it was in another room with some stained glass and construction work. We had thought for paying 25 Euros for a one-hour concert, advertized as being at Saint-Chapelle, it would have used the accoustics and grandeur of the sanctuary, but not so. The price of the concert did not even include a visit to the sanctuary, so we skipped this during our one-week visit to Paris. This was very disappointing. A tip is to skip Saint-Chapelle - Notre Dame is free, as is Saine-Genevieve and many others.

Best part of our trip to Paris. We went here for a concert (You will see fliers all over in Paris, as the concerts are frequent). It is an experience like no other - we went for Vivaldi's Four Seasons, and were so moved by the music and the beauty of Sainte-Chapelle, it was something I will never forget. Don't miss this - and do try one of the concerts, it is well worth it (Paying extra for the VIP tickets was also one of the best choices we made - puts you right up front!)

mind-blowing. Some of the most beautiful stained glass in all of Europe. They're in the midst of a multi-year project to clean all the windows, and the difference is striking. The light streams through the ones they have cleaned so far, and the effect is mesmerizing. You have to pay extra to get in, but it's well worth it. Just a short walk from the Cathedral of Notre Dame.

A Masterpiece of History. One of the most beautiful collection of original stained glass windows in a well preseverd church. Yes there is a line up usually but it does move fast and this should be one of your top ten places to see if it is not on your list.
Don't miss this church. It was on our museum pass and we heard about the stained glass windows - wow. It was so lovely and its not going to eat up a huge part of your day
avoiding lines. Buy the combo ticket (Conciergerie+St. Chapelle), it is cheaper and you avoid one of the queues. The chapel is little, but very beautiful.
Worth it but pricey and busy. Once inside the windows were very impressive but it was a little expensive (€8.50 each I think) and it was the longest thing we queued for. Glad we went though.
Underwhelming. It was under renovation, and you do not see the whole beauty of the chapel.Small and crowded.Good to see with a museum pass, not something i'd go out of my way again to visit.

Lovely concert. I was fortunate enough to visit twice. Last year via the Rick Steves tour. This year, we attended a lovely and intimate Vivaldi concert. For the encore, the conductor gave us an explanation of the music and how it relates to the subject matter. However, he did it in French. I was able to follow some of it. For example, he told us what sound on the violin was a bird, the heat of summer, ice skating, and falling on the ice.

Beautiful - must see. Truly wondrous- must experience. Can make it the same morning trip with Notre Dame tower and cathedral- would choose over Notre Dame cathedral if limited on time... No museum pass priority line so there was a queue to get in but did seem to go by fairly quickly.

Amazing use of glass and light. Do not let the lines deter you, this is a MUST SEE for Paris. If you get a Museum Pass you can skip the ticket line on the inside and will get moved to the front of the security line.The chapel downstairs is beautiful, but it is when one goes upstairs that one is overwhelmed by the extravagant craftsmanship. Don't be rushed and spend time "reading" the windows and meditating on what grand feats the design and construction of this beautiful chapel were. There are good guides in English available in the chapel.

Beautiful stained glass.. This is my second visit to Ste-Chappelle. The first time I was really wowed. The vibrancy of the stained glass is amazing. If the sun is shining on the glass it's stunning. The wait could be a hassle but I had a museum pass and walked past the ticket line and could have gone in a separate security entrance to bypass that line too if I had entered the queue from the opposite direction where a sign directed ticket holders to enter. This time it was still beautiful but with almost a third of the glass under construction it's not as nice. The symmetry of all the stained glass reaching to the peak of the roof was part of what I liked. With some windows covered it's still stunning but some of the effect is lost. The chapel is small so size isn't impressive, it's the lavish stained glass that is so good.  People were thoughtful and mostly quiet the day my daughters and I visited so it was a good visit. I would still recommend seeing Ste Chappelle. I haven't seen that concentrated amount of stained glass anywhere else before. I like Notre Dame, and Sacre Coeur also, but Ste Chappelle is unique in it's being almost completely stained glass, instead of the usual stained glass scattered about the churches. It's a stairway walk up to the glass windows, I don't think I saw an elevator or alternative approach for the stairs. If you don't go up the stairs and see the stained glass in the second level you will miss the real reason to see Ste-Chappelle.
Gorgous. Get the Museum Pass and skip the lines. Well worth your time. We listened to the Rick Steve's free audio tour.

Beautiful. This was the only museum I paid for to get in. I'm not religious by any means but I appreciate good artistry. This place does not disappoint. Make sure to get there at a good time or you could be waiting a while. This place is amazing,

Beautiful. When we first entered the Chapelle, we thought what a waste of money to see a small room. However, we soon found out there were stairs leading up to the main room where the stained glasses were just so beautiful. Next to the Palace du Justice and security guards everywhere to make the area safe.

Beautiful chapel under renovation. My daughters and I loved the Sainte-Chapelle when we toured it in 2011 so it was a no-brainer to return in May of 2012. My daughter and I arrived early before it even opened and so we were some of the very first in the beautiful chapel.The stained glass literally glows from the towering windows, reaching to the sky. It was nice being the chapel when it was not crowded but unfortunately, the chapel is undergoing renovations and so about 25% of the gorgeous windows are under wraps. It's been a lengthy process and I'm surprised we were able to view the entire chapel when we were there last year. They must have been taking a break on the project.It is still very beautiful, but some of the effect was lost and it was more challenging to photograph so not so show the wooden structure covering the work area.I'm still glad we went, but hope to return someday when the project is complete.
Saint-Chappelle. Went there on our Rick Steves tour. It was beautiful! Wish that the wall being renovated was completed, but renovations probably go on all the time there!
Amazing site, but dirty. Obviously Sainte-Chapelle is a jewel of high gothic architecture. But why is the lower chapel filled with gift shops? And why is the upper chapel so terribly dirty?

queue. We had a fairly long queue in the sun on a very hot day which wasnt great but this is a truly amazing church. There are cards in different languages that explain about the church, it was built in 1248 and has 15 huge stained glass windows on the top level. Some of them are closed off as they are doing them up but its still worth paying the entry and seeing this beautiful sight

The Miraculous Medal. We were on pilgramage of the Shrines of France and now I have visited this place twice. What amazes me most about St. Catherine Laboure is her heroic humility. She was an amazing woman and truly worth reading about her life. I do not think anywhere in all Christendom is there a more humble saint to be found. She was young when Mary visited her and died an old woman who never spoke of her vision except to her confessor. She worked at the humblest of tasks with the cows! I love this small corner of Paris. It is peaceful.

Memories of times gone by. This is a lovely church but it is in serious need of renovation. It is also very touristy and the poor guards do not quite manage to keep the crowds from being noisy which detracts from the experience. I will be going back next year in the hope that their efforts to restore it has been sucessful ..it truly is a treasure.

Very impressive set of stain glass windows. This thirteenth century chapel has an impressive set of stain glass windows depicting stories from the bible, as well as a large rose shaped stain glass window from the fifteenth century depicting the biblical Apocalypse.

Many other better options. Our second visit to Paris, my biggest disappointment the first time was that we did not go to Sainte-ChapelleWell, this time I made sure we would not miss it, on a sunny afternoon we took the line (must confess I was a little worried about it since there are so many negative comments on how much time people spend waiting, but, to my surprise, in less than 10 minutes we were in)First things first - Sainte-Chapelle will not amaze you, Notre Dame and Sacré Coeur, to cite exclusively religious attractions, are more interesting and beautiful and have much more to offerDo not get me wrong, it is beautiful and different, but it's so much smaller than I expected, one of the walls was being repaired (nothing worse than having a small attraction with its third part blocked by construction stuff, anyways it feels like it needs repairing, but we should be warned about it before paying almost 20 euros to see it)10 minutes in line, 20 minutes inside, the best of it is that you will not spend much time and can go see the dozens of better places to see in Paris (and by saying dozens I am NOT exaggerating since we are talking Paris here)As I have said above, do not get me wrong, it is beautiful, but highly overrated

Loved the concert. What a beautiful setting, and our family enjoyed hearing a 7pm concert for Vivaldi. The music was lovely and musicians so animated. Our concierge helped us get tickets (and reserved front row seats for us which was particularly nice for our children (6 and 9 and their friends). I didn't find a website easily.

One of the best churches in the world. Seen a # of churches but this not so large church is a true gem. The stained glass is simply the best in the world. Also, entry is free with your paris meseum pass, so if you are in the area, absolutely no excust to miss it. And definitely less crowded than Notre Dame next door.Amazing effort to renovate this - you should see the work the folks are doing to keep the stained glass in pristine condition - educational for the kids as well
Great visit. beautiful bldg (former abbey) with intact portion with a greta collection of 15-17th Century tapestries and essentially pieces form other catherdrals.
Skip this one. I found it disappointing , unless you are really a big fan of stained glass windows. It is also under renovation and charge to enter.
Outstanding!. Absolutely beautiful. Download the Rick Steves' Audio Guide (free on iTunes) and listen while you visit. The stained glass is absolutely amazing. Buy the MuseumPass.

Don't miss the highlight!. Going here, don't think you've seen it all with a walk in the main chapel. Thou must goest up the tiny spiralling stairs to get to the main attraction. And it won't disappoint!

A Must See. Although we have been to Paris a number of imes, we still went back to see Sainted-Chapelle for its beautiful tined glass windows. We were a bit disappointed tht it has become more touristy than it previously was.

Excellent-best cathedral in Paris. Around the corner from Notre Dame but without the crowds-very beautiful cathedral. Church is undergoing a massive restoration and cleaning of stained glass (underwritten by Velux Foundation). When we visited, about 1/2 of the windows have been restored and the differences between the clean and dirty windows is striking. Cleaning expected to be completed in another 2 years. Other note-this chapel is on the grounds of the French Justice Ministry so you have to undergo a metal detector and security check to gain access.
Beautiful little Chapel!. Well worth seeing - the place is stunning! There is typically a line-up to get in, but don't get discouraged - well-worth the wait.

Nicer than the Norte dame.. I prefer this church over the Norte dame. The stained glass windows are the most amazing I have ever seen, and is easily worth the entrance fee. Even though you go there to see then stained glass windows, the ground floor area is beautiful as well with the "fleur de lis" painted on the walls. This one of the most beautiful churches that I have ever seen, and a must see if you are in Paris.

Color, Color, and More Color!. This is truly an astounding place. After entering the building through a humble lobby, and climbing up an even more-humble staircase, you emerge into a chapel full of color. The expanse of stained glass, painted ceiling, and colorful statues will take your breath away. It's truly stunning. It's a short visit, often with long lines, but SO WORTH IT.

Stained glass wonder!. The windows are terrific but make sure you see them with plenty of sunlight to get the most of the colors. I would recommend getting the combo ticket for the conciergerie..the palace/prison next door.

Sainte - Chapelle. Absolutely stunning stain glass windows, superb and breathtaking view once you enter the Church. The hundreds/thousands of individual stain glasses depict a different scene or story. I believe the Church was built around the 13 or 14 century. Its close to Notre Dame and easy enough to find on the map, take a closer look and you won't be disappointed.

The most beautiful display of stain glass you will find. This is written up in all the Tour guide books as a must see. Take their word for it. We found this Chapelle on a podcast entitled 'Historic Paris' takes around 3 hours starting at Notre Dame...

Heavenly strings in a celestial setting!. Went there at 7pm on a summer's evening..the sun setting through the immense areas of awe-inspiring stained glass and sat down to the sounds of maestro 'Bertrand' and his sextet chamber orchestra playing Albinoni,Handel andThe Four Seasons.Standing ovation and encore!Tickets available beforehand or at the door.

It will be perfect when they finish the restoration. Two chapels on two levels in one majestic building. The upper chapel has an impressive altar, beautifully lit. The whole of one side was being restored and, when completed, the high stained gless windows will be amazing. The ones that were visible made the visit worthwhile. When the sun came out the effect made the visitors gasp!

Go early to mimimize Q line. Best stained glass windows (floor to ceiling of vivid colors) I've seen after visiting numerous other churches and palaces in Paris and London, but get there before it opens, as the Q line can be very long and slow. It's also included in the Museum Pass.

Breathtaking. Renovations going on at the moment so it looses a bit of impact. Having said this church has some of the best stain glass in all of Europe.Access is very limited for the physically impaired. Overall breathtaking

Great Church. Less of a line than some of the other more well-known churches but very historic & so beautiful. Recommend getting the audio here as there are all kinds of explanations of things in the church that otherwise I would have never known. Very interesting & worthwhile.

Breathtaking. We went to 'La Conciergerie', which is next door to 'La Sainte-Chapelle' and purchased combo tickets for both sites. However, we almost missed La Sainte-Chapelle as we initially thought they were referring to the chapel in La Conciergerie. It was only after leaving La Conciergerie and walking down the street where we noticed a line up. Wondering what the line up was for, we poked around and realized that this was also part of our admission price.It isn't overly obvious where you have to enter to get into La Sainte-Chapelle, but once you get in you realize what a gem it is.The stained art is absolutely breathtaking.

Takes your breath away. The Sainte-Chapelle should be on every visitor to Paris' 'to do' list. Takes a while to enter due to security checks and my first impression of the lower chapel was one of being rather underwhelmed (although it is quite lovely). Then you go up the steps to the higher level and ....wow - the beauty of it takes your breath away. On my visit the sun was shining brightly and the glorious stained glass was lit up to perfection. The size of the windows is particularly impressive when you consider the era when the chapel was built. Definitely don't miss this.

Beautiful Stained Glass. The Chapelle is truly beautiful. The stained glass is very unique and the history is of course amazing. The lines and security to get into the chapel are very long, which is why I rate this a 3. If you have the time, it is worth the wait.

Stainglass of Exceptional Quality. This was our second visit to this royal chapel, situated close to Notre Dame. It is a little difficult to enter, as the entrance is shared with (legal) court buildings where security is tight. However, it is worth making the effort to visit. Since our last visit most of the massive stain glass windows (I believe from the 11th century) have been cleaned and restored. The sun shone through them. There is a lower chapel, but it is the main one upstairs that gives one a magical experience! In Europe there are so many amazing cathedrals and churches, but Sainte-Chapelle is better than most, and should leave you with a wonderful happy memory of your visit!

Stained glass wonder. Having seen fragments of 13 th century stained glass displayed in museums, it is truly spectacular to see it insitu, as intended by the craftsmen of the age. 70% of the glass is original which is truly astounding.Even though some panels were being restored during our visit the overall effect was still incredible.

An often overlooked visual wonder!. Perhaps due to its proximity to Notre Dame on the Île de la Cité, this church doesn't seem to get the attention of its far larger neighbor. However, I can say that the stained glass in this two story chapel is nothing short of amazing! There are handouts which explain the biblical stories depicted in the very intricate windows. Don't be fooled by the "plain" windows on the first floor that you see as you enter. The second floor is where the kings used to go to church, so that chapel is worthy of royalty. This one is on the Paris Museum Pass also, so if you have it and are going to Notre Dame anyway (who doesn't?), it is well worth the short detour.
Beautiful. Beautiful, go early to avoid queues or try sunset when the sun comes through the Rose window. Well worth a visit.
A beautiful place to visit. This is a tiny exquisite chapel inside the palais de justice/conciergerie area and is just stunning to see!! The top floor took my breath away!

A little gem. We loved the small size - compared with Notre Dame just around the corner. We had to queue to get in - and it cost E8 each. Three windows are being worked on at present but there are plenty of othes to look and marvel at. Try to spend some time working out the stories in some of the windows - us ethe boards (some in English) that are available - look for them by the way out!!

It's Beauty is Breathtaking. If you can, go to a concert in the evening to experience the beauty and magic of this amazing building. Tickets are on sale at a nearby cafe or at the chapel itself. The restoration work is an amazing feat of extreme expertise and dedication. Take binocs to see the detail. A wonderful place!

Top of my List - Visit it EVERY time !. Don't let the size fool you. Don't let the fact that it is hidden away in a courtyard fool you. Believe me that despite the 'famous' Paris attractions that 'everyone' knows - Sainte Chapelle is #1. It's an absolute historical gem. Furthermore, you will not find more beautiful stain glass (upstairs) anywhere... (Indeed try to be sure to get there when the sun is out & strong to really enjoy the windows in all their glory.) I've been there on my own (yes, using the laminated information cards available); with a local guide (wow!); and just popping in again and again to take in the magnificence of this amazing site. I have been to Paris multiple times - and every trip go back here.Don't miss it.IF you can catch a concert here - don't think twice, do it!
Loved it. Really nice - we loved visiting this area - good value on anything we bought here and found the people really friendly

Stunning!. Let me add my two cents to all of the other rave reviews. This chapel is just beautiful with its majestic stained glass windows and was worth the security search and long line to get in. Don't miss it!

Amazing, but under renovation.... the ongoing renovation is an amazing task in itself, but can detract from the visit right now. Take the time to study the information cards and learn about the story to get more from your visit.

What a surprise!. Everyone visit Notre Dame but in comparison to the Saint Chapelle this is a dull and colourless church. Just across the road behind the Palais de Justice hides the entrance to this fabulous jewel in Paris. The gasps of wonder as first-time visitors enter the main chapel area bear out how brethtakingly beautiful this is .... don't miss it!

Disappointing. Long lines and security checks for only 2 rooms, not as well preserved as expected, waste of time and money. Crepe store on the corner across the road is great but, as is the pizza cafe in the centre of the opposite block

A gem of stained glass. Easy to miss but worth a stop. If you have an hour, try a performance after the chapel is closed for touring. Sitting with the light coming through all the amazing stained glass windows while a string quartet and a singer perform in this space created just for this, Will give you chills.
Stained Glass Heaven. Be sure to visit on a sunny day to see the windows at their best. It's not really worth standing in line for an hour or more on a cloudy day.
Small yet breathtaking!. You can walk by this without knowing. We researched before leaving so decided to take a look. Won't write in detail but will say you need to just see it for yourself. Supèr!

To get the full effect, must see a performance!. I had a Paris pass and stopped in early in the day on the first floor and I wasnt all that impressed. However, I decided to come back for a Violin orchestra play at 7 pm (Vivaldi Les Quartre Saisons). They sold the tickets midday across the street at the tabacco shop or at the door prior to performance time (if not sold out.) The price was $ 35 US dollars but so worth it! From the afternoon light against the beautiful stain glass windows, to the old church acoustics it was the most profoundly moving experiences of my life.
Small Gem. This is a smaller cathedral, but very beautiful. Not as crowded Notre Dame, and still very interesting.
A Little Piece of Heaven. Such beautiful stained glass windows and we caught them when the sun was perfect. Breathtaking. Interesting stair case though - not for those wobbly on their legs.

Stunning, amazing, fantastic.... I was almost shocking, when I entered the Chapelle! It was the biggest experience in Paris.The huge stainedglass windows everywhere was simple fantastic and unique. I couldnt imagine, what holds the building, when only windows. I have never and nowhere seen such a beautiful chapelle. As the sun shines through the windows its unforgettable. Must see!

See a concert here if you can. We enjoyed a lovely concert here at dusk in June, 2012. The string quartet was fantastic, and the setting, inside Saint Chapelle, was other-worldly. The windows are a sight that should not be missed in Paris; in my view, much more intimate and awe-inspiring than Notre Dame. Don't miss this beautiful place.

Took my breath away!. I read about Sainte-Chapelle on Trip Advisor and had missed it on previous trips to Paris. I am so glad we went this time. We didn't think it was difficult to find. It's basically just down the street from Notre Dame in the Palais of Justice. There are signs also where to line up. You do have to go through a security checkpoint (probably because it is inside the Palais of Justice). It's your average security checkpoint, you are allowed to bring in bags, just not weapons of any kind. A tourist immediately in line in front of us had to throw his pocket knife in the garbage. We went right when it opened in the morning on a Friday and didn't experience any lines at the security checkpoint or at the entrance gate. None of the employees stand out in my mind, they were neither especially rude nor especially friendly. The chapel doesn't look like much from the outside and when I saw the entrance hall on the bottom level, I was still wondering what everybody considered such a big deal. Then we climbed up the winding staircase and when I turned the corner it took my breath away! So beautiful! They were the most amazing stain glass panels I have ever seen in 30 years of traveling in Europe. Incredibly impressive--a true must see! One of the panels was covered for restoration, but most were recently cleaned and displayed in splendor. There was information in many languages on the pictures and stories on the windows and on the restoration process. It's included in the Museum Pass (which is absolutely worth getting) and children up to 18 are absolutely free. One of the highlights of our visit to Paris! I would recommend going early in the day to avoid lines.

Much smaller than expected. We went to Sainte-chapelle because it was one of the highest rated attractions in Paris. The stained glass windows of the church as truly majestic. However, we were so surprised on how small the church actually is. Basically you can see 2 small rooms about 2000 square feet each. I think admission is included if you purchase the museum pass so if you have that, it may be worth it as there is not much of a line-up to get in. Otherwise skip it.
Amazing!. Breathtakingly beautiful. Brought tears to my eyes. A welcome treat after climbing the stairs. Did the combined ticket with the Conciergerie so I did not have to endure the long line.
So beautiful!. Really beautiful stain glass windows. We didn't wait in the line for Notre Dame and went here instead, very short line and definitely worth it!
A must see. Go on a sunny day for best effect. The windows were amazing but if you go on a wet day you lose half the effect

Beautiful and great value. Since doing an art project related to Sainte-Chapelle I have wanted to go and I wasn't disappointed. I dragged two other members of my family along who hadn't heard of this attraction and we all loved it. The stained glass was breathtaking. I would highly recommend a visit ! One of the highlights of Paris.

A religious jewel box. The lines to see this are very long, so try to figure out when to go, perhaps when it opens in the morning. Part of it is obscured by construction, so the effect of the wall-to-wall stained glass windows is likely to be reduced just now, but it's a must-see sight anyway, especially if this is going to be your only trip to Paris.

Don’t miss this chapel!. Brought a friend with me in December and she thought it was awesome! The windows are so beautiful… Amazing what could be built in 1300 century! We were lucky and visited the chapel the first Sunday in December and the entrance was free. There are a lot of museums with free entrance the first Sunday of the month.

Hard to find but do try. This takes a little planning, but this is truly worth it to see. An astonishing profusion of stained glass that survived the bombing of Paris. This is probably the coolest church to see in Paris.

You can't NOT go. This is a sublime experience. The only thing to beware of is that anyone with accessibility issues is going to have trouble getting up to the chapel. Narrow, winding staircase. It's a pity, because everyone should experience this stunning masterpiece.
A must see. Do try and see this beautiful chapel, a feast for the eyes. Don't be put off by the possible queue, it is worth the effort.
Breathtaking. I almost don't want to recommend Sainte-Chapelle because I would hate for it to become overrun with tourists. It is absolutely breathtaking. I'm going there this next Monday...

Go here!. The Saint-Chapelle is amazing and definitly worth the queue (even in the rain). What an amazing piece of architecture!To see the bible in stained glass was fantastic, teh craftmanship, the ingenuity! Don't miss htis on a trip to Paris.
STUNNING!. We went to a concert in this place, and it was magical... The music mixing in this amazing stained glass chapelle... Magical!

Can't Say Enough. Fantastic, Amazing, Extraordinary, Unbelievable. All these adjectives apply. The stained glass is so overwhelming that I just stand awe-struck. I took pictures, of course, but nothing does justice to the sight of all that color in the sunlight. No trip to Paris is complete without a trip to Sante-Chapelle
wonderful, wonderful experience. our experience of a twilight concert in this beautiful space was, as my wife puts it, "pretty close to heaven".

Incredible stained glass!. The lines can be long, but this is an incredible place to see. Tip: Buy a ticket next door at the Conciergerie for that tour (it is the old prison where Marie Antoinette was held before she was beheaded) and Sainte-Chapelle. With the combo ticket you can by-pass the line at Sainte Chapelle.

Sainte Chapelle. I don't know what I was expecting but it wasn't this - the stained glass is astonishing in both its beauty and scale. The panels are huge and richly coloured even on a gloomy February day. The richness of the architecture and the glory of its execution are one of the things everyone needs to put on thier list.
Not too bad. it's good, but isn't more different from other cathedral. There are a duo called "The presteej" that play wonderful music near. Must listen

Beautiful Small Cathedral, Great Setting For Concerts. My family and I saw a concert performed at Sainte-Chapelle. It was our favorite experience during a week spent in Paris. It is a beautiful cathedral with incredible stained glass. Much more manageable than Notre Dame and a lovely setting for concerts, which they have fairly frequently.

Gem of a chapel. This gothic chapel has superb stained glass windows that have been restored. The lines to enter were about 35 mins on a Wednesday at 3 pm. The restoration process for stained glass is quite intensive and this is covered in the museum. Well worth a visit. Location is Boulevard du Palais, Ile de la Cité and the hours: Daily 9:30 am – 6 pmMetro stop: Cité

Beautiful Chapel, long line and expensive. I was told I must visit Sainte-Chapelle. It is a beautiful chapel near Notre Dame that is surrounded in stained glass. I love stained glass and churches, so I had to go. It was beautiful! It is quite small though and the line very long. The thing I found interesting was it cost $8.50 euros, I believe when even Notre Dame was free. I assume this cost goes to the preservation project they are doing though, so I am ok with that. I wish I could have been there for one of the 7 p.m. concerts. I think that would be amazing!

Timing is everything. This is a very, very pretty church and the stained glass windows inside are just incredible and unique. Each window depicts section or story of the Bible (new and Old Testament). It is a small church, compared to Notre Dame.The difficult thing about this church is the wait. We waited for almost two hours to see it because the security equipment (airport scanner/bag check) was broken and they had to do screens by hand. It is a very popular attraction, so bring a sandwich and a bottle of water and be prepared to wait. Definitely worth a visit, but you will only need to do once. Can't remember if photography is allowed ore not.
