Sainte Chapelle Under Restoration. We were a little disappointed because some of the church was closed due to restoration. It was very hot and crowded but the audio commentary was excellent and the stained glass exceptional. Don't miss the carvings on the outside of the upper chapel that telln the story of creation. This is a great example of how people in the middle ages learned Bible stories without being able to read.

8.5 euros for two rooms. The chapel is great for its windows but you only have two rooms to visit and you will pay 8.5euros per person. The tour is very small and the rooms were both noisy despite the signs saying "silence".

Beautiful. This is a beautiful church that was built to house some holy relics (no longer there). It has stunning stained glass windows. It is truly very beautiful. I found it to me much more beautiful than Notre Dame. It is also part of the Paris museum pass and is certainly worth at least half an hour. The lines were not long compared to several of the other Paris attractions.

Fabulous on a sunny day. After reading about this site on trip advisor, we decided it must be worth it. After queueing in the blazing sun & paying approx €9 we walked in & were immediately disappointed. We both scratched our heads & thought "what was all the fuss about". But then we discovered a tight set of stairs up to the main Chapel area. WOW stain glass overload. Beautiful colours & designs.I don't have a need to return but beats lining up for Notre Dame.
Just beautiful. This lovely place was not easy to find but was well worth the effort. The stained glass windows were breathtaking.
worth a visit. saint chapelle is a gotic chapel in the heart of paris it was a big surprise for me the high glass windows and the story some of them tell it is worth a visit

Simply beautiful!. The small church with its amazing stain glass windows is simply beautiful. Especially on a sunny day, the colors in the windows are shining brightly and the whole chapel is covered in colorful light. Definitely worth a visit!

Fabulous stained glass. Inattended a solo violin concert in this jewel-like chapel. Enchanting visually with fabulous acoustics. I've been told that many concerts are given in this spot for the same reason. The stained glass depicts biblical scenes for the most part,

Beautiful!!!. This is such a wonderful chapel. I saw a few reviews of folks that didn't like it, but I guess they don't get it. It is a small place, that's why is a chapel, not a cathedral. The work that went into the stained glass is incredible. It was built in the 1200s, that's amazing! A few tips: use the Paris Museum Pass!!! This will shave hours and aggravation from your visit! The chapel is small, it is not a cathedral. Keep that in mind.

Long wait and high price. We waited in a long line to enter this beautiful church in Paris. The cost was 8.50 euros. Don't get me wrong, the church is amazing, but I was surprised to pay that amount to visit, when other churches in Paris and in Rome are free. Anyway, you will enjoy the experience. It's noisy and hard to pray, but the stained glass is so pretty you should see it in person. Tip: Make sure to bring toilet paper with you the day you visit in case you need to use the rest room. It's lacking! :-)

Really nice church you should see at least once.. The security line was pretty long but once we got past that the line for tickets and to enter the church went by pretty quick. I highly recommend everyone to see this beautiful church at least once. Walking up the stairs and seeing all that beautiful stained glass for the first time relly will take you breath away!!
Amazing stained glass windows. Does not take long to go round if you are near by but really worth a visit to see the windows. Amazing

Cool!. A beautiful place, the line was pretty long but went by pretty fast though, spent around 15-20 min inside taking photographs. You just need to see this place once, if I'm going back to Paris I'm not going here again. But, you should see it once!

Sainte-Chapelle--Stained Glass Splendor. Visited this amazing visual feast using our Paris Museum Pass. The lower chapel initially served as a parish church for the inhabitants of the royal palace. You then will ascend the narrow staircase to the royal chapel. This is a beautiful example of a Gothic architectural style called "Rayonnant" which is marked by its sense of weightlessness and strong vertical emphasis. The windows tell the story of the Bible panel by panel. Although damaged by revolutions and wars, the renovations (which are still on-going) have done a beautiful job restoring this stained glass splendor.
Most favorite. This gem of a chapel is absolutely stunning...a must see. Use your Museum Pass to bypass the ticket line and gain quick entry.
Under renovation through 2014. Beautiful church, but the light is significantly diminished during the restoration work. Bummer, because the windows are simply amazing.

Pillars & windows-wonders. The amazing first impression of all the colour, light, and high windows and ceiling... then discover all the details of the second-floor paintings on the pillars and walls!Unfortunately almost too crowded and noisy (high season).

My favourite chapel in Paris. The most beautiful chapel I have seen. Amazing!!! It is a sure stop every time I go to Paris!!! And make sure you go to the gelateria right across the street in the corner, they have also awesome crepes

Beautiful stained glass windows!. We were wandering around Ile de la Cite and found this gem. It's a small little church tucked within another palace. It was used for the royal family functions and is much more intimate than Notre Dame. The stained glass windows are beautiful.I used the Paris Museum Pass to enter and I was able to skip the line. Definitely worth it on a crowded summer day. This isn't really a Paris MUST-SEE on a first trip, if it hadn't been included in the Musem Pass, would likely have skipped it.
An amazing visual experience for an hour. Well worth visiting and doesn't take too long, wondrous visual feast of the glass and painted Walls.
Amazing Place!. We got to see a performance of Vivaldi there and it was beautiful. Well worth a vista. You will never see windows this beautiful!

Exquisitely beautiful - not to be missed. This chapel has the deserved reputation of being the most beautiful in Paris. We were mesmerised and wished we'd had longer there - and that there weren't so many people. Perhaps it would be a good idea to go first thing when it opens. It would also be amazing to go there for a concert. The colours in the stained glass are deep and lustrous. The Chapel on the ground floor is also beautiful, and it's worth spending time there also.
Stunning. A must-see each visit. Even for those who think they've seen enough stained glass for a lifetime, this small chapel is in a class by itself.

I wish I had a brocade robe and a tiara..... Walking into Sainte-Chapelle is like walking into the past or a movie set. One can only imagine what it was like when first built. It is like a jewel box. The fact that it survived two world wars is amazing and a blessing. A must see.

Good sight to see.. After a long line waiting in the sun for an hour, we finally got inside. It was worth it because it is a pretty amazing sight to see. Just bring an umbrella if you are not a fan of the sun because they have nothing above you when waiting on line.

wow. I like it even than St. Peter's Basilica in Vartican, and all the more famous religious sites I have visited so far. It's definitely not among the biggest and the most visited sacred monuments in the world. However, it's the only one that caught me with a jaw dropping wow, when I ascended to the upper level. See it for yourself on your trip to Paris. Buy a Paris Museum Pass , which is an excellent bargain, and visit this place free.

Nice!!!. We located this chapelle on our own which made us walking a lot. but when we were looking for it we went to this another chapelle which comes on the way and loved that one to. so these two chapelles are a must for tourists.
See a concert here!. You won't regret it. It is a gorgeous stained glass chapel and concerts are held frequently. The sound is excellent, it is an intimate setting, and historic too.
Jaw dropping!. Wasn't sure what to expect - perhaps not the most talked about site. But it was one of the most memorable - very dramatic. A must see!

Upper level.... When you first enter, you are confronted with a dull and gloomy room (if beautifully decorated). As you go up to the first floor (and especially when the sun is out) you can't help but be impressed by the stunning stained glass windows. It's worth a look if you are also visiting the Conciergerie, though I wouldn't travel to Ile St.Louis just for this.

Surprisingly amazing. We made a list before going to Paris on the things we wanted to do. This, for whatever reason, was not at the top of my list, but we ended up close to the Chapel one day and decided to go in. The windows in the upstairs chapel are currently under construction (through 2014 if I recall correctly) as they are replacing glass in quite a few of them, so there were windows which were blocked from view. However, with that said, it is quite an amazing chapel. The windows are absolutely gorgeous and the chapel itself is beautiful. It's a pretty quick walk-through, but definitely worth it!

Breathtaking. In beautiful Sainte-Chapelle, you can see up-close the astonishing architecture, design and decoration of a high gothic chapel unlike anything else anywhere the world. For such a small site, it's a real gem of historical ecclesiastical design. Worth the 30-min queue.

beautiful. the chapel is still under renovation but you can still admire the architecture and the beautiful stained-glass windows. It is said that Saint Chapelle is the most beautiful chapel in Paris, so it must be seen :)

Beautiful. We bought our museum pass here and this lasted for 2 days. It was only 39 Euros per person to visit a range of museums throughout Paris. The Sainte-Chapelle was lovely and the stained glass windows were very impressive. Get here early as the queues build up quickly.
Beautiful stained glass. The stained glass windows are great but did not get the whole grand feel as the place is undergoing restoration for some of the stained glass windows
Unexpected Highlight. Should be on the must-do-list. A rare sight, so don't expect to capture great photos which capture the true light of this chapel unless you have a great camera.

Beautiful and Uplifting!. One of the jewels of Christiandom, you should plan not to miss this outstanding chapel of the Royals. It has a sister chapel at Vincennes but the stained glass windows at Sanit Chappelle are truly magnificent...

a true gem. Even with the renovations this is the most awe inspiring example of stained glass I have ever seen! You don't have to be religious to appreciate the art and workmanship. Save some time in line by going near the end of the day, line ups were very long in the AM but we only waited 10 min at 2PM.
A Must for Any Visit to Paris. Get in line early to see this little gem of a church with its gorgeous stained glass windows. If possible, take in a concert to truly enjoy the experience.

Queues!. Clearly a must-see for God-botherers, this modest church contained some impressive architectural features, along with a well-stocked gift shop and no restriction on photography. I didn't think it deserved the entry fee or warranted the long queues.

A jewel undergoing renovation. The royal chapel is undergoing renovation until2014 and has one wall blocked off.still the beauty of the soaring stained glass shines through. Did not like the 45 minute wait to get in.

Pretty Nice. Lots of detail and lots to see. This is one place you wont want to miss if you're here. The intricate detail was amazing to see. You can stare the entire time and still not get everything here.

Beautiful!. This is a beautiful Church in Paris, my daughter and I enjoyed it so much more than the others. The line to get in was minimal, esp. compared to Notre Dame. Only key advise, which is important throughout Paris, Carry kleenx (or TP) and hand sanitizer as the bathroom in this facility (and many others) is without T.P and soap! So come prepared!!

Stained Glass Galore. Be ready to wait in line to get into the chapel. We waited for about 30-45 minutes to get in. It wasn't quite what we expected. We thought it would be much bigger - it's just a small chapel. But the stained glass is absolutely beautiful and breathtaking.
Wow! Beautiful. Do not miss this. THe stained glass windows were everything you could imagine and then more. A little disappointinging to see a sales shop set up in the middle of chapel
Highest point in Paris. Brilliant view of Paris, lots of history behing this church, good souvenir shopping in this area too.

Absolutely gorgeous!. We somehow missed this little gem of a chapel 20 years ago when we were last in Paris. Go to see the breathtaking stained glass windows. The museum pass lets you skip the long lines for tickets.

the Loveliest church in Paris.. Get up early and head towards Notre Dame. Stop on the way at St Chapelle to see where the Kings worshiped. be sure to go early as there will be a line and a security check as it is located in a ministry building area.

Beautyful glass decoration.. Major renovation is going on when we visited. Could not see much of the building. We saw only one hall and it is good. Very picturesque and good. I felt the ticket price should have been reduced as there is renovation going on and we can see larger part.

Awe-Inspiring. No words could adequately describe this beautiful church...I didn't know what to expect having to go through the same entrance as a courthouse but once in, you are in a place with the most beautiful stained glass. A definite must see
Gorgeous Church. Small but lovely with blues, greens, and reds...windows soaring up above. Do be prepared to wait though...it was a long security line even with the Museum Pass.

Not much to see. To be honest I was a bit disappointed. Everyone raved about this place and I set the bar quite high because of it. The wait was about 15 minutes to get in. The first floor didn't have much to see. The gift shop was on the first floor. There was a small narrow winding staircase to the second floor. Though the windows were very pretty there wasn't much else to see. You can easily do this place (minus the wait) in 15 minutes. The ugly huge white restaurant scaffolding sign took away from the beauty of the windows.
A great church with no sermon. You can visit this place fairly quickly and it is worth going to for the glass. Museum pass is the way to go.

The most beautiful interior space in the world. On our last trip to Paris, I marveled at the exquisite beauty of the upper chapel and pondered the engineering feat represented by the thin columns surrounded by so much glass so long ago. So, on our second trip to Paris, I wanted to make this place our sure revisit. We went to a Sunday night concert of renaissance and baroque music from violin, clavichord, flute and soprano. I was very happy to see that the French are restoring and repairing the north wall of the upper chapel, though the scaffolding detracted from the experience that night. It is still the most beautiful space I have ever been in.

Surrounded by beautiful stained glass. Sainte Chapelle is in between Pont Neuf and Notre Dame (about 10 min walking distance away) in Ile de la Citi, You should definitely spend an hour here. There are stained glass in many churches, but you don’t see panels after panels of ceiling height as in here.Everyone needs to get through security check (for the Justice Dept), once you get through it, you can go to the front of the line with your museum pass (so don't just stand in line with others). The wall of stained glass is on the second floor after you climb up a narrow winding stairway.There is restoration going on, but you still enjoy more than 3-quarter of wall. This is also not very crowded compared to other major Paris tourist attraction.
Splendor of the world. The stain glass has mostly been restored. How special it is to see the respect for our God and savior Jesus Christ. What a beautiful room. Praise God.
Amazing. The windows were impressive, especially if you visit when the sun is shining. Don't give this a miss!
Sainte-Chapelle. So beautiful, but I would recommend going at an off-peak time to avoid long lines-- we waited for quite a while (though it was definitely worth it)

Update on touring this site. Just recently returned from a trip to Paris and my second visit to this wonderful chapel. I thought it would be wise to give folks a heads up that there is a major renovation underway inside the chapel. Although this is to be expected at times with antiquity, it really does take away from the beauty and serenity of Sainte Chapelle. The chairs that use to line both sides of the chapel have been removed and one can no longer sit in quiet contemplation while soaking in the beauty of the stain glass windows. On a sunny day with the light streaming through the panes of glass, it is still a breath-taking experience. So, go but be aware that unti 2013 you might not get the best of Sainte Chapelle.
Gorgeous stained glass. We attended a Vivaldi concert at Sainte Chapelle and it was marvelous. The acoustics were superb and the surroundings splendid.

Breathtaking!. Did not know what to expect. You enter through the lower chapel which is stunning by itself; then take the stairs up to the upper chapel. As people come around the corner and have their first glimpse of the upper chapel, the gasps are audible! We have seen many gothic churches and cathedrals throughout Europe, but this is an absolute jewel. There are fine details in every square centimetre. It is a smaller church because it was for the use of the king and his courtiers. A must see!
Nice, but a slightly disappointed.. Another nice attraction to see in Paris. My wife really wanted to go here, and while nice, I had anticipated it to be a bit larger.

Skip Notre Dame and come here. If you had to choose between the two, this is the one. Even with many of the windows covered for renovation, this is the most exquisite Gothic church I've ever seen (and that's a lot). It's a tiny gem with all of the great BiIble stories told in its windows. Take your time and see the details. It's worth it.

A must see. Many people overlook this gem since it is sort of hidden within the Justice Department compound. It is one of the finest collections of stained glass to be found anywhere. As far as I could see, it is NOT handicap accessible.

Colorful lights and intimacy. The vitrages are gorgeous of course, but I would say that it is a little bit dollish from the close sight. In comparison to gothic cathedrals all over Europe it is so miniature.
Just okay. It was pretty inside, but it just wasn't something I would go back and tour again. It was free with our Paris Pass, so that's why we went.
Not the easiest to reach - but well worth it. Beautiful once you get there and walk around. Amazing singing as we walked around as well adds to the mood.
Beautiful. The stained glass in this chapel is really magnificent. It is a bit of a wait to get in but was worth the wait.
Beautiful. Recommend a tour or audio guide. We did not have these and feel like we missed out on some of the significance. Lots of stairs if you want to see the entire thing.

Heavenly Concert. The concert we attended here was fantastic. Vivaldi Four Seasons . . . I've heard this a thousand times, but never like this! The violin soloist, Paul Rouger, and the rest of the ensemble took it to a whole new level. Their performance, plus the venue, took my breath away.
Stunning. We went to one of the evening concerts held in St. Chapelle and it was moving and beautiful. If you have a free evening try to see a concert here, you won't regret it.

A work of art, not to be missed. Incredible that this level of art was achieved almost a thousand years ago. The small church is alive with the richest colors of any thing I saw in Paris, including the art museums. Don't miss it. It doesn't take long to see.

stunning exterior but interior average. a tad dull for me, but if you are catholic and want to pray, then go - its very well set out for that purpose and the attendants ensure that the noise of visitors is kept to the minimum

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. As everyone says, the stained glass windows are simply beautiful. This is a "must see" in Paris. One side of the chapel is undergoing renovation. We waited about 30 minutes in the security line and had a museum pass.

A jewel of a Chapel. Imagine a tiny church but built in the same style as a cathedral: Louis IX, or Saint-Louis, built it in the 13th century to house relics of Christ he had brought back from the Crusades. The stained-glass windows are exquisite! Inquire about musical performances that regularly take place there.

Paris's hidden reliquary. The fact that the Sainte-Chapelle is hidden from public view inside the walls of the Palais de Justice creates an aura of undeniable mystery; this may explain in part the long lines of tourists waiting to get in on any given day. Yet it maintains that aura even once you've made the pilgrimage inside. This 13th-century chapel built for Louis IX was designed to resemble a medieval reliquary -- a kind of jewel box on a giant scale. The result is a magnificent and utterly unique structure in stone and glass, well worth the wait. The nightly Renaissance and baroque music concerts in the summer offer an alternative way to experience the chapel.

The Most Beautiful Spot in Paris. Unfortunately, there was noisy and unsightly construction going on as they attempt to clean some of the gorgeous windows. But its a magical place and an excellent site for concerts if you get the chance. I try to visit every time I'm in Paris.

Indescribably Beautiful!. We had walked by Sainte-Chapelle for a few days, hoping to find just the right time when the lines were not so long to go inside. We finally decided just to go for it one day, because we had heard it was so worth the wait. We walked up to the HUGE line, but then immediately saw that we could go right in with our Museum Pass. What a welcome surprise! Sure, there was the obligatory bag check, but that took no time at all. There is simply no way to describe just how beautiful this church is! I've read that lots of people miss the little spiral staircase, and never see the truly spectacular chapel. Whatever you do, don't let that happen to you. The chapel upstairs is breath-taking! My favorite pictures from our trip to Paris were made here and show my boys standing there, looking up at the enormous stained- glass windows that encircle this magnificent space, with their mouths literally open in amazement. That moment was priceless! Saint Chappell will be at the top of my list any time I'm fortunate enough to be back in Paris.

13th century impressive stained windows. The church is one of the oldest Rayonnant gothic building in Ile de la Cite. . It was commisioned by King (St) Louis IX to house his collection of Passion Relics (now in Notre-Dame CAthedral) and served as the royal cathedral, one of the reasons it was severely damaged during the French Revolution. Today, the elegant church serves is used for baroque and camera music concerts.

Spectacular interior, but a very long wait.. First you wait outside to go through security. Then you wait inside to buy a ticket. It took almost 2 hours to get inside today, on a busy summer Saturday.It's a small place, but the interior is fabulous. Downstairs is a little odd, as they seem to have set up souvenir purchases, etc, inside of the lower area. But the sights are upstairs, where the stained glass windows are a surprising delight. Unfortunately, right now a couple of the windows are covered for renovations, so you don't get the completely surrounded experience, which I'm sure would be fabulous.I don't know if I would have gone if I'd known that it was going to be such a long wait, particularly for something so small.

Beautiful stained glass.. This was a lovely church with the most amazing stained glass we have ever seen. You will have a wait, and a security check to get in so keep that in mind. Once you go in, don't pay any attention to the gift shop, climb the steep stairs and the view will take your breath away. Keep in mind, St. Chapelle is undergoing renovations so you cannot see all of it, some in shrouded with drapes and scaffolding. I would love to go back once it is completed.

Stunning. This church is pretty well hidden and you wouldn't know it was there if you didn't already know about it. The stained glass windows here are a spectacular sight! They were working on renovating the left side of the windows but it did not interfere too much with our visit. The only complaint we had was that we used the museum pass (Paris Museum Pass) and it didn't allow us any special accommodations (such as a shorter line). Sainte Chapelle is not to be missed if you enjoy stained glass.
Extraordinary!. Largest expanse of stained glass in the world. Beautiful chapel and wonderful concerts inside at night.

Breath taking. If you are in Paris don't miss this Chapelle. Try to remember that you have to wait in order to get in, but it's worth every minute of it. You will be breathless, you will be enchanted and if you will be lucky enough to have a sunny day, than it's stunning.
Go for the Windows. With the Paris Museum Pass, we went directly in. This small chelp is a feast for the eyes. The interior blue glass is amazing. Not to be missed.
Amazing concert in a beautiful cathedral. The music was wonderful! The concert feautured Verdi's Four Seasons with a very talented 6 piece orchestra.

Tips to reduce waiting times and optimize your visit. An amazing cathedral that I recommend not to miss while in Paris. The is no secret that the cathedral is a masterpiece of Gothic architecture having one of the most extensive collections of 13th century stained glass anywhere in the world.The queues are usually long and waiting times may vary because you have to do a security check as the cathedral is in the garden of the Justice Palace.TIP: if you want not to wait in line too much and optimize your Paris visit I suggest you to choose a combined visit: Sainte Chappelle and Conciergerie. It costs 12.50 euro together for an adult but it worth the price. First go to the Conciergerie, 100m far from Sainte Chappelle entrance on the same street. As an indication, compared to the golden gates of the Justice Palace, Consiergerie is 50m on the right and Sainte Chepelle 50m on the left side. Buy there a combined ticket and visit Conciergerie (20-30 minutes visit time; TIP: don’t end your visit here after you see the 2 big halls, continue with the rest after you pass through the souvenirs shop. Strange map, I know). After You visit Conciergerie, skip the big line of the Sainte Chapelle and go directly to the special one in front.If there is no clerk at the special line go and find the guardian that’s between the 2 lines (Sainte Chappel and Justice Pallace share the same entrance and security check) and tell him you have already a ticket and he/she’ll direct you. This way you’ll save at least 1 hour of waiting time and see an additional monument too. Remember that between 13.00 and 14.00 Sainte Chapelle is closed.
Beautiful. Amazing stained glass windows and a wonderful piece of architecture. Close to other attractions such as Notre Dame Basilica, la Palais de Justice, and la Conciergilerie.

Amazing! Nothing like this has been built for centuries upon centuries!. La Sainte-Chappelle is the only surviving building of the Capetain royal palace on the Ile de la Cite. It was commissiond by King Lous IX of France to house his collection of Passion Relics, including the Crown of Thorns -- one of the most important relics in medieval Christendom. I was able to stand in the middle of the chapel and video tape 360* of incredible Gothic architecture. It blows your mind that it first started to be built in 1239, and 9 years later consecreated! If something today takes 9 years to be built, it wouldn't be built; but then again, nothing like this has been built for centuries upon centuries. It is a must see of Paris! Words cannot describe the detail and depth of this chapel! One of my favorites of Paris!!

The view from outside. The stained glass windows are beyond compare. After you tour the first and second floors from inside, go outside on the second floor, sit down, and view the stain glass from a farther vantage point. Your fellow tourists won't obstruct your view of the windows as much.

Beautiful stained glass. this church is so much more beautiful than Notee Dame.Not as well known, but the stained glass is amazing. We bought tickets for an evening Vivaldi concert. It was amazing Definitely worth the price

Most beautiful stained glass. Built as a chapel to house the Crown of Thorns relic, this sanctuary is accessible through the Conciergerie and is well worth the climb up a narrow winding staircase to see. The stained glass tells the bible stories in pictures if you know how to read it.

Early morning visit to St. Chapelle. The light was amazing coming through the stained glass windows. It's a beautiful chapel and interesting to see something on a smaller scale. The lined moved quicklyl

a little treasure that is not to be missed. My family of four (including two teens) totally enjoyed Sainte-Chapelle because of the amazing stained glass windows and beautiful interiors. It doesn't take very long to see it and if you have a Parish Museum Pass then you can bypass the line.

Stunning Stained Glass. We visited the Sainte-Chapelle recently and the stained glass windows are just amazing to see - it is very beautiful. We had a Paris Museum Pass, which saved us buying tickets but there was only one queue to join for the security check - we picked a time mid afternoon when it was less busy than we had seen it earlier in the day. My only observartion is that we did visit the Sainte-Chapelle straight after visiting the Notre Dame, so I think it did not seem quite as fabulous as it would have, if we had seen the Sainte-Chapelle first or had seen it on a separate occasion. Understandably it did seem quite small in comparison. It does not take a lot of time to look through but was well worth the visit.

Less famous than Notre Dame but more emotionally charged. Maybe it is because it is on two floors or because it has delicate and skilfully decorated arches all the way, maybe it is the dar reds and dark blues which lack in other churches but la Sainte Chapelle is always a place that fills me with joy. There is a line and they do close for lunch. Alsomas it is in the Justice Department courtyard there is a security check to get in so make sure you have no pocket knives. Not to be missed!
Very pretty. A very pretty small chapel with gorgeous stained glass windows. It cost 8.00 or 8.50 euros to get in....we were so happy to have the Paris Museum Pass.
Beautiful stained glass windows. The line-up for this site is always long. Try to go on a weekday. You have to walk up a lot of stairs. It may be difficult for people to access with limited mobility.

Have you been inside a glass paperweight?. Saint Chapelle is one of my top 3 "must sees" in Paris along with Place de Voges and Blvd Saint Germaine. The first time you will be amazed by the light and color of the surrounding stained glass. Every time after, it will be different. After that astonishes you enough, begin to study the stories told by the glass.

Stunning!. Ste. Chapelle is simply stunning - the stained glass windows are awe inspiring. On this last visit, we were privileged to be able to attend a performance of Vivaldi's "The Four Seasons" in Ste. Chapelle - great evening!

Did not live up to my expectations. You had better love stained glass to make it worth your while. 1 hour wait to buy tickets, then 45 minute wait to get through security to get inside and one full side of the chapel is covered (for renovation?). Stained glass is impressive, but just not worth the wait or cost of admission. I wandered into at least 3 churches in Rome that were far more impressive.

Beautifull as always. I love this place! Its beautifull, you dont have to stay very long to just admire the beautifull windows, or you can go to a concert there its very close to many other sights in Paris and not to be missed.
Stained glass like no other!. This has some of the best stained glass you will ever see in a church. If you have the museum pass don't let the line scare you as that is just for security.
amazing stained glass. beautiful church, lines weren't too long, and fast moving. purchase the double ticket €12 to see the conciergerie as well. its next door and otherwise you pay €8.50 as well

Worth seeing. This beautiful chapel is smaller than I expected but exquisite. Even though it's undergoing renovations so you don't get to see it all, there is more than enough to give you the idea. The colours are brilliant. In July, the queue took about 40 minutes to go through security. You then need to queue again to buy your ticket (about 10 minutes).

Breathtaking Beauty. This church is something that simply takes your breath away. The stain glass windows are breathtaking and can't imagine one would take a trip to Paris without seeing them.We visting during peak tourist season and right in the middle of the day and the wait was minimal. The line outside was about 30 minutes to get through security and we were able skip the 10 minute ticket window line with our Paris Museum Pass. It's a quick flight of stair up into this heavenly room. There was restoration being performed on one of of the three sides, however, we all still smitten by what we saw. A must!

Glorious stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle is an incredible church, with the most gorgeous, soaring stain glass windows delicately supported in stone. It is surrounded by the Palais de Justice, so visitors to the church must go through security. It's worth it for the view inside.
Brilliant. Stunning stained glass - be prepared for queues but it is worth the wait - you can use a Museum Pass to get in - go on a sunny day to see the glass at its most effective.

Just go for the stained glass windows if there is not a concert!. Words are not sufficient to describe Sainte-Chapelle! We went in the daytime to see the sun blazing through and then purchased tickets for one of the many evening concerts. This is an incredible place to visit and listen to great music!

Not to Be Missed. We had a combo ticket for Saint Chapelle and the Conciergerie (virtually side by side) - and loved both. They do not rate high mentions in the tour guides, however they are both well worth a visit, for different reasons. Our visit was in early December, so relatively low season, but still incredibly busy. There was to be a function in the afternoon, so there was a note advising that the venue would close within two hours; slowly the queue inched closer and closer, and we were sure that we would just get to the doors and they would be locked. We watched the time tick away, and we queued for almost two hours - but made it in!This is such an impressive building with ornate walls and ceilings in the chapels, gilt everywhere, and so much history. The stained glass windows are amazing. Do get an audio guide - you may feel, like us, that you have heard so many of these over Europe that you are well and truly over them - but you will miss such important information if you don't.We did have some trouble in the gift shop, trying to by certain postcards, as the women behind the counter either did not speak any English, or chose not to on that particular day, despite my feeble attempts at French and many hand gestures. In the end I just gave up and purchased something else.
It's GREAT!. On a very small scale, it is a wonderful church with simply amazing windows. If you are visiting NotreDame, I highly recommend seeing Sainte-Chapelle, no lines!

Fantastic stained glass!. The 1st floor is incredible, how the windows are supported is a miracle in itself, the colours of the glass, particularly in the sunlight are just incredible.Well worth a visit but try to get there early to avoid long queues

easy, cheap, very beautiful. It was very fun to try and read the bible through the stained glass windows. The attention to detail was gorgeous. Two of the walls were being renovated, so we didn't get the full experience, but it's easy, cheap, and beautiful.

Don't miss it.. Astounding. Skipped this on my last trip, but am SO glad it took the time to seek it out this time. The audio guide provides good background and interpretation of the narrative imagery in the windows. Unlike anything you see elsewhere. the intimate feel of the chapel renders a truly spiritual experience when filled with light from these magnificant windows.
Magic evening!. Vivaldi concert in Sainte -Chapelle was just magic, with light coming thru stained glass windows and acoustics brilliant. Don't queue get tickets to an evening concert.

Best site in Paris. It is a small church that is breifly mentioned in all tour books but it was by far the most breathtaking experience I had in Paris. The stained glass is vibrant. Try to go on a very sunny but also cloudy day to see the best views of all sides. When the sun isn't shining through it, its a dark grey and you can barely make out the images or colors.
Extraordinary. A must see - small but very beautiful. Beware of the summer crowds. This was one of the busiest places we visited.

Surreal Saint-Chapelle. Like standing inside of a beautiful, sparkling gem! For only 8 Euros, you can take a quick staircase to stand inside the chapel with eye-catching stained-glass windows that mesmerize your senses!

Most amazing stained glass in such a small space. This used to be the Kings chapel. The glass is just incredible. You can sit and stare for hours (or minutes if traveling with kids). Much has been recently rehabbed. Totally worth a visit.

Wow!. A beautiful church, if you get a chance go to one of the evening Vivaldi performances. The sun setting lights up the church wonderfully and listening to the music is like a dream. One of the best things we did in Paris.

Stained Glass Windows Galore!. What an incredible historic chapel to visit. This church sure is a beauty. Make sure to go on a day with lots of sun to really get a chance to see the lovely color in the windows. There was a bit of restoration work taking place when I visited, but that hardly got in the way. If you go to Paris, you must see La Sainte-Chapelle!

Most beautiful chapel I have ever visited. Stain glass beats that of any surrounding building.. blew Notre Dam out of the water in my opinion! Under construction at my time of visit which was a bummer and long line made for not the best conditions but 100% worth it! Loved every second.
Unbelievable windows. It is incredible to me that this building was completed in six years. The windows are a marvel. The audio guide was very helpful.

Beautiful!! Amazing!. This is a very unique piece of architecture. The leaded glass windows are amazing. A sting ensemble performs Vivaldi's "The Four Seasons" at night. If you like classical music you should avoid the long tourist lines to get in the cathedral during the day. Go across the street to the cafe and buy ticket so the 7PM performance in the cathedral. You will be able to experience wonderful music in the historic location.
Astonishing!!!!. The interior of this small church is amazing!!!! the window art is the most beautifull and hopefully you'll se it in a sunny day!!!!

In a word - Meh.. Does not hold up to its same-island counterpart. You stand in line for security and another line for the church itself. Once inside you think, oh, that's all? If you weren't certain all you have to do is visit the loo and discover that there's no real sign for men's and ladies', no toilet paper, no soap, and no paper towels/ hand dryer. Where is the 8.5 euro going exactly?
Stunning stained glass. Long line to get in, but well worth it. Halfway restored, the stained glass is amazing! So glad we waited in line to get in.

Don't miss this. I can't believe we almost missed this. These have to be the most stunning stain glass windows I have ever seen.My only regret is that I did not see this with a tour guide that could have enlightened me as to the stories of each of the windows.

Remarkable. This was the first stop on our trip this year. I never get over walking into Sainte-Chapelle and seeing the light through the stained glass windows. It is breathtaking. We had the Paris Museum pass and were able to get in quickly.
Most amazing a must to visit. Amazing and so beautiful. My husband said it was stunning and like being inside a jewel. He is a man of few words!!!!!

Glorious, transporting stained glass. The space was absolutely breathtaking, the sort of place where you could have a spirtual experience with just a bit of effort (and quiet, which is hard to come by ... although they keep the crowds much better controlled than many other churches)

Better than Notre Dame?. We took our children to Sainte-Chappelle after our visit to Notre Dame; To us the second floor was more magnificent than anything at the Cathedral. The line up was also not as long.

Stunning.. I had seen a lot of cathedrals in the last few days so I was expecting to be a bit underwhelmed when we decided to head to Sainte-Chapelle on our last day in Paris. I was stunned when we walked into the main hall. Do not leave Paris without seeing this.

Gorgeous - a must see!. We loved this hidden place - I had heard about it from many people and was so excited to see the stained glass. When we walked in, I was shocked to see a very boring scene and then realized - you have to go upstairs. The chapel and windows were going through a renovation so only 3/4 of the walls were visible and it was still absolutely gorgeous. There is a laminated info sheet at the back of the chapel that explains the windows and what they display, which brought it to life even more strongly. We spent about 30 minutes taking it in - really beautiful. It is worth getting the museum pass to save time as you go about Paris - we didn't and we waited for about 30 minutes which wasn't that bad...but get the pass if you are going to several places and save yourself loads of time.

Whoa. One of my "mon dieu" moments in Paris was walking up to the upper church from the crypt church (entry level) and seeing the stained glass windows in this church. We went *because* we had heard they were beautiful, but that is not adequate preparation for the experience. This deserves to be an even more famous landmark!
Tiny and dellicate. In the other side of the square of Notre Dame. A tiny chapel, constructed by Saint Louis. Coloured windows, with a mistic, medieval, atmosphere.

Beautiful concert. We had a wonderful experience at Sainte Chapelle: a violinconcert. It was magic, although the chapel is being renovated. One side of the walls with stained glass is covered. Nevertheless there was a magical atmosphere.

Worth the wait. To gain access to the Sainte Chapelle you have to queue outside an unprepossessing looking doorway outside what looks like a law court in the Cite. Once inside you will be treated with the amazing Sainte-Chapelle and its 13th century stained glass. Later you can pick out the chapel itself back on the street from its classic gothic style - it is the sole survivor of the Capetian Palace of Louis XII which once stood on the same site.
wow. ofetn overlooked for the Notre dame cathedral and yet is far superior. upstairs the stained glass works are mindblowing.

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Go early and beat the crowd. Right down the block from Notre Dame Cathedral. Be sure to go up to the second level. You will always remember these windows. Be sure it is a bright day.

Average Concert in a Stunning Setting. We visited Sainte-Chapelle only for one their evening concerts. Our hotel concierge booked the tickets for us. You have to be careful when you go for a concert, because the entrance is not the one used for the daytime tours. You actually enter from the ministry of justice down the street. There are signs, but it is confusing.The concert we attended was a selection of church music performed by a string quartet and a mezzo Soprano. The music was well performed, but it was all serious music with vocalist and accompaniment. It would have been more effective if there had been some instrumental music and perhaps something secular music from the period that provided a change in color.The chapel itself is shimmering walls of stained glass. It is a testament to the piety and devotion of those who built it.

Wow. I've been to the Sainte-Chapelle twice now. It should not be missed -- coming up those stairs to the upper chapel to discover those amazing windows just takes my breath away. When next I'm in Paris, I'll go back again.

St. Chapelle-GORGEOUS. Get the Paris Museum Pass. Recently visited St. Chapelle and I was in AWE!!! The stained glass was beautiful!!! Get the Paris Museum Pass to skip the line. The line was so long but with this pass, we were able to get in MUCH quicker. This is wonderful and near Notre Dame. Also nearby is Place Dauphine Park. Go visit it. It is quaint and cozy.

amazing. if coming in high season (and on a weekend), make sure you get your tickets upfront. don't spend more time in the queue then in the church. also try to make sure it is a sunny day as that's the time when this little church becomes magical

Must see stained glass at Sainte Chapelle. Go see some of the prettiest stained glass and see the difference between stained glass that has been restored (clear and full of color) and the non-restored stained glass.

An Intimate Chapel Experience Not to be Missed. Go on a sunny day and not too early or late to see the windows in their glory. The upper chapel is bathed in light, through the stained glass of various biblical scenes. Much more intimate than the experience at Notre Dame. Don't forget to get your Museum Pass, skip the lines and save some money.

A national gem. Saint-Chapelle is one of the most beautiful places to visit in Paris.The stained glass windows are beautiful and the history of Paris surrounds you.Do go after a service in Notre Dame or to an evening concert.

Stained glass everywhere. It's beautiful but not worth the time. If you hare tired and need a place to sit and cool down from the heat of summer, that is a perfect place. Otherwise, you can find another place to visit.

Romantic Stained Glass. Try to include this in your Paris itinerary. Even though it may be a little crowded (like any other place), it's worth it. There isn't much of a line when we went in summer, and if there is, it moves pretty fast. Highlight of the church is the beautiful and intricately made stained glass art that adorns it.

Nice surprise. We didn't check the reviews before we went there and were not sure what to expect but it really is as one reviewer said, "a hidden gem." The stained glass is awesome, when we first went in there I was like, oh yeah, this is alright but after going up to the top floor, that is where the real awesomeness begins. The windows are huge and intricate, there are place cards in a variety of languages that explain the windows and are very informative. I would definately recommand checking this place out, you can be in and out of this place alone inside half an hour not including the line up to get through the metal detectors or buy tickets.

Such a lovely chappel !. A chappel with two floors ! Both are quite small but phantastic. Did you know the upper floor was almost copied at the gothic part of the Dom church in Aachen ?Not known by many tourists, this Chappel is a must go. It is not as impressive as the hughe Notre Dame, but far more beautiful.

Stunning. This should definitely be on your list of must-sees! I would recommend buying a combination ticket to the Concierergie and Ste. Chapelle - the line for the Concierergie was minimal and it was a very interesting place to visit - for a combination ticket the price was 12 Euros. The best part was that when we went to get into Ste. Chapelle, because we already had a ticket, we were able to bypass the line, which would have resulted in at least a 2 hour wait. The church is a work of art and highly recommended.
Brilliant Stained Glass. The stain glass on display is better than in Notre Dame cathedral - can you believe that?

Gorgeous -- and incredibly friendly staff.. I've seen a LOT of old churches througuout Europe, and Saint-Chapelle might be my favorite. I was told the stained glass was amazing, but nothing prepared me for just how beautiful it is. I have to thank the staff for recognizing a hugely pregnant and uncomfortable woman waiting in the queue ... I went to sit on a park bench while my husband waited in line because I am unable to stand for long periods of time these days. I was just reading quietly on the bench, when a staff member noticed me there and guided both me and my husband to the disabled access entrance -- I can't thank him enough for that. Kind, friendly staff, and an amazing building too. I love it.
Stained glass. The amount of stained glass is amazing. We visited on an overcast day which may have affected the impression. Portion of the interior was under renovation in June 2012.

Must Be Seen. The only way to do justice to Sainte-Chapelle is to experience it. The stained glass, light, uniqueness of this sacred space defies common vocabulary to do it justice in describing. Must be seen to fully appreciate what a special and unique place it is.

Small delight, gem of a chapel. After briefly surveying the dark, medieval downstairs chapel, climb the small, winding staircase and burst into the medieval splendor of Sainte-Chappelle's upper chapel. Beautiful, colorful and inspirational, it truly must be seen to be appreciated.
A hidden gem!. Beautiful chapel. Stained glass is everywhere. I've never seen anything like it. Absolutely stunning!

Loved the Stained Glass!. Saint-Chapelle is an incredible building. Its interior is vibrant and its history is fascinating. Dating back to the mid-13th century, this church is the only surviving building of the royal palace on Île de la Cité. It was commissioned by Louis IX to hold his vast collection of relics, which included the Crown of Thorns. The church is also known for its spectacular 13th century stained glass windows.
Impressive. This is worth seeing if you are in the neighborhood.
Spectacular but under much needed cleaning and repair. Queues move quite quickly so dont be put off. Once inside the stain glass is stunning especially on a sunny day but well worth it even if dull.

Will visit again. This is one spot that on my next trip to Paris, I will visit again. I did not expect this. The Chapelle features 13th century stained glass - just understanding what this building has survived and the history is incredible. Be respectful when visiting the upper chapel - Quiet is expected and they will correct you if you are not. Picture taking is allowed - we have a large picture in our home that I took here and it reminds me constantly of our experience in this beautiful place.
Spectacular stained glass windows !. Buy a Paris museum pass at the tourist desk at the airport so you can avoid the long lines at beautiful sights such as this! The stained glass is stunning here.

Breathtaking. The upper sanctuary of Sainte-Chapelle literally took my breath away when I stepped into it. The complete immersion in the brilliant colors of the stained glass is awe-inspiring. It is the most beautiful human-made experience I've ever seen. Absolutely incredible.
a must see. Hidden behind an administrative building is the most beautiful 13th century stain glass, I would say one of the best in France.

Spectacular Stained Glass. I was a little frustrated with the long wait - even with the Paris Pass you had to wait in the security line, which took about 30 minutes. However, it was totally worth it to see the beautiful stained glass! Try and get there early!

Quiet little jewel box--must see if you like churches. Beautiful if you know nothing about it and quite interesting connection to the original Paris if you read a bit about the history. Excellent restoration in progress but you can see plenty to merit a visit. If in town for a few days and visiting a number of museums get the Museum pass that gives you no-line entrance --the lines are brutal here. Enter by the Palais de Justice entrance if there is no special Musee Pass line.
Beautiful!. What a beautiful little chapel all tucked away. Such beautifully stained glass windows!

Lovely stained glass windows. A visit to Sainte-Chapelle is worth it just to see the beautiful stained glass windows. They are amazing. A museum pass helps avoid line-ups. There is a security check, so leave anything like a pocket knife behind when you visit here.

Good to see. Although we spent more time in the queue rather than inside the building, it's still worth it to go and have a look, at least once. The museum pass does not allow you to skip the queues as you still have to go through security. As said before, the enormous stained glass windows are awesome, but I found them difficult to interpret so I just enjoyed looking at them and contemplated the work and effort put into them. Some windows were covered due to cleaning/restoration, which did diminish the experience a bit. I admit to being underawed on entering the building, as all I could see were a few statues and a souvenir stand. But once upstairs I was pleasantly greeted by the windows. It may be worth waiting for a sunny day to view this church as it is quite gloomy, especially downstairs, and the windows might be more 'alive' with the sun shining through.

Saw it from outside only. The queue to get into this attraction was very long.We went to the Conciergerie next door, however after doing that tour and seeing the references and photos to Sainte Chappelle I regret not visiting it. Looked absolutely stunning from the references I saw. Note there were 2 queues - one to buy tickets then the queue to get into St Chappelle

Stunning Beauty. This really is the most beautiful chapel in the Western world in my humble opinion. The stained glass windows are breathtaking in their colors and I enjoyed the architecture as well. We had to stand in line to get in but the line was not overwhelmingly long--quite bearable even for this middle-aged lady! Worth taking a visit to and I would do it again.

Captivating. Can be difficult to find since it is completely surrounded by a french office building, and it is often overlooked because Notre Dame is just steps away, but do not miss out on Sainte Chapelle. I have gone nearly every visit to Paris and I am still captivated by the beautiful stained glass, the ceiling, the sculptures, even the floor is beautiful. The chapel is quite small and you need not spend more than an hour, but it will be a wonderful hour.
Spectacular stained-glass windows. Absolutely amazing! I'm not a big fan of churches, but i sat in the top chamber for around 30 minutes and didn't want to leave!

See chapel during evening concert - but sit up front!. Be aware that one side of the chapel is covered right now for window cleaning. The stained glass is amazing, but the scenes are so small that we wished we had a handout or tour guide to tell us what stories are depicted. Friends told us a chamber concert in the chapel was the highlight of their trip to Paris, so we went and were glad we did. Buy tickets online (viennaticketoffice.com) for a small discount, but bring booking confirmation (they don't tell you this, but it serves as your ticket) and ID. Be sure to follow instructions and arrive 45 minutes early to get through security (you enter through Palace of Justice) and wait in the line to be seated. Latecomers are not allowed entrance...we found out the hard way on our first try and had to buy tickets again for the following evening. We sat in the first row of cheap seats and couldn't see musicians. But Vivaldi's Four Seasons with clavichord sounded beautiful. Fidgety kids in the back kept us from fully immersing, so I'd go for the VIP tickets next time. Saw everything from jeans to cocktail attire.

Amazing!. I did´t have much of expectations of this old church but i was simply amazed by it. Beauty of stained glass, ceilings and details is hard to express with words.Pay attention to statues of animals that serve as gutters!

Don't miss this High Gothic gem!. We rented an apartment in the Quartier Latin, knowing that we would be in the middle of other tourists like ourselves, but hoping that the tourists would be made up for by the ease of access to the underground and by the information we could get right in our neighborhood. The BEST bit of information we found during our honeymoon week was a flyer announcing a free performance of Vivaldi's Guitar Concertos in a church called Saint Chapelle. We had no idea that we were in for such a treat. The acoustics were amazing, but the light was spectacular. As the tones of the small ensemble and the glorious classical guitar wafted toward the heavens, the sunset turned the stained glass windows into a kaleidoscope of light and color. Be aware that you will have to go through a fair amount of security to get in (bring your passport), because it is the middle of a government complex, but well worth any hassle to see this perfect example of High Gothic architecture.
A small treasure!. Another excellent thing to do in Paris!The atmosphere is magic and you feel in another century.

Most beautiful church in the world. In my humble opinion. But not mine alone, as the gasps of everyone who entered the church behind me were quite audible. This is a church you experience rather than describe. Walls made not of stone but of speechlessly beautiful stained glass, gilded surfaces, starry canopy above. A medieval jewel.

Magnificent. Not as well known as many other attractions, but the one thing I wanted to see in my short time in Paris. I was not disappointed! What a beautiful, breathtaking chapel. Note the gargoyles on the exterior and do not be fooled that the ground floor is the main attraction. The entrance to the spectacular chapel above is via an ancient winding stone staircase. (Note: For special events there is access/egress to the main chapel level from a building next door.) The ancient stained glass surrounding all sides and soaring into the heavens is inspirational. My architecture history professor once declared it the most beutiful chapel in the world and I believe he was right. I wnet during the day when the exterior can be seen and the sunlight ours into the wonderful strained glass windows, but I was fortunate to learn there was a live chamber music performance in the chapel that very evening. I spent my last night in Paris listening to Vivialdi's "Four Season's" at Sainte0Chapelle. (Check out "Music at Sainte-Chappelle.) The fabulous setting, great acoustics and lovely music brought tears to my eyes and to most of the audience. It was the highlight of my visit and a magical way to end my few days in Paris.

Incredible windows and architecture. Sainte-Chapelle was high on my husband's list of places to see in Paris. We waited more than an hour, and I doubted the wait was worth it. When we walked into the building, I realized how right he was. The cathedral is simply breath-taking. Study the windows, but take time, as well, to look at the intricate floors. Our kids (17, 14, and 7) enjoyed it as well. This is the most beautiful cathedral I've ever visited (though I have a few still to see!)Karen Dawkinshttp://familytravelsonabudget.blogspot.com

Beautiful Artistry For A Price. The Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most beautiful chapels I have ever seen, as it should be since it once housed the crown of thorns. That being said, there was not a ton to see and there was currently restoration work being done which limited the views. Overall, I would recommend coming to check this masterpiece out.
Gorgeous!!. Always beautiful! Another top attraction for me in Paris.

Not the best Cathedral, but the most expensive. Worthwhile with the Museum pass as it is included but otherwise skip it especially if crowded. We waited ~45 minutes to get in to face about 250 people including screaming kids trying to cram in the rather small church. The whole walk through took less than 20 minutes. Notre Dame, although also crowded, is a better choice.
a jewel. hopefully you will avoid a high tourist time, this is so worth a quiet moment.

FLOATING CEILING !!!!BREATHTAKING!!!!. Has to be THE MOST BEAUTIFUL CHAPEL in Paris. So GOTH , ALMOST STEELY AND COLD on the outside ,one is very pleasantly surprised to find warm and rich jewel tones inside in a myriad of reds, blues and golds!!!!You enter, after along wait in the queue, through the municipal offices, requiring security screening.. First visit a small chapel under Sainte- Chapelle,full of warm jewel tones ( check out the frescoes/ murals/paintings done with gold and studded with semi/ precious stones) and then walk upstairs to the main chapel. It is truly stunning..., the very very high ceiling seems to be held up by stained glass windows, floating on them actually..very ethereal!!!!.. the supporting stone columns being so very thin and barely noticeable amid the glowing magnificence of the windows.They seem alive... those windows they do!!! I found it hard to draw breath what with my mouth hanging open most of the time!!! Take your time looking at all the details ...this is one place you DO NOT WHIZZ THROUGH. The stained glass windows each depict a chapter of the bible..Genesis to Revelations. and the altar is great as well....WOW...WOW...WOW... all the way!!!!.iF THE QUEUE IS TOO LONG YOU CAN KEEP AN EYE OUT FOR IT FROM ANY OF THE LITTLE CAFES ALONG THE STREET WHILE HAVING A BITE!!!!
Beautiful!. I really liked The stained glass and painted walls

Amazing windows, you feel the age. This is a Unesco site and you have to be prepared to go through a rigorous security check. Well worth the visit. The stained glass windows are overwhelming. Even if you are not religious you can feel a special atmosphere in this building that makes you understand why some people believe there must be more to our world than what is tangible to us. The age of the structure, floor mosaics, windows, carvings, etc. is amazing.

Don't forget this one!. When in Paris, even you already saw another churches, don't forget this one.It is smaller than ND, but very beautifull with her vitrals.And there you could watch concerts almost every day.
Only on a sunny day. It is beautiful and worth the line and the crowds when the sun is out.

this is the one thing to see if you can only see one thing. It is amazing. Could make one cry, how beautiful it is. If you are wise, go on a sunny day and get there early. To be in this very special place without crowds is very spiritual.
Magical. Small, intimate...highly recommend seeing a concert in this beautiful chapel. ALthough undergoing some renovation it felt as though we were invited into a special screening! Bon voyage!

No other place on Earth like this. If you have the time, go ahead and stand in line for this one. The atmosphere in the 13th Century stained glass sanctuary of Sainte-Chapelle will be something you will never forget. So many sights to see in Paris but this one is really unique.

Sainte-Chapelle is also a Music Box. First I have to agree with the reviewer who called Sainte-Chapelle a jewel box. Unlike Notre Dame and Chartres, the windows dominate the walls giving you the effect that the whole thing is one big stained glass window. This alone makes it worth the trip even if you've already visited dozens of cathedrals in France and Europe. But Sainte-Chapelle has the added bonus of floors that have been designed to also look like windows. This is no help to your neck because you will find yourself straining it looking up and down, and in your amazed state you will probably run into that many more people (although at least you won't step on their feet).There are two ways to visit Sainte-Chapelle. You can line up on the street and pay 8.50 Euros for adults. Or you can buy tickets to see a classical music concert in the church and visit in the evening. These tickets range from 16 Euros on up and are free for children under 10 years old.We chose the 25 Euro tickets. We bought them two days in advance (recommended because the concert was definitely sold out on a Thursday night). We purchased our tickets at the Tabac/tourist shop across the street from the Church entrance (location clearly marked on signs at entrance). The woman at the Tabac was incredibly helpful, but she only accepts cash. We arrived at the Church about 30 minutes early and entered further down the street (at #4 on the other side of the ornate gates for the Palais du Justice). At this point it's like entering an airport (except you don't have to take your shoes off) since you are entering the court building. Everyone was nice and helpful though, and you end up circling back through the court building to the back of the cathedral.Now, about the concert. Was it worth the 25 Euros? I'm on the fence on this one. Of course you can't find a more beautiful place to listen to classical music, and you will leave having noticed a lot of the fine details of the Sainte-Chapelle that you wouldn't otherwise have seen. But we were in the cheaper seats towards the back, and the weather didn't cooperate. It rained hard while we were in there and that combined with the noise on the street made it hard to hear the music well. The concert also only lasted one hour which was good news for my son, but classical music buffs might feel a little ripped off. Of course, 25 Euros is pretty cheap for classical music, so maybe it all equals out. Sainte-Chapelle is still being renovated. If you look at my 15 second Tout video clips (addresses below), you will see that part of the church is hidden by a big box. And yes that detracts somewhat from the experience, so it might be a good idea to plan another trip to Paris when the work is done. I'm just glad to see that the French are working hard to preserve their national treasures.Tout clips:http://www.tout.com/m/osn7ylhttp://www.tout.com/m/ju4mlvhttp://www.tout.com/m/hjvwe1http://www.tout.com/m/uq0zlihttp://www.tout.com/m/jw8zt7

Pretty but small. Spent more time in the queue than we did in the chapel. It was pretty but I was probably expecting more after reading rave reviews. It was brightly coloured & very different to many churches in that respect. The ceiling was beautiful too.Make sure you head virtally next door & do the la Conciergerie. No queue & it was very interesting.

Medieval Splendor. Rather than visit this superb chapel on a tour, why not book a musical performance in it? This will give you 1.5 to 2 hours to absorb the brilliance of its architecture, decoration and stained glass under different lighting conditions in Summer.We have heard Mozart's Requiem and a number of excellent recitals in this unique venue. Our latest was mezzo soprano Ghislane Roux recital with a superb string quartet in June of this year.Enjoy! Admire! Be blown away!
Beautiful restoration. The restoration of Sainte Chapelle is almost complete and is beautiful.

Gorgeous stained glass. Sainte-Chapelle was under construction in May 2012 when I visited, but it didn't take away very much from the overall experience.It's a relatively small chapel, built to house one of the instruments of the passion (the crown of thorns) in a small altar. The upper level, with the altar, is covered with amazing 15-or so foot tall stained glass windows on all four sides. The room is absolutely breath taking. The place is small, so it can get congested, but it's certainly worth visiting.

Jewel Box. I don't understand why this is often missed on Paris sightseeing excursions, it is truly one of Paris' treasures, a veritable jewel box sitting right in the middle of the city, easily combined with a trip to Notre Dame. If you buy the Paris museum pass, you can skip the long line and head straight for the entrance. Return in the evening for a concert and continue to enjoy the windows as the sky stays light well past 9 pm in Paris in the summer.

Incredible stained glass windows. Fantastic chapel with 360 degree large stained glass windows from floor to ceiling. Must be seen to fully appreciate it. Undergoing some renovations but is still quite enjoyable.
Awesome stained glass. It feels like you're in another world. Read the history about it before going for a more enhanced experience.

Concert at Sainte Chapelle. We went to a Vivaldi concert here, and it was one of my favorite things that we did in Paris. Great acoustics, beautiful stained glass and amazing performers. Go to a concert here if you want a truly special and unique experience!
Beautiful. Small chapel with stunning stained glass. Go for a concert! Lines are long if you don't get there early.

Waited waited waited - Couldn't get in. We were in Paris in early June for 8 nights and tried three different times to get in but couldn't. Fault us for not showing up way early or for lining up later in the afternoon. However, we did s how up one day around nine. The only time the line moved was when those ahead of us got frustrated and gave up. After an hour of no movement, someone smarter than us asked a ticket-taker what was wrong. They had experienced a security system malfunction (equipment) and wouldn't be open to visitors for two more hours. Wouldn't you think they'd say something to those lined up? We never got in but we tried. I've seen it before. It's worth seeing but we couldn't spend so much time waiting when there's so much else to see

Small but stunning. You have to wait in line for security, regardless of whether you have the Musee pass, but it is well worth it. The stained glass at St. Chappelle is beautiful and amazing to see. You could see it in a half hour, or stay much longer depending on how much you want to learn about the stained glass.

Be Amaized. When you enter this chapel you are filed past a "gift shop" stile counter and find yourself bumbling around with others who are taking pictures of a seemingly ordinary space - nice, but nothing special. It isn't until you discover the small winding stairway in the corner of this large space that you discover the magic. You ascend to a second floor that is flooded with marvelous light given by huge (and I do mean huge) stained glass windows - spectacular! When we visited, the restoration was about 75% complete and after watching the short video detailing the process it is astounding in it's scope. A bit crowded, but not stifling - worth the trip.

Classical concert at Saint Chapelle. Decided to attend a chamber music concert at Saint Chapelle, partly to see this church and partly to experience chamber music in France. Saint Chapelle is under restoration till at least 2014 and I was disappointed that it was not kept up to its full potential. This church is one of the fanciest with extra tall rosemary windows. Now is not the time to see but after 2014, I am sure it will be amazing back to its former glory.

Stained glass doesn't get any better than this. I told my daughter that we had to visit Sainte-Chapelle so she could see the stained glass. I was kind of afraid I built it up too much. Not a chance! She saw the windows and her jaw dropped. One of the most beautiful small churches that just glows in the colors of its glass. Most of the glass has been restored recently though part of it is still shrouded in scaffolding. Still plenty of amazing glass to impress.

Take my breath away!. You don't want to miss this jewel box. As I reached the top of the narrow spiral staircase and looked up - I literally gasped! It is the most beautiful sight of stained glass. Take the time to just stand in the middle and take it all in - chairs to sit as well. Go early in the morning to get the best light coming through the glass. Don't miss it - read the brochure to check out the stories and original panes of glass.

amazing stained glass. A beautiful chapel, small but very interesting. The Conciergerie, also very interesting, is right next door. Here's a tip: Buy your ticket for both museums at the Conciergerie, instead of a the chapel, and save your self 30 minutes in line!

Major renovation ends 2014. The Sainte-Chapelle is spectacular. The light from all the stained glass takes your breath away. Try to go on a sunny day. Beware that there is major renovation at present. It does take a bit away from the experience. I wish I had organized to buy tx for a musical performance - maybe you can!
Spectacular!. Beautiful! The stained glass has been resorted and is a must see!

Go to the concert.. Evening concerts are held in this beautiful royal chapel. Vivaldi's four seasons and the like. The performances are stellar, and as you listen to the music the sun sets filling the beautiful stained-glass windows with golden light.
Concert. Try and get reservations for an evening concert. We heard a quintet perform Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It was wonderful.

Beautiful. Although there was construction going on, the stain glass is magnificent. Get there early. It is small and slow to enter. First thing in the morning is best. The Museum Pass has the wrong times listed. Be sure to find out the times otherwise.
the reign of st louis,. grandiose, perfect condition all around, great mediaval chapel

Oh so beautiful, but go upstairs or you won't see it!. A line to get through security then you can get into the Chapel with your museum pass. The gift shop is right inside which is confusing. Go the the stairs on the right and you will arrive at the site of gorgeous stained glass art. A must see.

Ethereal. This most spectacular of all chapels stands out in a country filled with awesome chapels and stained glass. It's stained glass is legendary and unsurpassed. Choose a sunny day and plan to spend hours there "reading" the history through the spellbindingly exquisite stained glass windows that surround the relatively small chapel. The glass was saved from the Nazis when it was secretly dismantled and spirited away in Samaritaine department store delivery trucks and kept in secret safety until the end of the war.For another unforgettable experience, attend an evening concert in the chapel. The acoustics are astonishing, and the experience will give you goose pimples--it is truly ethereal--even for the non-religious!
over my exceptations. The most beautiful and incredible piece of Gothic art I have ever seen. Amazing stained glasses, colorful vaulting. Long line to get in is worth to stay.
Not much to see. Nice stained glass but not much else. Small and crowded, a bit disappointing.

Excellent deconsecrated church, don't visit in July-August. This is a very nice church to visit for the lead light windows but the queues in July and August can be overwhelming. Some parts are being renovated at present and some of the work has not been looked after all that well. The "guards" don't seem to do much guarding.
WOW!. The beauty in the stained glass is unlike anything we've ever seen. The architecture was fantastic and it was so interesting to see the different floors for the different "classes"....

Beautiful stain-gladd windows. This is the place to see real stain-glass windows. None like them anywhere else in Paris, perhaps in Chartres, but not Paris. Love this place. Pull up a chair, sit, study... great way to spend the morning. Near Notre Dame Cathedral, but for a quiet, "take your time" visit.

Stunning on a sunny day. One of my favourite places in Paris, but now still under extensive renovations I believe. The walls of stained glass are stunning and on a sunny day, staying in the middle of the chapel with the towering walls of stained glass is simply awesome. Almost hard to catch the size and beauty on a single frame of a photo.
Great concert. This is a great thing to do if you appreciate music, however right now there's some kind of construction going on. The concert was still great, but this did take away from it a little.

Sainte-Chapelle, Paris. Astoundingly beautiful stained glass windows in a rather stark setting, not to be missed...Our bags had to be checked before entering by gendarmes due to high security alerts at the time...

Fabulous. This is a museum dedicated to Impressionist art. If you like anything from Claude Monet to Paul Guillaume, this is a "must see". It is right next door to the Louvre, which is strenuous to visit by comparison.

Go for the evening concerts. We were so fortunate to visit Sainte-Chapelle in the evening and attend an absolutely perfect violin concert playing Vivaldi.The concerts do change and you can find the information on what is playing posted in all the METRO stations. It was a highlight of our trip- To watch the sun setting through those beautiful stain glass windows while listening to Vivaldi was a lovely experience.

Crowded.... But for good reason, this little Chapel is spectacular. Prepare to be blown away upon first glance of this spectacle of stained glass. Even better on a sunny day when the rays of light shine through majestically. So, budget some time, wait in line and don't miss when in Paris. I have experienced the Sainte-Chapelle five different times and loved every second each vistit! That is besides what can be ludicrous lines.

Worth the visit for the Stained Glass. The main chapel is overwhelmingly beautiful. I'd recommend visiting the Palace of Justice while you are there because it is adjacent. If you are visiting Notre Dame, you should also stop here!

Beautiful Beyond Words. This is one of my favorite sites in all of France! Because the chapel is in a complex of government buildings, the opening hours are variable, and many visitors miss it. Make the effort! Sainte-Chapelle is unique and unforgettable, and put this on the "A List" of things to see on a first visit to Paris.

worth a look. Within 10mins of Notre DameQueues build up after 10am largely because you have to go thro' security as it is in the same courtyard as the french law courts. A much smaller queue for the law courts is adjacent giving access to the same courtyard. You then have to pay an admission charge to go in to St. Chapelle. Stained glass is amazing but almost all of one wall is not visible as it is undergoing renovation, Glass windows are high up- binoculars are useful.

Not nearly as spectacular as I expected.. A teacher told me that Sainte-Chapelle was a must see in Paris, and I decided it was worth a visit. I was very underwhelmed. There is an entrance fee which surprised me. I think that if something as amazing and grand as Notre Dame does not charge an entrance fee, something as small as Sainte-Chapelle certainly shouldn't. Sainte-Chapelle is very close to Notre Dame, so it's easy to visit both destinations on the same day. I found Sainte-Chapelle to be shockingly small. The stain glass is undeniably beautiful, but the room that the most impressive glass is in, is very small, and half the room was under construction. I expected much more.
