Unexpectedly Beautiful. I went to Sainte-Chapelle with others in my group who knew about it & had wanted to go. I didn't know anything about it before going. It was really lovely, with beautiful stained glass windows, decorative floors, & an interesting history.There was some restoration work going on that limited viewing the whole chapelle in tact &, as I understood it, limited the overall 'jewel box' feel that the windows create when they are all in tact.
Amazing stained glass. Great place. Beware of closing between 12:00 and 1:00 pm. The stained glass is truly awesome.

Fantastic glass and light. We escaped the crowds by coming a half-hour before closing time. Treat yourself to this experience! The chapel with its many large stained glass windows is something you'll never forget.

Beautiful glass. The good: Perhaps the most beautiful stained glass room you can see - or at least should be when restoration is completed in 2014. Still extremely beautiful now. The bad: Gift shop on first floor seems crass and takes away from the historic and religiously important room.  Not much to see beyond the glass. The few relics not lost in the revolution are now housed in the treasury at Notre Dame. Info:  I was surprised at the fee to enter €8.50, but because it is not an active church and the great work being done, I understand. However, if money or time are limited, I would prefer the free access to Notre Dame a block away.

BEAUTIFUL STAINED GLASS. Sainte Chapelle was a real find. It is absolutely gorgeous. In my opinion, the stained glass is much better than that of Notre Dame. This church was commissioned by Louie IX in 1239. To see a structure of such beauty built so long ago was just amazing. The colors are vibrant and the entire structure is a feast for the eyes. It's one of the smaller churches, but it's not to be missed.

Better than Notre Dame!. Don't bother with the lines for Notre Dame when this place is so close and INCREDIBLE. The most amount of stained glass housed in one place in the world, this was built to house the supposed Crown of Thorns (King Henry IX was convinced he had found & purchased it...now it's held in Notre Dame and only comes out on Friday afternoons). Sainte-Chapelle is worth the visit.

Something that must see in Paris. Simply stunning! One of the most beautiful medieval churches in Europe. I've seen the Sainte Chapelle 5 or 6 times so far and each time it takes my breath away. Bad note: since 2009 a lot of stands, selling souvenirs and stupid things, are wasting the view of the low chapel. I sincerely hope that they will be remove soon, they are insulting.

Magnificent stained glass. It is a very small building from the late medieval period. The feature here is the amazing stained glass windows. Some of them are under restoration from now until 2014 but there are still plenty of them to gaze at. Gorgeous! Downstairs is worth looking at too, but there is a lot of space devoted to a gift shop.

Small and stunning, but under reno.. I attended a string quartet recital at the Saint-Chapelle chapel. It was a wonderful way to see the chapel, as well the halls of the Palais du Justice. The chapel itself is small, but feels expansive under the vaulted ceilings and stunning panorama of stained glass. It's a beautiful and inspiring space, unfortunately half of it is covered for renovations that are scheduled through 2014. Still worth seeing though, and if there are concerts scheduled, I recommend seeing it that way. The acoustics are wonderful.

Best stained glass in Paris. I naively thought Notre Dame would be the place to see the best stained glass in Paris.
We didn't get to see Sacre Coeur so I can't compare but the glass in this place has to be seen to be believed.
Don't miss this place.
The tour is quick.

Awe inspiring. The entry floor has some pretty windows and I wonder whether some tourists miss the tiny stairs up to the actual Chapel. That would be too bad -- it's soaring stained glass walls of windows are spectacular. Note that you can go to the Chapel entrance to get a ticket to enter just the Chapel. We went past the Conciergerie (a block before the Chapel) and thought we had to buy a combo-ticket for both places.

Stunning!. I consider this church a masterpiece. Definitely worth the visit even though the lines are long. When you enter the upper floor you can not believe it! The stained glasses are unbelievable! Enjoyed it!
Beautiful stained glass. It's worth the wait. Be sure to climb the stairs to the second floor to see the windows None of the motifs are repeated in any of the windows.

The 16th century Chapel. Typical french architecture, the stained glass work is beautiful and loveley intricate peice of artistry. Every bit is a paoetry of art. Must visit.A visist during the day, the sun shining through the stained glass is just beautiful.

Heaven on Earth. The Sainte Chapelle is one of the most beautiful examples of Gothic architecture on a small scale. As of now (July 2012), it is under renovation, so you won't be able to see about a third of the stained glass windows. The lines to get in are formidable but move swiftly. The Museum pass will NOT allow you to cut this line.
Long lines, worth the wait. Colors, history and drama. The stained glass windows are masterpieces and a national treasure.
Love the stained glasses. The church itself is quite small - and I strongly suggest you buy the museum pass to bypass the lines - but the work inside is amazing.

Right up there with Notre Dame.. Sainte -Chapelle is a magnificent jewel box of a cathedral. It doesn't have the gargoyles or bell tower, but the stained glass surpasses (to my mind) that of Notre Dame.

Cheap entry and absolutely beautiful!. This is probably one of the most stunning churches I've ever seen. The windows absolutely beautiful and the of the windows is astounding. Loved it. Definitely worth the money
Skip this and go somewhere else. Not much here, just stained glass windows and half of that was closed for repair...pretty disappointing. Not worth the money you pay to get in.

Fabulous stained glass--best in the world. Here's another Paris attraction to which we've been returning time after time for over 40 years. Gert your ticket in advance to avoid the lines. Binoculars are helpful here to see the fine details on the stained glass windows. Here are some of the oldest stained glass artworks anywhere, and some of the finest examples of this genre in the entire world. Don't miss it. Just grab a seat and gawk at the beautiful colors and the bible stories the art tells.

partly under restoration. The windows are beautiful and the part that has been restored looks amazing. I think the admission price (8,5 Euro) is a bit steep given the size, but it was lovely. Especially, if you have the Paris Museum Pass it would well worth a trip.
"Wow". The upper chapel at Sainte-Chapelle is certainly a "Wow" moment. It is certainly worth the hassle of the Palais du Justice security to get there!

Jaw-dropping. We had been told not to miss this site. Upon entering, we wondered at first why we had spent 8,50/per person to enter. After we went up the winding staircase, it was very clear! These windows are truly "not to be missed"!

a pretty church near Notre-Dame. Thank you to all the Tripadvisor reviewers who gave excellent advice. I did not have to wait an hour in line like all the other pissed off tourists who obviously did not read this site. Outside on the sidewalk of the complex that houses Sainte-Chapelle, there are two lines. The very long one on the left is for Sainte-Chapelle. There is a much shorter line, sometimes no line on the right, that goes to the Palais du Justice. They both go to the same courtyard, but most people do not know that you can just wait in the Palais du Justice line. You can. And doing so will cut your idle time by at least an hour if not more.That said, I don't really recommend this church unless you have an inclusive package like the Museum Pass and are in the Ile de la Cite to visit Notre Dame anyway. I would not place this church on my A list of places to be. Yes, it is really pretty and you can take a lot of nice photos, but unless you are really into churches, I think it is something of a ripoff at 8.5E just because there are so many free churches in Europe that you don't need to pay so much to see this one. In my opinion, the photos you see of this church is pretty much it. But admittedly, I am somewhat ambivalent to buildings, even very pretty buildings. I mean, it's not as if you did not see Paris if you missed this particular church. Also what soured my trip was that the first time we went, all the workers in the Ile de la Cite were on strike. That meant that we waited for half an hour outside Notre Dame only to realize it would not open at the time it was supposed to be open, and might not open for the rest of the day. Sainte-Chapelle had a similar strike. So when we came back the next day, both probably had more people in line than normal. With that aggravation, this church had to be pretty special for me to really root for it, and honestly it wasn't.

Beautiful stained glass. This church has the most beautiful stained glass i think I've ever seen. Only about half of the stained glass on the second level is viewable, as the rest is getting restored. The church will be even more impressive once the restoration is finished. The line is a little long, but it's important to see this beautiful church. Don't miss it!
Worth a trip. Sainte-Chapelle is a bit out of the way, but it offers a different side of Paris and some lovely views. Just be careful not to be conned, and watch your bag

Evening Concert at Sainte-Chapelle. We encountered a truly special evening at Sainte-Chapelle. We were able to visit this lovely landmark to take in a chamber music concert and it was a spectacular venue to experience chamber music the way it's suppposed to be heard. We would definitely do this again.

Beautiful. I have seen this church 4 times and I am always amazed at its beauty. The story of the books of the bible and the rose window of the Apocalypse are truly works of art. It's easy to get to, close to Notre Dame.

Stunning and memorable. Beautiful church in an interesting part of the city. Great destination for a walking day, head to the river and have some Gratin and a walk over to Sainte Chapelle to take in the light show and architecture. Don't miss the floors which have interesting patterns as well.

Amazing glass and law courts too. Dont miss these glass walls. Like standing inside a Tiffany lamp. Quite magical. The Law Courts next door are wonderful to wander the halls, and if lucky peak into the courts. The dress of the various court personnel, little interactions you witness, you can compose a mystery novel as you watch!

Most beautiful and sublime place, concert included. The Paris Saint Chapelle is an absolute must-see place. If you miss it you will bit your nails in regret over this. On top of how gorgeous the building (just enormous stained glasses held together by so incredibly thin columns and a rosace out of this world all surrounded by medieval paintings), the place also hosts evening concert series. We attended one concert this summer, Vivaldi's Four Season concerto. OMG! This was unbelievable. If I have one advice, not only visit the place but make sure you attend one of their concerts. This is $ well spent.
Vivaldi's Four Seasons at the Sainte Chapelle- Heavenly. So beautiful it made me cry. The acoustics are incredible for strings.

Vivaldi, Four Seasons concert. David Bracinni and 5 friends from the symphony play concerts at Ste Chappelle, it was the highlight of 3 weeks in France, if you like classical music. In the midst of this small chapel, the aucoustics and the setting were magical.
Restoration in process, viewing area very small. While the church itself was beautiful, there was only two small rooms to view the stained glass. Very disappointing.

Great visit. The line was a little long, but it is worth the wait to see this chapel. I only wish my pictures would do it justice. You can spend as much time as you want, but 30 minutes is probably plenty.

Classical performance at Sainte-Chapelle. We did a free city tour with Discovery Walks Paris (you pay what you feel the tour is worth) and got a goody bag of information including discount information for Classical Performance at Sainte-Chapelle. I originally had looked at purchasing tickets at $44 (Euros / person) and got last minute tickets for $16 (Euros / person) just by mentioning Discovery Walks Paris!!! Great savings and well worth it! The site is absolutely stunning - the stained glass work is out of this world!

Stunning!. We were "wowed" when we first went in and saw the ground floor. But it paled in comparison to the main floor. The stained glass windows are breathtaking. Don't miss it! It is one of the finest sights in all of Europe.

Breathtaking!. My Fat Tire bike tour guide had said how beautiful it was in this church, and it was included on the Paris Museum Pass, so I decided to stop by before heading to the Notre Dame. I'm so glad I did. When you first enter you're on the ground floor chapel which isn't really anything special. But then you head upstairs and your jaw drops. This is how stained glass should be used everywhere. My old art history teacher used to explain that being inside a church with stained glass would make the congregants feel like they were in a jewelry box, and now I know exactly what she was talking about. Definitely stop by here; it ended up being one of the highlights of my Paris trip!

Omg, the stained glass. You must visit this place. In 24 years of marriage I have hardly heard my husband gasp with awe. The stained glass is magical and breathtaking. An absolute top of the list must see!!

Sainte-Chapelle Concert. We dearly enjoyed the sight. But the concert Four seasons - Les canons de Pachebel - Adagio de Albinoni were tourist music.. played in a rush to pass to a personal version of the same by the interpretors that was more of a very twisted show play that was not at all of our like (personal opinion of a classic first violin player)
Beautiful!. Simply stunning stained glass windows.Make sure you see the Concierge as well - we didn't realise what the concierge was and therefore didn't get the reduced tickets.

Like a jewelry box. Long line in the hot sun- but when you get in it's worth it. Climb up an ancient spiral staircase, and suddenly you're in this colorful box. Exquisite stained glass, interesting info about refurbishing- worth the trip.

Amazing stained glass with a musical accompaniment. Having visited Sainte Chapelle by day last year, I thought it only fitting to pay another visit, this time by night and with musical accompaniment. By standing in the queue fairly early for the 08.30pm performance of sacred music, we were fortunate to score front row seats and therefore get the full impact of the stained glass windows (a few covered over as much needed and painstaking restoration work is completed) with the music. As it was mid June and a sunny evening, the sun set during the performance and the long dusk accentuated the colours most magnificently. The performance (string quartet and mezzo soprano) was businesslike without being virtuoso, but the entire performance of place, time and repertoire melded together into a memorable experience.

Unexpected pleasure. The interior--especially the stain glass windows -- was breathtaking, even though a few sections of the stain glass were being redone while we were there. One amusing aspect of the visit is the fact tthat visitors to Sainte Chappelle use the same entrance (and security check) as the folks going to the main court of the city.
Brilliant. We walked into the upstairs chapel and were blown away by the beauty, not to be missed.
Magnificient. High point of our trip. Incredibly beautiful. Be prepared to wait in line to get through security however.
Closed!. After finding my way on foot, the building was closed and locked. Very disappointing as I had been advised it was open.
Impressive but undergoing restoration. Very impressive stained glass. Is under construction/restoration though and it might be best to wait until next year.

Unbelievably beautiful. The first time I saw this place, I just couldn't believe how beautiful it was. The beauty of the stained glass, with the light coming through it, just takes your breath away. Can be crowded - get a Museum Pass and bypass the lines.

Takes your breath away. This small historical church is amazing. You enter through a high security screening (it's attached to the law courts buildings) and first see the delicate downstairs chapel. When you go up the steps and enter into the church the stainglass windows will literally take your breath away. Unfortunately when we went they were still doing renovations so we couldn't see all of them but what windows we were able to see were simply amazing. To think about the history of the church and the time as to when this was accomplished just adds to the wonderment of the church. Just be patient as you wait in the long, long queue as it is well worth it. Bring a book or your travel book to read while you're waiting in line as they strictly control the number of visitors allowed in at any given time.
Beautiful Stained Glass. The stained glass was incredible. Definitely carve out an hour to check it out.

Windows of light. Well worth any queue. Choose a sunny time to go if possible because the light shining through the windows into the Chapel is stunning. You can almost see the Court of France paying homage to the Kings and Queens in this evocative chapel.

A jewel. This is not to be missed. It truly is one of the wonders of Europe and I agree this tiny cathedral's stained glass windows are the most beautiful of all. Go ahead and wait in line for this! (Try odd times of day for the line, we got in faster going around 10:30 am.) When we were there, there was a school group that came in, and one little girl, eyes wide, couldn't stop going "oh, oh, oh" from the beauty. I agree.

A spiritual experience. The stained glass windows left me in awe! When we entered the chapel, it was a breathtaking moment that will last a lifetime. Do not miss the beauty of Sainte-Chapelle. Wait on line, know that your effor will be rewarded. Breathtaking!
Truly awesome. Some stained glass sections under renovation but you still get the effect of being surrounded by the magnificent stained gless windows

out of this world. we stumbled across this lovely chapel full of stained glass via the museum pass. it was one of our best experiences in paris. an absolutely must place to visit on a sunny day when the sun shines through the stained glass.
Delightful treasure box. The stained glass upstairs and the painted chapel downstairs are lovely to behold. The line is not so lovely, but it cleared out around 4pm.

Have a little stain glass with your vivaldi. We were fortunate to go to a concert in this most spectacular chapel. The music was beautiful and the venue -sigh- oh so beautiful. If you get a chance to go to a concert in this chapel, you will not be disappointed. it was such a lovely evening.
Amazing. DO NOT MISS this site. It is tucked away, but is the most magnificent stained glass you will see. Worth the entry fee 10 times over!
Sainte-Chapelle is glorious. Every visitor to Paris should see the spectacular private chapel of the Kings of France.

Best Stained Glass. The lines to get in were long & slow because it is attached to the Ministry of Justice . Security is as tight as the airport , but worth the wait . The stained glass just takes your breath away . It is small enough to visit in an hour or so .

Gorgeous!. If at all possible, visit Sainte-Chapelle on a sunny day. It is fun to watch the "amazed" expressions on people's faces as they come up the stairs and get their first glimpse of the beautiful stained glass windows. Try to include this "jewel" in your visit to Paris if possible. Other than the time you spend waiting in line to get in, your visit should not take more than 15 - 20 minutes. Enjoy!!
Restoration underway. It is a beautiful church, however, be prepared for some restoration currently being done which impacts the drama of the space in my opinion.
Breathtaking!!. The inside of this chapel is indescribable! Itis absolutely beautiful. Make sure you go upstairs. We had never heard of this and almost didnt go, but this is a must see!

Captivating!!. Apart from its historical significance, the best display of stained glass, I have ever come across. Captivating!!!. My entire family loved it and found it worthwhile waiting in pouring rain for more than an hour.Must see if you are a stained glass art lover like me.

Glorious stained glass.. Better than Notre Dame in my opinion. The wonderful soaring stained glass windows are best seen in the late afternoon with the sun shining through at a low angle. At present one side is covered up and being renovated, but not the west side, so the sun still shines through. Simply stunning!

stunning. Sainte-Chapelle is my favorite church in Europe. It is so stunning with all of the intricate stained glass. The line is always long so try to go first thing in the morning or later in the evening. Ask at your hotel if there is a service or concert there while you’re in town. Seeing a concert makes for an amazing memory.

Worth it!. St. Chapelle is definitely something that needs to be on your visit to Paris if you're staying for a week or longer (if you're only there for a few days it's alright to skip). The line to get in is very long, but for a few euros more you can get tickets at the concierergie (the prison where Marie-Antoinette was housed) for both attractions, and then just go right into the chapel after seeing the prison! Anyone who is a stained-glass fanatic (as well as anyone who isn't) will marvel at the almost floor-to-cieling stained glass panels. Also worth the money if you're there for a while is to see a concert there. We heard Vivaldi's Four Seasons there in the evening and it was absolutely magnificent. Tickets for the concerts are for sale at www.classictic.com.
Prettiest Church Ever. I've been to many, I've been to bigger, I've been to more famous, but this is easily the prettiest. Get the pass to skip the line.

Breathtaking. Wasnt even aware they had an upstairs which is the main chapel, so dont leave without going upstairs from the narrow staircase.
Very nice stained glass windows, ceiling, etc.
Not worth the admission. Yes it was beautiful but really do they have to charge that much to admire their stained glass?

Small but beautiful stained Glass. This is pretty small. But, the stained glass is beautiful. And, its style is quite different from Notre Dame. But, actually, the entrance price is a bit high, if you do not buy the Museum pass.
Do not miss. Centrally located, with its medieval structure. Something to see.

Amazing stained glass windows!. Long line, but worth the wait. This is the place to see the best stained glass windows in France.
Second floor is what you hoped Notre Dame would look like, but didn't!

Amazing. All the rage is to see Notre Dame...but don't let Saint-Chapelle go unseen. True, the lines to get in can be long, although we got there early and the line was manageable. Inside, the stained glass windows are simply stunning. Nothing can prepare you for what you see. Any hassle to get in is well worth it. There's not a better church in Paris.
paristrip. stunning stained glass windows change depending on direction/intensity of sunlight

Colors!. Is absolutely worth to visit this little church, its stained glass windows are unique and very beautiful. Be sure to visit the chapel in the afternoon with the sun high: the effect of stained glass is the best!

WOW!! The most stunning stained glass that I have ever seen! Must be viewed from the inside to appreciate beauty.. Located on the Île de la Cité, the gothic Sainte Chapelle is the only surviving building from the Capetian palace that once stood here. The upper chapel has one of the largest collections of 13th century stained glass in the world…it is truly breathtaking! The soaring vaulted ceiling seems to float above magnificent stained-glass windows. Check-out the sculpted statues of the 12 apostles which lean on the columns. The lower chapel, dedicated to the virgin Mary, sports low vaulted ceilings. The walls are decorated with trefoiled arcades with 12 medallions which represent the 12 apostles. TIP: As Sainte Chapelle is so close to Notre Dame Cathedral and La Conciergerie, you may want to see both Notre Dame & Sainte Chapelle on your same trip. Queues seemed longest on the weekends. If possible, go on a week day near opening time and you should experience no wait.Location:4, boulevard du PalaisFee: 8.50 eurosOpen daily from 9:30 am to 6 pmMetro: Cite station (line 4). Saint Michel (RER B).

Small but gorgeous. We walked over to Sainte Chapelle after seeing Notre Dame and liked it very much. Be prepared to stand in line to get in - or get in a much shorter line with the Paris Museum Pass. The incredible stained glass windows are the star attraction of this small chapel. We spent about 30 minutes here and that was more than enough time to take everything in. The only downside was the construction/restoration work that is ongoing. At the end of May, there was a big white covering on one side of the interior that makes it hard to take good pictures of full interior. There is also scaffolding on the outside that makes it hard to get good pictures of the beautiful steeple. It's still definitely worth a short visit though!

Stained glass heaven. If you are there when it is not too busy, lie down in the middle of the floor and get a great photo of the lofty ceiling and the stained glass windows that reach up to support it. Fantastic.

Loved this!. We wanted to see St-Chapelle, but didn't want to stand in a block long line so we learned this trick...Next door, at the Conciergerie, you can buy tickets to both St-Chapelle and the Conciergerie (where Marie Antoinette was jailed before she was beheaded and other interesting Revolutionary history). We spent a nice, non crowded hour at the conciergerie, and then went to a cafe across the street for wine and cheese until about 45 minutes before St-Chapelle closed and they had shut down the ticket booth. We walked right in and had the place practically to ourselves. It is breathtaking. There was some construction, but that in itself was interesting.

breathtaking!. Couldnt help feeling slightly disappointed when I first walked in. Its smaller than I'd assumed and quite dark. That was the ground floor...I know its an over-used phrase but coming up the stairs to the second floor literally took my breath away...brilliant!
Be prepared to wait but be amazed. Long line to get through security, but once in an amazing site. Beautiful stained glass windows. The architectural is stunning.
Book a concert. The church is simply beautiful. To sit in the midst of the most beautiful stained glass windows while enjoying a performance of Verdi's Four Seasons was magical. Highly recommend!
Okay but overrated. We waited in line for over an hour, the entry fee was a bit much for very little to see. Some of the areas were under construction.
Stunning. Under renovation.Long queues to get in but breath taking and worth the wait.

Fantastic Stained Glass. Sainte-Chapelle is relatively small and was completed after 11 years construction in 1248. Construction was ordered by Louis IX and was under the direction of a single architect hence there is a uniformity of design not seen in the majority of cathedrals. It was built to house the alleged crown of thorns from the crucifixion of Christ that allegedly cost Louis IX more than the cost of the chapel! The big draw is the fantastic stained glass windows that are being restored with the work 75% complete. We visited early in the day and had less than 30 min wait.
a gem. Interesting history, interesting architecture, and amazing windows of stained-glass. High on the list of things to see whilst in Paris.

Stunning!. If you think you have ever seen beautiful stained glass windows, you might be about to change your mind. The windows at Siante-Chapelle are stunning, absolutely worth a look.
Enjoy!
A Medieval Masterpiece. this was a total revelation, there was no big fanfare about Sainte-Chapelle but it was what I call a travelling bonus. Not on the main agenda but well worth visiting.

Breathtaking chapel with glorious stained glass.. On our recent visit to Paris and after a wonderful visit to Notre Dame, my wife and I made our way to Sainte-Chapelle. Located in the heart of Paris on Ile de la Cite, Sainte-Chapelle is part of the La Conciergerie complex. We arrived and were met with the longest (and slowest line we encountered during our trip). The security is some of the most thorough you'll have to go through in Paris and that's the main reason the line moves so incredibly slow. But it's worth it.Once through security a very short unmarked walk takes you to the entrance. It's hard to really admire the exterior of Sainte-Chapelle but the inside is where the real attraction is. Once through the entrance you come to a sounvenir stand and a pretty first room. But a narrow spiral staircase in the corner of the room takes you to chapel's real treasure, the stained glass. We were amazed at the incredible glass that dates back to the 13th century. Each huge window is dedicated to a book of the Bible and tells different stories from those books. It's truly breathtaking.There were some renovations going on upstairs so we didn't get the full effect but our experience was unforgettable. We visited a lot of churches in Paris and Sainte-Chapelle was one of the best. Make sure you make time to see it!
Amazing place. Brilliant but always a queue. Lots of people so be prepared to get jostled

Colors, light, crystal. Churches are my least favorite points of interest. But you know the windows are famous. When you walk, face to butt, up the cramped medieval steps from the altar downstairs, you can't expect the crystalline shower of deep primary colors. You're suddenly unaware of all other tourists, you stop breathing, and a choir of angels can be faintly heard in the background.
St-Chapelle. Best church stained glass in Paris. Nasty security line--the guards randomly close the facility. It sits in the palace of justice.

Do not miss!. Definitely make this a part of your Paris itinerary. While the church doesn't look extraordinary on the outside, it is spectacular once you step inside. You can spend an hour just staring at the intricate stained glass windows.
Beautiful. Worth it after going into Notre Dame - the stained glass windows are exceptional.

Of course a must!!!. you will have to wait in line; go through security, get your tickets, walk again inside the official building... Don't be put off by the dust, the construction site, it is worth all the trouble.Yes if the sun is shining you will get the most of the window's work, I would almost bring a chair to spend the adequate amount of time to "read" the windows. What a delicious work of art, it is under renovation and will last a long time, but it will be the jewel it once was.Stairs are very small but impossible if you are in a wheelchair. Enjoy!!A little book store with interesting little gifts for the young ones and the others.

Beautiful. This was under construction but in any condition it is a MUST SEE in Paris. The outside isn't much to look at and there are always lines but come early to minimize the line and don't miss the view from the interior second floor.
Le bijou de l'architecture gothique. A must see in Paris. In spite of the current renovations, this is a chapel that is always worth a visit. Attending a concert here is even more impressive!

Beautfiful windows. Very pretty, but the line can be quite long, as the cathedral is located inside a government complex. The line outside is to go through security, which is quite tight.
They are refurbishing the stained glass windows, so some are covered, but it doesn't diminish the beauty.
Don't miss. You will feel like you are in heaven and will hear the angels sing. The most amazing stained glass.
Like a jewelbox. We attended a concert here: Vivaldi's Four Seasons played by a string sextet with a harpsichord. It was magic. Check out what's on in Paris and "use" the sights.
When the light is right. The stain-glass is amazing in this church when the sun is shining and if it is not the ceilings and structure is worth the visit.
Chapel of the Kings. Very old and undergoing major renovation but the stained glass is amazing

Worth the queue.. In fact the queue was an experience in itself - people watching. Also provided an opportunity to read the posters outside advertising a wonderful a concert which we returned that evening to hear. It was magical. What a spectacular and intimate place to visit.
Stained Glass Heaven. If you love stained glass, you will LOVE this church. It is small and intimate so beware that if you go in high season/high time of the day it can get quite crowded.

Breathtaking Stained Glass Windows. This was a church that my fiance and I was not planning on attending. After some more research and learning about the architecture we decided to stop in. The long line on the street can be very deterring for people to visit. This line is just for security. The church is location inside the government office structure. Once you are inside you can access the church easily. The first floor is cool but the main attraction are the windows on the 2nd floor. During our visit and till 2014 the church is doing some major renovations to the windows. Each window includes various panels that tell different biblical stories. The church entrance fee was very reasonable with the museum pass that we purchased. Definitely worth a visit during your Paris visit.
surprise. we had no idea how beautiful this little gem is. we liked it better than notre dame

If you have a chance to visit at sunset, go then. My daughter and I attended a Vivaldi concert at dusk, and the light coming through the windows was amazing. The music was wonderful in the small venue. In one word: "Breathtaking."

If in Paris don't miss Sainte-Chapelle. I visited Ste Chapelle many years back when the guide book was a printed two sided sheet of paper. I hadn't remembered just how beautiful this building is. It is good to know the history of it, for it will show you how remarkable the structure really is.
Read how it is unique for the time it was built.

Breathtaking stained glass. When you visit Sainte-Chapelle, you remember that the parishioners couldn't read. It is fascinating to look for Cain and Abel and other stories from the Bible depicted for the medieval folk. It is so lovely.

Stunning. On two floors - accessed by a narrow, circular stone staircase. Ceiling to floor stained glass around most of the building - you would need to stay a while to take it all in as to begin with its a little overwhelming.
lots of steps. be prepared to climb steps into the chapel. worth the climb

Stunning surprise. I had no idea it existed until a friend told me about it. Visually more beautiful than Notre Dame with it's newly restored windows. The entire chapel appeared to made of glass. It was a marvelous treasure.

Jaw Dropping spectacular. It all seems so ho-hum until you clime the stairs and see the stained glass windows. Never seen anything so spectacular in a building, just stood there for 5 minutes taking it all in. The queue to get in was lengthy but it was worth the wait.

impressive stained glass windows, but not worth the time. The tourist brochures and people we talked to indicated that the crown of thorns which Jesus wore was housed in this chapel. We found that the crown allegedly USED to be housed here, but was moved elsewhere (Notre Dame?). The chapel consists of 2 floors, the top of which has tall, intricate, beautiful stained glass windows. The bottom floor has a few items of interest, but is used mainly for the gift shop. There was a long wait to get into the chapel because everyone had to go through security (the chapel is attached to a major police station). We definitely felt that this attraction was not worth our time.
Beautiful stain glass. Stained glass currently being renovated and the parts that have been restored are just beautiful!
My favorite spot in Paris.. I visit the gem EVERY time I am in Paris. I would love to hear a concert here.

Must See Ornate Upstairs and Windows. Sainte-Chapelle is as gorgeous inside as Notre Dame on the outside. Built much earlier than Notre Dame, with spectacular coloured glass windows like no other Cathedral. It's very close to Notre Dame, almost looks like part of the Cental Police station, you have to search it out and see it.

lovely church. We went here twice. Once to tour and once for a concert. The concert visit was SOOOOOO worthwhile. If they have it and you like classical music, do attend. It was a 4 piece chamber orchestra in the evening and WOW, not enough I can say about it. Definitely a high point on our trip
Just beautiful. Stained glass like nothing you have seen before. The line can be a little long. No special line for the Paris Pass due to security as it is inside the Law courts.

Incredible. I would have to rate this as the top thing to see in Paris.If you are lucky enough to go inside on a sunny day, the views of the stained glass windows, that stretch from ceiling to floor, are breathtaking.A laminated guide is provided in the back, (away from the alter), that gives one a description of the images on the windows. One could spend hours, starting from "the beginning", circling around the church, following the story.Do yourself a favor and stay for a bit, grab the guide, and admire the beauty.
Lovely lovely. This is just a short walk from the NotreDame cathedral. The stained glass windows are awesome and well worth a visit if you are in the area

Renovation in progress..Go later!. This was the 2nd time I was visiting Saint Chapelle and I was very disappointed to see that a part of the upper chapel has been closed (around 4 windows) for renovation. It was also disappointing that the prices were not reduced inspite of the renovation work..I felt quite cheated as I paid full fare to see only a part of the glorious glass paintings..The paintings are very beautiful on a sunny day...I would suggest wait till the renovation gets completed before spending 8.5euros to see only a part of the structure..This chapelle is one which should be seen in full and not partially...
Beautiful !. Went there twice .. worth every penny ! Its a beautiful church with the most beautiful stained glass I have ever seen. Pity it was used as a store for the court for so many years !

Just as wonderful 20 years later!. I went here on my first trip to Paris 20 years and it was one of my favorite things at the time. What I loved was the surprise when you go upstairs and have the beauty of the sun coming through the stained glass. Of course, it does not have the grandeur of Notre Dame, but I love the intimacy of it. We arrive a bit before lunch and thankfully I saw the sign that said they close between 1-2:30 (can't remember if this was the exact time, so check) because we left and came back at 3. I met a women line who waited for 30 mins only to get to the front of the line and be told they were closing and to come back later.

A Must-See. I was recently in Paris as part of a Rick Steves tour, and this was one of the included guided tours. I knew the Rose stained glass window was here, but I wasn't prepared for the breath-taking beauty of the church's stained glass. You enter through the lower level, which is a beautiful little painted chapel. Once you go up some steep stone steps into the main church area, you will be blown away. The stained glass windows were lit with sunshine, the carvings were amazing, and the whole thing was very peaceful in spite of the crowds. Definitely worth seeing.

Stunning and inspiring. This is my favorite spot in Paris. On a sunny day, the brilliance of 800 year old stained glass is overwhelming; it's easy to imagine how the people of Paris felt attending Mass here in 1300 AD. Make time for this experience.
Beautiful!. You can spend an hour or many hours analyzing the most beautiful stained glass windows in Paris!

Stunning stained glass!. This is our favorite chapel because of the stunning stained glass windows. Even with scaffolding on one side, it still was amazing. We also like the smallness as compared to the larger cathedrals. You really feel like you are in a private place.

Beautiful stained glass!. As we were under 26 we were able to visit for free. However we felt that if we had paid for it (8.50euros) we would have been slightly disappointed as it was much smaller than we expected.Having said that it's still a very beautiful and interesting attraction and is currently undergoing restoration work which will make the windows look even better.

A very dramatic church, arrive early. Buy a museum pass and have breakfast at L'Annex across the street. The access line starts forming at 9 am for the 9:30 opening. The chapel is a dramatic with stained glass windows. (This chapel is 10 minutes walk from Notre Dame.)
Long slow line. It took a while to get in and the Museum Pass doesn't allow you to cut the line here. Beautiful stained glass windows.

Marvelous stained glass - a stunning cathedral of the old kings. We stopped by to see Sainte Chapelle late in the afternoon on a sunny and warm Friday afternoon. The lines weren't super long, about a 20-minute wait to enter. We opted for the audio tour so that we could get the story on all of the stained glass panels, and we are glad we did.The left-hand side inside the chapel had restoration work being done on the stained glass, so mostly the right-hand side was available to view. It was rather crowded, but it is possible to see each panel and hear about it if you have patience (and can ignore pushy tourists).Overall, I would recommend this because it is a different church experience than Notre Dame. This was the chapel of the kings, and was the site of the relic of the "crown of thorns", brought back to France from one of the crusades. For those who are religious in nature, it is a wonderful site to view the biblical stories in stained glass.Tips:Best to go early, around opening when it is not so crowded.Best to go in the middle of the week.You must go through a metal detector since it is next to the courts buildingTake the audio tour so you can understand what you are seeing, and take the time to hear about each panel.Do not go on a dark, cloudy, or rainy day - you won't get the marvelous view of the stained glass.Overall, I'd go again; especially to view the panels that were under renovation. I would recommend this to family and friends.
Breath-taking. This is by far the best thing I saw while I was in Paris. The light shining through the stained glass is stunning. Plus I got in free because I am a student! Worth the queue!
Wouldn't go a 2nd time. I found this church to be rather pricey for what it was. Perhaps b/c it was under construction, but there was not much to see.
Awesome. Gorgeous windows, bit of a queue to get in but worth it.
Catch it on a sunny day. The windows are just glorious in the sun but an evening concert is also very enjoyable.

A gem of early Gothic. I believe this chapel, which was designed to be a royal chapel within the Conciergerie, has more stained class per square foot of chapel than any other. At any rate, it is the amazing stained glass, with its intense blues, that draws people to the chapel. Lines can be long in the morning, but by mid afternoon, it doesn't take too long to get inside. The chapel is still consecrated, so it's not a place for loud voices or flash photography. But, on a sunny day, the light is sufficient for regular photography and it is a photographer's dream. The color scheme of the pillars and walls is also extraordinary. It is one of the three most extraordinary chapels of early Gothic that still survive (St. Martin du Champs and St. Germain de Pres are, I believe, the other two). It's worth it to buy the extra admission to see the Conciergerie as well, where Marie Antoinette awaited her execution.

Undergoing renovation---underwhelmed. Waited in a non-moving line a very long time and found out once we got in it was because they had closed for lunch!! No info about that anywhere. Due to renovation/restoration, much of the church was closed off. The stained glass available for viewing was limited. Not worth the wait to me.
Wonderful surprise. They call this a gem of a church and they are correct; a must see in Paris
Concert Night. Attending concerts in cathedrals I've found is the best way to soak up the beauty of both. Wonderful Vivaldi-Four Seasons. Sainte-Chapelle is a glorious place!

Restoration works wonders!. They have been working to clean the stained glass for quite some time now and WOW what a difference! I've been once before many years ago. The glass was pretty but now that it's sparkly clean it took my breath away!

Stunning stained glass. Wow! What a Chapelle - this is definitely worth a visit. The stained glass windows are amazing, with the largest area of stained glass there is, so i was told.We also watched Vivaldi 4 seasons concert in the evening which was also a very good performance, made even better by the surroundings.

Under restoration. Really long queue to go through security, which is manned by really mediocre ushers, he was not clear, was not guiding and was chaos for no reason at all. We finally got in to a underwhelming display of stained glass, some of it was clean and some of it was thick layered in dust or covered by dust sheets as it is under restoration. We had bought Museum Passes so did not have to cough up money for tickets. I would have been quite annoyed if I had done so.
It is on your way to Notre-Dame, so don't miss it.. I loved the feeling you get when you step in the chapel, reflecting on all the kings and queens who have also stood where you are.
Too expensive. For what it is, i thought the ticket was way overpriced!

Beautiful, crowded and under renovation. I was prepared to fall in love with Sainte Chappelle but it disappointed me a little. I believe the large Saturday crowds may have been part of that. I also didn't rent the audio tour and should have. I'd read a lot and thought I knew the high points, but somehow it's not as straight forward once you get there. I liked I could photography the stunning architecture and 13th century stain glass windows, but between the blocked ares for renovation (yes, I understand it must be done) and the crowds pushing you along, I failed to experience that unique personal connection I love to find in such sacred places of beauty. I tolerate larger crowds poorly. A museum pass is a must and will save you an hour or more waiting in lines.Also, the area marked "toilets" was barricaded off. Where do people use the restroom in Paris? Plan accordingly. I think it's worth seeing at a time of low demand or for a classical music concert. Check the website for the latter.

A Vivaldi 4 seasons tribute. We went for a Vivaldi 4 seasons tribute, it was simply divine, magical, I can't find enough words to describe how you feel when you are in the monumental sacred Sainte-Chapelle and you listen to such melodies, it feel like your in heaven!

Good if you like stained glass windows. We managed to avoid a long queue for security thanks to a very helpful Frenchman, who told us to join the queue for the Palais de Justice next door. I'm glad we did this as I would not have wanted to queue for half an hour or more to see what, in my opinion, are some very impressive 13th century stained glass windows and, err, that's about it.
Long lines. Paris Museum Pass does not allow for "front of line" access. We tried twice on two different days to see this site and the lines were very long. We did wait to get in...
okay. check hours of operation , they close the lines. not as impressive as churches in italy, if you have little time in paris, i would pass up

Windows, just wow!. This is one of those places, that you just have to see yourself! No photo can give you the same experience. Imagine 15 meters high windows of coloured and painted glass all around you. It's worth the wait in the queue!
Stunning windows. Its a little jewel hidden away but well worth a visit
Evening Concert at Ste Chapelle. Vivaldi's Four Seasons was fantastique! Great acoustics, beautiful surroundings and amazing musicians made for a lovely evening

Amazing stained glass. The stained glass and detail were very nice to see. Unfortunately part (1/3) of the upper chapel is under renovation (which isn't noted anywhere). The line up is long to get in, particularly due to going through security detection. The Museum Pass did not allow you to bypass the line up which is disappointing and not consistent with some of the info provided in guide information. Supposedly (according to one couple) there are tickets you can get that do allow you to bypass the line, but I'm not quite sure where - maybe at the Conciergerie next door.

Go With a Guide. I've been to Sainte-Chapelle a number of times, but really enjoyed going with a guide, in this case, Iris with Paris Walks. The stained glass really is amazing, and some has been cleaned recently which highlights the bright colors. Iris was able to "walk" us through the stories told in the glass, something that you really can't do without a professional guide. Having a small set of binoculars, or a camera with a great zoom lens really helps to see the top of the windows. I should also mention that you have to go through a metal detector to get into Sainte-Chapelle since it is attached to the Palais de Justice. Why do I mention this? Because I had to toss a really nice manicure set because they thought I might use my cuticle nippers to hold someone hostage. Meh.
Not to be missed!. Sainte-Chapelle is amazing for the stained glass and the concerts. However, avoid the crowds of the months of June, July. August and September!

under construction. You have to pay an admission fee, and they don't tell you that 1/3 of the chapel is covered due to a renovation.....also, there were no English guides left when i visited late in the day. Ask first.

Very beautiful even if it is half under restoration. Close to Notre Dame and with much shorter queues to get in, this was actually worth the wait. Strangely the entrance to the upper floor, where the magnificent stained glass is found, was tucked in a corner and would be quite easy to miss in a crowd. Very little in the way of explanatory notes as they want you to buy the guide book of course, but truly beautiful. There is a notice outside that explains that the chapel is under restoration until 2014, but it's worth the visit for the two-thirds of windows that are visible. The tiling on the floor is also very impressive, I spend almost as much time looking down as up.

Stain glass windows are drop-dead gorgeous!. This very ancient and cozy church somehow survived the centuries intact and what a reward that was to us! The floor-to-ceiling stain glass windows are spectacular. The acoustics are wonderful too, as we had the opportunity to come back at night to hear a violin concert.

Disappointed. Perhaps we visited at the wrong time of the day/year (late morning, end of May), but the stained glass windows were not at all spectacular. On the ground floor the sales area obscured some of the architecture. It cost 8.50 euros to enter, and no doubt this goes towards upkeep and repairs, but if you have to choose, go to Notre Dame instead and make a donation!

Being inside a jewel box. A little hard to find with the construction, but oh my -- I think kaleidoscopes were invented to try and replicate the stained glass in this chapel. I can see why the French royalty were given the reputation for extravagance after being here.

Best church in Paris. Notre Dame may be bigger and more famous, but Sainte-Chapelle is a unique, classic Gothic masterpiece. It was built in only six years, truly amazing when you see it and consider that construction took place in the 14th century. The stained glass windows are truly marvelous.Suggest you arrive early or just before reopening after the lunch break. The museum pass doesn't work for the main entry and passage through security (make sure you use the Sainte-Chapelle line and not the adjacent line for the Ministry of Justice). But it works for entry into the church itself. Take a look around the downstairs chapel for the palace staff, then head upstairs and prepare to be amazed. Don't miss it.
Breathtakingly beautiful - Must see. Absolutely stunning chapel which is in the middle of the Palais de Justice.

Beautiful stained glass. First tip: Buy the Paris Museum Pass to bypass the long line into the church, and there will be a long line.Second tip: when you walk by the entrance to the Palais de Justice (the church is inside the Palais de Justice and you have to go through the security check-- Paris Museum Pass won't help you there), get in either line. There was a long line with signage for the church and then another line for the justice department. Use either one- these lines are just for a security check.Beautiful stained glass, even the second time around (we visited before a few years ago).
Beautiful color. A small by beautiful chapel. The stained glass and the painted columns and floors were most impressive. Worth seeing and no line like lots of attractions in Paris.
Prettiest church. The stain glass is absolutely incredible! Will be even nicer when all the restoration is completed.

Stunning!. As we descended to the top of a narrow spiral staircase, we turned the corner and the beauty of the sun shining through the detailed stained glass dome was absolutely beautiful! One of my favorite sites during the trip!

Beautiful stained glass windows / no crown of thorns. I had read about Sainte-Chapelle and how it was built to house the Crown of Thorns (and other relics from the Passion), so was looking forward to seeing the Crown of Thorns on my visit. I guess I didn't read close enough as these items are no longer housed at Sainte-Chapelle, but have been transferred to the Notre Dame Cathederal Treasury where the Crown of Thorns is displayed the first Friday of every month and on Good Friday during a service, "Veneration of the Crown of Thorns" - so if you are looking for the Crown of Thorns (as I and a few other visitors were), you won't find it here. What you will find however, are beautiful stained glass windows, that are worth the visit.Also, regarding the security line and other comments that I've seen posted: we did not have the museum pass and waited in the lengthy security line. While there was not separate signage posted, those people who had the museum pass were given priority over those without (i.e. if they came to the front of the line and asked, they were allowed immediate entry through security - we saw many people with museum passes do this while we were waiting to go through security).
Breathtaking. When you arrive in the upper chapel you feel as though you've walked into a floating room of magnificent stained glass. Unforgettable!
Beautiful and very ornate. Worth a visit along with la conciergerie. Incredible amount of stained glass windows. Classical concerts sometimes held here too.

Beautiful Windows But Limited View. Yes, the stained glass windows are beautiful, but the church is very narrow and you can't see the details of most of the windows. Each window is arranged in three columns with 15 windows in each column. Maybe you can see the bottom five rows, but there is no way you can see the rest. Maybe you should bring binoculars to help you see the rest. Museum Pass holders beware. You have to wait in a long security line with non-pass holders before you can "skip the line" to buy tickets. We waited over 30 minutes in the security line. Also, we just made it in time as they were randomly closing the entrance from 13:00-14:15. If you don't have the Museum Pass and have to pay a the entrance fee it is quite expensive at 8.50 Euros when you will only spend 30 minutes there.
Under construction.... It took over an hour to get in and get through scurvy only to fin it was under construction. Check on this before waiting too long.

A beautiful space even better with concerts. The stained glass windows of Sainte-Chapelle are legendary and beautiful. Bring your camera and spend some time watching the play of light. The entry level windows are lovely but the real gems are on the second floor. Sainte-Chapelle has a very active concert schedule and you can't beat the combination of acoustics (hear the concert just as Rameau or Mozart might have) and the sheer splendor of the site.
Fantastic place.. Skip the Louvre and go here instead. This is the most beautiful building I have every been in . Be ready for very long lines!

Awesome!. We weren't prepared to be blown away over Sainte-Chappelle since Notre Dame next door gets all the hype but we came away from our visit to Sainte-Chapelle with some amazing photographs of the ceilings and stained glass windows.

Interesting but not the greatest sight in Paris. It is interesting but small and only one room, not much to see, not worth the wait in the queue. It is best to arrive early to get ahead of the queue and through security before the crowd arrives.

Restored and magnificent. The stained glass windows on the second floor here are just amazing and next year when all of the scaffolding has been removed, they should be breathtaking. They have been restored over the past four years and there is one section left to do--when it is fully restored, you will miss the difference between old and restored--the amount of light that passes through the restored windows highlights the jewel tone colors. It is certainly worth a visit and will take about 1-2 hours.
Lovely. This is one not to miss.--Beautiful stain glassClose to Notre Dame

Stunning and unique. Sainte-Chapelle was one of my favorite churches out of the very many that I saw on my whole Europe trip, and one of my favorite places in Paris. The stained glass is unbelievable and they are in the middle of cleaning each and every piece of glass one at a time so now it is even more luminescent than it was before. Gorgeous!

Beautiful stained glass...worth a visit.. My daughter and I both were impressed with the stained glass and how beautiful the colors were. There is a nominal entrance fee, but worth the price to see the stained glass.

Fit this into your schedule!!!!. Go to the Vivaldi concert of The Four Seasons for the early (7 PM) performance on a sunny day. The combination of the music and the sun streaming in the stained glass windows will make you think you're in heaven,

Fab Concert and Incredible Space!. We saw a chamber music concert at 7:00p, that lasted 70 minutes. Albinoni, Correlli, and Vivaldi, by a seven piece group with fantastic personal chemistry among themselves. The sun, streaming through the stained glass, was awesome. Great venue

Fell in love. I love stained glass, and this church may have set the bar too high for any other church. The church is absolutely stunning and it has to be seen to be believed. They are in the midst of refurbishing the church and the results so far are incredible. Take the time to see this.

Beautiful. We skipped one day when line was wrapped around the block but returned later in the week. Quite a beautiful site! The documentary on its restoration was quite interesting. Stained glass was amazing.
Disappointing. I was told not to miss but could have. It was pretty but high priced for not such great return. Spend extra hour in Notre Dame & skip this.

Go In the evening to avoid lines. We saw the lines in the morning/ afternoon nearly circle the building so we went to another site and came back around 615pm. Had a little trouble getting in as the main door was closed and the side door was not prominately marked but the police men were helpful in pointing us in the correct direction. While the evening light may not have been as great to see the windows i was glad we didn't wait in the line to see a two roomed structure.

Great venue for concerts. Apart from the traditional daytime tours, I recommend attending one of the concerts generally held at 8:30 in the evening. The combined effect of classical music and the sun's setting rays through the long stained-glass windows is magical.
Sight and Sound. Attended a Vivaldi concert here and enjoyed it immensely.

absolutely beautiful. Don't miss it! This is a real gem, stunningly beautiful, far beyond what I had expected. It's an otherworldly space that seems to float up to the heavens (even with some of the windows covered during the restoration process). And when you can take your eyes away from the stained glass windows, look at the bas-relief on the portico. One thing you might want to keep in mind, if you are a fan of chamber music: just go to one of the 7pm concerts in the chapel (25 euro/per ticket)--no line, no hustle and bustle of tour groups, and ample time to take in the chapel. Lasts for about 1 hour. Otherwise, the ticket to visit is 8.5 euros.
Windows being renovated...sigh. In spite of the renovation going on, the rose window was visible & one side of the chapel. There was an interesting video about the renovation work.

Very small, especially because of restoration.. The stained glass is absolutely gorgeous! We were disappointed by the small size of the cathedral, though, especially considering that one entire wall was blocked off due to restoration. The price seemed high for what we saw, but what we did see was amazing.

Not a must and quite expensive. I'm not saying it's not an amazing vitrage, but since it is being renovated (until 2014 - they state so before you pay) sob you don't get the full effect with the addition of the 8.5 Eur entrance fee it shouldn't be on top of your to do list.If you decide to get in try when it's sunny to get the full effect, might get a better 'wow' factor if you go while there is a concert as it is rumored the acoustics are great.Expect queues.

A must see!!!. If you visit this breathtaking church, you must climb the stairs to the 2nd floor and prepare to gasp in awe. You will feel like you are a tiny person in a large jewelry box. The view of the stained glass windows is beyond stunning!!!!!

It's fantastic!. This is one of the most fantastic places I've seen, I just could not manage going out of there. It's one of the best examples of vitrage art. The view is especially amazing in sunny weather, when the sun light does through thousands of coloured pieces of glass. It's definitely must see, if you are in Paris

Combine your visit with an evening concert for an amazing expereince. Dont que up during the day to see the chapelle rather book a ticket to see a classical concert in the evening with no crowds or hassle. They start at 7.30pm and 9.30pm. Go to the earlier one so you can see the evening light through the stained glass windows (May-Sep its still perfectly bright). Amazing atmosphere and space for a concert and aucoustics are superb. There are 3 classes of seating. Buy the 2nd class as they are as good as the first class and only 5-6 rows away from the stage..3rd class are at the back. Use an online site like classictics.com to book your tickets in advance to avoid disapointment.A s please note that the chapelle is undergoing some renovation work so not all the stained glass is on display at present and wont be for another few years.
The FINEST stained glass in France!. So close to Notre Dameand so beautiful. If you are on Isle de las Cite do not miss it!!

Fantastic stained glass, but not worth the entrance fee!. We were quite excited about going here as it had some pretty good reviews - well, I was not as impressed as i'd liked to have been. First of all, it is too expensive at 8.50 each, it wasn't overly busy yet we queued longer at this than we did anywhere else... around 45 mins, beware that when you get past the first queue (bag checks), there is another one where you buy your ticket. Now, I can appreciate the beauty of this place, but, when you first go in you kind of think "is this it", then you realise that to the left of the entrance is the staircase up to the next floor. When you get to the top of the stairs, you do get a "wow" factor. The stained glass is amazing, but there's only so long you can look at the same windows... the guides say to allow 1hr for your visit inside...i'd say more like 30 mins. Put it this way - I wouldn't really recommend it if you think it's going to be big and grand - it's not. I'm glad I can say i've been, but I would rather have had the 17 Euro's we paid to go somewhere else.

First Site in Paris to take my breath away. This was one of the first sites that we visited in Paris and when stepping up the staircase to enter the chapel, I was amazed at the beauty of this gorgeous location. The stained glass and architectural details are amazing. One of those locations that I could admire for admire for hours.....
Most amazing stained glass!. Sainte-Chapelle has the most amazing stained glass I've ever seen! There isn't a whole lot more to see, but the stained glass makes a trip worth it.

A surprising church in the midst of the Ile de la cite. The beautiful stained glass windows in the upper church are well worth standing in a long line for. This place has more recently been "discovered". Years ago hardly noone visited!

Playing Flute in Sainte-Chapelle. I asked if I could and they said yes! We discovered this place when we went on a Discovery Tour. The line for Notre Dame was too long but we got right in here. It was beautiful.

Worth a visit.. Visited Sainte-Chapelle for a concert and was blown away by the sheer beauty of the place. Stain Glass panels surround you completely. A smaller cathedral as far as cathedrals go..yet big on incredible architecture and the light pouring in most of the daylight hours. Excellent.

Lovely. We have been back to Sainte-Chapelle on numerous of our Paris trips. The place is just spectacular. Don't spend too much time downstairs before you head upstairs to the "real action". The windows are just beautiful & the whole room is just breathtaking. Photos you see don't prepare you for how amazing it is to stand in a room made almost entirely of stained glass.Note, when we were here most recently in May 2012, two panels of glass were boarded up and under restoration, which sadly takes something away from the experience. If you are a first-time visitor, don't let that put you off - its still worth going as is.And a tip for getting in. The queue on the street is just for security. Once you are inside, there is typically a long queue to buy tickets. For €2 more than the price of the admission to Ste-Chappelle alone, you can buy a combined ticket to Ste-Chappelle & the Conciergerie (buy them 50m down the road at the Conciergerie ticket office - usually no queue). With the combined ticket, you can completely skip the queue to get into Ste-Chappelle. It's worth at least €2 to save up to an hour of queuing time, especially in the rain or blazing sun.

Different experience from Notre Dame. Even if you've already been to Notre Dame and many other churches in Europe, I would still recommend to visit Sainte-Chapelle. It's a small place so you don't need to spend more than an hour - we lined up around 4:30pm so there were much less people and got in there within 20 minutes of waiting. Currently, the rehabilitation work on the stained glasses is underway so you can see clear difference between the old part and rehabilitated part, also get to see a video of what's involved in keeping this monument for generations.

"Gorgeous". I enjoy looking at the architecture of the old churches, not to mention the stained glass windows. It was a small enough venue that you could squeeeze it in while waiting for a dinner reservation.
If you only see one church in Paris, see this one!. The stained glass is overwhelming it its beauty and quantity. It is a chapel so it isn't as big as others but it is truly a vision.
GO - Must see. The stained glass on a sunny day is spectacular. Even a cloudy day it is stunning.
Good stop to see.. The stained glass and gargoyles are worth the stop.
Go at dawn. Go at dawn. It is all about those windows you know. If you get there first then there is no one there but you and God

Expensive for what you see. The chapel is undergoing renovation, so only about half of the stained glass windows are visible. There is also no English audio tour, and the information on the windows is a little sparse. Overall, disappointing, especially after hearing so many wonderful things about it.
The renovation is underway.. When I visited Sainte-Chapelle, it's left side wall was being renovated. Beside that, it is worth to visit.

A beautiful church and quick stop to admire stained glass and architecture!. This church was a stop on our Paris sight seeing tour. I was impressed with the stained glass, the flow of the pedestrian traffic and that anyone could worship there at all opening church hours. The beautiful stained glass even shone through on a rainy overcast day. I would recommend this a must do on either day 2 or 3 of your Paris trip.
Excellent. The chapel is upstairs, don't think the lower level is it, cause you will miss out.

Under construction. Delay your visit.. The usual reaction to viewing the upstairs chapel is one of awe. Not so right now as the church is under construction and cleaning. One whole side was covered and the light was blocked, making it impossible to feel the full effect of the stained glass. You are Usually able to sit and read the history and study the stories as told through the glass. There weren't any chairs and because one side was blocked, everyone was looking at the same thing, which made it terribly crowded. Wait until 2014 if you can!

Beautiful . . if the line is not too long.. We stood in line 30 minutes in the hot sun. It was worth it. But if it's hot, and the line extenders back toward or on the street, it could be a 1 hour wait. And it would not have been worth one hour.

Gothic perfection, and yet.... Well, to tell the truth, you HAVE to rate this place "excellent" because it's the pinnacle of High Gothic, the glorious culmination of medieval architecture. And it's breath-takingly beautiful. But oddly, the vibes were just so-so and I discovered I prefer the less perfect kinds of old that don't feel so much like showcases or exhibitions...

If you miss everything else in Paris, don't miss this. Sainte-Chapelle (literally, Holy Chapel) is architecturally spectacular and unique amongst the many European churches and cathedrals open to the public. It is small, tall, and absolutely gorgeous! We've toured many cathedrals, churches, and tiny mountaintop chapels and this is just special.Sainte-Chapel has good if slightly echo-ey acoustics, and features string ensembles performing classical music many if not all evenings. Built by Louis IX in the mid-13th century and originally surrounded by his dynasty's Capetian royal palace, a down side to a visit here is that the palace is gone and the Chapel is now surrounded by, and must be entered through, the Justice Ministry -- so you wait in a line, sometimes in Parisian rain, and pass thru a gendarme-manned security checkpoint to enter.The other downside is access to the one-at-a-time, not-very-private toilet outside the Chapel and in the Justice building -- for which you have to wait in a line in an unsheltered courtyard. Not fun in the rain.BUT Sainte-Chapelle is worth it! Just gorgeous, good music, and very close to Notre-Dame, transit, cafes, and walkable to most central hotels.Located near the metro station "Cité" on the Ile de la Cité in the middle of the River Seine, in the heart of Paris.
heavenly.. Vivaldi concert was angelic and divine. Violinists were from heaven.
Go on a sunny day!. The stained glass windows upstairs are beyond beautiful.

Beautiful stained glass windows. This is a church that's often overlooked by most tourists due to the allure of Saint Chappelle and Notre Dame (incredible in their own rights), but the stained glass windows in this smaller chapel are amazing.

Powerful. While it's rather hidden the little gem is a MUST for a sunny day. The incredible power one feels are you enter is ominous. The story told will keep one occupied for hours. Go during the late morning or early afternoon on a sunny day for your best experience.
Beautiful. Best time to visit is on a sunny afternoon to get the best out of the windows

Not necessarily worth the wait.. The chapel upstairs is a wonderful place to visit because of the beautiful stained glass and the light that pours through it. But the whole place is crowded and the line to get in is long. Luckily, if you have the Paris Museum Pass you can bypass the very long ticket line, but you still have to wait in line to go through security first. It moves quickly so it isn't so bad, but if you're not interested in seeing the stained glass then don't bother, because there's nothing else here. The entire downstairs is really nothing more than a postcard vendor. But if the security line is short (on the street outside) and you have the museum pass, it's a short stop that's good for a few great photos of your loved one bathed in wonderful light.

disappointing after long queues. you have a long queue for the security check and then another for the ticket. You enter the old servants chapel now the shop and ticket office and quite a climb to the royal chapel. amazing windows but that's it very small and crowded. go next door to the Conciergerie well worth a visit

Visit to Sainte-Chapelle in Paris. During a trip to Paris my wife and I toured Sainte-Chapelle. It is a very impressive chapel, especailly so if you like stained glass. Sainte-Chappelle is neart Notre Dame, and one can take a "Hop On Hop Off" bus tour and get off at Notre Dame then walk the few blocks to Sainte-Chappelle.This is one of the "really nice to see" items in Paris.

Disappointed. We went here in 1980 and were amazed at the beauty. It was like finding a hidden gem. Things have changed now, it must have been "discovered." Long lines (30+ minutes) to get in and relatively expensive (7.5 euros). Then you find out that about 1/2 the stained glass windows are covered up for restoration and about 1/3 of those uncovered are grimy black with pollution. I am sure it will be well worth it when restored but not now.

Beautiful, but not sure why it is ranked 2nd.. We went here because it seemed this was something we should go to (ranked 2nd on Tripadvisor). And indeed, the windows are beautiful, in combination with the light that goes through. However, I don't really see why this is the best attraction of Paris. There is quite a queue, you pay 8 euros and the place is being renovated. But in the end, we didn't regret going there.

Awesome!. This is my favorite place in Paris. Several windows are under restoration at the moment, which means they're blocked off. But it's worth it of course. We attended a concert in the evening... really, what could be better than Vivaldi at Ste. Chapelle? Absolutely wonderful, at a reasonable price.

Beautiful. We didn't get a chance to go into the Saint Chapelle as the queues were huge. We went a few years ago in October when there were hardly any queues. The Chapel is beautiful the colours of the glass are amazing, it was a hidden gem but now it seems to be very popular. The Di Vinci code has a lot to answer for.
Ces't si bon!. Like all of Paris, La Saint-Chapelle, is just one of the oh so many historic and beautiful sights to see in Paris.
Greatest church I have ever visited. We have seen a lot of churches during our trips but the decorations in this one were superb!

A stained-glass wonderland. Don't miss it.. Yes, it's a pain to get in, since you have to go through a security procedure. But once you are in, and have ascended to the upper chapel, you find yourself in a stained glass wonderland that enthralls even the most jaded traveler. Yes, bask in the sensation of being surrounded by light and color, but don't fail to also take in the exquisite detail of the windows and panels.and painted decor. European historic churches and cathedrals tend to be dark.This one, more than any other I've seen, is filled with glorious light that is an inspiration in itself. Don't miss it.
Breath Taking. Upon entering the Chapelle, the light pouring through the stained glass windows, takes your breath away in wonder and transports you to another world.

Glorious windows. The most stunning stained glass windows I have seen. Unfortunately part of one wall was under renovation so the 360 wall of dazzling color could not be appreciated. The negative? The 40 min queue to get in.
Not what I expected. This was on the list of must sees, but not sure why. They are doing restoration work which takes away from the overall enjoyment of what you might have been able to see.
Wow !. Even with one third of the windows undergoing restoration, and a 45 minute wait to get in, this was an awesome sight.

Long wait for security. Be sure to arrive before it opens. Sainte-chapelle has the tightest security in Paris. Unless you are a stained glass aficionado, you might want to skip this. The chapel was stripped during the revolution, and, when compared with churches in Italy, is relatively bare.

Wow. Takes your breath away.. I won't upload photos because they just do not do this Place justice. When you walk into room and see the stained glass windows surrounding you on nearly every inch of the walls it really truly takes your breath away. Not to be missed.

A wonder of the world. The Notre Dame is a very grand gothic cathedral but the Sainte Chapelle is the true wonder of the era. It's stained glass windows are a miracle of light and colour. Climbing the stairs to the upper level is like ascending into heaven, which is just what St Louis intended.

Only if you really have time to kill. This attraction features stained glass panels. I went there because the museum pass included it and it's on the way to Notre Domes. The church is very small, and one side was closed for maintanence during my visit. I only stayed there for less than 5 minutes. If I didn't have the Museum pass, I wouldn't spend 8.5 euro and 20 minutes wait time for that.

A Special, Intimate Space. I went to an evening concert inside the chapel. This was a great way to spend time there taking in the whole of the room. The music repertoire was classic crowd-pleasers performed adequate to please most people.
Get there early. This has a wow factor but the line is otrocious. You also have to go through security because it is inside a government complex.

tour guide would have helped. been in a lot of chapels and while it was stunning, it was just hard to absorb the many different details without a guide. based on other posts i went to the conciergerie (the prison) to buy my tickets for st. chapelle and the prison. unlike the paris pass this let me cut to the front of the line. total bonus. think you have to buy both tickets at the conciergerie (not just for st. chapelle) - but the prison really brought to life the revolution, and it didn't cost much either.

St Louis's stained glass master piece.
