Its entrance is not evident: you have to pass through the justice palace, but it really worth.It's very old (medieval period - XV century) and smaller than the traditional Paris' churches. You have all the history of the bible described through its stained glasses. It's really amazing.If it's sunny, try to go by the end of the day, so you can see the effect of the sunset in the glasses. It makes a very nice effect.

Worth the line. Stunning.. Got there before it opened and there was already a 30 minute line. Worth the wait as it is still the most amazing church I've visited. Words can not describe this place -- fittingly you can hear a pin drop in the chapel even when it is full of people.
Beautiful. n obscure chapel that is breath takingly beautiful
Wow. Beautiful preserved cathedral, pay attention to each stained glass windows, each has a story to tell about the bible.

Unparalleled design and beauty. We attended an evening Christmas concert (which was fantastic, but chilly) and we went back during the day to see the sun through the stained glass walls. Unbelievable. Go early and during the week if you can to beat the crowds.
amazing stained glass. The stained glass is amazing. We purchased the museum pass. If we wouldn't have had that, am not sure we would have stopped in and visited.

Brilliant!. The stained glass windows were incredible, I wish I could have gone at a time when there were less people there. Pictures were tough with all of the tourists in the shot, but thats to be expected.

Totally amazing.. Try to choose a sunny day for your visit to Sainte-Chapelle. The main attraction is the second floor with the soaring stained glass windows. Make time to sit on the benches lining the chapel and just stare up.
Breathtaking!. Once again, the scope was overwhelmingly beautiful. Even on a cloudy day, the light coming through the windows brought tears to my eyes!

A special place in Paris. We went there twice, first to visit the Chapelle and then we went for a night concert.Both occassions gave you a very different outlook on the chapelle.Make sure you visit it, even though it is being refurbished, the colour of the wall, the paintings & stained glass is worth the visit.Try and go on a concert night, its very small and books out quickly.

Magical leadlight. A fabulous inclusion to a Paris walking tour, whilst you don't get a good impression of the outside of Sainte-Chapelle inside is a must see. Over 700 stained glass windows which make for some stunning photos.
Man made rainbows!. Beautiful! Not great in size, but the light through the stained glass is awesome.

Highlight of my Paris trip. Not only is this the most stunning cathedral in Paris the concert we attended was amazing. We chose an early evening performance and arrived while it was still daylight. We were able to enjoy the beauty of the stained glass as the concert began and then as the light faded we became enthralled by the music. This is a wonderful way to spend an evening in Paris and is one of my fondest memories of the week I was there with friends. Don’t be concerned with spending the money on the highest priced ticket, any seat in the cathedral is a good seat.

Do-not-miss Paris!. I didn't know of Sainte-Chapelle until my husband read about it in a guidebook, and I'm so glad we went here. It was breathtaking! The stained glass here is unbelievable, and learning about its history is fascinating.Our best tip: Get the Paris Museum Pass. Just going to three or four museums will make the pass worthwhile, and if you're not sure about going to a site like Sainte-Chapelle, this will tip you over and make it worth it. (It's small enough that a guided tour isn't needed and it doesn't need a long visit.)

One of Paris's Absolute Highlights. The Sainte Chapelle--located on the premises of the Ministry of Finance, and accessible only past a row of temporary office containers--is one of the city's highlights if you are interested in late medieval stained glass windows narrating the biblical history. But beware of concerts during any other time but hot summer evenings--it is extremely cold in the upstairs part of the chapel, much too cold for a one-hour concert ...
The Most Beautiful Stained Glass Windows. Just across from Notre Dame Cathedral on Isle de la Cite, the stained glass windows are spectacular. Not to be missed.

very lightful chapelle with exellent masterpiece in window art of lighting. you can attene concerts at night such as vivaldi and otherstry to go during the morning to see the effect of light through the stained glass windows

Stained Glass Beauty. This chapel's windows should not be missed. I find them more beautiful then Notre Dame's which I think are awesome. The chapel is located right near the Palace of Justice, near the Ile de Cite.

Outstanding. A must see in Paris. Lines are long for security but then short for ticket and entrance. Look into concerts held here, they are surely fantastic - and must be a great way to experience this unique place.
Amazing History. It was amazing to step into Sainte-Chapelle. The medieval architecture and sense of history was amazing.
Elegant & Beautiful. This is worth the visit. The church is almost completely walled in stained glass with lots of history. Compared to several other churches in Europe, we rate it a "Don't miss!"
Just Fantastic. Waited in the queue for an hour to get in but well worth it. Amazing inside and a real sense of history and very different from the Notre Dames of this world
BEAUTY. Amazing church nestled on the same Island as Notre Dame. Small, but gorgeous glass panes and art.

Small church with breathtaking stained glass windows. The Sainte-Chapelle is the only surviving building of the Capetian royal palace on the Ile de la Cite, and is now part of the Conciergerie complex. It was commissioned by King (now Saint) Louis IX to house his collection of the Passion Relics, including the Crown of Thorns. Its exterior is not as impressive or grand as the Notre Dame, but its interior is breathtaking in its beauty, especially the second floor. The walls are dominated by stained glass more beautiful than the Notre Dame’s, and the remaining surface is richly decorated, even the floor! The ceiling of the lower chapel looked like the inside of a jewelry box. The Sainte-Chapelle is open from 930AM to 6PM from March to October, and 9 AM to 5 PM from November to February. The usual entrance fee is €8, and the usual combination ticket price for Sainte-Chapelle and the Conciergerie is €1. Note however that if you have the Paris Museum Pass, you can enter for free and do not have to wait in line to get in.

Beautiful to see if in the area. We visited Sainte-Chapelle in July 2011. The stained glass was beautiful, but try to go on a sunny day to get the full effect. We stayed in Paris for 5 weeks and every time we went by it there was always a pretty long line. Make sure when you are waiting in line that you are not waiting to Buy Tickets if you already have them or have a pass.... as you can enter at an earlier door!
A MUST. You MUST visit this when in Paris. The sheer beauty of this will take your breath away!

Unlike other cathedrals. The stained glass is exquisite!. The main attraction is the large sanctuary with the stained glass nearly from wall to wall depicting the story of the Bible in its entirety. Best time to go: when it is sunny. The colors of the glass gleam their brightest when the light shining through. Miss the lines: we went less than an hour before it closed and there was barely a line to get in and plenty of seating to take in the glass.other: we realized a bit too late that there was a classical concert to be held in the sanctuary and wished we would have purchased tickets, so check out events held there!

Magical!. Not many people know of Sainte Chapelle in France; however, it is very worth visiting! It is full of rich history and INCREDIBLE stained glass windows. In fact, the majority of the walls are made of stained glass which makes the entire church just breathtaking. You can make the tour as long or as short as you'd like. We did audio tours when we went; however, the teenagers stopped paying attention after 10 minutes. It does provide interesting history. I would suggest only paying for an audio guide if you are a history fanatic, otherwise information provided at the info desk and in travel books will be sufficient. I would highly recommend visiting Sainte Chapelle!
great!. a masterpiece of architecture and art, not so crowded as other places.
Awesome Stained Glass. This is a must-see when in Paris. I like this better than Notre Dame. You need to get there early since the lines for security get long as the day progresses.
Buy a combo ticket with prison next door.. very gorgeous. read rick steves descriptions while in the church. stained glass is worth the trip!

Fantastic colors. The Sainte-Chapelle is a relatively lesser known place and I fail to see why. Sainte-Chappele was commissioned in around the 10th century and the stained glasses are pretty similar to what you will see in other chapels in Paris. What stands out is the roof and the plethora of colors on it which is perhaps unparalleled in the any of the others in Paris.
Huge wait for a small room. I waited on a queue for almost 2 hours, and the part you can visit is simply a room. It's really pretty, but still a room...

Visiting Notre Dame? Go Here!. Located near the Notre Dame, Sainte-Chapelle is worth the 5-minute walk to see the incredible stained glass windows that are much easier to see than in Notre Dame since they are located closer to the floor and aren't roped off. Great finds in the store on the mainfloor as well.

overrated. Yes it was a nice Cathedral but i find it very gloomy from the inside. The line-up is about 20min then the security measures to get in. The glass windows are very unique but at the time I visited almost half of them are being cleaned and restored. Overall, if there is nothing else to visit, then you should head out to see Sainte-Chapelle apart from that take a walk Ile Saint Louis and have an ice cream at Le Berthillon.
Lovely little church. Well worth a detour. wait for the tour groups to leave, sit on the benchs upstairs. And don't forget top look at the floor!

Takes my breath away. I am wandering around the first floor sanctuary, in wonder at the beauty of the building and completely unaware there is a second story. In case you don't know, like me, the ground floor was for the commoners and the king worshipped on the upper level. So my wife says, lets go upstairs. (Climb a really narrow stone staircase.) Oh my. Oh my. Oh my. Two story-tall stained glass windows up one wall and down the other, each depicting various religious scenes. You have never ever seen stained glass like this anywhere. And at the end of the hall is a vision of end-of-days.I did not understand the translation of the symbols, but the vast expense and excellent workmanship, both examples of France's considerable excesses, are not to be missed. Certainly one of the most outstanding architectural displays on this earth - right up there with the La Sagrada Familia.

Beautiful old Chapel. I wish it were sunny when we went to Sainte Chapelle. The stained glass was very beautiful but the room was dim and cold and without the sun shinning through the windows we didn't get the full effect.
As seen in the movies. Interesting church. Visited the day after Christmas.
As seen in the movies. Interesting church. Visited the day after Christmas.
Must go for a concert.. As the sun sets and the stain glass window light fades the intrior lights come on and there is yet more beauty to look at.

yes the windows are cool, but many other things I'd see in Paris. It's ok to swing by this if you are nearby, It is close to Notre Dame. I personally liked Notre Dame way more and I thought it was much cooler, we spent over an hour walking around the inside of Notre Dame and about 5 minutes inside Sainte-Chappelle. What made it worse was that it closes during lunch and we actually waited about a half hour before we got in. The windows are beautiful, and they actually have some brochures that explain what each window depicts. I am very into history and architecture but I found myself bored here, it's basically just one big room with a lot of stained glass. Maybe if you are very religious you'd appreciate it more than I did. Again if you want to stop by quickly and see it go ahead it is neat for a few minutes (especially if your using the Paris pass and your visit is free), but I'd rather spend my time visiting the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, Invalides, Versailles etc. Overall this was my least favorite place we visited while in Paris, though my dad liked it a lot. To each his own I suppose.

Great Concert. A string concert with some near operatic singing in this setting. Can't really go wrong! The church is quite small, so don't expect a Notre-Dame experience, but very beautiful and intimate. Unfortunately the beauty of the stained glass isn't really shown at night. C'est la vie
2 hours of waiting. La Chapelle is very beautiful and one can just admire the architecture but to get in you have to wait always at least 1h. It's security check witch takes so long time.
only if no line. it was a special place with beauty but glad we didn't have to wait in line as it wasn't that special or that beautiful.
#1!. If you can do just one thing in Paris, make it this. Get there first thing to avoid lines.

Don't miss a concert here. The Sainte Chapelle is breathtakingly beautiful. If you are visiting during the spring or summer when the sun doesn't set until late, be sure to get tickets (you can purchase ahead of time online) for one of the evening concerts. The combination of the sunlight pouring through the stained glass and the gorgeous music (We heard Vivaldi's Four Seasons) simply takes your breath away. An added bonus: you avoid the crowds!
Space for the mind and eye. Loved the visit; it is truly breathtaking, but the lines to get in can be a challenge.
Simply lovely. My favorite surprise in Paris. Gorgeous and intimate.
Atmosphere Pus!!!!!!. I and my family attended a Christmas Concert here and it was wonderful. It is a glorious jewel box and you're sittinig in it! A must see!
Not to miss. This is one of the most beautiful chapelles I have ever seen, its a must see in Paris. We came back for a concert in the evening which was just wonderful.

A Must See. We were going to the Louvre but didn't have enough time to go through the whole thing (as we had a 3:30 ticket for the Eiffel Tower). We decided to do Rick Steves walking tour but backwards (see as we were at the Louvre). The line was not very long to get in, but the stained glass windows were awe inspiring! The time and effort they put in to make these and the church for the Crown of Thorns was amazing! Glad we stopped.

Scaffolding really took away form the experience. I was disappointed by all the scaffolding and the Construction going on around the outside of the building. I understand the preservation efforts and the attention that is required of such old treasures, none the less it was a downer. That all changed when I went inside. It was amazing! I highly recommend a visit, scaffolding or not. Consider it an unexpected surprise if the scaffolding is gone.

See in in the daytime, then go to a concert here.. Be sure to see this in daylight to get the full effect from the breathtaking stained glass. But also be sure to take in a concert here in the evening. I just heard Albinoni's Adagio, Corelli's La Folia, and Handel's Four Seasons here, and it was truly a religious experience.
Delightful Sainte-Chapelle. A friend told us to visit Sainte-Chapelle and we were very impressed with this exquisite building and magnificent stained glass windows.This is a must see in Paris.
Beautiful Concert Venue. Beautiful little chappel not far from Notre Dame. Attended a classical concert here. Very nice.
Paris in spring.... Loved it! It's amazing to think how long it's been standing. Hope you go on a sunny day to take full advantage of those windows!
Hidden jewel. The stained glass windows. A deconsecrated Church which is now a national monument. Amazing glass work.
Saint- Chapelle. What a fantastic church. The interior of the place is unbeleivable
Wow. this is a must see - the stain glass windows are spectacular. And I was only able to visit on a cloudy day - plan to return so I can see this in full sun.

must see in Paris. We waited for quite a long period of time to see this, even in March, however it was well worth the wait. Stepping inside the doors and seeing just basically a room was disappointing until I went up the stairs and was amazed with all of the stained glass! What a beautiful small space that anyone can appreciate and the history behind it is once again superb. Anyone who loves a great church will love this. I recommend going to Notre Dame first, seeing that in all its glory and massive size and then going here. It is such an opposite to the Notre Dame but still such a moving expierence.
a must-see church. albeit the long lines (come at the beginning of each visiting time), it is one of the most interesting churches in Paris. Do no miss!
Marvellous. The intricate carvings/sculptures are nice, with generous stained-glass windows and arched high-ceiling structures. Might need to queue up for tickets though.

Great concert. The stained glass windows are really impressive and you can get close up to them. The church is very interesting and the night concert is a great experience. You can book for the night concert on the internet . In our opinion the B seats are just as good as the A seats. You enter through the Justice Palace entrance security check, so you can not take in certain items. Get there early for the concerts and get a good seat.

Best thing to see in Paris. We loved this church, think it was the highlight of our trip to Paris. We made a point of seeing a lot of gothic cathedrals while in France, and really none compare to this one. Amazing. Don't be discouraged, the line moves pretty fast, it just looks daunting.

the very highlight of Paris. One of the most beautiful places to visit in Paris, a must. Breathtaking! A chapel built for relics that are not kept there any more contains a collection of gothic stained glass windows, most of them original and only few damaged during the II WW.

Fantastic !. This very touristic point is really worthwile to qeue for. A little chapel but unique with its levels and colors. A must... Try to go first thing in the morning when it's open, so it's not so busy !!

Amazing stained glass windows!. Words cannot adequately describe the breath-taking beauty of the stained glass windows in this building. I thought the first floor was wonderful, but...the upper chapel was even more amazing. This is a MUST SEE while visiting Paris. When the sun shines through those windows, it just might take your breath away!

What light through yonder window breaks .... Sainte-Chapelle and the Notre Dame Cathedral and neighbours, but distinctly different. While Notre Dame is grand and imposing, Sainte-Chapelle is intimate and draws you within. The stained glass windows are truly outstanding and occupy much of the available vertical space on the walls. Chairs are provided all around the chamber - for the best way to view them are to sit down comfortably to gaze at the many biblical scenes portrayed. Take one of the plexiglass encased guides (available in several languages) and spend some time trying to spot the ones mentioned there - an engaging bit of fun!
The. the light of the chapel is fantastique because stained glass windows are great .Don't go before to read about the stained glass is manufactured.

Just amazing. Absolutely fabulous church on two floors with spectacular stained glass windows. Try to go there in a sunny day - the reflections inside are just breath-taking.
Take your time absorbing the surrounding beauty - perhaps sitting on one of the benches on the upper floor.

Check out the Upper Level. The lower level is very dark and not so special, but wait until you get to the top of the spiral stair and see the soaring walls of stained glass! Beautiful and being restored. Read up on your history before you go. There's more to this chapel than meets the eye.

Nothing great. This was a a bit of put off, for the sheer price of the entry ticket. Not worth unless you have a 7 day museum pass and have time to kill. Not worthwhile if you are on a short trip, you can skip this.

Just Beautiful. Twenty five years ago when I visited St. Chappelle - Marie Antoinette's personal chapel, very fiew visitors went to see it. Now there are lines, there is a gift shop on the first floor, but when you walk up those circular stairs in the corner of the room andthen see the fabulous main chapel it takes your breath away. It is like a wonderful jewel with huge stained glassd windows on three sides and the ceiling is navy blue with gold fleurs-de-lys. It is truly an exceptional vision.

Breathtaking!. A must do in Paris if you are impressed by churches. Built to be the kings own private Chapel the second floor is just amazing. It consists of the most beautiful stained glass collection in all Europe. It is unbelievable when you consider the time where it was built.There is a waiting line since you have to undergo a security screening (like the aiport) since this building is situated in the interior court of the courthouse.Since this attraction is related also to the Concergerie (2 doors down) you can buy your tickets at the Concergerie for both attractions and cut the line at the Sainte Chapelle. Really smart thing to do!ENJOY!

Incredible stained glass. You have to see Sainte-Chapelle to believe it. The walls of stained glass are dazzling. If you have the Paris museum pass, Sainte-Chapelle is included and you can skip the queue to get in. It's just a few blocks from Notre Dame, and the Conciergerie is right next door. If you have only one day in Paris, this should be on your list of don't-miss sights.
Like a jewel.. Saint Chapelle is definitely like being inside a jewel box. Try to go on a bright, sunny day. The spiral stairway is a bit dauting but worth the climb. The windows are beautiful.
Much needed refurbishment. The splendour of Sainte-Chapelle will reappear when the refurbishment, i.e. cleaning, that has just started is completed.

Breathtaking beauty. Stepping into the lower chamber is beautiful enough but just wait until you enter the upper chamber. Even on a cloudy day the windows cannot help but express their wonder and beauty. Being a church the noise levels inside are kept to a minimum which allows one to just absorb the beauty of what surrounds and leaves one wondering just how something so beautiful could have been made so long ago. Just look up and all around, say wow, and enjoy the moment.
Small but beautiful. The glass windows were amazing! Go in and see and feel for yourself!

Most amazing place I always revisit!. It's worth the security line to see this site. When you climb the stairs into the main level, it's like entering a kaleidoscope. Totally amazing feat that man created this so long ago by hand.

Awe-inspiring, and if timed right, not a long stop.. We went to the chapel on a Monday around 1240. The chapel was to be closed from 1-230, I assume for a routine break. We got in line for 15 minutes and had the line cut off not too far behind us.Once we went thru the metal detectors there was another short line to buy tix outside the chapel. First you go into the lower chapel, which is interesting in its own way. But then, up a very narrow winding stairway, the upper chapel will just take your breath away. We spent 30 minutes inside looking at all the bible stories on the windows, and since the line had been cut off behind us, gradually the crowd inside the chapel began to get smaller. Soon we were just about alone in this beautiful place. We were in and out of there in just about 1 hour. I can see where the visits could take much longer if you were not as lucky with your timing... but look online for the site to buy tix in advance.
Dazzling!. Stained glass galore - truly dazzling. Not to be missed.
stained glass. this attraction takes very little time but is so worth it... some of the most beautiful stained glass... and so much of it!

The most beautiful stained glass we've ever seen. The stained glass windows are the reason for visiting this church, and should not be missed. There is a restoration programme under way at present that is making the glass even more wonderful. The building can get very crowded, so try to go mid-week and early or late to miss the crowds.

one of the top gothic marvels in the world. As you won't be the only one to experience this unique masterwork of stainglass and light my recommendation is to avoid days where tourist are most numerous and if you're in summer, use the great privilege of listening to a (good) baroque concert held at early evening'sday light with the sun irradiating this extraordinary place.In any case try to visit on a sunny day as it really makes a huge difference in enjoying the fabulous stainglasses...
Don't miss this one!. It's worth the extra security clearance. The stained glass windows are not to be missed. Best to go on a sunny day.
BEYOND Notre Dame. Although Notre Dame IS magnificant, Sainte-Chaplle is more so. A two-for on the Isle. NOT to be missed. Inspirational. The stained glass windows and the history here. Nuff said.
Don't miss it. It is awkward to get to with the court house and security but well worth it. It is a must-see chapel.
One of the most beautiful churches in Paris. This chapel was amazing. The burst of colour and beauty of the stained glass windows was awe inspiring. Definitely well worth a visit.

Probably should be seen. Fabulous glass walls, whole building inside (and possibly out) needs a cleaning, only one single large room to be visited but priced the same (€8) as the Pantheon where you could easily spend 2 hours.

A Block from Notre Dame - don't miss it. This tiny church is amazing on just the first floor. But you will be breathless when you go to the second floor. People just just sit and stare. The windows are huge and colorful, but it seems as if all the wood surfaces are painted in detail, too. Very small, but worth the short trip from Paris's grandfather of all churches, Notre Dame.

The most beautiful chapel in the world. to get the best out of the Saint Chapelle do the following:1) Choose a sunny afternoon, the stained glass windows will show much better.2) Choose a day with out too many tourists3) Enter through La conciergerie, the tickets covers both sites, you will bypass the usual two hours line to go into the Sainte Chapelle.4) Once inside, sit down and enjoy the nicest Chapel in the world

A jewel. if you can manage to visit here on a sunny day outside the tourist rush, you will have an experience you won't forget. Like standing inside a jewel. Find an appropriate music piece on your iPod (Ave Maria, for example) and you'll feel about as close to the gates of heaven as many of us will get ! :)
Beautiful stained glass. Clearly, the stained glass here is ethereal. A must see when visiting the Ile de la Cite
Beatiful. Bit of a line to get in, but worth it. The stained glass is more magnificent than I had imagined.
beautiful. stained glass windows are beautiful. worth the time.
a jewel of a chapel!. if you can wait for 30 to 45 minutes to get in, you are awarded by this beautiful small jewel box!
One of the greatest churches I've seen. Amazing!!!Fully recommended visit.Sometimes the line is long but it is worth it.Try to visit it in a sunny day for better appretiation of the vitraux.

OK, a nice custom build church.. It's always nice to be able to build your own chapel larger than most churches. Old and needs more restoration. But when the sun is bright, the light is alright. Got there too late in the day this time and saw the real church.
another beautiful Parisian Chapelle. another beautiful Parisian chapelle:-- not to be missed. lots of beautiful stain glass on windows: also a gorgeous rose window.
Gorgeous.. Beautiful stain windows. An experience not to miss.

Spectacular.. We got there early and got through security quickly and no line for tickets (bought our Paris Museum Pass there). It is small but the stained glass is truly special. It was sunny and would have been even more beautiful when the sun was high in the sky. Very intricate and elaborate glass and carvings. Highly recommend!

Heavenly seen at night with Vivaldi's Four Seasons playing. Beautiful glowing chandeliers incredible stained glass windows, Gothic details filled with light and shadow, excellent accoustics - all the better to hear the 6 man string group with Paul Rouget as solo violinist. Music extraordinaire in a setting to match. If this group is still playing in the months to come, go go go.

Great site. Lovely to see this inside at sun set...brilliant stain glass windows.
Try to catch a concert here if you can.

Extraordinary. The architecture, the windows, the details, the sculpture. There is a wonderful group of reliefs of biblical scenes that I enjoyed up close. In Jack Kerouac's book about Paris he mentions Sainte-Chapelle; that may be part of what impelled me to go, and I am so glad I did.

always loved this little church. It used to feel much more intimate before it was cleaned and properly lit but now the brilliant colors of the windows are magnificent. This is a special place in Paris.

Religious fantasy in blue. Once on the Ile de la Cite, you can't miss this gem of christian faith. The glass-leaded windows ( vitraux) mostly in blue ARE the walls of the chapel-the pillars in stone are just to support them ! Visit it in the afternoon, so the sun shines through the blue glass-it's a fabulous sight both for believers and non-believers, believe me !!! Now that the works of cleaning the glass are in full progress, it's even better. A pair of binoculars is a great help if you want to check out the religious scenes depicted in glass.

hiddened gem. i had no idea that this place was here until we walked by it. we loved it much more then notre dame and would most likely come back here than the other. the stained glass windows are truly breathtaking and was most talked about by us when we returned to the states.
Evening concert in brilliant setting. Keep your eyes out for concert flyers posted on storefronts. Our visit to Sainte-Chapelle was for Vivaldi's Four Seasons, great acoustics & enchanting at night.

The jewel in Paris' crown.. It took 3 previous trips to Paris before we finally visited Sainte-Chapelle, and we were so glad that we did. This beautiful church is probably the most spectacular of all those that we visited in Europe. It is small, but perfect. The stained glass windows have to be seen to be believed. Purchase tickets next door before you line up to enter, and go early as it is very popular. We avoided long queues by reading the signs and buying the tickets at the separate ticket office before going to the church entrance. The Conciergerie (next door to the church) is also well worth a visit and you can buy tickets to see both at the same time. Add these 2 interesting and historical sites to your Paris "must-see" list.
A definite MUST!. So much history, so much beauty! A tour of Sainte-Chapelle should be on every visitor's list.

Magnifique..... Such a lovely place...well worth the €11 entrance fee which also gets you in the Conciergerie next door, the prision where Marie Antoinette was held before she lost her head! At the mo there are live evening classical concerts on at Sainte-Chapelle so worth investigating if planning a visit (we found out too late in our stay to go)

Take your Binoculars. La Sainte Chapelle is a stained glass marvel. To really appreciate the detail that those mediaeval craftsmen created, sit back with your binoculars and enjoy. Best to choose a day and time when the light outside is bright.
Beautiful Small Church on the Ile de la Cite. When in Paris don't miss Sainte-Chapelle, a wonderful small medeival church with amazing stained glass windows and architecture.
Small two level church. Loved the large stained glass in this church which are perfect. The good days are in summer or a nice sunny day.

What a sight!. This is a must to see stain glass at it's best, especially when the sunlight hits the windows. Unbelievable colors and the art work to create each piece. Must take a seat and try to absorb the immenseful history behind all these stain glass!

Beautiful Stained Glass!. Beautiful! Make sure to go when the sun is shining so you can get the full impact of the stained glass. It is a small venue and a quick tour, but it was worth taking the time to see.
Stained Glass. Small church, however, the stained glass is perfect. Makes for some wonderful photos.
Took my breth. You can not stop going to concerts in Saint Chapelle in the evening. The endless shafts and the beautiful stained glass windows to the sound of Vivaldi.

A display of marvelous medieval art!. The beauty of the 13th century Gothic architecture is seen here and it awed me a lot. The intricate design of the stained glass windows and the crisscrossing arches are amazing. It is a pity that no one is allowed to position his tripod to get the best photo. The detailed design, if it can be examined closer, tells about the a religious ceremony. It is so nice that even to this date people of our generation are able to see the marvelous achievements of the past.A rare opportunity. I am glad i visited this.

Wow, a MUST SEE when in Paris!. Go when the sun is out and high in the sky! You will have to pass through a metal detector, so don't take any type of knife with you (I had a small poscketknife which was taken). Wow, what a place to visit!
Long wait. Not worth the wait and the cost for me. Long lines even in November. This would be special in Podunk, but nothing special in Paris.
Wow. A must see to believe . Go on a sunny day or when sun is setting, so you see the stained glass in it's glory.
Stunning. I think this is the prettiest chapel in Paris.Don't miss the concerts, the setting is unbeatable.an often forgotten gem!

Amazing stained glass windows. Getting to Saint-Chappelle is a bit of a hassle since you have to go through security since it's next to the Supreme Court, but it's a must see Paris attraction. We went there 10 years ago and had to go back this time. There are 2 levels and you have to go upstairs to see the amazing stained glass windows. It may not be good to go on a rainy day, but even a cloudy day allowed enough light to appreciate the stained glass. Much better stained glass windows than the Notre Dame.
Stunning Stained Glass. Stained glass windows are reallythe only thing worth visiting this site to see, it is fairly expensive to see not a great deal
history, heritage architecture. good information for self-guided tour. beautiful building associated with history of paris and france.

Stunning. Do not miss this gorgeous chapel while visiting Paris. Choose a sunny morning before the line gets too long. The stained glass is beautiful and the setting dramatic. I have visited many times and love to sit and savor the sight.

Stunning windows. This chapel is definitely worth a visit. I was especially impressed by the upper chappel, which used to be reserved for the king and his family alone. It's great to sit down here and marvel at the high windows, take in the magical atmosphere.
Entrance was 8 euros, there was no queue on a Sunday early afternoon.

Worth seeing. Sainte Chapelle is certainly a beautiful little church. Make sure you go upstairs to the upper chapel though. It is easy to miss and much, much better than the lower chapel. Handy tip - find a toilet elsewhere - their toilets are disgusting.

Not super impressed. This was the only cathedral we had to pay to enter and after walking form Notre Dame to Saint Chapelle it was a little anti climactic. The stained glass was awesome and if the line is not long, it's worth the money but I wouldn't wait an hour to see this particular cathedral.

Overlooked by many but absolutely stunning. Though it might get passed over in favour of Notre Dame for many, make the effort to go here. In the main chapel there are seats around the outside where you can sit and admire the stained glass. We could have stayed for hours, or longer had we had small binoculars. Truly breathtaking!
Amazing. The expanse of stained glass will overwhelm those not expecting it. We stayed for over an hour with small children who were equally amazed.
one of paris' secret treasures. a bit of a wait... but worth it.... serene and peaceful. a bit difficult to find the first time as its within the walls of the Justice Ministry.

Amazing monument. Although Sainte Chapelle is actually very small, it really packs a bunch: glorious stained glass, wonderfully decorated walls and history everywhere. The atmosphere, even when packed with tourist is very special...
At 8€ a ticket (12,5€ if combined with concierge) it might feel a bit expensive but it really worth every euro cent.

Like the Sistine Chapel in glass.. Sainte Chapelle was created to house the holy relics - and as such - when you walk up into the higher chapel through winding stairs you are met with a beautiful radiance of colour that takes your breath away. 16 large stain glass windows shower the space with colour, pillars have beautiful decorative reliefs and any photographs you might have seen really don't do the space justice. Ignore the loud pitches of tour guides and the tour parties as they swarm from one window to another - and marvel in the detail.

Spectacular surprise. It is worth standing in line for this incredible place. It will take your breath away. The lower level is great but take the stairs to the second level and just sit and gaze around - a true place of wonder. There are great information cards in many languages available so if you haven't read in advance - you get it all in a few minutes.
A highlight attraction!. Amazing art work, and mystical objects, not to be missed!
Beautiful Stain glass. Very good atmosphere to Enjoy such a Beautiful Stained Glass. Highly recommended

So beautiful but needs a good dusting. A must see when you go to Paris. The stairs are very steep and narrow but worth the climb. I wish we had gone to one of the concerts held there. It was very dusty inside.

Beautiful Stained Glass Windows!. Loved this place. It is quiet small so you can do it in less than an hour but it is worth the visit. The neighborhood between it and the Pont Neuf is very delightful also.

Magical. I have heard of the concerts at Sainte Chapelle but had never gone.I was worried that it would be too stuffy and too long. The ticket website really doesn't provide a lot of information. Before we went, we had read a little bit about the interior through Rick Steves, which really helped to appreciate it. I chose Vivaldi's Four Seasons concert, as I am familiar with it. Arrived a little early, as it was open seating. Sat mid-way in the back, to take in the ambiance and look at the stained glass. As soon as the music started, my mother started crying - it was so beautiful, the acoustics were so good, it was that emotional for her. The program lasted an hour and we left very inspired.

Stained glass story. What a beautiful place. All the panels tell a story. Be sure to go and find the sheets that are broken down into languages from french, english, spanish etc. It tells the stories of the panels and the church. Just beautiful.
unbelievable stained glass windows. Most people do not even know it is there, across from Notre Dam. Try to go in the afternoon when the setting sum illuminates the west facing windows. Unbelievable!

Glorious Sainte-Chapelle. I've been to Sainte-Chapelle numerous times and never tire of its splendor. Day or night it's gorgeous. I recommend your first visit be on a sunny morning. The try to return for an evening concert. Whatever you do, do not miss visiting Sainte-Chapelle!

If you only see one church in Paris. I've seen more European churches than hot dinners so it takes something pretty special to make much of an impression to be honest. However, Sainte-Chapelle is a stand-out among churches with the most awesome stained-glass windows I've set eyes on. A must see for anyone stopping by in Paris.

Stunning. Quieter and smaller than other churches in Paris but almost more beautiful! Amazing stained glass - just around the corner from the Notre Dame so pop over and see it after that! :) It's a must see.
Impressive. The most impressive stained glass I've seen. Not very crowded, giving you plenty of time to linger

Spectacular Stained Glass. The church of Sainte-Chapelle, just down the street from Notre-Dame, is well-hidden inside the local Palace of Justice. There are good signs on the outside of the building. Lines are usually long due to the fact that everyone must pass through the metal detectors, just like in the airport, although you can keep your shoes on. So don't bring any sharp objects. Also no smoking, eating, drinking, or gum chewing in the church. Cost about 8 Euros.You first enter the lower church which is relatively unexciting and shopworn, but then you climb the tricky and steep circular stone medieval staircase to the second level and it will blow your mind. The 15 stained glass windows contain over 1000 scenes from the Bible starting from the bottom left and continuing all the way around. Every one of the windows has different designs in the stonework and leadwork supporting the glass. There are large handouts telling you what each window displays. When the sun is shining, the view is spectacular. But don't go on a cloudy or rainy day as you will lose the effect.Because the courts are built so close around it, the exterior is not as easy to view or photograph without a very wide angle lens.
Visit to St Chapelle. Lovely location with views all over Paris, visit to Montmartre to see the artists compulsory.

Beautiful. Loved this, jumped the queues with a Parisienne pass, a beautiful building the windows are stunning. A real do not miss in Paris, you can sit quietly in the upper room and just take it all in. Wonderfully peaceful

The most beautiful place in the world. I can't say enough about this gem, except perhaps to try and avoid the queue. I was grumpy after a 90 minute queue in hot weather and european toursists puffing smoke all over me, but when i got inside, all was forgotten......
beautiful chapel. This is one of the most beautiful chapels I've every seen.
Nice. Absolutely fantastic testimony of the French fantastic history
I don't see what all the fuss is about.. It's €8 to see this and whereas they are really nice stained glass windows I think I could have found better things to spend this on.
Breathtaking. Don't miss it...the mosaics will take your breath away!

A secret at Sainte-Chapelle. A fabulous tip from Rick Steves saved us hours in line at Sainte-Chapelle. You can purchase a combined ticket for Sainte-Chapelle and the Concierege in the adjoining Palais of Justice. The Concierege, the restore prison, was a treat. We then walked past a line that extended at least two blocks to the Sainte-Chapelle entrance, receiving immediate access! Saved at least one hour in line and what a fabulous visit. Arguably one of the finest Gothis churches in Europe. Should be one the "must see" list. Many thanks to Rick!

Stunning. To be honest, I really wanted to see the Conciergerie, but I had read that you could get a combined ticket and see Sainte-Chapelle for only a few Euros more. However, when we turned up.... the Conciergerie was closed!!! Not impressed as there was no mention if it on the website - apparently they were setting up for an exhibition.However - decided to see Sainte-Chapelle anyway, and we are really glad we did....it is beautiful! Downstairs is gorgeous, but upstairs is really Wow. Would love to return for one of their candle lit concerts - that must be something extra special!!
A beautiful, amazing chapel.. Most amazing stained glass windows in Paris. Entry floor is like being inside a decoration.
If you visit only one one attraction in Paris. make this the one! From the outside it looks much like any other church, but prepare to be astonished. A work of art from every craft involved.

Magnificent stained glass windows. The majestic stained glass windows when they get lighted up in the sun is simply a magnificent sight. Sit there for a couple of hours and if time permits even more as the windows light up one after the other as the sun moves. The holy Bible depicted on the windows is engrossing.
Had to revisit. the windows naturally.....the groups who seem to be always in other's way

Jewel-like glass. We went to see a beautiful classical music concert at sunset. There was a quartet doing Vivaldi. We were surrounded by the music as the setting sun streamed through the amazing spectrum of colors of the stained glass windows. It was a wonderful experience.
Stunning beauty. The stained glass windows are stunning and really worth the trip through security. Its better on a sunny day so you get the full effect of the colours and scale of the work

Pretty but not worth it if there is a line or other things you want to do.. When we visited, the line was quite long, but moving a bit. Suddenly the line quit moving so I asked a security person why. He just said that the doors were closed and would reopen in 30 minutes. I guess it was lunch time or something. We waited about 45 minutes in total and I would not say that it was worth the time. The windows were pretty, but all the literature talks about the religious relics that were once held there making it seem like a big deal, but there wasn't a plaque or anything about them inside. The windows and the surroundings were extremely dusty. I would recommend it only if you have a lot of time in Paris, but I wouldn't go out of my way...

Breathtaking!. As so many other French attractions, the elderly or disabled are disavantadged. My elderly mother had a very long walk to get to the disabled lifts.But, once inside, you don't know where to look first. It's best to take your time, sit down, if you can, and just slowly take in one area at a time.

Do not miss!. Beautiful!! It does not look like much from the outside, but the interior is gorgeous! There are a set of spiral stairs that you must go up to enter, but it is well worth it! The stained glass windows are gorgeous and nothing can compare! Would highly recommend and it is within walking distance from Notre Dame and the Seine!
The perfect setting for Vivaldi. Keep an eye out for concerts at Sainte-Chapelle. We were lucky enough to enjoy Vivaldi's Four Seasons in this wonderful setting. Don't miss it.

Beautiful - don't miss it.. Sainte-Chapelle is one of the most beautiful chapels in the world. The stained glass windows and dark blue gold starred ceiling incredible. I can't even believe with the density of windows that the building remains standing. You can go through it quickly, in less than an hour, and after making it through the security line it isn't often crowded. Don't miss it!
Gorgeous!. Beautiful, amazing, picturesque.... Be sure to have lots of film in your camera. If the line is long don't worry it goes really fast.
Favourite place in Paris. Have visited previously - never seen anything so beautiful. Added bonus this time was Vivaldi concert at sunset .

One of the must see spots - they say!. Ok it is worth a visit but compared to what? If you see Notre Dame or the Vatican this is a small old building with some nice stained glass. Hundreds want to see it so long lines again. Security at many Museums now so leave your pocket knife at home.

Beautiful stain glass. Do not miss this while in Paris. It is tucked behind a building and may have a line. We visited soon after opening and it was not busy. Read the history before you visit as this adds to the depth of appreciation of this fine building. The stain glass windows are so beautiful.

A great place to hear Vivaldi's Four Seasons. My third time. Don't bother visiting Sainte-Chapelle during the day. Head there at dusk for the early concert. The windows are fantastic and the music is heavenly.
Just the chapel. What is really amazing is... how it is called a chapel. If we should account for its artistic importance... it should be a holy basilica.

Overrated. Lots of stained glass, but too far away to make out any of the real details. Not to mention the cost of entry and confusing entrance - I'd save the time and money and check out any of the other free cathedrals across the city.
A Beautiful Church. You must visit Sainte-Chapelle along with Notre Dame. Sainte-Chapelle has magnificent stained glass windows that are unbelieveable.
Lovely!. A beautiful church - but don't tour during mass, the parishioners won't look to kindly on you.

No place like it!. Fortunately we found out about this gem the evening of our second to last night in Paris. Not having bought our tickets online or being in posession of museum cards meant that we had to spend a lot of time in line to purchase tickets. In fact we almost turned around and left. My francophone wife asked one of the guards how much longer our wait would be and he, almost immediately, let a bunch of us through.We walkwed onto the Palais de Justice grounds and saw the church from the outside. When inside we marvelled at the colourful stained glass windows and painted ceiling and decorated pillars. When we were ready to leave both of us wondered about what happened to the very tall windows we had glimpsed when walking by the church. Luckily we spotted small staircases on either side of the entrance with people going up and down on them. So we went up. I was walking behind my wife and when she reached the top of the stairs she stopped as though stunned. she had her hand over her mouth and just stood there awed by the brigh and colourful scene in the upper part of the church. Because we happened to be there toward the end of a sunny day, the rays of the setting sun amplified the brilliance of the colours of the windows and decorations on the inside of the church. An amazing sight! A single row of charis on both sides of the main space allowed us to sit and contemplete the beauty of the windows and ceiling. Don't miss this spectacular site!

Most beautiful building in Paris. There is nothing quite like this place in the world. It is the best example of gothic architecture. To believe that this building was created centureis ago, and that they could craft windows like that -- or rather, a building that is comprised almost solely of windows. A must see when in Paris
Gorgeous!. One word - breathtaking. Tiny little chapel tucked into the center of government buildings but very worth the visit.

Classical Music at Sainte-Chapelle. I attended a classical music event at Sainte Chapelle. It was amazing, because the location acoustics at the church are so amazing. One of the best deals in Paris (we paid 30 Euros).

Amazing stained glass!. We visited Sainte-Chapelle on Rick Steves' recommendation--and loved it! The stained glass is truly breathtaking. The line to get is rather lengthy but well worth it. The chapel is small but incredible!
A site of peace. Went to a night concert and loved. The acoustics amazing. Expensive but worth it

skip Notre Dame and visit this church. We visited this church twice: during daytime to see the sun shining through the most impressive, colourful windows; and at night to join a concert from Vivaldi 'Vier Jahreszeiten' - four seasons. A great place to watch and listen to clasic music. I recommend to skip hte ground floor and immediately visit the first floor where the king was sitting in former times.

The most beautiful place in Paris!. This site is a can't miss. St. Louis designed this chapel to resemble the entrance to heaven and to hold sacred relics of the cross. It showcases the entire Bible in stained glass. It will absolutely take your breath away!

Bible Comes Alive. The windows are amazing. The stained glass has the biblical stories on them. Bring a binocular in order to enjoy the experience. We enjoyed looking for Adam and Eve, noah's ark, Cain and Abel, Passion of Christ even the Apocalypse is there. Be patient and invest time doing this.

Wait Until You Get Up The Spiral Staircase Before You Judge!. Located on the grounds of the Palais de Justice (Court house). So the first thing you will see is a security line where you have to strip off all your metal and put them on the tray to be examined through an x-ray machine and then walk through a metal detector. When you get past this checkpoint you walk in and over to the line for the tickets (unless you were smart enough to have bought the museum pass, whereupon you can just walk right in!)The downstairs includes a store and you look and you are wondering... what the heck am I doing here, nothing special... and then you notice an unassuming staircase in the corner and you walk up and then you realize what everyone is talking about and why everyone is here.... it's wall to wall stained glass. The first five panels are the most difficult to see and are soon to undergo restoration, but they are magnificent and well worth the wait.

Vivaldi rocks. Attended the Vivaldi 4 Seasons concert and it could have been a standard conventional conert, but here Vivaldi rocks, incredible tempo and incredible technique and incredible joy of performimg. Very happy I attended. Recommended!
A Jewel Box. Magnificent stained glass. Perimeter chairs where you can sit and take really good look at the chapel. Printed guides in a variety of languages.
Breath taking stained glass windows. Loved the wow factor when you walked in, disliked not enough explanation / guides in English

If you love fleur de lis. Waiting to go through security was probably the biggest surprise here. But after all this is on a government site(2 separate screenings). The wall coverings and stained glass were beautiful. Not a far walk from Notre Dame.

Amazing beauty in a hidden chapel. You can't see this from the street but if you read any guidebooks they will highly recommend it. If you like stained glass in a church setting this is the place for you. The upper floor is wall to wall stained glass depicting scenes from the bible - just incredible beauty!

Breathtaking church. Mind numbing line outside.. If not for the line I would give this church the best rating possible. The stain glass windows truly take your breath away. There is a moderate crowd in the church which bothered some in our group (it is not unlike the crowd within the Sistine Chapel in Rome). We were lucky enough to see it on a very sunny day and I suspect it would not be so impressive on an overcast day.BUT the line outside lasted more than two hours on a weekday morning. Since it is in the main court building there is a airport like security check which seems to cause the delay.Despite the fact that it is stunningly beautiful, I would not recommend it to anybody who is does not have a particular longing to see it as it will eat up half a day, 80% of which is spent standing on a sidewalk (with a rather dull view too).

Spectacular!. I have been to Paris a number of times, but the highlight has to be the chamber music concert I went to 2 weeks ago at Sainte-Chapelle. It was 4 violinists and one cello player in the chapel. We booked over the phone and got there early as the seating was first come first serve, except some VIP's in the front row. We were in the third row, smack in the middle. We asked one of the men directing us where to go for an elevator, and we were escorted right away, although a bit of a walk. There are a lot of steps otherwise. I forgot my camera but many took pictures of the rose window and chapel before the concert. The concert itself was absolutely SPECTACULAR. It was fascinating being so close to the performers and watching their faces as they played. The program included Vivaldi's Four Seasons, Canon in D, and a soprano who sang both versions of the Ave Maria. I will never forget it. These concerts are open to the public and are offered several times a week, I think. Unfortunately I forget the exact price, but I think perhaps 30 Euros. Well worth it! The head violinist even did a duet with the cellist that was not even on the program..I have never heard anything like the sounds coming from his violin. The setting is also a dream; a must see, in my opinion.

Heavenly. Sainte-Chapelle is an absolute must-see in Paris, make sure you visit on a sunny day to enjoy the sunlight going through the beautiful stained glass. One of the most beautiful place i've ever seen. Considering the time it was built (13th century) and all the history behind it, I can't see why someone would skip this place when visiting Paris. We were there on two occasions and made sure we visited the Sainte-Chapelle both times. DO NOT MISS the classical concerts at night, totally different ambience but an amazing intimate experience.

AWESOME!!. would not miss this architectural beauty! You can hear the people ahhhing and ooohing as they reach the last step and into the chapel area with the stained glass walls all around the perimeter of the second storey.

Superb opportunity. Iam told Vivaldi´s Four Seasons is a common music concert , but if you have not seen it there is a very good experience. The space is very adequate and the chapelle has some ' vitreaux' which somewhat takes your attention away from the music itself

Unforgettable experience!. I expected it to be exceptional, but was moved to tears when I reached the upper level ot the cathedral! The scale of the windows, the intricate sofistication and magnificence of the leadglass just blew me away! To think that these were created in the 13th century is humbling. There are chairs positioned so that visitors can sit down everywhere and have a good view of the windows which towers above you. Both levels of this building are fabulous and absolutely worth a visit when you are in Paris. Do a bit of homework before you go, in order to appreciate the interesting history and all the art , including the beautiful statues, paintings and sculpture of this relatively small cathedral that comes with a punch you won't easily forget! The lines not long - I visited on a sunny Saturday in Spring and there were about 20 people in the line.
Stunning. Amazing stained glass and design. Will take youra breath away.

Gorgeous Jewel in the Evening Light. Sainte-Chapelle has evening hours during the summer months on Wednesdays. The setting sun gave a beautiful display of colors. Chairs are set up specifically to look at the stained glass.Not only was the view spectacular, but the lines were short. So short, I did not have to wait on line to buy my ticket. The place was so empty, I could wait for people to walk by before taking my pictures without anyone in the photograph.This place is a must-see - it has a spectacular interior, and the design and construction is amazing.

Like being in Heaven. The greatest single building in Paris is Sainte Chapelle. It was a wondrous sight when built in the 1200s, and its stained glass walls are still exceptionally remarkable. No trip to Paris is complete without viewing the architectural and artistic majesty of Sainte Chapelle.

Uniquely Beautiful. Though the line to enter stretched down the block, and the admission is not included in the beneficial Museum Pass, the first time traveler to Paris should not miss the delicately beautiful chapel tucked into Le Conciergerie on the Ile de la Cite. The magnificent stained glass windows beg to be studied - or just allow time for the colors to wash over as you sit in the chancel.
Closed. Joined the queue and then for no reason they shut the entrance to the Sainte Chapelle with no explanation!
Must visit. Even if it is your first time in Paris you should visit the Sainte-Chapelle just like the Notre Dame ou the Tour Eiffel

Nice but lineups are unreasonable. As one can find in any guide, Windows of Sainte-Chapelle are second to none. Unfortunatelly, the number of visitors greately exceeds the capacity. Paris Pass, that allows you to see many attractions throughout Paris is borderline to useless here because it does not allow you to cut the queue and when one is in rush to see many things over the short time span, standing in line for hours is not fun.

Do not miss it! An amazing building of the 13th Century. ...and you thought that glass walls were hallmarks of 20th Century architecture? Sainte-Chapelle has stained-glass walls with a tracery of Gothic masonry. You wonder how it has held up for over 800 years. And its beauty will bring tears to your eyes!The best way to see it is to buy tickets for a chamber music concert in the early evening.
Exquisite stained glass. This chapel is a gem. More stained glass per foot of wall than anywhere else.

A miracle of light and color!. I finally--on my third visit to Sainte-Chapelle--was treated to a sunny day in Paris and was able to see the incredible stained glass windows, for which it is so famed, in the sunlight! They were exquisite! What an experience!

Glorious Setting for Bach. We attended one of the Bach concerts at Sainte-Chapelle. The setting was perfect and the sound was amazing. My only disappointment is that we did not realize that the chapel was closed for one hour before the concert and tours were not allowed after the concert. But, this was one of the highlights of our trip to Paris.

A Gem!. After three visits to Paris I finally made it inside Sainte-Chapelle. It was worth the wait! I am a fan of stained glass and this was the ultimate. I could have sat there for hours reading and admiring the stories told in glittering, brilliant glass.
Underwhelmed. This is left behind by the other main churches in Paris like Notre Dame and the Sacre Coeur. If you are not into stained glass, save yourself 8 euros.
Definitely go!. Only went because other people told me too, most incredible stain glass windows in Paris!

Beautiful stained glass. Paris has many beautiful old churches and this is definitely worth visiting for the stained glass...but be warned, there are lines and it is crowded. Glad I went but wouldn't go back.

Sainte Chapelle- most beautiful chapel in all of Paris. Sainte Chapelle is a must see when in Paris...beautiful and leaves one breathless. Try to visit in late afternoon when the late afternoon sun hits windows to illuminate the whole space.
Beautiful and interesting. Recommended by a seasoned traveler and it was wonderful. BUT, see below, we spent so much time here we did not have enough time for d'Orsay.
Vivaldi at Sainte Chappelle. Saw a fabulous concert (Vivaldi--The 4 Seasons) at Sainte Chappelle. Acoustics were amazing and concert was most enjoyable.

Beautiful.... I had seen pictures, but seeing it live was awe-inspiring. There is a restoration going on so half of the windows were still dusty and a bit grimy (but still wonderful to see) and half was glowing and clean.
A MUST to see. AMAZING Church! Worth the wait. I could sit in there all day!
breathtaking. Go early; the line gets long. The entire story of the Bible is told in stained glass. Incredible.

AMAZING. If you visit Paris,you should go to Sainte Chapelle. You'll have to queue up at the line to enter. But that's worthy of doing so.
When you see its stained glass, you'll gasp with beautiful scene.
I recommend!!

Go to a concert. See it in the daytime so you can appreciate the stained glass. Then go to the ticket booth and buy a ticket for a concert. Come back in the evening for a concert. The can't be any better venue for classical music than this!
Unbelievable resatoration of the Vitrage windows. Come in the morning or the afternoon to enjoy the sunlight through the colorful Vitrages

The ONE thing we really wanted to see -- and we're glad we did!. We arrived at Sainte-Chapelle just before noon on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. The line wasn't too long -- 15-20 minutes tops. As we had hoped, the high-noon sun really lit up the beautiful windows surrounding the chapel.Later in the day, we learned that on Saturday evenings at dusk, the chapel hosts a small concert for a nominal upcharge -- which would have been lovely, even though the windows may not have been so well illuminated.

Much better things to see in Paris. Just returned from a trip to Paris. My wife and I were quite disappointed about Sainte-Chapelle. Waited in line for an hour and paid 9 euros each to get in just to see around 20 statues of saints and some stained glass windows. The whole thing took around 30 minutes - definitely would have preferred to use the time for something else. There were much better stained glass windows in Notre Dame... which, by the way was free. Save yourself some time and see something else. This pales in comparison to Notre Dame.
A hidden beauty. Liked - pamphlets explaining the interior of the chapelDisliked - delay in queue to enter the building and then purchase tickets
Stunning. The queues can be off putting & the security measures but stain glass windows in the upper chapel are more than worth the wait.

The most beautiful stained glass windows.. Visiting Sainte-Chapelle was a highlight of my European trip. The stained glass windows are magnificent and it was wonderful to visit a Holy place with such a long history.

Must-visit.. The Sainte-Chapelle is also known as the 'Holy Chapel' & is in the premises of the royal palace. It housed Louis IX's collection of relics of Christ (included the Crown of Thorns). I really loved its color combination & grandeur.

Remarkable stained glass - enter and be amazed!. One could spend hours admiring the high ceiling stained glass wall which surrounds you when you enter this palace of grace.
Definitely worth visiting when in Paris. Drop by the Palais de Justice next door before hand to make the most of a visit to this side of town.

Awesome! Stained glass addicts stay away! Your doomed if you come!. They eventually ask you to leave here. The best stained glass I have personally seen. Fabulous. We got lucky as we walked right in and immediately sat......middle of the summer, but I bet sunsets or whenever the sun hits them just right would be breathtaking. Amazing works and I would say a must see if your doing the sights......great museum breather.
Do NOT miss this place. Stunning, simply stunning. Notre Dame is impressive for sure, but THIS place is far more beautiful in my opinion.

Incredible Concert Experience!. I had been to Sainte-Chapelle during my first visit to Paris in 2007 and was amazed by the beauty and scerentiy of the church. I can't tell you how excited I was to attend a concert in Sainte-Chapelle during my most recent visit in October. It was truly an amazing concert experience.We try to attend a concert in a church during our European travels and the musicians and venue was far and away the most incredible concert experience we've had to date. The sun was setting lighting the inside of the chapel with a beautiful glow and the music gave you goosebumps. The musicians clearly had played together quite often, the interplay between them was quite amuzing to watch.The concert was a little over an hour long and cost 39 eu. We purchased the tickets ahead of time and was the highlight of our trip. Highly recommended!

Incredible stained glass. It was just beautiful, even on a drizzly day - go on a sunny day if possible. The lower chapel, where you enter is very pretty, but it's awe-inspiring in the main chapel upstairs. The only distraction is that everyone talks, and the chapel loses some of it's solemnity from that. The artistry of the glass is amazing.

You won't see 50ft stained glass anywhere in Paris but here. Although they are restoring the chapel, this is worth a visit. It's interesting to see how the restoration is being done (5yr project) which is posted for visitors to view.

Buy a combined Sainte-Chapelle & Conciergerie ticket. Sainte- Chapelle is so beautiful inside. More impressive to me than Notre Dame.Line ups can be long so walk 100 metres north (just past the big gates) and buy a combined ticket for the Conciergerie (first prison in Paris and where Marie-Antoinette was kept) and Sainte-Chapelle. Cost is E11 compared to E8 for Ste- Chapelle and E7 for Conciergerie. Visit Conciergerie first - it will take less than an hour and then go to St- Chapelle. You do not have to line up. Go straight to the front and go through the security check. Once inside, there is another long line up to actually buy tickets. Again, just walk past this line and walk to the front. You will save so much time.Go on a sunny day for the best view of the windows. Download Rick Steve's guide or similar explanations of the windows.Andrew
Unexpected Treat. I had no idea that this chapel would be so beautiful. When I went up the stairs and saw the stained glass, it literally took my breath away!
Stained glass and vaulted ceilings...like you have never seen.. beautiful stained glass, beautiful...ez in and out, lines, but not crowded.

Take the time to see this. We saw many, many cathedrals and churches throughout France and this is easily the most memorable inside. What it lacks in size and structure it makes up for in beauty. It is virtually impossible to stand in the center of the church and not find your jaw drop just before you say, "Wow, this is amazing." It's easy to miss from the outside and took longer to enter than many other churches, but it's worth the effort to find.
Breathtaking!. People! Climb to the First Floor to be swept off your feet! :D The glass work is mind-blowing.

The most beautiful church, with fantastic live music!. I visited Sainte-Chapelle twice on a recent trip to Paris; first as a tourist, checking it out during the day, and second as a concert attendee in the evening. Both were fantastic! Visit the church on a sunny day to REALLY get the most out of the amazing stained glass windows. I still cannot believe how magical it felt.... Also, if you're into classical music in a very unique setting, by day-of tickets (you can't buy them any more ahead of time than that) to see a concert. We attended a 5-piece string concert that played Pachabel and Four Seasons, and in such a setting, it was incredible. I'm not a church kind of girl, but this one is now in my top 2 of all time (along with the famous one in Reykjavik, Iceland). Worth the wait in line!!

Wonderful intimate music. The concerts at Sainte-Chapelle are a must hear experience. The musicians are always excellent, but it's the chapel that makes the concerts so beautiful. A small narrow church ... the confessional for Fench royalty ... the stained glass windows, each telling a biblical story ... the soaring vault ... the acoustics ... any concert at Sainte-Chapelle brings you to the music ... close and personal.
small church. large crowd. very narrow and winding stairs led upstairs to the chapel. difficult to enjoy due to the crowds

If you can visit only one attraction in Paris, this is it.. As an architect, Sainte Chapelle was on the top of my list to visit in Paris. It represents some of the finest achievements in high Gothic architecture and stained glass fabrication. It is a small chapel built for the royal family to house Christian relics. I was not disappointed. Because it is a small structure, it is much easier to take in and appreciate the detail, workmanship and beauty of the place than many of the larger churches. The line to get in can be long (we waited 50 minutes), but the beauty, warmth and intimacy of the space is well worth the wait. I recommend Sainte Chapelle even ahead of Notre Dame, Sacre Couer, etc.

Oh, to stand in the light of St. Chapelle!. We had visited St. Chapelle a few years ago and unfortunately it was a gray day and many of the windows were covered over for restoration.This trip, we were passing by on a very sunny day. The line was rather short, so we stopped in again. What a different experience. All the windows were a glow with sunshine and the pattern of light on the tile floor was mezmerizing.

AMAZING. This church is just one block around the corner from Notre Dame. Not everyone makes it here but if you can fit it into your schedule, GO, GO , GO! The most amazing stained glass windows I have ever seen. Worth the wait and time......your Paris Museum Pass works here.

Stunning but noisy. This is the most fabulously stunning stained glass I have ever seen but unfortunately everyone wants to exclaim about it to their friends! There is little respect for people who want to sit and reflect but if you can shut out the incessant babble it is just the best.

Wow, overwhelming and moving. We went to Sainte Chapelle in the late afternoon and found the line to be very long to purchase entry. Having a pass we went past the long line and right in. Take time to look up before entering, the gargoyles and statues are amazing. On the first floor we spent over an hour just looking around. There are information sheets in all languages that explain the story of each window. There are also apps for the Iphone. Upon going upstairs our jaws dropped. Every window leaves you asking more questions and wanting more. I don't know if a day spent studying each window would still give enough time to see each detail. A heart moving Church not to be missed.

Just go. Once inside, hold your chin. It might drop.... The colors are fantastic. And bring a wide angle or a fish-eye lens. The entrance money is well worth. Ok, kids might find it boring, but if you are reading this, you will like. I´m shure.

Most magnificent stained glass. We were told by several people not to miss this and they were right. It is not the most amazing chapel, and it certainly isn't the biggest, but the beauty in the stained glass makes up for it. We all walked in and literally said 'Wow'. Don't miss it.
Beautiful Windows. Small church with loads of beautiful stained glass windows,

Most adorned church in Paris. True, it does not have the grandiose size of Saint Sulpice or the magnificence of Notre dame, but when it comes to stained glass and Middle-age adorned churches, this is the place to go. Keep in mind that the place is quite small so plan accordingly in terms of lens choices for pictures, as well as with regards to big groups.
My Favorite Paris Church!. I think this old, old church is so awesome! Downstairs is beautiful, but upstairs is such an awesome surprise! Hard to explain or imagine! Don't miss it!

I was awed by the lower chapel and then dazzled by the upper chapel!. I consider the Sainte Chapelle one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. I bought a Paris Museum Pass (great deal) and normally that allows you to cut ticket lines but since it was National Heritage Day every national building/museum was open to public there were no lines to cut. I am so glad I waited anyways though. The building is actually of two chapels and the lower one for non-nobility was still beautiful and I only wish I could have returned on another day with less people around. The upstairs is also wonderful because the entire walls are stained glass and its more interesting if you know the stories being depicted in each vertical panel. Definitely go. I didn't see an evening concert there but I would love to do that in future, but fyi, the concert line starts lining up early.
Dont lose it. I just love it ... I didnt pay nothing cause i am E.U. citizen under 26 years old.

Go early Sunday morning. We walked by several times with long lines waiting to get through security. We ended up going on Sunday morning around 10-10:30 and did not wait at all. It is also free on Sundays. It was crowded inside at times but if you wait for tour groups to get through you can get good views of the windows

A marvel of stained glass and restoration. I was asked to visit Sainte Chapelle by friends to take photographs of the stained glass windows which are being restored. These windows are truly magnificent and the colours so vivid as to be startling - that is downstairs at the entrance - previously servants' level. Up a narrow spiral stairway the full magnificence of the windows was overwhelming and no photography could ever do justice to them. Just a word of warning about the souvenir shop - I was there late in the day and it closed before I got there despite the chapel not yet being closed. I had hoped to get professional photographs but was out of luck.

Stained glass wonder of the world. What a gorgeous little chapel. It probably has the most beautiful stained glass windows I have ever seen. You have the see it to believe it.Every single one of the windows are gorgeous in their right, and at the right time of the day, looks like thousands of little glowing gem stones as the sun shines through them.There is a surprisingly long line to get in but this is driven by the security checks since the Sainte Chapelle is located in the Palais de Justice - law courts. The line could be as long as 45minutes long especially since school groups always managed to get preferential treatment in queues. In spite of the line, seeing the windows itself is a wonderful reward and no matter how many pictures you may have seen in books etc, it will surprise you even more in person (unlike a little painting housed in the Louvre).Highly recommended.

Magnifiscent old church with stained glasses. Saint Chapelle is one of a kind I'd say.. a wonderful Gothic church with exquisite stained glasses, through which the passing light creates heaven-like iridescences, uncovering the well-known Biblical stories.. The best moment for visiting is late afternoon, when the sun is going down.. Then the stained glass above the main door is breathtaking.. Also, I noticed that, no matter how many people are inside at one given time, if you take a sit for a while, you have the feeling that you are there alone, but not feeling lonely.. You feel surrounded by a profound immemorial love..As for practical aspects, the best time to go is early in the morning or during lunch time.. The lines are always huge, but those moments seem to be less crowded.. Be aware that groups have priority :D (as everywhere else in paris or versailles), and that having a paris pass won't help you skip the lines (again, as everywhere else in paris or versailles, except for Arc de Triomphe - if you ask - in French :) - why they don't comply with that as promised when you've bought the pass, they usually become rude)Also be aware that you are not supposed to carry anything sharp in your bags. The security control is similar to that in airports.

Don't Miss This Jewel!. This is "only" a small chapel, but it is one of my favorites of our trip. The rich colors and gold work were breathtaking! Don't miss it. It's just a short walk from the Notre Dame cathedral.

A beautiful little jewel. This is always one of my highlights of Paris. I think this is my third visit to Sainte Chapelle but I love it so much. There are a couple of things to point out, if you have not been before. There is very tight security to get in here because it is within the grounds of the court of justice. Therefore, you firstly have to go through an airport-like security screening process. Pick your time because the line/queue to get through this process can be horrendous at certain times of the day. The earlier you go, the better chance you have of missing the big crowds. Once inside, if you do not have a museum pass (which is invaluable in Paris), you will then have to queue up for tickets, which I think are around 12 Euros.
