If you do have the museum pass, you can walk straight through (once you have cleared the security area). However, this beautiful little jewel is worth it. The Kings Chapel, in the upper part of the church is not to be missed. You must climb a narrow stair case to get up there, but once you are up inside, you can grab a seat and just sit and wonder at the beauty for ages. Virtually all of the upper level walls are stained glass. It is particularly stunning in late afternoon, when the sun in shining through the stained glass windows. It is only a tiny church but stunning (in the upper chapel). Once you are up here, it is up to you how long you sit or stand and admire it. It is tiny, so you can see if very quickly. The longest part is getting through the security (and ticket) queues.

Love Glass - Love St Chapelle. No wonder this place is sponsored by Velux, it's a fantastic site and wonderful to think it has been here for so long. We went at the beginning of September and there were long queues, but we went straight to the front as we used our "Paris Pass".

Stunning Stained Glass. On the island where Notre Dame sits is the Saint Chapelle. It is in a palace called the Palais de la Cite. The French kings had their palace here before they moved to the Louvre. Now they have law courts in the buildings. King Louie IX was the king who built the royal chapel. He is known as St. Louie because the Church canonized him. He built the chapel around 1238 to house the relics he had bought from the Frank king of Constantinople. These relics are the crown of thorns that Jesus wore and part of the true cross. He bought these relics for a large fortune.The lower chapel were for the people who worked for the king. This has a low ceiling and is not very impressive. The windows have a lot of stained glass. Then you ascend to the second floor by a very narrow and claustrophobic stone staircase. On the second floor is the royal chapel, only for the king. The beauty and amount of stained glass from the middle ages is very impressive. The building is very light and the colors from the stained glass windows are overpowering. The ceiling is very high here. At the end of the room is a rose window, also of stained glass. The glass has more than a thousand panels that you read from left to right and from down to up. They are scenes from the Bible, from the Book of Exodus to the Book of Apocalypse. This is truly a remarkable place to visit.During the French Revolution, the chapels were damaged. It was during the 19th century that they restored the chapels.

A beautiful jewel box. Sainte-Chapelle does not get the play that Notre Dame, which is only about 3 blocks away, does, but it is a beautiful little church with magnificent stained glass windows that cover the entire walls, almost from floor to ceiling. If you are going to go to Notre Dame anyway--since it is almost required on a trip to Paris--then make time to go to Sainte-Chapelle too.

Not to be missed! Stained glass: It's like being surrounded by jewels. There are plenty of reviews of Sainte-Chapelle. Just adding our bit: it's completely worth it! Best on a sunny day -because the windows really shine then. My 18 you son who loves to draw was stunned. Go. See it.Oh - get the Paris Museum Pass: http://en.parismuseumpass.com/This gives you access without waiting in line to purchase tickets.

A let down. After standing in line for 30/45 minutes passing through security & paying the fee, Sainte-Chapelle was such a let down.Having read up on Sainte-Chapelle & read all the reviews I was expecting something truly amazing but alas it was not to be. Once inside we were told that some of the windows were being restored, this really took away from our experience here.FYI - We used the toilets on the way out, it was about 12.30pm & they were filthy.However I would like to return when there is no restoration to give this place a second chance.

gorgeous!!. They weren't kidding when they said that this church was the most beautiful in Paris. From the outside it looks like most other churches but when I got inside, I was simply awestruck by its magnificence. We were lucky that it was super sunny on the day we went and the sunlight shone through all of the wonderful stained glass. The meticulously detailed walls, statues and even floor just added to its brilliance.We bought joint tickets to La Conciergie next door (which was actually rather disappointing) but was totally worth it that we could cut the queue for Ste-chapelle. This church is a definite must see!!

upon entering church I was overwhelmed by the stained glass. Rays of light made it the images come alive.... After a necessary security chek we entered at ground level. The chapel was beautiful but in no way could compare with the brilliance i saw in the main church upstairs.....go on a sunny day so as to enjoy the exquisite stained windows. Preferred Sainte Chapelle to Notre Dame on aesthetics. There is a steep, spiralling staircase to enter the main church above the less impressive but also stunning interior.

beautiful stain glass windows. Sainte Chapelle is a must do when in Paris. We bought a combine ticket to Le Conciergerie and Sainte Chapelle for 14 Euros and the advantage is not having to queue up to buy tickets to enter Sainte Chapelle. In my opinion, it is more beautiful than Notre Dame for sure. However, the highlight was attending one hour Vivaldi's Four Seasons concert at night at the chapel. One could buy tickets at the chapel or at FNAC on Champ Elysees. It cost us 27.50 Euros which was worth it. If you have the time, don't miss it.

Most amazing and beautiful stained-glass. I would never miss to come this place every time I visit Notre-Dame. My last visit was my honeymoon in Paris. There is an incredible peace every time I wander here, the windows are breathtaking

Stain glass was amazing. A smaller church but the beauty was outstanding. As was the case with some other attractions the kids enjoyed it but were ready to move on before the adults were done. Nice thing was they explained the story behind the stained glass windows which were out of this world.Purchase either the Paris pass for 141 euros or the museum pass. Includes a bunch of sites and the paris pass which we bought on the eurotrain and then went to hard rock cafe to pick up included 4 days of attractions and metro passes which paid for itself probably 5-7 times.

Overwhelming experience. Saw this last month and was absolutely overwhelmed. It was not on our list of things we wanted to do, as we were only in Paris for five days and I didn’t want to overdo things, as I am a “senior citizen”, but we had a copy of the fabulous Paris Guide from AA, lent to us, which contains a removable street map too, and this proved invaluable. After reading what this Guide, which only costs £6.95, says, we decided we must definitely see it. I am so glad we did as it proved to be the highlight of our trip. I could have sat looking at the wonderful stained glass for hours – until you are surrounded by it as here you do not realize the full impact of it. For the record, in case it proves helpful to anyone else who does not want to get overtired, I would like to recommend the boat trips on the Seine by night (we went twice, once on Bastille night when we saw the spectacular firework display, and once the following night, as my son was disappointed that because of the fireworks the boat didn’t go as far as the Eiffel Tower, and he was looking forward to seeing it at close quarters when lit up). I could also recommend the Open Top Bus Tours of the city – though don’t leave it too late, as the driver will stop as soon as the finishing time comes, and you will have to make your own way back on the metro! Since I am both a history nut and a Catholic we also visited the great Churches, Notre Dame, St Sulpice and Sacre Coeur Basilica, and Sainte Germaine des Pres, the oldest Church in Paris, though we did have to give the Church of St. Denis a miss, which was a pity, as it is the burial place of the Kings of France. Our favourite was Notre Dame, in which we also attended Mass on the Saturday evening and was very impressed by the precision and magnificence of the Mass and how well trained the young servers were. We unfortunately chose the hottest day of our visit to see Pere La Chaise, and had to climb uphill to see the graves of Chopin and Sarah Bernhardt and Oscar Wilde. I was very sad to see how this latter tomb has been defaced with numerous inscriptions, some in very dubious taste. However, I would not have missed this visit for the world. We also had to give Versailles a miss to my disappointment. We consoled ourselves with the Luxembourg Gardens, as it was very near to our hotel and spent quite a lot of time there. I hope we shall be able to see St. Denis and Versailles on another occasion. I think, after Sainte Chapelle and Notre Dame, possibly what I liked most of all (though I loved every moment I was there) was just sitting with a cup of cappuccino outside one of our favourite bistros and just soaking up the atmosphere. I am now absolutely in love with Paris.
This is a must see. Worth the money as it is breathtaking. If you have time for only one thing make sure this it it!

AH-MAZE-ING. Sainte Chapelle is one of my favorite places in Paris. This was my second time visiting the church and I was equally impressed eight years later. The stained glass on the second floor is truly unbelievable. I knew what to expect, and even explained it to my family, but I still went up to the second floor, up the spiral staircase, first because I wanted to see their reactions. I turned around as everyone was entering the main chapel to "Wow" "Whoa" "Wow" and another "Wow." Nothing I said could even prepare my family for this amazing place. As you're here, take some time to look at the story being told in each stained glass panel. It's truly an amazing work of art. The colors are so vibrant, which has a powerful impact on you, even for someone who isn't religious, like myself. Like many of the places in Paris you're transported back to a different time, amazed at how something so grand could be constructed (and in just six years for Sainte Chapelle) without the technology that we have today. Don't forget to look down at the floor, as that has a lot of detail as well. You only need about an hour to view this amazing place, and I would highly recommend it. Go on a day that's sunny and you won't be disappointed.

loved the stained glass windows. Saint –Chapelle is a beautiful church which has beautiful architecture and beautiful stained glass windows. Through these windows the sunlight filters in ,which adds to the beauty of the church .On each of these windows is a pictorial presentation which combined together narrates different stories .On one of the corners is a stand which has placards on which is written what story is depicted on each window.There are chairs on each side,one must sit on the chairs to admire the architecture,stained glass windows and ceiling .After admiring the architecture and the beauty of the church, you can also go to Conciergerie which is in the same complex.

Beautiful..... Saint Chapelle is not far from Notre Dame...... it is stunningly beautiful, not on the same scale as Notre Dame, but absolutely breathtaking.It seems to be somewhat hidden away so when you actually step inside you are really amazed. We just bought our ticket on entry and the queue wasn't very long.Don't miss it... !

Wow!!. My daughter insisted that we see the Sainte-Chapelle. I had heard that there was such a place, but I was unaware of what I would see when I entered. Well, it was beautiful! The first chapel you enter is not that spectacular....especially after you have just left Notre Dame. However, once you begin climbing the circular stairway you suspect there is much more to see...and there is. The upper chapel is splendid. There is much more stained glass than stonework. The windows tell the stories from the Bible, beginning with Genesis and covering many of the remaining books. There are explanations for the windows available in many languages. There are chairs lining the room to allow those out of breath after the climb to sit and rest, or to just stare in awe at the way sunlight is dispersed by the glass.I am told there is usually a wait to get in, and we did wait for around 30 minutes. The fee is 8 Euros too. However, the wait and the cost are certainly worth see the splender of the upper chapel.

Don’t miss the concerts that are preformed in this charming chapel. We saw, by an incident, an invitation to a baroque concert (the Vivaldi’s four seasons, the Albinoni's Adagio …). We decided to go to the concert and this was one of the greatest moments in our Paris visit. The quite small chapel has very impressive stained glass windows that enter beautiful light into the building - great atmosphere. We also very enjoyed the music that was played there. Please note that you have to be there early because the chapel is within the area of Palais de Justice and you have to pass the security examination that may take time.

The most beautiful stained glass windows ever!. We almost missed this one - please make sure you do not! Sainte Chapelle is in the vicinity of Notre Dame and can be easily visited on the same day. Pay the entrance fee, (included with the Paris Museum Pass) and prepare to be wowed by the most beautiful windows ever! Spend an hour or two just sitting on the seats that are arranged all around the church, gazing up at the stained glass and try to make out some of the biblical scenes in the windows. What a peaceful respite amidst the hustle and bustle of Paris!

Beautiful stained glass church...also offers evening concerts. This church is about a 5 minute walk from Notre Dame and is worth visiting. It is surrounded by stained glass on all sides, leaving you with a stunning impression. They also hold evening concerts. I saved some money by purchasing my tickets directly from their kiosk inside the bistro across the street from the church, after visiting hours were over. (I believe during visiting hours you can buy tickets at the church's gift shop). The baroque concert was entertaining and the historical venue was perfect!

Wonderful night concert at Sainte Chapelle. I purchased our tickets for our concert on the FNAC website. So this meant that we had to collect our ticket at a FNAC outlet.Our concert was at 7pm but we got there a little earlier in anticipation of having to go through the metal detectors and the possibility of queues (that seemed to be a recurring theme around anything touristic in Paris). But we were pleasantly surprised to find that there were no queues at all. We struggled a little to find the entrance and had to ask around before we were told the entrance was via the Palais de Justice.The interior of Sainte Chapelle was beautiful. The stained glass was all aglow with the yellow light of the evening sun. It really looked like a slice of heaven.Our program for the night was Antonio Vivaldi’s Concerto for 2 Trumpets and Orchestra and ‘The Four Seasons’, performed by Les Violons de France and soloist Frederic Moreau. The entire concert was about 90 minutes. The performance was world-class. Even though hubby is a classical music neophyte, he enjoyed the entire performance, made even more glorious by the beautiful surroundings. After the concert, there was an opportunity to meet the virtuoso Frederic Moreau himself. After congratulating him on a fine performance, we purchased one of his CDs and got him to autograph it.We both thought it was a wonderful experience. The concert really added to our experience of Sainte Chapelle.

Must see. Truly spectacular and not to be missed. We were there when it opened so did not have to wait. My shoes got the attention of the security guard, but they were very nice about it. The next time we're in Paris, I want to go later in the day when sunlight is streaming through the windows.

So Beautiful!. If you visit Paris, Sainte-Chapelle is an absolute must see. Truly one of the most beautiful chapels in the world. Forget Notre Dame! This is better! Great for photographers, but... none of the pictures I have seen do this place justice! It needs to be seen in person to be fully appreciated! It's just an unforgettable moment, when you walk up those stairs, and suddenly, your eyes are flooded with so much beauty and color! Are there any other chapels with this much stained glass? The first floor is gorgeous as well, just no stained glass. A gorgeous spot for quiet contemplation. I've been there twice and can't wait to see it again! If you aren't sure you can fit this into your itinerary... you should definitely switch things around and put this at the top of your list!

Spectacular stained glass windows - look for concerts. Sainte-Chapelle is quite possibly the most beautiful chapel I have ever seen. The stained glass windows are breathtaking. If you are visiting this summer, look for concerts held in the evenings. We discovered this while waiting on line to go in, There was an A-frame sign advertising the concert that evening - a concert of various Ave Marias, including Caccini's. Tix were 20euro and could be purchased at the little souvenir shop across the street. If you are a music lover, I highly recommend it. Instead of paying 11 euro to enter just to see the chapel, pay 9euro more and hear beautiful music played in one of the most beautiful chapels in the world. Concerts seemed to be held frequently both there and at Notre Dame. Definitely worth it.

Awe-inspriingly beautiful as it takes your breath away.. I am a professional photographer who enjoys making images of stained glass wherever I do. Here, we went in late September, there were no lines, and it was quiet and peaceful. The four of us just sat in the chairs and didn't even speak for a while. It is one church visit I will not forget. And, of course, I got fabulous photos.

Heavenly Concert. Visit Sainte - Chapelle if for no other reason than to see the glorious stained glass windows.Why not add to the experience and book for an evening concert. You can do this online before leaving home.I must admit I went wondering if I had heard Vivaldi's Four Seasons just once too often, but as soon as you sit down and drink in the superb setting you will appreciate the music all over again as the light streams through the coloured glass and you reflect on the construction and history of this very special place..

Amazing place to check out a Christmas Eve concert. We didn't visit Sainte-Chapelle during the day to sightsee. We went at night to take in a concert of classics that included some Bach, Handel and Pachelbel. Even at night, the church was stunning and the perfect setting to experience the music. The musicians, many of them members of the Paris symphony and opera, were excellent. The concert was beyond sold out, but the staff got everyone seated comfortably and provided blankets to help fend of the winter chill.

Beautiful, but expensive. On our 6th trip to Paris we decided it was definitely time to visit saint Chapelle, as we had heard a lot about it. It is beautiful - the stained glass windows are something very special, but you don't really get a good enough all round experience for the entry fee they charge. Our teenage son was bored within about 2 minutes, so it's not somewhere to take children in our experience!

This should be on everyone's bucket list.. Go early and watch the light travel across the windows bringing them to life. This is one of the most amazing places I saw in Paris. It is small, intimate and majestic at the same time. The guides are passionate about the place and their stories enrich the experience, but you can wander off on your own to appreciate the beauty. I felt like I was inside a jewel. It was the one cathedral on my list for my Paris trip and since it was closed on my first stop, I ended up visiting several others. I have seen most of the best know cathedrals in Paris, but none felt as uniquely special as Saint Chapelle.

An ORIGINAL. Yes the line ups are long, however if you appreciate stained glass and the beautiful reclamation project in progress this is a real piece of PARIS that you can truly admire, read up on the history of this great Catholic Church to truly understand the artwork at hand, this site is not on the tourist list, a wonderful cafe sits across the street after you have toured this church, Cheers, Enjoy!

Beware the security checks!. I turned up early and queued for about 45 minutes to avoid the summer crowds, having just done the same around the corner at Notre Dame. So I had plenty of time to read all the signage on display, about opening hours at carols seasons, entry prices, the restoration of several of the famed stained glass windows. Absolutely nothing about having to pass through a security scanner like a terrorist about to board an aeroplane.Not that scanners are uncommon at major tourist sites - I and my small penknife had passed and granted to The Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay in the preceding couple of days.So I was a bit astonished and nonplussed when the gendarmerie refused me entry to Sainte Chapelle unless I tossed away my pocket knife (a necessary item in France, for slicing fromage and removing corks from wine bottles- the stelvin closure has not made much impact on the French wine industry). He wouldn't 'mind' it for me and I wasn't about to go out and queue up again, as the queue was by this time out around the block. So I missed out.Of course the French have every right to apply what ever conditions they wish to visitors of their national treasures. I just wish they could have included this particular and critical condition on the sign up front, so I could have made appropriate arrangements and not wasted my morning. But I suppose when you count your annual visitors in the millions and they just keep coming, you don't have to bother much with notions of visitor experience and customer service.

If you really like stained glass windows in churches, this is your place to visit.. The actual church building is not that great compared with other historical churches. However, this church stands out for its stained glass works.

Simply Beautiful. One of my faveorite things to do when I travel is to visit old churches, and this is one not to be missed. It was a bit tricky to find since it is kind of hidden in another complex which is too bad since it hides the beautiful exterior. The stained glass is what this chapel is really known for and no wonder why, it's AMAZING! I beleive the Museum pass was accepted here.

St. Chapelle is a must see jewel in Paris' crown..... St Chapelle is small but stunning. The carvings and stained glass are superb. Plenty of time to browse and drink it all in. Easy access from the bus stop, and very close to Notre Dame...not to be missed. There is food available at the many restaurants across from the bus stop.

Unknown gem and amazing stain glass windows. Unkown to us until we bought our tickets to La Conciergerie and were offered tickets to the Saint Chapelle. The extra 4 EUR is well worth the expense, and saves you time.

A Paris must-see. Like previous reviews, I was at first somewhat disappointed in the lower level of the church. Then I found the small winding staircase up and ascended the stairs. When I came into the main room the beauty brought tears to my eyes. The memory of the beautiful stained glass windows will always be with me.This site does not take that long to visit, but should be on every Paris tourist's list.

Experience a Classical Music Concert in Sainte-Chapelle. In Paris again with friends and had booked a concert in Sainte-Chapelle before we left. A truely memorable experience, Vivaldi's Four Seasons in this setting was spectacular. There are regular concerts here and it's well worth the opportunity to sit and admire the scenery while listening to beautiful music.

Breathtaking - Go first thing in the morning. I love looking at old cathedrals, so I was a bit disappointed when I first arrived here and realized how small the church was. The first floor (entry) definitely pales when compared with the other big churches in Paris. However, the second I stepped off the narrow stone staircase leading to the second floor, I literally gasped. The stained glass windows are incredible. There is no way to describe the beauty of Sainte Chappelle, and the pictures don't do it justice. It must be experienced. We arrived first thing in the morning, and I would HIGHLY recommend doing so, because in addition to beating the crowds (which is extra important here because it is so small), you'll get to see the morning light coming through the windows. Read the free guide provided that walks you through the story - it makes the experience all that more incredible.

Hidden Gem. We went to this site not expecting much but were blown away by the beauty and magnificence of the stained glass! The downstairs is like a teaser which leads you to believe the stained glass is not too impressive, but when you walk upstairs you literally gasp at the size and majesty of the colorful windows. If you go to Paris, you must see this church!

Parisian Paradise - la Sainte Chapelle's Wednesday Evening Hours. La Sainte Chapelle is one of the world's most spectacular cathedrals. The upper chamber's stained glass windows, radiating intensely with a pervasiveness of carmine reds and cobalt blues, punctuated with splashes of amethyst and jade, canary and white, draw huge crowds that line up all day long awaiting their chance to pass through metal detectors to enter and enjoy the play of light against the cathedral's spiritual glass walls.For years my wife and I have been visiting Paris and, on each trip there, we make it a point to visit la Sainte Chapelle as frequently as possible ... sometimes to join the daytime crowds, at others to attend one of the many choir or violin concerts that are periodically staged in the evenings there throughout the year.On our most recent trip, however, we discovered, and quite by accident, that there is another way to enjoy the Cathedral's wonders ... and that is on a Wednesday evening during the summer months, from May through September, when la Sainte Chapelle has extended hours and is open with special entry times from 6-9PM. Because Paris is situated in a northern latitude, the light, which is a prerequisite for appreciating the building's stained glass, remains bright well into the evening and bathes the cathedral's upper chamber with a brilliant, yet softly subdued, glow. The bonus that one receives from visiting la Sainte Chapelle during one of these extended-hours Wednesday evening openings is the utter lack of crowds that flood the cathedral during the day. On June 1, when we entered at 7:00PM, there were no more than a handful of visitors and we all had uninterrupted, un-jostled, un-flash punctuated opportunities to slowly examine, study up close, and reflect upon the biblical scenes and interplay of prismatic light that bathed the upper chamber in a tapestry of colors. As a matter of fact, there were more guards than tourists in the cathedral that evening.BOTTOM LINE: If you are in Paris on an in-season Wednesday evening, avoid the long lines and visit la Sainte Chapelle after 6:00PM. You will be rewarded with all of the beauty of the cathedral's stained glass, but without the intrusion of the crowds.

Saint Chappelle is gorgeous! But not worth waiting hours upon hours.. I really enjoyed Saint Chapelle. The line is staggering- but if you have a museum pass you can skip ahead of security (the first long line you must wait in) and again you can skip the ticket line (the other very long line). It closes at odd hours during the day, so make sure to check the times before you go. Also, there is often a long line outside, so make sure you are smart about the time you decide to go. We tried going on 3 different occasions- once the person at the line said our museum pass would not let us skip the line, the other time, it worked. So- I would suggest that you keep checking. Make sure you bring some sort of materials that will explain what the designs on the stain glass signify- it is much more interesting to know what you are looking at. I would also try to go at a time when there is a lot of light- it is staggering how beautiful it is! The chapel is very small, so you could spend a very quick visit, or you could spend a long time really looking at all of the designs. If you have time, I would also go next door to the Conciergerie and see where Marie Antoinette spent her time in prison. They have a mock prison cell and have decorated the area as it would have been in the past. Again, make sure you have a book or a tour or something to really give you context into what you are looking for. There is a restroom and there are a few stairs. I think Rick Steves has a GREAT audio tour that can explain everything in St. Chapelle and the Conciergerie.

Wouldn't Pay For This. The church was pretty but the line was so long and the part of the church you actually get to see is so small I don't think it's worth paying for. However, if you can get in when there is a fairly short line on the first Sunday of the month (when it's free), do go. We went when it was free and the line took well over an hour for a visit that lasted maybe 10 minutes.

Absolutely tremendously beautiful!. We waited probably over an hour to get in, but it was well worth it! I had never even heard of Sainte-Chapelle before preparing for our trip, but I was absolutely blown away once I got there. Notre Dame is impressive, but this was beyond amazing. When you enter, you do really just see a lower part of the chapel and then just the chapel itself, but the majority of the visitors there stayed well over half an hour. If you're interested in reading while you're there, they have a lot of information available regarding the making of the stained-glass windows, the meaning of the scenes shown in each panel, etc. If you can go on a sunny day rather than when it's overcast, you'll have a really exceptional treat inside the chapel as the colors stream down in beams from the windows.

One of my favorite places in Paris!!. Sainte-Chapelle is breathtakingly beautiful! Never seen anything quite like it. The size and exquisite details of the windows are overwhelming, and especially within the size of the chapel. It is small!! You feel like you are in a surreal hidden jewelry box.Go on a sunny day!!Go back for an evening concert!! Amazing!!!

Glorious. As you queue up for a long wait outside the court which doubles as the entrance for Sainte-Chapelle you wonder 'is it worth it?'The answer is, yes, absolutely it is! Notre Dame, York Minster, Lincoln Cathedral all pale compared to the beauty of the stained glass windows in this unassuming chapel - a realy must see in a city of glorious sights.

Jewel Box of Paris-must see!. This small chapel is a gothic architectural jewel box, not far from Notre Dame. It is quiet, cool, and stunningly beautiful. There are many places to sit and take in the view.

Spectacular. Dont be put of by the queue,its just to get throught security, once through it takes no time at all to get your ticket. You enter into the lower chapel which is a bit of a disappointment but once you go up the stairs you will be amazed. The windows are spectacular, it takes time to take it all in. The size and the colour are amazing and with the sun behind them it turns the chappel into a giant jewellery box. Well worth a visit.
Security and other staff. Thanks to both these groups for being very helpful about allowing me to carry a fully bagged up folding bike through security, charming and efficient throughout

You must see this. This is the most magnificent sight in a city of spectacular sights. Photographs can not do this justice. You have to see the amazing stained glass windows. We went to Notre Dame de Paris immediately after and were let down by comparison (but only by comparison - don't miss Notre Dame either).

Pretty, just make sure there is no construction. When we went in Sep of 2009 there was construction covering most of the windows but we didn’t know this until we were already inside. Once we got inside there was a picture showing what is was supposed to look like. When we asked for our money back as there was really nothing to see as all of the best parts were covered, the people said in their normal French rudeness, didn’t you see the sign saying there was construction? The sign they spoke of was not displayed when you bought tickets or even near the line, but on the side of the church on a fence. We felt very mislead and didn’t see the most beautiful part as it was covered. Would have been pretty if not covered.

Not only the windows glow. We (myself, wife and 12 year old daughter) went at the start of the day on a beautiful Saturday. We were guided by a brilliant guide from Context Travel (review in that section). The church has to be on everyone's must see list in Paris. The stained glass rivals Chartres.Do not be put off by the lines and security; the church shares a courtyard with the justice department.

Don't give the guards your property! They steal it.. Yesterday my husband and I went to St. Chapelle to buy tickets for an upcoming concert. You need to go through security before you can go to the ticket booth. The guards took my husband's Swiss Army knife. The last time he had it with him when we visited the city, they gave him a receipt and he returned it to get his knife back. This time, they took his knife he asked if he could come back for it in 5 minutes after we'd purchased concert tickets. They said yes, but I was concerned that they didn't give him a receipt like last time. I was also concerned that one mentioned to the other "Swiss Army." (We speak enough French to get by.) When we came back less than 5 minutes later, they disavowed any knowledge of the knife and showed him that of the ones they'd collected, none was Swiss Army. We realized that the young men had scammed us and there was nothing we could do about it. If you go to St. Chapelle, DO NOT give the guards at the security desk anything you don't mind losing. We've visited Paris many, many times and this is the first time we've ever been robbed...albeit by voluntary compliance with security procedures.

A Parisian gem not to be missed.. Not as well known as Notre-Dame, The Louvre or the Eiffel Tower, our visit to Sainte-Chapelle was one of the highlights of our recent trip to Paris. Located near Notre-Dame on the Ile-de-la-Cite, it's unforgettable. Upon entering the lower chapel, we were impressed by it's beauty. But it is the upper chapel which will make you gasp and take your breath away. The magnificent stained glass windows are 360 degrees around you , and extend almost from floor to ceiling. There are 1,113 scenes illustrating the story of mankind from Genesis to Christ's resurrection, shown in 15 enormous windows. Prepare to wait in line outside for entrance. We waited about 1/2 hour, but it was well worth it. The windows are best seen on a sunny day.

This should definitely be amongst the top 5 attractions in Paris!. The reviews here are absolutely right, as soon as you get to the 2nd floor of the chapel, one glimpse at the windows will *literally* take your breath away! This was one of the most beautiful attractions I have ever seen, and I have been to London, Rome, Amsterdam, Barcelona... Pictures definitely don't do this justice, trust me! If I could go back to one place in Paris right now, it would be the Sainte-Chapelle. Do NOT miss this when visiting Paris!

Beautiful. A very small chapel but covered from head to toe in stained glass. I would love to have a personal tour sometime. We just had information gleaned from the internet. The cost is 8 euros per person. Seeing the chapel where the royals worshiped requires that you walk up a narrow winding staircase, I did not see an elevator. We fortunately had some bright sunlight that day and the stained glass was brilliant, over 6,000 square feet of it.

In my opinion, this is a # 1 must-see in Paris. I was not prepared for the view as I entered this church. It left me speechless, and I watched as each person who entered the room/chapel audibly gasped as they saw the beauty fo the the stained glass and the views. A beautiful chapel with so much strong theology throughout. Excellent in every way. It's hard to believe this was built in 1245.

Magnificent place, best vitraux in Paris.. This Chapelle was part of the palace once. Now part of the government building of justice department. Just have in mind simple things visiting this place.Go there first thing in the morning, before visit other museum or attraction. Every single visitor is passing by access controls and scanned for metallic or forbidden objects. Put all your coins or metal objects in your bag. Be prepared as going to an airport with destination to US. No need to lose objects, or lose time in that.Museum pass card can be used in here.Sainte-Chapelle has an entrance level and the well known upper level. Before you go up from the staircase on the right of the entrance, finish anything you want to see on the ground level. If you see the upper level, you will not want to see anything else from the base level and perhaps miss some interesting vitraux in there.See the signs about which staircase to use. There are 2 that have room only for 1 person at the time, one for going up and the other as exit.You can use your camera, but not the flash.The number of vitaux is big to spend time taking photos, buy an album if you want but don't waste time photograph all you see. Something special yes, not anything.There are some very well written cards about Saint Chappele on the upper floor in 5-6 languages. Pick-up one in your most familiar language and read some interest things about what you see. There are some interesting things about this place. There are 15 chapters that have different thematic synthesis from the holy books to the story of how the objects were taken from the french king during the crusades. It is an interesting story and the reason why this chapel was built at first place. To gather the holy objects taken from Constantinople during the capture from the crusaders of the eastern roman empire's capital.After you finish your upper floor visit and exit Sainte-Chapelle have a look at the wonderful made gargoyle's and demons on the top of the building.WC are next to the exit on the other yard that you came in first place. Remember that you will exit from the other yard than the first you enter.This place is a nightmare for a disabled person to visit, as i can tell. Except the checks that propably will simply not let you in, the place itself is build in a way that no disabled person can access. Do not even try to go there at first place.A must see for crusades thematic travelers and medieval history lovers.As someone wrote, "If you have time to visit one cathedral only, choose this one if you can", i agree on that too.

Breathtaking!. It is a bit of a rigmarole to get into the Chapel. It is on the same site as the Palais de Justice and access to the Sainte-Chapelle, which is a national historic monument, is controlled by the gendarmerie and it is strictly forbidden for visitors to be in possession of any metal objects such as knives, scissors and any other pointed or sharp metal instruments. This can prolong your waiting time - especially if like us you get behind someone who wants to take a spoon in with them (I kid you not). They will confiscate anything they find, and you don't get it back - so be warned if you want to take cutlery with you (!)But, once inside...stunning, breathtaking, stupendous - can’t think of any more superlatives that are adequate. It is a really special place. The lower chapel (originally for servants and lower orders of the Royal Palace) is very beautiful, but the real surprise awaits you upstairs in the upper chapel – the visually striking stained glass windows, that soar up to the gothic, vaulted ceiling. The windows are in the process of being renovated at the moment, and from the parts that have been finished you can see just how stunning the chapel will be once the renovations are finished. Literally took my breath away – I didn’t want to leave. I could have sat there all day just taking it all in.Will definitely go back in a few years once the renovation is complete.

The most beautiful Cathedral in Paris. Sainte-Chapelle is hands down the most beautiful Cathedral in Paris. From the outside it does not look as extravagant as Notre Dame, but the inside is breath-taking. When on the ground floor walk to the end of the church (past the gift shop area), look up and to the left... there is a painting of (I believe) Gabriel Angel and Mary.... this is the oldest wall painting in all of Paris.When you reach the 2nd level (french 1st) and see the windows, it is absolutley amazing. It is one thing to see pictures and postcards of it, but they're nothing like the real thing. There are restorations going on until 2011/12 but it is still worth the visit. Everything about this church is nothing short of astonishing.TIP: When in line... there is a line for the Palace de Justice as well one for Sainte-Chapelle... they both go to the same place so you can just stand in the shorter line. As well, there's a line for people with passes and one for people without passes, no one checks if you have a pass until you try to enter Sainte-Chapelle so you can stand in any line.

If you only have time to visit one Cathedral- choose this one!. Yes, yes. I know all the hype is about Notre Dame, But really- if you have only a short time in Paris, Sainte-Chapelle is the one to go to in my book.I went here several years ago, and still remember it being the most beautiful man-made thing I've ever seen. This cathedral was made just for the Royal Family. Hence, it was the best of everything.It is really awe-inspiring.The stained glass windows are truly amazing, as are all the other decorations. You will never forget the windows.

Beautiful church, wonderful concert. Visited this church during the day. Yes there were lines, no we didn't have the museum pass that would have let us skip ahead. But the wait was worth it,. Its beautiful. It is under restoration, but what you can see is gorgeous. We returned that evening for the violin concert. We purchased tickets in advance on classictic.com. Fantastic concert! Don't miss any of the Paris church concerts,. Many are free and frequent!

Great, but restoration. When the sun shined through the stained glass windows we knew this chapel deserved rave reviews. There was one major problem, one side happened to be in the need of a huge cleaning. Three windows were spotless, but one can not feel the full affect looking at three windows. Also, just to be clear, the staircases to the windows are VERY narrow so do not attempt to walk up if you need a cane to walk normally.

God's Jewelry Box. If you only see one thing in Paris, see Sainte Chapelle. Built for a king (and no one else), the upstairs of this chapel is ALL stained glass -- all four sides. Go on a SUNNY AFTERNOON and you will see colors that are eye-popping, mind-blowing -- and many centuries old. The reds are what God used for rubies, the blues for sapphires and the greens for emeralds. Overwhelmingly beautiful. The downstairs souvenirs make great gifts -- not tacky at all, Their CD's of choral music are great holiday gifts -- and will fit into your suitcase!

Spectacular. The first floor is not the best; at either side of the first floor, there is a circular staircase leading to stunning second floor. As you walk into the second floor, the spectacular stain glass windows take your breath away. Sainte-Chapelle is included in the Paris Museum Pass; you have to stand in the regular line (45 minutes).

Wow. Tiny chapel tucked away behind grand government and state buildings. But really, really worth a visit. I didn't have to queue at all to get in, although that seems to be a recurring problem in reviews. Perhaps going near to shutting time? It's very small, so you don't need more than 30 minutes, depending on how long you want to stay and gaze at all the beautiful glass. You could spend an hour or two, it's so beautiful. I much prefer it to the dingy Notre Dame (which is nearby).

Poorly run entrance but worth the wait. We waited an hour to get into Sainte Chapelle in a chaotic line that moved extremely slowly. The hold up seemed to be the ticket window, which we never got to because after getting within 25 feet of the ticket window they allowed museum pass holders to enter through a separate line for advance reservation holders. Not sure why they can't just have signs that allow museum pass holders to use this line. This would shorten the line considerably.Once we got in, we were amazed by the beauty of the interior. They are redoing the front seven windows until 2013, which is a little disappointing but you can still get your fill of stained glass by looking at the rest of the church. After visiting so many huge churches in Paris, it was a nice change of pace to see this different design. There is so much stained glass in this church, you wonder how they were able to build the walls so high without it falling down. It is kind of amazing to think that for hundreds of years this was the King's private chapel and now you are able to stand in the same place as the Kings of France.

So worth the hassle with the ticket lady to get in. I have always loved going into the Ste Chapelle. It is the most beautiful church in France, and a must-see. We had a pre-set reservation for our group, and were able to bypass the long line b/c of that. But, at the ticket window inside the courtyard, I had quite a problem with the worker. Our pre-printed reservation had one price, and I had a check from a French bank written for that amount. She disagreed with the pre-set tarif, reserved in advance. She made me pay more. Then she refused the check since the agent had written 60 in English and not French. She was rude and unhelpful. It put me in tears. The girl at the booth taking the tickets was most apologetic. I was shocked to be treated this poorly, especially at a church. BUT once we got inside, the magic of Ste Chapelle erased the bad attitude outside!!

Stunning Stained Glass Chapel. This small jewel box of a chapel is not to be missed. Please note that from 2008-2013 the stained glass is undergoing restoration. It was actually a great time to visit, because you can compare one wall of stained glass windows which hasn't been restored since it was installed in 1200, and a wall of stained glass that was painstakingly restored piece by piece. If you are looking for a grandiose cathedral like Notre Dame, you will be disappointed, like some reviewers on this site, and consider it a second class site. However, it you understand that this was the King's private chapel, built next door to his Palace, and he had it built in a mere five years, you will be amazed. The stained glass walls tell the story of the bible, beginning with Adam and Eve and going through the Old and New Testaments. Consider that some of the other churches in Paris are supported by huge columns. This chapel was a real advancement in building technique at the time. The columns are so thin that they almost disappear and the walls appear to be made of stained glass. It was a huge technical feat in 1248 and remains a masterpiece of Gothic architecture. If you can't appreciate this, and the craftsmanship in the stained glass, you will run in and out in five minutes and wonder what all the fuss was about. I would recommend visiting the Conciergerie next door and buying a combined ticket. You will need to go through a security check, because the chapel is located in the middle of the Paris Supreme court buildings. After seeing the chapel, you might want to take the time to walk up the stairs to see the Paris courts and the attorneys standing outside for a smoke in their black robes. We walked right in and peeked in at a tribunal that was in session. As for the cost, I was pleased to support the restoration of this important site.
Sublime. Not better space anywhere. Try to go when its not too busy or go to obe of the chamber concerts. Do not not miss this fantastic room.

Absolutely stunning!. Visiting Paris for just one day in August, we had to pick our sites carefully. Based on my research, we chose Sainte Chapelle over Notre Dame, where the lines and crowds were crazy. We visited in mid-afternoon and the line was very short. Once inside, it was a little crowded - plenty of standing room but no chairs available. It was beautiful and I only wish I had been able to spend more time there. I also would love to see it at a different time of day, when the sun hits the windows directly.

The Church of Windows. I call this the Church of Windows because the ceiling is so high and the walls are pure windows. Another great edition of the Paris Museum Pass. This is a must stop if you are exploring the Palais de justice de Paris.

Concert at Saint Chapelle, priceless. For a cost of 25Euro had a priceless experience of a Sunday evening concert at this most beautiful chapel in central Paris. Great to get away from the (other) tourists and experience something sublime. Just turned up and got in. These concert eperiences are held every night at the different churches and I should have gone to every one. Beats the heck out of the restaurant browsing I did instead which usually resulted in a dissapointing meal. Visit the Conciergerie while waiting and see a simple and beautiful mediaeval hall.

A jewel box of stained glass. We were lucky enough to stumble upon a concert about to start at this wonderful church. We heard Vivaldi, Bach and Pachelbel performed by a stellar group of musicians called the Soloistes Francaise. Anyone with an ounce of poetry in their soul will see the beauty and enchantment in this place. Would visit again for another concert in a heartbeat.

I must be missing something on this.... So we see all the great reviews, and hear from people how spectacular of a place this is that we decided to check it out. After waiting in line for about 25 mins we finally made it through security and to the ticket window. After buying what I considered to be a kinda expensive ticket for my wife and I, we went in. So the first floor is really nothing more that a big gift shop, we then go upstairs where everyone was hanging out. So I admit, the stained glass is impressive, but in my opinion, pretty expensive to look at. After a couple mins my wife asked if I was ready to leave, I told her we needed to stay a little longer just so I can feel I got something for my money. At the end of the day, there was a lot of other places we could've spent our time and money and had more excitement.

My favorite memory of Paris. We visited this church as a reaction to not being able to get into Notre Dame within a reasonable amount of time - Notre Dame was chock a block with one bus after the other. This church is a wonder - the stained glass that everyone talks about is beautiful, like being inside a jewel box. The glass tells bible stories, I have read that it was the 'bible of the poor' in the Middle Ages - one did not have to know how to read to relate to the stories. We noticed that there was a violin concert happening that evening in the church (le 9 violins de France). We went and it was wonderful. We wanted to go all over again on the next performance! The fact that there was plastic, etc. hanging behind them did not matter - the contrast of the tuxedos against the plastic was rather interesting! I will have to dig out my photos and post a few. Do go to this wonderful church. The next time I am in Paris I will certainly go again.

Beautiful - a must see. Amazingly gorgeous chapel, truly like a "jewel box" as it's frequently described. The walls of stained glass is like nothing I'd ever seen before. If you see only once church in Paris, see this one.

Sainte Chapelle- A small gem that you shouldn't miss!. Wait until the sun comes out and find your way to visit this site. Even if you're not interested in the history, the sheer magnificence of the stained glass will be worth the visit. We were fortunate to be there during a performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. This was a feast for the senses.

Breathtaking. We stood in line for this 3 times before finally going in.Once, we stood in the line for the ministry office instead of the church. My fault.Second time we got there and waited 10 minutes and they stopped the line at the people in front of us. BitterThird time we were there in line for a hour. It was worth it though. The stained glass is amazing. Not what I expected at all. AND it was a cloudy day. Please go early and check it out!

First time walking into a room has almost brought me to tears.. We'd been in Paris for 4 days, seeing beautiful building, after beautiful church, after beautiful statue, after beautiful garden. So when I walked upstairs at Sainte-Chapelle, I was prepared to see one more. What I saw was so beautiful, it almost brought me to tears...and I'm not that type of a person. The sun coming through the stained glass was amazing! If you see one thing in Paris, see this church. However...don't bother going if the sun is not out!!! If it is cloudy, I doubt the room will seem all that special.

even amazed our 12 and 14 year old. Must admit some how missed visiting here on my last few visits to paris without our childrenThis time with both in tow decided to visitHad to queue with no idea of building we were about to see as hidden from sightVisited downstairs and then went upstairsWe were all speechless and in awe of the beautiful windows. UnbelievableFeel a bit like paraphrasing Dr Johnson(?) " those not impressed here,not impressed anywhere!"

A hidden Gem in Paris. Sainte Chapelle is an exquisite gem that should be at the top of everyone's list of must-see attractions in Paris. Like the Sistine Chaple in Rome, this is one of the most beautiful sights that Paris has to offer.It is only a few blocks from the Notre Dame Cathedral. Anyone visiting the magnificent beauty of Notre Dame, should also taske time to see the exquisite elegance of Sainte Chapelle. The windows in Notre Dame are certainly impressive when viewed from the dark interior, but Sainte Chapelle is a compltely different experience. The interior of Sainte Chapelle is tiny and intimate. The stained glass windows rise above you on all sides to implausible heights. When the sun shines, the entire interior of Sainte Chapelle is bathed in the multicolored glow of a jeweled prismatic kaliedoscope. It is breathtaking!I am amozed that so many tourists miss seeing this spectacular Paris attraction.

Stained glass masterpiece. There are alot of churches in Europe, but Sainte-Chapelle took my breath away when I walked in-- it is like being inside a multifaceted jewel- not to be missed! It is inside the Palace of Justice, a true government complex, so you go through security and metal detectors to get in, but it is truly worth it.

ok. maybe my expectations were too high after reading the other reviews and the glowing descriptions in guidebooks, but this didn't seem spectacular to me. clearly a nice place with beautiful windows, but not the event of a lifetime. to each his own. (much cooler was the Gregorian chant mass with the Gloria in Latin at Notre Dame, just down the block).

Breathtaking - not to be missed. If you're in Paris, then don't miss this! It's a wonderful chapel which stands out from the rest. From the outside, you can't really see much, as it's within a Police courtyard area, but step through the doors and you're pretty taken by it, the gold on the ceiling arches, and the stained glass windows. Then you walk up the stairs, and it's unbelievable. I was stunned by it. It is incredibly beautiful, and for me, better than Notre Dame. It's very close to Notre Dame, so if you go to see Notre Dame, go and visit Sainte-Chapelle too, its a very different place, architecturally and in it's atmosphere. There are no excuses!

Almost passed out. I have to admit that I was leary of the glowing praise that Sainte-Chapelle received on TA prior to visiting yesterday (I am on vacation in France as I type), but the reviews are an understatement and I am left with a lifelong memory. The line was long when I arrived around 11am, but I later found out it's because everyone is slowly being led through a metal detector that must be run by the good folks at TSA. No way to skip this queue with the Museum Pass (or with the intention to purchase it as I did) and it actually moved pretty quick. If you're hungry, there's a couple places to grab food to go right across the street while in line.Once past the metal detector, you're led into a courtyard where the outside of the church becomes more visible. It's a fascinating structure from the outside and the numerous carvings in the arches are a sight. Just a little longer in the queue for a ticket (8 euros or 12,50 including a visit to the Concierge) and I was inside. It is a beautiful chapel with a statue of St. Louis where the altar would have been and some very nice stained glass that has survived remarkably well. There's a large gift shop right there as well. All in all, I was thinking "this place is nice, but what's the big deal?" Then I happened to see some folks going up a staircase which is pretty easy to miss in the corner of the room and followed them up a narrow spiral staircase (wondering if anyone misses this and actually leaves without seeing the top...I almost did). The worshipping area on the second floor is the most beautiful thing I have ever witnessed. St. Louis must have paid a pretty penny for Christ's crown of thorns (reportedly 3 times the cost to acquire of building the church which was meant to house it), because this place is awe inspiring. Stained class windows everywhere and if you're there on a sunny day as I was lucky enough to be, the whole room lights up in a pretty awesome way. Words cannot possible describe how one will feel when seeing this marvel. Do not miss this amazing site!

Beautiful, even more so this year since the scaffolding wasn't up.. A truly incredible building. The downstairs is very understated but feels like you are inside some kind of Moorish tent. The upper level with the stain class is stunning. Even on a dull day the whole room was awash with colour.Downside: it can take a long time to queue to get in because of the security measures. It doesn't actually take that long to go around the chapel so it might be worth waiting until nearer closing time when I guess the wait would be shorter.

worth the effort. I've enjoyed visited many churches and cathedrals in the UK, France, Spain, Italy, etc., over the last 25 years. This is one of the smallest, most challenging to enter, yet most memorable. Most old churches are gray and somber, with spots of gold leaf and some colorful stained glass. A few have visible remnants of faded interior paint. Entering the upstairs of Sainte-Chapelle is like walking into a kaleidescope the size of a basketball court. Rather than side walls, spaces between the columns are filled with vibrant stained glass windows. The remaining interior surfaces are covered with vibrant colors and patterns or gold leaf. This church helps you understand the exuberant religious message other churches had when their interiors were brightly painted showplaces, rather than the bare, dull stone interiors we see today. As others have said, plan for a wait on the sidewalk to pass through the metal detector/bag x-ray. I had a museum pass and had no wait at other Paris attractions, so this unexpected wait put me in a bad mood. But I forgot about it when I got inside.
beautiful windows, not much else. The windows alone make this a recommended spot, but it's a shame how poorly maintained this church and its grounds are.

Beautiful chapel. First place I visited on arriving in Paris. Very impressed by the beautiful chapel. A good place to start a tour of Paris.The queue for tickets was long but moved quickly. I bought the joint ticket for Sainte Chapelle and the Conciegerie for €10 instead of the €7.50 just for the chapel.You first walk into an outer chapel and gift shop. I thought this was the actual Sainte Chapelle and was feeling very disappointed but the real chapel is clearly sign posted.It was wonderful and bright thanks to the amazing stained glass windows. It's a very romantic place to bring someone but there are lots of other people there.About 100 chairs have been set up around the chapel for visitors to sit and admire the place.

Sad Remnant of a Beautiful Church. While this was a beautiful chapel with all of the stories of the bible depicted in stained glass, I was sad to see that the stories that they were depicting were not being practiced in this building. It seemed as a picture of what is happeneing to the church overall in France. They had hired a man to keep silent reverence but for what?? There was no alter, no worship. Even a rude French woman sitting next to me gave our child who was not loud a "shhht shhht" I was quite offensive. This was the third time on our trip to Paris where the French were rude in my opinion. I had always thought the rude french generalization was just that and it would not be so. I found however esp in this building that it was. Honestly the government would do better handing this one over to the church. If you have a museum pass though it is worth the line if even for what this chapel once was. . .:(

Over-rated. I agree with some of the previous reviewers; it's OK. The stain glasses are beautiful but the church looks run down. And it's not a functioning church now (I asked one of the ushers).The line to enter was about 20 mins' wait to go through the security. They even closed at lunch hour! So if you are pressed for time, you can give this place a miss.We went with high expectations but having come from England, visiting York Minster, it was an anticlimax. York Minster is much more grander with equally beautiful stain glasses; and we didn't have to go through a long line of security!

Concerts at Sainte-Chapelle....the best way to visit. In May, my 18 year old daughter and I spent a week in Paris.A friend recommended going to a concert at Sainte-Chapelle.We booked our tickets ahead of time online through Classictic but we saw others pay at the door. We listened to Les Solistes Francais string ensemble play a full hour of beautiful music, including Vivaldi's Four Seasons and just gazed at the amazing stain glass. We loved it!

pompous doorman. I'm sure it's beautiful, but I'll never know because I was unceremoniosly ejected from the line. The egotistical "doorman" took exception to the fact that I was slow to pay attention to him calling "madam, madam". Of course I didn't know he worked there or that he was speaking to me, but these explanations did not preventing him from insisting that I leave. this was a church of all things! If the French don't want to perpetuate their hard-earned stereotype, they should seriously chose better tourism ambassadors than this guy. He was nearly battering me out the door. This severely impacted my opinion of Paris, much as I tried to get over this one nasty, horrible glorified doorman.

The Sainte-Chapelle restored 2008. This is the best time to visit the Sainte-Chapelle. After a year of scafolding and plastic sheeting, the restoration of the stained-glass windows that represent the Passion of Christ is now completed and all the windows are visible. Take time to read the detailed information available in the upper chapel and understand the complex lecture of the stained-glass windows. To avoid long lines come early in the morning (best light of the day for reading the windows). The entrance to the chapel is also that of the law courts of Paris, hence the long lines! Priority is always given to those who are called to attend court. The concert season of the Sainte-Chapelle runs from 14th March through 11th November, two concerts are programmed every evening at 7pm & 8.30pm. The concerts are not organised by the chapel administration, the chapel is rented to private orchestras. The chapel is not heated, due to conservation restrictions, so be warned that concerts in early spring and late autumn can be a chilly experience.

Not worth the price of admission. We went the last full day we had in Paris, and did not have any idea what we should expect. The line was long (but not terribly) and you do have to go through the metal detectors. My advice is get the ticket for both the Chapel and the Concergierge (Prison). The ticket is around 13 Euros for both. If you do not by them together, you end up spending almost 18 Euros and that is WAY too much. The Chapel is quaint but small and should be free for what you see. We also went on a partly cloudy day and while the glass is probably pretty vibrant on a sunny day, it was less than that when we went. I also suggest you skip it if pressed for time.

Just OK. This is not a must if you do not have a Museum Pass or if the line is too long. Yes there is quite a bit of stained glass, but let's face it, only a small portion will be backlit during any time of the day. The rest does not look like much. There are more than a few awkward moments at this site. The entrance requires you to go through metal detectors and there are many guards. Once you get through the guards, you enter a enclosed courtyard type area and it is not clear where to enter the chapel. Finally, once you get inside the church, you are inside a small gift shop area and it take a while to find the spiral staircase that lead to the main part of the attraction. Once you get there, you realize that it was probably not worth the effort.The inside of the site was under renovation and there was scaffolding blocking some of the glass. The place was very dusty. Don't know if that was due to the renovations, but it did not look nice.If you have plenty of time, go for it, if pressed for time, you can skip this one.

May be worth it for Museum Pass holders. I was pretty disappointed in general since it is quite small and was not as interesting as I thought it would be. It features a main room that is packed with stained glass but other than that, nothing too amazing. I went on a semi-cloudy day and when it was briefly sunny it was quite beautiful, so if you do intend to go, try to take advantage of that.Bottom line is that the Notre Dame (like a 5 minute walk away) is a bigger version and it is free. It also has lots stained glass and history. The line-up for the Sainte-Chapelle was quite long and it is not cheap. I would only suggest you visit if you have the Paris Museum pass since I doubt you will spend more than 30-60 minutes inside. Perhaps this has special significance to the religious, but to me it was a sub-par attraction.

we were turned away. after hearing from one of my cousins who is an architect that Sainte-Chapelle is THE cathedral to see in paris, i immediately planned a trip there during my stay. i was 23 (this was 4yrs ago) and i was chaperoning my younger sister's high school trip. i took 3 of the students with me and we went with very high hopes of seeing all of the stained glass. we waited in line for about 1 1/2hrs and when we got to the ticket booth we were turned away. i know that security is tight at this particular site but we were refused admittance because the students were under 18 and i was not their parent or teacher. when i tried to explain that i was their chaperone and their parents were not in the country i was told to please step aside as there were other people waiting to pay. it was awful, we were devastated.the point of this is to make sure you bring proper identification and make sure that if you are going with children under 18 you are prepared and have the appropriate documents for them and for yourself. it really was terrible, it was the only bad experience we had in our 8 day stay.

Not that large of a place. This is an old historical church, not too large at all so the price is pretty steep to see it. I think during a sunny day the stained glass is beautiful, but it was raining and dark the day we went. We had a museum pass which includes entrance to this and we were in the area. It is right by Notre Dame. I would not call it terrible, but you can see from the outside it is not the big so do not expect that much. Also they build a bunch of government building around it so it does seem a little odd.

Concerts in Ste Chapelle. I was warned to not see Ste Chapelle before seeing Notre Dame because the stained glass windows are so much more beautiful at Ste Chapelle. They weren't lying. Additionally, we went two nights in a row to hear concerts of classical music (Vivaldi one night and Bach the next) in Ste. Chapelle as the sun was setting. It was magical. We found out by reading a poster outside S. C. We also lucked upon a concert of Gregorian chants in Notre Dame by an amazing choir. These were about $25 -$30 each.

Do not miss....go early!!!!. Sainte-Chapelle is the jewel of Paris.....yes, everyone goes to Notre Dame, and it is the Catholic center of Paris, and etc, etc etc......but Sainte-Chapelle truly feels more personal. I am not of the Catholic faith, but the artistry is overwhelming....almost Byzantine compared to its Gothic equivalents.Yes, it is small, and basically one chamber (the altar was under reconstruction when we saw it) and the lines are long for admission.....this may make some think it is not worth the wait, or they are expecting to see more. What you are experiencing is the intimacy, beauty and splendor of a medieval chapel....if this is not your thing, then no need. It is quite a different experience than Notre Dame, so if you appreciate stained glass and magnificence, then do see it.A note of warning: if you purchaes the Museum Pass, you will NOT have any special access to Sainte-Chapelle. We had to learn this the hard way, as there are seemingly two lines for access, but one line is dedicated to the Palais of Justice, which I believe is a government entity. They will be VERY cranky with you if you try to enter Sainte-Chapelle through this way. The reason the lines are so long is because there is an airport-security type checkpoint before you can pass (the entrance is shared with the Palais of Justice). This can deter lots of people and causes for a LOT of confusion. If you choose to go here, try very early in the morning.

Beautiful, Unbelieveable. There is April 2007. Reading other reviews I suspect people felt it was overprice (It's only 7.50 Euro) for your view. I suspect none of them actually spent any time to appreciate the chapel. Most comment on spending 5 or 10 minutes. If you’re only spending 5 minutes it is a waste of money. I am not a religious person at all but still found it unbelievable. If you actually know what you’re looking at, it’s breathtaking. The lower chapel is unassuming, used for the lower class of 13th century (Yes, 13 Century, it is over 750 years old. Yes 750!!) French society. However the upstairs Royal chapel is fantastic. Each panel of stained glass is a book from the bible. and each pane in each panel tells a chapter from the books. EVERY thing in the bible is there in stained glass. You can "read' the bible in stained glass. The colors are phenomenal. Each pillar is a carved with an Apostle. The photos on someone's review don't do it full justice. This chapel is also the original vestibule for Jesus' Crown of Thorns and a piece of the cross. The actual crown of thorns!! So deal with the lines and security (it's on the grounds of the Palais du Justice). TAKE YOUR TIME AND SIT AND STARE AT THE WONDERMENT AROUND YOU. This isn't Disney World or Times Square. So you can see why those who spent 5 minutes didn't get much out of it. I like this chapel better than Notre Dame and neck and neck with St. Sulpice.

Over priced attraction. We visited on 22nd April. We had to line up for tickets and then line up to go into the chapel which was very time consuming. Once we got into the chapel although the window panels were amazing I felt for the price of admission it was over price and not worth visiting. I am sure the price of the tickets are high due to the cost of looking after the chapel but it only took about 10 minutes to look around so is not worth the visit.

see it 'after hours,' with a soundtrack!. To those who complain about the cost of seeing this lovely place while being elbowed by hoards of people, at a high ticket cost, I sympathise. By accident, we found the absolutely perfect way to see and enjoy it, at a reasonable price.First, it is true that the lines during the day (in tourist season) are long just to get though the metal detector. But, once inside go to the ticket booth and see what the concert schedule looks like (sometimes confusing, as there may be an early and late concert the same evening, e.g., 7:00 and 9:00). This still will require waiting in line to get the tickets (but my recollection is that there is a separate window for concert tickets, over to the side near the doorway into the Palais de Justice), but it's worth it. Also, I seem to recall that when you show up for the concert, the entry is actually through the big wrought iron and gilt gates of the Palais de Justice as well.The best time to hear music is in summer when there is late sunlight. One of my very favorite Paris memories is a concert at Sainte Chappelle on the night of the summer solstice, listening to a chamber orchestra play Vivaldi and just gazing around the room. It made me feel that I could sense what it would have been like 700 years ago for those who went there for a quiet time of contemplation, or for those who served there as the clerical staff. When the late evening light is coming through the stained glass, and the music is playing, it's absolutely magical.

Only if it's free. My wife and I visited here on a museum pass, so it was free. As the previous reviewer stated, the lower chapel contains a gift shop. It's a waste because the room was attractive, but it wasn't photo worthy anymore. The upper chapel was beautiful, but very vertical, so it's difficult to photograph. All in all, we were in and out in a half hour.

Dirt. The ticket is rather expensive, but so is everything in Paris. In my honest opinion, I think Paris is over-rated. The saint-chapelle is an example. The lower chapel is of no interest whatsoever. As for the sainted glass, some of them were so dirty you couldn't see anything. The place was overcrowded (as everything in Paris) which kind of spoils your sightseeing mood.

Know what to expect. When you find this entrance from the street there will probably be a line. Not too bad, you think, but this is just the line for the airport-style metal-detector. Once you're through this there may be a MUCH longer line to buy a ticket (at 7.50 Euro, not a bargain). Once you've got your ticket, you go into the lower chapel which is (a) covered in gaudy 19th-century re-painting and (b) half-full of a shop selling books, postcards, and the usual rubbish. You then go upstairs and have an experience like the Sistine Chapel: generally very impressive, but crowded, and if you don't know what you're looking at you may as well be in a Las Vegas re-creation rather than the real thing, so why bother? (If you *do* know what you're looking at--one of the finest collections of 13th-century stained glass, in one of the most important Gothic structures--you may be disappointed at how hard it is to see things properly)The best bits of every city are the free bits (e.g. Notre Dame), so save your money and spend it on food and drink which you will really enjoy. If you tell the folks back home you saw this they'll believe you

CUSTOMER SERVICE UN HOLY. This is the one place out of an eight day trip to paris that I wished I had not went to first of all at the ticket window there was a red headed lady at the ticket window yelling at a lady because she was asking if there was a discount for disabled visitors the lady was very rude and I could not believe I was about to enter a holy church, so against my better judgement paid my 7.50 euros and went in there was one real thing to see the stain glass window I went upstairs and looked around and stayed in there for probably five minutes I asked one of the ladys outside is this all there is to it she said yes I was shocked this is a complete waist of time it was hard to find and not worth it when we finally found it if someone gave this attraction a five star they must be in some way affilated with it . believe me this is a waist of time and your euros go to notre dame cathedral for a real experience and scratch this one off your list......

The most beautiful place in Paris!. This exquisite church lives in the shadow of its more famous cousin, Notre Dame -- what a shame! Over the years, other buildings on the island crowded around the church so that it's rather easy to walk past without noticing -- especially since the Palais de Justice is in the same complex, with a fence around them both.The stained glass (the largest single display of stained glass anywhere in the world) is breathtaking; do try to get there on a sunny day, so as to really see Sainte Chapelle at its glowing, jewel-like best.Also, try to get there for one of the evening concerts -- there is nearly always some kind of an event there at night, and the acoustics are just wonderful. Whenever or however you get there, do not miss Sainte Chapelle!

Not to be missed!. This place was truly like being inside of a Tiffany's lamp, a sparkeling jewel. So hard to describe the magnifigance. Seeing the stained glass with the late afternoon sun is glorious. There are not very many signs indicating it's entrance. The church is tucked into the Palais de Justice area and is not really visable from the street. If Notre Dame is on your checklist of sites to see in Paris, take 5 more minutes for this one...it is just down the street.
Breathtaking Sight. One of the underrated sights.The glass is stuning especially in bright sunlight.A must see.

too good to be missed. So close to Notre Dame, you must take the time to see Ste Chapelle. The line for the metal detector moves quickly enough and then you see the chapel. It looks much smaller than the huge basilicas--more readily appreciated. The detail in the lower level helps set you up for the upper level--take the time to look around here first. Moving up to the upper level, you notice the bright, open feel from all the stained glass. You can also appreciate it more because you are so much closer to the windows than possible in the larger churches. The royal connection of the chapel enhances its historical signigicance.

Concert at Ste Chapelle = Wonderful. Best evening in Paris was attending a Spring evening concert at Ste Chapelle. It was magical - the music was wonderful, the windows with the early evening light coming through the rose window so beautiful.An evening to remember. We had ordered our tickets on line whilst still in the States and received a confirmation voucher via e-mail. Very easy to arrange.

Best Stained Glass in Paris. Too many people visit Notre Dame, then decide they've had enough of churches and skip Sainte Chapelle. Big mistake!! This is the most beautiful stained glass you will see in Paris, and anywhere in France except Chartres. The lower chapel (designed for the peasants) isn't much, but when you climb the short staircase to the king's chapel your jaw will literally drop in amazement. It's ALL windows; 15 gloriously colored stain glass panels shooting 50 feet up.It's tiny, not very crowded and you can see it in under an hour. Notre Dame is great, but if you can only stomach one church visit, it should be Sainte Chapelle.

A beautiful experience!. Sainte Chapelle is a tiny Gothic chapel located quite close to Notre Dame. You enter into the lower chapel (which is beautiful) where the "common people" worshiped, then climb a circular staircase to the main chapel. When you come out of the dark staircase into the chapel you are met with a thrilling burst of colors--the beautiful stained glass windows create a room full of jeweled light. It is an awesome experience to see these windows, each telling a biblical story, that ring the chapel. My husbasnd who originally came to St. Chapelle only because I wanted to, was fascinated by the beauty and craftmanship of the windows. Takes about 20 minutes to see (or you could spend hours gazing at the windows). A great experience (and free if you have the Paris Museum pass--as is Notre Dame, the Louvre and the Orsay).

Most memorable night in Paris. The music was excellent, two performances in one night. If you wait for the second and pay between performances, the second one is half-price. Tickets may be purchased at outlets in places such as FNAC. The audience is divided roughly into the front half and the back half, the latter seats being less expensive. There were only folding chairs, but one hardly notices. The staff is very friendly and helpful. I was embarrassed by an overbearing, obnoxious American man who was shouting at the usher because he, the American, had had difficulty finding his way in. The entrance was through the Conciergerie into the back entrance of La Chapelle. The chamber music was enchanting as we watched the sunlight filter through the stained glass windows. "Le Cygne" on the cello was my favorite while my husband's was "Meditation" from the opera "Thaïs." Afterward we watched one of the violinists put her instrument into a specially made backpack and bike off into the night. Dress ranges from casual chic to elegant.

It's All About the Windows. If you have time in Paris, I highly recommend stopping in to the amazing cathedral of Ste Chapelle. For a few Euros, you will be surrounded by the most extensive and amazing stained glass windows you have ever seen. You can sit and gaze upon them as long as you like and hopefully the sun will be shining to brilliantly illuminate them!

Beautiful setting for a concert. I attended a concert here one evening a few years ago-- it was a countertenor (whose name unfortunately escapes me), and it was spectacular. This church is, in my opinion, the most beautiful church in Paris.
